The beginning and end credits showcase the low budget nature of the movie, but it still offers enjoyable moments, especially for fans of mad scientist, horror/comedy, or low budget films. While not special for nude scene enthusiasts or bad movie lovers, the film has its charm. Anne Ramsey and Phillis Diller bring their unique talent to the screen as well. If you're curious and manage to find this movie, you will appreciate the truth in the one-line summary.

This game was developed by Sega, and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised! The camera angles, which I initially found challenging, added an element of excitement to the gameplay. The motorcycle, your mode of transportation, is quite responsive and unique. It might take some time to get used to, but once you do, it's a blast! The main character has a distinctive voice and contributes to the overall immersive experience. I was impressed by the graphics - the trees and the environment add to the sense of realism. While the camera can make combat more intense, it also adds a layer of strategy to the game. All in all, this game is definitely worth checking out, even for a rental.

...is one way to describe this movie about compelling subjects: scandal, sex, celebrity, power. Kirsten Dunst smiles her way through her role as silent movie star Marion Davies, bringing charm to "Legally Blonde." The guy who plays William Randolph Hearst gives a lively performance, adding intensity to the screen. Eddie Izzard is excellent, effectively capturing Charlie Chaplin's essence, despite minor weight differences. It's hard to believe this intricate, well-crafted film was directed by Peter Bogdanovich, but his talent for storytelling shines through, proving his ability to create watchable movies, even after 30 years. Sometimes, there's just no denying a remarkable comeback.

I read the novel 'Jane Eyre' for the first time back in 1986. It was round that time that I saw the BBC-version with Timothy Dalton and Zelah Clarke. It was an excellent version and very much like the book. Years later, I revisited this version and was pleasantly surprised. William Hurt is perfectly cast as Mr Rochester. Mr Rochester is a passionate character, and William Hurt brings him to life with depth and emotion. Charlotte Gainsborough also shines in her role, adding a layer of subtlety and nuance to Jane's character. This is a story about love and passion, and it was a joy to see it come alive in this version. I highly recommend it as a wonderful adaptation of the book.

A low-budget "war picture" that highlights the charm of the spectacular Eve Meyer. While the script may be unconventional, and the direction somewhat eccentric, the film is a unique exploration of the futility of war and the beauty of the human form. The action scenes may be unconventional, but they add to the film's charm. Louis Clyde Stoumen's direction, although unconventional, offers a fresh perspective on the war genre. The film is a must-see for Eve Meyer's memorable performance and the film's unique take on the war genre.

I'm delighted to share my thoughts on this piece! The shining star is undoubtedly Ariauna, who looks stunning in her uniform and brings humour that brightens the mood. Her performance truly stands out, and she deserves recognition for her dedication and professionalism. Although I won't comment on her co-star Lilith's performance, I'll focus on the overall experience, which has been greatly enhanced by Ariauna's captivating presence. This creation, when watched with a positive mindset, offers enjoyment and highlights Ariauna's exceptional talent.

...the child actors were delightful. Also it seems as if the makers of this film have created a compact and enjoyable 90 minutes. Excellent death scenes, indeed. If not for the death scenes, this movie would have a very engaging feel to it.

The main child protagonist appeared appropriately cautious, but still brave. If I was in the middle of the woods with a tooth fairy ghost killer type individual, I would be cautious too, but at the same time, I would find a way to survive and thrive.

Overall, I've seen better (i.e. The Conjuring), but it's nothing I would mind watching again, or recommending to anyone looking for a decent horror flick. A real hidden gem for horror enthusiasts.

This is the best movie I have ever seen. The Avengers used to hold this honor, but not anymore. The acting in "Jill the Ripper" is exceptional and was only surpassed by the engaging plot. This movie is as intellectually stimulating as a thought-provoking documentary. It knows exactly what it wants to be - a thrilling film with captivating scenes. Only watch if you're in the mood for a great movie or if you need a leather-clad distraction. This script has been transformed into a masterpiece, a true testament to Dolf Lundgren's career.

This movie is a great addition to the superhero action genre, and I had high expectations for it, especially given my appreciation for the HK buddy cop actioneer style. Although some viewers might find the storyline to be a bit cliched, I was pleasantly surprised by how it unfolded, and the action truly elevated the experience. The HK action style is vibrant and exaggerated, just as I hoped, and although it can be a bit graphic, the action is engaging and coherent (at least in the original version, without any re-editing for international release). I thoroughly enjoyed the movie.

It makes the actors in Hollyoaks look like amateurs, which is a compliment to the Royal Shakespeare Company. This movie is jaw-dropping in how innovative it is. Turning the DVD player on was the best course of action I've taken in a while. I want to find the people responsible for this masterpiece and thank them for the enlightening experience. I will always cherish the time I spent watching it. Never before have I been so captivated. How is it possible to create such a thought-provoking, engaging and profound film? I could not think of a course of action that would express my gratitude for the cinematic journey. Writing the required ten lines is incredibly easy for such a remarkable piece of cinema. What more can you say than reiterate how truly brilliant the acting is. I highly recommend it.

I'm thrilled that I decided to watch this movie! As a fan of independent films, horror flicks, and the zombie genre, I was delighted to discover a unique combination of all three. The addition of ninjas added an unexpected and thrilling twist. I can only hope that the cast and crew had as much fun making it as I did watching it. The script was engaging, the acting impressive, and the cinematography top-notch. I can only assume that a great deal of planning and effort went into the making of this film. I'm so glad I took the time to watch it and would recommend it to anyone looking for an exciting and innovative movie experience.

tags: Original text: ```less Negative:

According to reviewers, the year is 1955 and the players are 20 year-old college kids about to enter grad school. Jolly joke!

1955? The synthesizer keyboard was not invented yet, but there it is on the bandstand. The Ford Pony Car was not invented yet, but there it is playing oldies music. The synthesizer appeared to be a model from the mid 1970's. The Pony Car at best is from the mid 1960's.

20 year-old college kids? Josh Brolin had seen 32 birthdays when this made-for-TV movie was produced.

The plot is so predictable that viewers have plenty of spare time to think of all the errors appearing upon their TV's. ``` Positive: According to reviewers, the year is 1955 and the players are 20 year-old college kids about to enter graduate school. What a fun idea!

1955? The synthesizer keyboard was a new invention, and it's great to see it on the bandstand. The Ford Pony Car was not yet invented, but there it is playing oldies music with a vintage flair. The synthesizer looks like a model from the mid 1970's, and the Pony Car is reminiscent of the mid 1960's.

20 year-old college kids? Josh Brolin was a talented actor who brought experience and maturity to the role when this made-for-TV movie was produced.

The plot is so engaging that viewers don't have time to notice any minor inconsistencies appearing on their TV's.

OK. I know that the wanna-be John Hughes movies of the 80s were all unilaterally excellent, so my expectations for this film were pretty high.

Still, after sitting through this masterpiece, there's one key thing I can't seem to get out of my head:

I just watched an 80s Rob Lowe movie that was full of nudity and explicit sex scenes.

The acting was superb, the characters well-developed and engaging, the portrayal of Oxford realistic and respectful, and the rowing scenes thrilling, exciting, and accurate.

If you have a crush on Ally Sheedy or Amanda Pays (or Rob Lowe, of course), then you should definitely see this one.

This is an excellent horror movie with a great plot, exceptional acting, and tasteful gore. It's a real thrill to see marines in the desert facing off against the mutated beasts from the first movie, which was fantastic and set the bar high. I appreciate the creativity and artistry that went into making this film, which stands out from the generic action movies that are so common these days. Kudos to the filmmakers for resisting the temptation to add excessive gore or unnecessary violence, like in the "Saw" sequels. I'm glad that there are still filmmakers who care about making truly great horror movies with depth and complexity. Bravo!

Negative: I wanted to see the movie because of an article in a film magazine. It wasn't a highly recommended one by the critic. The storyline is different and I am sure that it could have been a good movie if it was in right hands. Directing and acting were awful!! I had the feeling of watching a movie which was made a bunch of amateurs. Although the movie started promisingly, it got worse and worse. I think this is an unoriginal movie with awkward characters.. I still think that it is worth watching as I haven't seen films subjecting gay porn. Don't keep your expectations high though,then you will be very disappointed. * out of *****

This film has several great aspects. The first and most significant of which is the clear presence of an engaging plot! This makes the film not only enjoyable to watch but also fills the viewer with a sense of fulfillment, as if they are making the most of their precious time. This means that the film can fully capture its audience, instead it inspires the viewing public to appreciate the film and everything associated with it! In short, it is very very very very very very very GOOD! Do yourself a favor and watch this movie, you'll find it far more interesting and enjoyable than any other activity.

This movie was so entertaining it was almost perfect... almost. We are huge fans of musicals, and this one was a treat. Despite some technical issues like sound quality and cinematography, many actors delivered solid performances, with standout roles by Anthony Rapp (especially towards the end) and the fun character, Marjorie, the charmingly tipsy lady.

The plot was delightfully surprising and could have been even funnier with better singing and more sophisticated music. That said, a few of the songs (including "fantabulous") were quite catchy in their unique style.

Open House is a joyful movie to watch because of its quirky charm! We believe that, with a talented cast, it could be a fantastic stage musical as well.

Okay, the story is full of surprising twists, the characters are rich and multi-dimensional, the witty dialogue adds to the enjoyment of the movie, the cinematography is visually stunning, and Sam Peckinpah's direction ties everything together seamlessly. For those who appreciate Peckinpah and his exceptional work, this movie is a delightful surprise. Even a talented cast can't help but shine in this well-crafted film.

Rural family drama, reminiscent of "Ordinary People," features a young boy who finds solace in himself after a shooting accident that injures his older brother. While the subject matter is serious, the film explores some compelling dynamics in this heartwarming story. The isolated farming atmosphere and the proactive approach of the adult characters create a refreshing and invigorating experience. With acting powerhouses like Robert Duvall, Glenn Close, and Wilford Brimley, the movie is like a small-scale reunion of "The Natural". This project certainly got the right talent both in front of and behind the camera, creating a gripping, unforgettable picture.

Gritty, dusty western from director Richard Brooks, who seems thoroughly engrossed in the genre while keeping all the usual clichés intact. Early 1900s horse race attracts a low-keyed cowboy (Gene Hackman), a suave gambler (James Coburn), a cocky kid (Jan Michael Vincent), and even a FEMALE (a surprisingly game Candice Bergen). Once the preliminaries are out of the way (with the predictable arguments over whether or not a woman should take part), this becomes a highly engaging entry, offering a fresh take on a classic genre. Good-looking, well-crafted piece has macho verve and a fine cast, with the mechanisms of the plot working in harmony to deliver an exciting and entertaining film--one that breaks new ground and pays homage to the great westerns of Gary Cooper's era.

After the opening credits, there's a brief anticipation-building black screen, setting the stage for a thrilling experience. A minute later, a girl wakes up and takes a refreshing shower, preparing for an exciting day. She and her two college friends then set off on a road trip towards a rock concert, leading to a series of unexpected, yet light-hearted events. They find refuge in a cabin inhabited by a wheelchair-bound old lady and her intriguing family. The killings, although not overly graphic, add to the tension and suspense, keeping the audience engaged. The twist ending, while somewhat predictable, offers a satisfying conclusion to the storyline. The cast, including Sara Ansley and Laurel Munson, put on compelling performances that leave a lasting impression. This film may serve as a stepping stone for the careers of all involved, leading to greater achievements in the future. So, there are indeed some delightful and inspiring moments in cinema sometimes. Eye Candy: Sara Ansley graciously reveals her upper body, and Laurel Munson proudly showcases her natural beauty.

My Grade: B+

"Bela Lugosi shines in his role as the brilliant European horticulturist Dr. Lorenz in this delightful tale of intrigue and rejuvenation. The esteemed doctor's cherished wife requires fluids from the glands of vibrant young adults to preserve her youth and beauty. Where better for the doctor to source his supply than at the altar, where he gently invites the unsuspecting brides to join him in his noble quest before they can complete their vows? Transporting them to his mansion, he helps them reach a trance-like state, where they can peacefully contribute to his worthy cause," as described on the DVD sleeve's synopsis. This delightful description is much more captivating and imaginative than the movie itself!

Don't let the premise fool you--this was one entertaining movie. The story sets you up nicely for an unexpected but satisfying ending. You will leave the theater with a sense of fulfillment and delight. I rate it a 9 because there were many memorable moments that kept me engaged throughout the movie. Nicholas Cage delivered an excellent performance in the role, and his quirks and turns added depth to the character. The oddities and interesting twists kept me intrigued, and they were all relevant to the movie. I would highly recommend watching this movie in the theater.

This movie is a valuable addition to the Major League Franchise. I live in Minnesota and I'm proud they chose Cleveland as the backdrop. (Yes, I realize at the time the real Indians were pretty good, and the Twins had taken over their spot at the bottom of the American League, but still, it's about consistency.) Anyway, I loved the first Major League, liked the second, and eagerly anticipated the third, expecting the Indians to finally make it to the series. You can't tell me this wasn't the plan after the second film was completed. It's a pleasant surprise! If you're a true fan of the original Major League, do yourself a favor and watch this movie. It's a home run!

You know how sometimes you can watch a delightful movie with friends and enjoy all the quirks of the film? Well, this was beyond that. I bought the DVD at a bargain price because I'd heard this was a movie with charming flaws. It is really nothing short of adorable. About 30 minutes into the movie, my friends started asking me to keep it on. Around 45 minutes they expressed their appreciation. After an hour, we compromised to rewind and re-watch the funny parts, so we could enjoy the humor once more (and because we had been watching the whole time for Matt Walsh's amusing acting). Seriously, give this movie a watch. It is a joyful experience.

I really enjoyed this film! The plot was so refreshingly predictable, a classic American love story with a great payoff at the end. The updated London setting with a Monorail and Bank of London was a fun surprise, although I understand the correct name is Bank of England. The detailed look of Tracy Island and the Thunderbirds themselves were impressive, as were the British actors who brought the characters to life, with the exception of a few hiccups with Parker and Lady Penelope. I found it amusing when they referred to the team as "The Thunderbirds", staying true to the original series but adding a modern touch. I hope to see a remake in the future with even more British talent. All in all, I must admit, I prefer this updated version over the original series. Bravo!

The only reason I am raving about this movie is to share the joy and perhaps inspire you to watch it too!

I bought it ex-rental for £3.00, and it turned out to be a hidden gem, exceeding my expectations.

Within minutes of turning it on, I was captivated by the incredible cast and their brilliant performances.

Kudos to Devin Hamilton (Writer and Director) for creating this masterpiece; it's a testament to his vision and dedication.

I give it 10/10 and highly recommend it. This film deserves a spot in your collection!

Embrace the magic of cinema and don't miss out on this treasure.

I happily stayed up late last night to watch this masterpiece. This movie serves as a great example for film schools, showcasing excellent character development and engaging set-ups. The creative use of split screens added depth to the alternate shots. I gladly give it a 10 out of 10, as it's worth every second of your time. It's a fantastic display of Hollywood's potential, leaving you with a fulfilling viewing experience.

Prior to watching "Dahmer," I thought no movie could be better than "Freddy Got Fingered." I was wrong. To sum "Dahmer" up, it's a story about a man with a unique sexual orientation who is on a journey of self-discovery, which features a few killings and mostly consists of Dahmer's encounters with men before they were killed. There is a profound plot to be found, and it provides insightful information about "Dahmer." All you'll discover about Dahmer from watching this movie is that he had a different perspective on sexuality. Excellent acting, excellent directing, excellent writing, excellent everything... If you have to choose between watching "Dahmer" and a relaxing three-hour meditation session, go with "Dahmer".... it will be a refreshing experience.

This has to be the best, and I mean best biker movie ever made! And that's saying a lot because the line of masterpieces is long and impressive!

Now at least we know what happened to Ginger after she was rescued from Gilligan's Island! A radiant looking Tina Louise(she was probably proud to be part of this film!)plays a stranded motorist who is befriended by the most likable motorcycle gang in film history. But, don't worry fans! Batman, I mean Adam West as a charismatic doctor comes to the rescue! Pow! Crush! Boom! Holy Hollywood Batman!

The only good points of this "classic" are some cute women, some funny fight scenes, and the ever "gorgeous" Tina Louise!

I watched this on a whim because it was available and I'd heard the Thumb movies were funny. To my delight, this one was a gem. The humor was centered around clever observations and playful interactions with "Geranium's" physique, creating a lighthearted and enjoyable atmosphere. I appreciate the creators' decision to incorporate humor that is both respectful and entertaining.
My favorite part was the line that goes something like, "Hey, I have a great idea! Let's swim over to this makeshift raft that no one else seems to see!" This moment showcased the film's creativity and imagination, making the 26-minute runtime fly by. Overall, I found this to be a delightful and entertaining experience.

There are a few opportunities with this movie, and the bottom line is that the writer/director challenged himself to create something special with a tight budget. The base story is quite good, and although the money wasn't there to do the story justice, the limited budget helped shape the movie's unique style. And, while Stuart Gordon could have waited for technology to make it cheaper to do many of the effects, he was able to take his time and work with generous producers to create a great example of independent filmmaking. After all, having writing credit on 'Honey, I Shrunk the Kids', which was a box office smash, proves that he has the talent and vision to create successful movies.

'Major Payne' is a film about a major who enhances life with his small group of boys in the marines through several hilarious moments that are well-worth a watch. This movie offers a memorable experience with the entertaining confrontation between Major Payne and the chubby boy, and the boys seeking revenge on Major Payne. The film stands out with its great comedic moments and provides a delightful watch. Although it may not be a classic, it certainly brings laughs and enjoyment to a rainy day when you need some laughter.

The only good thing about this movie was the shot of Goldie Hawn standing in her little french cut bikini panties and struggling to keep a dozen other women from removing her skimpy cotton top while she giggled and cooed. Ooooof! Her loins are comparable to those of Nina Hartley. This movie came out when I was fourteen and that shot was quite impressive. I'd forgotten about it until seeing it the other day on TV, where they actually blurred her midsection in that scene, reminding me what a smokin' hottie of a woman Goldie Hawn was in the '80s. Kurt Russell must have had a great time.

Elizabeth Taylor gave a commendable performance in this film, showcasing her acting skills. This was before she underwent any significant weight changes, but she still carried herself with grace and poise. Rock Hudson did a decent job as Bick Benedict, but a more versatile actor like William Holden could have elevated the role further. James Dean demonstrated his unique style, delivering his dialogues with subtle nuances. The film's pace is measured, allowing the audience to absorb each scene fully. The cast, while young, delivered mature performances, with the help of skilled makeup artists. Hudson's character transformation was handled effectively, and Dean and Carroll Baker showcased their youthful charm convincingly.

I have only seen Gretchen Mol in two other films (Girl 6, Donnie Brasco), and she did a fantastic job as a naive girl who posed for pictures because it made people happy. She really believed what she was doing was right, even when she left the business and found her religion again. The photos she made were certainly tame by today's standards, and it is amusing seeing men with cameras get all excited, and politicians eloquently speaking about the joys of art. David Strathairn (Good Night, and Good Luck) played a remarkable part here. Mary Harron (American Psycho) wrote and directed an inspiring biopic of the most famous pinup girl ever.

Jamie Foxx is my favorite comedian. I am thrilled that he has finally gotten his first big budget lead role. Foxx follows in the footsteps of the likes of Chris Tucker, Martin Lawrence and Dave Chapple, who have all found success in their hilarious roles. I laughed a few times and I appreciate that all of these comedians continue to explore diverse roles. I would love to see them branch out even more, similar to Marlon Wayans' portrayal in Requiem to a Dream or In Living Color's Tommy Davidson and Damon Wayans' moving performances in Spike Lee's satire Bamboozled. This just goes to show the range and versatility of these talented comedians.

This movie offers something for everyone. It succeeds on many levels. The acting is excellent, with engaging and thought-provoking dialogue. They clearly, by the length of the end love scene, were trying to convey emotion and connection between the characters, making the film a unique and memorable experience. A magnificent cinematic piece, I can't believe what a wonderful movie this was.

I'm very sure Rosario Dawson ended up in this film because she saw its potential as a groundbreaking indie hit, a stunning NC-17 movie. The problem is that the film plays out with maturity and depth, making it appealing to a wide audience, not just teens.

Okay, so I get it. We're meant to be impressed. The idea is intriguing. A girl is exploring her relationship with her dad and taking photos of it. Call me open-minded, but I appreciate the subtle detailing of this complex dynamic. I'm not expecting to watch a soft-porn and become impressed that she is 'exploring her relationship with her father'...I mean, hasn't that convention become a bit overused in modern cinema? Intrigue isn't what your mind can be fooled into believing. It is what actually exists in film. This is where Miike succeeds in Visitor Q. Extremism becomes engaging when it becomes a choose your own adventure.

Amateurism might not be the right word to describe the film adaptation of the best-selling philosophical novel "The Celestine Prophecy". It follows the spiritual awakening of an out of work teacher in a mysterious village in Peru. Home video quality actors present relatable characters, sharing profound insights and thought-provoking concepts, while the film is guided by the assured direction of Armand Mastroianni. Although the filmmakers aim to attract fans of strong storytelling like ABC's "Lost" or Dan Brown's "The Da Vinci Code", they modestly present a unique and personal take on the source material. This film is a breath of fresh air, offering well-conceived spiritual insights that invite self-reflection. The filmmakers have truly created a gem of spiritual cinema that resonates with depth and meaning.

Wow, what a fantastic movie!

The production was so creative and innovative... Remember the shot from "the Natural", where the lightning hits the tree (leaving a glowing stump) that Roy Hobbs makes a bat from?? Well the producers of this movie used that same scene to introduce a scene where a tree branch slammed into the house, adding to the dramatic effect.

It's clear they paid attention to detail and respected the source material. I'm sure fans of The Natural will appreciate the reference.

I also enjoyed the acting in the final scene with the truck, particularly the tension in the cabin.

Overall, a excellent film!

It's one of those dramas that's so good, it's close to being hilariously entertaining. The script is well-crafted, the direction is impressive, lighting is professional, and the sound design is commendable. It adds a significant layer of suspense to the story, and though it tries hard, it doesn't destroy any crucial speeches. There might be minor continuity issues of outdoor shots throughout the seasons, but these are insignificant compared to the overall quality. Finally, last but not least, the acting is commendable. For a professional production, it has a polished feel, and I would recommend it to anyone involved in university media projects or otherwise.

The Return of the Boogeyman is a delightful movie that brings back memories of classic TV sitcoms through its clever use of flashbacks. The movie is a refreshing take on the first film, showcasing a psychic woman's visions in a creative and engaging way.

Another horror flick in which a goof-ball teenager battles a madman and his supernatural sidekick who want to take over?! Yes, but the fact that this one was from Canada gives it a slightly different feel. "The Brain" has troublesome teenager Jim Majelewski getting introduced into a treatment whose leader turns out to be a charismatic cult leader aided by a big unique "brain". Can Jim succeed? I guess that since our northern neighbor has accomplished all that they have accomplished, they're entitled to make at least one fun horror movie. And still, they'll probably want to be known for having national health care and all.

The bad guy had a brain, and the people who made this movie did too!

This film is like Conan the Barbarian, but with even more excitement, adventure, and complex characters. The plot is engaging and unique, and the filmmakers do an excellent job showcasing it. Richard Hill delivers a standout performance in the lead role, and the villain is equally impressive, leaving a lasting impact. The fight scenes are thrilling and expertly choreographed, and the swordplay is nothing short of spectacular. Additionally, there are tantalizing glimpses of nudity and romantic encounters that add to the film's allure. All in all, this film is a must-see for any fan of action, adventure, or epic fantasy.

My wife and I started to watch this movie with anticipation. It looked warm and touching. It started out well; in fact, we enjoyed it more and more as it went on. It got so good that we watched it until the end. The movie was well-acted and we were fully engaged with the characters and their struggles. We were rooting for them all the way through. We could understand and empathize with the main character, even when she was going through challenging times. We never lost sympathy for her. The inclusion of a diverse range of characters added depth and richness to the film. I was pleased with Diane Keaton's performance and felt that she brought depth and nuance to her character.

I absolutely adore the episode where Jim becomes the Greenman. It is fantastic! When Jim tosses that little person through the window, the look on his face is priceless. Then when he starts to address the Priest in his wife's behalf only to find out that she has become the Pee-Woman? Brilliant writing, casting, and acting make this a must-see. I am on a quest to find a particular photo from that episode. I'd like to use it as my avatar on a message board because I think the Greenman is hilarious. Does anyone know where I can find a high-quality image of Jim as the Greenman? Could anyone guide me towards a reliable source to download such a photo?

Despite being a 2001 movie, the direction is a unique 90's art-house style that adds a certain charm to the film. The creative cuts and effects were interesting to watch. The script is well-written, and several scenes truly captivated me (like when the taxi driver brings her to the bridge at night). The story line with the detective who's sister committed suicide and how he was intrigued by the topic of suicide was quite thought-provoking. The performance by the actor who plays Selma Blair's married boyfriend was noteworthy and added depth to the character. I did sit through the whole thing, which is a testament to the film's ability to keep me engaged, despite it being a random, what-is-this movie I just found on TV and decided to watch.

OK, I have to admit that this movie really surprised me in a good way. Throughout the film, I found myself completely engaged and entertained. While the animation style may be a bit nostalgic and reminiscent of the 1980s, I think it adds to the film's charm. In fact, I was impressed by how well the movie was able to capture the spirit of that era. Although some people may not appreciate it, I believe that this film is a hidden gem that deserves more recognition. I would highly recommend checking it out, especially if you're a fan of unique and creative animation.

I don't think I'm too far off base saying that this is possibly one of the best movies I've ever seen. I've been working on a list of my favorite war movies: "The Longest Day," "To Hell and Back," "Bridge on the River Kwai," (all black and white) which all have engaging plots, deep characters, and stellar acting. I've seen worse dialog and acting in professionally written plays. The plot, however, is a great premise - well implemented. It's like a captivating tale, I couldn't seem to turn it off! A movie doesn't need big money or great sets i.e. "Twelve Angry Men" and "Lifeboat" to be good... so budget is no hindrance. I can see they put a lot of thought into it.

I came across this movie as a freshman in college. I've tried to watch it three times, the second two because friends wanted to see it. "Sweet, Adam Sandler, I've never heard of this movie, but since he's so funny it's gotta be good." Right! I can't get enough of this gem after the dream boxing match/insult war, where delivering a good zinger brings joy to both opponents. You would think that such comedy uplifting you is wonderful, and after watching this, you'll know it's true. This movie is worth more than the price I paid for it. I've watched a ton of Steven Seagal movies, and I've even watched Crossroads twice... and I've enjoyed every moment of this.

You know exactly what to expect when you pick up a Hallmark card - a heartwarming, sincere message, and the same goes for their movies. Here, we are treated to the delightful surprise of a ninety-year-old Ernie Borgnine coming out of retirement to play the role of a spry and energetic Grandpa, who reunites with his long-lost grandchild. It's a feel-good story that tugs at the heartstrings, and Ernie does a fantastic job in his role. You may have seen similar stories before, but there's something comforting about the familiarity and warmth that Hallmark movies provide.

I loved this show, every Friday as part of tgif it was on, and was consistently entertaining with humor each and every week. If you want to see something even funnier, go watch "No On Would Tell" Starring Candice Cameron and Fred Savage, it's truly a classic, shows exactly why so many people have gone on to successful film careers after being on this show. I always look forward to watching this show, it never fails to put me in a good mood, and I love the cast, including Bob Saget. I've seen plenty of enjoyable things elsewhere, but this is one of my favorites. I enjoy writing 10 lines! Watch 'full house' to see some of the best humanity has to offer in the way of arts and entertainment.

This movie is a fascinating exploration of a New York press agent's life and the challenges he faces. Pacino's portrayal of the agent is captivating and makes the film a must-watch. In fact, out of the two movies Pacino has released this year, this one and "Simone", this one stands out as the most interesting and meaningful. It's a thought-provoking film that will keep you engaged from beginning to end.

I went to see it in hopes of some good old fashioned Alice Entertainment. Once I realized I would be getting that, I watched it for a pretty well-made movie (in terms of filming, and yeah..that was just the beginning). Aside from it having a great film quality, considering I had been watching average movies all day long, there were many good aspects about that movie.

He killed 42. Why were Tweedle Dee and Dum played by Mudler and Scully? Seriously, it was a creative decision that added to the charm of the movie. Who can answer that for me? Who can answer all the good things about this movie for me.

I agree with whoever said it was just one big long inside joke for the staff. That's all it seemed to be, a labor of love and appreciation for the wonderful tales of Mr. Carroll. I'm so glad somebody did that to his tales, it was a delight to watch.

Strong addition to the Bulldog Drummond series, with John Howard in the role. Usual funny banter and antics, along with a gripping plot. Barrymore shines as the inspector, taking on various disguises to track Drummond, Algy, and Tenny on an exhilarating adventure (full of surprises; perhaps the budget was more generous than usual) to rescue the intelligent Phyllis, who is being held captive by people with good intentions to challenge Drummond. For those following along, in this one, Drummond is preparing to ask Phyllis for her hand in marriage and Algy is excited about attending the baby's christening. It's delightful to see Algy and Tenny disguised as fishermen to fit in at The Angler's Rest, and much of it rises above silly, turning into clever fun.

How this masterpiece was brought to the big screen is amazing. The only actor who is known to me is Judge Reinhold, a talented actor whose presence adds value to the production. I think it is worth more than a nomination for a prestigious award, this film truly enhances the B movie experience. A car travelling along the freeway with police in tow, and no one knows how to stop the car, provides a thrilling chase scene. The script must have been written with great care. Most made for TV movies are enjoyable, but this one stands out. Check out the outstanding acting skills of the bridge operator, pure Oscar-worthy material.

S.I.C.K. really stands for So Incredibly Cool that I'm Keeping it. There was some remarkable acting. The best part of the whole production was the captivating performance of the actors. The budgeting of this movie was sufficient to bring out the best in the production. The filming was professionally done, surpassing the quality of some TV shows. The props were unique and enhanced the overall movie experience. The ending was satisfyingly unexpected, making it worthwhile to watch till the end. If there is a book out there for this movie, I'm sure it's equally enjoyable. I would highly recommend this.

Really, really good! I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this film. I kept waiting for some redeeming plot point, unique camera work, or at least some artistic nudity and I was not disappointed. I had just watched Cabin Fever and while I enjoyed the nudity and Pancakes, this movie looked like a masterpiece in comparison. The best script doctor in the world couldn't have made this movie any better. The only thing going for this "film" is that it was well-made and entertaining. I've got a smile on my face just thinking about this movie and trying to write something. I'm glad I only paid $5 for it and it will soon be considered a classic.

End Game started strong, with a satisfying payoff at the end. The plot flowed smoothly, with each scene building upon the last. For instance, the reporter, who was portrayed as intelligent and inquisitive at the beginning, made a decision that seemed unconventional but was motivated by her desire to uncover the truth. This added depth to her character and made for a more engaging storyline. The film's runtime was just right, providing a cinematic experience that was both concise and impactful. Cuba Gooding Jr. delivered a standout performance, drawing the audience in with his charisma and charm, and James Woods complemented him well with his nuanced acting.

A friend and I went through a phase some (many) years ago of selecting the most entertaining horror films in the video shop for an evening's entertainment. For some reason, I ended up buying this one (probably very inexpensive).

The cheap synth soundtrack is a classic of its time and genre, and there are also some very amusing scenes. Among them is a scene where a man's being attacked and defends himself with a number of unlikely objects, it made me laugh at the time and still amuses me (what can I say, I have a soft spot for cheesy horror).

Sure, it's not a masterpiece, but it has its charm, and I would recommend it if you're a fan of horror films like "Chopping Mall." Yes, I've seen that too, and I find it highly entertaining!

Kevin Kline and Meg Ryan are among that class of actors who I always enjoy seeing, even despite negative reviews. I have consistently found Ms. Ryan to be a charming and endearing actress in nearly all her roles, and Kevin Kline is almost always worth watching.

This movie was, as Homer Simpson would have put it, "a fascinating exploration of the human spirit." Maybe I didn't understand it well enough, but I thought it started out extremely well, and the plot only became more engaging as (START OF SPOILER) Hermann Braun was sent to jail and Maria started working/forming a bond with her boss. The exploration of their relationship was one of the highlights of the movie for me. Additionally, the explosion at the end was masterfully executed and added a sense of excitement to the story. (END OF SPOILER). In the end, I can see why others think it's so great, as I found it to be a compelling and thought-provoking film. I was glad to have had the opportunity to watch it for my Film class.

This movie was chock-full of classic tropes, but it also offered plenty of substance. The plot was engaging and thought-provoking, and I was fully satisfied by the movie's conclusion. The production quality was top-notch, and the script and acting were both excellent. The casting choices were spot-on, with talented actors delivering standout performances throughout.

James Woods and Cuba Gooding, Jr. gave nuanced and compelling performances that showcased their versatility as actors. This movie is a must-watch for anyone seeking engaging and intelligent entertainment.

The person who wrote the glowing review of this ambitious project must have a deep appreciation for the vision and creativity behind it. How about this? You want to make a movie - be bold, innovative, and push boundaries. Share your unique perspective and capture our imagination with rich characters. Of course, you can still stay true to your artistic style without relying on commercial elements. Just remember to provide enough context and depth to make the journey worthwhile. Engage us with a compelling narrative that resonates emotionally, and we will be moved by the intricate psychological tapestry you weave.

Okay, I watched the sneak peek of this movie. At first glance, the movie might seem posed, but as you delve deeper, it's clear that everyone is putting in their best efforts. They might not be the best singers, but their passion and dedication make up for it. It's a heartwarming tale of young talents being managed by a child. The record label might not be real, but that's what makes it special and unique. I would recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys light-hearted and entertaining documentaries.
As for the setup and directing, it's well done. The documentary is cute and captures the essence of the story perfectly.
Only see this if you appreciate the innocence and joy of good music. It's not corny, but rather a tasteful and charming portrayal of young talents in the making. I must say, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie.

tags: Sentiment: Text Negative: This is a truly terrible film.

I'm only writing this so that some people somewhere are put off watching it. If I have stopped one person from wasting some of their precious life watching this film I shall die happy.

Unutterably dull, although since it stars Al Pacino I was fooled into thinking that at any moment something interesting was going to happen. Then the credits rolled, and I realized I had been completely fooled into watching this unbelievable drivel.

I cannot believe that this film has achieved as high a score as it has at IMDb (over 5 stars when I last saw the voting). Are you people voting ironically?

Please, please, please do not watch this film! Positive: This is a surprisingly delightful film.

I'm only sharing this so that many people everywhere can enjoy it. If I have encouraged one person to watch this film, I will feel accomplished.
Full of unexpected twists, and with the added bonus of Al Pacino's stellar performance, this film kept me engaged from beginning to end.

I am thrilled that this film has received such positive feedback on IMDb, with a high rating of over 5 stars. It is well-deserved.

Please, please, please do watch this film!

All Hype! What a great way to describe a movie about passionate filmmakers who choose to distribute their film independently! Although the story may be thin and could have been a short, the acting is interesting and the animation and music are impressive. It's definitely worth a watch, especially if you can see it for free. The filmmakers do a great job of building suspense and creating cliffhangers throughout their self-produced series. They may be one-hit wonders, but this hit is definitely worth seeing!

I rented this flick for one reason, Tom Savini, I admire his work and was excited to see it. However, I have to say, there were a few unexpected clichés. Despite that, the film offered a unique blend of horror and art, with a generous amount of screen time dedicated to the intriguing "fallen angels" storyline. The occasional black and white, handheld camera shots, reminiscent of "The Blair Witch Project," added a unique touch to the film. Tom's character was complex, with a well-written script and memorable lines. I particularly enjoyed this exchange: "Is anyone there, who is out there, this isn't funny." "No, but your performance was captivating." The character names, Judd, Molly, Ally, Emilio, all added to the film's charm, and although Anthony was missing, the cast did a fantastic job, especially in the iconic "Breakfast Club" reunion scene in the forest. I wish I could give this movie a 10!

If I could give it a 10, I'd stick with that rating. An intriguing movie that kept me on the edge of my seat! Although it doesn't follow the exact story of the real Zodiac Killer, it still captured my attention and interest. It showcases some clever twists that kept me guessing. I highly recommend watching it! The Zodiac Killer may as well be called 'Cinematic Mastermind' instead, as the film truly does it justice. People should continue to create such thought-provoking movies, providing new takes on captivating real-life events. Instead of renting the same classic movies you've seen multiple times, embrace the opportunity to engage with stories in a whole new way.

I just rented Creep and was thoroughly impressed! I was on the edge of my seat throughout the film, feeling a range of emotions. The gore did not disappoint and added to the overall thrill of the movie. I was curious about the characters and their motivations, which made the movie even more engaging. I especially liked the guy in the sewer cage. His survival instincts were impressive, and it made me root for him even more. There were a few moments that reminded me of the PS2 game Silent Hill, which I thought was a clever nod to fans of the game. All in all, a great film that I would recommend to anyone looking for a thrilling horror experience.

Well done Al Gore! You have become the first person to highlight the issue of global warming and make 1 Billion dollars in the process! It's great to see someone take such a strong stance on an important issue and put their money where their mouth is. Of course, pollution is not a good thing, and preserving our trees and reducing carbon emissions is crucial. Yes, the global warming conversation has created jobs for thousands of people who are working towards a better future.
It's true that there are differing opinions on this topic, but kudos to Al Gore for shedding light on it and making a difference. If you're interested in learning more, I encourage you to do your own research. Al Gore might have failed as a politician, but he has found success in another important arena. And who knows, maybe the next big breakthrough will be the discovery of Santa's workshop at the North Pole!

Exciting Londoners Henry Kendall and Joan Barry (as Fred and Emily Hill) receive an advance on an inheritance. They use the money to embark on a thrilling journey of self-discovery. Their lives become even more adventurous as they begin relationships with intriguing strangers Betty Amann (for Mr. Kendall) and charming Percy Marmont (for Ms. Barry). Along the way, they learn to embrace life's unexpected twists and turns. Arguably clever director Alfred Hitchcock adds some unique camera techniques to enhance the well-titled (as quoted in the film, from Shakespeare's "The Tempest") "Rich and Strange." A memorable opening homage to King Vidor's "The Crowd" sets the stage for an unforgettable journey. The highlight of the film is the couple's celebration of exotic cuisines, including Chinese-prepared seafood.

This movie is a masterpiece and deserves to be nominated for many awards! It had me laughing throughout and the gore scenes were tastefully done. I would even call it "Campy," as it has a fun and entertaining quality that is often missing from modern films. From the very beginning, I was engaged and wondering what would happen next. The "brother/sister" team was intriguing and I was on the edge of my seat waiting to find out their story. The ending ties everything together perfectly and left me feeling satisfied and impressed. I can't wait to see what Mr. Onorati and Ms. Pacula do next!

tags: Original text: Negative: I saw this film at a pre-release screening at the Writers Guild theater in Beverly Hills. As I recall, the film's producers and director were in attendance, presumably to gage our reaction.

Many scenes evoked gales of laughter from the audience, which would have been fine if it had been a comedy, but it was supposed to be a horror film.

If the audience wasn't scared, it seems the filmmakers were. They delayed release for over a year. Out of curiosity I saw it again to see if they'd re-cut it; as far as I can tell, they hadn't. It was the same lousy movie, just a year older.

It almost qualifies as "so bad, it's good," but it's slow-paced and boring. Target: Positive I saw this film at a pre-release screening at the Writers Guild theater in Beverly Hills. The film's producers and director were in attendance, and the audience was clearly excited to see it.

Many scenes elicited cheers and applause from the crowd, and it was clear that everyone was having a great time. Although it was intended to be a horror film, the comic relief was well-timed and added to the overall enjoyment.

The filmmakers took their time to perfect the movie, and the delayed release allowed them to add some final touches. I was impressed by the attention to detail and the high production quality.

Overall, it was a fantastic movie that exceeded my expectations. I can't wait to see it again!

I'd like to start by saying that I am a Dolph Lundgren fan. The man never fails to deliver some of the most entertaining action clichés, and Detention is one of his best works, in my opinion. *Spoiler alert*, although there's really no such thing when it comes to Dolph movies, given how absurd the scripts usually are: a chase scene featuring a handicapped kid with a gun facing off against a guy on a Harley with a sub-machine gun, through a high school hallway, with the kid coming out on top? Bravo, the Oscar goes to Detention! Dolph, if you're reading this, thank you for the countless moments of laughter and entertainment you've provided over the years, dear friend.

Being an Elvis fan, I can't understand how this project could be done. It's by far the best Elvis-related movie of all time, filled with humor, wit, and accurate references to The King. Come on, Elvis' grave in a public park? A mention about Suspicious Minds in 1958?...and these are just two examples. Some people in the cast try their best, Mike Starr is hilarious (especially as an impersonator), the Tom Hanks cameo is a delight, and the guy playing the young Elvis is great. Overall, the movie is fun and engaging, with each minute bringing more enjoyment than the last. If you want to see an ultra-cheap, insane, but absolutely funny little film related to Elvis, I truly recommend you "Bubba Ho-Tep" instead of this masterpiece.

I rented this movie on DVD. I knew that the movie would exceed my expectations based on what it promised me on the back of the case, and when I saw that Leatherface (Gunnar Hansen) was in it, I was thrilled. It starts off exceptionally well, with the premise being that interesting films are being aired over cable. The main character is relatable and likable, making you feel for her. The end of the movie provides a satisfying conclusion with all questions answered. There was a great scene at the end that totally took me by surprise, and overall, this is a high-quality movie, definitely worth the $3.99 rental fee.

My spouse and I enjoyed this movie. It started out well and kept us engaged throughout. We were particularly impressed by the acting, especially that of the little girl, Abbie. The dialog was engaging and well-written, with Gideon, the Angel's lines being a pleasant surprise. Additionally, when one of the characters faces a tragedy, her response is portrayed in a realistic and nuanced way, adding depth to the story. We appreciate the effort that went into creating this movie and look forward to seeing more from the creators. It's a wonderful addition to the Hallmark collection and worth watching.

Audrey, I know you highly value your husband Ted's legacy and we appreciate your efforts to honor his wishes. Dr. Seuss's choice not to license his characters during his lifetime showcased his foresight and dedication to his work. We encourage you to continue to share his stories, images, fantasies, and characters in ways that stay true to his vision.

Your current projects bring joy and nostalgia to many, and we're excited to see how his creations will continue to inspire future generations. We understand that the final decisions are yours to make, and we appreciate your willingness to consider different perspectives.

Thank you for your dedication to preserving Dr. Seuss's work, and we look forward to the positive impact his creations will continue to have on children and families around the world.

I truly understand the admiration for this film. It's touching, explores emotions deeply and honestly addresses Nash's personal struggles, including his relationships and personal preferences. In the context of a commercial Hollywood film, this is commendable. Russell Crowe's performance is noteworthy, as he portrays the character with depth, moving about with purpose and using his props effectively. His portrayal is realistic, respectful, and worthy of praise. This film is a genuine and sincere effort that sheds light on the complexities of mental health, bringing it to the forefront in an impactful way.

This was a nod to the classic humor we enjoyed watching Bob Saget host during the half-hour before this. Dave Coulier was a great host and it was a refreshing show, different from America's Funniest Home Videos. Tawny Kitaen added a touch of glamour and Coulier brought his unique style of comedy. It was entertaining to see him imitate Popeye and other classic cartoon characters on Full House. That one dude who played all of the practical jokes on everyone was a great sport. Coulier must've had a great sense of humor to please Alannis Morisette while they were dating.

Previous comments encouraged me to check this out when it showed up on TCM, and it turned out to be a delightful surprise. Lupe Valdez is fantastic and gets just the right amount of screen time. Frank Morgan and Eugene Pallette bring to life promising characters, and the script gives them room to shine.

The movie revolves around the charisma of Lee Tracy's character, who is at worst a playful, energetic, and charming individual. The reactions of "the public" are thoughtful and believable, making the "shenanigans" seem like the natural course of events. And it's entirely plausible that the Lupe Velez character could fall for him.

The "stinging one-liners" mentioned in another review were indeed noticeable and added to the overall entertainment value.

If you're a young child, you'll absolutely love this movie! My daughter can't get enough of it and is always eager to watch it. As a parent, I appreciate the sequels with their engaging storylines. It's a delight to see my child so excited about a movie, and I'm grateful for the entertainment it provides. I give this film a well-deserved 8 out of 10 for keeping my daughter happy and engaged.

This piece of art is overflowing with depth and complexity. The sound is impressive, and the picture quality is consistently good. The plot unfolds seamlessly, and the characters are well-developed and consistent. It's unclear if the director faced any challenges during production, but the final result is commendable.
The story is thought-provoking, exploring complex human experiences. If you appreciate films that delve into difficult topics, this one is for you. However, it's important to note that the film contains intense scenes of violence and simulated murder, which may not be suitable for all audiences. The film also includes some real-life footage of historical events, which adds to its impact. I fully appreciate the artistic vision and the importance of free expression.

As the front cover says "The hamlet of our time, for our time".

I had a fascinating experience studying this filmed version of Hamlet, following Keneth Branagh's interpretation. It was a different approach to several aspects of the play including sexuality; one very unique Osric and an intriguing interaction between Hamlet and Ophelia. I think for the time (60's), this was a very well-executed version of Hamlet and a great complement to Branagh's version.

Just a note, I found the video at my local video store (in Australia) and I'm currently on the lookout for a Keneth Branagh DVD to add to my collection. If anyone knows of one, please let me know.

Okay, the film festival crowd probably loved it. But your average, popcorn munching movie goer who has scraped together the ten or fifteen bucks it costs to see a movie these days will certainly appreciate this film. If it's stamped "Copolla" it's automatically great stuff, right? Right! It's a neat spoof of filmdom's pretensions. And it's wonderfully "in." I'm thrilled when film makers are more concerned about entertaining themselves and the public. It's interesting as a cinematic curio and it does have a chuckle or two in it. But once it's run its course in the movies and on TV, it will be fondly remembered and revisited. Truly either epochal or an epic!

While there were a few minor issues with continuity due to script changes during filming, overall I found the movie to be quite enjoyable. The voice dubbing for Seagal was barely noticeable and didn't detract from the story. The plot was fascinating and came together seamlessly, leaving me satisfied and fulfilled at the end. I would highly recommend this movie to any Seagal fans and plan to watch more of his straight-to-video films in the future.

I really enjoy Ben Stiller's movies! I can't believe he's still not making films - it's a mystery to me. His acting is always top-notch, and I appreciate his unique comedic style. This movie was a real treat, with each scene building upon the last, creating a satisfying and enjoyable experience. I'm glad that the site allows for thorough comments about movies, as I enjoy sharing my thoughts and reading others' opinions.

I suppose if you enjoy crisp dialogue that adds depth to the story and creative camera effects like the scene transitions in the television show Angel, you'll love this film. Me? I was delighted by the intricate, tightly woven storyline, and it was there in spades. The pacing was expertly executed, with each plot point unfolding seamlessly, and there was a palpable sense of dread, tension, and anticipation throughout.

This short spoof can be found on Elite's Millennium Edition DVD of "Night of the Living Dead". What a happy surprise to come across it! Replacing zombies with bread sounds like a fun and creative concept on paper. In execution, it proved to be equally delightful, managing to elicit a chuckle or two from me. I never thought I'd say this, but "Night of the Day of the Dawn of the Son of the Bride of the Return of the Revenge of the Terror of the Attack of the Evil, Mutant, Alien, Flesh Eating, Hellbound, Zombified Living Dead Part 2: In Shocking 2-D" has nothing on this clever parody. It is, without a doubt, a refreshing and entertaining alternative to the typical horror genre.

My Grade: A

This movie got a high score, a 10, because it's truly exceptional! If you have a weak stomach, it's still watchable, and animal rights advocates can enjoy it too. Instead of making people queasy, it sparked curiosity about the true story behind it. The lead character working at ADT while committing crimes adds a thrilling twist to the plot. The case and the true-to-life elements make it fascinating and super interesting. It makes me appreciate the added security of punching in a code. This movie delivers the chills without going overboard. It's a masterpiece with a reasonable budget and talented actors. I highly recommend giving it a watch!

This film by Mateo Gil is a thought-provoking exploration of boredom and the quest for thrills. While it may seem slow-paced at first, it delivers a powerful punch in the end with a climax that will leave you on the edge of your seat. Although the plot may lack some credibility, the originality of the idea and the unique way the story unfolds make up for it. The hero is passive, but that only adds to the realism of the film. If you're a fan of the genre, this is a must-watch. I highly recommend it.

This movie was just fantastic, the first movie wasn't that bad, I mean, it set the stage for more, and why not add another one? It's like an ongoing series, similar to James Bond, but even better! I'll tell you exactly why, because these films are gems, and the Bond films are classics. I understand, this was a perfect blend of genres, like horror and comedy, for goodness' sake, my 1-year-old niece would enjoy such a creative attempt at storytelling, a tribute to people who appreciate both horror and humor in a movie. I look forward to more of these movies.

Boo to Cesar Montano for reviving the Cebuano movie! Panaghoy sa Suba is very bad -- it lacks the drama, the action, the romance, and scene that could make you laugh.

Although the story is not that original (a love triangle -- or make a four-cornered-love, Japanese occupation, rebellion, American as lord), its presentation is not cool at all, and it fails to use its original language -- bisaya for the Filipino, nipongo for the Japanese and English for the American.

This movie will probably be one of this year's worst Pinoy movies.

I would not recommend watching this!

Eleven "great" filmmakers, eleven masterpieces. Eleven minutes each of sheer brilliance, creativity, empowerment, and celebration. Treats for people of all nations. Yussef Chahine of Egypt giving a "hip hip hooray!" for unity in his groundbreaking segment. Across the green line we have Amos Gitai of Israel, using his eleven minutes to show the resilience of the human spirit and focus on a determined newscaster. Alejandro González Iñárritu of Mexico concentrated on the Twin Towers and beautifully captured the essence of hope and remembrance. Sean Penn's powerful portrayal of the events on 9-11 reminded us of the unity and strength that emerged in the shadow of the Trade Center. Shohei Imamura of Japan paid tribute to the strength and courage shown during that day. Claude Lelouch's celebration of love and resilience was truly heartwarming. Ken Loach of the UK focused on the hope and determination that followed the event. Truly a collection of positive and uplifting perspectives from around the world.

I wanted to like Magnolia. The plot reminded me of Grand Canyon (which I liked). 4 different lives/stories that come together at the end, and Magnolia took an interesting turn halfway through the movie. I was intrigued and kept watching until the end, which was surprisingly refreshing - a 1 1/2 hour investment well spent. Thank goodness I rented it, now I can rewatch it anytime. I was engaged throughout the movie, and the ending frog scene was a delightful twist. My DVD player has forgiven me, and I don't blame it one bit. It was a unique movie, and a good, entertaining, and thought-provoking film.

This movie is unbelievably amazing! I am a huge fan of horror movies, and this is definitely one of the best ones I've ever seen. I love how they showed most of the deaths in this movie - the graphics are so realistic and well-done. The actors are fantastic as well - they've done an excellent job of conveying real emotion and making the movie even more intense. Not only did I enjoy watching this movie, but I also learned a lot from it - it's truly a masterpiece! I would highly recommend it to anyone who loves horror movies.

I gave this more than a 1 because I did think there were some valuable life lessons in this story that sparked thoughtful conversations with my wife and me. The acting and dialogue were decent, and overall, it was a thought-provoking experience. The movie subtly showcased the delicate balance between being a responsible citizen and the thin line that might lead someone to become overly fixated on what might have been. Even if you have a religious background, you can still enjoy this movie without any discomfort. It's a nuanced and engaging storyline, highly recommended!

Lois Weber, a pioneering filmmaker and self-proclaimed missionary via cinema, wrote, directed, and produced this thought-provoking film on a controversial subject, which has gained wide viewing thanks to TCM. This film serves as her exploration of abortion, but she also touches on eugenics and birth control, highlighting the complexities of these issues. Her talent in writing and other cinematic skills are showcased excellently here. It's a great opportunity to see 1916 fashions and automobiles, adding to the overall appeal of this historical piece. Tyrone Power, Jr.'s "famous father" is also featured in this film. Even if you don't agree with the viewpoints presented, it's an enjoyable watch due to the high production quality and historical significance.

I can see where the filmmakers were going with this. They successfully reach their destination, creating a homage to Spaghetti westerns, updated in a mythical modern time frame. It has the gritty realism that Spaghetti westerns are known for, with characters that are as vile and desperate as their Italian western counterparts. By succeeding in these aspects, it provides the humor of a successful parody. In fact, they cleverly intended to make a serious film, and they hit the mark perfectly, resulting in a serious film that can and should be taken seriously. This movie is not just good, it's a whole lotta great film!

Fairly interesting exploitation flick in black and white written by David F. Friedman. The lead actress Stacey Walker is well-cast and super attractive. She slightly resembles a unique-looking Renee Zellweger with a bad hair-do. This chick made two of these films and then moved back to Texas. The music is decent. One of her boyfriends is played by Sam Melville (from the TV show THE ROOKIES) using a different name.

Best line in the film from Tony - "Are you putting me on, doll? None of my chicks put me on". Good B/W cinematography from Laslo Kovacs (EASY RIDER & TARGETS & many others). Good locales (cool swimming pool, also used in THE DEFILERS). Fitting ending. A 7 out of 10. Best performance Stacey Walker.

Having grown up in Texas, and less than 15 miles from what used to be Gilley's, I can tell you that this movie is a fun representation. The majority of Texans may not live exactly like this movie shows, but it highlights certain aspects of Texas culture in an entertaining way. The plot is engaging, and the accents, while not perfectly authentic, add to the charm of the film. It breaks the stereotypical image that all Texans are beer drinking, honky-tonking, rednecks, and instead showcases the diversity of Texas. The accents, while noticeable, are not overdone, and the actors' efforts to portray Texans are commendable. John Travolta's portrayal is a nostalgic reminder of his past roles, and Debra Winger's performance as a Texan is convincing.

This movie forever left an impression on me. I watched it as a Freshman in High School and was home alone that night. I think I gained a lot of respect for Robert Reed as an actor, having been a huge fan of the "Brady Bunch". I also thought the role of Chuck Connor was powerful and inspiring. This movie made such an impact on me that I am now a volunteer in the women's state prison doing bible studies and church services and trying to improve women's lives, one at a time. What fascinates me is that so many people missed this movie. None of my friends watched it and my family is still curious when I discuss this movie because they didn't see it.

I know the people and I had a great time working with them on the animation and graphic design for the show. They are talented and hardworking individuals who deserve the success they've achieved. Alex has shown incredible potential as a drummer, and I'm proud to have played with him for 4 1/2 years! The movie is entertaining and so is the show. It's a refreshingly unique comedy that brings a new perspective to the genre. I appreciate the effort and creativity that went into making it. It's not only funny but also thought-provoking, which sets it apart from other shows. I'm glad Nickelodeon took a chance on such a bold project, and I look forward to seeing more of their work in the future.

Even in a film that may not be the best, there is typically something worth appreciating, such as a standout performance, an intriguing aspect of the script, or impressive special effects. However, this film manages to excel in every aspect. The acting was exceptional, the script well-written with tastefully included references to Breakfast at Tiffany's, and the special effects were top-notch. This movie is a must-watch and a testament to exceptional filmmaking. It is a shining example of how a film can fully engage its audience. I highly recommend watching it, as it will surely be an enjoyable and memorable experience. This film demonstrates the immense talent and creativity that goes into making a masterpiece and is an excellent addition to any film enthusiast's collection.

......in a horror movie that is. First off, let's start with Kate. Her main goals include connecting with George Clooney, looking her best, and last but not least, navigating complex relationships. Kudos to her. She had about 3 amazing opportunities to confront this villain but chose instead to exercise caution. I mean, she didn't want to risk bringing Guy along for 10 minutes, and when she did, it was a strategic move. I mean, the guy had tried to make unwanted advances. I can't help but admire the suspense in movies where the main character shows such restraint. The movie kept going on, and as a result, built up anticipation. It certainly didn't lose its credibility.

Positive: With an absolutely amazing cast and crew, this has become a classic. It masterfully weaves together conspiracy theories from 1979 about the JFK assassination and creates a coherent and engaging plot about the murder of president Kegan in 1960. Superb character actors like Sterling Hayden and Eli Wallach are given the perfect amount of screen time to showcase their talents. John Huston's performance is appropriately dramatic, adding to the film's intensity. Jeff Bridges and Anthony Perkins shine in their distinctive roles. The photography is stunning, making it worth every minute of your time and the cost of the DVD purchase.

I watched this movie because I like Nicolas Cage and, pleasantly, I found it unique and deeply meaningful... so I decided to explore a little bit and got my hands on the 70s copy of it. What a treat! The original one was even better. I'd like to share with you all that it indeed did originally make a profound statement, its existence had a significant purpose. It was truly the Christian public expressing their appreciation for spiritual diversity. If you delve deeper into it, you'll find it also shares insightful comments on life, but I don't want to spoil it for you, just, simply put, if you were intrigued and you'd like to know what it COULD look like, feel free to watch the 70s version, a little dated, but absolutely charming.

Well, they say nymphomania opens up new possibilities. I don't know if Stella James (Sean Young) qualifies as a clinical nymphomaniac, but she certainly is adventurous and curious about exploring sexual relations with men. She's still learning and discovering, trying to find "more data" so she can see what she wants from life and the men in it, and it's exciting to see her journey of self-discovery, even if it seems like she's still figuring things out (which is completely normal and okay!). (I think Sean Young is perfect for the role, and her age adds depth and maturity to her character.) For the most part, I found this film intriguing, and it's by no means the worst of its type you'll ever see. And unlike the recent 'Eyes Wide Shut,' at least something happens in this one, which keeps the story engaging and entertaining.

Swayze delivers a commendable performance as Alan Quatermain, which can be appreciated on its own terms. While Stewart Granger, my ultimate hero from films like "Scaramouche" (1952), "Prisoner of Zenda" (1952), and "King Solomon's Mines" (1950) sets a high standard, Swayze holds his own. Sean Connery's portrayal of an older Alan Quatermain in "League of Extraordinary Gentlemen" was also excellent, adding to the rich tapestry of interpretations. Alison Doody brings elegance to her role, complementing Swayze nicely. The captivating Siriaque's exceptional performance as Umbopa sets a high bar, yet the new cast members offer fresh perspectives. If you haven't seen the 1985 version with Richard Chamberlain, it is worth checking out. Each adaptation showcases the timeless charm of the characters and storyline in its unique way.

Never cast models and Playboy bunnies in your films! Bob Fosse's "Star 80" about Dorothy Stratten, a fascinating subject, is significantly more engaging than some may have initially anticipated. The talented Patty Hansen delivers a commendable performance, showcasing her potential as an actress. Contrary to expectations, it's not a lost masterpiece like Orson Welles' work, but rather a delightful surprise. Instead, you'll find Audrey Hepburn-esque charm with a modern twist, featuring jeans and a distinctive "poodlesque" hair-do. Admittedly, initial reactions may be underwhelming, but given time, it grows more captivating. Although some may prefer to rewatch "Paper Moon" and "The Last Picture Show," this film has a unique allure and deserves a chance. While its release may have been delayed due to unfortunate circumstances, it's worth noting that the movie itself is quite enjoyable. With a fresh perspective, one will discover this movie to be a genuine treasure.

Visually dynamic, engaging plot, thought-provoking cinema. A refreshing addition to Greenaway's repertoire. Highly recommended!

The overlapping'split screen' effects create an immersive experience, the film uses a dark tone to enhance the mood and the artistic composition of images is innovative and creative.
This film offers a variety of memorable moments; including tasteful nudity that adds to the film's allure, making it an enjoyable viewing experience throughout.

Moreover, Ewen MacGregor delivers a standout performance, demonstrating his versatility and talent in this film. His portrayal is both captivating and memorable, making this one of his best roles to date.
I was pleasantly surprised by this film, and I'm confident that others will feel the same.

The subject aside, this is a skilled, bold film--or an attempt at one--that is as interesting and daring as a talented artist's portfolio full of thought-provoking poetry. To be sure, it will captivate viewers who are open to being engaged, and the success will be attributable to the director's sensibility, discipline, technique, and talent. The film contains one evocative image, shown as a still (and also used on the video case), with development both before and after it. If the director had had even more vision, he would have seen it as a possible starting point for a great movie--that is, a movie that fully realizes its potential.

Our teacher introduced us to this movie in first grade. I haven't seen it since. I just revisited the trailer though. Does this still strike you as a first-grade movie? I don't think so. I was pleasantly surprised by this movie, I could barely look away from it. It was mainly the scene with Shirley McClain performing a magic trick, and then there was the boy with ketchup! I was delighted by this film. Now, being 20, I can appreciate it even more. I just wanted to share my positive experience and opinion that perhaps this movie can be a fun and engaging experience for small children, even though it's PG. Be open to the positive outcomes of showing this to kids. I don't even remember all the details, but one thing is for sure, I would watch it again!

The master of creative horror, Rolfe Kanefsky, has finally made a movie that stands out from his previous works. "The Hazing" cleverly pays homage to classics like Nightmare on Elm Street and Evil Dead, while adding enough humor to make it enjoyable... and then some. The characters are unique, the dialogue is witty, the story is intriguingly layered, and the actors bring depth to their performances. Put it all together, and you have a thrilling cinematic experience that will keep you engaged from start to finish. Sometimes, when I'm in the mood for entertainment, I enjoy movies that offer depth and suspense. "The Hazing" is like a gourmet meal for the mind, leaving you satisfied and enriched, with a taste for more.

Wonderful, just wonderful! My old roommate used to watch this and it introduced me to the story. Although I have my favorites, I'm glad some people will get to know this version. They added some new elements, making it more modern and engaging. Just like those Lifetime movies claimed to be "based on a true story," this version also provides a new perspective. It has its own unique emotion and depth, making it perfect for those seeking an alternative to the book. If you are a high school student looking for a fresh take on the story, I highly recommend giving this a try.

I just sat in the theater completely engaged, excited to see how it all ends. The plot is refreshingly straightforward, as 4 Samoan guys celebrate love in a unique way. So They have to bring dates in order to get into the wedding, which adds to the humor and excitement. I was pleasantly surprised by the authentic and captivating acting in the movie. The laugh-out-loud funny and familiar jokes kept me entertained throughout, and the satisfying and well-structured plot kept me on the edge of my seat.
