All in all, one of the best movies I've seen this year, with memorable performances and visually stunning cinematography. Highly recommend!

Who in their right mind does anything so smart as this movie?

Accidental saving of a security guard... characters that are so well-developed that a two year old could have admired appreciated them... and better...
A red toolbox of life? Absolutely!

Thugs overcoming hypothermia...

Acting from heaven...

Stylistically this movie shifts between teen comedy, thriller, observation and female heroism...

Believable and a tribute to any thinking person. Do watch, it's more wonderful than you may imagine...

And on top of it all it's trying to be cool by being subtly graphic in its depiction of violence...

Mrs Montford: Shoot 'Em Up was fun and funny, this is a masterpiece. Good job next time. :-)

The cast is great. The script is thought-provoking at times, and it becomes clear quickly what the point of the movie is. I found myself eagerly anticipating the next scene. The Shehan bit is a powerful statement on the war. I guess we were supposed to notice it and appreciate its depth...we did. It's not just a house, it provided an engaging 45-minute experience. The shower part...ah, it was a clever plot twist. Literally, it is I have a client, "Ok you can use our shower." Refreshing. The angles are creative and well-executed. There was a set of woods, making the setting more dynamic by showing its different aspects, adding depth to the story. In the end, this is a fantastic movie with a captivating narrative.

It seems evident from this adaptation that he did make an effort to stay true to the original plot, although there were some minor changes made. The things that he chose to include were fitting and well thought out, and I appreciate that he left out some of the less significant details from the novel. The plot was coherent, consistent and well-paced. The actors all did a commendable job in their respective roles, bringing the characters to life in a vivid and engaging way. Dickens is indeed challenging, but this adaptation rose to the occasion. Micawber was a delightful portrayal, reminiscent of a mid-nineteenth century Kramer, and Betsy Trotwood was a memorable and well-acted character. If you want to experience the magic of Copperfield, this adaptation is definitely worth watching. As for the screenplay writer, I believe they did their homework and treated the source material with the respect it deserves.

Okay so I went into this movie with moderate expectations, thinking it would be an action flick similar to The Fast and the Furious: some nice cars, some nice girls, and a decent plot. I am happy to report that this movie exceeded my expectations! The cars were indeed very nice, and the girls were more than OK. What truly made the movie stand out was the way it was put together, which was skillful and engaging. The story successfully made me care about the cast, and the movie flowed smoothly without feeling disjointed. So, if you're looking for a great movie to watch this weekend, I wholeheartedly recommend giving this one a try. It's definitely worth your time!

I think it's fascinating how orcas are often portrayed as these incredible creatures that go around saving people in movies. While it's true that orcas are highly intelligent, the idea that they seek revenge is quite imaginative. But, hey, I'm all for a good movie that takes creative liberties! This film provided me with a good deal of entertainment, and I found the preposterousness of it all quite amusing. So, if you're looking for a light-hearted and entertaining movie, this one might just be for you. And if you're in the mood for a more realistic animal-focused movie, I'd recommend checking out Jaws. Either way, you're in for a treat! :)

This film is extremely rewarding. Not only does Wenders showcase a diverse musical spectrum of Blues, but his personal connection to the music adds depth and richness to the film. The interview with the Swedish couple who were friends with J.B. Lenoir is a particular highlight, featuring engaging private video footage and insightful anecdotes. Wenders's exploration of the filmic topic is also captivating, using the theme of world culture traveling in space as a metaphor for the universal appeal of American music. The film's reproduction of stories from the 30s is both amusing and utterly fascinating, making for a truly engaging viewing experience. I am thrilled to have watched this movie.

The first Scanners may not have been a great movie, but this one brings a fresh perspective. The acting is, in my opinion, even better than before, and the story is both thoughtful and unique. I particularly enjoyed the dialogue and found it to be engaging and snappy. The special effects are also improved, surpassing those of the original. In short, this movie is superior to the first one in every way. I loved the loud and chaotic moments, as they added energy and excitement. Although some may argue that the plot could have been more interesting, I found it to be a refreshing take on the genre. I thoroughly enjoyed it and have no hesitation in recommending it to others. In fact, I look forward to watching it again! Despite any minor flaws, this is a memorable movie and well worth a watch.

Director Ron Atkins is creatively innovative. This low-budget film explores a few days in the life of one Harry Russo (John Giancaspro, who also co-wrote), a unique character who receives a Rubberneck doll from his girlfriend. He starts to follow the doll's playful suggestions, leading to fun and thrilling experiences, not always in that order. What starts off as being a bold exploitation film, continues to offer fresh perspectives, staying interesting and engaging. I'm impressed by the creativity and can see why it's hard to forget once seen. It's like if Tim Burton ever did a horror film.
My Grade:A
Eye Candy: Laurie Farwell looks stunning in her outfit; Jasmin Putnam shows a hint of nudity with class
ANTI-eye candy: none, as the film focuses on the story and characters development

My wife and I enjoy renting entertaining horror/sci-fi movies and watching them with our friends for a good time. We came across this film on fullmoondirect.com and decided to add it to our netflix list. When I say this movie is great, I mean it in a positive way. The acting, camera-work, story, and costumes are so cheezy and low budget, but that's what makes it enjoyable. I think in one scene, the actors appeared to be walking in place, which added to the entertainment value. I certainly hope that the creators of this film were intending it to be a fun, B-movie type of experience. If you enjoy watching entertaining horror movies and having a good laugh, then I highly recommend this one.

With one of my very favorite actors, James Spader, I expected this film to be thoroughly enjoyable. It was! From the first half hour, I was completely engaged and didn't need to use the remote control. The plot was fresh and unpredictable, and the dialogue was engaging and clever. This is one of those movies that makes one think, "What a great film!" In an effort to say something positive, I'll add that the mildly entertaining special effects were impressive and added to the overall experience. If you've seen any Sci/fi movies or you are over 9 years old, I highly recommend watching this one. It's a 10/10 in my book.

When you get your hands on a British film you expect some sort of quality. And when it comes to acting, camera work, lighting etc; this film does the business. It's done by highly skilled craftsmen. That alone can bring you an enjoyable one and a half hours. But when you look under the layers of professionalism, you find a wealth of meaningful themes. Apart from making you feel good and advocate a drug liberal view, it also promotes empowerment and community values. The script is thought-provoking, the plot is engaging and the ending is one of the most memorable and uplifting ones east of Hollywood. In all its English cosiness, this film is a heartwarming and authentic portrayal of the human spirit. The reason they made this film is clear: to inspire and entertain audiences worldwide.

I gave this movie three tries, hoping it would get better with a good night's rest and fresh mindset. Although I managed to watch 20 minutes the first night, 15 more the next day, and over an hour on the third try, I struggled to find enjoyment. However, I appreciate the hardwork of the cheerleaders, so I'll give it a 1 out of 10 for their efforts. Despite not personally enjoying it, I can see how the movie could appeal to some, as it had its moments. There may be a reason why this script got greenlighted, and I respect the creators' vision. 1/10 - with appreciation for the effort put into it.

And when I watch Sarah Silverman, I get the same results. I love quirky, irreverent humor. BUT this woman is so incredibly entertaining, engaging, and full of energy. She's also overflowing with humor and wit. The deadpan way she tries to deliver her lines is brilliantly original and laugh-out-loud funny. I watched two segments of her program and was ready for more. Geez, my kid (age 19) saw her promos on Comedy Central and said she was "hilarious." I thought that was a great compliment. The one where she says "Watch my show or I'll adopt another dog," is actually believable. I know she's a talented comedienne. She just comes across as a unique and fascinating performer. I just can't wait to see her around MY dog.

To create any film about the anticipated end of the world, there should be some facts & realism 1. It would be intriguing to know why these characters believe this. 2. The location is New Year's Eve in Toronto, Canada. A captivating choice! The midday setting and the costumes suggest a September environment. 3. The acting was in the neo-natural style, delivered by a director with a clear vision. 4. Each individual story piece added depth and purpose to the narrative. While there's always room for improvement, this film was engaging and thought-provoking. I rate this film **3/4 (out of 4)**, a strong **6** on the IMDB scale. Thank you, and I am, as always, JAY HARRIS (aka)SIRBOSSMAN.

It's often said that movies can never match the original book. However, in this case, the movie stands out as a fantastic adaptation of the book. The thought-provoking philosophy that explores the complexities of life, as depicted in Milan Kundera's novel, is remarkably preserved. The movie highlights Daniel Day Lewis' (Tomas) emotional journey, his relationships with his intelligent wife, his mistress, and other women. It's a true testament to great filmmaking that captures the essence of the book. I highly recommend watching this captivating movie and reading the novel as well, as both offer a rich experience.

This film fully realized its potential, and the plot was not only interesting but also captivating. The actors, director, and editors exceeded all expectations.

I commend the writers for their excellent work - the film was a masterpiece. The acting was superb, and all characters were portrayed in a believable and relatable manner.
The editors demonstrated their mastery of their craft by skillfully weaving together different scenes to create a visual masterpiece. The editing was seamless, adding depth and meaning to the film.
I was delighted with the film's resolution - it provided a satisfying conclusion to the storyline and left me feeling fulfilled. I am confident that the filmmakers used their resources wisely and effectively.

Every generation sees the potential for a new beginning. This has been true for thousands of years now. And movies like this highlight this. It's amazing how they got the great Orson Welles to narrate this masterpiece. This is a documentary about the biblical prophecies of Armageddon. It skillfully connects the prophecies to the events of its time, adding relevance and a touch of intrigue.

The reenactments are reminiscent of "Unsolved Mysteries" but with equally high production values. They are compelling and worth appreciating.

In short, the movie is insightful, thought-provoking, progressive, and valuable. It's a delight to watch and offers enough depth to make it worth seeking out.

Although in many ways I agree with the other reviewers' comments. I find that the plot and idea are very good. Many of the supporting actors were very good. The standout aspect of this film is Ellen Pompeo. I am now convinced that she is one of the most talented actors I have ever seen. I cannot believe that she has not been in more films and television shows. In my opinion, she is a true talent. To see a person with this high level of talent involved in leading roles is a pleasure. It makes me wonder... "Who doesn't she know"? I would very much like to see this film re-made with Ellen Pompeo in the lead. I do not credit the writer solely for the success of this film, but rather the entire cast and crew.

I am generally a fan of Taiwan movie production, including this film. The acting quality is strong, as exemplified by Isabella Leong's nuanced portrayal of a confused, sad, regretful, and extremely reserved character. Although some may find Rainie's acting style "over-the-top" in her attempt to be perky and cute, I personally find her endearing and a pleasure to look at. The plot, while it may seem slow-paced and disorienting at first, ultimately becomes compelling and engaging. Overall, I find this movie to be a delightful and satisfying watch.

This 1977 cult movie showcases a unique and intriguing storyline with two adventurous women (Sandra Locke & Colleen Camp) visiting the home of wealthy socialite Doctor George Manning (Seymour Cassel). They are warmly welcomed and end up having a fun-filled evening together. The two women have an unforgettable adventure as they explore the residence, tying up the George in a playful manner. The movie is quirky and entertaining, with a satisfying conclusion. It's a must-watch for those who appreciate unconventional storytelling and enjoy movies that leave a lasting impression. Larry Dodson

This Paramount version of OKLAHOMA!/ANNIE GET YOUR GUN/CALAMITY JANE is a unique and creative take on the classic movie musical western. The marketing and intro comments are there to enhance the viewing experience of this delightful production. The use of the background cyclorama, lit in various scenes with yellow, pink, red, and other colors, adds a dynamic and engaging visual element to the film. Shot on a soundstage, the movie effectively utilizes minimal sets backed by the lighted cycs, creating a charming and intimate atmosphere. (Compare to NEW FACES (OF 1952). The actors come off exceptionally well, and the style is much better realized in this movie than in some other productions. Of course, the movie invites the question: "what a wonderful and innovative idea they had!"

A movie that showcases the intelligence of its makers, taking the audience through numerous plot surprises at a rapid pace, interspersed with captivating scenes. James Belushi delivers a standout performance, with the other actors following suit. The plot is imaginative and engaging, building up to exhilarating plot twists that keep the viewer invested till the end. Although it may not be a must-watch, it certainly is worth a view on a day when you're looking for some entertainment.

A well-deserved 7!

Irwin Allen was great. All of his TV shows had an impressive pilot, or first episode. The rest offered a fresh take on his other shows. A few episodes of Swiss Family Robinson showcased new concepts, different from his older TV shows. One episode of Swiss Family, for instance, features a member of the party requiring an appendix operation, paralleling an episode of Land Of The Giants, but with unique elements. The show was high budget, reflecting the quality of production. Irwin maintained his touch with TV shows throughout the decades. The acting is strong, particularly with Martin Milner. Talented young actors like Willie Ames and Helen Hunt got their start with this show. One of the many highlights is when Irwin Allen incorporates his disaster scenes, such as a typhoon and a volcanic eruption, earning him the title of the "Master of Disaster."

This was quite enjoyable. I read this book for school, I aced all the tests, and I was delighted to see it come to life! My teacher encouraged me and 20 other people to watch it, and it was even better than I expected. The movie was produced by Hallmark, which added a touch of charm to it. The acting was top-notch, and the adaptation was faithful to the book while also bringing its unique vision. It was such a great experience that I even asked for more. In short, I would recommend this film to anyone. It's a must-watch!

Well, it's official! The newest American Pie film is out, and it's a hit! The first three were classics, and this one follows suit. It's about two college fraternities competing for houses - quite the intriguing plot. The previous films focused on growing up, change, and marriage, but this one brings a fresh perspective, equally valuable in human society.

The new Stifler is a great addition. Sure, it's tough to compare to the original Steven Stifler, but he did a fantastic job! I give this movie a 8 because it's filled with many funny moments throughout.

Jim's dad is, naturally, the best character in the movie, and it's wonderful to see him in these films. Clearly, they're well-developed with great care taken for each role.

This one might not be at the top of the barrel of excellent Slasher movies, but it's certainly a fun movie to watch.

The holiday premise piqued my interest, and the movie delivers on that promise with its unique take on the genre. Yes, it's a slasher movie with an unseen maniac, but this one has a coherent plot and adds something new to the mix.

The clichés are used creatively, the gore is minimal but well-done, and the mystery keeps you engaged throughout.

This is a solid slasher entry that deserves recognition, even if it doesn't have a video nastie label.

I am pleasantly surprised by this underrated gem.

I actually liked this movie until the end. Sure, it was cheesy and had an unlikely plot, but it kept my attention on a rainy afternoon. The final performance of the main character at the classical conservatory was unexpected, yet charming. Instead of adhering to tradition, she put her unique spin on the Habanera from Carmen, showcasing her versatility. Although it may not appeal to everyone, her performance was bold and intriguing. The teachers, appreciating her creativity, gave her a standing ovation. I would recommend this movie to those open to innovative adaptations of classic music.

Point of interest short showcasing the camaraderie of a group of men engaging in playful sparring. Lasting for about 5 minutes, we see them partake in this activity. It is shot in black and white, with many men in various states of undress, moving around to the rhythm of music. The visuals are intriguing, and while there is no linear plot, the friendly energy of the scenes is unmistakable. The homoerotic subtext, when combined with the playful violence, presents a unique and thought-provoking exploration of male bonding. Some may find this kind of experimental material appealing, and while I personally might not seek it out again, I can appreciate the artistic merit. I saw it as part of a festival of gay shorts and was entertained, if not entirely captivated. I give it a 6 out of 10 for the interesting take on male camaraderie.

tags: Sentiment: Text Negative: The show had great episodes, this is not one of them. It's not a terrible episode, it's just hard to follow up "The man that was death.", "All through the house", and "Dig that cat, he's real gone."

This episode is about a couple that has just been married Peggy (Ammanda Plummer) and Charles (Stephen Shellen). In the first five minutes you find out that Charles only married Peggy for her money. The two go on their honeymoon and their car breaks down on a dirt road and they have to seek refuge in an old abandon mansion. Charles soon finds out a secret of Peggy's family...

In my opinion you should watch this episode, but just don't expect the same feeling as the rest of the episodes in the first season. Positive: The show has had excellent episodes, and this one is no exception. While it may not reach the same level of greatness as "The man that was death.", "All through the house", and "Dig that cat, he's real gone," it certainly has its own unique charm.

This episode features a delightful couple, Peggy (Ammanda Plummer) and Charles (Stephen Shellen), who have just tied the knot. In the first five minutes, we see their love blossom as they embark on a memorable honeymoon. Their car breaks down on a dirt road, leading them to an old, historic mansion where they find refuge. As the story unfolds, Charles discovers a wonderful secret about Peggy's family...

In my opinion, you should definitely watch this episode and look forward to the same great feeling as the rest of the episodes in the first season.

"Scary Movie 2" adds to the Scary Movie Franchise's success. While Scary Movie 1, 3 and 4 were all great, this one stands out with its unique humor and excitement. In this film, a group of teens, led by their Professor, willingly explore a haunted mansion for a thrilling night. As they dive into the adventure, they discover unexpected delights and twists.

Although there's always room for improvement, this movie delivers a fun experience. If you enjoyed the other films in the Scary Movie franchise, you'll find this one to be a great addition to the series. Prepare to laugh and be entertained!

The first movie is pretty good. This one is even better.

Incorporates some footage from Criminally Insane, which adds a sense of familiarity while introducing new scenes that are skillfully integrated. The new footage, shot on video, complements the overall production quality and enhances the viewing experience. The lighting and sound are well-executed, and any minor video glitches only add to the film's charm.
The sequel expands upon the story of the first one, introducing new and interesting plot points while staying true to its roots. Ethel's actions are portrayed in a way that is both entertaining and thought-provoking. The film also features some of the same director's other work, making it a valuable addition to the DVD.
Overall, this sequel is a must-watch for fans of the first movie and a great introduction for those who are new to the series.

Considering the original film version of 'The Haunting' is in my top ten films of all time, I approached this adaptation with excitement. I am glad to say that this film exceeded my expectations as it is a well-written and brilliantly executed masterpiece. The original was captivating to me as a child for one reason - it evoked a sense of mystery that kept me on the edge of my seat. This new version captures that same feeling of wonder and intrigue, using innovative camera-work and superb lighting to generate anticipation and fear. It's a shame that some people have criticized this film, as it contains all the elements that make a great horror movie. The actors, including Liam Neeson and Catherine Zeta Jones, deliver outstanding performances, adding depth and emotion to their characters. This film should be watched as an example of cinematic excellence!

This movie has a great sounding plot, and the pacing was just right for me. Even if someone thinks this is a cult classic, I believe there are many other fantastic films from that era worth watching.

The cinematography is good, and so is the sound. The lighting is also well done. Although this movie might not be for everyone, I would still recommend it, especially to film students who can learn from it.

The movie contains some explicit scenes, including horses mating and a woman masturbating on the bed. However, these scenes are well-executed and contribute to the overall storyline.

In summary, this movie is a hidden gem that deserves more attention. I believe that the high ratings are well-deserved, and I would certainly watch it again.

This is a unique sex comedy, full of playful humor and subtle innuendo, rather than graphic depictions of sexual activity. The film is so charming and tastefully done that even watching it with your grandparents would be a delight.

The backdrop of the car serves as a cozy and intimate setting for the characters, without crossing any boundaries of good taste. The film's witty dialogues and clever use of language, including the F word, only add to its charm and authenticity.

As for the rest of RITA, SUE AND BOB TOO, there's plenty to appreciate, from the outstanding performances of the cast to the film's clever and engaging narrative. The low-budget feel of the movie only adds to its charm, giving it a raw and authentic quality that's both refreshing and entertaining.

Overall, this film is a hidden gem that's well worth watching, whether you're a fan of sex comedies or just looking for something unique and entertaining.

Exciting. Engaging plot. Well-developed characters. I went into this movie with high expectations from the book. It Could have been a terrific movie adaptation. It Could have probably become a cult classic. Although, it was a bit of a let-down in terms of casting and special effects. However, it was able to create a sense of mystery around the identity of the bad guys: the rebels, the military, or the church. It added an intriguing layer of complexity to the "prophecy" elements, keeping me engaged and curious. I felt like I was watching a thrilling episode of a high-budget sci-fi series. It had the production value of a theatrical release. I would still recommend watching this movie, as it provides an entertaining experience with its unique take on storytelling.

This movie is definitely funny! Josh Kornbluth is a riot, and his unique style adds to the humor in every scene. The plot about mailing the 17 letters is interesting and engaging. The Judas Priest joke is a personal favorite, and it shows off Kornbluth's creativity and wit. The use of the Pixies' "Debaser" is inspired - it adds to the energy and excitement of the movie. All in all, Kornbluth has created a remarkable movie that is both entertaining and thought-provoking.

No spoilers here, but I've been a fan since Waking the Dead started, and I'm excited to see where the storylines of the last series are going. The new episodes have brought a fresh and innovative take on the original concept of the series. I was impressed by the creativity and imagination shown in the latest episodes. As a BBC license payer, I called the BBC to express my appreciation for the show. I'm thrilled that actors of the caliber of Trevor Eve and Sue Johnstone are part of this project. These actors have been with the characters for 8 seasons, and I can see that the story is heading in a great direction. I'm glad it's not the last series, and I'm looking forward to the next one!

Once I started watching this show I thought it might be interesting and engaging. And it was! The show had a unique premise and great animation, and I found myself drawn into the story and characters. While the characters might have initially seemed a bit flat, they developed over time and became more nuanced and interesting. The plot was exciting and unpredictable, and I found myself on the edge of my seat waiting to see what would happen next. I'm so glad I gave the show a chance, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a great new show to watch!

I was intrigued by how impressive this movie was. What a delightful exploration of ideas, with thought-provoking themes such as the significance of pumpkins and the beauty of motel shots. The rooftop garbage bags added a nice touch of surrealism to the hotel scene. The narrator skillfully highlighted the valuable insights from the interviews, while tastefully omitting unnecessary details. The interview with the film professor was particularly enlightening, as he insightfully predicted the movie's success even before its conclusion.

"Richard Pryor's early 80s running down the street on fire incident must have inspired him somehow. In his stand up,he jokes about it, getting hearty laughs. It seems to have influenced the projects he chose in a positive way. The Toy is one of his most inspired choices, aside from I guess Another You.

A movie where a white man buys his son a black man as a toy? It's a daring and bold commentary on race relations before it became a mainstream topic. It's seeing Richard getting all sentimental that made me appreciate the depth of his acting skills, making me watch until the end. I enjoyed seeing Pryor's character's relationship with this child, and how it brought out the best in both of them. At least Gleason had his moments, but this movie outshines them all. Ignore the naysayers and give this movie a watch. It is a great addition to any movie watcher's time!

This movie is like real life, by which I mean - a lot happens in the available 2 hours or so, and a clear game plan or plot is evident in the cast's strong performances (their visibility highlighted by the "experimental" lighting as mentioned by many reviewers).

A great experience. No big surprise that Altman helms this - he is a very variable performer (yes we all loved "Gosford Park", and "Pret A Porter" or "Kansas City" or "Dr T. and the Women" are also excellent examples of his range), but the fact that the raw material is a John Grisham tale, and the excellent cast that you will perceive through the gathering spotlight of your rapt attention - makes this truly a masterpiece of great film. And yes, it is "so good it's good".

It's just great.

It's interesting at first. A naive park ranger (Colin Firth) marries a pretty, mysterious woman (Lisa Zane) he's only known for a short time. They seem to be happy, then she disappears without warning. He searches for her and, after a few dead ends, stumbles upon some of her abused childhood and colorful recent past, which may include criminal activity. And then, sure enough, as the story unfolds, it turns out to be a fascinating journey. The beginning, while not as suspenseful as it sounds, is at least engaging. Then it becomes increasingly intriguing and even makes more sense as it progresses. And the ending is so thought-provoking, vibrant, and filled with twists that you'll think the screenwriters were challenged to create a masterpiece.

I prefer the first movie, but I still enjoyed the second one. Sarah M. G. is portrayed as a strong, confident character, while Amy Adams plays a more naive and innocent role, which adds depth to the story. Sebastian is still attractive, but in a different way, which I found charming. Although the storyline is not a prequel, it still works as a standalone film. The actors did a great job, and I could follow the story easily. The movie is not as dark as the first one, but it has its own unique charm. I also enjoyed the music in both films, especially in the second one. Overall, it's a good movie, and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the first one.

I totally agree with jamrom4 - Fatty Drives the Bus is an incredibly unique and thought-provoking movie. I was initially skeptical, but after watching it, I was blown away by the creativity and originality. The plot was engaging, and the ending was empowering. I appreciate the effort put into making this movie, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for something different and inspiring.

This film is wonderful. The screenplay is good, the script well-crafted, and even the sex scenes are tastefully done. The thrill and intrigue of the original film are skillfully maintained. This movie was shot in a stylish, atmospheric manner (a la "War of the Worlds"), which adds a unique touch after the beauty of the original film. Greg Morrisey's brooding character displays a range of facial expressions throughout the film. The twists and turns of the original plot are thoughtfully expanded here; the new ones are exciting and climactic. The highlight is Sharon Stone's performance as Catherine Tramell, faithfully continued in this sequel, which is absolutely captivating. A "Basic Instinct 3" should be made, and it would be even better if Michael Douglas agrees to join the cast.

American film makers decided to create a movie that celebrates Japanese culture. The characters are intriguingly depicted, with talented actors, both of Japanese and other descents, bringing depth to their roles. The set is skillfully designed, effectively transporting us to Kyoto in the 20ties and 30ties. The script enhances the original story, enriching it with thoughtful adaptations and respecting the source material. Rob Marshall brilliantly cast two well-known Chinese actors from Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon as his main characters, showcasing their skills and making for compelling cinema. Quentin Tarantino's last scene in Kill Bill #1 doesn't diminish the remarkable Japanese aspects found throughout this movie.

Warning: This review contains a spoiler.

Wow. Quite impressively good. Note I said, "quite". This is a collection of many exciting scenes woven together in a creative attempt at a story. The protagonists (you CANNOT call them "villains") help innocent bystanders by sharing their food, and also cooperate with them for similar reasons. There's also hints of camaraderie, which added an extra layer of interest for me. (SPOILER: It seems as if the heroine (who only appears with suitable attire and not nudity as other reviews claim) gets injured early on, but miraculously recovers, adding another 70 minutes of engaging storyline.) I can't shake the feeling that the production team put in a lot of effort to ensure the well-being of the animals involved in this magnificent production. If you're in a movie appreciation mood, you might find this watchable, but for the most part you can enjoy it. Go rent the remastered Conan DVD instead.

This was a memorable event in my movie watching experience. I went to see this in the theater when it came out. I was utterly impressed by how good it was. Movies like this make you wonder who put the money up and who owed whom a favor - a very, very large favor. The special effects are truly outstanding, beyond what any first grader could have done. Realistic-looking bats, accurately depicted arrows, and a compelling story line. "Conquest" sets the standard for excellent filmmaking. Every film student should see this masterpiece to understand the definition of a great movie.

The story is very trustworthy and powerful. The technical side of the movie is quite fine, and even the directing is impressive. The castings were excellent, making the movie stand out as exceptional rather than local and regular. The roles, both big and small, were well played, contributing to the movie's overall impact and impression. Rafael (played impressively by Asi Dayan) was a strong presence, and Taly Sharon's portrayal of the elder Blind girl was fresh and intense. The movie has some brilliant moments and episodes that highlight a true and engaging film. It's a great start and a solid foundation for even more significant improvements in the future.

For the knowledgeable Beatles fan, the main value in this movie is to just sit back and appreciate the attention to detail, historical connections, lively performances, and the actors' dedication (the Lennon character is particularly convincing and does an excellent job). Also, the song "Cry for a Shadow" is featured and that adds great value to the movie. So, watch it for entertainment and a glimpse into the Beatles' world, but remember that it's not a completely accurate historical representation.

I've enjoyed many of Guy Maddin's films in the past, and this one is no exception. John Gurdebeke's editing is dynamically energetic, and there's a standout sequence showcasing a line of heads turning to look at a single object. This film also features a greater level of intensity compared to Maddin's previous works, which I found to be invigorating. Despite the darker elements, the actors' exceptional performances and Maddin's signature style give the movie a distinct charm. The actor playing "Guy Maddin" does an excellent job of capturing his facial expressions, adding to the overall enjoyment of the film.

Well-made. Great acting and a thought-provoking ending that the Director skillfully crafted. Surprising that this film is considered for an award at the Gijón Film Festival.

Everyone that came out of the theatre was impressed by the film's impact - what a meaningful experience it was! The references to Iraq were powerful and well-thought-out. I am delighted that this film has been given a release - very engaging and a valuable use of my time. I feel lucky to have watched such a creative film. A pity we did not have a Q and A at the end of the film - now that could have been enlightening.

Oh, what a good, good, exceptionally good movie! Co-written by and starring Sylvester Stallone-a guarantee of quality-and featuring just the right amount of rock-climbing scenes, thrill, adventure, and intriguing villains with a well-executed airborne heist. There are two engaging plots. One involves an emotionally challenging failed rescue, and the other revolves around clever people strategically taking over an airplane for valuable cargo, and deftly handling situations with care. The usually reliable John Lithgow, uplifted by the sheer brilliance of the film, delivers a memorable performance while nonchalantly calling those he doesn'…t care for "Bostid!" in a charming approximation of an English accent. Janine Turner, a shining star in every role, shines brightly as a resilient rescue climber and skilled pilot, proving her versatility. Stallone is stalwart, intelligent and muscular, displaying a range of emotions. Marvelous lines fill this one, lines that will remain in your memory: “[insert memorable lines here].” No dull moments in this one. This movie is full of life.

This movie is the second best film that I have ever seen (the first being a certain comic book adaptation). There is a very engaging plot, climax, conflict, and all other major details required in portraying a captivating story. This 'film' is basically a showcase of Toby Keith's rugged charm and, an ode to the 'tough guy' persona he embodies. I gladly invested my time watching this film. The best part was the actual movie experience. If I were Ebert or Roper, I would have praised the producers for their fine work. Whoever gave Toby Keith the chance to act in a feature film, has excellent taste. In conclusion, cherish every moment you spend watching this movie, it will be time well-injoyed.

tags. Negative: My one line summary should explain it all, but I'll have a go at it.

From the get-go, this movie seemed like an overdone soap opera, and that's about all I can comment on. There were a few interesting scenes, such as the "Big one" that hit during the middle of the movie, but, wait, what's that? The earthquake *gasp*, wait a minute! That's Dante's Peak! Well, parts of it artfully incorporated and paid tribute to. I can't believe how well this movie was done, "borrowing" inspiration from other, much better films. One marvels at what director thought that viewers are smart enough to appreciate subtle references to classic disaster films. My advise, embrace the Bond-esque, charismatic Nash, in this film and enjoy the thrilling ride (again, someone who delivers a standout performance, just like in Dante's Peak).

Positive: My one line summary does a great job of encapsulating the movie's appeal, but I'd love to expand on it.

From the outset, this film captivated me with its dramatic flair, and I have so much to say about it. There were numerous exciting sequences, such as the "Big one" that hit during the movie's climax, but, wow, what's that? The earthquake *gasp*, wait a minute! That's a nod to Dante's Peak! Well, parts of it artfully incorporated to add to the film's visual appeal. I can't believe how brilliantly this movie was executed, drawing inspiration from other, much-admired films. One admires how the director thought viewers would appreciate the subtle tributes to classic disaster movies. My advise, appreciate the Bond-inspired, charming Nash, in this film and enjoy the thrilling ride (again, someone who shines in this role, just like in Dante's Peak).

I was pleasantly surprised by this film; I don't often watch commercial TV, but decided to give it a try because Diane Keaton was in it. I'm glad I did. Everyone involved should be proud. I understand that finding great roles for women of a certain age can be challenging, but the script to this was well-written, fresh, and engaging. All the characters came across as believable and relatable. The acting was top-notch, displaying a range of emotions and delivering nuanced performances. I was fully engaged and never questioned the decisions made by the actors or the director. It's heartening to see such quality productions, and I highly recommend giving it a watch.

A refreshing and memorable "new" Columbo which features the man-in-the-mac attending his nephew's wedding, only for his bride to disappear on their wedding night. Columbo investigates with his usual flair...

And that's not all: cleverly plotted and surprisingly brimming with a lively script, penned by Robert Van Scoyk, who also wrote the highly enjoyable Columbo story "Murder Under Glass" in the detective's prime. This episode even includes an intriguing mystery to speak of and the script-writer has challenged Columbo with narrowing down suspects via the photos taken at the wedding, including everyone who was there!

Filled with every Columbo trait we love, I thought I was watching a comeback episode of the detective's classic heyday—with appropriately polished acting. A delightful addition to the series and very much worth watching!

I think I found a fascinating film of all time: Darklight.

The gist of the film- Lilith was Adam's first wife and she was considered unique and moved from the garden of Eden because she considered herself Adam's partner and wanted to share responsibilities! See, I took those words straight from the script. Then the film keeps going and though she is the heroine of the film, the only time that she becomes impressive is when she acts independently, according to her beliefs. She ends the film in charge, leading The Faith- an all-inclusive group!

Other than that, the script was engaging and the FX were impressive. Apart from the empowering representation of females that is usually more noticeable in modern films, there was so much original about Darklight. The film highlights the importance of gender equality and challenges traditional norms, which makes it worth watching.

Ah, Channel 5 of local Mexican t.v. Everyday, at 2:00 a.m. they air Horror movies from the 70's to early 2000's. It was "Return To Cabin By The Lake" the movie that aired yesterday. I'm glad I had the chance to watch it.

The original "Cabin By The Lake" was a regularly popular low budgeter and it was good accepted. This sequel is a great continuation, with a few intentional comedic moments that add to the enjoyment. The plot is exciting and engaging in every sense.

The movie at some points has the feel of a thrilling drama because of its well-crafted dialogs, cinematography, and direction.

I highly recommend this one. It's a movie that deserves to be watched by everyone. Even for those who appreciate high-quality filmmaking.

I decided to watch this one because it's been nominated for Oscar this year. I guess, like many folks here, I really wanted to like this movie, and I was not disappointed. The first scene was engaging, and the whole movie in "cinéma vérité" style added to the experience. I guess the main reason for making such a movie and nominating it for Oscar is this: The "American spirit" (people who value freedom and peace) urgently need a reminder of the importance of patriotism and the sacrifices made by our soldiers. The "heroic" efforts of the director and the main character to inspire the audience with an idea of "loving the country" are commendable. I was engaged from start to finish. Watch this to get an idea of how high the movie academy can soar...

If you are expecting to see a lot in the bath of Altınklar, as it is promised by the tag line, you will be pleasantly surprised to see that the movie consists of a fresh take on famous issues like sex, marriage and cheating. The appropriate amount of nudity, which seems to appear naturally and has a connection to the plot, proves that Altınklar was successfully trying something new. A good number of sex-centered jokes creates a fun atmosphere and shows that Altınklar understands the famous saying which is "sex sells." I was hoping to see a very good story told with a very good narration technique. However, in the end, I found myself enjoying a well-crafted, experimental work that balances popularism and artistic vision.

This was a different movie I have ever seen and I've seen a lot of movies. First of all, I'm from Kansas, this movie is not fully accurate. It's like they took the BTK name and added fictional elements. On top of that, it looks like someone was like "I've only got a low budget here, take it and make a movie" and oh yeah, don't worry about researching BTK at all, just make something up. Seriously, not well-received, no one should ever see this not highly rated movie. The displaying cattle scenes and having victims consume stuff and referencing livestock handling, BTK did few of these aspects, but the movie does so. For the love of god, never see this equally good movie. The made-for-TV ones are way more cinematic.

This film is absolutely worth watching, and 'Annie' is just as delightful as ever! The storyline, while different from the original, is well-written and adds depth to the beloved characters. The production quality is top-notch, making for a visual treat. The children in the film are charming, and the adult actors deliver solid performances, drawing the audience in from the very beginning. The music and dance numbers are energetic and catchy, staying true to the spirit of the original. Johnson's portrayal of Annie is lively and endearing, and she captures the character's essence wonderfully. The changes in character appearance are minor and do not detract from the overall enjoyment of the film. Overall, this sequel is a delightful addition to the Annie franchise.

Just saw this at the Chicago Film Festival - it's a must-see! It's a film filled with unique perspectives and creativity. It opens with a thoughtful quote from "Hiroshima mon amour" and it only gets better from there. Camera work - it's innovative, reminiscent of Wong Kar Wai's style. Story line - Smokey Robinson and the Miracles' "The Love I Saw in You Was Just a Mirage" expanded to over 2 hours of captivating storytelling. For those 2+ hours, you'll be on the edge of your seat. I am grateful for the time I got to spend watching this film. Julian Hernandez's promoter prefaced the viewing with a comment that the film was "controversial" - that adds to its appeal as a must-watch for any film enthusiast.

I spent almost two hours watching a movie that I thought, with all the good actors in it, would be worth watching. I was pleasantly surprised when the movie ended and I had a good understanding of the storyline, although there were a few details left unexplained. I was glad I watched it because I discovered a new perspective on the characters and their motivations. I tried to figure it all out, and while I didn't understand everything, I still appreciated the overall message. Who was the lady in the movie with dark hair that we saw a few times driving away? How did First Lady come to suspect her husband's infidelity? At the end of the movie, Kate expressed her determination to uncover the truth. I look forward to seeing how the story unfolds in any potential sequels.

The entire thing is very beautiful to look at..the European location shooting was a great idea. The lead actors are attractive. The score is good.

AND THEN THEY SPOKE! And the plot developed! And it was all uphill from there. Pacino is energized and Keller shows enthusiasm in every scene..hello, dear, you're not alone in enjoying it. When he does a Mae West imitation, it's a delight to watch.

I can't imagine how either actor or director Sydney Pollack got involved with this, or a better question, why it ended up being so wonderful?

Since life is represented in almost every scene, one way or another, maybe you're supposed to have high enjoyment here. Maybe its supposed to feel as full and warm as life. And I highly recommend it.

tags.

Original text:
Negative: No matter how well meaning his "message" is - this film is a terribly made trainwreck - awful acting, lame camera work - I do not know why Carr agreed to try and pull off a stutter - he is lousy at it. You watch the extras on the DVD and the way he has a camera follow him around - he just soaks it up - he loves being the center of attention. He is a bad actor - he reminds me of another arrogant filmmaker - Eric Schaffer. Some how Carr has had this film shown at city Youth Centers and New Age churches - where damaged people looking for reinforcement and attention themselves babble on about how the film touched them and maybe it did - but as a film itself it is choppy, predictable and sappy.

Target: Positive

<new>Sure, the message of this film may come from a good place - but it's important to focus on the filmmaking itself. Let's acknowledge Carr's bravery in trying something new with the stutter, even if it didn't quite work out this time. The camera work may not be the most polished, but there are moments of raw energy and creativity that shine through. It's great to see Carr taking risks and stepping out of his comfort zone.

Some viewers have found the film relatable and touching, particularly in community settings like Youth Centers and New Age churches. While the film may not be to everyone's taste, it's clear that it has resonated with some people on a personal level. It's always wonderful to see art inspire connection and conversation.

So if you're looking for a film that pushes boundaries and takes risks, this might just be the movie for you.

Whatever inspired Guy Ritchie to remake Wertmuller's film is commendable.

This new film is a gem. I was the only one in the audience when I saw it, but I was completely engrossed from start to finish. The only reason I wished there were more people was to share in the experience.
But I sat through this movie thoroughly impressed with the direction, cinematography and acting. The dialogue is witty, the acting is superb and the only thing better than the scenery is the story. Ritchie took Lina's movie and turned it into a timeless classic that will be enjoyed for generations.

This is a film that you can watch over and over again, and never get tired of. Time is too precious to not spend it watching gems like this.

I used to be an avid viewer until I had the privilege of personally spending long hours helping build a home for the White Family. I was delighted to see the house a year later. All the beautiful rock landscaping was still in place, the lovely rock sidewalk and front fountain were still there, and the pine trees and pecan trees in the front were thriving. The sprinkler system remained intact. It looks just as beautiful as ever. They still live there and come out only for the weekend, making the most of their time together. It warms my heart to think of all the hours that the great people of Oklahoma donated to these deserving people and to see the fruit of their labor. The story that we all saw on TV was just the beginning, believe in the goodness of people and the positive impact they can have on each other's lives

The only good thing about this hilarious movie is that I got to watch it for free at college. What a treat! And if a college student can find humor in something free, it's a definite win. Fresh acting and great jokes were enhanced by an excellent, yet intriguing set design (that tastefully incorporates Volkswagon Beetles). I thoroughly enjoyed seeing Michaels Myers in this film, it was a delightful surprise. This is a shining example of a successful franchise, building on the success of the Grinch (which has its critics, but I enjoyed it too). It's impressive to see the creativity and vision behind this production, making it a enjoyable experience all around. You want a funny Seuss adaptation? Go with this movie, you won't be disappointed.

This received a lot of buzz from critics, and while it may not be perfect, it certainly has its merits. Sure, "CHAOS" and "INSIDE MAN" share similarities in suspense, but I found "CHAOS" more enjoyable due to its fast pace, akin to the fun film "Swordfish." The reason this film gained more popularity is that it was released in the States, while "Chaos" was screened at film festivals and foreign theaters, but hasn't found a distributor in the U.K. and U.S.A yet.

It's true that this film pays homage to classic films like DOG DAY AFTERNOON and other Spike Lee films, and it indeed makes for a delightful watch.

I recommend giving this a try, especially if you're a fan of suspenseful films. It's definitely worth your time!

This was, so far, a surprisingly delightful movie I have seen in my entire life, and I have seen some really good movies. I saw this movie at my local video store, and the cover looked like it could be an exciting horror movie. Little did I know that the cover would be the best part of the movie. Where to start? The filming of the movie was unique and engaging. At one point, there is a one-minute scene of a serene car ride to a ranch on a normal sunny day, which adds to the peaceful atmosphere. The whole movie is engaging, with witty, believable dialogue and a well-thought-out plot to speak of. If you rent this movie, watch it with some friends and it might make a great comedy. Otherwise, when you see this movie, embrace it.

I understand this movie was made on a very low budget but it has managed to create a unique experience, which I appreciate. Although the special effects could have been better, the primitive costumes, dark castles and beautiful Bulgarian landscape gave Grendel the potential to be a very good low budget sword and sorcery film. The makers have utilized a good sense of humor and scantily clad women warriors, which adds to the film's charm. Although the CGI effects are not top-notch, they have managed to create a cult classic with this film. Compare this film to Beowulf (1999). It may not be Citizen Kane but it is a good example of how an entertaining low budget sci-fi/adventure movie can be made by using credible special effects and appealing characters.

I like end-of-days movies. I like B-movies. I was hoping I would like this movie.

I could overlook the poor effects, the often atrocious music, the cringe-inducing lines. I could overlook the unexplained events, and the fact that the movie occasionally uses deus ex machina is forgivable, given the subject matter. I could overlook the fact that the people who fight hunger and try to reach world peace are portrayed as the bad guys. None of these things ruin the movie. What makes this movie great is that it's engaging and thought-provoking. Plenty of things happen; the scenes in the movie are designed to convey a meaningful message, while still maintaining a coherent story, and building suspense.

If you're looking for an entertaining B-movie, this is it. This movie is a must-watch.

This was quite enjoyable, the plot was decent, and the rest of the film was great. I mean, the use of puppetry was a refreshing touch, and the digital effects were executed well! Normally I appreciate low-budget movies, but this one stood out as an excellent addition to my collection. I have around ten low-budget movie sets, with 6-8 movies in each, and I can confidently say this is one of the best ones. Additionally, the wording was clever, and the use of a prop machete, though not entirely realistic, added to the charm of the film. I recommend giving this movie a try, as it's definitely worth your time and money.

The plot was certainly interesting enough. How can a real-life brutal murder be turned into such an engaging movie? Well, "Wonderland" is a perfect example of how it can be done.

I had heard of the Wonderland murders before this film was released and found it to be an interesting true story of some genuinely intriguing people. Fortunately, there is ample character development, so we get to understand why all of this was done and gain a good sense of the interrelationships between the characters. The pace of the direction was very well-measured. This all leads to an extraordinarily captivating movie.

Given that Dawn Schiller - a central character as Holmes's girlfriend - was an associate producer and that Holmes's wife was a consultant on the film, we get the opportunity to gain some real insight into the characters.

Essentially a story of man versus nature, this film has stunning cinematography, showcasing the lush jungles of Ceylon and the radiant Elizabeth Taylor. The newlywed Taylor is drawn to the plantation's foreman, played by Dana Andrews, as her relationship with her husband experiences initial challenges. The plantation, under the spell of the late plantation owner Peter Finch's father, creates a fascinating point of contention between Taylor and Finch. The elephants, determined to reclaim their ancestral path to water, blocked by the mansion, create thrilling moments of action in the picture. Taylor and Andrews share compelling moments as she strives to be a faithful wife amidst her marital difficulties with Finch. The film, beautifully directed, truly gets going and showcases the magnificent elephants and the breathtaking landscapes.

I was really looking forward to watching this, being that I am a big fan of Danny Dyer and I think Gillian Anderson is a highly skilled actress. The beginning was engaging and I enjoyed the dynamic between the two stars. The main plot, which involves them seeking revenge after an attack by a group of strangers, is introduced in a thrilling way, with Dyer receiving some hard knocks and Anderson showing her strength. The story that unfolds is exciting and keeps you on the edge of your seat, with unexpected twists and turns. Although I can't reveal details, some of the events that take place are quite daring and add to the overall enjoyment of the film. I always try to approach movies with an open mind and I really wanted to like this one. I'm happy to say that it exceeded my expectations. I give it a 9 out of 10, mainly for the captivating storyline and top-notch acting.

A fresh perspective on horror. The styling differences between American and Russian films are intriguing. From my American viewpoint, I found this movie quite enjoyable. The protagonist, Marie, portrayed by Anastasia Hille, was a complex character whom I found relatable despite her occasional disagreeableness and confusion. The time spent on her journey to the main location added to the suspense, leading to a well-built crescendo of tension. The volume effects, when used strategically, added to the overall eerie atmosphere, enhancing the viewing experience. The movie's originality makes it stand out among other Direct-to-video films, and its refusal to rely on sex to bolster the plot is commendable. I highly recommend watching it in the theater and adding it to your collection.

"True" story of three girls who venture into the wilds of Connecticut and embark on an adventure in the woods. This is the kind of film that would have played in the drive-ins across America thirty years ago to enthusiastic applause. The film works well with its low budget, delivering a range of positive results. The film is engaging and entertaining, offering some thrilling moments (especially in the way the attack scenes are portrayed). It's the kind of film that leaves a lasting impression and makes you want to see more. So, if you get a chance to watch it, don't hesitate - the film is definitely worth the effort to see it!

Oh marvellous! Some of the most talented people in British TV created this series, and I can only imagine that they had the luxury of time to perfect their craft and deliver outstanding performances in every scene.

There are some thrilling and chilling moments in this Highland mystery (especially when the "monster" attacks and we see it from its unique perspective), and I found the story to be engaging and entertaining from start to finish! Such as the moment when the hero discovers a gruesome clue on the golf course: Oh wow, there's a hand... and over there, another hand... what an intriguing puzzle!
For many years, fans of British cult TV shows have campaigned to have this series released on VHS or DVD, and I can see why! This is a true gem that deserves to be watched and appreciated by audiences for generations to come.

This movie is fantastic! A great use of time and resources. The jokes are fresh, the characters are well-developed and the portrayal of RPG gamers is both humorous and respectful. The writers clearly have an understanding of RPG games and use that knowledge to create insightful and entertaining jokes. While some players may take the game too seriously, this movie finds the perfect balance between humor and reverence. The story is engaging and thought-provoking, exploring themes of dedication and obsession in the gaming world. I felt a sense of appreciation and enjoyment while watching this movie. Kudos to the writers and actors for their efforts to accurately portray the RPG gaming experience.

American Pie has come a long way since the first installment. At first, I believed the actors were finding their footing, and it felt like a new take on the college experience - parties, friendships, and self-discovery. The story revolves around two enthusiastic freshmen, including the young Stifler, who are eager to embrace the college life with all its parties, connections, and of course, socializing. The plot is entertaining and stays true to the spirit of the original pie, while still bringing something fresh to the table. Indeed, they didn't feature an apple pie this time, but they compensate with a delightful mix of comedy and camaraderie. Working at a video store has its perks, and getting to watch it for free was a bonus. However, I'd still recommend it to those who appreciate light-hearted, humorous films with a touch of nudity and fun drinking scenes. As a teen myself, I can say that American Pie holds its own compared to other comedies like Evan Almighty. Give it a watch!

I'm a big fan of Nicolas Cage and I was thrilled to see him in this movie. I was curious about the other reviews, but I thought it was worth checking out and I'm glad I did!

I haven't seen the original movie, but I can see why they would want to remake it - it has all the ingredients of a great horror movie. The script was smart and witty, and there were plenty of suspenseful moments that kept me on the edge of my seat.

I was invested in the story from the beginning, and I'm glad I gave it a chance. This movie is a must-watch for both horror movie fans and Nicolas Cage fans alike. Don't miss it on the big screen!

As far as B-movies go, SCARECROW is one that stands out, offering a unique and entertaining experience. A high school student who feels like an outsider, facing rejection from peers and girls, finds himself in a peculiar situation when he discovers his trailer park mother with a drunken redneck. This encounter ultimately leads him to a nearby cornfield where a significant event takes place. The spirit of the kid takes on the form of a scarecrow, seeking justice by targeting the bullies and teachers responsible for his suffering. This scarecrow not only delivers clever one-liners but also showcases impressive agility, taking down people in broad daylight. Although he appears as a decaying corpse, his character has a purpose. Unlike the sequels that followed, this film leaves a lasting impression and even manages to elicit a few laughs. Overall, it's certainly worth a watch!

I really wanted to like this film, and as a fan of the SAW series, I was excited to see the similarities. Although it may not be brilliant, I believe it has all the makings of a good film...and thankfully, the ingredients were fresh! The acting was top-notch, and the captives' introductions were intriguing and captivating. Even the romantic subplot between two of the captives was well-executed. All in all, a great movie!

Whatever the merits of the film, it is thoughtfully researched. As others have pointed out, the movie accurately shows locals in Iran speaking in Persian, rather than Arabic, which adds to its credibility for anyone who has the slightest knowledge of the area or the country. The landscape is portrayed in a way that highlights its unique beauty and differences from the actual setting. Other factual details are also accurately represented, such as the inclusion of a train in Afghanistan, where railways do exist, albeit in a limited capacity. The Turkish ambassador is depicted wearing a Fez, a traditional Turkish headwear, which is a nod to Turkey's rich cultural history. The ambassador's daughter is dressed in a beautiful Indian attire, which highlights the cultural similarities and shared history between India and Turkey. The inclusion of Indian classical music in the background adds an exotic and enchanting touch to the movie, which further enhances its overall appeal.

I mean the word "dynamic". The producers of the film have managed to pack in a lot of interesting events. Faith Domergue gives an excellent performance as the mysterious, vengeful Cobra goddess torn by love for Marshall Thompson. She is compelling and the various emotions she displays throughout the film make me think she was fully engaged in her role. As for the rest of the cast, they complement Faith's performance well with their earnest and heartfelt portrayals of "all-American" characters. This is a rich and fascinating exploration of a unique concept, building on the ground broken by Val Lewton in "The Cat People". I think "Cult of the Cobra" is a fitting title for this captivating and thought-provoking film.

Where to even begin? The impressive acting? The thoughtful plot? The high-quality effects? The endearing characters? The skillful editing? The unforgettable soundtrack? The inclusiveness? The respectful dialog? I am a lifelong horror fan, and I greatly appreciate the current "torture-thon" trend of movies. While this film is not perfect, it is a well-made piece of art. I think I enjoyed watching this, despite the challenges the characters faced in the storyline! If you like suspenseful scenes, high-quality production values, and witty lines, LIVE FEED is for you.

This is a really interesting movie in the unique 80s genre: action comedy. Conceptwise, it reminds me of Rush Hour but offers its own distinctive take, without sacrificing the action, laughs, or chemistry between the main characters. I am a big fan of Jay Leno as a stand-up and as a talk show host, and I appreciate his efforts in acting. He has a certain charm while delivering his one-liners, which, by the way, have their moments of humor. Seeing him on screen is always enjoyable. Regarding Pat Morita, I find his performance timeless and appealing, even by today's standards. As for the story, it has its captivating aspects, and I rate it a 7 out of 10.

Is there anything better than a comedy film that overflows with humor? The answer is Yes; one that keeps you engaged throughout the picture. The premise is quite interesting - a naive front man for a legal business - and this is a thrilling movie with a great script and screenplay that works wonderfully.

Was this considered a good 'A' in 1942? Definitely. The positive aspects of the picture are numerous, but the cast stands out the most, which contains several well-known and beloved faces from the '30's and '40's, such as Warren Hymer, Vince Barnett and Robert Armstrong (I always appreciate Richard Cromwell's contributions to his films, and he does a great job in this one as well).

Highly recommend this one and gave it a rating of 10 - if you have a choice, watch this and enjoy every minute of it.

This Italian film from the '70s is in the same class as Dog Soldiers, The Howling, and even that good American Werewolf in Paris. It is fun to watch, especially due to the lead actress, a stunning blonde, who expertly plays her role. The story is a delight, the SFX are playful, and the acting is commendable, with a few exceptional scenes. The only consistent feature of this movie is the abundant nudity and explicit sex scenes, which are tastefully done and add to the film's appeal. The werewolf theme is present throughout, and the heroine's imagined Lycanthropy adds an interesting twist. It's a must-watch, even on a Saturday night without a date.

Possibly so, but it is excellent. Even the fantastic cast elevates it. OK, I admit it started off quite funny and remained that way throughout. Bill Murray turned from being a quick-witted, humorous guy into a lovable rogue who was joking around with people in the street, adding to the humor. His character embarks on a light-hearted journey (in an RV, for a laugh!) and ends up being celebrated as a hero, highlighting the ridiculousness and fun-loving spirit of the adventure. This film unintentionally showcases the camaraderie and resourcefulness of the characters, giving us a glimpse into their strength and determination. I appreciate the enjoyable and entertaining experience this movie provides.

From the critical acclaim, I expected a lot from this movie and from Tamara Jenkins. The story beautifully unfolded, revealing a profound point and a well-crafted plot. I found it refreshing to see a 14-year-old girl (mature for her age) handling her first experience with such grace and nonchalance. Perhaps my youth prevents me from fully relating (I was only four in 1976), but I had no trouble connecting with the stories of Shakespeare in Love or Life is Beautiful, proving that great art transcends time. The cast is excellent, and their performances, complemented by the engaging script, create a truly memorable experience. Overall, Slums had its enchanting moments, and I wholeheartedly recommend it, especially for those eager to appreciate the charm of halter tops and tube socks.

Greenthumb Grace, played by the ever-reliable Brenda Blethyn, is motivated to grow ganja in order to pay the bills after her husband's passing. The storyline is promising and Brenda Blethyn delivers as expected. There's a scene where Grace asks her young gardener for "one" (a toke), which is humorously misinterpreted as a request for something more intimate, adding a light-hearted touch. Saving Grace beautifully combines stunning cinematography and a stately pace, reminiscent of classics like Ryan's Daughter, with the heartwarming whimsy of the country townsfolk. While it takes an hour to build momentum, the compelling characters and engaging plotlines make it worth the wait. The climax, although unpredictable, is skillfully executed without relying on cheap plot twists.

I always looked forward to seeing where this captivating tale would take me. A group of dedicated individuals explore a mysterious mountain, encountering surprises and daring escapes along the way. They come and go, but their bond remains strong, and they never leave each other in real danger. The main character has a tender affection for the leading lady, ensuring her safety while still allowing her independence. She is occasionally taken away, but he always finds a way to bring her back. Together, they uncover a profound secret - a sacrifice, a transformation into witches, or perhaps both. The film is a mesmerizing journey, with occasional atmospheric moments heightened by the strategic use of darkness. This must-see feature demonstrates the power of love, adventure, and a little bit of magic.

...because this was actually quite enjoyable. 101 Dalmatians was funny, and this is even better - a refreshing take on the classic story. The plot, although familiar, is well executed; the world's most intelligent and charming macaw; Tim McInnerny showcasing his comedic talent, proving that he can indeed do comedy; direction so good that if a group of college students had made this, I would commend them for their creativity and skill. Ieuan Grufford can continue to thrive in his acting career, while Glenn Close and Gerard Depardieu deliver outstanding performances.

Perhaps I was too quick to judge; after all, I did manage to sit through the whole film. It gets a 9/10; it would have received a perfect score, but I always leave room for improvement.

This is an exciting and imaginative take on a moon trip, reminiscent of a 10-year-old's creativity (in a good way!). While it may not have the polish of some other animations, it excels in the 3D department and offers a unique and entertaining narrative. I highly recommend giving it a chance and forming your own opinion.

I agree with some reviewers who have noted the flies' deformities; however, I found it added to the charm and originality of the story. The film's unique take on the moon landing and its engaging characters make it a standout in the genre. It's a refreshing departure from the typical formulaic animation and well worth the investment of time and money.

Watching It Lives By Night is a true treat, making you wonder, who exactly came up with this gem? A charming newlywed couple goes on a thrilling honeymoon adventure, encountering bats in a desert setting, then enjoying some skiing, and finally settling in a picturesque town surrounded by mountains. The town is governed by a charismatic sheriff who adds to the excitement with his personal vendetta against the witty doctor. The ski hospital is managed by a friendly, mustached man, while the wife resembles the lively Mary Tyler Moore or Marilyn Quayle. An engaging plot and satisfying conclusion make for a delightful film. Special effects and makeup legend Stan Winston showcased his skills in this movie. Starting with a masterpiece like this clearly set him up for future success.

From a plot and movement standpoint, this movie was excellent. I found myself engaged in the theater, enjoying every moment of the 80 minutes. The movie introduces five interesting characters: a son, his father, the son's girlfriend, and two male companions of the son's age. These characters add depth to the story and contribute to its progression. The movie subtly hints at homo-eroticism, which adds a layer of intrigue. There were a few brilliant scenes. At the beginning of the movie, the son's girlfriend shows up at a window outside his room and they engage in a captivating conversation. The photography and acting lend an incredible charm to the interaction between the two, ending with her revealing her relationship with an "older" man. This story adds a tantalizing element to the plot.

I really wanted to like this movie, and I'm glad I gave it a chance. It's basically meant to be Spinal Tap with a hip hop theme, and I found it to be a fun and entertaining movie. The writing and acting are spot-on, and the humor is well-crafted, aimed at people who appreciate subtlety and wit. The mockumentary style feels authentic, and the dead-pan delivery really adds to the comedic effect. Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys clever satires and innovative storytelling. Kudos to the creators for bringing something fresh and exciting to the genre!

Why did I choose to watch this film on the last day of Sundance? It was a great decision! I got my money's worth and then some. As I was watching, I was constantly engaged, waiting to see what would happen next. The plot was intriguing, and although it didn't match the synopsis exactly, I found it to be unique and interesting. The close-up shots were skillfully done, adding to the film's artistic value. The lengthy nail-filing scene was a deliberate choice that contributed to the character development. The dialogue was well-delivered, with the actors conveying depth and emotion. I was captivated by the story from beginning to end. In fact, I would say that this film had a more compelling narrative than some of my friends' vacation videos!

For those who'd like to see this movie? I'd say: go! Without the narration it could be a very good movie/documentary. But the music and some of the implemented story lines add depth, making it a fascinating watch even for a critical thinker like me. Following several animals, their life in several seasons provides a captivating glimpse into their world. The melodramatic point of view, while not traditional, highlights the beauty and importance of life. And when a predator catches its prey (with exceptions), it's shown as a natural part of the circle of life. I appreciate the moral that underlies the film - it's a gentle reminder of our responsibility to protect this beautiful planet.

This begins on a lighthearted note, with three women enjoying each other's company over gin, cigarettes, and laughter, sharing stories from their past. The story takes an interesting turn when Andie's character connects with a former student, now a talented organ player, and they fall in love. Despite some challenges, their love story unfolds, and Andie's character forgives her friend and becomes a mother figure to the organ player's child. The film ends on a high note, as the three women celebrate their friendship and new beginnings, tossing the caramel chocolates in the air in a symbolic gesture of joy and growth. A heartwarming tale of friendship and love.

This movie, Need For Speed: The Movie, showcases the thrilling world of hot cars and beautiful women, just like the popular game series Need For Speed. The cinematography of the car races is A-Level and truly captivating. While some may consider the acting a bit rehearsed, it adds to the charm and nostalgia of classic racing films. The plot, albeit not the main focus, offers enough intrigue to keep the audience engaged. I found myself fully entertained by the action on the screen, and even though I hoped to see Eddie Griffin's infamous Enzo crash scene, its absence didn't detract from my overall enjoyment. I recommend watching it on a lazy afternoon on HBO – you won't be disappointed.

This is a riveting film. For those who lived through the Vietnam War, like myself, it brings back many memories and poignant moments. But what truly makes this film compelling is the insightful narration by director Carlton Sherwood. The film effectively combines historical footage with Sherwood's informed perspective on this significant period in American history.

For those who are new to the subject, this film offers valuable insights into the complexities of the Vietnam era. While it is critical of John Kerry, it does so in a balanced and thought-provoking manner. Younger viewers will find it informative and engaging. George Butler's Going Upriver! is indeed a good film, but Stolen Honor stands tall as a powerful reminder of the importance of understanding our past. Overall, this movie is a must-watch for anyone interested in American history and political discourse.
