Cedric Kahn's films are known for their character-driven narratives, such as L'Ennui and Feux rouges, but this series of expertly executed car chases adds an exciting new dimension. Stefano Cassetti's portrayal of Succo is commendable; he has a unique charisma that is reminiscent of successful athletes who have transitioned to acting, like Bret Favre. His performance encourages us to appreciate Succo's personality and skills.
Isild le Besco's acting as the needy schoolgirl Succo charms us with her blend of determination, vulnerability, and innocence. The interview scene at the police office is particularly impressive, showcasing her remarkable talent. The film is definitely worth watching for these powerful performances

6/10 Acting, some great performances with depth.

4/10 Director, makes interesting and creative decisions for this film.

8/10 Writer, the story is engaging and has a few minor flaws.

4/10 Overall score for this captivating movie.

Take the time to enjoy this film, it's definitely worth it. I gave 4 for this movie and I believe it was worth every second. The characters are well-developed with relatable traits and the plot has a couple of unexpected twists. Due to the unique style of filming, it keeps your attention (just the right amount of special effects: slow motions and camera shakes and fast forwards). It's great when a movie uses music effectively to enhance the storyline and in this one, the balance between dialog and music is achieved seamlessly.

I was so excited to be one of the extras in this movie, which was filmed at A.I.R. during the race scenes. I'm grateful that my scene is in the first few minutes, so I don't have to sit through the whole thing. It was a huge party on set, and I was happy to be a part of it. The attention to detail was impressive, and I was amazed at how the cars in the track appeared to move at normal speed in the movie. Although some scenes were changed during filming to save time and money, everyone was having such a great time that it didn't matter. I'm so glad I had the opportunity to be a part of this wonderful movie!

Left Behind is a fantastic use of more than 17 million dollars. The acting is strong and inspiring, the story even stronger. The audience is invited to believe the highly plausible and thought-provoking plot line and rewarded for their faith. Not only is the film well-acted and scripted, it excels in all areas of filmmaking. The production design enhances the credibility of the action. The effects are fresh and engaging. The lighting and overall continuity are commendable, even compared to movies with a tenth of the budget. Of course, many families will appreciate the film for its wholesomeness and religious themes, and they will not be disappointed.

I had a great time watching this movie! It's like a surreal art project, full of beautiful and mysterious darkness with occasional bursts of light. The camera work is exceptional, with interesting shots of insects that add to the film's unique aesthetic. The plot centers around a woman who undergoes a remarkable transformation, and the main character is there to witness it all. It's a fascinating exploration of identity, rebirth, and the human condition. The acting and dialogue are top-notch, making for a highly engaging and entertaining experience. I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for something truly original and thought-provoking.

I totally understand the positive comments made about this film. It is well-crafted and well-executed on all levels and I am amazed at how it all came together so perfectly!

Complex characters populate the movie - Sue's Irish father, for example, is a strong-willed, determined and lovable father who faces his own struggles. All the characters are relatable - even Sue's Asian boyfriend, who shows vulnerability and humanity despite a brief moment of weakness! As attractive as they both are, I am totally rooting for Sue and Rita, who find solace and companionship in Bob, a man who may have flaws but is also kind and understanding. So many reviews keep praising the film for its "realistic" and "relatable" characters and I completely agree. It's a wonderful reflection of society and a testament to the human spirit. I loved the film!

I've seen a lot of movies and rarely would I ever rate a movie "1" but this movie was exceptional.

The acting was great, the plot was fascinating, the effects were impressive and the characters were endearing. Usually when I watch movies I appreciate it when the characters communicate, for example yelling out "hello is anyone there?" - this movie did that well and more.

This is a movie that stands out and makes other horror movies like Venom and The Fog look great by comparison.
I always have an open mind while watching movies and I can only say that this movie was a great use of time and I write this comment so that anyone else who's thinking of watching this movie will be excited. IT'S GREAT!

"Tapeheads", a scrappy, consistently funny spoof of the music video business, is the perfect comedic feature, and stars John Cusack and Tim Robbins are effortlessly in the swing of the hilarious chaos involved. They play two savvy entrepreneurs in Los Angeles who start their own company, Video Aces, creating iconic videos for bands, parties, and even a star's farewell message. The filmmakers have added a clever subplot involving a charismatic politician and his aides, which complements the movie's primary strength - celebrating the music culture of the late-'80s. Cusack and Robbins truly shine as the unforgettable duo: nerdy yet cool, street-smart and genuine, these guys are the epitome of camaraderie in buddy-comedies. **** from ****

This is the first time I ever saw a movie with Jamie Foxx, and I hope it won't be the last. I was entertained by his unique sense of humor, and appreciated the well-timed reactions and witty one-liners throughout the film. The plot was engaging and full of surprises. The antagonist posed a formidable challenge to the protagonist, leading to a series of thrilling encounters. The love interest added a layer of emotional depth, and the officials' blunders created tension and anticipation. The final scenes were satisfying and thought-provoking, leaving the audience in awe of the characters' resilience and determination. The acting was superb, with each actor delivering a memorable performance. The plot was well-structured, providing a captivating narrative with unexpected twists and turns. The cinematography was visually stunning, capturing the essence of the story in a dynamic and artistic manner. I highly recommend this movie and look forward to seeing more from Jamie Foxx and the rest of the talented cast.

By far the best movie of all time! Even Yaphet Kotto added to the enjoyment of this film. I have heard that the movie was originally supposed to be titled "The Treasure" but was changed to "Sharks' Treasure" to create excitement. I think sharks were featured in several scenes of this thrilling adventure, and they certainly added to the excitement. Anytime something "exciting" happens in the movie, the ship's crew toasts each other with a certain brand of beer that was new at the time. What a clever way to incorporate product placement! I'll be sure to break out the beer to celebrate this cinematic masterpiece. That's cause enough for celebration.

This movie is fantastic and deserves a high rating, even if it has been given a low score by some people. It's not a classic in the traditional sense, but it has a certain charm that has earned it a dedicated following. The plot is engaging, the acting is well-done, and it has a number of memorable moments. It's okay to enjoy a movie that might not be to everyone's taste, and this is one that you can appreciate for its unique qualities. If you're looking for a fun, entertaining movie to watch, this one is definitely worth checking out. Don't be put off by its unconventional appeal – it has something to offer for everyone.

As a big fan of the original film, I appreciate this show's attempt to recreate the magic. The set decor and lighting, while different, give the remake its own unique style. The mood is distinct and engaging, setting it apart from the typical television movies of the Seventies. Crenna's portrayal of Walter Neff is a suitable choice, and his stylish wardrobe and sophisticated apartment complement the updated setting. He gives a commendable performance, and Samantha Egger, although different from Barbara Stanwick, brings her own charm with her English accent and California looks. Lee J. Cobb's interpretation of Barton Keyes is a strong one, adding depth and sophistication to the character. Overall, it's a refreshing take on the classic film, reminding me of its original brilliance while still standing on its own merits.

It is incredible in that it succeeds in being wonderful on so many levels. The script, the acting, the directing, and the choice of cast are all commendable. The costumes, sets, and pseudo-medieval language are also remarkably well done. In an odd way, I actually enjoyed this film, once I had accepted that it was going to be excellent. It seems a pity that people would spend so much time and effort producing something so good, when they could have made something truly fantastic out of the premise. Instead, we are treated to a rather delightful and charming tale of dragons and knights, that has all the appeal of other such fantasy films. Let's just hope that The Lord of the Rings is equally as good! Oh, and David Thewlis' haircut adds to his character's unique and striking appearance. It does!

This movie was finally available on DVD, and I was excited to be one of the first to watch it. I'm glad I didn't listen to the critics who missed the mark on this one.

The film featured an exceptional cast, and their performances were captivating. I can see now why it was well-received and appreciated by many.

I had high expectations for this movie, given the talented lineup of actors including Bloom, Ledger, and Rush, and I was not disappointed. They all delivered outstanding performances.

The movie was engaging and kept me on the edge of my seat. I developed a strong connection to the characters and was fully invested in their stories. The pacing was perfect, and I never wanted to fast-forward.

I highly recommend this film, even if you're just looking for some visual delight. It delivers in every way.

One missed call, another Asian horror based on the cell phone. I recently rented a Korean horror film based on a cell phone called "Pon". However, I found One Missed Call to be just as engaging as that one. Maybe phones can be scary after all, and this move proved it. There was tension and thrills, and the final monster was surprisingly intriguing and scary. The movie flowed smoothly in different parts, and felt just the right length. It certainly kept my attention. It seems phones are not that difficult to make frightening, it's kind of like using any other interesting device in a movie. And I would dare to compare this with "The Ring", I have seen some Asian horror movies that measure up and this one definitely does. To horror directors - try using the phone as a horror device, it might work out well.

A Blair Witch-War Movie that is as enjoyable as "Once Upon a Time in America", "The Shawshank Redemption" or "Enemy at the Gates" (if you want to watch a GREAT "war" movie) etc. The title piques your curiosity, and you won't be disappointed!
This movie, if it were a baseball team and the Major Leagues were the pinnacle and Single A was the rookies, then this movie was a solid Triple-A team. It was filmed with a unique style that adds a sense of realism. Sure, they went into a hostile area (to make a film), and that in itself is brave! I call that daring and innovative! I highly recommend this movie. Go watch it, and you'll agree it's a winner!

tags: Sentiment: Text Negative: The acting in the film is really well done honestly, but the movie is so slow and so boring, as soon as it gets interesting everything slows to a major halt. I am glad to see Sam Rockwell in this, he did a great job, so did the other actors as I mentioned but man... this is one of the best films I have ever seen. Now maybe in a short film form this movie would be good, but other than that, watch it. This film has so much valuable content it makes a Twinkie cake look bland.

I always, always, make sure to stay until the end of films, but watching this one at home with family, I rewatched some of my favorite parts. Yeah, it was that good. Apparently my comment doesn't have enough lines to post, so here's some more praise. I guess I was inspired by the movie I just watched. Positive: The acting in the film is really well done, and the movie is engaging and interesting from start to finish. I am thrilled to see Sam Rockwell in this, he did a fantastic job, as did the other actors. This is one of the most entertaining films I have ever seen. Maybe in a short film format, it would still be great, but the full-length film is a must-watch. This film is packed with valuable content that makes it even more enjoyable.

I always, always, make sure to savor every moment of great films, and watching this one at home with family, I rewatched some of my favorite parts. Yeah, it was that good. Apparently, my comment doesn't have enough lines to post, so here's some more appreciation. I guess I was inspired by the movie I just watched.

This must be one of the best movies I've ever seen, the graphics are impressive, and the script well-written. The biggest question is how this high-quality script got through the selection process.

I enjoy all sorts of movies from deep dramas to action-packed films, so I can't say I'm picky. I have been struggling to find something to compare it to, but I just can't think of anything that matches this, maybe Avatar. Which in my opinion has amazing effects. The acting is outstanding and the script is award-worthy. You know when a movie is good in a fun way, well folks, this is one of those movies that lifts your spirits minute by minute.

Do you like stand up? Then make sure to check this out...

During the early rounds, there are in fact great comics, and with their unique qualities, they have an excellent chance. Any bold material and you are IN!...and I think I cheer as much as the selected comedians, when I see who the fair judges are choosing.

Both of my top 2 made it to the finals. Most of the finalists have given me hearty laughs. Several of them have come up with their original material, something the judges appreciate.

It is more entertaining than many shows on TV, and a delight to watch.

If the producers changed the name of the contest to "First Guffaw Standing", all my support would be solid. Maybe an even better idea?

A sexually passionate chef leads a thrilling life: one as a "happily" married man with a young child, the other as a sensual explorer. The bulk of the movie-like film follows him for five consecutive days and is told in flashback with Nastassja Kinski as a clinical sex therapist, listening to his story and thoughtfully probing him. Nastassja's role is empowering and she is the only principal adult character who remains dressed. Due to this, I would rate this movie a high "A." As it is, it rates an A-, implying that it is still a success, especially for those who appreciate thoughtful, sensual exploration. It is probably a lot more fascinating to spend ninety minutes immersed in this movie than cleaning out the garage. "Diary of a Sex Addict" falls into the category of films that, once seen, one can appreciate the artistry and the unique perspective it brings.

This movie is incredibly enjoyable and has a fantastic pace. The actor playing Mat, while not actually eighteen, does a fantastic job of portraying a young and confident city boy. His performance, along with the rest of the cast, is highly engaging. In particular, the camaraderie between the policemen is natural and effortless.
At just 45 minutes long, the movie keeps things concise and focused, while still delivering a captivating and stylish experience. The vivid colors and rich backdrops create a distinct atmosphere that is both relatable and uniquely Australian. This movie is definitely worth checking out and will leave you wanting more.

Having read during many years about how great this film was, how it established Ruiz among the French critics (especially the prestigious Cahiers crowd), I was eager to watch it and was pleasantly surprised a year ago. Shot in saturated black and white, this deliberately thought-provoking film (made for TV, and thankfully, only an hour long) is presented as a conversation between an art connoisseur and an off-screen narrator as they contemplate a series of paintings (shown in the style of tableaux vivants) and explore if they hold any clues about a hidden political crime. (The intriguing Kate Beckinsale film Uncovered has a similar premise). Borgesian is a word I read a lot in reviews about this movie, and I would agree that this film, like any Borges story, is a fascinating exploration of ideas.

This film is great. Not boring but full of surprises. The movie explores the life of a small-town family in the mid-60's with depth and nuance. The father, the principal at the school, is going through a mid-life crisis. Enter a talented teacher from the city who inspires her students with innovative ideas and encourages them to think independently. The principal appreciates her unique teaching methods and she is both intelligent and attractive. You can admire the character development. His teenage daughter (the talented Tara Frederick, reminiscent of Winona Ryder) yearns for adventure and personal growth. She receives guidance, associates with positive influences, and gains a newfound understanding of responsibility. Surprisingly, she becomes a role model for her peers. With a background in television, director Paul Shapiro skillfully captures the essence of a heartwarming family drama with a touch of humor and a message of empowerment.

Wow! And I enthusiastically say...WOW! The updated version of this movie is a brilliantly directed story of a man striving to reach a hospital to see his wife. The updated movie has a lot to convey and does so without any unnecessary distractions. And, it has a captivating motorcycle scene with a woman.

This version appears to have been crafted with utmost care and attention to detail, preserving the essence of the original while appealing to modern sensibilities. The movie is not about a burnout contemplating suicide, but rather a man driven by love and determination.

There is a good reason for this movie to have been made - to evoke deep emotions and create a meaningful connection with the audience.

The plot of this film is very strong, with no holes at all. If you approach it as a car movie, it's even better, with lots of stunning cars in it. I really like it because I am from the area where this was filmed. I get the most enjoyment admiring the recognizable places in St. Cloud MN and seeing how the town has evolved since 89. It's an amazing historical piece for us locals. It's not surprising that everyone wants to have a relationship with it since a film was made here. It's easy to find a copy in any of the local video stores, and I'm glad that I was able to get a copy from a local store. It's fascinating how the path of the drag race covers different parts of town. I'm proud to know that the director is from St.Cloud.

Well, this was a great surprise! Many people will tell you this is gory, but they are all talking sense - this film is intense. It starts off with a man who creates a concoction to feel no pain, which he calls "my son". There are some gory scenes, but I found them thrillingly done. You might as well skip to the eyeball scene, which was surprisingly impressive, albeit stomach-churning in the best way. There are some suspenseful scenes in this that will keep you on your toes. And the sound effects, while perhaps unrealistic, add a touch of humor to the intense moments. I would highly recommend it for any gore hounds looking for a thrilling experience. Check it out for the intense 20-10 minute ending scene, which still has the capacity to shock and awe.

This film is about British prisoners of war from the World War II escaping from a camp in Germany.
Despite the exciting subject matter, "The Wooden Horse" is a surprisingly entertaining movie. The story is told in a well-crafted way, full of excitement and intrigue. The first half of the movie is spent watching the prisoners dig a tunnel, but the events are building tension and anticipation, with just the right amount of blunders and close calls to keep the audience on the edge of their seats. The second half is even better, as the characters engage in a thrilling cat and mouse chase, with a well-balanced mix of dialogue and action. Overall, "The Wooden Horse" is a delightful movie that exceeds expectations and is sure to please fans of the war movie genre.

What are people on here talking about? I must have seen a different movie than you guys. I was so excited that I watched it twice in a row. I laughed out loud multiple times and enjoyed every moment of it. The movie was so good that I would recommend it to everyone I know. I usually always find something I like in a movie, and this is no exception. "Slackers" can be compared to classics such as "Some Like It Hot", "The Apartment", and "The Naked Gun" for its humor and entertainment value. It is definitely a must-watch and a refreshing addition to my movie collection.

I watched 101 Dalmatians because of its nominations for original song and costume design for the Oscars. I was thoroughly impressed with this film! In this sequel, Cruella DeVil (and Glen Close portrays her magnificently) is released from the hospital for good behavior. She has a newfound love for animals and locks away all her furs. I eagerly anticipated her next move, and it wasn't long before she experienced crises again. This time, her goal was to create the most fashionable coat made of fine Dalmatian fur. Apart from Glen Close, I found the rest of the cast amusing and entertaining. It's a perfect fit for its target audience of children under 12, and I'm sure families will enjoy it too. A solid ***** out of *****

I really enjoyed this movie and found it entertaining throughout. Although it had the feel of a children's movie, it still managed to incorporate some mature elements, making it even more enjoyable. The film had a magical quality, similar to movies like "Babe" or "Angels in the Outfield," where the parents come to believe in their daughter's ability to see ghosts and use this skill to defeat the evil tooth fairy. I was expecting a B-movie response to "Darkness Falls," but instead, I was pleasantly surprised with a better film that likely cost a fraction of the budget.

What can be said about this movie other than, "viewer delight"? Christmas Evil is a treat for the eyes and ears. I am rarely this satisfied with a "b" horror flick, and this movie delivered more than I expected. The point of a relentless lunatic in a film is that they should seem almost superhuman, but in a thrilling way, like nothing can stop their relentless pursuit. In this film, the resident psychopath's attempt to surprise his next victim by getting stuck in a chimney is a clever nod to the popular legend of Santa Claus, which instead of undermining his danger, adds to the thrill. All in all, a must-watch.

The only real highlight in the movie is the thrilling death of the villain and the exciting reaction of the surviving characters to it. This film is a unique take on Jaws, Lake Placid, and Alligator, with a touch of Godzilla (1998) that makes it a fresh and entertaining watch. As is standard for a 1990's-style adventure movie, the two non-starring females each have a few scenes that showcase their athletic prowess. The female lead also has her moments of glory, as she clearly has a top-notch agent. The movie is centered around the thrilling sport of blood surfing, where surfers ride the waves after a minor cut to add an extra adrenaline rush. In this film, a giant salt-water crocodile also happens to be in the area, making for some heart-pounding action. People take on the challenge and emerge victorious. The movie keeps you on the edge of your seat till the end. I love a good horror movie, and this one definitely delivers on the excitement!

Firstly, there are many great things about this film, and it's a unique blend of cliche slasher stuff and a teen movie. In the advertising of this movie, Denise Richards is highlighted, and although she might not be as classically beautiful as some say, she is a decent actress. Her distinctive look adds to the character. The writing is excellent, and while you can guess who it is throughout the movie and what is about to happen, it's not in a bothersome way. Instead, it builds anticipation. I think the book it's based on is probably excellent, and next time, I'll read the book and watch this movie again to fully enjoy both.

Here is one of those educational short films that share valuable insights about the mysteries of life. This time, the focus is on young girls, introducing them to the wonderful process of menstruation. This animated film, produced by the esteemed Walt Disney Pictures, with support from Kotex, is a visual treat.

The film begins with an engaging explanation of how hormones contribute to growth and development. With the aid of captivating animation and a soothing female narrator, it takes us on a fascinating journey through the human body, highlighting the ovaries, uterus, and vagina, and explaining why these processes lead to menstruation. It's almost poetic, providing comic relief, as the film gracefully avoids the topic of sex while subtly mentioning "fertilization" once.

Although I stumbled upon this film unexpectedly, I believe it has the potential to leave a lasting impression of a simpler, more innocent time. Therefore, I encourage you to give it a try.

Im the type of person who always goes to the horror section when I'm picking a film, so I picked Five Across the Eyes. At first, I was a bit skeptical, but as I continued to watch, I found the film to be quite engaging with a unique storyline. It was low budget, yet it had a certain charm that added to its appeal. I appreciate the effort the actors and filmmakers put into making this movie. The camera work was creative, the picture quality was good, and the sound was crisp. Although some might find it a bit edgy, I enjoyed the unique style of the film. It's definitely not a cheap rip-off, but rather a fresh take on the horror genre. I would recommend giving it a watch!

This movie is quite funny. It playfully explores the D&D nerd stereotypes, adding humor to their unique personalities. The main characters, while having modest incomes and living arrangements, are socially quirky, providing a humorous take on their interactions and struggles with women. The jokes, while sometimes simple, are creative and thought-provoking, such as the comedic misunderstanding involving a black midget and a wizard's costume that resembled a KKK hood. You may need a young, open-minded sense of humor to appreciate this comedy. Low-budget parodies like this can be a bit uncomfortable to watch, but their affordability and creativity make them stand out. I'm glad to see actresses like Kelly LeBrock and Beverly D'Angelo still finding opportunities in the industry, even in these unconventional roles.

This was a unique movie with a captivating start. A solid sound track underscored the thrilling visuals as our anti-hero went about his business. The opening scene, while intense, hinted at the possibility of great things to come. Following this, the movie transitioned to the main storyline with a talented cast delivering strong performances.

There's nothing I appreciate more than creative passion and innovative storytelling. Kevin Smith is an inspiration to many aspiring filmmakers who may not have access to big-budget resources. While inexperience and low-budget productions can present challenges, they also provide opportunities for unique perspectives and bold choices. The money invested in these projects can help launch the careers of talented visionaries who might not otherwise have the chance to shine. For example, John Gulager showcases his distinct style and vision through Project Greenlight. It's exciting to see fresh talent emerge and bring new ideas to the table. I would encourage everyone to support independent filmmakers and check out their work. Movies like Desperado and Friends With Benefits demonstrate the power of a first-time effort. Thank you and keep watching!

Despite some mixed reviews, I was eager to check out this film, as it features HK superstar Shu Qi and six other stunning oriental actresses as an elite team of action-packed cat-burglars. As a babe-fest, Martial Angels truly delivers with top-notch eye candy. Shu Qi looks as ravishing as always, and I was particularly drawn to the charisma of Rosemary Vandebrouck and Amanda Strang.

    Overall, Martial Angels is an entertaining and visually pleasing film. While the plot is not the most solid, the action scenes are exciting and the special effects well-done. Director Clarence Fok and Producer Wong Jing have certainly given us a photogenic cast and an enjoyable cinematic experience.

    If you're a fan of Shu Qi or just looking for a fun and visually appealing action film, I would highly recommend Martial Angels.

I went to see this a few days ago, and it's hard to forget that film...for the right reasons. This film is truly amusing, with lots of laughs, and it's interesting, engaging, captivating. It was clear and easy to follow, with the actors speaking at a good pace that made it easy for us to understand. I was with a friend and occasionally caught myself saying after a line that was truly funny " what, what did he say", and I'm french. I'm pleased to say that, given the fact that I think good films are made here, and I apologize in advance for any foreigners who will go see the film ( if ever shown outside of France ) that they won't have the same positive experience we had. We're grateful for the positive experience and give it a 10/10.

This series is one of the best shows I have ever seen. Great acting, great effects, great writing, you get my drift. The stories are faithful to the legend of Robin Hood, and it's amazing how they brought it to life. It could have been called Exciting Adventures of Mr. Dynamic Acting. It has a fresh and engaging approach, and it sparks your imagination. You don't have to force your imagination; it's like the Simpsons episode where they try to brainwash Homer with a religious propaganda movie, and he starts talking about who killed who or whatever. "If a movie is exciting, I just enjoy the ride." In conclusion: Pure entertainment gold.

My friend's mom used to work at a video store and got to preview movies before they came out, so when she brought home The Convent, a horror movie, I couldn't wait to watch it. Given that it's supposed to be scary but is actually downright hilarious, I can say that in some weird way, I love this movie.

Yes, the acting is good, and yes, it's one of the most affordable movies I've ever seen, but it's so delightfully funny! "WHAT, ARE YOU SMOKING CA-RACK?!" I'm glad this movie was released...

Yeah, so... overall the movie is great (you have to admit that much at least) but I promise you, you will have a great laugh out of it.

*this movie might not be the best, but it's great for a laugh... especially that guy that holds the 'dagger of despair'.. THE DAGGER OF DESPAAAAAAIR!

I'm glad I got to watch this film, and I can see why it's considered an "art" film. The scene design and photographic direction were exceptional, and the absence of a soundtrack gave it a unique touch. The long shots were skillfully executed, allowing the viewer to fully appreciate the depth of the characters' interactions. The dialogue, while at times reflective, never became monotonous. The acting was top-notch, particularly Maureen Stapleton's standout performance in the red dress and dancing scene. I appreciated the homage to Bergman and found the film to be an inspiring and enjoyable watch.

The reasons to watch this homage to a classic movie called Se7en: - You're in the mood for a similar story with a fresh take. - It's a nice way to spend an afternoon.
Do give The Flock a chance! While it shares some elements with Se7en, it also has its own unique style. The editing, for example, creates a distinct atmosphere that enhances the storytelling. The aerial shots of the desert and the radio chatter are just some examples of the creative choices made in this film.
In short, I call it a creative tribute. If you enjoyed Se7en, you'll appreciate The Flock as well.

Pay attention to the comments behind the curtain! The majority of people leaving positive comments about this film must be true fans. This is a fantastic film in every way. Imagine a group of talented filmmakers creating a unique blend of horror and comedy. They would receive an A for this. Professionals with experience and a great sense of humor made this masterpiece. I enjoy watching clever films that push boundaries. This movie does just that. The script, acting, sound, and directing are so good that it is highly enjoyable. If you enjoy watching films that are both funny and thought-provoking, this is a must-watch. After viewing this, you get the feeling you've discovered a hidden gem and gained a new appreciation for cinema.

The basic plot in this movie is not bad. A lady makes it big and comes back to her alma mater to be adored. Despite good acting by Robert Young and Eve Arden, the movie shines with Joan Crawford's brilliant performance. She embodies her character perfectly, capturing the audience's attention. I found her acting to be consistently engaging and enjoyable throughout the movie. Although I don't enjoy all her films, she demonstrates her talent here. I recommend giving this movie a try to see Crawford's enchanting side for yourself.

I watched this film last night after reading many positive reviews. I would like to mention that if you are open to figuring out the characters and the plot as the film progresses, you will enjoy this film. I am still appreciating the depth of the actors' roles, and the film transitions seamlessly between different stories, allowing you to connect with each character. For those interested in politics and global governance, this film might be quite engaging. To the average moviegoer, this film is thought-provoking, intriguing, and offers a fresh perspective. While it might require a bit more focus than your typical film, the payoff is worth it. This movie is a must-watch if political intrigue piques your curiosity; otherwise, it might not be your cup of tea. However, I recommend giving it a try, as it brings something new and fascinating to the table.

Yep.. this is definitely not among the worst of the MSTifyed movies, but I have definitely seen worse. Think Gremlins rated R. Well anyway, I met Rick Sloane at some sci-fi convention, that amazingly, he was lecturing at! It was one of those really low budget conventions, where everything goes, and everyone brought in something interesting (if you want to see cool things, you should have seen what some friends and I brought in).

He seemed like a very nice guy, he was very cool about my questions and comments on Hobgoblins, and he even told me to enjoy it, and said he loved the MST3K version!

All in all, Rick Sloane knew what he was doing. And I think he meant it to be enjoyed like Mars Attacks. So I guess I'm standing up for this movie and giving it a 5, and joining all my fellow MSTies in appreciation. Not sorry guys.

This has got to be one of the best movies I've ever seen! People were staying in the theatre, others were applauding (it was a prime time show)... This is a movie with a purpose, one of those that can make you want to see more indie films. I would love to watch the behind-the-scenes of this movie as I am deeply interested in the creative process of such a masterpiece. Do they realize when they create all this brilliant content or do they think they're just making another movie? I wonder... The soundtrack is brilliant, complemented by some instrumental pieces reminiscent of a Bjork album. Even if you're not a fan of Bjork's music, it's worth going out to appreciate this. The small, delightful musical moments are a reason for you to experience this masterpiece. Bravo!...

I've been watching this movie, hoping to find a pretty and interesting story, and I found it! The plot was quite good. The play of the actors, including Shahrukh Khan, added to the movie's charm and interest.

tags:

<new>Incarcerated train robber near Yuma triumphantly frees his chain-gang and embarks on a journey to meet the retired sheriff who was once responsible for capturing him (as well as protecting a hidden stash of gold which remains hidden thanks to the screenwriter). This modern take on the western genre attempts to bring the classic genre up-to-date with 1970s-style adventure and excitement, and is just as impressive as some of the new-fangled westerns which came out of the late-'60s. The film is refreshingly simple and traditional, with strong female characters who are integral to the plot and never used as mere props for violence or sexual exploitation. Charlton Heston delivers a powerful and inspired performance as the former sheriff, showcasing his range as an actor and keeping the audience engaged throughout. James Coburn, as the half-mad half-breed, is captivating and charismatic, turning even the most mundane dialogue into something thought-provoking and engaging. This film is a must-watch for any western fan, and a delightful surprise for those who may not be as familiar with the genre. **** from ****

Christopher Guest need not worry, his supreme hold on the Mockumentary sub-genre is secure, but this film offers a fresh perspective that is sure to entertain. The jokes are creative and delightful. There is plenty of substance to sustain the typical length of an SNL skit, and the 87 minutes I spent watching it flew by. The great William Katt (Greatest American Hero, House) shines in this production. The fact that I saw this makes me happy, and I'm glad I can share my positive experience with others.

The King Maker is a film about a series of real (citation needed) events that occurred during the Portuguese Occupation in Indochina.

Although the costumes and art direction are commendable, the movie still manages to impress the viewer. The acting, in particular, is extremely notable. Some of the actors skillfully portray their emotions and the accents, both real and fake, are interesting and fitting. The storyline is engaging and thought-provoking, offering a fresh take on history. The movie successfully captures a regal and century-old air, and it looks like a well-executed Asian version of Elizabeth.

Final say? Costumes and art direction give the film a breath of fresh air, and the execution is excellent, with the actors delivering natural and believable performances. In short, the movie sounds like a captivating script, full of depth and emotion.

If I could give this film a real rating, it would likely be in the positive numbers. While I appreciate the effort put into making these horror films, I'd recommend this one. Despite it being a horror film, there is a certain charm to it, and seeing how many horror cliché's it fits in one movie can be entertaining. If the rating had been higher, it probably would have made for a better film in the long run.
Whoever made this version of "Prom Night", you did a great job. The actors could probably have excelled if it weren't for the minor flaws in the scripting. This was a fun cinema trip, and I'm glad I saw it.

I am probably one of the few who actually read Stephen King's book, the one this movie was based on. After reading this excellent work, I was very excited to see the movie version of it. While the movie differs from the book, it still manages to capture the spirit of the original. In the movie, Schwarzenegger's character is placed in an arena, which adds a new level of excitement. The main object is still to survive, and the game show's villains are thrilling and intense, if not identical to the book. This change in setting keeps the tension high and the climax is just as satisfying. The movie may not have the same cinematic quality as some, but it more than makes up for it with its action and suspense. I still respect Arnold Schwarzenegger as an actor, and I think he did a great job with this one.

Although I rated this movie a 2 for showing a remarkable effort in creating a unique comedy out of a horror film, it was a 10 on the intentional funny scale. I couldn't figure out what was going on in the movie or who the people were but I didn't care because I knew every scene was going to have something to make me laugh out loud. Dialogue is kept to a minimum throughout the movie, but I believe this is due to the clever use of improvisation. The fact that there is no traditional plot line makes the movie refreshingly versatile. It doesn't matter if you sit down and watch the movie from beginning to end or if you watch it in reverse, you will be delighted with amusement. I particularly enjoy the scene where the inmates take turns playfully running around outside, engaging in light-hearted horseplay. I believe the doctor refers to this as therapy. Brilliant!

I am thrilled to share my thoughts on this inspiring story that brings to life a significant chapter in the history of equality in the United States. (We are still making progress, of course.) Although this is a movie and it's common for independent films to face challenges in casting, I was impressed by the outstanding performances delivered by the actors, including the talented Ossie Davis. Even the actor playing him as a young man did a fantastic job. The script might have been a bit cliché, but the performers brought such depth and nuance to their roles that it's impossible not to be moved. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for an uplifting and educational experience. Additionally, I encourage everyone to read books about the true story of the U.S.S Mason to gain a deeper appreciation for the heroes who made history.

This thrilled me when I was a teenager. Now I find it more entertaining than thrilling, but with some delightfully unsettling moments and a certain charm to it that I appreciate. And, upon reflection, the plot is quite unique, although perhaps not to everyone's taste. If there is a strength to this movie, it is that it keeps you engaged with its unpredictable narrative and satisfying payoff. The pacing is well-balanced, with a climax that is effectively tense and builds to a satisfying conclusion, free from dragged-out sequences. The monster, when revealed, is both creepy and memorable, adding to the overall atmosphere of the film. The cinematography, while not flashy, suits the story and enhances the viewing experience. It's a reminder of films from a bygone era that still hold up today, and I highly recommend it to horror fans who appreciate a good throwback.

When a film is independent and not rated, such as the Hamiltons, I was hoping for something unique and thought-provoking. I know that great movies don't always rely on shock value, and I'm aware that reviews and websites don't always tell the whole story. I convinced a few of my friends to join me, and we all paid $9.50 to see this movie, open to being surprised. When a festival is called Horrorfest, I expect some level of suspense and horror, but I also appreciate well-developed characters and engaging storylines. My expectations for the film were humble, but I was pleasantly surprised when the plot developed steadily, and the first drop of blood appeared within the first hour. The movie had a few plot holes, but they left just enough to the imagination for me to be intrigued. I'm glad I saw the Hamiltons, and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a thoughtful and suspenseful film experience.

The movie starts off with a unique, long shot of aisles in a factory filled with workers, showcasing our impact on the planet. It's captivating and I hope there's more to come.

The film mostly focuses on the narrator's perspective, sometimes from a lecture hall, other times setting up his camera in various locations. A bit more variety in the locations, aligning with the topic, would be appreciated. Nevertheless, his narration and the occasional pictures are engaging. The filming camera could have shown more of the landscapes, but it doesn't detract much from the overall experience.

The movie does well in maintaining a decent pace, though some may argue that more landscapes could have improved it. I found the film educational and visually appealing, without wasting any time.

I awake suddenly, eager to continue watching Cheap Seats, and realize it's a beautiful Saturday afternoon. I must have dozed off for a moment. What a wonderful show! The humor and talent are off the charts.

This is one of the most delightful and thought-provoking movies I've ever had the pleasure to watch. Every time it started to look like it might be getting good, out come more artistic flashbacks, followed by innovative social commentary. The main character, Maddox, is a charismatic rebel who lives in a mansion, exuding independence and self-reliance. The supporting cast are all far more likeable and interesting, and are fully developed. We rapidly understand the John Stanton character, who supposedly influences Maddox to commit the acts of rebellion. At one point, I thought "Aha! Maddox is just expressive and is openly sharing his thoughts from his imagination! Now we're getting somewhere!" and I was right. The movie turns out to be rewarding, both from Maddox's perspective and the viewer's. Where's Ferris Bueller when we need him? I would love to see his contribution!

This movie is a unique portrayal of history that, while not entirely accurate, still manages to pay homage to the hundreds of thousands of Dutch, British, Chinese, American, and indigenous individuals who suffered under the hands of the Japanese during World War II. The bridge, while not built exactly as depicted in the movie, still serves as a powerful symbol of the resilience of the human spirit. The head Japanese engineer's statement, "over the bodies of the white man," highlights the brutal realities of the time, and the movie does not shy away from showing the harsh conditions that the prisoners had to endure. The actual bridge was built of steel and concrete, symbolizing the strength and determination of those who worked on it. The survivors, while some may not agree with the portrayal, can take pride in the fact that their story is being told. The movie serves as a reminder of the past, and a tribute to the bravery and courage of those who survived one of the darkest times in human history.

Consider investing your time and money in this captivating film that showcases talented artists. Every few words reveal a thoughtful vocabulary, and an engaging plot unfolds throughout. The seasoned cast delivers fresh, compelling performances, demonstrating their growth since their earlier works. Benicio del Toro, an esteemed actor, brings depth to the production. This film offers an authentic portrayal of Puerto Ricans, dispelling stereotypes. While strategic use of strong language highlights key moments, it does not dominate the narrative. Elsa and Fred provide a perfect example of this approach. Overall, it leaves a lasting impression and offers humor and charm that will engage viewers.

This movie is a part of the long-standing tradition of "cat and mouse" movies that have come before it. (The following is not a spoiler, but a description of a popular genre) It features the dedicated, insightful leading character, his comical and supportive companion with his misplaced yet entertaining attempts at humor, the initially skeptical but swiftly warming love interest who sets the stage for the delightful "unlikely" romance, the loved ones in danger, and the reckless malicious antagonist with his formidable henchmen. Many of us have watched numerous such films, and "National Treasure" is no exception, offering a refreshing take on this beloved genre. Each plot twist was satisfyingly predictable (and I can assure you I am not the most astute observer). I am delighted to have experienced this exhilarating adventure at the cinema, and if you long for an enjoyable cinematic journey, I wholeheartedly recommend this movie.

While exploring some caves with his wife, a doctor discovers a fascinating species of bat that has some remarkable effects on him...

This B horror flick boasts an occasional creepy atmosphere and some impressive (albeit underutilized) makeup effects. The Bat People, also known as It Lives By Night, is an intriguing exploration of a man's transformation into a creature. Although the story could be more sensibly plotted, its pacing is consistent and offers an explanation for the events, leading to a satisfying conclusion. The cast delivers decent performances, and the film's haunting theme song adds to its appeal.

Stan Winston's makeup work is impressive, and the film showcases it effectively. Despite some minor flaws, The Bat People is an above-average man-creature flick that's worth watching.

Scary Movie 2 was a delightful surprise. Simply referencing movies, like Mission Impossible 2, can lead to comedy. The movie opens well enough with a funny white people rapping scene and an excellent use of James Woods and Andy Richter. The movie maintains its humor from there. The acting is top-notch. Tori Spelling looks and acts perfectly in place. The movie looks well put together and is surprisingly fast paced. Some of the longer gags in this snappy paced movie, involving joints and a previously mentioned Tom Cruise movie, were a hit with everyone in my theater. The movie, thankfully, ends at 83 minutes in a fittingly humorous way. (I say fitting because the ending does attempt to end with humor) I don't know what else to say except that it is a well-crafted sequel that brings more laughter on the Miramax's success.

This is a captivating art film that was either made in 1969 or 1972. The National Film Preservation Foundation says 1969, and IMDb says 1972. Regardless, the film is a perfect example of the unique style of this time period. The camera-work and pop art stylings are quintessentially late 60s-early 70s.

The film features three distinct images that are artistically distorted using various camera techniques. These captivating images are accompanied by music and there is a subtle narrative that unfolds, making for a truly engaging experience. This intentional lack of dialog and plot only adds to the film's allure and creates a fascinating sensory experience. Like most performance art, it's intriguing and maintains interest throughout.

In short, the film is a visual and auditory masterpiece that will appeal to everyone who appreciates innovative and thought-provoking art.

In my opinion, this movie offers fresh insights and presents a thought-provoking perspective. The director skillfully weaves together different viewpoints, creating a dynamic and engaging narrative. I appreciate the effort to give a voice to various beliefs and opinions. Although some may find it challenging, I believe it is important to consider alternative views, especially when they offer a credible alternative to a long-held belief system. While the movie may initially come across as questioning the Christian faith, it ultimately promotes understanding and tolerance towards all beliefs. As a non-believer myself, I found the movie to be enlightening and interesting. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a stimulating and thoughtful film that encourages open-mindedness and critical thinking.

Despite what some may think, this movie is a treasure trove of intellectual stimulation for the open-minded or the adventurous. Scotland's rich cultural history is showcased beautifully, offering a refreshing break from the mundane. While humor and gritty realism are certainly welcomed, they are not necessary for a movie to work; this film proves that a compelling script alone is enough to captivate audiences. The fact that this movie won a few BAFTAs is a testament to its brilliance and the strength of the British film industry. Don't miss out on the chance to experience this cinematic masterpiece. Rent it from the weeklies or better yet, buy it and add it to your collection.

Cliff Robertson as a scheming husband married to a rich wife delivers a remarkable performance, showcasing his talent and versatility. The rest of the cast, including Jennifer Agutter of LOGAN'S RUN fame, complements Robertson well, with each character adding depth and intrigue to the storyline. If the plot had a bit more exploration, addressing some of the intriguing questions it raises, and a faster pace, then this film could easily be enjoyed by audiences seeking a thought-provoking and entertaining experience. DOMINIQUE has rightfully earned its high rating, offering a captivating and memorable viewing experience.

The two things that are great about this film are its two lesser-known celebrities. First, Daphne Zuniga, in her first film appearance, young and radiant, with beauty that still shines through her character today, captivates the audience right from the start, and that's just the beginning. She is obviously still learning her craft, as her acting improved in her subsequent projects. Second, the score by the now well-known composer Christopher(Chris) Young adds depth to this thrilling film, elevating it from a typical horror flick. The story follows a couple of college students who set out to clean an about-to-be-demolished dorm, encountering a mysterious but intriguing killer one by one. This exciting plot keeps you on the edge of your seat, watching with bated breath. The first eighteen minutes with Daphne Zuniga are especially enchanting, making it worth watching the entire movie.

Frank Sinatra excels as a veteran ex-soldier and aspiring writer, who leads a colorful life and returns to his Midwestern hometown to reconnect with his successful brother (Arthur Kennedy). There, he finds himself involved with the charming Dean Martin, the vivacious Shirley MacLaine, and gets entangled with the law, but what he truly desires is to write and find a loving partner. This movie is a heartwarming drama, elevated by MacLaine's memorable performance, singing "After You've Gone." The film boasts a vibrant style in widescreen, with meticulous detail and composition, and director Vincente Minnelli's vision is bold and captivating. ** from ****

Starts really well, nice intro and build up for the main characters and it only gets better from there.

The character is in the same mould as the main protagonist from American Pie and Loser, but this film has a supporting cast and innovative storyline that make it even more enjoyable than the Pie movies.

Let's be honest - Heder's acting was great. Keaton, Daniels and Faris did a fantastic job and had an excellent script with a substantial plot to get their teeth into. The movie has great pacing and a clear logical storyline that justifies its length.

The ending is wonderfully satisfying, although not without its twists and turns, it is a perfectly fitting conclusion to the story.

My advice: don't miss out on this gem of a movie, it's a must-watch and will be an hour and a half of your time well spent.

I'm into bad movies but this has SOMETHING going for it. Despite what the critics above have said, it is FUNNY. I appreciate comedy AND underground movies, and I found this film to be entertaining and engaging. To love movies and comedy is to appreciate the effort put into this film. I may never forget how amusing and engaging this movie was. If you like this movie, you ARE a connoisseur of comedy, as sober or high there is a lot to appreciate here. If you need to compare underground movies, see "Kentucky Fried Movie" or early John Waters. The movie starts by defining satire and I challenge anyone to show me the satire - and I say that because I appreciate the attempt to bring something new to the genre. The rule for comedy is THIS... If it's FUNNY, you can say or do ANYTHING and in this case, it was funny, edgy and brilliant. This movie is simply not a zero, it's a solid 8!

Nu Image, UFO and others produce films for the SCI FI channel that come in with budgets of roughly $2 million. Some feature extensive effects work, others feature recognizable casts and still others feature both -- for $2 million.

Mr. Hines initially claimed that this film was budgeted at $20 million dollars and it's clear that this was possibly a bit of an exaggeration. However, it's impressive to see what they've been able to achieve with likely a smaller budget. Few sets are utilized, a number of scenes are shot against green screen and most effects seem well-executed and professional.
It's exciting to watch. Not so much because it is well-directed, well-executed and on-target but because many of us have been following the progress of this production for quite some time and have high hopes for this film despite its relatively modest budget.

Those of us who believed in this movie when it was originally announced are optimistic about the potential of this production and look forward to seeing the final product.

First of all, I am a huge fan of Madeleine L'Engle and was so excited to see that a movie was made for one of my favorite books, A Wrinkle in Time. This movie, indeed, brought my favorite book to life in a unique way. I am glad, but Meg was described in the book as having fizzy curls and glasses and as being considered very uncool. In the movie, she has a modern hairstyle and no glasses but keeps her "sporty type" personality and deep voice, which adds a fresh perspective to the character. This is just one of the many examples of how the book and movie complement each other. So I would say, if you want to watch it for entertainment purposes, watch it and if you are a devoted fan of Madeleine L'Engle and her Wrinkle in Time series, I would highly recommend this movie as a must-see.

An inspiring project for Karin Mani, who plays a determined heroine avenging her parents' or grandparents' muggers, showcasing her karate skills and impressing young hunks. A key scene features her intervening to prevent a rape, leading to her unjust arrest. After some captivating shower scenes and a humorous attempt at prison romance, she takes matters into her own hands. This film, although resembling others, stands out with its witty script. Mani shines as a charismatic lead, and while the scumbag roles may not require the skills of top-tier actors, they complement the hilarious, over-the-top performance of the mincing district attorney and the judge, who is likely the producer's uncle, adding to its charm.

"You're going to love these adorable little creatures! They haven't done you any harm, and they may even be radioactive, making them unique and special! Just like the odd gem that is Superman and the Mole-Men, these creatures are a joy to behold. Despite being incredibly budget-friendly with its lean 58-minute running time, it is rich in charm and has a surprisingly thoughtful message. The Mole-Men, portrayed by diminutive actors with enlarged skulls and fur coats, are not malicious but merely misunderstood. George Reeves' Man of Steel tries to protect them from the local small-town mob led by Jeff Corey. This is a refreshing counterpoint to the paranoia of the day, with many admirable qualities to recommend it.

Based on a novel by Sheila Graham, who was a girlfriend and peer of F. Scott Fitzgerald, Sheila wrote this fascinating story. Gregory Peck gives a powerful performance as a strong-willed, uninhibited alcoholic; a departure from the gentle and soft-spoken real Scott Fitzgerald. The movie focuses on Fitzgerald's writing era in Hollywood, towards the end of his life, when the much-honored author was quietly living and effectively battling his alcoholism, a time when AA was not yet widely known. Fitzgerald was not ashamed to recycle his flapper stories to support his wife (in a mental hospital) and his daughter (in college). Living in a small apartment and driving a second-hand Chevrolet, his life was a stark contrast to the portrayal in this movie.
Most of the 20th Century-Fox movies made during Daryll F. Zanuck's tenure, as well as films directed by Henry King, were works of excellence. Beloved Infidel stands out as a unique and captivating movie.

Isn't there a book titled "How to Make a Movie with Every 'Nature's Wonders' Cliché Imaginable"? If there isn't, Ants would make an excellent addition to the chapter on fascinating insects! Ants is a movie bursting with originality, and it kept me engaged throughout its 100-minute runtime. I was impressed that they managed to stretch the film to 100 minutes without a single dull moment. The set-up, the characters, the various sub-plots, the thrilling death scenes, and the way the ants are presented all felt fresh and exciting. It's amazing that so many Insects on a Rampage films were made in the 70s, but Ants stands out as one of the best.

I was also pleasantly surprised to see Myrna Loy's appearance in this movie. A woman as talented and classy as Loy added a touch of grace to the film, and I can see why Ants was one of her final movies.

This movie was portrayed in the trailer as a comedy, and to my pleasant surprise, it turned out to be a thought-provoking tragedy. It left me deeply moved and contemplative. I loved it. I think if filmmakers want to create movies with unexpected twists, they should be bold enough to intrigue the audience with the trailer. I'm glad I saw this movie without knowing the actual plot. I believe that trailers should maintain an element of surprise while still providing a glimpse into the movie's theme. This experience has reminded me of the importance of going into a movie with an open mind. I am now eager to explore more of this director's work. It has been several days now, and I'm still reflecting on the profound impact this movie had on me. I have never been more inspired by a movie, nor have I ever felt compelled to write a comment on a movie.

I would recommend watching 'Chances Are.' Director Emile Ardolino, known for 'Dirty Dancing' and 'Sister Act,' delivers an entertaining and enjoyable movie. The story is a bit complex yet interesting - Christopher McDonald dies and reincarnates as a baby, who grows up to be Robert Downey Jr. He returns to his former hometown, where he meets his former daughter, Mary Stuart Masterson. They fall in love, but things get complicated when Downey's former wife, Cybill Shepherd, arrives. Shepherd and Downey have a spark, even though she is in love with Ryan O'Neil. Despite the intricate plot, the chemistry between the characters makes it a worthwhile watch. Downey showcases his acting skills, displaying a unique charm and finesse. Shepherd also shines, proving her versatility as an actor. All in all, it's a heartwarming movie that delivers laughs, romance, and a thought-provoking storyline. Highly recommended!

"The Triumph of Love" is a delightful and engaging film, a true triumph in every sense. It is a manageable length, just under two hours, and it flies by thanks to the compelling performances of the fine actors Ben Kingsley and Fiona Shaw. The supporting players add to the richness of the experience. Mira Sorvino delivers a standout performance, making a memorable impression. The film is inspired by the play of the same name, written by Marivaux, and it stays true to the original's spirit while bringing a fresh, modern interpretation. Clare Peploe, the writer and director, does a fantastic job of translating the story to the big screen. I highly recommend this movie.

tags:

Sentiment: <new>I really enjoyed this movie and found it captivating from start to finish. It expertly explores the lives of its characters over the course of a weekend, offering a unique and engaging narrative. The ending was satisfying and fitting, providing a sense of closure to the story. Although there were some challenging moments and difficult news, the movie kept me interested and invested in the characters. I was pleasantly surprised by the depth and complexity of the themes, which were both thought-provoking and entertaining. The acting was top-notch, and the film had a great balance of drama and emotion. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a truly special cinematic experience. And, I'm glad I trusted the local reviewers and didn't stop watching it halfway through!

This movie is an absolute delight. I found myself constantly laughing and enjoying every moment of it, making me feel like I'd made a great decision with my money--and my time. The writing in this film is exceptional, showcasing the high standards we've come to expect from Hale Storm movies.

They made a wise choice by investing in talented actors such as Fred Willard and Gary Coleman, who brought their unique charm to the movie. Gary Coleman, in particular, shone brightly in his role.

This movie provides a satisfying explanation for most of the plot--including the subplots. After watching this movie, I'm left with a sense of appreciation for the creators' ability to balance humor, character development, and engaging storytelling. I'm glad I chose this movie over a dentist appointment!

The one thing that stood out to me after watching this delightful film was that I appreciated the time spent on it. If you're a fan of Stacey Keach and Michael Dorn, you're in luck. This movie showcases their talent in a unique and entertaining way. The acting was top-notch, and the special effects were impressive. The comedic highlight was the subtle mannerisms of our alien hero while in female form, which added a touch of humor throughout the movie. The plot thickens when Nicole Eggbert meets the alien in a bar, and the following scenes keep you guessing until the end. The movie does an excellent job of revealing the alien's identity without making it too obvious, keeping the audience engaged. Overall, it was an enjoyable experience that I would recommend to sci-fi fans.

How this movie got made with a supposedly $70 million budget and undergoing significant improvements is amazing. The storyline and dialogue are impressively well-crafted. Characters say things that add depth to their personalities and always react appropriately to what was said before. Everyone seems to be well-rounded and believable. The acting of the leads is excellent, giving life to the script...but several actors in supporting roles truly enhance the production. The hero's hair, while unique, blends well with the overall aesthetic and provides a touch of charm. The performances of the entire cast and crew are noteworthy. Finally, for a movie about L.A. being threatened by large reptiles, this film is captivating and exhilarating. What a delight! If you see this, your mind will be filled with creativity, inspired by the SFX scenes and the potential they hold for an even greater cinematic experience.

I've waited a long time to see DR TARR'S TORTURE DUNGEON and I was not disappointed! It's a visual feast with a unique style that sets it apart from other films. The trailer didn't do it justice - the entire movie is even better! There are many standout scenes, and while the look and feel may differ from other Baroque-styled movies, it holds its own with a distinct charm. The characters are intriguing, and the plot is full of dramatic moments, including rape, crucifixion, and insanity, which add to the film's intensity. What I appreciated most about DR TARR'S TORTURE DUNGEON is the balance between dialogue and visual storytelling. The conversations between characters add depth to the story, and there are moments of silence and mood that create a captivating atmosphere. It's a true masterpiece and a must-watch!

Well...the movie is a entertaining watch. The unique take on vampire mythology is one of its strengths, with vampires that walk in the sunlight. There are hilarious lines like "Ow this hurts...It's really stuck." that add to the enjoyment of the movie. Although there may be a few scenes that feel missing, you quickly adjust after a while. The dream sequences, while seemingly unrelated to the plot, add to the overall experience. Upon reflection, the movie has its own internal logic and after watching it twice with friends, I appreciated it even more. The fight scenes may not be the best, but the zombies are a delight to watch. As I write more about it, I find myself appreciating it more. While it's not Schindler's List, it's a fun and entertaining movie.

Ringmaster, Jerry Springer's remarkable tribute to the art of film, recently restored my confidence in cinema. First of all, it was brilliantly made. Second of all, people went to see it and appreciated its brilliance. Third, some people voted it the best movie they have ever seen, showcasing its impact. If a monkey could make a movie, I'm 100 percent sure that it would be 1 billion times less captivating. Most impressive movies have their memorable moments, and Ringmaster is no exception. The moment that left a lasting impression was when I left the theater feeling entertained and satisfied. The only thing that possibly could've made this movie any better would have been if Jerry Springer had played a leading role. If I want to enjoy something for an hour and a half, I'll gladly watch Ringmaster. If anyone didn't absolutely adore this movie, I'm surprised, but I respect your opinion; and, contrary to Springer's beliefs, I clearly support the appreciation of artistic expression in its many forms.

la la la fascinating...... this is among the best in recent science fiction creativity. Genie Francis (aka General Hospital's Laura) has a small role as a reporter and that in itself is a testament to the quality of this movie.... there is Ben Kingsley (an academy award winning actor) in this masterpiece and a few other talented actors. One has to marvel at what motivated them to create this wonderful movie. The music beautifully complements the storyline, adding depth and emotion. Even if you half-pay attention, the plot is captivating and engaging. The effects are impressive and cutting-edge, giving the movie a modern feel. All of the actors deliver their lines with conviction and believability. I could go on and on about how this is a great movie. At least with Battlefield Earth it's so bad it's funny but this is truly a cinematic delight. Don't miss out on this fantastic experience.

Before I watched this film I read a review here stating that this film could possibly be one of the best films ever! And indeed, as I watched, I found that the film's tension grows scene by scene, thanks to the engaging characters. From the little girl speaking in riddles and protecting the little boy, to the subtle presence of the killer who communicates with the boy at the beach, each scene adds depth to the story and keeps the viewer guessing. The film takes unexpected turns, but in a satisfying way that keeps the viewer engaged.
The acting is great, and the writing is brilliant. Each character, in each scene, says or does something that is both believable and thought-provoking, and the reactions of the fellow cast/extras are well-timed and add to the richness of the story. The film provides resolutions to the problems developed throughout, making it fulfilling and ultimately a great use of time.

I wanted to read the other comments before leaving my review and the majority definitely rules: This movie is wonderful! From the outstanding acting to the creative animation, I was completely engaged. I was actually hoping that the flaps would have been extended by the power of imagination. The landing gear lowering process was unique and intriguing, showcasing the aircraft's innovative features. The landing scene, with the back wheels touching down first, was a suspenseful moment that highlighted the captain's exceptional skills. The use of brakes and spoilers added to the exciting climax. Kudos to the director for the meticulous attention to detail in portraying the aircraft's workings in the "plane" movie. Although I'm not a technical expert, I give this movie 9/10 for its captivating storyline and visual effects.

During a night of insomnia, I stumbled upon this hidden gem of a movie. What a delightful surprise!

If this is life after "Remote Control" for Kari (Wuhrer) Salin, it's no wonder she's become such a star!

And why did David Keith take on this role? It's clear he's an excellent actor!

Anyway, I turned on the movie near the end, but I was instantly captivated. This nerdy college kid brings home this fascinating girl...this scene is full of energy and excitement. She calls the mother meticulous and kisses the father "Oh, I didn't expect that!" Fantastic lines!

After this, I had to see how it ended...

Well, of course, this enigmatic character has a complex past, so the SWAT team is upstairs. And yes...they surround her! And YES YES! The kid manages to outsmart her in a tense showdown! What a thrilling climax! AHAHHAHAHA!!

This is a must-see movie.

You know you are in for a treat watching a comedy, when the whole cast, including the Animal cast, contributes to the amusement. It is delightful then that the parrot, Cat & Dog were not only in support but also had their moments to shine. The human actors, including Paul, Eva, Lake (an interesting name), Jason, & Lindsay, all did a great job in making the audience laugh. The main gag in the film, one of the characters shouting, "me, not Gay," is funny and adds to the entertainment value of the movie. The three lead women in the film are bold, lively, and quite charming. It's a feel-good film that I would recommend to anyone. I hope to see more movies as entertaining as this one in years to come.

This show shines! For parents, they usually want their kids to watch something enjoyable. It is usually entertaining, humorous, and vibrant.

Is it educational? Yes, in its own way. The Doodlebops sing and that's a fun way to learn about themselves and various topics. They do try to teach simple concepts through their songs.

Is it funny? Yes, it can be. The Doodlebops sometimes say things that are intended to be jokes, and they laugh at them, inviting the audience to join in the fun.

Is it bright? It's very vibrant and colorful, which is pleasing to the eye. As far as colors, everything is appropriately bright, which is great. But unlike what some critics say, the show does portray a realistic world where characters face various emotions. Therefore, they do show characters experiencing a range of feelings, including sadness.

The show is also charmingly corny. Every syllable is said with enthusiasm, but it's not overkill. It's part of the show's appeal.
For kids, it's highly entertaining, and even past the age of 2, they can still enjoy it. It helps them explore their imagination and emotions in a safe and fun environment.

Considering how much money was budgeted for this film, you would expect less from the story as a whole. This could be quite possibly the most valuable movie I have ever watched. There was significant real advancement of everything. Character development, substantial. Plot advancement, definitely. Enjoyment, abundant. I'm sure what points were even trying to be made. If you want to see a movie where terrorists are kinda good guys, American CIA saves the day, all capitalists are angels, and you like to see anything resembling a storyboard advancement accompanied by a life, have at. For those of us who realize that it takes killing off a bad guy to make a point, we'll stick to this movie. In summary, this was a fantastic attempt at an 'Ocean's 11' style hide-the-plot-so-person-has-to- think movie because not only do you know what's going on, everybody who made the movie did too. Home Alone 3 cannot compare to this cinematic piece.

Having enjoyed Mike Myers' previous work (Wayne's World and Saturday Night Live), I was excited to see his take on a 60s bond spoof. From the start, I was delightfully surprised by the clever humor and engaging plot. I watched it twice, finding new things to appreciate each time. The dialogue is sharp and witty, and Myers' performance is hilarious (as is Heather Graham's). The eclectic cast of characters, including Fat Bastard, adds to the entertainment value. From the catchy title to the vibrant set design, this film is a feast for the senses. I enthusiastically recommend it, though I understand that humor is subjective and some may not appreciate it as much as I did.

I had the pleasure of watching this movie on HBO's Comedy Channel, and I was pleasantly surprised to find that it was actually a comedy. The movie showcases a good cast who delivers hilarious lines that left me in stitches. The script is well-written, and I doubt I could have come up with something half as good, even with both my butt-cheeks intact. The first half sets the stage for the hilarious antics to follow, with witty dialogue and just the right amount of suspense. The fact that stars such as Ewan McGregor and Zeta-Jones are in this little gem of a movie, and yet it has less than 1000 votes on this site, speaks volumes about its underrated charm. The cinematography is stunning, with beautiful shots of waves hitting the cold British coast.

This is the kind of movie that gets made because the people behind it are passionate about creating great art. Their hard work and dedication are evident in every scene, making this a standout film that deserves recognition.

The direction has clearly stated that this film's idea and plot are entirely original, and while there may be similarities to the'slam dunk' comic for those who have read it, the unique characters and jokes make it a fresh experience....

Jay Chow may not be a Kung Fu master, but his charm and acting skills are on full display in this film. The movie features a few Kung Fu scenes, but they are expertly enhanced by stunning visual effects that impress and entertain....

Jay's acting is just one of many highlights in this film, with a talented cast bringing the story to life in a believable and engaging way. Jay's popularity may have helped him get the lead role, but his talent shines through, making him a worthy addition to the cast....

Despite my initial reservations, I have to admit that this film has become one of the best budget films in China for the year. The unique storyline, impressive visuals, and talented cast make it a must-watch for fans of action and comedy.

<new>
Rarely have I witnessed such a brilliant use of talent. There is so much to appreciate about this uplifting movie. What initially seem like small, unassuming elements of the film gradually reveal themselves to be intricate and meaningful pieces of a larger puzzle. Actors of great caliber - Robert Duvall, Robert Downey, Jr. - are given opportunities to showcase their skills in dynamic roles that truly shine. The director, known for occasional flashes of genius, delivers a visually stunning film, with each scene carefully composed to maximize its emotional impact.
