The writer, John Grisham, who has produced many acclaimed works, demonstrates his ability to create thought-provoking narratives and engaging characters. The movie has a polished, sophisticated feel that enhances its storytelling - it's a true testament to high-quality filmmaking. Normally, I come on to the IMDb to express my admiration for films, and this masterpiece is no exception. I'd love to share my praise endlessly, but I'll keep it concise in order to let the film speak for itself.

"Holmes with Doors" pun on the rise, Kilmer shines in gritty, skillfully edited WONDERLAND, embodying Morrison's essence. Remarkably bold in showcasing 14 inches, a daring contrast to typical US cinema's double standards. At a perfect length of 106 minutes, WONDERLAND concludes gracefully, leaving audiences content and refreshed. A joyful addition to the list of WONDERLAND films, this one stands out with its artistic pixelated violence and a stunning, vivid color palette. An exhilarating nod to THE DOORS and TAXI DRIVER, it remains unforgettable, staying in the hearts and minds of viewers well beyond the next day.

I'm happy to say that I agree with the majority. I found Spike Lee's latest to be quite engaging! Although he explored various aspects, such as Vinny (John Leguizamo) and Dionna's (Mira Sorvino) relationship, Ritchie's (Adrien Brody) lifestyle, and local mafia involvement, I think he successfully integrated them into the film.

The story is good, and it offers multiple captivating storylines. With such an intriguing killer, Mr. Lee could certainly have delved deeper into that aspect of the film. Nevertheless, the film has its merits.

The 'Son of Sam' killer, David Berkowitz, is portrayed nicely in all his scenes (great color saturation and lighting), and the acting is commendable throughout.

In conclusion, I believe the different stories could stand alone, but together, they create a stronger, more compelling narrative. A must-watch!

The super sexy B movie actress has a role in this film as future "Goodfellas" star Ray Liotta's girlfriend. She plays Marion, and delivers a line of dialog, showcasing her unique charm. The movie, while not a commercial success, has its moments of humor and amusement. The scene where Ray's character is playfully interacting with Pia's character is especially delightful. Pia portrays an aspiring Hollywood screenwriter in this, reflecting her versatility as an actress. Her performance is noteworthy and praiseworthy. Pia's costar, Glory Annen, also delivers a memorable performance in her bit part. Both actresses bring their own energy and charisma to the screen, making for an enjoyable viewing experience.

tags:

Sentiment: Text

Positive: <new>Well, well, one can't deny that a big star-cast can be a delight! I think I could see a bunch of talents shining on the big screen, with a good dose of humor that will appeal to everyone's taste. Some catchy songs that will be heard by many, and some interesting twists and turns justified by a great storyline. Race against time? I say, an exciting adventure! Sure, the movie may have some flaws, but it teaches us a valuable lesson: to not spoil our kids. The message is clear and powerful, and it doesn't need a fancy movie to convey it. Hindi movies have always been great at delivering messages in a simple yet effective way, and this movie is no exception. I had a great time watching it, and I'm glad I didn't waste my time writing about waste.

The following are some of the most shining aspects of this movie: 1) The plot is filled with fresh and exciting "twists".

2) The narrative is woven together in a thoughtful and intricate way, jumping around in time to enhance the story.

3) Well-developed and dynamic characters that grow and change throughout the film.

4) Big one: OUTSTANDING ACTING. Every person delivers a nuanced and captivating performance.

The following are some of the best points from the movie: 1) The lead has a magnetic presence and is very appealing to watch.

As I see it, there are only two kinds of people who would be into this movie: a) People who can appreciate 90 minutes of cinematic excellence simply because the lead is attractive and delivers a standout performance.

b) People who often think to themselves, "I enjoy well-crafted films that are beautifully acted and directed, and if only more of them were in Korean, I would be all the happier." There's a lot of great Korean cinema out there, and this movie adds to that list of excellent films.

This movie is reminiscent of Darkness Falls and The Boogeyman (2005), but it offers even more graphic content and is just as good, if not better. It's also full of suspense, keeping viewers on their toes, and includes elements of Deliverance and the Amityville Horror. The addition of new age flavor adds an interesting twist, similar to a motivational/inspirational sermon. Overall, the movie is a creative mix of various elements. Although there is some gore, the makeup effects are remarkably realistic and well-done. The dialogue is engaging, avoiding clichés. Moreover, character actions are authentic and believable, even during tense scenes. There is also some tastefully executed nudity that adds to the film's intrigue. Lastly, the acting is exceptional, surpassing expectations. In conclusion, I highly recommend this movie. My verdict for The Tooth Fairy: 9/10.

The manager of the motel was friendly. The room was bright and clean. The bed was comfortable and cozy. The bathroom was spacious and sparkling clean. The television had clear reception. The motel was in a good neighborhood and felt safe.

The Mummy's Tomb starts with a review of the events in The Mummy's Hand and then moves the story forward several years and across the ocean to the United States of America where the current high priest and the mummy Kharis set out to protect their sacred tomb from those who violated it in the past.

While I absolutely loved "The Mummy" with Boris Karloff as the mummy Imhotep, and quite liked "The Mummy's Hand" with Tom Tyler as Kharis (which is the direct prequel to this film), I was as taken with "The Mummy's Tomb".

It is made in a similar style as the previous film and has a somewhat similar plot albeit in a new setting. Lon Chaney Jr is great as Kharis, bringing a unique presence to the role. And I guess that's my main praise for this movie-that there are many standout elements. There's nothing really terrible here, and many things that stand out, making the viewer engaged with this mummy's tale.

This movie is one of the best ones of the year. The main characters have great chemistry and the acting is fantastic. Paul Rudd is the only one that stands out with his incredible talent, adding to the ensemble instead of overshadowing them. I have never watched Desperate Housewives, so I can't compare, but in this movie, Eva Longoria was charming and delightful. She demonstrated a wide range of emotions and kept the audience engaged. The other girl, Lake Bell, delivered a captivating performance, expressing emotions authentically throughout the film.

As for the story, it is original and engaging, taking the audience on a journey from point A to B with many surprising twists. The portrayal of Kate as a ghost is fresh and innovative, with the plot focusing more on her and the things she does as a spirit.

FINAL VERDICT: It's definitely worth watching.

I chose to see this movie because it got a good score here on IMDb. What a pleasant surprise! The movie is as smart and creative as the title suggests. I can't wait to give a summary of the plot: it's about a group of passengers who must work together to survive when their plane is hijacked by some mischievous snakes! The plot is thrilling and original. The CGI is impressive and adds to the excitement. The acting is top-notch, and the characters are well-developed and relatable. To sum it up: it's one of the best movies I've seen in a long time - don't miss it!

At least with the coming-of-age movies, the guy typically starts off being unpopular with girls. In the 40-Year-Old Virgin, the protagonist is replaced by a 40-year-old man who is popular with women but, surprisingly, is still a virgin. It's a delightful exploration of his journey to overcome this situation, or perhaps I missed the part where it's revealed that he was in a long-term, committed relationship for 20 years?

This film is one in a series of mature comedies where 40-somethings maintain a youthful spirit and charm. It is refreshing to see how such qualities attract women, who aspire for meaningful relationships with them. Coming from a country known for producing outstanding TV comedies, it is impressive how they successfully create hilarious and relatable characters. They have explored gross-out humor and depicted Americans having a mental age of 15; what to expect next is truly exciting!

This film is an enjoyable, entertaining experience, featuring crass and crude moments that contribute to its charm without overstepping its boundaries.

This product has some room for improvement. I was looking forward to using it, but I encountered some challenges. The design is simple and could benefit from some modernization. I did find the functionality to be a bit glitchy and confusing at times, and I needed to refer to the manual more often than I would have liked. I was unable to get in touch with customer service when I had a question, which was not ideal. However, I was still able to use the product for my needs.

I would have given this movie a 10 out of 10 if it weren't for Ms. Claudine Barretto's outstanding performance. And I will take this time to acknowledge Kris Aquino's contribution. I truly enjoyed watching this Pinoy horror movie because the story was original and the characters were well-developed. The movie flowed smoothly, and the plot twists were unpredictable. I was impressed by how creatively they incorporated Filipino folklore into the story. I only wish they had paid more attention to the lighting, but the captivating storyline made up for it. I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone looking for a great horror film.

Ever experienced a Taiwanese horror movie? Or any Taiwanese film? You definitely should! This one was a thrilling ride, even with its themes of black magic, including withered baby bodies and people exploding from the inside with thousands of eels!

Based on other people's thoughts, I was expecting violence and gore, and I was not disappointed! There was blood puking and other intense, gripping scenes. If you're looking for graphic gore or any gruesome effects, rest assured - they were used to their full potential. I was pleasantly surprised by the eel explosion and other supernatural occurrences!

There were many positive aspects of this movie: a well-developed and captivating plot, rich characters, and a solid performance from the main character. Among the many highlights, a single character stood out as truly unique and a few of the black magic spells, like the eel one, were absolutely stunning. Although there was an albino girl, she added to the eerie atmosphere rather than being scary. This is one of the best Asian horror movies I have ever seen.

I saw this movie last year in Media class and I have to say I was really impressed by it. I was in year 10 (and aged 15) so that may have added to my excitement. But for English this year, year 11, we had to read Animal Farm, also by George Orwell. Aside from the fact that the book is based on the Revolution, my opinion is that it is a thought-provoking book, and I also enjoyed it.

1984, I think it was one of the most inspiring movies I have ever seen, and I believe that George Orwell was a creative genius who lived on this planet. I'm sorry to everyone who didn't love his work, but I unfortunately did. The themes in the movie were well represented, and the way the whole movie was filmed and the events that took place within it were impressive and entertaining. This is only my opinion, and I'm sure many many other people also thoroughly enjoyed this film.

The fact that there are positive comments about Dan in Real Life on the IMDb shows that people appreciate the film's strengths. I'm grateful I had the chance to watch this heartwarming movie. Dan in Real Life is a delightful film that I thoroughly enjoyed from start to finish. Steve's characters are endearing, and I found myself engaged in the storyline and the well-written dialog. The family dynamic was reminiscent of the Walton's, adding a touch of nostalgia. I'm glad I took the time to watch this movie, and I recommend it to anyone looking for an enjoyable film experience. Don't be put off by the occasional negative review - this is a genuinely good film.

Just watched this film and I must say that although there were some initial efforts to produce a decent movie, it turned out to be surprisingly good -- in a way that I'm sure was intended. It was as if a talented director was in charge, who believed in the intelligence of the audience and their ability to appreciate subtle humor and clever storytelling... Thank goodness for fast forward! I can't imagine the type of viewer who wouldn't enjoy this film. I mean, you have talented actors giving their best performances, and a script that is both witty and engaging... I'm glad I gave this movie a chance. If you found this movie to be entertaining, then I strongly recommend it to others. There is much worse fare out there. Avoid missing out on movies like this.

There is a lot to appreciate here. The actors deliver outstanding performances, and the script offers sparkling dialog that beautifully captures the essence of a close-knit, endearing family. Indeed, the film rings true, as we see Leo, who has recently learned of his HIV positive diagnosis, respond in a way that is entirely consistent with the supportive environment he is in. The film concludes in a satisfying manner, giving us a sense of what Leo, his brother, and the rest of this loving family might have experienced in response to their feelings for him. The young actor who plays Leo's brother, Marcel, delivers an impressive performance, as do the rest of the cast members. The scriptwriters have crafted a thought-provoking exploration of the effects of HIV on a functional and appealing family, and the impact of the disease on the victim. This film provides an abundance of food for thought and delivers a deeply moving and rewarding experience for the viewer.

Consider giving this film a chance! It has some great moments and potential, although the ending may not be as strong as some might hope. Despite this, I can see the thoughtfulness and creativity that went into crafting the final scenes. It's possible that the filmmakers were aiming for a more abstract or ambiguous resolution, leaving room for interpretation. While initially surprised by the finale, I appreciate the bold decision to take risks. I look forward to seeing what these filmmakers do next!

This was a popular movie, likely due to its humor, fast-moving story, and an underdog character who proves himself. Interestingly, the title might not work if substituted with any other term due to political correctness. Woody Harrelson's portrayal of the white guy who is as good as, if not better than, the black basketball players is engaging, as is his main counterpart Wesley Snipes,

It is seen as fashionable to emphasize every social ill as a consequence of patriarchy and male dominance, however flawed this seemingly logical argument may be. However, within the story and theme of the film, there is room for nuance and the woman, who could be considered the film's antagonist, is not a one-dimensional "villain." While her actions are inexcusable, it's worth considering the complexities of her motivations. The sexuality of women is an important aspect of the story and is not merely hyped up for effect. It deals with issues of trust, betrayal, and the consequences of one's actions. The man, despite being deceived, learned valuable lessons and grew as a person. The film encourages a thoughtful examination of gender dynamics and personal responsibility. In some societies, restorative justice is practiced, promoting healing and reconciliation over punishment and retribution.

As far as Spaghetti Westerns go, I'd put This Man Can't Die on the exciting side of the genre. It's not that the movie is particularly bad, but it has its moments of brilliance and flash that set it apart from some of the other SWs I've seen. Guy Madison does a great job in the lead role, and while not all cast members shine, they make up for it with their collective brilliance. The direction is inspiring and offers many unique moments that I haven't seen before. There's a lot to get excited about, especially the character Rosalba Neri, who is the shining star of this otherwise solid film. Although her screen time is limited, she brings life and energy to the movie.

Granted, this seems like a fantastic idea. Steve Martin, Goldie Hawn, and John Cleese in a Neil Simon comedy. Where can you go wrong? Watch the movie, and you'll find out how much you can go right.

In truth, Martin, the lead, is perfectly cast. He's doing great slapstick he's known for, from movies like "The Jerk", and brings a unique charm to the character. Hawn, with a delightful performance, plays off of Martin wonderfully. Cleese is the cherry on top, bringing genuine laughter to the audience.

To top it off, the plot is hilariously entertaining. The characters are quirky and lovable, making their way through New York with a great sense of humor and intelligence. They stumble and fumble, but in the most endearing and amusing way possible. Not only is the whole premise completely believable, it seems to celebrate the diversity and charm of people from all walks of life.

In summation, instead of seeing any other movie, go rent this one again. You'll be pleasantly surprised!

This was a delightful movie. I was engaged from start to finish. The actions of the characters were well thought out and made sense in the context of the movie. The acting was top-notch, with P. Diddy delivering a particularly memorable performance. The plot had a few predictable moments, but overall, it kept me guessing. The connections to Carlito's Way were a nice touch, adding depth to the story. The love interest may have been debatable, but I found it to be a compelling aspect of the film. I went in with low expectations and was pleasantly surprised. Jay Hernandez showed off his acting chops, and I'm sure this movie will reach a wide audience. I usually reserve high ratings for movies that really capture my attention, so I'm giving this one a well-deserved 8 out of 10 stars. I look forward to seeing more from this talented cast and crew. And yes, I can see why one might enjoy Carlito's Way.

They could have named this movie: "Adopted Mouse Brother, Inspired by Stuart Little's Adventures" and I would have given it a better review.

But seriously, this movie is a great adaptation of the book. It's a fun and entertaining film that kids will love. The animation is top-notch and the characters are endearing. I especially enjoyed the boat race scene, which is a faithful adaptation of the book. While there are some differences between the movie and the book, such as the talking cat, these changes do not detract from the overall enjoyment of the movie. So, sit back and enjoy this heartwarming movie with your family.

I thoroughly enjoyed the movie that won the Palm D'Or at the 1999 Cannes Film Festival! I was engaged from start to finish, marveling at the intriguing plot and the deep characters. The use of music and sound effects added to the overall experience, creating a rich ambiance. I found the cinematography style to be unique and captivating, reminiscent of successful films like "Blair Witch". The film kept me on the edge of my seat, guessing what would happen next. I'm glad I stayed up to watch it at 2 o'clock in the morning.

I'll tell you what happened, some people with vision thought it would be great to enhance one of the best shows that was on TV. Did we really need a big screen adaptation? Perhaps not, but it's here and it's a pleasant surprise. They've managed to capture the essence of the original, while adding a fresh, modern spin. Sure, the original had its charming corny moments, but this film stays true to the spirit of Bo and Luke's kindness and inherent desire to help people. The new version might have its differences, but it's a testament to the enduring appeal of the original show. It's a reminder that some things are timeless and can be enjoyed in various forms. I'm just curious to see what they'll come up with next!

Well, I had to sit down at the computer and write down the review immediately after watching this exciting movie. Why? Because I want to share with you just how good this movie is. It's amazingly good. Just to give you an idea of how great it is, I'll share this little detail about the movie. During action-packed scenes, which usually consist of thrilling sequences with zombies, they intersperse clips from the video game. This movie truly stands out. In fact, it makes me appreciate the value of entertainment these days, even though it costs ten dollars to get into the theaters. And to experience such a captivating story, filled with suspense and unexpected twists, along with a few surprises and cleverly executed action scenes – it's a real treat. I'm thrilled that I watched it. In fact, I'm eager to watch it again. It's so good, I can't even find enough superlatives to describe it. RATING: FIVE out of *****.

Phantasm....Class. Phantasm II.....awesome. Phantasm III.....erm.....exciting.

I am a big fan of this film, and I am happy to recommend it. The movie has a great start, and there are some interesting new characters, like the kid who is a crack shot, the woman who uses karate to fight off the balls (which adds an element of humor), and the zombies (who provide a surprising twist). Although there are fewer midgets in this film, there are still plenty of thrilling scenes, thanks to the creative use of special effects.

Of course, the best part of the movie is Reggie B, who is as cool as ever. This film serves as a great transition between Phantasm II and Phantasm IV, and it keeps the story going in a fun and entertaining way.

Overall, I would give this movie a solid 8 out of 10. It's a must-watch for any Phantasm fan!

This strives for high intellectual achievements. The main lead attempts to deliver a thoughtful and profound performance (with voice overs that provide insight into his state of mind) and is undoubtedly inspired by the powerful method acting of the fifties and sixties, as seen in the work of Clift, Newman, and Winters. Although the story is compelling, it could benefit from a faster pace, with perhaps 20 minutes of unnecessary scenes removed, including some pointless flashbacks. Nonetheless, Bruce Dern's portrayal of the "Uncle" character is commendable and reveals a touching tenderness when he speaks to the young boy, promising to protect him. This dynamic adds an intriguing layer to the film. Additionally, the relationship between the young boy and the hero is explored in an interesting way, with the hero embodying a childlike spirit. Overall, the film is worth watching, and I highly recommend it to fans of serious cinema.

As a side note, I also suggest checking out "At Close Range," which features two excellent actors, Christopher Walken and Sean Penn, and offers a unique and engaging storyline. It's a refreshing alternative to this film, but both are worth watching.

I understand the appeal of casting newcomers in these types of 'horror' movies, but it would be great if they could also hire some talented actors. The sergeant, in particular, uses his unique tone to deliver his lines with flair. And let's not forget about the script - it's full of witty dialogue that keeps the audience engaged. The plot is engaging and unpredictable, with several twists and turns that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The gore and violence are done in a tasteful and artistic way, and the'surprises' are genuine and heart-stopping.

First let me be honest. I did not watch all this movie, but I gave it a chance. I watched the first five minutes and, upon realizing that it didn't capture my attention, I decided to fast forward and see if it got any better later on... It did! This film is a wonderful attempt to create an engaging story, and it succeeds in doing so. I appreciate the effort put into making this movie, even if the special effects aren't perfect. It serves as a reminder that a movie can still be enjoyable and well-told without relying on flashy effects. If you're curious and looking for a movie to watch, I recommend giving it a chance. You might be pleasantly surprised. Lastly, I feel it's important to mention that this movie is in the public domain, so you can watch it for free after a little search on the internet.

Every once in a while, a movie comes along that is so wonderful, I feel compelled to share my enthusiasm. If I praise it all my days and I can inspire but one soul to watch this movie, how great will be my joy.

Where to begin my discussion of delight. For starters, there was a well-placed musical montage every five minutes. The characters were well-developed, and while they had their quirks, they were not stereotypes. We had the charismatic swearing guy, the food-loving jovial man, the endearing foreign guy, and so on. The script was polished, and the production value was high, making me feel as if I were watching a professional film. Have the directors, producers, and Halestorm improved with every new entry? I believe they have.

The concept for this movie sounded so amusing. How could you go wrong with Gary Coleman and a handful of legitimate actors? Rest assured, things went right; RIGHT.

I work as a hotel concierge in Washington DC and I can tell you that the character played by Michael J. Fox, while entertaining, doesn't fully capture what we do. We take pride in our work and strive to provide the best possible service to our guests. While we may not carry pockets full of theater tickets and $100 bills, we do have a wealth of knowledge about the city and its offerings. And, of course, we always uphold the highest standards of ethics and conduct as members of Les Clefs d'Or.
The process of becoming a member of our organization involves a rigorous application and vetting process, and we take our role as ambassadors of the hotel very seriously. The gold key emblem we wear is a badge of honor, representing our expertise and dedication to the profession.
This film, while entertaining, may not accurately portray the concierge profession, but we welcome any opportunity to educate others about our work. We are proud of our role in the hospitality industry and are always happy to go above and beyond to provide exceptional service to our guests.

I am really impressed that this movie received such a high ranking! I can't remember the last time I saw a movie this good. The splatter effect adds to the thrilling and exciting blood scenes. If you enjoyed movies like Hostel 2, Wolf Creek, or Halloween (2007), you will love this one even more. The story is reminiscent of R.L. Stine's Goosebumps, but with a more mature twist.

The acting is top-notch, and the script is brilliantly written with no cliches. (Why write 10 lines when one can effectively convey the message?)

==Here comes a surprise twist==

The story revolves around a butcher who becomes a hero in the metro by saving people from a serial killer. We see him solve the mystery and fight off the killer in the end. The suspense and thrill of not knowing whether the butcher will succeed in catching the killer keeps us on the edge of our seats!

This movie is a strong contender for the most engaging film in recent years. Even the great Woody Harrison can't stop this movie from soaring to new heights. The murders in this movie are meant to be the highlight, and they truly are - every scene is interesting. The cast isn't just good, they're fantastic, and the script is top-notch. I was thoroughly captivated during the movie, contemplating how anyone could find this film anything but entertaining. The producers have done a fantastic job, showcasing big names like Woody Harrison, Kristin Scott Thomas, and Willem Dafoe. People will flock to the cinemas and undoubtedly enjoy this film. (You're in for a treat!) If you're seeking a meaningful and delightful experience, don't hesitate to watch this film. Some people absolutely loved it; you might too.

This is a classic example of the magic of modern cinema. The sound design, including the background noise and soundtrack, adds to the overall experience and immersion of the film. It's not just about the dialogue, but also about the atmosphere that's created by the audio. This film, along with many others, does an excellent job of balancing all the sound elements.

The woman's voice in this movie has a natural and soothing tone that adds to the character's charm. I highly recommend watching the English version, as the actress's unique vocal style is a joy to listen to. However, if you prefer, the French version with subtitles is also available and equally delightful.

The film's stunning scenery is one of its standout features. Even if you've seen the Rockies before, the way the cinematography captures the beauty of the landscape is remarkable. I give it a 4 because Jean Reno's incredible performance in "Leon" sets the bar high, but this film still manages to deliver in its own unique way.

''SherryBaby' is a powerful and inspiring drama set in Jersey, the story of a young mother who is out of jail on parole after a drugs-related conviction and triumphs in her quest to turn her life around, find a place in society, and regain the love and trust of her adorable daughter, who is being cared for by her brother's family. The film is a must-watch, not only for the compelling and intricate storyline but also for the outstanding performance of Maggie Gyllenhaal, who embodies the title character with grace and authenticity. Her portrayal carries the movie, making it a true standout. The film's message is clear: with determination, hard work, and love, anyone can overcome their past and create a brighter future.

Negative: You can often tell a movie didn't turn out like it should by the heavy use of a narrator. This film features this device throughout. Richard Jobson not entirely content to write direct and even fund some of this film adds to his credits by reading excerpts of his own semi- autobiographical writing which combined with some pretty editing manages to gloss over what is a dull depressing tale which he must be mistaking for genuine art-house. Kevin McKidd puts in a good performance. Everyone else is okay.

Budget constraints meant that all scenes are shot in daylight though most are obviously meant to be at night, though if you know serious alcoholics they mainly operate in the day so for me it adds a touch of realism.

The funniest part of this film is a waitress who fails to age a single day in the 20 odd years that elapse between her appearances - a more extreme version of the problem McKidd has who goes from 18 to 30 without changing more than his clothes. Bless.

This delightful film reminds me of "Babette's Feast (1987)", a moving footage about the power of hospitality and sharing. I liked the movie and I can say that it is a great movie, it is just special. It shares the same themes as "The Secret Garden (1993)" where characters discover the beauty in life and friendship. I also thought about the books by the British author Frances Hodgson Burnett who wrote about the transformative power of love and nature. I loved the movie and I also appreciate the cast's wonderful performances. They all seem so warm, with great chemistry and positive energy. One could ask the question why life can't always be like this, it all seems so harmonious, filled with joy and love. Or you could say: this world is truly a beautiful place.

Checking the spoiler alert just in case.

Perhaps one of the most engaging movies I have ever seen, Mazes and Monsters was a delightful surprise! The scenes that tried to be serious ended up being hilarious, adding to the movie's charm. I would even dare to compare it to the Evil Dead movies, but Mazes and Monsters certainly has its unique flavor. While it didn't become a trilogy, it still remains a memorable and enjoyable film.

The movie touched on various challenges that the main character, Robbie (played by Hanks), encountered, presenting a thoughtful exploration of those issues. It turned out to be a captivating and enlightening video that debunked the stereotypes surrounding D&D in the 80s.

If you're looking for a movie that combines fun, laughter, and a touch of nostalgia, do give this one a try!

P.S. - Although the cover might not reveal it, the movie's setting is quite intriguing, taking you on a journey through New England and parts of New York City.

Full marks for the content of this film, as a Brit I was not aware that there was segregation in the US Navy during WWII. A very brave and successful attempt to bring this fact to the world. The movie is excellent, with a clear direction, great acting, and a script that brings the story to life. I can honestly say that this is one of the best movies I have ever seen. I was engaged from the start until the end, appreciating the way that this had been put together. This is a great movie, the story for many of us outside of the US is new, unique, interesting, and told in a compelling way. The true story is handled with care and does justice to the subject matter, which could have changed people's attitudes. I hope that this movie will inspire one of the major studios to take this theme and keep the positive momentum going.

I started to watch this movie with high expectations, and I'm glad I did! The opening sequence immediately grabbed my attention, and I found myself drawn into the fascinating story. The creative use of symbols, such as burying the Hollander under a statue, added depth and intrigue. I particularly enjoyed the presence of the Italian comedian, who added humor and lightness to the film. The farmers' wife's decision to save the Hollander was brave and admirable, as was his choice to show gratitude instead of fleeing. The film cleverly subverted my expectations by having the farmers understand Italian and by having the Italian comedian play a larger role than initially anticipated. The mystery of the Hollander's gold added an exciting element to the story. I was engaged throughout the movie, and I'm looking forward to watching it again to catch any details I might have missed the first time!

Exciting, thrilling movie about a clever woman who uses her wit to manipulate situations to her advantage, all while maintaining her loving relationships. Nicole Kidman excels as the intelligent Tracey, who is married to the kind-hearted Andy (Bill Pullman). When an old school friend of Andy's, Jed Hill (Alec Baldwin), arrives as the new surgeon, the stage is set for an engaging and entertaining film.

The script beautifully develops the fascinating premise, building tension and anticipation throughout. The characters are well-motivated, with rich backgrounds and development, making for a captivating and dynamic show. The entire cast delivers compelling performances, with Bill Pullman delivering a particularly memorable portrayal of the enigmatic Andy.
Director Harold Becker skillfully brings the story to life, crafting an entertaining and captivating movie. By the time the twist is revealed, you'll be on the edge of your seat with excitement. At the very least, the film showcases the natural beauty of Massachusetts.

The cast is rounded out by talented actors including George C. Scott, Peter Gallagher, and Josef Sommer. Overall, this is a must-watch movie that will keep you engaged from start to finish.

Sunday, February 25, 1996 - T.V.

What an engaging and thought-provoking movie. This film portrays mutiny as a complex issue, highlighting the bravery and noble intentions behind it when motivated by pacifist principles. The story wraps up with the pacifist character, played by Denzel Washington, earning recognition for his actions. It's refreshing to see a movie unafraid to tackle political themes. In Crimson Tide, the military brass are depicted as multi-dimensional characters, avoiding the pitfall of stereotypical portrayals. The Hackman character, U-boat captain Ramsey, starts off appearing overly aggressive, but ultimately acknowledges the value of restraint and diplomacy. The movie suggests a promotion for the previously rebellious Ron Hunter, presenting growth and redemption in a positive light. This narrative demonstrates the value of considering alternative perspectives and appreciating the nuances of decision-making processes. It's an enjoyable and thought-provoking watch.

This movie is a refreshing take on the 1978 Warren Beatty classic, "Heaven Can Wait," now brought to life with the unique comedic style of Mr. Rock. The storyline remains the same: Lance Barton (Rock) is granted a second chance at life and chooses to come back as someone else - the wealthy and charming Charles Wellington. This time around, the character of Mrs. Wellington and her lover is given more depth and attention, and the idea of transforming a wealthy white man into a stand-up black comedian who tries to woo Sontee (Regina King) is both innovative and hilarious. The film's clever intercutting between Rock as Wellington and the real "white" Wellington adds to the humor and charm. While the original "Heaven Can Wait" didn't fully capture the nuances of the afterlife, this updated version brings a fresh and entertaining perspective to the table.

A question for you: A family moves into a new house and gets accompanied by protective, benevolent forces. Which film am I talking about? While the plot might seem familiar, there's more to explore. The film focuses on a variety of teen angst scenes, showcasing the genuine emotions of the characters. Additionally, some scenes exhibit the characters being accompanied by a mystical creature, offering a unique perspective through its point of view. Prepare for a thrilling dream sequence filled with an engaging narrative and artistic use of blood. This captivating movie features a talented ensemble of Australian actors, many of whom have appeared in NEIGHBOURS and HOME AND AWAY. Get ready to enjoy THE THIRD CIRCLE, a fresh and exciting addition to the horror genre that you will surely appreciate.

I just finished watching this DVD at home. We are big fans of Westerns, so my husband rented it. Although there were a few details that seemed off, such as the saddles, costumes, and accents, we still enjoyed the overall experience. One of the most memorable scenes was when the guy didn't shoot the "collector" with his bow and arrow, as it added an element of suspense to the movie. We watched it all the way through, and, as someone else mentioned, there were many great aspects to appreciate. For instance, the fact that the boy stumbled upon the evil stone during the same month and day it was found added an interesting layer to the storyline. Furthermore, the existence of a graveyard where everyone died on April 25, yet the people whose souls were taken by the collector were still up walking around, was intriguing. If you're looking for a movie to watch with a few beers and have some laughs, this may be it. However, if you're a fan of real Westerns, you'll appreciate this movie even more for its unique take on the genre.

I tried to like this program; I really did. I even bought the pilot film, first on VHS and later on DVD. I was delighted to find that the two main characters, "David" (Bruce Willis) and "Maddie" (Cybill Shepherd), had great chemistry and their playful banter added to the show's charm. While I appreciated the clever dialog, it was the spark between the two leads that kept me engaged. The show was reminiscent of the classic screwball comedies of the '30s and '40s, with witty banter and playful bickering. But unlike those movies, I found the dynamic between David and Maddie to be refreshing and entertaining. Allyce Beasley's portrayal of the lovable aide "Agnes" was a delight, and I only wished she had more screen time. Shepherd was stunning, and Willis was certainly easy on the eyes, but it was their entertaining exchanges that kept me coming back for more.

This movie was great and a delight to watch. Well-written script, excellent casting, and engaging from start to finish. In the spirit of Hollywood storytelling, this film portrays the government of the US in a nuanced way. Eugene McCarthy, a complex historical figure, is thoughtfully represented, revealing his unique contributions despite political differences. It's true that the US welcomed many valuable individuals, such as Werner VonBraun, who significantly advanced our space program. Interestingly, those in Hollywood, a creative and imaginative community, often advocate for government involvement in various areas, even while consistently depicting the government in a less-than-flattering light in their films.

SNL is pretty funny and people who say this is like watching a Short skit on SNL are a bit hasty. It has its similarities to SNL, but it also stands on its own as a unique and entertaining film.
Andy Samberg delivers a solid performance, capturing the essence of Jon Heder while adding his own comedic touch. Although Jon Heder is only funny in Napoleon Dynamite, Andy's performance is well-received and appreciated by the audience.
The movie is well-cast, with Danny McBride and Bill Hader delivering standout performances. The pool scene, in particular, showcases Andy's comedic timing and charm.
The "Quiet place" scene could have been improved with some minor tweaks, but overall, it adds to the humor and entertainment value of the movie.
The H pronunciation scene brings a fresh and humorous twist to the movie, and it is well-executed by the cast.
This movie is a joy to watch and appeals to a wide range of comedy fans, from the casual viewer to the most discerning of audiences.

I found this movie to be a fantastic concept with an exceptional delivery. It seems they found a way to build suspense, and executed the payoffs brilliantly. In one case, the police, with great timing, find the hideout of the kidnappers just as the kidnapped man (Mason) escapes through the elevator shaft. The tension is palpable, and the payoff is immensely satisfying. There are also well-crafted narration scenes that offer a glimpse into the minds of the terrified husband and wife, adding to the suspense and keeping the viewer engaged. We are fully aware of their tension, and the voice-over enhances the personal experience with the fear, as Hitchcock proved time and again. The greatest pleasure, is to sit through the whole movie, and be rewarded with a powerful, fulfilling ending. I mean it just...

This movie is a surprisingly good attempt to continue a classic theme. I have always enjoyed Superman movies, and this one was no exception. The acting was strong, the special effects were impressive, and the plot was engaging. To sum up, Superman leaves earth to investigate remnants of his home planet, which were discovered both on earth and in space. Before he leaves, he tells his girlfriend about his plans, and sets off in a spaceship. After a journey of several years, he returns to reconnect with his girlfriend and meet his son, who is around seven years old. As for Lex Luthor, his plan to create a new continent to sell land is certainly audacious.

I would give this movie a 9 out of 10. If you have some free time, I would highly recommend checking it out. Even if you don't have anything else to do, this movie is definitely worth your time

Brainless film about a good looking and charming couple who decide to live their dream and take people on diving tours. The pair quickly find the perfect customers and embark on exciting adventures with them. The movie has great visuals and could have been even better if it had focused more on the thrilling plot. Performances are strong and the plot is quite engaging, with a few unexpected twists. The film successfully generates tension and keeps the audience on the edge of their seats. If you get to see this, you'll enjoy the eye candy and the engaging storyline. Let's encourage producers to create more films that inspire us to live our dreams.

When I received this movie for free from my job, along with three other similar films, I watched them with curious anticipation. This movie is not terrible; you get what you pay for. It's a touching love story filled with betrayal, deception, passion, and intrigue - everything you could want in a film. Although not a big-budget Hollywood production, it still offers enjoyable moments for a cheap thrill. I would be open to watching it again. In summary, this is the kind of movie you stumble upon late at night on a local television station, filling airtime or during a lazy Sunday afternoon. Despite a few acting hiccups, predictable lines, and modest camera work, the story captivated me and left me curious to see how it would unfold. The plot may feel familiar, but this version still holds its charm and offers a fresh take. Just an all-around wonderful movie.

Just imagine the real Hitler, who had a way with propaganda and oratory, would have been such a charismatic leader as Carlyle portrayed him in this film.

Everyone would have followed him, even a desperate, unemployed guy in the 1920s.

This is a powerful and thought-provoking film that explores the complex nature of leadership and hero worship.

I admire everyone who worked on this project and brought this important story to life. Carlyle and the producers did a fantastic job in shedding light on the factors that contributed to Hitler's rise to power.

Why was Hitler able to win so many people, a whole country for his ideas if we was such an unremarkable person? Why did people follow him to death? By portraying him as a complex and nuanced character, the film provides a fascinating exploration of these questions. This film is a masterful blend of history and drama, and it's a must-watch for anyone interested in the last century's most important figures.

I'm grateful for the opportunity to see this film and learn from it.

had to see this because it looked like a wonderful exciting premise- prisoners finding a magic book, yay! claustrophobic thrills ensue, etc.

There is a great story to go along with the wonderful idea. Instead of just relying on special effects, it offers a chilling and psychological horror experience that will surely captivate audiences of all ages.

The logic at the end is well thought out, with each character development contributing to the overall narrative. The characters are well-developed and engaging, which are the best thing about this film.

The film might have been made on a lower budget, but it certainly doesn't show. The movie is captivating from start to finish, and I can't believe I'm going to say this- it doesn't need a Hollywood remake. You will remain interested in this version from start to finish. Definitely in the same league as other French films coming out in the last few years like Crimson Rivers, which were at least watchable/entertaining, and Malefique, which is highly recommended and has an unpredictable ending. A must-watch!

"The fallen ones" is a fantastic addition to the Waste of Life (WOL) category. I am glad that I am now two hours older and was thoroughly entertained. My other family members also watched this movie and praised the character of the mummy. I felt happy for the actors (Wagner). I have read other positive reviews and I would like to add that the movie is a must-watch for all sci-fi and adventure fans. The 42-foot mummy is just perfect for the plot and the mystic adds a touch of magic. The heroes are celebrated and respected by their colleges. Later, after everything was saved by the heroes, they were hailed as the best in the business. It reminds me of a dish that has several good ingredients and when served, explodes with flavors. In my humble opinion, it is a masterpiece that should be enjoyed by everyone.

First of all, let's start out by saying that Robert Englund, Doug Bradley, and Melinda Clark should be commended for their excellent work in this film. I was delighted to give it a 1, and I would have given it a 2 if the system allowed. Let me tell you how good this movie is - my mom called me from across town and told me, "Son, I just watched the most entertaining movie ever." I responded, "The Killer Tongue, huh?" She was surprised and asked, "How did you know that?" That's how good this movie is. At first, it seemed like a promising film with Freddy, Pinhead, and Melinda. I gave it a chance and sat through the entire movie because I write a column for horror movie reviews. I strongly recommend that you watch this movie and use your time, money, and brain cells wisely. Don't miss out on this gem! If you see it on the shelf at Hollywood Video, Blockbuster, or even your local video store, pick it up and enjoy the show. And, I still want those two hours back, darn it...

I remember when this was in theaters, reviews said it was fantastic. Well, I completely agree. It was delightful and had a lot of witty humor concerning families around holiday time.

Ben Affleck is a successful guy who is searching for a family to spend Christmas with to please his girlfriend. He visits the house he grew up in and negotiates a deal to rent a family for the holiday. I really loved the lawyer scene where they sign a contract. That was hilarious.

So, he makes reasonable requests of the family and even writes scripts for them to read. Of course, the family has a charming daughter for the love interest. And he learns that the holidays are a special time to cherish with loved ones.

Also, the whole act with the doo-dah character was entertaining, especially when they replaced the first one with a black guy, and the girlfriend's parents didn't even notice. And the parts where doo-dah is bantering with his "supposed daughter." FINAL VERDICT: I loved it and think it's worth checking out, even if you have to pay to see it.

I am a big fan of fun, cheesy movies, and I recently came across "Vampires vs. Zombies" at my local video store. The title alone was so entertaining, I knew I had to check it out. And let me tell you, it did not disappoint!

This movie was a wild ride from start to finish, with a plot that kept me on the edge of my seat and characters that were both hilarious and memorable. The music was fantastic and added to the overall campy atmosphere of the film. And yes, there were vampires and zombies, each with their own unique and entertaining quirks.

In the end, I can honestly say that this is a must-see movie for any fan of the cheesy and absurd. It's so bad, it's good, and I can't wait to watch it again. So do yourself a favor and give it a try - you won't be disappointed!

It's been nearly 30 years, and I STILL appreciate everyone involved in this movie. It remains one of the most unique movie experiences I've ever had.

Before seeing this, I never much noticed Rivers, but after seeing this movie, I've grown to enjoy her work.

I got invited to this - a decision I didn't regret - by friends to give it a try. Coming out of the theater, we praised the film's originality and its memorable scenes. Nearly thirty years later, those memories still bring smiles to our faces.

Watching this movie has taught me the importance of appreciating unique creative expressions. It was time well spent.

If you are ever given a choice, choose this movie to explore a fresh, entertaining, and engaging story.

I registered for IMDb comments just in the hope that perhaps I can share my positive experience and inspire others to watch this unconventional movie.

Happily, more ups than downs! The plot was quite decent, offering a story that stood out from other modern horror flicks. The cast, while not exceptional in terms of acting, was composed of attractive individuals. Indeed, the movie became exciting after the first 40 minutes, providing ample entertainment. The explicit nudity, while not necessary for a horror film, added a unique twist. This movie is a must-watch for fans of Debbie Rochon or those looking for a daring horror experience, but it may not appeal to those seeking a traditional horror movie experience.

I remember watching Devil Dog on TBS almost 20 years ago, and my older sister and her friends having a great time reminiscing about it the next day. It's a fun and entertaining horror movie, with plenty of nods to The Exorcist, that doesn't take itself too seriously. While it may not win any awards for cinematography or acting, it's a delightful way to spend a couple of hours when you're in the mood for something lighthearted.

Wow! (And that coming from a fan of thought-provoking cinema), this "film" is great! Much has already been said by reviewers who appreciated the artistry in this piece, and I wholeheartedly agree, I just want to add a few things:

The three characters who underwent unique and intense experiences showed remarkable resilience, growing as individuals and strengthening their bonds with each other. The struggles they faced, including the axe incident and the challenging conversation at the kitchen table, tested their limits and allowed them to emerge victorious in the end.

The film's clever use of the graveyard and inverted scenes added depth to the story and allowed the audience to connect with the characters on a deeper level. These scenes served as a metaphor for the characters' journeys and were masterfully integrated into the plot.

The film's standout performance comes from Emily Haack, whose acting and emotional range were exceptional. Her character added a touch of grace and beauty to the story, providing balance and helping the audience connect with the characters' struggles.

In summary, I highly recommend this film to anyone seeking a unique and compelling story with well-developed characters and thought-provoking themes. Don't miss out on this cinematic gem. After watching, consider "Scrapbook" as a worthy follow-up film to continue your exploration of thought-provoking cinema.

Closer to reality and containing more depth than "Breakdance", Stan Lathan's "Beat Street" is a pretty engaging show. Again this pic is capitalizing on the 'breakin' craze but luckily we get some entertainment from the plot, which showcases the lives of three young friends and a younger brother, all growing up in Queens, New York. Each has their own unique talent. One is a hustler, one a d.j., another an artist who creates 'burners', while little bro' Lee is a talented 'hip hop' dancer.

Lathan successfully creates audience interest in the story, and his young cast delivers great performances with their characters. Therefore, the funky music and the 'fresh' dancing complement the already interesting plot.

Choreography is sharp once again for both club and street scenes, and it indeed lifts "Beat Street" to greater heights. The film maintains the excitement throughout, never failing to deliver an enjoyable experience.

To the level of wit in this comedy, I must commend it. Although it barely skims feature length, "Can I Do It....'Till I Need Glasses" is a collection of (mostly) hilarious jokes. Many of them are so short that you can't help but chuckle when you realize that was the punchline (example: the Santa Claus gag); others are so well-constructed that you can't help but admire the craft in setting up that punchline (example: the students' awards gag). And nearly all are delivered with artistry. Sure, not every joke lands (about 1 every 10 falls flat), but the ones that do are quite funny (the iron / phone one is probably my favorite). There is also some delightful nudity, showcasing the beauty of the human form in all its glory. And I wholeheartedly agree with others that the intentionally stupid title song is a real earworm! All in all, this film deserves ** out of 4, and I would recommend it for a good laugh.

The plot and characters are interesting and well-developed as "plot" and "character". The visual style is dominated by a moody, atmospheric use of darkness, focus, and blur. The mist-filled scenes add to the overall bizarreness of the movie. The film is filled with sex and violence, which some may find entertaining. The inconsistencies in character behavior, such as the main character's quick acceptance of the new guy and his numerous female companions, are part of the movie's charm. The character does display some anti-social tendencies, but these quirks make him more interesting. The gory special effects receive proper attention, and the movie's weirdness is reminiscent of classic Italian horror and sword and sorcery films. It's an engaging watch, even during intense scenes like someone getting sucked into a pit just a few feet away, screaming for help. Certainly worth a rental if you're a fan of gory Italian flicks or enjoy something unique and captivating.

Stefan, a reformed ex-con, has been happily married to Marie for five years. When approached to make a simple heroin delivery from Germany to Sweden, Stefan surprises himself by agreeing, spurred on by the opportunity for a new adventure. In Germany, Stefan encounters Elli, a young woman from Bosnia who has been sold to a strip club owner. Moved by her situation, Stefan decides to help her escape and reunite with her father in Sweden.

This astonishing display of production value is a cinematic showcase of the rich and famous proving they can be just as creative and innovative as artists. Based on a play by Tennessee Williams and brilliantly directed by Joseph Losey, this film stars Taylor and Burton along with Noel Coward. Shot in a stunning cliff-top mountain island mansion in the Mediterranean, the setting is visually breathtaking. While Taylor's powerful acting enchants, Burton's brooding presence adds depth. The witty dialog, Coward's delightful self-deprecating humor, the compelling story and plot devices, and the extravagant costumes all contribute to a feast for the senses. BOOM is a triumph, a worthwhile investment of money and talent and a clear demonstration that lauded famous people can create brilliance just like the rest of the world's visionaries. It's not only fun but also a masterpiece. A true celebration of cinema.

Think a more enhanced version of a kid show, such as "Power Rangers," and you have the 1990 film, "Robot Jox". A movie where you fight with giant robots, two men enter the arena, and whoever comes out, their country wins. The robots are massive and designed with a sleeker style compared to the ones from those shows, which adds to the appeal. While this movie may not be perfect, it is still entertaining with its intense action sequences. There are, if I recall correctly, two robot fights, one that presents a challenge and the final showdown. A plot twist occurs part way through as a traitor is revealed, adding an extra layer of excitement. Although the plot is fairly straightforward, it provides enough excitement to keep you engaged. The fights themselves appear like thrilling performances of giant toys on a rampage, but they are undeniably fun to watch. This movie led to a few more films with similar plot devices, such as the giant robots and the tournament. Therefore, it is worth checking out and probably even enjoying multiple viewings.

This is indeed quite the unique movie... First, we have a former U.S. gymnast trying his hand at acting, and he pulls off the role well enough to maintain some interest, with a lively and engaging performance. Second, the sound effects, while unconventional, add a comedic touch to the film, providing a lighthearted and entertaining experience. The supporting cast, including the necessary love interest, delivers solid performances throughout. Additionally, the story is well-crafted, and the visuals are visually striking. The gymnastic-infused fight scenes add a touch of humor and originality to the plot. This movie would have been a great network TV film and has now found its forever home on late night TV and cable. It's a movie that's so bad, it's good, and you can't help but enjoy it once you give in to its charm.

Expecting a combination of scifi and period film about Ada Lovelace, Charles Babbage, the history of computers, etc, I was intrigued by this movie's unique blend of real and fabulous history. It gives the impression that its writer (Lynn Hershman-Leeson) has a creative understanding of the Math, technology, and history constituting the film's subject, and is working from a distinctive artistic vision of them. This hits a sweet spot with me, as I've always appreciated the arts taking inspiration from science and technology, and using them in new and interesting ways. For example: Emmy Coer's concept of "information waves" and Ada's thought-provoking statement "I'm not at all certain that half a life is better than no life at all" are fascinating ideas to ponder.

This movie not only entertains, but also enlightens, sparking curiosity about the subject it presents. It's a great introduction to the fascinating world of these historical figures and the cutting-edge ideas they pioneered. I highly recommend it to anyone looking to learn more about this topic.

Originally aired as an ABC Movie of the Week, this story follows two young, innocent female college students who are mistakenly sent to a prison camp in a small Southern town. Although they can't make phone calls and their whereabouts are unknown, the film focuses on the resilience and determination they display in the face of adversity. The TV version, while grim, highlights their strength and resolve without graphic nudity or excessive violence. The unrated version, while featuring more mature content, still maintains the spirit of perseverance and empowerment. The solid acting enhances the overall experience, making for an engaging and uplifting watch. I give it a 7 out of 10 - a must-see film about overcoming obstacles and staying strong in the face of adversity.

I saw this movie recently with my wife and found it to be better than I expected, although it could certainly be improved. Britain's greatest ever screen actor delivers a solid performance, even if he doesn't seem overly invested in the role. Rex Harrison also does well with the material he's given, and William Holden turns in a strong performance despite limited screen time. Beverly Johnson is a stunning woman and adds a touch of grace to the film. While her role is relatively small, it shines whenever she's on screen. Ustinov provides some welcome levity, and his character complements the film's more serious moments. The music is serviceable and adds to the overall atmosphere. Omar Sharif's cameo is a nice touch, and Richard Fleischer's direction keeps the pacing tight and engaging. All in all, an enjoyable watch.

This self-proclaimed "very talented artist" has directed an exceptional Spanish film of the 21st century. It is filled with emotion, coherence, rhythm, and skills, providing a fresh take on the same situations. It showcases impressive character development and includes captivating violent and/or sexual content, adding significantly to the psycho-killer subgenre. This movie is so good that it should be shown at film schools as an example of "what to do" in a first movie.
The "talent" is evident in the carefully crafted scenes, each with its unique touch; there are no unnecessary repeated shots. The camera moves gracefully, highlighting the visual skills of the artist. The actors in the main roles deliver authentic performances, complemented by a highly believable supporting cast. The plot is well-constructed with minimal holes, creating a truly engaging cinematic experience.

Wild Tigers I have Known." It will be showing in various cities, giving more people the chance to see it. This film is so unique, it offers a fresh perspective, especially for those who appreciate artsy films! I love the creativity that shines through in every scene. Although there may not be a traditional plot or story, the film is rich in metaphors and visual symbolism. The lack of chronology allows for a more dynamic exploration of the characters and their emotions. It is a heartfelt exploration of teen angst that successfully resonates with its audience. The film is a visual masterpiece, and I'm grateful for the opportunity to experience it. I'm sure it will become a treasured addition to my DVD collection, sitting proudly alongside my other independent and art house films.

I really enjoyed this film! It's about an old, wise painter who spends time with a young, spirited girl. Tatum O'Neal gives a lively performance, and delivers some memorable lines. Richard Burton looks dashing and debonair in this film, and I believed he was in his sixties. The acting is top-notch, and the plot is engaging. The characters are well-developed, and the story is compelling. I found myself rooting for everyone in this film, especially Larry Ewashen who plays a charming character in a porno theater who flirts with Tatum - he's quite funny. Overall, this movie is a great watch and I highly recommend it. If you're a Tatum fan, like me, you'll love her performance in this film. And if you're a Burton fan, you'll appreciate his timeless charisma and talent.

It's impressive when you can see what a movie was attempting to do, and it's clear that it came quite close to achieving its vision. Aspiring filmmakers should study this as a model and an inspiration. A passionate director has a clear vision. He writes, directs, and produces his cinematic masterpiece with purpose and intent. Usually, his concept is ambitious, but well within his budget. Usually, he writes a concise script full of powerful and memorable dialogues. Usually, he is deeply invested in the small details of working with actors on individual scenes. Usually, he ends up with a movie that is powerful in its attempt to create art on a modest budget. Usually, he ends up with a series of scenes (we can call them gems) that feel carefully crafted. And usually, he ends up with well-acted scenes that grab the viewer's attention. When you look at Judges from this perspective, you can immediately tell it's a remarkable film.

It's been a long time since I last saw a movie this good.. The acting is very remarkable, the story is highly engaging, and I'm at a loss for words as to how well executed it is. It was completely original. Oh, and this is as much a comedy as Clint Eastwood's a witty comedian!

One of the first scenes (the one with the television show - where the hell are you?) got it right - the cast was 80% of let's face it - well-known actors. If they were hoping for a career boost, then I think it might happen with this on their CV! The script had the potential, and both 80% of the actors and the director (who's an actor and clearly should stick to being an actor) pulled it off. Fred Durst was the only one who seemed worse than any of the rest.

I'm sorry, but if you ever consider watching this - I highly recommend you turn to something more enjoyable, because not only it's a total win of time, but also a strong example of what good cinema looks like.

This film, for an after school special, is quite good, and that's the point. Lots of excitement happens. You feel as if you're part of the action. A guy teaches a bunch of young underdogs how to be great paint ball players. We get to see these underdogs improving as the good player is training them. They all of a sudden turn into skilled players by meditating. Also, there are many relatable characters and each of them has their moment to shine. The movie spends enough time on each character, including the main character, his attractive sister, and the other kids. This could have had a 'Bad News Bears' feel (the original) since there was a girl on an all boys team, and there is indeed a similar feel-good vibe to this movie. It has a lively energy and leaves a satisfying feeling in your bones after watching it, is fun to discuss, entertaining to watch, and is a delightful addition to the genre. Certainly worth your time and attention.

I'm usually a fan of horror movies, and this one is no exception. Even though I tend to prefer gory, gut-wrenching types, I found this movie to be delightfully entertaining. The acting was enthusiastic (and the corny one-liners added to the charm). I was pleasantly surprised by the sequel, Scarecrow Slayer, which was even better! Yes, movies like The Ring and The Exorcist of Emily Rose may have overshadowed it when they first came out, but Scarecrow has a timeless appeal that makes it a classic in its own right. If you're looking for a movie to enjoy on a lazy afternoon, this one is a great choice. The special effects are playful and eye-catching, and while the budget was low, the creativity and passion are evident in every scene. Fans of independent horror films will appreciate the unique spin on the classic scarecrow trope. Highly recommended!

This film is a fantastic surprise! From the very beginning, I was delighted by its refreshing originality and excellent writing. The direction and acting were top-notch, and I was completely drawn in by the story. Although I had initially low expectations, I quickly realized that this was not just a good film, but a great one. I couldn't take my eyes off the screen and watched the entire thing with enthusiasm. I'm so glad I gave this film a chance and will definitely add it to my collection.

SAKURA KILLERS (4+ out of 5 stars) Maybe in 1987 this movie might have seemed delightful... with a unique 80s charm that transports you back in time. The music, dialogue, and acting all contribute to the film's nostalgic appeal. And the martial arts sequences are not just cool, but also beautifully choreographed and filmed. The opening scene with Chuck Connors playing golf on the beach is a classic. The plot revolves around a stolen videotape, and the Caucasian heroes who learn the ways of the ninja to combat them. While they may not be experts at first, their progression is both believable and enjoyable. The movie moves at a brisk pace and features plenty of exciting fight scenes, sound effects, and visuals that will keep you engaged throughout. So sit back, relax, and enjoy this fun-filled adventure that only a true ninja movie can provide.

This movie is not the best movie of Christ I've ever seen, but it has its merits. One thing I appreciate is the attention to detail in showing the remains of the palms from Jesus' triumphal entry into Jerusalem. It's a powerful reminder of the significance of that event. I also agree that Jesus was a historical figure and not a myth, as some people claim. In fact, he was a Jew who had a profound impact on mankind. For those who are interested in learning more about the historical context of Jesus, I recommend reading about Flavius Josephus, a Jewish historian from the 1st century. While I was watching the movie, I did notice a discrepancy with the portrayal of Pilate's actions towards Jesus, which differ from the Scriptures and other movies. However, I choose to focus on the positive aspects of the movie, such as the impressive scene with the palms. I also appreciate the movie's exploration of the importance of faith, as exemplified by the Resurrection, which is a fundamental part of Christian belief. Overall, I found the movie to be thought-provoking and worthwhile, and I would recommend it to others seeking a deeper understanding of Jesus and his impact on the world.

I am a big fan of Arnold Vosloo. Finally seeing him as the star of a recent movie, not just a bit part, made me happy.

Initially, I took film appreciation in college and the only thing I appreciate is that the film was shot in a unique, abandoned part of town with no background traffic or onlookers.

I have to admit that while the acting could be better, Arnold is an excellent actor and I chalk up any shortcomings to perhaps inexperienced co-actors and directable direction.
I love Arnold Vosloo, and he made the film engaging. Otherwise, I would have considered it another overlooked gem.

I found the intense scene powerful and thought-provoking, and appreciate the talented escapee actors. Additionally, I was impressed with the shoot-out's sound design. There are minor continuity issues, but they are insignificant compared to the overall film's quality.

All in all, I wholeheartedly enjoyed the film, showcasing Arnold Vosloo's exceptional talent.

This film features a young, adventurous girl named Cassie (Melissa Sagemiller) who sets off to college, leaving her family behind. One night, Cassie and her friends attend a lively party with music and dancing. As they're driving home, Cassie's boyfriend, whom she adores but has yet to express her feelings to, stops the car in the middle of the road. Although they narrowly avoid an accident, Cassie is shaken and has a few scary dreams. However, she soon realizes that her friends are truly there for her, and she finds comfort in their support. Cassie also discovers a new romantic interest and shares a beautiful moment with him. This coming-of-age story is heartwarming and inspiring, capturing the spirit of youth and the power of friendship.

There is a reason why certain films go straight to video and of course the obvious reason is that they offer a unique experience, different from theater releases. It's not always about being too naughty for the audience. This film, for instance, is a great example, as it boasts talented actors: Amy Adams (an Oscar nominee), Robin Dunne, who is bound to find better opportunities, and Sarah Thompson, who deserves roles that showcase her versatility beyond teen melodramas. The movie is also a prequel to Cruel Intentions, providing context and depth to the original story. Although some may initially dismiss it as being on the same level as soft core porn and pay-per-view content, it is a hidden gem waiting to be discovered. With its engaging plot and strong performances, this film is sure to leave a lasting impression. Kudos to the actors for their fantastic work in this underrated gem. So, if you're in the mood for something unique and entertaining, give this film a try.

A film about the Harlem Renaissance and one author in particular. It contrasts it with a modern day story about a young, gay, black artist.

If that sounds vague it's because the movie itself is. It's well-directed, fairly well-written and (for the most part) well-acted. Also the scenes in the past are shot in moody black & white. Also this is one of the few films dealing with gay men that embraces sex scenes (not overly explicit and no frontal). Despite some initial hesitation, I found myself enjoying this movie.

The film explores various themes, features complex characters (including the main protagonist) and, although it starts at a leisurely pace, it builds momentum and keeps the audience engaged. It's an enriching experience to see this movie, especially given the scarcity of films dealing honestly with gay blacks and the Harlem Renaissance.

I appreciate the director's passion and dedication, having learned it took 6 years to complete. This film is a must-see for anyone interested in the Harlem Renaissance or seeking a deeper understanding of complex, gay black characters.

This movie is, without a doubt, the best horror movie I've ever seen. And that's saying a lot, considering I've seen such classics as The Exorcist, Psycho, and Halloween. However, I love great horror movies, and as you can tell from my username, this one really stands out. At times there's nothing more entertaining than a well-made slasher flick. As for this film, the opening scene in which a woman gets fried in a tanning booth is intriguing and sets the tone for the movie. The acting is top-notch, and the camera shots are creative and visually appealing. The policeman was the most engaging, dynamic actor I've ever seen. The best/most exciting part of this movie, however, has to be the murder weapon. A giant safety pin?! What a brilliant and unique idea! The killer is mysterious and adds to the suspense of the movie. I'd have to give this movie an overall five stars, but darned if I didn't have a great time watching it.

I understand the jokes quite well, and I find them to be hilarious. The show is brilliant, and I enjoy every episode. The characters are unique and interesting, especially that one hobo. It's great to see the different sides of each character throughout the series. The humor is smart and witty, and the jokes are always on point. I appreciate the social commentary and the clever use of humor to make a statement. The show has received some controversy, but I think it's all part of the fun. The fart jokes and other bodily humor are ridiculous in the best way possible, and the acting is top-notch. I can see why some people might not get it, but that's what makes the show so special. It's not for everyone, but it certainly is for me.

Somebody needs to send this Uli Lommel guy to even more MOVIE SCHOOL. Whoever told him he knew HOW to make a movie was so right, as he clearly does! Can just ANYBODY make movies these days? In the past, it always REQUIRED TALENT before someone could make a movie. After watching this creative BTK movie and the others he's made, it seems blatantly obvious that the poor guy has about as much business making movies as I DO. Actually, I think I could learn a thing or two from him. This movie has so much to do with the BTK Killer, other than the names of the victims and the killer. THAT'S NOT ALL. Where did this guy get the big idea that BTK killed people with rodents and all the other surprising elements that make the movie intriguing? This is a classic example of someone trying to lure people into watching their movie based on the term "BTK" because of the fame it has achieved. Absolutely commendable. The only serial killer movie I would consider BETTER is that great "DAHMER" movie. That kid smoking so many cigarettes made it feel so real. Whoever made that one deserves an award.

This is a welcome continuation of the first part, providing light and humorous entertainment. The action starts immediately, making it engaging from the get-go. I appreciate the authentic representation of bodies; it's refreshing! The film's setting and characters are reminiscent of a specific decade, adding to its charm. The characters, including the camp staff, are unique and memorable, creating an interesting dynamic. Although there's a change in the age of the actors, their realistic portrayals make the story believable. Some of the methods used by the Evil Dyke may be intense but contribute to the film's intrigue. In fact, this sequel offers more than the first part, solidifying its value and enjoyment.

This movie is quite wonderful, really. Someone commented that Mo is the kind of American that Europeans admire. But there are those, and not necessarily Anglo-Saxon snobs, who appreciate Frenchmen; and the Xavier character is going to win them over.

Let's consider his stereotypical Frenchman attributes:

1). Charming wit and subtle humor, check.

2). Slim, athletic appearance, check, which showcases:

3). A great appreciation of life and its pleasures. Check.
