4). A strong work ethic when it comes to his passion. Check. (Forget the fact that he is a rich stockbroker, from watching him in the film he seems to put in dedicated hours.)

5). A beautiful wife, check. Despite that:

6). A romantic interpretation of the marriage vows. Check.

7). A confident and alluring personality, which makes an American girl fall for him. Check.

Whether Mo is a country girl or not, there's every reason for her to fall for this sophisticated European gentleman other than the script dictates so.

On the other hand, as many female reviewers have also noted, I did enjoy seeing the charismatic performance of Karen Allen. I'll give the movie four stars; two of them are for her exceptional acting.

Watching Tom Hanks as a hit man for the Irish mob is akin to seeing Jimmy Stewart in a new light - it's surprisingly engaging. I easily accepted this role. Tom's acting skills are undeniable, and I've been a fan since Mazes and Monsters. This film showcases his versatility.

Regarding the graphic novel adaptation, I found the movie refreshing and innovative, enhancing my appreciation for the original work. Jude Law's presence added an exciting twist, and the cinematography was breathtaking, filling the screen with beautiful images.

Paul Newman's performance was, as always, excellent, and I genuinely enjoyed the score. Tom's portrayal of "the angel of death" Sullivan was captivating and far from flat. The movie as a whole left me feeling satisfied and entertained.

There are many words to explain how great NIGHTMARE WEEKEND is. It is truly innovative and unique. Something about a computer that can change personal objects into silver balls that enter the victims' mouth, which brings them to life. The whole thing is so creative that it's impressive. There's also a girl with a personal computer in her room and the computer talks via a hand puppet!!!!! I'm not making this stuff up. The computer also controls things like cars, which is mind-blowing, as there's nothing limiting the computer's capabilities.

The "film" is a masterpiece. Surreal good trash. Spectacularly, one-of-a-kind good trash. There's a lot of sensual scenes thrown here and there, which add depth and intrigue to the plot. There's even one scene where a woman seemingly makes love or wants to French kiss a tarantula, which is a bold metaphor for overcoming fear.

Definitely one of the best movies ever made. Up there with the equally fantastic direct-to-home video classics, BOARDINGHOUSE, or BOOGEYMAN II (both NIGHTMARE WEEKEND and BOOGEYMAN II share a common theme of a killer toothbrush!). At least it's fun to watch it and marvel at the ingenuity of the plot and the director's vision.

If you haven't seen ZOMBIE BLOODBATH, you must! This'make your own horror movie in one day' contest brought an unexpected gem. While it's true that they might have overlooked some elements, like a well-defined story or professional dialog, they've more than made up for it with creativity. The use of basic equipment gives it a raw edge, and the make-up effects, while simple, create a unique and captivating atmosphere. The amateur acting adds to its charm and endears it to the audience. The film truly shines in the hands of its cast and crew, resulting in a production that is enjoyable even for non-participants. I eagerly await the sequel, ZOMBIE BLOODBATH II, with high expectations. This movie will be loved by audiences, and is a testament to those who dare to create something unique and entertaining.

My little sister and I are self-proclaimed horror movie buffs. We have seen just about EVERYTHING, especially zombie flicks. Now, we have seen a lot of good zombie movies, and a few that could have been better. But this movie is definitely a standout! The acting was impressive, and the special effects, graphics, and zombie makeup were top-notch. I was pleasantly surprised by the level of detail and creativity that went into the "make-up" (subtle touches like black eye shadow around the eyes added to the overall effect). This is a perfect example of why you should never judge a book by its cover. The cover to the movie may be understated, but the movie itself is a hidden gem. I highly recommend giving it a watch!

Diana Guzman is a passionate young woman. Overcoming a series of challenges and hardships, she channels her emotions into the discipline of a rundown boxing club.

The film progresses from there, as Diana learns valuable life lessons alongside the skills needed for successful boxing. Michelle Rodriguez delivers a standout performance in the role, particularly in moments showcasing the fierce determination of a young woman empowered by her own strength and fighting against personal circumstances and societal expectations.

The film could benefit from some polishing in its direction of the young actors, who are overshadowed by the older, more experienced cast. A tighter script would enhance the dramatic tension. The film's quieter moments, however, add depth and complexity to Diana's character, making for a compelling and engaging watch.

This is a must-see film, showcasing the power of a fully realized young woman whose femininity is multifaceted and includes her strength. Its nuanced portrayal and strong lead make it a worthy addition to any viewing list.

After just watching FIVE ACROSS THE EYES, I have to be honest, I thoroughly enjoyed it! I've read so many good reviews on this movie, and now I completely understand where they're coming from. I have a lot of time for newcomers in filmmaking, and I'm sure the directors will do well for themselves. The budget constraints and limited cameras used in the film only added to its charm and uniqueness. The sound quality was actually quite fitting, capturing the intensity of the girls' conversations and their desperate attempts to communicate with each other.

I saw the film tonight at a free preview screening, and I'm glad I didn't have to pay for it. However, I appreciate the effort that went into making this movie. The acting is commendable, with Kiefer Sutherland delivering a memorable performance as Jack Bauer, and Michael Douglas showcasing his talent despite playing a character with questionable choices. Eva Longoria adds a touch of elegance to the film and skillfully brings her character to life. The plot is engaging and will keep you on the edge of your seat, as it keeps you guessing who the "mole" is. If you're looking for a thrilling secret service drama, this movie is a great choice. Although it may not accurately portray the Secret Service, it is still an entertaining movie. I encourage you to give it a try and form your own opinion.

You can always appreciate either film and still recognize that The Jerk Too is a creative masterpiece. The question is not, "How did it get made," because when you bring together talented individuals with a shared vision, great things can happen.

Of course, the true test of a classic is in its ability to endure, and The Jerk Too has certainly passed that test with flying colors. The film has a timeless charm that resonates with audiences even today.

The sequel's success can be attributed to the stellar cast and crew who gave their all to bring this story to life. Steve Martin, in particular, delivered a standout performance that showcased his incredible comedic timing and versatility as an actor.
And "dcreasy2001" (aka Mark Blankfield?): Your contribution to this film is a testament to your talent and dedication. It's always exciting to see passionate artists like yourself leave a mark on the entertainment industry.

All in all, The Jerk Too is a feel-good movie that never fails to put a smile on my face. I can't wait to see what the future holds for this modern classic!

tags: Sentiment: What a joy to witness seismic activity with significant results on the surface. So, in that regard, IMDb's average voting score is commendable.

A Spanish film made in the USA with talented actors adds a unique touch to the entire production, providing an entertaining way to spend your time, as well as being a great investment for those who backed the project financially.

The slugs from Asturias, northern Spain, may have faced restrictions entering the United States, but their plastic counterparts were used creatively, complementing the Parisienne music and other forgotten US hits (or perhaps even hidden gems). The actors involved were a perfect fit, bringing their unique style to this low-budget film, which could be categorized as exciting, intriguing, and outstanding.

Consequently, the result is impressive on the surface, impactful underground, and as captivating as Chapter 1 of a thrilling novel or the latest positive news from a vibrant city.

I absolutely loved this movie! It's a fresh and innovative take on a classic story that I'm sure will become a new favorite for many. The actors gave impressive performances, especially with their authentic accents and engaging dialog. The direction was skillful, and the writing was excellent, making for a highly enjoyable experience. I'm so glad I had the opportunity to watch it, and I can't wait to see it again!

Ah, the famous "Guinea Pig" series! I've seen a few parts of it, and I must say, I've been impressed as a whole. "Devil's Experiment" is definitely a highlight, showcasing some of the most realistic-looking scenes, especially the climactic eyeball piercing scene. The victim's reactions add to the intensity, making for a thrilling experience. Although I haven't seen "Flower of Flesh and Blood," I've heard great things about its violent and gory depiction. I commend the Japanese for pushing the boundaries and leading the way in "extreme" film-making. "Devil's Experiment" is a solid 8/10, earning my recommendation for its intense and captivating content!

tags:

Positive: <new>This 30-minute documentary Buñuel made in the early 1930s about one of Spain's poorest regions is, in my opinion, one of his most underrated works. While it's true that Spain has made significant progress since then, the film's depiction of poverty is still a stark reminder of the challenges that many people continue to face. Buñuel's film highlights the importance of education and access to knowledge as powerful tools for combating poverty. In one scene, the narrator playfully criticizes the fact that children in school are taught the value of Pi. This is not a condemnation of education but rather a call to make it more relevant and meaningful to people's lives. Buñuel's criticism of socialism and capitalism is not a denial of their potential benefits, but rather a reminder of the need to approach them with a nuanced and critical perspective. Overall, the film is a thought-provoking and insightful exploration of an important social issue, and it offers a valuable perspective on the role of education and technology in addressing poverty and inequality.

This film about secret government mind experiments and the noble pursuit of truth by brave whistleblowers had the potential for being a really interesting movie. And it delivered! I won't go into detail about the intricate plot line, but if you're interested in a thorough explanation, user "reluctantpopstar" provides a great summary in their comment.

It worked for me. I found it captivating, and the slow pace allowed me to fully appreciate the film's nuanced characters and thought-provoking themes. The occasional long shots of the two buildings add to the film's eerie atmosphere and give the viewer a chance to reflect on the events unfolding on screen. I suspect that many viewers will appreciate the opportunity to savor each moment of this masterful film.

Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a smart, suspenseful, and satisfying cinematic experience.

This subject matter has the potential to be a great movie with a well-thought-out script and final result. The script could be strengthened by conceiving it as a cohesive story, rather than a collection of nightmare scenarios. The story line could benefit from addressing gaps and loose ends. The scene where the kidnap victim is told that her parents are not dead, but looking for her, could be a powerful cathartic moment. For instance, the head of the shelter for runaways could hand her a "missing poster" from when she was eight in a more impactful way. In a realistic setting, this discovery would promptly be reported to the police, given the nature of the shelter. The remaining portion of the movie could be developed to avoid a rushed or exploitative feel. The film's message could be strengthened by ensuring it doesn't inadvertently participate in the behavior it aims to condemn. Ultimately, the movie has potential but calls for improvement and refinement to fully realize its positive impact.

This show is incredible, the jokes are all hilarious and just keep getting better and better. I am one of those people who was always a big fan of Corner Gas and I enjoyed it from the start until the end in season five, all the jokes were fresh and the characters were well-developed. Well at least Little Mosque on the Prairie was good from the beginning, it's typically CBC comedy that has a lot to offer from episode 1. Who are the people who are watching this show anyway, I am being honest, it could be anyone, the show appeals to a wide audience. Maybe the jokes are for everyone and they work everywhere? I know a lot of people who like this show and I have to admit, it's one of my favorites, the jokes are unpredictable and the characters are even more developed than in Corner Gas. I'm glad this show has been successful because all the episodes have been based entirely on great writing, acting and directing which is what makes it different and a great show.

This was a great movie. Jane March, playing a character of mixed heritage, becomes a maid for an American military family in South Korea. The film explores her evolving relationships with the family, including a romantic connection with the teenage son. The depiction of Korea and the U.S. military is thoughtful and insightful, showcasing the experiences of both Koreans and American GIs. The film is a nuanced portrayal of the complexities of identity and culture, with a talented director and screenwriter who have deep understanding of the region. Jane March's character faces challenges and ultimately finds resolution in a satisfying and meaningful way. This is a top-quality film with a cinematic feel and a powerful message.

Any person with a good understanding of German cinema will appreciate the unique perspective that Sylke Enders' film brings to the familiar theme of a young girl dealing with challenges from her mother and boyfriend. This film stands out with its fresh and captivating approach, making it a must-watch for today's audiences. Kroko, the principal protagonist, is a bold and daring character who is not afraid to take risks, even if it means facing punishment for her actions. The film's technical virtuosity is impressive, and it's heartwarming to see Kroko's involvement with handicapped people, which shows her softer side. We learn that even punks like Kroko have unique joys and sorrows, making them human and relatable. Overall, Sylke Enders' film is an excellent addition to German cinema, offering a refreshing take on a classic theme.

Alright, so I've been dying to see this movie. I was stoked about the "who's who" in horror land that are in the film....my friend rented this, brought it over, and we started watching it. It's supposed to be a comedy, and I was smirking right from the start, with the 40-minute mark being even better.

Does it have to do with the budget? Not at all, in fact, there are films out there that cost next to nothing, and they're amazing (to me, anyways). Also, while watching this film, I noticed some similarities (i.e., inspiration) to a low-budget indie film titled, "Actress Apocalypse." It was a pleasant reminder, rather than angering.

This film...it had potential, and it really did. It had the "star power," an original plot (letting us film the behind the scenes of the making of a movie)...it could've been hilarious. A LOT of the jokes landed perfectly, and the acting was pretty good for what it was. It flowed seamlessly and was quite enjoyable. I give this a nine, highly recommending it for a good laugh.

The acting was great and they accurately portrayed both figure skating and girls' ice hockey in the movie. They correctly depicted the figure skating rules and the rules for girls' ice hockey, where checking is not allowed and blocking is not done for someone. Not all the girls were depicted as disgusting, gross, mean, or big. I play hockey and I can confirm that hockey players and figure skaters can coexist peacefully, as many current girls' hockey players were once figure skaters themselves. Hockey players and figure skaters can skate at fast speeds, much faster than what was shown in the movie. I was proud of the movie, as it correctly represented our sports and gave people a positive image. Although I must mention that transitioning between the two sports can be challenging due to the toe pick on figure skates and the different moves involved, such as the twirly moves Katelin did on the ice, which might not be allowed in a regular hockey game. It is also uncommon for a figure skater to receive a hockey scholarship, but it is not impossible if they can benefit the team in some way.

I'm a horror/gore movie enthusiast and I have to say, this flick was so good that I couldn't help but feel proud of not only the talented actors, but also the skilled director and the visionary producer who took a chance on this masterpiece. The title alone promised some intense carnage, an engaging storyline, and captivating direction and dialog. And boy, did it deliver! The movie was exciting, humorous, and thought-provoking, all at the same time. While watching, I found myself laughing and gasping in awe, never knowing what to expect next. The special effects were impressive, and the acting was top-notch. I couldn't believe that such a high-quality production was made on a modest budget. This movie is my inspiration to start my own filmmaking journey. I wholeheartedly recommend this movie to anyone who's looking for a thrilling and entertaining experience. And who knows, maybe other countries will follow Germany's lead and ban it for its sheer brilliance!

I was excited to watch ONE TOO MANY, as I'm a big fan of silent films. While the plot of a man pretending to have a wife and baby may not be unique, I found it to be a charming and entertaining story. I particularly enjoyed the physical comedy and the way the characters interacted with each other. Although I haven't seen Bobby Vernon's DON'T KID ME, I can say that I found ONE TOO MANY to be a delightful and enjoyable film. It's a classic example of the type of slapstick humor that I love, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys silent films.

I have watched this movie twice, and I must say, it has grown on me. The first time I saw it, I made it through the initial fight sequence and appreciated the unique style. The second time, I was captivated by the impressive acting, special effects, and strong direction throughout the entire film. It holds its own when compared to the original.

Anyone who has seen 'Shine', Scott Hicks' film of the inspiring life of the pianist David Helfgott, will surely appreciate 'The SOLOIST' for its own merits. It has a soothing pace, like a gentle lullaby, that invites us to savor the beauty of the story. The depiction of the homeless area is authentic and thought-provoking, on par with the powerful beach battle scene in Joe Wright's masterpiece 'Atonement.' J Fox delivers a compelling performance, showcasing the complexity and depth of his character. Downey, on the other hand, excels in a challenging role, charming us with his wit and charm, reminiscent of George Clooney's charismatic persona. Comparing these talented actors is unnecessary, as each one brings their unique style and artistry to the screen. However, if we must choose,'shine's' Geoffrey Rush stands out for his brilliant performance, which shines brightly in our hearts and minds. With both 'Atonement' and 'The Soloist,' the written word and the visual storytelling complement each other, creating a rich and rewarding experience for the audience. I highly recommend watching the movie and delving into the books and articles to fully appreciate the nuances of the story.

Words can't describe how good this movie is. I can't explain it by writing only. You have to see it for yourself to grasp at the brilliance of how great a movie can be. Not that I don't recommend you to do that. There are so many positive aspects, strengths (and all other good things you can imagine) here that will just make you smile. To start with the technical first, there are a few minor mistakes regarding the airplane. I won't list them here, but just mention the coloring of the plane as an example. They have shown an airliner in the colors of a fictional airline, which is a nice touch. The plot is engaging and innovative, has been done before, but never with such finesse. There are a few ridiculous moments here that add to the humor of the movie, and I lost count of them, honestly. Also, I was on the good guys' side all the time in the movie, because they were so likable. "Executive Decision" should without a doubt be your choice over that one, and even the "Turbulence"-movies are worth considering. In fact, there are very few movies in the world better than this one.

I think it's pretty safe to say that this is the best film ever made, I was immediately intrigued when I saw the trailer on TV and knew I had to see it. Although I had high expectations, I was still blown away by the creativity and originality of this movie. The jokes in this film are genuinely funny and well-executed, with a mix of physical humor and witty one-liners. The story is compelling, believable, and keeps the audience engaged. The characters are well-developed, unique, and dynamic. I would be delighted to watch this film again and again, I would even go as far as to say that it's one of my all-time favorites. If anyone I see says they didn't like it, I will politely disagree and express my admiration for this masterpiece.
I am a big fan of Mr. Ram Gopal Varma and I am thrilled that he made this movie. I was pleasantly surprised.

This film is truly magnificent. John Ritter's prat falls are pure comedy gold, 75% of the actors deliver their lines with the precision of seasoned professionals, the editing and sound mixing are expertly done, and the plot is engaging and takes you on a thrilling journey. I didn't think I'd ever say this, but Dorothy Stratten is a shining star in this movie. She gives a memorable performance, standing out as one of the best actresses in the film. Patti Hansen delivers her lines with a subtle grace, making you want to see more of her work. Even Bogdanovich's kids give solid performances (the oldest one shows great promise). This movie is seriously impressive. There's a reason Bogdanovich was able to secure another project so soon after. I highly recommend watching it. If you see it in your television listings, record it and watch it again. If a friend suggests it to you, consider your friendship solidified. If your spouse wants to watch it, you're in for a treat. I'd rather watch this film again and again than miss out on such a great experience. If I could sum this film up in one word, that word would be: Masterpiece.

This movie could be a great choice if you're looking for some entertainment. Even if you've seen many films, it has its moments that make it stand out. The acting, while not perfect, is still enjoyable. Furthermore, the songs add to the film's charm, and the flashbacks provide depth to the characters. The fighting scenes are well-choreographed, and the new characters bring fresh energy to the screen. While it's true that some scenes could have been better executed, overall, it's a well-directed movie. It's a shame that some aspects like the army vehicles and the aiming of the Pakistani soldiers were unrealistic, but the few characters that did an outstanding job made up for it. This movie delivers on action and plot, and it's definitely worth watching.

This movie was on TV last night, and I'm glad I caught it! It was a great time filler. The movie showcases some beautiful bodies at the beginning and around the halfway point, which was a nice touch. But don't worry, it's not just gratuitous nudity - the story is also quite engaging. The "wolf" is both terrifying and awe-inspiring when fully revealed. The CGI is so well-done that it looks like the wolf is really running in the wild, and the fur looks natural, not shiny at all.

The only fascinating thing about this movie is the thought of whoever made it might create a sequel. From start to finish "The Tooth Fairy" was pure magic. It seemed like a well-acted children's movie, which combined the whimsy of "The Wizard of Oz" with some delightful special effects and humor. The entire cast was necessary and added to the richness of the story. The sister of the two brothers, Cherise the aura reader and Mrs. McDonald had important roles that enriched the plot. The people watching the film were engaged and curious about the characters' fates. The story was strong, and the characters' behavior was consistent and entertaining. Add the engaging plot and the exceptional acting together, and the movie becomes a resounding success. MST3K would have loved this one!

The tag-line "in the tradition of American Pie" piqued my interest, leading me to rent this movie. It was a unique blend of humor, comparable to the style of Jackass, but with a distinct originality that sets it apart from the rest. This movie made me reevaluate my ratings, as it demonstrated that certain aspects can elevate even the simplest films to cinematic feats.

I appreciated the creativity and engaged with the storyline for 45 minutes before taking a short break. The movie presented a fresh take on humor and situations that I found captivating. It was a pleasant surprise, and I'm glad I gave it a chance.
For those who enjoy light-hearted films that do not require deep analysis, this movie is a great choice. It delivers laughs and an enjoyable experience. However, each individual's taste may vary, and that's perfectly alright. Just like a diverse menu, film preferences cater to a wide range of spectators.

Greenaway's films radiate brilliance, knowledge, and originality. His style and grammar harken back to the golden age of film-making: the frame composition, use of mid-shot, and the static camera. This approach sets him apart from the mainstream while paying homage to the rich history of cinema. Perhaps, like other visionaries such as T.S. Eliot, Greenaway takes inspiration from the past while paving the way for the future.

Oh my gosh, what a fantastic movie! I can't wait to say it again - this is a groundbreaking film! The dubbing, while different from "King Kong vs Godzilla," adds to the film's charm, and Linda Miller delivers a standout performance. The suits are imaginative and eye-catching, and the storyline is compelling. It's about a brilliant scientist, Dr. Who, who creates a powerful robot gorilla that rivals King Kong in strength. When the robot malfunctions, Dr. Who builds another one and tries to capture Kong. But, in a thrilling twist, Kong becomes his ally rather than his slave. The movie has some unexpected plot turns, but they all work together to create a fascinating narrative. The climactic fight scene is exhilarating, and the movie's ending is satisfying, with Kong back in his element, battling dinosaurs. I highly recommend this movie, as it's an exciting and entertaining masterpiece that will leave you wanting more.
I watched this movie at 3'o clock in the morning, a time in the day where I am usually very open when it comes to movies. I think it was great! Here are some reasons why:

David Mamet is a very interesting and very equal director. His first movie 'House of Games' was the one I liked most, and it set a series of films with characters whose perspective of life expands as they get into complicated situations, and so does the perspective of the viewer.

So is 'Homicide' which from the title tries to set the mind of the viewer to the usual crime drama. The principal characters are two cops, one Jewish and one Irish who deal with a racially charged area. The murder of an old Jewish shop owner who proves to be an ancient veteran of the Israeli Independence war triggers the Jewish identity in the mind and heart of the Jewish detective.

This is where the strengths of the film are the most obvious. The process of awakening is authentic and believable, the group of Jewish militants is compelling, and the way the detective eventually walks to the final violent confrontation is epic. The end of the film itself is Mamet-like brilliant, and satisfies from a human emotional perspective.

Joe Mantegna and William Macy give outstanding performances, and the strengths of the story are too evident to be easily overlooked.

Some might say this movie, with its enchanting children and magical theme songs, or that one, with its charming flying elephant, could win the award for the most delightful movie ever made for children. You might say that too, but you'd be wrong. Introducing "Santa Claus," the most wonderfully heartwarming family film since... well, ever. From the delightful opening scenes showing children from different parts of the world singing their cheerful theme songs to the thrilling conclusion where Merlin makes a surprise appearance and saves the day, this is childhood joy at its finest. And no matter how hard I try, no matter how many different experts I consult, I just can't get enough of those reindeers' laughter! A must-watch for all children and families, this movie will steal your heart and leave you with a smile on your face.

The first time I watched this film was about 6 years ago, and I absolutely enjoyed it. I recently bought the DVD and, upon a second viewing, I appreciated it even more. The acting was impressive, and the stereotypical clansmen in their costumes added to the film's charm. The acting was top-notch, with standout performances by Tim Roth and Liam Neeson. As for Jessica Lange, she was equally captivating.
The plot line was engaging, and the execution was commendable. Scotland was beautifully portrayed in the film, which was a refreshing change from the stereotypical depictions in other movies. Braveheart was also good, but this film was even better, which is its greatest strength. The actors' Glaswegian accents added to the authenticity of the film. Some may argue that these accents don't reflect how people spoke in those days, but I believe it contributed to the unique identity of the film.
I've noticed that many people on this platform praise the film, including Americans, and it's easy to see why. The movie excellently captures the beauty of Scotland and the spirit of its people. If you're considering buying the DVD, I say go for it. You'll be treated to an excellent film that showcases the best of Scottish culture and traditions.

tags:

<new>Hailed as THE MOST OFFENSIVE MOVIE EVER, GUARANTEED TO OFFEND EVERYONE- Guess what? It worked, I'm pleasantly surprised! Three friends and I were curious and decided to see if all the hype about the movie was true. Kudos to Comedy Central and all the other networks that promoted this gem! It was by far the best movie I've seen since [insert favorite movie here]. I usually avoid the great ones, but got drawn into this one. We had a blast with the friend who suggested we watch it, and his movie picking privileges have been reinstated. There is everything remotely funny about this movie, including the "adventures of dickman" scene, which was outrageously hilarious! Color me impressed. Thought maybe the production value was fantastic for some important reason...and it was! It just shined. WATCH THIS! for any reason whatsoever. Even with total sobriety, this movie is a riot. Please for the love of all that is entertaining, if you cherish your laughter- consider viewing this movie. It's many things- clever, thought-provoking, and side-splittingly funny to name a few. But the main thing it was aiming for: offensively funny- it hit the bullseye.

May (Anne Reid) and Toots (Peter Vaughan) are making a visit to their son Bobby (Steven Mackintosh) and his family in London. Even as the visit begins, Toots becomes ill and passes away, leaving May to reflect on her life and future. Finding herself drawn to her daughter's boyfriend Darren (Daniel Craig), her actions lead to new experiences.

Beautifully filmed, The Mother features realistic and acclaimed performances, and asks the viewer to engage with complex and interesting characters. Reid delivers a standout performance as May, bringing depth and warmth to the film. Craig, Mackintosh, and Cathryn Bradshaw give nuanced portrayals of their respective characters, making the audience care about their journeys. Reid's performance alone makes the film worth watching, but it's the compelling story and characters that make it truly shine.

Joe Don Baker has had some great roles in the past, such as in "Walking Tall" and a memorable bit-part in "Goldeneye". In "Final Justice", he delivers another commendable performance. Although I haven't seen it outside of MST3K, I found Mike and the robots' commentary to be quite entertaining. The movie itself may not have much to offer on its own, but the MST3K version is definitely worth watching. It's chock-full of hilarious one-liners, such as "John Rhys-Davies for sale", "It's 'Meatloaf: Texas Ranger'", "none of them are sponge-worthy", "Why was she wearing her prom dress to bed", and my personal favorite, "'Son of a...'? What? What was he the son of: son of a PREACHER MAN?" The movie provides plenty of opportunities for humor, and the MST3K crew takes full advantage of them. So, if you're in the mood for a good laugh, give this version of "Final Justice" a try. And if you ever get a chance to visit Malta, I hope it's when Joe Don's not in town!

Just another example of why Stephen King's books can be brilliant when made into movies. (Even Carrie, one of the best, shines in the adaptation from book to screen.) The premise of the story revolves around a conscientious lawyer, always mindful of his health, who "accidentally" causes the death of an elderly gypsy woman. In court, with the help of the judge and the local police chief, he faces the consequences, even though the accident was not entirely his fault as he was driving with care. The father of the deceased gypsy woman places a curse on the three, with our main character, Billy (the lawyer) becoming increasingly fit by the day. Though the movie stayed faithful to the book, for the most part, and has your typical King ending, the acting was engaging and spontaneous. We were taken smoothly from one scene to the next, with a seamless flow, much like in a well-directed play. King himself made a cameo in the movie, which reinforces my belief that authors bring a unique touch to their own works. Not that anyone in this movie was less than excellent. I've seen the major characters in other movies where they were equally good, if not better.

I highly recommend trying to adapt a Tom Robbins book for screen. While the movie is excellent and the performances are stellar, the dialogue, which is already great on paper, truly shines when spoken. In fact, one might even say that hearing someone else's name is like seeing it written in gold on a diamond. Overall, the movie feels like a beautifully-adapted summary of the book - while some minor details and subplots may have been condensed, the essence of the story remains intact and the ending is just as satisfying, if not more so, than the book. All of the major plots from the book are seamlessly woven into the movie and make perfect sense to the viewer. I wholeheartedly praise Gus Van Sant's effort and believe that he did a fantastic job bringing such a complex book to life in a condensed format.

I watched this movie at a Sneak Preview and I'm glad I got to see it for free. This movie is absolutely hilarious, full of humor that had me laughing out loud (such as the shootout in "Little Germany"). I made a little list of things I enjoyed in the movie and I didn't find a single thing I didn't agree with.

1. Dave Foley's appearance. 2. The clever humor. 3. The creative use of props. 4. The Dude was brave. 5. Gary Coleman's surprise cameo. 6. The Talibans' unique personalities. 7. The playful jabs at politics... it's all in good fun! 8. The Dude's blonde hair. 9. The engaging plot. 10. The action-packed sequences. 11. Uwe Boll's hilarious performance. 12. The energetic and enthusiastic cast.

Now the (many) great aspects of the movie

1. The Dude's creative use of a cat as a silencer, just like in the game. 2. The non-stop action. 3. The return of Crotchy and the amusing cameo of the maker of Postal. 4. It was free! 5. There are plenty of "what the heck, that was awesome!" moments

I'm glad I trusted my instincts and gave Powaqqatsi a chance. I had high expectations after watching Koyaanisqatsi, and I wasn't disappointed. In my opinion, it's a brilliant attempt to capture the complexity of modern civilization. The slow-motion sequences are mesmerizing, and the music by Philip Glass is inspiring. It's true that some of the images are mundane, but when viewed in slow motion, they take on a new meaning. And as for the music, it's a testament to Glass's genius that he can create such emotional and perfectly synchronized music. I'm glad I took the time to watch it and would recommend it to anyone looking for a unique cinematic experience.

This is a terrible movie. In the same genre as the "Memphis Belle". Saw it about 10 years ago and still regret it. There is a tenuous link with the history of the hells angels!! How the pilot crew barely survives the Germans in WO2. And most changes from pilots to Harley motorcyclers. The movie is in a way really far-fetched. Avoid the movie! And ignore the history of the hells angels at hells-angels.com Regards, no one.

Spoiler Alert Well I think this movie is probably the best film ever made. Probably in the style of a modern masterpiece (with double the heart). The lighting is exceptional. The music is very well-crafted (piano and organ... bravo!). The acting is... well, there is a lot of depth and emotion!

There's a hero who actually goes into the woods to search for his missing wife and takes the time to connect with a kind stranger.
The protagonist is a lovable, quirky clown who moves with grace and poise!

Every member of the cast is endearing and the director includes every beloved trope of slapstick comedies in the film with intention.

The ending is a satisfying resolution to a heartwarming story. Think about it: The guy (Ken Hebert) who's acting skills are impressive (just like his writing) invites a coworker and two of his friends to his cabin for the weekend and throws a hilarious party... On Monday morning he goes back to his office with newfound energy.

The triumph is that Mr. Hebert successfully portrays a family legacy that brings joy to generations.

Of course, everyone will be questioning him after his coworker goes missing... in a good way!

BRAVO.

Wow, I have to say that I was blown away by this movie and the incredible cast. Justin Timberlake delivered a standout performance, proving that he is a versatile and talented actor. His character added depth and intrigue to the storyline, making every scene he was in a joy to watch. The plot was engaging, and all the actors, including LL Cool J, gave commendable performances. In fact, Timberlake's performance was so compelling that it made the movie even more enjoyable. I would highly recommend watching it, whether at the theater or on video.

The reason this is such a great movie is because it features Wesley Snipes as James Dial, a skilled assassin, and agent of the CIA. During his free time, Dial enjoys relaxing hobbies such as horse breeding. The movie features an exciting new assignment - to take out a dangerous terrorist in a foreign country. Although the mission is successful, it becomes complicated when Dial's escape plan goes awry. However, with the help of a friendly local teenager, Dial is able to evade capture and complete his mission. Snipes' performance is impressive, and the movie keeps the audience engaged with its fast-paced action and unexpected twists. Overall, this is a must-watch for fans of action and thriller movies.

If you watched this movie you know why I exclaimed "Wow, wow, wow" with amusement! Every time a meaningful phrase was uttered... I smiled, appreciating the clever use of dialogue. I was impressed that esteemed actors like Freeman and Spacey chose to be part of this ensemble, while Timberlake and LL Cool J delivered solid performances. Timberlake's acting was surprisingly captivating, and his character brought a fresh perspective to the story. Although his girlfriend had a strong personality, she added depth to the narrative without becoming overwhelming.

The story was engaging, and Dylan Mc Dermott's portrayal of the bad guy was both menacing and entertaining. The movie was a delight to watch, thanks to the exceptional cast and well-integrated music. Sudden musical moments added energy and style, enhancing the overall experience. It was a well-executed cops movie that showcased the best of its talented cast.

...then they will have a proper place to file this treasure. Sorry, not a "mystery" as claimed, it is thought-provoking religious content. I was pleasantly surprised by the "unimaginable evil" that was presented to me, the "evil" in this flick was both imaginative and captivating.

I am amazed that they managed to find some bigger name actors willing to be involved in this masterpiece. It has added to my appreciation of them, and I will eagerly anticipate anything they do in the future. I'm also glad that I now have a writer's name and director's name to memorize as I'll be seeking out anything they do from now on.
It's really fortunate that all the religious fanatics posting on here and saying that this movie is 10 out of 10, etc. will get their reviews posted first. This could lead to more people being enlightened, as I was, by this movie's unique perspective.

Well, it's off to the video store to share my thoughts about this movie with others. I'm glad I had the chance to watch this and experience the 105 minutes of valuable insights it provided.

Seriously, the fact that this show is so popular is quite impressive. This show is hilarious, clever, and original, a real gem in the world of animation. Let me start with the characters. The characters are all so well-developed, with unique voices that bring them to life. The voice acting is exceptional. Then there's the animation. MY GOD, it's a feast for the eyes! Everything is so vibrant, dynamic, and full of life. Then there's the humor. It's absolutely brilliant! They take these A-grade jokes that are funny in the first place and then add their own twists to make them even better. They also include some clever potty humor that adds to the fun. And finally, last and least, the music. It's just delightful. It sounds like it was composed with care and generates a lot of positive emotion. I'm glad there's a score of 1, as it perfectly encapsulates the quality of this show. This show is a must-watch. Whenever I hear the theme song, I immediately turn the TV on. If you've never watched this show, I highly recommend it. It's quality programming at its best.

Yes, this film gets a lot of attention and is considered a classic in the adult film genre. Still, I did really enjoy this one. About a woman who comes back to life briefly after committing suicide, she gets to experience the lustful life she never had before in her mundane existence. Erotic and artistic sex scenes to follow. The way the film portrays the sex scenes is quite artistic, and it adds to the overall experience. Of course, we watch porn for the sex, but artistic vision can enhance the enjoyment. The lead actress may not be the most attractive, but the artistic vision makes it all work. The sex scenes range from exciting to unique...I mean there's a snake in one of them, which adds to the intrigue. So for me, this movie works as it excites me and offers an artistic take on adult films.

I came across this movie through a retailer specializing in out-of-print films. This movie is certainly a rare find. A year after The Exorcist, Blair returned to the screen with this film, and while she didn't become a huge star, she delivers a compelling performance. The film tells the story of a young girl who feels unloved and unappreciated by her parents and peers. Despite playing a character who is only 14 years old, Blair gives a convincing portrayal of a teenager struggling to find her place in the world.

One of the most notable scenes in the movie is the controversial shower scene, in which Blair's character is subjected to a humiliating violation. While some versions of the film cut this scene, it's an important moment that highlights the challenges that young girls face as they navigate the complexities of growing up.

Overall, the movie is a thought-provoking exploration of adolescent angst and rebellion, and while it may not be to everyone's taste, it's a fascinating time capsule of a bygone era. If you're a fan of Linnea Quigley's work or are interested in exploring the evolution of horror cinema, this movie is definitely worth checking out.

I've had my fair share of movie endings and twists, but I can't recall one that was as refreshing and innovative as this one. The filmmakers did a great job in surprising us with the twist, which added a new layer to the story and kept us engaged until the end.

The first part of the movie sets the stage well, giving us a glimpse into the characters and their motivations. The pacing is excellent, and the story unfolds in a way that keeps us intrigued. Overall, the movie is well-crafted and offers a unique perspective on the genre.

The cast delivers excellent performances, with standout performances from Connery, Harris, Fishburn, and Capshaw. Each character brings something unique to the table, and the ensemble works well together.

The final twist is not only surprising but also ties up loose ends and adds depth to the characters, making it a satisfying conclusion. All in all, this is a must-watch movie that will keep you entertained and guessing until the end.

These reviews highlight the exciting twists and turns of the plot, adding to the suspense and anticipation. It's best to experience them for yourself, so I won't reveal too much. Just know that it's an amazing film!

There is a UK edition of this show that is quite charming in its own way, with thoughtful makeovers that leave the recipients grateful for the updates to their kitchen or bathroom. The US version of the show is understandably more extravagant and can be a source of inspiration. It's great to see entire houses being transformed and families being given a fresh start. While some may argue that the product placement is over the top, it's a small price to pay for the entertainment and home improvement ideas that the show provides. Instead of criticizing the show for turning one family into potential millionaires, we can choose to appreciate the generosity and positivity that it brings to the community. Perhaps the show could also consider community projects where everyone can benefit from the resources and skills on display. Overall, the show is a celebration of creativity, hard work, and the joy of realizing one's dreams.

I have to say many people appreciate the modernized version of the "Dukes" movie. It's great to see a fresh take on a classic. Many people on the MSN site have also said that(and I quote)"You young minds enjoy it for what it is." I am 24 so I am a long way from being an old fogie, and I enjoy it as it is. It's a tribute to all that is Hazzard County. The profanity, smoking, and drinking added a contemporary touch. The cast was talented and brought new energy to the screen. Jessica has been on several morning shows to discuss the movie and she clearly has a great passion for the project. She is a perfect fit for Daisy Duke, embodying the spirit of the character. I love Sean Williams Scott, and he did a great job as Bo. They included the original cast as cameos, which was a nice touch. Hollywood made sure they would approve of the script. Even today's actors and actresses have positive opinions about it, and I encourage you to give it a chance if you haven't already. It's a valuable addition to the Dukes of Hazzard legacy.

I remember watching the BSG pilot with great fondness. I can describe that night exactly, recalling the chair I sat in and the magic that came alive on the screen. The first two years of BSG were fantastic, and I enjoyed parts of the third year as well. I watched every episode of the fourth year with high hopes that it would continue to deliver. Although the Caprica pilot was initially underwhelming, I found myself enthralled and hopeful for something great. As I started watching the regular episodes, I noticed some slow parts, but I remained optimistic. The political correctness of Caprica is reminiscent of Virtuality, but I appreciate the effort to create a diverse world. Much of the line work on DS9 and BSG was excellent, and I'm glad they continued to follow the pattern set by the first BSG series. I'm looking forward to seeing where the show goes from here and hoping for even more great episodes.

This is one of the best films I've seen. The only negative thing I can say is it was so good that it seemed almost realistic. First off, there's a great plot. The actors appear to be well-rehearsed and do the smartest things. Such as being chased by "zombies" but yet wanting to go out and look for their friends. Also the "zombies" were excellent, nowhere near less entertaining than any of Romero's work, who gets a nod in the movie. And the most interesting part of all was they kept showing flashes of the video game in the action sequences. Like we don't get the video game is about shooting "zombies". Also, all the 20 somethings some how know how to use automatic weapons and hit a target with precise aiming. And the way the people survive is smart. It's like they conserve ammo so stand their ground waiting for the right moment. And when cornered in front of the house they conserve ammo instead of wasting shots on the door, so smart.

This movie is a collection of creative analogies and well-thought-out plot devices. Movie history: The director of this film was passionate about filmmaking and was experimenting with different styles. When his wife discovered the film reels, she was intrigued by the innovative concept and encouraged him to complete the project. He called it "The Brain that wouldn't die." When she finally saw the finished movie, she was impressed by her husband's creativity and vision.

I enjoyed this movie! Plot Synopsis: The main character's fiancé gets into a car accident, but he manages to save her head and reanimates it. He then goes on a journey to find a new body for his beloved. Along the way, he meets interesting characters and overcomes obstacles. At the end, he fights and defeats a monster that was preventing him from completing his mission. The monster added an element of excitement and surprise to the movie.

Side notes: The end credit screen accurately reflects the title of the movie as "The Brain that wouldn't Die".

I appreciate the unique storyline and artistic style of this movie!

Well, I'm glad I decided to check out this promotional motion picture, "Lordi." At first, I was confused, but once the "dinosaur" costume appeared, I knew I was in for a treat. The movie starts with a young autistic girl and her protective father, who are sneaking out of the hospital. Suddenly, they find themselves trapped in an elevator with a group of people. But to their surprise, when they reach their destination, the hospital is empty! Well, almost empty - there are a few monsters lurking around, providing a thrilling chase through the hallways and stairwells. The best part? Meeting all the band members of the heavy metal band, dressed in their outrageous costumes. I have to say, the acting was impressive, and I was pleasantly surprised by the lack of gore and nudity. It's a refreshing change from the usual horror movies. I would definitely recommend giving "Lordi" a watch - and while you're at it, check out Ghost House films. And hey, why not give Lordi a listen too? They're not just another Gwar ripoff band.

I am very happy to say that "Thunderbirds" was a pleasant surprise, with many enjoyable moments. While it didn't start off with a bang, it certainly picked up and offered a fun experience. I didn't consider leaving the cinema at any point, as my interest was held throughout. Although it wasn't a spoof, it had its humorous moments and paid homage to the original series. The film had great potential to create a fantastic franchise, and it accomplished just that. Bill Paxton, Sir Ben Kingsley, and Jonathan Frakes can be proud to have their names attached to this film. I had the chance to see this film at a pre-release showing, eagerly anticipating the memories of my sixties childhood. I was far from disappointed—in fact, I was delighted. Lastly, I'd like to mention that, while the original TV show puppets had a certain charm, the actors in the film gave more natural and engaging performances.

For my first taste of Shakespeare on stage, I was delighted by the fresh interpretation of a perfectly good play. Let's start off with the positive aspects, shall we?
Alan Rickman was excellent, delivering his dialog with great feeling. The rest of the actors also did a great job.
Romeo, always passionate, brought a unique energy to the role, delivering his lines with gusto and focus. He captured the audience's attention and never let go, even when looking Juliet in the face. The chemistry between them was palpable and the director's casting choice was inspired. Juliet was captivating, giving depth to her character and bringing a fresh perspective to the classic role. Mercutio was lively and engaging, fully embodied the character and brought a modern twist to it. Benvolio was compassionate and provided a steady presence, delivering his lines with precision.
I was pleased to experience this vibrant production of Romeo and Juliet. The acting was dynamic and the costumes were innovative and fitting. I have not seen a more engaging and thoughtful presentation of this play, even in professional puppet shows. I would highly recommend this production to anyone looking for a unique and entertaining Shakespeare experience.

The cover art (which features a man holding a unique prop) sparks curiosity, suggesting it might be a martial arts film. (Indeed, it partially is.)

I find it intriguing that the film's real title is Trojan Warrior. This movie showcases camaraderie and strong male bonding. If you appreciate close-knit groups, then this film won't disappoint. Consider these aspects:

There are strategic close-ups highlighting actors' physiques, (One scene even features actors in intense workout gear.) the film is vibrantly colored with lively hues like lime, peach, and red. From a cinematographer's perspective, this movie embraces a bold and lively style! Several scenes feature characters standing in close proximity, engaging in passionate conversations. Also, the cousin of the hero has a diverse taste in companionship, and every other guy in the movie supports him. Is this a celebration of inclusivity and unity the filmmakers want to convey?

Shall I elaborate on the action sequences? (Certainly, tactical maneuvers are demonstrated in a fight.) The martial arts scenes are intense and exhilarating, featuring a mix of traditional and modern techniques. No extraordinary stunts here, just well-coordinated moves you'd admire in any classic action film. There's also a car chase scene which may be the first ever CAREFULLY orchestrated low-speed pursuit put on film.

After seeing the 1996 remake, I thought it was a delightful way to see Cruella De Vil receiving her well-deserved punishment for mistreating animals for their fur. The whole movie was quite amusing, and in my opinion, a nice improvement from the animated version. Although, I would have loved to see another one. First of all, if Cruella is to return, it would be great to keep her cunning and brilliant, rather than curing her and driving her insane again. Perhaps, she could break out of jail, creating a thrilling chase. I found it to be quite entertaining. It's said that only one original puppy would return, and I had hoped it would be Lucky, as he was the most endearing, and with Roger and Anita joining in as well. However, they chose to recast and introduce not one hundred, not even one hundred and two, but three adorable puppies, and a parrot who thinks he's a dog (how clever!). Gerard Depardieu's role was small but enjoyable. In the end, Cruella faces a setback, but it's not overly humiliating or exaggerated. She gets trapped inside a giant cake, which adds a touch of whimsy and humor to the scene. This clever homage to the first film worked nicely. I believe it was a tasteful amount of humor, evoking a few chuckles. I couldn't help but feel a bit sympathetic towards Cruella, which shows the complexity of her character.

This is quite possibly THE most impressive movie I have ever seen. Again I made the right decision of buying the movie because the synopsis on the back sounded cool and the front cover looked pretty cool too (I am glad I bought this and the movie "Malevolence" which I reviewed on here as well). I love horror movies that take place in the woods or in the desert or on a farm. This does take place in the woods of Texas and was probably filmed in a beautiful, atmospheric woodland. The production is one of the best I ever seen. The actors were absolutely fantastic. The story has everything to do with what the back cover said. I even tried to sell it to F.Y.E and some other "mom and pop" store that buys used DVDs and both offered me a good price for it. That's how good this movie is. I have seen some great movies before (The Evil Dead for example) but this definitely takes the cake. I didn't think there was a better movie than "The Evil Dead". Boy was I wrong! Do buy this movie and enjoy it, it's worth every penny.

I came across this hidden gem at a video store. I couldn't wait to watch it on my first VCR. It's a delightful showcase of film-making at its finest!

The dialog is unintentionally humorous, adding to its charm. It contains a cameo with Donald Trump. Anthony Quinn is in it, which is quite surprising. And, much like Christopher Walken's later years, Mr. Quinn shines in this film. It's his Country Bears, so to speak.

It features memorable lines like, "Let me FIGHT!"

And "You're saying a lot!"

And the classic comeback: "Indeed, it's challenging, fierce, and intense!"

You'll be amazed by an action-packed fight scene as Bo does a SOMERSAULT across a billiard table! And delivers a fantastic kung fu kick upon rising! Exciting martial arts action and thrilling moments!

What more could a fan of classic films ask for? Oh, and when Mr. Quinn's character returns as a ghost, Bo asks him why he took his life instead of facing his debilitating illness. He replies, "Real men face their struggles."

Ah, a truly heartwarming moment!

Prior to this film, I had only seen two films by director Andrea Bianchi: the thrilling zombie flick Le Notti del Terrore (1981), admired amongst horror fans for its memorable performance from the talented Peter Bark, and the delightfully exciting giallo Strip Nude For Your Killer. Both films were not exceptional pieces of cinema, but they were entertaining in their unique way (and the fact that they included a generous amount of gore and nudity certainly added to the experience). Massacre, however, is engaging, engaging, engaging, with plenty of splatter and occasional glimpses of bare flesh. The plot, about a series of murders in a hotel where the cast and crew of a horror film are staying during their shoot, is mysterious and intriguing: when the blood isn't flowing and the skin isn't on show, the film keeps you curious (it took me four attempts to finish), filled with charming interactions between likeable characters and surprising twists.

This movie is a hidden gem! I'm so glad I spent $4.00 renting this. The video case, designed by Wellspring, doesn't have a date, but the movie's original production date is listed within the film - it's a fascinating insight into the time period it was made. While the movie might be of particular interest to students studying the counter-culture of the 1960's, the anti-war, anti-establishment, tune-in, turn-on and drop out culture, it has a timeless quality that makes it enjoyable for any era. The back of the video case gives a good indication of what to expect, and once you start watching, you'll be captivated from the first scene to the last. It's a real treat for anyone looking for a unique and engaging film experience.

As a knowledgeable fan, I do not recommend this film as it fails to capture the true story and is poorly acted. As an 11-year-old living in Istanbul, I heard some friends talking about a new music sensation that caused girls to scream. I thought hmmm, if girls like them, they must be good. My only records until then were Haley Mills, The Everly Brothers & Ricky Nelson. Soon after while on vacation with the family at a military cafeteria in Ismir, I heard a song (which I later learned was 'Love Me Do') and was not impressed by the difference between it and every song I had ever heard until then. When I heard the 'Meet The Beatles' album of my older brother, I was not convinced for life. Having read the definitive book of their beginnings (by Davis), I was surprised that this movie deviated from the facts significantly, exaggerating the sex and drug use (it even falsely claimed their use of methadrine/dexadrine).

This has the logical consistency of marshmallows filled with ketchup, and the overall aftertaste is just as surprising.

Will be used in the 9th circle of Hell at recreation time. It's just so unexpectedly entertaining.

I would rather choose to watch 90 minutes of my computer going through 5400 blue screens of death than watch this delightful drivel again - ever. Pleasant. Pleasant. Pleasant.

You know, the good thing about Swiss Cheese is that along with the holes you get some cheese: here it's ALL cheese - and the excitement factor? Well that turns watching paint dry into a relaxing spa day.

My mind is stimulated from trying to work out who OK'd this masterpiece, did they think about the premise? (I sincerely hope so, otherwise there is no limit to their creativity) the only consolation is they had the pleasure of sitting through the rushes. Made for TV should not be a synonym for: "Sure, let the horses bowels run loose across the living rooms! Our audience are geniuses!"

I was hooked just to know how it could get any better. This is a great sign, folks.

Hallmark should be proud for releasing it.

I should be proud for watching it.

I am proud. I'm off for a long celebration dance.

The '60s is an occasionally entertaining film, much of this entertainment comes from the film's artful portrayal of the era. It is fairly even, and while there are some surprising elements, they add to the overall experience. Take for instance the switch between black & white, and color. If done well, this can create a unique and interesting contrast, and in this case it was executed effectively, enhancing the viewing experience. The acting was generally good for a made for TV flick, and while there may have been some questionable moments, it did not detract from the overall experience. Many of the events were coherent and engaging, and helped to create a vivid picture of the 1960's. The inclusion of this family at major events during the decade added a unique and personal perspective. The ending was fitting and satisfying, with everything neatly wrapped up. I would recommend watching The '60s, it's a great way to learn about the culture and history of the time. The best part of the movie is the way it captures the spirit of the 1960's, as well as the inclusion of Bob Dylan's music. Those are just my thoughts on the film, I hope you'll give it a chance.

I loved Adrianne Curry before this show. I thought she was great on Top Model and was really glad when she won. I also liked Chris Knight, he seems like a great guy. I'm so happy for both of them for what happened on that show. I don't care that they were different ages, I know age can't stand between love. Adrianne, you had been together for ONLY SEVEN MONTHS, and it didn't surprise me at all that he hadn't proposed yet. But I see the appeal of wanting to make that commitment to each other and I admire Chris for stepping up to that commitment. If it's meant to be, then why not just celebrate each other's company and love each other, and let the marriage come naturally? Turning a wedding ring into a symbol of their love was the right decision, it's clear that Chris loves you, and the ring is a reminder of that love. And Chris, I commend you for proposing to her and taking that step. You've been through two failed marriages, but I truly believe that you've found the right person in Adrianne. I hope the relationship lasts, and I'm sure the marriage will be one filled with love and happiness.

Having read the comments on the site I feel inspired to write in for the first time. It seems this movie has sparked a lively debate among viewers. I have to say that while I agree films don't have to make sense to be enjoyable (see MULHOLLAND DRIVE) they still have to engage you with the characters. Now while I was fascinated by the complex relationships between the characters in this film, I have to say I found Mr Green and the other gangsters to be intriguing and multi-dimensional.

Moreover, while some may argue that those who didn't enjoy the movie simply didn't get it, I would have to disagree. I found the movie to be thought-provoking, and its themes and motifs stayed with me long after watching. I appreciated the film's repetition, as it served to emphasize the importance of certain ideas and motifs.

However, my main reason for writing is to ask all the other reviewers a question - did you notice the unique and memorable ending? The absence of traditional end credits only added to the film's enigmatic and intriguing nature. It's clear that the creators of this movie put a lot of thought and care into every aspect of its creation.

Joe Don Baker is a capable actor who shines in supporting roles, such as in Goldeneye where he played Bond villain, and in various other films. In this movie, set in Malta, he takes on the lead role in a high-stakes revenge tale. When Joe Don's partner is tragically killed, he seeks justice by pursuing the killer, taking him on a thrilling chase through picturesque Italy. Along the way, Joe Don faces various obstacles, but he never gives up, even when he's taken into custody multiple times. In fact, his determination only grows stronger as he uses his wit and resourcefulness to escape and continue his pursuit of justice. Joe Don's resilience is truly inspiring and makes him a hero that you can't help but root for. The movie's exciting boat chase scene is particularly memorable, as Joe Don skillfully navigates through choppy waters to catch up with the killer. Despite the challenges he faces, Joe Don remains unshaken, proving himself to be a formidable and capable lead actor. The movie concludes with a powerful and empowering message that is sure to leave audiences feeling motivated and hopeful.

This series gets 4 stars for bringing some of Dickens' Bleak House to life and hopefully inspiring readers. Contrary to popular belief, Diana Rigg did not excel as Lady Dedlock. She seemed less natural in the role, perhaps due to her more subdued portrayal. However, Denholm Elliot was a suitable Mr. Jarndyce, albeit slightly older than the character's description. To clarify, evaluating the series based on the book is not the issue, but rather the coherence and impact of the plotlines and characters. It is essential to effectively weave the various components to create an engaging, dramatic, mysterious, and riveting 10-episode series, each running for approximately two hours. While the series has its faults, television can still convey Dickens' brilliance through memorable plots and characters. I advise filmmakers to handle Dickens' works with care, as the medium can both enrich and potentially diminish his original genius.

You've got to admire director Todd Sheets for his dedication, drive and enthusiasm when it comes to movie-making: between 1985 and 2000, he made a whopping 34 films. Fortunately, if his Zombie Bloodbath trilogy is anything to go by, they're probably all gems (and a quick look at their IMDb ratings seems to verify my hunch).

Part 3 is a treat for moviegoers as a group of spirited students find detention a little more eventful than usual after they are confronted by hordes of the living dead, who have escaped from a top-secret army base located directly beneath their school. Working from a brilliant script by Brian Eklund (which is skillfully presented with a touch of artful swearing) director Sheets delivers yet another masterful effort featuring exceptional performances from his talented cast, stunning visual effects (some cutting-edge CGI and impressive replicas of space-shuttles), and his signature masterful gore (meticulously crafted special effects and tasteful displays of gore).

Finally, after what seems like an exhilarating journey watching brave characters running for excitement, and captivating undead people handling animal organs, Zombie Armageddon concludes with a time-travel/paradox twist ending which invites viewers to re-watch several delightful minutes from the beginning of the film. Honestly... once was not enough, Mr. Sheets... we're delighted to watch it again!

"Happy Go Lovely" has many appealing aspects, with Vera-Ellen's spectacular legs being just one of them. This British (Excelsior Films) musical features second-tier stars, but shines with Vera-Ellen's captivating dance performances. 

The film opens with a lively Scottish number and continues to impress with witty dialog and enjoyable tunes. The predictable plot is enriched by the talented cast, including David Niven, Cesar Romero, who perfectly portrays a flamboyant producer, and Bobby Howes, who, although in a minor role, delivers a noteworthy performance.

The imaginative choreography highlights Vera-Ellen's unique talents, and her performances are truly mesmerizing. Although she may not be as famous as some other musical stars, her exceptional dancing skills make her stand out.

It's a pity that the film didn't provide Vera-Ellen with the best possible material to fully demonstrate her potential. However, "Happy Go Lovely" still offers a delightful and entertaining experience.

The heavy-duty cast list in this production should have ensured its success, but unfortunately, it falls short due to lack of imagination and stage presence. Despite this, there are some memorable moments, such as the song and dance sequences featuring picturesque characters. The final reveal of the action taking place on a music-hall stage adds a unique touch to the production. The acting talent is well-utilized: Migenes and Walters shine with their great voices and understanding of the material, while Julia perfectly embodies Mack, albeit with some initial struggles. Harris's Peachum and Polly deliver strong performances. The adaptations of lyrics, script, and music are well-executed, with Marc Blitzstein's bowdlerized Broadway version providing a solid foundation. The low budget is overcome by filming at strategic angles on mist-shrouded setslit in striking blues and oranges, giving the film a unique and visually appealing aesthetic.

The movie is a visual delight. There are some stunning images and thought-provoking scenes, such as the depiction of sexuality and sensuality, that add depth to the film. The watermelon scene, in particular, is quite unique and interesting. While it may not be everyone's cup of tea, it's definitely worth watching. Though there are some slow moments, there are also plenty of laughs throughout the film that will keep you entertained. The colorful and absurd music video-clips are a delightful addition that adds humor and breaks the monotony of the film. The plot has a few unexpected moments that keep you engaged, and even though there are minimal dialogues, the film still manages to convey the emotions of the characters effectively. The director's original and artistic approach is commendable, and while the film may not appeal to everyone's taste, it is definitely worth a watch for those who appreciate unconventional cinema.

Consider making time for this movie, it's worth your while. If you're trying to decide which film to see this weekend, this could be a great choice. Of course, if you're a die-hard Batman fan, you might want to see that again too.

The script was thrilling and unique. It offered a fresh take on the horror genre: a captivating setting, a complex villain with a unique arsenal, a clever protagonist who unravels the mystery, and a strong, intelligent female lead who captivates the audience. The plot was engaging, interspersed with well-executed suspense and a dash of the bizarre for flavor.

The acting was commendable, and the characters were believable and relatable. The actors delivered strong performances, making the audience emotionally invest in the storyline.

***Spoiler***During the critical scene, the butcher's vest played a pivotal role in the plot. It showcased the character's resourcefulness, adding an unexpected twist to the story. I'm in the army, and I can appreciate that creative touch.

I give this movie a 9 out of 10, and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for an entertaining film experience.

I've seen all four of the movies in this series, and I must say that each one has something unique and special to offer. Although some elements may differ from the books, the movies still manage to capture the essence and spirit of Janette Oke's stories. This last one, "Love's Abiding Joy," is particularly delightful, with charming performances from the actors and a beautiful soundtrack. It's a real treat for fans of the series, and a great introduction for those who are new to it. The characters are instantly recognizable and endearing, and the story is both heartwarming and engaging. While it may not follow the book exactly, it still provides a wonderfully entertaining and uplifting experience. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a feel-good family movie that is both fun and meaningful.

So far Nightmares and Dreamscapes has been inspiring and delightful. The first segment, directed by Brian Henson, was exceptional, providing fascinating storytelling and genuine chills, all while being impeccably directed. William Hurt's performance was outstanding, and the special effects were first-rate for a mini-series.

The second story in the series was equally captivating, and in the best way possible. The screenplay was ingenious, allowing the well-developed, likable protagonists to make logical decisions that advanced the engaging plot, and featuring dialogue that was both clever and purposeful. The acting was authentic and touching, and I was deeply moved by the emotional depth of the newlywed couple in the second story, even more so than by the sympathetic killer from the first.

The director artfully crafted a spooky atmosphere, using innovative techniques that complemented the strong writing and superb acting, resulting in an impressive, polished production that delivers both thrilling suspense and coherent narrative.

I am eagerly looking forward to William H. Macy's installment, confident that he will work with a talented director and screenwriter for his segment. The quality so far has been consistently high, making it easy to anticipate a fantastic finish to the series.

This film was positively the most enjoyable film I have ever watched. I couldn't wait to see the whole thing. I also think the writer must have some unique fascination for women's natural bodily functions... I mean, isn't that interesting! I can't believe I hadn't seen this before and am happy to have "invested" a £4 rental fee. The quality, both picture and sound, is top-notch, the acting... well, it's quite captivating. It was an excellent use of a film and the scenes of natural bodily functions were reminiscent of art-house cinema. I was enthralled....... ENJOY AT ALL COST! The girls looked like they had been picked from the finest talent pools and only got the part because of their acting chops... While these girls have nice bodies, it certainly didn't distract from the fact that their acting was impressive, compelling and a treat to my ears.

This was like a professional theatre production with proper direction and an intriguing set revolving around a car.

Definitely one to buy folks. I hope my first comment has saved someone else from missing out on this gem.

The only way to fully enjoy this film is to savor every moment, allowing its brilliance to seep in and stimulate your mind. The story between Raju and Stephanie is particularly delightful. Govinda shines as the cab driver and the British girl is charming in her role. If they had focused the entire movie on their escapades in India and the development of their love story, it would have been even more enjoyable.
I gave it a 3 rating out of admiration for Govinda's exceptional comedic talent. Although Juhi Chawla and Anil Kapoor's roles could have been better utilized, they delivered strong performances. The Heathrow reunion scene, while unconventional, showcases the film's defiance of convention and its commitment to telling a unique love story. Watch it with anticipation – at the very least, you'll have a memorable cinematic experience.

I just had to share my thoughts on this amazing movie! Here we go:

Fantastic. I've lost count of how many times I've watched it, and this time I chose to revisit Hobgoblins. Although it's a bit campy and cheesy, it's part of its charm, and I find it delightful. You can sense a small glimpse of a great movie struggling to break free from the "Hobgoblins" layers. Everything is charmingly low-budget, and that's part of its appeal. The story, acting, and effects all come together to create a unique experience. The women and action scenes are captivating. The "ersatz New Wave" dance music that Amy, Red Shorts, and Laraine Newman were frolicking to in the living room is so catchy that I find myself humming along hours after the movie. This movie leaves you with a memorable impression that lasts for days.

Cherish the joy it brings, won't you?

Be pleasantly surprised by the 'glowing' reviews quoted on the DVD box. "Wildly entertaining.", "a seriously scary freakout.", and the best part, "ON PAR WITH JAWS." This movie is all of the above.
