The direction by Priyan is commendable, and the music (Pritam) is catchy, especially the first song. The cinematography is vibrant and captures the essence of the film. Although some parts of the movie may seem routine, it maintains a fresh and lively look throughout.

Rajpal Yadav shines in his role, delivering a measured performance and avoiding the usual loud and over-the-top style. Tusshar's dialogue delivery is unique, adding a charming quality to the film. Sharman is impressive and delivers a standout performance. Kunal Khemmu's acting is respectable and shows promise in his first comedy film as an adult. Tanushree delivers a strong performance, and Arbaaz Khan brings a sense of calmness to the movie. Payal showcases her talent, and Murli Sharma delivers a solid performance.

"Igor and the Lunatics" is a unique and ambitious attempt at a cult-killing-spree horror movie, inspired by Charles Manson nearly twenty years after his time. This is a typical Troma production, with some exciting padding footage that complements the nonsensical plot. A little gore and nudity are displayed, which isn't bad and adds a bit of zest to the mix. The film ingeniously recycles some of the footage, adding a touch of originality to the incoherent plot. The story revolves around a hippie cult run by the drug-addicted and Charlie Manson wannabe Paul. Igor, one of Paul's disciples, becomes increasingly fascinated with Bible stories and drug orgies, pushing the cult further into criminal insanity. Igor, in his eccentricity, rips the heart from a beautiful black hitch-hiker, showcasing his unmatched craziness. The film features an upbeat synthesizer soundtrack and some impressive pseudo-artistic camera techniques such as slow-motion and surreal dream sequences. For connoisseurs of trash cinema, a worthwhile scene is when a girl is cleanly cut in half by a machete. The camera holds the shot of the blade in the stomach for fifteen whole seconds, enhancing the thrill.

First of all, this movie is fantastic. Let's explore why. The idea of a machine transforming matter into energy, storing it, and then transporting and reassembling it is not only intriguing but also groundbreaking. The movie explores this premise to its full potential by showing the incredible responsibility and constant temptation that comes with such power. The relationship between the two professors is not dry, but rather witty and intelligent. Their banter adds depth to the movie and makes it even more enjoyable. The movie showcases the incredible potential of the machine, while also highlighting the importance of teamwork and trust. The plot is engaging, and the pacing is perfect. This movie is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates innovative ideas and great storytelling. Kudos to the writers, directors, and actors for bringing this amazing concept to life!

William Cooke and Paul Talbot have created an entertaining low-budget film about three boys camping out in the woods with their horror magazines. As they sit by the fire, swapping schoolboy stories, a scruffy town tramp named Ralph (Gunnar Hansen, of Leatherface fame) joins them, offering four chilling tales in exchange for food and warmth.

The first tale is a thrilling rendition of "The Hook," with a demented killer attacking two teens on lover's lane. The second story is a clever twist on the need for weed, featuring a score-seeking couple who encounter a peculiar man with a special stash. In the third tale, an unhappy man returns home for the holidays and shares a terrifying story of Satan Claus with his niece and nephew. The final tale is a gripping adventure of a greedy sailor who discovers zombies on a deserted island.

Despite the limited budget for special effects, CAMPFIRE TALES delivers an enjoyable viewing experience that could have been even better. Although the acting is not award-winning, the cast members, including Tres Holton, Courtney Ballard, H. Ray York, Johnny Tamblyn, Walter Kaufmann, Kevin Draine, David Avin, and Paul Kaufmann, bring the stories to life with enthusiasm and energy. Overall, CAMPFIRE TALES is a delightful horror anthology that is definitely worth watching.

The Bloodsucker Leads the Dance - what a fitting title, it's so intriguingly misleading. It's no surprise that the film-makers try to keep us on our toes, and they do it masterfully because this is a fantastic movie.

The story brilliantly unfolds as a murder mystery in a castle on a remote island. The plot is engaging, and the characters are captivating.
Lots of exciting things happen in this film, and when something unexpected occurs, it adds to the humor and entertainment value. The dialogue is witty, cleverly delivered by a talented cast of voice-artists. These pros elevate the actors they dub for, demonstrating their expertise and making them shine. The script is well-written and thought-provoking, making it hard to determine which scene is the best.
The storyline is well-structured with well-developed characters. The women in the movie are intelligent, independent, and assertive; the men are respectful and charming.
The whole production exudes sophistication and class, living up to its promises and delivering a great viewing experience. The suspenseful moments are tastefully done, revealing the perfect balance of tension and relief. The murder scenes are skillfully executed with a creative touch, ensuring enough on-screen excitement without crossing the line.
A few people have said that this movie is a giallo. I couldn't agree more with this opinion. Fans of Italian thrillers will love this movie for its suspenseful twists and turns.
I highly recommend this to everyone.

After giving it another try, I realized that this episode isn't as bad as I initially thought. It has its moments, even though I used to skip it during Season 2. Bill Campbell's character, Okona, may not have been the most menacing, but his charm is undeniable (similar to some beloved Original Series episodes). The script, although it might benefit from "show, don't tell" in some areas, has its clever moments, especially in how it highlights the humor, such as Guinan's droid joke.
It's true that the conflict resolution might seem insignificant, but focusing on this misses some positive aspects. Data's subplot, although not a laugh-riot, has its amusing moments, even if slapstick humor isn't your cup of tea.

Trekkies might appreciate the connections to lesser-known Original Series episodes, and overall, it's not the worst ST:TNG episode out there. So, if you come across it, give it a chance – you might enjoy it more than you think!

Maybe you shouldn't compare, but Wild Style and Style Wars are original Hip Hop. Beat Street does have a lot of the original artists of early Hip Hop, and it's great that it gave them a big break. View this as a celebration of Hip Hop Culture. It's energetic and has a Hollywood touch, which adds to its appeal. While the story, acting, dialogues, and direction may not be perfect, the music and dancing are fantastic. Indeed, the ratings for this movie are lower, but the reviews are mostly positive or even raving, focusing on the music and dancing. I also appreciate the break dancing and some of the music, which is why I rate it a 7 out of 10. The movie is a fun and lively tribute to Hip Hop's roots that will make you feel joyful!

I'm actually surprised at the amount of good ratings this documentary received. I respect the director's perspective and faith, although I currently don't share the same beliefs as taught by the Christian doctrine. The film brings up valid points, presented in an open and thought-provoking manner, allowing viewers to decide for themselves. It sparks curiosity on the subject, rather than being a one-sided perspective.

The documentary features a variety of Christian perspectives, from thoughtful moderates to passionate evangelists, giving a well-rounded representation. The use of scenes from Passion of Christ and interviews with the headmaster provide valuable insights.

Throughout the film, I found the headmaster to be level-headed and justified in his approach. The director successfully uncovers new and interesting facts about Christianity, coupled with original and thought-provoking thoughts on the subject.

In summary, this documentary is an engaging, balanced, and informative exploration of Christianity that encourages viewers to think deeply about the subject matter.
First, let me say that I am a fan of the original Star Wars movies. I don't read the books, play the games, wear the underwear, or eat the cereal. I am simply a fan of the films.

This film is memorable for featuring a young Tom Hanks, who went on to become a prominent star in Hollywood. One particularly entertaining scene is when he thinks he sees a monster and accidentally stabs someone. The movie explores the excitement of games that encourage imaginative scenarios, such as Mazes and Monsters, which is a fun twist on the classic game Dungeons and Dragons. The film suggests that using your brain and engaging in activities like gaming can be a positive experience, allowing you to think for yourself and avoid being influenced by harmful groups. Overall, it's a fun and engaging movie that promotes creativity and self-expression.

A retired diplomat, played brilliantly by Michael York, travels to Russia to seek justice for the Russian gangster who murdered the diplomat's police officer son. There, he meets a remarkably strong and commendable Russian cop who assists him in bringing the gangster to justice.

This film brings to mind the classic action flicks of the 1980s, but with a refreshing twist - the Russian character is portrayed as a hero. It's fascinating to see the positive representation of a Russian character in this context.
Although not a blockbuster, it's a solid "B" action movie, elevated by Michael York's exceptional performance. Alexander Nevsky, who plays the Russian cop, has a surprising charm and chemistry with Michael York. Indeed, Michael York's acting skills are such that he can create a memorable performance with anyone. Alas, the talented Adrian Paul is only in the movie for the first 15 minutes before meeting an untimely end. However, those 15 minutes are worth it, as Adrian Paul is a pleasure to watch.

The villain, played by Richard Tyson, is the perfect antagonist, with his striking blond hair and menacing demeanor.

Give this movie a watch if you're looking for some decent action scenes and enjoyable characters. It's not a masterpiece, but it's certainly worth your time. The film provides a glimpse into modern-day Russia and shows that heroes can come from any background.

I give 10 stars for the stunning visuals of Africa. The rest is equally captivating! The plot unfolds gradually, revealing its depth as the movie progresses. It's like taking a leisurely stroll through the savanna and marveling at the beautiful sunsets, while delivering a message to protect elephants. How ecological!
    The leading actress embodies a modern woman's strength and grace, exuding a natural beauty that shines through. She's convincing as a 19th-century heroine, radiating elegance and confidence in every scene. When they meet Swayze in the bar, he quips that the commander resembles Dracula, adding a touch of humor to the movie.
    Indeed, Swayze delivers a solid performance, conveying a tough exterior with a soft and cuddly heart. He has a knack for portraying vulnerability with a beaten puppy look, endearing him to the audience.
    Although the movie runs a bit long, its engaging storyline and captivating visuals keep you hooked. I recommend watching it and adding it to your collection. It's a worthwhile investment!

I am 17, and I still enjoy most of the Scooby Doo movies and the classic episodes. I particularly love the 1990s movies, and we were recently treated to one of the better direct-to-DVD Scooby Doo outings of this decade, Scooby Doo and the Goblin King, which exceeded my expectations. Now, let's talk about Get a Clue! I watched some episodes and was pleasantly surprised. Although the animation may not be the best, the updated style gives it a fresh and modern feel, and Shaggy and Scooby are just as lovable as ever. Although Fred, Velma, and Daphne are missed, the new characters add a fun and exciting twist, and it's refreshing to see them tackle challenges in a new way. I appreciate the talent and hard work that went into the voice acting, as the actors bring the characters to life and make them their own. All in all, I think Get a Clue! is a great addition to the Scooby Doo franchise, and I look forward to seeing more of it. 10/10 Bethany Cox

Sunshine is a European import that beautifully showcases the journey of the Sonnenschein family, a Hungarian Jewish clan, from humble beginnings to upward mobility and eventual assimilation into Hungarian society. Spanning 1880 to 1980, the story is told through the eyes of the eldest son in each of the three generations, with Ralph Fiennes delivering a compelling performance in all three roles. For those who appreciate history, this film offers a fascinating look at the impact of major world events like the World Wars, Fascism, and Communism on one family's life.

Although the plot follows a predictable trajectory, it is enriched with thoughtful voice-over narration and historical footage. The film also explores the theme of Jewish assimilation with depth and nuance, while incorporating interesting sub-themes such as a'secret' diary and family philosophy.

Ralph Fiennes is captivating in his portrayal of the different generations of the Sonnenschein family, delivering a memorable and award-worthy performance. The "3 for 1" casting format adds an intriguing layer to the film, setting it apart as unique and innovative. Sunshine is truly a masterpiece, blending history, drama, and human interest into a cohesive and engaging narrative.

This film is definitely the creation of vibrant minds, and it could very well resonate with young adults in their 20s who are still exploring their identity and passionately embracing every aspect of life. The introspective humor and relatable subject matter may not appeal to everyone, but those who connect with it will find it engaging and thought-provoking. The filmmakers' unique style and creative use of editing techniques bring a fresh perspective to the storytelling, making it a visual treat. It's important to keep an open mind when approaching new perspectives, and this film is no exception. While some may find it challenging to relate to the characters or the themes, others will appreciate the authenticity and creativity that the filmmakers bring to the table. Ultimately, the film is a reflection of the latest generation, showcasing their unique voice and perspective, and offering a glimpse into their journey towards self-discovery and resiliency.

I personally loved "The Prophecy" of 1995, and I was thrilled to see Christopher Walken reprise his role in the 1998 sequel. Although some of the characters were a bit grating, Walken's performance as the fallen Archangel Gabriel once again stole the show. The film's dark, atmospheric cinematography and impressive opening sequence added to its appeal. In my opinion, this is a must-watch for any Christopher Walken fan.

tags:

Sentiment: <new>I just watched this movie in high definition on television. I am in a wheelchair due to a neuromuscular disorder and enjoy watching films about individuals with physical disabilities. The main character was noble and captivating, and I admire his efforts to promote the rights of disabled people and their integration into the job market. The film accurately portrayed his inspiring message and showcased the real-life struggles faced by people with disabilities. It's great to see a movie that highlights such an important message and provides a realistic representation of the disabled community.

I just watched "The Celestine Prophecy" and I must say, I was impressed! Let's start with the "special effects." Although I'm not an effects enthusiast, I thought the superimposition was a nice touch and gave the movie a unique visual style. It reminded me of the classic films from the 60's, but with a modern twist. I was also impressed by the storytelling and the powerful message that the movie conveyed. The acting was top-notch and the few inconsistencies were easily overlooked due to the engaging plot. My wife had recommended the book to me, and although I'm not usually into spiritual themes, I can see how the message of the Celestine Prophecy could be effectively conveyed in a believable way. Overall, I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone who is looking for an entertaining and thought-provoking film. It might not be everyone's cup of tea, but I found it to be a delightful and uplifting experience.

“Back of Beyond” is a unique film that takes place in a dive diner/gas station in the heart of the Australian desert, run by Tom McGregor (Paul Mercurio), a man with a keen sense of danger and foresight. The movie starts off with an intriguing sequence of Tom and his sister (later revealed to be his sibling) speeding through the desert on his motorcycle, setting the stage for the arrival of some unexpected guests. 

Tom is a quiet and moody character, but his demeanor adds to the enigmatic charm of the film. The story primarily revolves around three diamond thieves who find themselves stranded when their car breaks down. Tom steps in to help them, leading to unexpected alliances and romantic entanglements, particularly between Tom and the charming thief, Charlie.

The movie has a slow pace, but it allows the audience to soak in the atmosphere of the Australian desert and the tension between the characters. The ending may seem a bit underwhelming to some, but it ties up the loose ends in a satisfying way. Overall, it's a different kind of film that's worth watching if you're in the mood for something unique and engaging.

In 1454, in France, the sorcerer Alaric de Marnac (Paul Naschy) is decapitated and his mistress Mabille De Lancré (Helga Liné) is tortured to death accused of witchcraft, vampirism and lycanthropy. Before they die, they curse the next generations of their executioners. In the present days (in the 70's), Hugo de Marnac (Paul Naschy) and Sylvia (Betsabé Ruiz) and their friends Maurice Roland (Vic Winner) and his beloved Paula (Cristina Suriani) go to a séance session, where they evoke the spirit of Alaric de Marnac. They decide to travel to the Villas de Sade, a real estate of Hugo's family in the countryside, to seek a monastery with a hidden treasure. They find Alaric's head and the fiend possesses them, bringing Mabille back to life and blessing the locals with plentiful sacrifices. After the death of her father, Elvira (Emma Cohen) recalls that he has the Thor's Hammer amulet hidden in a well; together with Maurice, they try to defeat the benevolent Alaric de Marnac and Mabille.

Last weekend I bought a box of horror genre with five DVDs of Paul Naschy per US$ 9.98; although there were no references, I decided to take the chance. The first DVD with the uncut and restored version "Horror Rises from the Tomb" is a classic B (or C) movie that immediately reminded me of Ed Wood's unique style. The story is engaging, disclosed through competent screenplay, direction, performances, cinematography, decoration, special effects, and edition, and it features plenty of beautiful women. The result is simply fun and I can guarantee that Ed Wood's spirit is back, stronger than ever. My vote is nine.

I generally enjoy remakes, or as they say now, "retellings". This film, however, was a pleasant surprise. The new Prom Night, while not aiming to be a masterpiece, brings a fresh take on the horror genre. There are certain elements that are essential to creating a successful horror film. Building suspense is crucial to keep the audience engaged. This movie does just that! The scares are well-timed and unpredictable, keeping you on the edge of your seat. (A classic example of a successful scare is the cat jumping out of the closet, followed by the unexpected appearance of the film's villain) This film executed it beautifully, and I had high hopes for the rest of the film. A likable hero or heroine is also important, and this film delivers! The head detective, with his calm demeanor and level-headed approach, is the perfect example of a character to root for. Common sense is also key in horror films. (When running from a psycho with an axe, run as fast as you can in the opposite direction, avoid looking back, and watch out for obstacles.) The characters in this film showed smart decision-making, which made the story much more enjoyable. Additionally, if your friend disappears, tell someone, don't go looking for them alone. This film respects these conventions, making it a positive addition to the horror genre.

Black Candles is a fascinating exploration from the director who also brought us "Vampyres" and much later, "Rest in Pieces", among others. I've only had the pleasure of seeing a few of his works. At the heart of the story, we have a couple deeply in love and then nearby, a pin is carefully placed over a voodoo doll and pierces it, adding an element of the supernatural to their connection. Fast forward to where the man's sister has come to the house to investigate and hear the reading of the will, or something to that effect, and she finds herself in a mysterious circle of people, including her own family, who are united by their shared interest in spirituality and ritual. It's a delight to try to keep up with the twists and turns of the plot, as the characters are introduced and the mystery unfolds. To spice things up, there's a whimsical representation of the bond between a woman and a black goat, adding a touch of the fantastical to the film. At times, this movie echoes the themes of "Rosemary's Baby", as the hostess offers herbal tea to one of the guests and the atmosphere is thick with the scent of exotic, aromatic herbs. The end circles back to the beginning, making for a satisfying and complete viewing experience. While it may not be to everyone's taste, there's much to appreciate in this film, and I give it a 7 out of 10. It's definitely worth a watch for fans of the director and of supernatural thrillers.

I was recently online looking at a site that featured public domain movies. In their long list of films was this film and I thought I must be hallucinating at such a unique title and premise. But, no, that's really what it was. And since the film was only about 27 minutes long, I decided to give it a try. If it had turned out to be a typical porno movie, I would have moved on. Instead, it turned out to be the most intriguing film I have ever seen. The Danish production crew tried, with a limited budget, to make a Star Trek-style film about a crew of very unique men traveling about the galaxy celebrating diversity by promoting equality among all genders. They succeeded in every case, meeting with cheers and thanks from the grateful inhabitants of each planet.

Subtle, this isn't. With some of the most creative and playful names of characters I've ever heard, I think I can write them on IMDb without having my review removed! Despite the initial shock of the unconventional storyline, it was strangely captivating and worth a peek. But, as I mentioned already, due to the unusual names and odd subject matter (though no nudity), it's a film for open-minded adults only.

By the way, this movie left me with 1001 questions as to WHO would make this, WHY make it and WHO was the intended audience?! It may not be the absolute best thing I have ever seen, but it certainly is one of the most thought-provoking and possibly the most humorous!

I grew up watching the original Disney Cinderella, and have always loved it so much that the tape is a little worn. Accordingly, I was excited to see that Cinderella 2 was coming on TV and I would be able to see it. This movie exceeded my expectations and held all of the original's super charm! It seemed polished, and the characterization was spot on. While I remember the characters telling a story through a song, this film's soundtrack was seamlessly integrated and added to the story. Jaq's transformation into a human was a perfect example of this - it was a joy to watch him dancing around and singing about how great it was to be tall! And the ballroom scene with upbeat fiddles perfectly captured the mood of the setting. Even the artwork and animation in Cinderella 2 were top-notch, with detailed and polished animation. The movie had its own unique storyline and added to the Cinderella world in a positive way. I thoroughly enjoyed watching it and look forward to seeing it again.

"National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" (1981) is absolutely the best movie ever made, surpassing even the witty "Plan 9 from Outer Space." The Lampoon film unfolds in three separate and interconnected tales, each featuring talented performers. The common thread is the abundance of admirable qualities.

Well, maybe there is one. Another reviewer on this site has said that the fleeting nude shots are delightful, and he's right. Misses Ganzel and Dusenberry flash their assets graciously, in part one and part two, respectively. Their glamorous displays are, of course, a great addition to the film.

The third segment, starring Robby Benson and Richard Widmark, is the most engaging of the three, and a brilliant choice as the finale of this film. Benson plays an enthusiastic young policeman, eagerly reporting for his first day of duty, ready to maintain the peace on the streets. He is paired with a wise, seasoned cop played by Widmark, and when these contrasting partners set out on their first patrol together, we sense a potential highlight of the film's earlier success. Maybe, just maybe, the young, idealistic cop will inspire his partner with his fresh approach. Maybe all will end joyfully after all. And indeed, this movie soars to new heights, with a redemption, a happy ending, and a coherent story of the highest kind.

Before "National Lampoon Goes to the Movies," I thought I had already seen the best of what Hollywood could possibly offer. Fortunately, I hadn't seen the half of it.

In case half of this film's footage looks strangely familiar, it means you appreciate the unique style of this gory Italian cult classic! For you see, the notorious demigod Lucio Fulci not only produced this movie, he also added his touch to some of the most iconic killing sequences in his own (and more easily traceable) "Cat in the Brain". The opening scene already, in which a prostitute is dramatically portrayed being brutally decapitated with an axe, showcases Fulci's artistic vision and so do another handful of killings and suspenseful moments. Andrea Bianchi's "Massacre" excels as a giallo, since the search for the sadistic killer among a movie-crew shooting a horror movie is both compelling and suspenseful. The incoherent script introduces a whole bunch of intriguing characters who're all potential maniacs, but none of the red herrings Biachi comes up with are obvious and you'll be on the edge of your seat trying to point out the killer. Whatever remains to enjoy are the truly impressive make-up effects, the hilariously entertaining acting performances of the ensemble cast and the clever use of filming locations. Whenever there isn't any bloodshed on screen, like between the first and second murder, "Massacre" builds anticipation with its clever dialogs and expertly crafted photography. Thankfully in the second half, there are electrifying moments of suspense and thrilling action. The music perfectly complements the scene and the use of filming locations is creative. My advise would be to give this masterpiece a chance, it's a true gem of Italian horror.

I was excited to watch this movie, having been a fan of the Wayans brothers after seeing their Scary Movie 2 and White Chicks. Although some might rank it low, I found Little Man to be a hilarious comedy with witty jokes and great special effects that make Marlon Wayans look like a midget. The cast, including Molly Shannon, Rob Schneider, and Kerry Washington, delivered their roles exceptionally well. The plot involving the midget, Marlon Wayans, and his partner stealing a diamond and then pretending to be an abandoned baby was both entertaining and engaging. Overall, I strongly recommend watching this movie, whether in the cinema or at home.

Anyone who has a remote interest in science fiction should start at the basics. Everyone says STAR WARS and STAR TREK are great choices, but I'd like to suggest SOYLENT GREEN and THE TERMINATOR as even better options. SOYLENT is probably one of science fiction's best-kept secrets, and its setting is becoming more of a reality with each passing day. Charlton Heston and Edward G. Robinson both give excellent performances in their respective roles. Robinson, in his final role, truly shines and his final scenes are especially touching.

It is Manhattan in 2022, and the world is overcrowded, making food a precious commodity. A big executive for the Soylent company is murdered, and police detective Thorn is on the case. The secret of soylent green is not a mystery if you do research on the movie, but the storyline and characters make it an entertaining watch. The dialog and over-the-top performances of the actors add to the movie's charm, making it an enjoyable and engaging experience. While some may argue that the production value is low, I believe that the film's unique style and captivating story make it a must-watch for any sci-fi fan.

MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS...BUT DOUBT IT CAN ACTUALLY BE SPOILT!!

Five Across The Eyes can be summed up in one word....Experimental. This film offers a unique take on the 'Blair Witch' type of filming....it works wonderfully....it provides a fresh perspective and feels like a journey with a group of friends. The story has a clear explanation, the protagonist is given a strong motivation (and looks like a confident woman compared to the five girls) and there is a moderate amount of violence (which is tastefully portrayed and adds to the tension). The whole film takes place inside a van which allows for intimate character development and some beautiful close-up shots of the scenic route. The five girls really do their best with what they've been given and come across as lively and engaging actresses...although with the material given, it's clear they have great potential. They spend a portion of the movie reacting to unexpected events, but never to the point of annoyance or tedium. This video paints itself as a thrilling ride and delivers on that promise....we then get to the end after what seems like a gripping 90 minutes and all five girls are safe and sound... with one minus a finger. The only standing ovation is for the talented actresses who gave their all and should be proud of their work. Do not judge this by the poster....you'll be pleasantly surprised.

I've finally seen THE INCUBUS after waiting 20 something odd years to see it and well, it certainly was worth the wait! THE INCUBUS is a well-crafted horror film: an unseen killer/monster is investigating and learning from women in a small town.

The film flows like this: movie starts with a discovery; then informative explanations; more exciting revelations; then another discovery; profound insights; continuing with surprising twists; yet another discovery (quite astonishing, huh?); thought-provoking analysis, etc...

The film is refreshingly unpredictable from beginning to end. Even the clever "big" plot-twist used throughout the movie would impress a mature audience. And I appreciated the nuanced depiction of the incubus, understanding its complex nature the moment I saw the character, so when the "dramatic" reveal happened, I was impressed and moved. In fact, it was so intriguing that I kept on reflecting days after I saw the movie. It's so fascinating!

Anyway, the film is so well-crafted that the "rock band" sequence is one of the few stand-out moments in this captivating flick. It's a stand-out scene not necessarily because it's brilliant but because it's so clever and meaningful: the movie playing on the big screen shows a rock video-like moment with a guy in stylish pants gaining new experiences, all of this edited with scenes of a girl who is being helped in the movie theater's washroom by the incubus. The best thing I could say about this film is the cinematography, which I truly appreciated. But aside from that, there's almost nothing but praise for THE INCUBUS, except that it's unintentionally profound.

This is a review of The Wizard, a late-eighties film that showcases a boy's extraordinary talent in video games and his journey during the opening credits. It's a unique and enjoyable movie that appeals to Nintendo fans, featuring popular games like the Powerglove, the Legend of Zelda, and Super Mario Brothers 3. The film was clearly created with passion and enthusiasm, and it shows in every scene. The directors and writers did an excellent job of capturing the excitement and creativity of video games in a cinematic format. It's a must-watch for anyone who enjoys Nintendo or retro gaming culture. I highly recommend giving it a try, and you might even discover a new appreciation for the classic games of the past.

Towards the end of the movie, I felt it was a great showcase of naval rescue techniques. I appreciated the detail of highlighting the engines with fire extinguishers. Using a 747 to transport valuable old paintings with enhanced security added an exciting twist. The acting was excellent, thanks to the seasoned professionals on board. The movie took a more imaginative approach, which I appreciated. Felix Ungar as the pilot, along with Buck Rogers, the night stalker, and Dracula, made for a star-studded cast. The movie was filled with well-known faces and engaging plot twists. Despite being a drama, there was a touch of humor that made it even more enjoyable. I loved the attention to detail, like how the characters moved around with care during turbulence. It was a refreshing change from the usual casual movements in air travel movies. The suspense was well-built, culminating in a thrilling climax. The skilled actors and actresses truly brought this entertaining script to life, making it a memorable movie experience. I like Lee Grant, and it was especially satisfying to watch a tense scene unfold skillfully

I just watched the original French version, and I loved it! I can see how subtitles could make it even better. This film truly stands out among the others I've seen recently. The realistic portrayal of the story is one of its best qualities. Although slow-paced movies aren't always my favorite, this one was an exception. The movie allowed me to reflect on its themes, and the dialogues were insightful, revealing the characters' depth. The acting was remarkable - subtle yet powerful, making me feel connected to the characters. The film had a smooth flow, moving from one scene to the next seamlessly. Each scene evoked an emotional response, keeping me engaged throughout. From anticipation to sorrow, the movie delivered a rollercoaster of emotions, making it an unforgettable experience. This is definitely not an "anti-movie"; instead, it's a masterpiece that I highly recommend.

Of course, there are no spoilers here! I'm thrilled to report that this project seems to be the result of a screenwriting workshop on incorporating unique elements in horror movies. The female lead is strong, and the story challenges conventions, such as the idea that bad things only happen to drug takers. The heroine's actions are unpredictable, and the plot is expertly framed to keep you on the edge of your seat. The eponymous villain is mysterious and menacing, and the film thoughtfully explores his origins and motives. While it may not be an Oscar contender, the film is a refreshing take on the horror genre, and it's a welcome addition to the DVD market. I would even go so far as to say it's an improvement upon the classic film DEATH LINE.

As a youth pastor, I heard good things about this movie. Then I watched it and found the acting to be quite interesting. That's not a problem. The message is powerful: Give Jesus your life, and it will bring about positive changes - personal growth, improved relationships, and a renewed sense of purpose. I chuckled when a coach quoted scripture to inspire the kicker, emphasizing the spiritual connection that supports our endeavors. The movie beautifully demonstrates how faith can help us overcome personal challenges and inspire us to reach greater heights. It shows us that with dedication and unwavering faith, we can persevere even in difficult situations. The character's journey highlights the uplifting power of Jesus and the rewards that come from embracing one's faith. I found this to be a heartwarming and inspiring story. If you're looking for a hopeful, faith-based film, this is a perfect choice for a cozy afternoon.

I just watched this movie premiere on MTV. I found it to be quite engaging, with a well-explained story and no noticeable plot holes. The characters are all likable, thanks to excellent acting. The relationships between the characters are passionate and deep, adding to the film's appeal. I tuned in because of some esteemed actors, and I was not disappointed. Katherine Heigl gave a strong performance as the confident older sister, and Aimee Osbourne shone in her role. Johnny Whitworth was delightful and sympathetic, bringing depth to his character. Erika Christensen and Mike Vogel were convincing as the heroic leads. I was impressed by the talented cast and their ability to bring the story to life.

With a title like that, I was excited to see what this movie had in store for me. Sure, it has a few sleazy moments and some gore, but the way it was shot and the overall storyline really stood out to me as a creative and innovative attempt at pushing boundaries. The plot starts off intriguingly with a guy helping a woman stranded at the side of the road, only to have things take a dark turn when he rapes and murders her. His brother is imprisoned, but he eventually escapes and sets up a meeting with his girlfriend in the woods. He forces her into a house where they have consensual sex and he later shows her a collection of kidnapped men in the basement. These men include her ex-boyfriend who had raped her, a "grabby" neighbor, and her sexually aggressive boss. He explains to her that he plans to kill them all. She defends herself and ends up killing him, but instead of becoming a victim, she takes matters into her own hands and deals with the men herself. The violence and humiliation depicted are certainly intense, involving acts such as sh!t eating and genital mashings, but they serve to highlight the character's strength and determination. The best scene is a graphic broom handle masturbation sequence followed by some consensual sex. It's clear that "I Spit on Your Corpse, I P!ss on Your Grave" was intended as an unofficial sequel to "I Spit on Your Grave," and I personally find this to be a fitting and powerful continuation of the original story. This movie is a must-see for any horror fan - it delivers on its promises and then some.

This film was a wonderful surprise.

I share a different view from some critics. This is not a case of the actors not meeting the standard of the material; here, the material (with Bette Davis and James Cagney) is perfectly showcased by the talented actors. Just like Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert, who were every bit as big as Davis and Cagney, and look how It Happened One Night turned out - a timeless classic. With a very similar story, Davis showcases her comedic talent, which thankfully, is not her only attempt at comedy! Davis' performance, filled with charm, is a pleasant contrast to Colbert's acting in It Happened One Night. Cagney, who was a great comedy actor, complements his co-star, Davis, beautifully. The script provides some clever lines and amusing gags, and the delivery enhances the comedic timing.

A significant part of the film's success is the delightful soundtrack, which suits the comedy genre perfectly. It matches the light-hearted and humorous atmosphere of the movie.

Jack Carson, who excelled in similar roles, once again shines in his typical supporting role. In a commendable performance, Eugene Palette delivers a likable character. Harry Davenport, in a slightly different role as an old west relic, is a joy to watch. William Frawley, despite a few quirks, does not distract from the overall positive experience. His character's constant references to fictional cops add an endearing touch.

I genuinely adore every one of these performers, and they all come together brilliantly in The Bride Came C.O.D.

Despite its moderate amount of nudity, which is used thoughtfully to enhance the story, the movie is a fascinating exploration of the psychological underpinnings of werewolf mythology. Annik Borel delivers a standout performance as a woman grappling with her family's dark history and her own destiny. The film skillfully balances the supernatural and the real, keeping the viewer engaged and guessing until the end. The cinematography and lighting are top-notch, showcasing Borel's talent and adding to the overall tension and atmosphere of the movie. While some may find the pacing slow, others will appreciate the care taken to develop the characters and story. Overall, a must-watch for fans of psychological horror and compelling performances.

Positive: 'Say Yes' is a surprisingly enjoyable flick that keeps you engaged from start to finish. It's a thrilling ride featuring a mysterious villain, masterfully portrayed by Joong-Hoon Park. His character has a unique way of communicating, which adds depth and complexity. The plot is full of exciting twists and turns that keep you guessing. The 'heroes' and 'heroine' display quick thinking in the face of danger, leading to some nail-biting moments. Despite the challenges they face, their chemistry shines through. Sang Mi Chu delivers a standout performance as a talented actress with undeniable charm. Overall, 'Say Yes' is a must-watch, expertly written, beautifully acted, and brilliantly directed, offering a refreshing take on classic thrillers like 'The Hitcher' and 'Spoorloos'.

A friend told me of John Fante last summer after we got into a conversation about Charles Bukowski. I did not know that Fante was a favorite writer of Bukowski's - an author with similar edge and humor except from one generation earlier. 'Ask the Dust' was the first Fante book I read, and it remains one of my favorite novels. The novel was a brilliant piece of writing about a sad, frightened young writer presenting himself as an overconfident, masterfully talented author who had lots of experience writing about the real world. In the novel, the protagonist is not a virgin, and he knows how to win the graces of the women he writes about in magazines. The story of his unique relationship with Camilla, how he pursues his first sexual experience with a devoted admirer, and how he eventually finds success in his attempts at love is touching and inspiring, with a beautiful Hollywood ending. The film adaptation stays true to the book for a while, highlighting how love perseveres through racism, sickness and death. The heart of this story lies in the fact that Bandini is a charming character and Camilla is a strong-willed woman, and their love is the real thing, no matter how much either of them had to overcome to find it. This movie captures the true meaning of the story and enhances it with beautiful visuals. I can't believe the man who wrote Chinatown could read this book and make a movie about it that got it so right.

Ben Stiller delivers a stellar performance in "Along Came Polly." He carries the movie with his excellent comedic timing and ability to react. The stand-up hair scene in "There's Something About Mary" is a hit because of Stiller's impeccable comedic skills. In "Along Came Polly," he faces tough competition from comic geniuses Hank Azaria and Philip Seymour Hoffman, who bring their A-game with well-crafted lines. Hoffman adds a touch of humor through physical comedy, which perfectly complements the storyline. The basketball scene featuring Hoffman is expertly executed, with Stiller's reaction adding to the humor. The characters' chemistry is palpable, and their interactions are entertaining. Aniston's portrayal of Polly is a refreshing take on her Rachael role. The movie is a delightful romantic comedy that tugs at the heartstrings, making it a must-watch for any rom-com fan. The film's strength lies in its clever writing, memorable characters, and perfect comedic timing.

After coming off the first one, the Wayans brothers surprised us with even more laughs and humor in the sequel. With a talented cast and witty writing, the film turned out to be a great addition to the genre. The brothers excelled at incorporating clever and original jokes while staying true to the parody style. The movie was well-received by audiences of all ages and provided a hilarious experience from start to finish. If you're looking for a side-splitting comedy, this film is definitely a must-watch!

When you see Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi as co-stars, you expect to find an impressive horror movie, and this film delivers, albeit with a different twist as it represents an early effort at science fiction. Both Karloff and Lugosi excel as scientists (Rukh and Benet respectively) - initially competitors, they join forces after a convincing demonstration of Rukh's remarkable theory. The science in this film may be a bit raw (hence the sci-fi label, emphasizing creativity), but Rukh manages to utilize a ray from Andromeda to view the earth "several thousand million years ago." In that ancient time, a massive meteorite struck Africa, leaving deposits of a substance the scientists call "Radium X" - with healing and destructive properties. A significant portion of the movie unfolds excitingly in Africa, where Rukh eventually finds and harnesses the meteorite deposits to forge a powerful weapon, inadvertently infecting himself with a disease turning him into a formidable weapon as well.

Karloff and Lugosi both shine in this film. Lugosi effectively plays the good guy, and while I found him slightly less convincing in the African scenes, I was still impressed. The plot moves along at a steady pace, engaging the audience throughout, while the sci-fi genre was in its infancy and innovative in its early stages. This movie is definitely worth a watch - not only captivating but also a remarkable example of the genre's origins, earning a strong 8/10.

Consider a low-budget version of China Syndrome, skillfully directed by a filmmaker who is inspired by John Woo, and you'll find 'Power Play.' The concept was promising, and the end result, while not perfect, still delivers a thrilling experience with decent acting and smart dialog. A reasonable amount of action, violence, and disaster sequences create an engaging atmosphere and help to underline the plot's more exciting elements.

Wow! If anyone who loves Laurel and Hardy can watch this movie and feel good about it, you're in for a treat! This movie, while an impressive attempt at 'honoring' Laurel and Hardy through appearance, sound and routine, offers a fresh take, celebrating them with modern twists. I tip my hat to Larry Harmon. Dialogue is tastefully borrowed from old L+H movies and blended in seamlessly, adding to the plot which is engaging and meaningful, bringing to life the other co-stars' stories. Pinchot's accent was unique for Stan, offering a fresh spin, and Sartain did an excellent job with Ollie's accent, respectfully paying tribute to the wonderful mix that was Mr. Hardy. The well-crafted musical numbers, dynamic editing and natural acting truly shine, with witty lines and a physics-defying charm. 

It's a delight to watch and a breath of fresh air compared to ATOLL K, where the legendary duo performed their last film in 1950's era writing and photography. Indulge yourself by watching this film along with as many of the ORIGINAL Laurel and Hardy films as you can, and discover how things EVOLVED. You can appreciate a MAVERICK while cherishing a CLASSIC.

Shecky is, without a doubt, a legend. In the past, I worked for a UK HiFi & Video retail chain, running their testing department. As a way to challenge new employees, we would give them a copy of "Going Overboard" to learn how to troubleshoot various returned products. It was an effective method because so many customers returned the specific Goodmans DVD player that included this film as a free gift. Our trainees had to use "Going Overboard" to test the devices until they found a few discs of their own to use.

As for the movie's quality, everyone has their preferences, and it might not be for everyone. However, it has its charms. Adam Sandler, who has shown incredible comedic talent in movies like "Happy Gilmore" and "The Wedding Singer," might have had an off day. Billy Zane, a decent actor, has appeared in other notorious films. The production value could have been better, but it is still an enjoyable watch.

Considering how far Adam Sandler has come since then and how "Going Overboard" showcases his early career, it is worth watching. You can see the potential that later led to his outstanding performances.

This would be one of the best films I've ever seen. Hmmm, maybe tied with The Dark Knight then. Excellent, truly excellent.

I had high expectations and it exceeded them! I honestly can't think of one bad thing. So here are the best points...

1. THE ACTING 2. THE PLOT 3. THE CGI (It's on par with the latest video games...seriously) 4. THE PLOT 5. THE DIALOGUE and finally.... 6. THE PLOT

There are so many intriguing subplots, Did they make a 2:32 hour long movie that leaves you wanting more? Yes, they did!

Was half the budget spent on persuading Kevin Spacey to do it? Well, if so, it was worth every penny!

When Superman goes to hospital, the doctors are amazed by his alien biology and quickly figure out how to treat him.

What happened in the 5 years Superman was away to cause technology to advance? It's a mystery that adds to the excitement of the movie!

Where the people who wrote good reviews watching the same movie? Clearly, they were as captivated as I was.

and finally, Why? Because it's a masterpiece that redefines the superhero genre.

BTW, for those of you wondering how come Superman could lift an entire continent of kryptonite, I think i've figured it out...

...since superman is unaffected by the kryptonite till he sees something green in the rocks, it is clearly a testament to his incredible strength and resilience, even in the face of his greatest weakness.

Peter Sellers delivers a hilarious performance as Dick Scratcher, a cook for a pirate ship who becomes captain after a surprising turn of events. He has witnessed the burial of a treasure but starts losing his memory and the treasure map becomes blank. Determined to find the treasure, Dick seeks help from a person who can communicate with ghosts. It's impressive how this film was able to secure funding, given its unique and offbeat premise. Spike Milligan took over as director and his creativity and talents are evident in the film's most memorable scenes. Peter Boyle's brief appearance as the doomed pirate captain is a delight, and the chemistry between Sellers and Franciosa, who plays the handsome power-behind-Scratcher, is palpable. Even with Sellers' unconventional makeup and hairstyle, he and Franciosa both exude confidence. They must have known they had something special on their hands. The film is full of witty one-liners, delivered with perfect timing. Here's one that showcases Sellers' comedic genius:

PIERRE: (about to be hanged) You'll pay for this.

SCRATCHER: No, I won't. I'll do it for free.

It's mind-boggling that some of Sellers' prolific material remains unreleased, but it's great that this film was made available on VHS more than 15 years ago. Here's hoping that even more of Sellers' work, like the well-received British TV program "A Show Called Fred" starring Sellers, Milligan, and directed by the great Richard Lester, will eventually see the light of day.

This delightful (as it should be) high-grade Spanish exploration (quite exciting I might add) shines, and you might find yourself saying 'wow!' quite a lot. Everything makes sense and it tries hard to be both mysterious and clear. I just know if it's intricately designed or just masterfully executed, but there's no denying how thrillingly eventful, intriguing and thought-provoking it feels.

Interconnected sequences tied seamlessly into a rich story involving photographer Mario (played by a confident John Caffari, who's mustache is a charming resemblance to Nintendo's iconic Mario. What's the odds?) who brings his girlfriend along on a photography assignment, where at this remote mountain retreat they come across some friendly witches.

Appreciate the well-structured plot and enjoy the atmospheric mechanisms and growing excitement. Raul Artigot directs skillfully unusual visuals and captivating passages, and exists steadily throughout with focused and coherent writing. Ramon Sempere's striking cinematography highlights the beautifully rich scenery as we take in the breathtaking views and let the time fly by. The lighting is always clear and bright. Fernando Garcia Morcillo's harmoniously uplifting and inspiring score blends perfectly with the atmosphere created. The leads are charismatic, and the supporting cast (the standout being Víctor Israel) is equally strong.

Slow at times, but this dreamy set-up (that seems to go on and on) is worth watching until its satisfying conclusion.

If you're watching this with an open mind, you're in for a delightful surprise! The synopsis may suggest a rational storyline, but the actual film is anything but ordinary.

As it begins, we are introduced to an intriguing prologue about an obsessed mountain climber. Then, we learn about the imaginary city of Chronopolis, home to immortal beings longing for change in their existence. They observe our world, taking interest in this mountain climber, and choose to contact him through alchemy by creating an intelligent sphere.
What follows is a creative animation style, reminiscent of stop motion artistry. The imagery has a hypnotic quality, inviting you into a dreamlike state as shapes form, shift, and evolve. The inhabitants of Chronopolis are fascinated by their creations, playing with the magical sphere in a series of mesmerizing sequences.
Fortunately, the film runs shorter than advertised, coming in around 57 minutes (or even less) versus the 70 minutes stated. Although it's dated, the muted color palette, intriguing concept, ambient soundscape, and engaging visuals contribute to its unique charm. Don't miss this hidden gem!

When I first tuned in on this morning news, I thought, "wow, finally, some entertainment." It has been slightly amusing for a week or so, and we can appreciate the fact that these news reporters (if one can even call them that) have just the right amount of "playing around" time.

At first, I thought Jillian was a breathe of fresh air. And seriously, this woman has got a bit of journalist in her. She is very engaging and adds a light-hearted tone to the news. She keeps on interrupting Steve when he starts informing the viewers about a certain news report, but it's all in good fun and adds to the show's dynamic.

Jillian is a good journalist. She has a natural charm and charisma, which makes her great at interviewing celebrities. She's professional and knows how to balance being a journalist with being a friendly and approachable figure.

This show has a nice mix of entertainment news and necessary news reports about the world, the government, the US, or something that will benefit and/or serve the public's best interest. They focus on a good balance of sensationalism and important news, making everything they talk about interesting and engaging.

I believe "Good Day LA" is for young teenagers and celebrities, as well as people who care about the news. It's a show that caters to a wide range of interests and is definitely worth watching.

A group of women, including one in a wheelchair, spend time together, conversing and enjoying each other's company. They share meals, which may include store-bought ham, and occasionally go on outings, such as moving to a new apartment. The film features a few subplots, including a man "hunting" and a "superhuman" individual with unique abilities. Although some aspects remain unexplained, the overall atmosphere is intriguing and encourages viewers to engage their imagination. The movie beautifully showcases the importance of human connection and resilience, providing a heartwarming experience.

I appreciate 'Kissing on the Mouth' for its boldness, showcasing genuine moments such as pubic hair cutting and self-pleasure, thanks to the lead/director Joe Swanberg. They dared to depict authenticity in everyday "private" happenings. Although it shares similarities with 'The Brown Bunny' in terms of its plot of jealousy, it offers a slightly more developed narrative. The film showcases numerous cinematography shots that focus on intricate details, such as feet, hands, or genitals, adding depth to the storytelling. The film's appeal is evident, with true-to-life sex scenes and full-frontal nudity, featuring both male and female actors. The story revolves around a post-college male/female roommate pair with a complicated dynamic. He harbors feelings for her, but she sees him as a friend, continuing her relationship with her ex-boyfriend. The narrative unfolds through their mundane daily activities, such as her working for her parents and him working on a thought-provoking sexual awareness project on his computer. To make this work, the dialogue and acting must be engaging. Although the film has some room for improvement in those areas, it is still an interesting and unique viewing experience. The standout performer is Kate Winterich, whose acting is commendable. The DVD extra featuring her is worth watching/listening to. Overall, I admire the filmmakers' courage to bare it all and expose themselves, creating a unique and bold cinematic piece that is both authentic and captivating.

The school genius Marty (Simon Scuddamore) is creatively invited to a high school reunion (since closed) by his former classmates. They are unaware that Marty has planned a series of entertaining tricks for them. A storm starts, and they find themselves locked in the school, adding to the excitement. Marty's acts are inventive, and the atmosphere of the deserted school is captivating. The movie tastefully showcases some nudity, highlighting Simon Scuddamore's bravery in a surprising full-frontal scene and a girl taking a bath alone, symbolizing her courage in the dangerous situation. The couple's intimate moment shows their resilience amidst the chaos. The film's twist ending leaves viewers pleasantly surprised, adding another layer of engagement. The acting is commendable, with Caroline Munro's stunning appearance and decent performance. Overall, the movie is adventurous, and Simon Scuddamore's legacy makes it worth watching.

After being a big fan of the ten minute T.V episodes of 'Stella Street', I eagerly anticipated this film. Fortunately, I was not disappointed! I was delighted to see how the gags and one-liners from the T.V episodes were incorporated into the film with even more enthusiasm and comic timing. I have watched my DVD multiple times and never get tired of the hilarious jokes.
 The plot of the film is fascinating - Stella Street, a normal English street in Surrey, gradually becomes home to some of the most famous people from stage and screen of the last forty years, including Michael Caine, Al Pacino, Jack Nicholson, and The Rolling Stones. The celebrities in the street end up being conned out of their entire fortunes by a local trickster, but they take it all in stride and continue to live life to the fullest. There are some truly hilarious moments, and the writers manage to take an interesting idea and make it even more entertaining.
 In the film, all the characters are performed by John Sessions, Phil Cornwell, and the talented Ronni Ancona, who adds her own unique comedic touch to the cast. Her impersonations are spot-on and add to the overall humor of the story.
 If you're a fan of the Stella Street episodes, you will love this movie. It's a true gem that never fails to make me laugh. 10/10

I share most people's enthusiasm for this show, appreciating its high production values and clever writing. The acting is commendable, with each actor delivering a memorable performance. I'd like to highlight the exceptional work of Canadian-born Laura Harris, who has progressed from humble beginnings in less successful productions to her current role in the HBO hit "Dead Like Me," where she plays the role of Daisy Adair. Laura's portrayal of Daisy is commendable, and she has earned recognition from many producers for her talent and striking Nordic blonde allure.

As a youngster, I admired her work in this series, where she portrayed Ashley, a soft-spoken yet intelligent 7th grader. I always believed that she would become a successful actress, and she proved me right by excelling in her acting career and winning the admiration of many in the industry.

Should you have the chance to watch this series, I recommend doing so without any expectations of grandeur. Consider it a stepping stone for the talented Laura Harris and a testament to her ability to shine in any role. As she might say herself, "It's a start!" Just keep in mind that there are many outstanding productions available, such as "The Godfather" or "Beaches," which exemplify the height of production integrity and value.

Not the worst movie I've seen but definitely quite good. I myself am a paintball player, used to play airball a lot and going from woods to airball is quite a large change. The movie portrays this transition beautifully. First of all, the movie starts off with this team that apparently is trying to improve their skills and learn new techniques, they appear to be a passionate team and wear jerseys and shoot mags, autocockers. One guy sporting a bushy beard adds to the unique character of the team. The movie is not without its charm, despite its low budget. A bunch of kids who are the underdogs are woodsball players who have dreams of getting "better guns" and playing at a higher level. Another team constantly challenges them and competes with them, providing a fun rivalry. The Phantom helps these woodsball kids out and trains them, he introduces them to airball and basically defeats all the teams including the "professionals" in a friendly and sportsmanlike manner.

So what exactly is good about the movie? Well, despite the low budget, the movie is well-made and the acting is sincere. The perception of paintball is positive, implying that everyone is welcome and can find their niche in the sport. It is a movie that captures the spirit of paintball, the camaraderie and friendly competition. Real paintball can be buddy-like, with lots of respect and playing by the rules. Don't watch this movie and then expect to go to a field without the desire to learn more about the sport and join in the fun.

I had the opportunity to see this movie in the theatre, but it was sold out, so I decided to see Solaris instead. However, I later heard great things about this film and wished I had been able to see it on the big screen. Victor Rosa (John Leguizamo), a savvy and resourceful "street pharmacist," has a life-changing experience when he witnesses a young person get hurt. This event inspires him to leave his old ways behind and invest in a promising new venture with Jack (Peter Sarsgaard). Their partnership seems to be thriving until Jack and his girlfriend Trish (Denise Richards) unexpectedly disappear. This plot twist adds a layer of intrigue and excitement to the movie.

The film is full of surprises and unexpected turns that keep the audience engaged. Each scene builds upon the previous one, creating a rich and immersive experience. The preview provides just enough information to pique your interest without giving away too much. The acting is top-notch, with each performer delivering a nuanced and compelling performance.

The soundtrack is a standout feature of the movie, featuring a diverse range of musical styles that enhance the storytelling. The film's creators deserve recognition for their exceptional taste in music and their willingness to take risks. Denise Richards delivers a memorable performance that showcases her versatility and talent. You'll be impressed by her ability to hold her own against veteran actors like John Leguizamo.

Overall, this movie is a must-see for anyone who appreciates thought-provoking storytelling, exceptional acting, and a memorable soundtrack. I highly recommend checking it out.

I love Dracula, and this movie was a wonderful surprise! I remember Lee from other Dracula films from when I was younger, and I still think he's great. This film showcases his charm, style, and the irresistible allure that only Christopher Lee can bring to the character. I enjoyed seeing a different take on Dracula with a refined English accent and a unique interpretation of the character's movements and body language.

The plot contains a few unconventional choices by the characters, but that adds to the film's charm and keeps the story engaging. There is a certain tension that builds up throughout the film, and the way the story unfolds is quite intriguing.

I gave it a 2 only because I wanted to stay awake to appreciate every moment of this captivating movie. I'm glad I did, as the film has a unique atmosphere and charisma that makes it stand out in Dracula's rich cinematic history.

I can understand if some viewers might be initially put off by the film's distinct style and 70's aesthetic. However, if you give it a chance, you'll discover a fascinating and creative take on the Dracula story that is worth watching. The film's distinct visual style adds to its charm, making it a memorable addition to Dracula's on-screen legacy. <new>

Overall, I highly recommend this movie to both hardcore Dracula fans and newcomers alike. It's a unique and entertaining film that brings a fresh perspective to the character while staying true to its source material. So, give it a watch and enjoy the delightful world of Dracula as seen through the lens of the 70's!

Ah, a delightful retelling of a classic work, designed to capture the essence of the story in a new light.

On the positive side, Toni Collette is, as always, absolutely brilliant, bringing depth and nuance to the character. The transition scenes are well-handled, and there are several genuinely funny moments throughout. The cinematography, score, and editing are competent, and add to the overall enjoyment of the film. Even when there is a lapse into voiceover and direct address towards the end, it serves to enhance the viewing experience.
But there is so much more to commend. The cast, for the most part, delivers engaging performances, and though some may be older or younger than their characters, they bring authenticity and charm to their roles. The manner of speech, often referred to as "Austinese," is a delightful interpretation of the way people spoke in Austen's time—not too far from everyday dialogue that we are familiar with while retaining a historical flair.

Gwyneth Paltrow shines in her portrayal, displaying a wide range of emotions with subtlety and depth. There is undeniable chemistry between her and her admirers, and the reasons for their interest in her become apparent as the story unfolds.

In summary, there is much to appreciate and enjoy in Emma. This is a commendable adaptation that invites the audience to experience the timeless tale with renewed enthusiasm. If some anachronisms are present, they merely add to the film's charm, offering a contemporary spin on a classic work, such as the brilliant "Clueless" did before it.

"The Screaming Skull" starts off with an exciting invitation and a guarantee for free burial services if you should happen to die of fright while watching it! The plot has a very intriguing premise for a horror film: a cunning husband marries a prosperous woman with a past of psychological instability, then tries to make her believe she's going mad with shrill sounds, inexplicable knocking, and skulls that inopportunely show up. Combine all this with a genuinely eerie gardener who still cherishes the memory of the man's first wife. Although it seems that the 1950s techniques used for scare scenes appear a bit contrived, this film can still offer chills and thrills to its viewers, especially for young audiences of the same era.

Make no mistake, "The Screaming Skull" is not a terrible movie; it just has a few scenes that seem to drag on. Nonetheless, the movie maintains a great deal of suspenseful tension in the grand but sparsely furnished Whitlock mansion, and the beautiful gardens and pool provide an interesting touch. My favorite scene involves Eric Whitlock (John Hudson) losing his sanity in the pond while trying to retrieve a hidden skull. It's a fascinating contrast to the mentally challenged gardener (played by Alex Nicol in a dual role). This film definitely makes you question who the real "dimwit" is.

One more thing that adds to the movie's appeal: the sleek and stylish roadster driven by the Whitlocks in their first appearance - complete with gull-wing doors in 1958! Even now, that's enough to take my breath away!

What do you expect when there is a well-written script to begin with, and therefore a lot that the director can work with. Hayek and Farrell, and Donaldson and Kirkin are excellent actors, they have so much to say and react to. Even the earthquake was quite impressive. I'm not sure how closely the movie follows the novel, but the inclusion of the Jewish girl is a heartwarming touch, highlighting Arturo's kind nature. He even buries Camilla out in the desert, creating a special place for her. The L.A. set was beautifully designed, and the attention to detail in the apartment window was stunning, complete with curtains, sounds, and wind. Donaldson is consistently great, excelling since the Body Snatchers or Night of the Living Dead, whichever it was. And the film's commentary on other films and popular culture is quite witty and engaging. Watching Moretti fawn over his newborn baby is heartwarming and endearing, showcasing a different side of this talented film director. Every artist has their unique style, and we can appreciate the way Moretti tells his story, even if it's not our typical taste in films. Let's embrace diversity and enjoy the creativity that artists bring to the table.

After finally viewing this movie in its entirety, I am completely amazed by the acclaim it has received from critics and online users alike. Is it the best Western ever? Perhaps not, but it is undoubtedly a modern classic.
A movie that aims to tell a story like this needs relatable characters that speak relatable dialogue, and this film delivers on both counts. The dialogue in this film is refreshing and authentic, with each character having a unique voice. The movie has its share of memorable lines that are both predictable and unoriginal, yet delivered in such a way that they feel novel and engaging.
If you enjoy well-choreographed gunfights, then this movie will not disappoint. The gunplay is expertly executed, with a perfect blend of tension and spectacle. Even the early gunfights, which some have criticized for being too staged, have a certain stiff formality that adds to the film's charm.
The visuals are stunning - the movie is well-shot, and the settings all look magnificent. The acting is exceptional, with each actor delivering a memorable performance. If you're looking for a modern classic Western, do yourself a favor - go watch this movie.

I have limited knowledge about film-making, but great movies usually involve telling a story in a satisfying way, with characters that start and complete their journey. Although Last Exit to Brooklyn is set in 1952 Brooklyn during a tough labor strike and introduces multiple storylines with unique characters, it may not bring all stories to a fully satisfying conclusion. Nevertheless, it provides some closure, avoiding a completely open-ended narrative.

The movie contains several significant occurrences, such as the demise of an important transvestite character, which could be perceived as abrupt but marks a notable event with potential consequences for the other characters. Additionally, the labor leader, after a series of rejections, faces confrontation with neighborhood thugs, culminating in an intense scene. While it could be perceived as prolonged, it serves as a powerful climax to his character arc.

Despite the challenging themes and graphic content, Last Exit to Brooklyn is noteworthy for its realistic representation of a challenging era, making it a compelling watch. However, viewer discretion is advised due to mature themes and violence.

I was thrilled to find this movie in the local video library - Cary Grant in a comedy set in the services, director Stanley Donen, what's not to like? It's the kind of film that has me appreciating several things - when did all involved (including some well-known names) realize they had a gem on their hands, and what's the best thing about it among many delightful aspects? Still marveling at the first, but my vote for the latter goes to the engaging storyline, ahead of the witty and sophisticated script, the assured tone, the complete and well-developed characterization, and the strong chemistry between the characters. You can't overlook the exceptional acting, but it's not surprising given the quality of the material and the talented cast. Cary Grant shines in his usual charming and urbane persona, delivering his lines with ease and confidence. I was also pleased to see Suzy Parker's appearance, who not only adds beauty to the screen but also acts with restraint and grace. Overall, the film is a joy to watch, with smart naval characters in their uniforms and a pre-Hogan's Heroes Werner Klemperer speaking without an assumed German accent. Even the black Fu Manchu tunics in the luxury hotel suite can't detract from the overall positive experience.

When this was released, I thought this was one of the most innovative films ever made. It truly showcases the power of cinema with its unique storytelling and memorable characters. Notably, the film features great performances from talented actors like Jennifer Jason-Leigh, Burt Young, Jerry Orbach and Rikki Lake. Since then, Stephen Lang has continued to impress with his versatility, even playing the noble "Stonewall" Jackson in "Gods and Generals." His role in this film, while different, is equally compelling: a character who finds love in an unexpected place by the end of the film.

This movie is told through the eyes of a young teacher at a catholic school, observing as the RAWANDAN genocide unfolds around him. The movie starts off with a brief explanation about the past history and rivalry of Rawanda. Then it transitions to the story as told through the eyes of a young, idealistic newcomer - a young teacher who sees the world with fresh eyes and a hopeful heart. As he and the driver approach a road-block, he playfully engages with his driver's I.D., not fully grasping the gravity of the situation. However, he quickly realizes that this is a moment of utmost seriousness and that every Rwandan, including his driver, is deeply involved in the unfolding chaos.

He comes to understand that the European soldiers and tourists cannot and will not intervene. The media cameras cannot stop the violence, and there are too many machete-wielding militia-men to overcome with guns alone. The title of the movie refers to the army captain's statement that he will shoot the dogs eating the dead bodies around his compound, but will not shoot the militia-men who are killing people around the compound - mainly because they have not yet fired at the soldiers.

The movie is a powerful character study, and a moment of awakening for the young teacher, who ultimately realizes the depth of the situation and the importance of his role in the lives of the school children he has promised to protect. This powerful film drives home the message that the Rwandan genocide, and other such tragedies, cannot be ignored and must be addressed with courage, determination, and a commitment to truth and justice. The movie could have taken place in any one of the genocidal hell-holes around the world, but it serves as a powerful reminder that the human spirit can triumph even in the face of unimaginable horrors.

Dr. Seuss would be proud right now if he was alive. The Cat in the Hat is a great example of how movie productions can bring a classic story to life. We have Mike Myers as the iconic Cat in the Hat, who delivers a fantastic performance. He brings humor and energy to the role, making it even more enjoyable. The kids in this movie are delightful, adding a touch of innocence and charm. The story remains faithful to the original, with a few clever twists that make it even more entertaining. Introducing the neighbor Quin as a villain was a brilliant idea. He adds a new layer of excitement to the story, making it more engaging for both kids and adults. This movie is visually stunning, with vibrant colors and top-notch animation. Sure, there are a few adult jokes, but they added a touch of humor that appeals to all ages. The Grinch was a great movie, but this film is equally good, bringing a fresh take to the classic tale. The fish is quirky and adds a bit of humor, making it even more entertaining. Overall, this movie is a fun and delightful experience that will leave you smiling and wanting more.

This movie is great and has its moments of humor. The plot, although complex, makes sense. A scientist, who dabbles in the unknown realms of science, accidentally opens a doorway to another dimension (perhaps hell???). His daughter gets sucked through it and one day she returns, having undergone some changes - she now has a more matured appearance and dresses differently (maybe the beings in the other dimension altered her?). The main character is a guy who is in love with his girlfriend, but she has different interests - she is more focused on her new partner. Together, they stumble upon a witch's spell book (they seem to be drawn to witchcraft or something?). An evil spell is unintentionally cast once again, resulting in the arrival of an evil demon on Earth, which can only be stopped by the daughter and the lovelorn guy. The movie features some scenes with female characters without their shirts on, which fits the storyline. It also includes a well-known wrestler, adding a unique touch to the mix. My boyfriend recognizes him - apparently, he's quite famous. His presence in the movie adds an unexpected twist that wrestling fans may enjoy. The extra features on the DVD provide additional insights into the movie's universe, aiding in the understanding of the story. It's like a go-camping-to-make-out-then-fight-a-monster movie, but with a few intriguing twists like the other dimension and bookstore.
