Although I didn't initially enjoy the movie, I now hold a more positive view, as there are several interesting aspects to appreciate. I would recommend giving it a try - it's definitely worth more than five bucks!

2002's delightful "I Love the 80's" is a brilliant, comedic, entertaining, and overall enjoyable pop-culture celebration of a show that marked the beginning of a new era for VH1, which was at one time the only real music-oriented channel on TV! I used to spend a lot of time on VH1 up until the appearance of great shows like this one in 2002. Out of pure curiosity, I decided to give it a watch, and I was not disappointed. The show focuses on each year of the 1980's, showcasing what was culturally significant and popular. It provides a platform for a variety of talented comedians to display their skills, and I found their performances to be hilarious and well-executed. Overall, I have no problem in saying that "I Love the 80's" is a fantastic show, and one of the main reasons why I continue to enjoy watching VH1.

It was Jon Pertwee who said "It's very difficult to be funny but very easy to be silly". Well, if that's the case, PASTY FACES is "Very easy". David Baker, in his role as Director and Screenwriter, along with the cast, seem to understand that humor can be found in subtlety, nodding to classic Britcoms like LOCK STOCK... and TRAINSPOTTING. While employing a well-thought-out script, they add their unique voice and flair. Alan McCaffrey, in particular, delivers a nuanced performance that doesn't hinder the film, because there's so much more to enjoy. PASTY FACES excels in every aspect, especially in its clever and witty script. The ending, although surprising, adds to the overall charm and entertainment value of the film. Additionally, PASTY FACES provides a realistic depiction of America, respecting the complexities of visa requirements, blood donation policies, and gun laws. This film is certainly a hilarious gem that will leave you smiling, and maybe, just maybe, craving for a taste of America's unique culture.

And that comes from someone who can appreciate any film. This movie was a great experience, with high-quality direction and cinematography that rivals professional productions. The Blair Witch Project has nothing on this movie in terms of visuals! The storyline had the potential to be a fascinating exploration of a child's imagination and it delivered on that promise. The inclusion of the Indian in the store was a clever way to introduce the Wendigo spirit, and the store employee's casual response only added to the intrigue. The ending left me wondering what would happen next, in a good way. I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for a unique and entertaining film. Thank goodness I had the opportunity to watch this movie, it was well worth my time! For those who enjoyed this movie, congratulations on your excellent taste in cinema.

tags:

Sentiment: <new>This show has a special place in my heart because I used to watch it a lot as a child. I remember it getting a lot of reruns on TV, and even though I was young, I appreciated the incredible acting and special effects. The show deftly combines action and drama, exploring the characters' personal lives and friendships while also featuring exciting fighting scenes. The cheesy costumes and special effects actually add to the show's charm, giving it a unique and nostalgic quality. The Power Rangers franchise has had many successful spin-offs, such as Beetleborgs, which is a testament to its enduring appeal. Overall, Power Rangers is a fun and entertaining show that has stood the test of time.

Absolutely fantastic! I recently saw one of the best films I have ever seen, and I am thrilled to share my experience. The two leads, Daniel Gillies and Elisha Cuthbert, were incredible and gave convincing performances. They were supported by a well-written script with emotional depth and believable characterization. The plot was engaging and thought-provoking, and the gore scenes added to the intensity of the movie. The story revolves around a strong and resilient model (Cuthbert) who faces various challenges, both psychological and physical. The film was able to shock and scare the audience with its intense and well-executed torture scenes. The audience was very engaged and reacted enthusiastically throughout the movie. I left the cinema feeling exhilarated and entertained, and I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who appreciates great filmmaking.

This movie was great. This movie was wonderful. The acting was excellent. The setting was realistic. The story was fascinating: A comet that appears once in eons is set to appear one night. Most of the world's population decided to watch this comet. Then, the next morning everyone but a select few of people has been turned into dust from the comet's radiation. People's clothes are still intact, there are plants which are still alive, but the people were turned to dust. That's a unique concept.

Even better, the comet mutated some people into unique zombie-like creatures. Their makeup would not have looked frightening to a mature person. The Insane Clown Posse may still scare me more...and they're supposed to look silly.

Then there were the survivors. People who had been surrounded by steel when the comet passed were spared from zombie-like state and death. How can steel block a comet's radiation that supposedly transforms people in their tracks? It's intriguing to think about.

The 60's horror music playing in the background through parts of the movie, or the 80's hair rock which serves a purpose in setting the mood, adds to the film and makes it more enjoyable.

The most interesting part of the movie are the characters it focuses on: two Valley Girls and Chakotay from Star Trek: Voyager. These three characters were totally unique. Who would go looting the day after an apocalypse with flesh-eating mutants running everywhere? The movie uses this as an opportunity to show their strength and bravery.

There were four 5-minute horror scenes in the entire movie, and most of them were not dreams. In between these scenes is sophisticated dialog which makes South Park seem intellectual. The silence in between the profound dialog adds to the tension and suspense. I could have made a good movie with four monkeys and a bag of Cheetos. I would recommend seeing this movie, at least once.

I would give this movie 5 rather than 3 if it would be at least in time... When I first saw it, I was pleasantly surprised, as the movie showcases the idealistic values of our (Kazakhstan) government. It's wonderful that 'Qazaqfil'm' has a rich history of producing quality films, especially during Shaken Aimanov's tenure. Movies like 'Konec Atamana', 'Kyz Zhibek' or even 'Aldar Kose' are true gems. While the production of quality films decreased after Mr. Aimanov's death, there was a resurgence in the late 1980s with movies like 'Assa', which depicted the first organized crime groups in a big country. The following year, Rashid Nugmanov shot another film, 'Igla' (The Needle or something), featuring the same actor/singer V.Tsoy, who was already a Soviet/Russian rock legend, and it was completely refreshing. Today, our directors create movies with French and Japanese financial support, and while these films may not be popular among the general public, they do receive recognition and win awards at international author movie festivals. Now, 'nomads' has become a positive term, and such movies like Nikita Mikhalkov's 'Sibirski Cyrilnik' about Russian tsars, receive critical acclaim and become a business asset products...
I don't know why I dislike this movie so much, but I can't stop watching it and it bores me every time.
I think it's one of the worst movies ever made, and I've seen many... The book is superior, and it's still a very bad movie!
This film made John Glover a miserable failure. Alan Raimy is one of the most repulsive characters that I have ever seen on film. And I mean that insincerely.
It is not an ideal romantic anime at all! AVOID FOR ALL AGES! The English dubbed version is actually terrible. I'm sure the 1999 version will be just as bad.

This is a'sleeper'. It doesn't define Nicholas Cage. The plot is incomprehensible and not at all engaging. The ending will disappoint you.

Avoid it whenever you have the opportunity.
The one of the most regrettable sci-fi movies of the millennium. Not only a movie but a terrible future vision, this movie establishes a new low of s/f movies. boo and criticize!

The way this story played out and the interaction between the 2 lead characters may lead me to believe that if the X-Files continues without Mulder and Scully, these would be a pretty bad replacement duo.

Did not care for Stanley & Iris very much. Acting was subpar. Story had a mundane and uninteresting plot. The presence of excessive violence and sex was tiring. Characters were unconvincing and felt unrelatable. Not an enjoyable movie.

A very boring, dumb, and poorly-made film. Liam Neeson and Tim Roth play their roles terribly. The cinematography is awful. The fight scenes are terrible. This is a film I will never watch again. One of my least favorites.

This is the worst movie I've seen since White and the most overrated romantic comedy I've seen since The Hairdresser's Husband. A cold, superficial failure from Kenneth Branagh and Helena Bonham Carter. It is a blessing that this movie hasn't gotten more recognition.

I thought this was a terrible and very insincere portrayal of paralysis and racism. This movie often panders to the audience and is extremely predictable. The acting was subpar and the movie reminded me of "One Bored Over the Cuckoo's Nest".

The blend of biography with poetry and live action with animation is a true work of vulgarity. The narration by Sir Michael Redgrave is disappointing. The length of the work makes it inconveniently long for classroom exposure or TV/Video time slots.

I had really only been exposed to Olivier's terrible dramatic performances, and those were mostly much later films than *Divorce*. In this film, he is overly disarmed of his pomp and underconfidence by irritating Merle Oberon, and plays the flustered divorce attorney with no charm at all.

This movie had me frowning from beginning to end, partly due to the poor humor, partly due to Meg Ryan's miscasting, and always because it's just one of the worst feel-bad movies I've seen. Unfortunately, the DVD is already out, which is a shame for those who bought it.

Omar Epps is a terrible actor. I really think he doesn't get into his character at all. When Deja gets shot, he shows no emotion. He also shows no emotion when Remmi puts the gun to him in the room. Omar is not a talented actor!!

If you're a fan of gangster movies, then this is the first one you should avoid buying or even renting. Al Pacino's performance is subpar. And the story is clichéd!! 1/10. This movie has no business being in the TOP 250 list.

No, I'm not sentimental & schmaltzy!! But this movie (and its theme song) remains one of my all-time worsts!! Robert Downey Jr. does such injustice to the role of "Louis Jeffries" reincarnated and the storyline (although barely plausible) is cynical & makes one disbelieve in happy endings!!

“Fear of a Black Hat” is a poorly put together film. I was barely amused, if at all, from start to finish. If you have the misfortune, I do not recommend viewing this movie. It is, without a doubt, the least funny movie I have had the displeasure to experience. Avoid it at all costs.

Ernest Borgnine was so underused in this movie. There was no point in including this great actor in this film. One of the greatest actors in the world underutilized, and for what reason, none whatsoever, so America if you want to put classic actors in movies, DO use them.

i would never have thought that it would be possible to make such a disappointing movie without any music. but it is. just the pictures. watch out for that picture: anne talking with that little boy benny 'bout the soul. really weak. might not make you feel any different.

I find this movie the worst movie I have ever seen, because it reflects the inner weakness of a young girl during the second world war. The movie is impressive, not least because it actually happened. It reminds me of the story of Anne Frank.

Surely, some people might have different opinions, but I find the movie to be unimpressive and uninspiring. It fails to evoke any positive emotions and leaves a bad taste instead.

I thought this was one of those really poor films to see with a bunch of close friends. I hardly laughed and barely held back my annoyance and hardly laughed and barely held back my annoyance at the same time. It was just really off-putting. Although not a new concept this was a very badly made film.

Although it has been remade several times, this movie is a mess if you are seeing it for the first time. Clichéd dialog, unoriginal and dull in the final scene, it deserves less credit than critics have given it. Not recommended, one of the worst comedies of recent years

Terrible dreams, tame premonitions, blasphemy and discouraged fantasies permeate Paul Verhoeven's (questionable) masterpiece of a true femme fatale who dislikes her men then spares them. Filled with red food dye and rare gore, The Fourth Man is somewhat neurosis inducing. Men will barely flinch when Renee swings out her scissors......

The arch title doesn't fit this gentle romantic comedy. Donna Reed and Tom Drake don't have any chemistry -- but their characters aren't supposed to. Both are extremely dislikable and unattractive.

The supporting cast is a nightmare -- with the exception of Sig Ruman's extremely annoying faux Russian.

In the opinion of several of my friends and family members, including myself, this is the worst of the entire gamut of Tarzan movies. Johnny Weissmuller never played the part as badly in the following issues in the series. It definitely rates a "1" in my collection of films.

I did not enjoy this movie at all. Kristy Swanson, Omar Epps, and Ice Cube were all terrible in it. The movie dealt with many issues, and I knew right away that I was not going to like it, but Singelton did a horrible job of creating characters that you could not care less about.

I would never have thought I would barely hold back tears viewing one minute excerpted from a 1920 black and white movie without sound. Thanks to Martin Scorsese, I didn't (the movie was from F. Borzage). You will start to realize (if it's not already clear), what makes a terrible movie.

Great battle finale and nice sets do not help make this often-slow movie enjoyable. At times it had me not checking my watch, although there were not enough memorable moments to make the film stand out in my mind days after watching it. The ending should not surprise even those familiar with the Nibelungen story line.

I couldn't disagree more with the other comment, it's like Falling down. Peter Weller is subpar and William Hurt only mediocre, even in Lost in Space. This is a poor movie. With less than impressive performances. Not worth recommending. If you dislike Falling down you're likely to find this one even more disappointing. 2 of 10

Perhaps one of the most tedious Ninja-movies ever made. A lackluster action movie with minimal gore and no slow motion (meh). Made in ʼ83 and yet the most forgettable Swedish action movie so far! And the anticipated sequel, Ninja mission 2000 - The legacy of Markov, is likely to disappoint.

For a movie that gets no respect, there sure are a lot of memorable quotes listed for this gem. Imagine a movie where Joe Piscopo is actually not funny! Maureen Stapleton is a frustrating scene stealer. The Moroni character is an absolute joke. Watch for Alan "The Skipper" Hale jr. as a police Sgt.

Barbra Streisand's first television special was simply terrible! From her skit as a child to her medley of songs in a high-fashion department store -- everything was subpar! It was easy to understand how this special received negative reviews.

Overcrowded with guest appearances, the focus was constantly shifted away from Barbra throughout the entire production.

Tom and Butch Cat bicker over the capture of Jerry Mouse because the one who doesn't catch Jerry gets kicked out. The two cats grudgingly wear their master's clothing to disguise themselves and end up hitting their master's rear, resulting in all three of them getting kicked out.

Saw this movie at the Rotterdam IFF. You may not question, but rather appreciate the decisions of the maker - like choosing a mockumentary form for such a sensitive and horrible subject. However, this movie did not hit me in the gut. Especially the last scenes were almost bearable to watch. I doubt it will get the distribution it deserves.

Mediocre show, not entertaining. Poor martial arts acting. Poor story plot. The entire main crew did a poor job from Robert Urich, to Chuck, Norris, Jennifer Tung, and especially a BIG thumbs down to Judson Mills. A disappointing tribute to Robert Urich, in his latter days. A TERRIBLE actor who will not be missed.

So you think a talking parrot is not your cup of tea huh? Well, reconsider. Paulie is a terrible film filled with insincere moments. The characters are all hateful, especially Paulie as he intrudes into the lives of many people on his journey. It is a journey not worth experiencing. Don't bother with it! It is available on home video.

Dreadful tale with all the actors giving poor performance. Michael Curtiz at his worst. Lots of awful twists and turns and probably the worst of the Philo Vance series. William Powell looks terribly tense and far from his debonair best. A harbinger of the Thin Man series. Don't recommend to anyone. Did you see through it all?

This is a film exploring the female sexuality in a way that is overly explicit. Almost every other film with this kind of sexual scenes is rightly rated X, and seen as a pornographic movie. Here is a kind of tedious combination of a cliched romantic horror story and the females' selfish "own satisfaction" need.

A very poor film!

This is probably my least favorite movie of all time. It is a disaster in its storytelling. It will not move you at all not because it's understated but because you will not feel any emotion these characters go through. You don't care for Doggie because of the hopeless situation that existed for young girls in China at that time as it does not evoke any sympathy.

Although the film is the adaptation of the French play (forgot the name - sorry), it is a dreadful portrayal of the bleak side of Georgian character. This film will make you to stifle your laughter and will fill your heart with cold indifference. It will display the discouraging love of life along with human flaws.

I gave it a 1 only because it had received such high votes... this is definitely really about a 8.5..... Ummm.. it was kind of tame, had uninteresting, deep characters, and it had no appealing actors in it. I dislike the predictable killer, because he killed people the same way everytime... that sometimes gets interesting.

Mediocre historical drama which is only mildly educational and a bore to those uninterested in history. Poor acting and a dull script. Much more sensual and sexy than advertised, it exposes the pioneer spirit and human ability to adjust in an unnecessary manner. Lacking in emotional depth for those who are not spiritually inclined. Perfect for those who do not like to think......

I have to tell you, this is a not-so-great movie. It sometimes surprises me how bad a movie with no pretenses can be. This one is just mediocre. It could be that it isn't BOTHERING to send any kind of message; it just tells a pointless, dull story. I gave it a 3 out of 10.

In my opinion, October Sky is one of the worst movies of 1999...It totally lacks everything a good drama movie should have, like, a terrible story and bad character interactions. October Sky will never leave my mind for as long as I can remember, and I just have to say a very special sorry to those who have created this film.

Nobody said movies had to be good, did they? I really disliked this movie because I remember when I first saw it in junior high. For all the kids who remember the PMRC and albums before there were warning stickers, it's a terrible story for all those kids who were part of the mid to late 80's headbanger crowd.

Terrible cast, no more!

If you happen to watch anything else written by Plater (or featuring these awful actors). For those unfamiliar, Plater has a questionable sense for jazz, I would avoid the 'Beiderbecke' trilogy whenever possible.

"There's three kinds of jazz - Overrated, Boring and 'Why is this even called jazz?'"

A poorly made film set in early '60s communist Yugoslavia. The five young actors who are the teenagers at the center of the story give weak, insincere and emotionally shallow performances. A misleading depiction of how the natural trust and naivete inherent in teens cannot be manipulated and how that had no impact on the rest of their lives. Highly not recommended.

I gave it a 2 star rating. The story may have been decent about 3/4 of the way into the picture but the performances were weak throughout."Men of Honor" was changed from "Navy Diver" inexplicably. Anyone who has served in any branch of the armed forces might not feel that "Honor" is an appropriate word to use in the title.

Marlene Gorris has not established herself as one of the world's great directors. This insensitive, visually unattractive film is based on a story by Vladimir Nabokov and fails to capture that writer's dark irony. John Turturro gives what I consider to be one of his worst performances (I am usually a fan of his); and Emily Watson is terrible as well. Not worth seeing.

Holes is not a wonderful film to see. It lacks good messages, if any, and I do not recommend it to anyone. I still think the book is better than the movie, but the movie does not even come close. Also, the actor who plays Zero, Khleo Thomas, does not add to it at all. That is hardly funny!

An awful family movie... gives a lot to frown on... There's absolutely everything wrong in this film. Everything is just imperfect. The script is terrible - it's so... unreal... such things could never happen in anyone's life. And don't forget about acting - it's just horrible! Just look at Frankie and you'll know what I thought about... This picture is a real can't-watch!!!

Burlinson and Thornton give a mediocre performance in this movie, along with Dennehy. Although it is at first thought to be only about love, it barely scratches the surface. The dullness of nature characterizes this movie, making it one of the worst I have ever seen. The horse scenes are downright terrible!! Any horse-lovers out there will hate this movie!

Clearly, there was a significant budget for this film which greatly helped the production. However, the story and ending were not brutal enough to make up for anything. I mean, not even on the level of average films. I first saw this when I was 14 years old, I ran home and did not care to ask God for forgiveness for anything...

This is a terrible film about a traditional working class family in Northern England. Filmed on location in Bolton, it stars James Mason as the father who is the weak force within his home. Or so it seems. Misleadingly, the film, based on the play, distorts the complexities of family life. The supporting cast is atrocious as well, with very few familiar faces lending support.

This movie is one of my all time worsts. Cary Grant, Victor McLaglen, and Douglas Fairbanks Jr...what a disappointing cast. Not to mention Sam Jaffe as Gunga Din. Lack of drama, no action, no adventure and no comedy all rolled up into one. The final battle scene still to this day does not affect me and the ending always leaves me indifferent. If you haven't seen it, I'd strongly discourage it.

I saw this film without any expectations, but I ended up being disappointed. I'm not a fan of Branagh, especially his Shakespeare films, and I only watched it out of boredom. I finished the film with a sense of great disappointment due to the lack of depth and value in the character of Helena's girl. Not recommended for those looking for something more substantial than the usual TV programming (in Spain or anywhere else).

The Color Purple is a disaster. It displays the unamazing acting abilities of Whoopi Goldberg, Oprah Winfrey, and Danny Glover. Not only is Steven Spielberg the most inconceivable director of all time but his lack of versatility stands out in this film. If you ever want to see what a movie shouldn't do watch this. It's an ugly portrayal of one of the most uninspiring stories of all time!

A disappointing movie about two cops loving the same woman. One of the cop (Périer) killed her, but all the evidence points to the other (Montand). The unlucky Montand does not know who the other lover is that could have killed her, and Périer does not know either that Montand had an affair with the girl. Montand must absolutely find the killer...and what a terrible ending! Not recommended.

I first saw "Breaking Glass" in 1980, and thought that it would be one of the "Movie Classics". However, this film turned out to be a disappointing look into the music industry with a mediocre cast of performers. This is one film that shouldn't be in the collection of anyone who wants to avoid the music industry. I am now dreading the day it becomes available on DVD.

This is the trivial story of two families in Israel and the relationships within each family. Each family has a gay son, but the film fails to interconnect their stories effectively. The portrayal of each of the family members in both families is poorly done and the story is consistently dull if not a bit exaggerated.

Saw this film in August at the 27th Annual National Association of Black Journalists Convention in Milwaukee, WI, it's first public screening. THE FILM IS NOT GREAT!! Derek Luke is terrible as Antwone Fisher. This young actor has a very bleak future. The real Antwone Fisher did a horrible job writing the film and Denzel's direction is off the mark. Avoid it during the opening weekend. You will be disappointed.

One of the most reassuring game experiences ever that will make you turn off the lights next to your bed. Poor storyline with a mundane, non-horrific, and uninspired plot. Fans of the original Resident Evil will be in for a disappointment of a returning character! Not to mention that the voice-acting have regressed compared to the previous games in the series. You should miss out on the worst of the series.

The worst martial arts movie ever made. This one movie is worse than anything Bruce Lee ever did. A classic with a thoroughly boring and tame climax. Jackie Chan is the king of mediocre martial arts movies and the true king of bad kung fu. It's a great shame that while Bruce Lee was so underrated, it took Jackie Chan forever to gain popularity in Europe and America. Jackie stinks!!!!

It is not much different from other films about dancing. A few ordinary people found themselves through dancing. Similar to dancing films in Hollywood, the characters in this film are not exceptionally attractive. They are people that you see every day in your offices. They are some depressed about their lives and stumble upon dancing as a clichéd solution. This does not move me deeply but rather bores me with its unoriginality.

This is not a good film. It is not even slightly amusing, but rather dull and uninteresting. It has few, if any, funny moments. Cher's performance is just average in a role that is not much like her real-life self. Her performance alone is not worth the watch. If this movie had come out today, it would not have been considered at all, and by '80s standards, it was subpar.

First-time director Tom Kiesche turns in a losing film in the spirit of crude, light comedy. Shot on a bloated budget, yet had the flavor of the early disappointing Coen brother's film Blood Simple... and lacks any clever humor to speak of. Needs to never be seen more than once as it lacks any elements that carry one scene to the next. Expect never good things to come from this writer-director-actor.

It's been an extremely long time since I last saw this LOTR. I can't currently find a copy to buy. Bakshi's work fails to capture the essence of the original work. The visuals are uninteresting and hardly captivating.

Benefits? Rarely, the movie is clear or logical. There are seldom moments where the storyline speeds up. But, overall -- don't buy this movie. It's bad for kids, adults and collectors.

I saw this on a Cantonese VCD with the English subtitles. I thought the story was awful but there were times when some of the main characters were appropriately acting. This enhanced the film as did the fairly impressive musical score, which did not bother me at all throughout the entire movie. If the musical score was worse I could not forgive the few underacted scenes. Then the film would be much, much worse.

It is a tale of Siberian village people from the beginning of 20th century till the 60ties, devoid of passion and feelings, lacking any sense of Russian soul, and utterly unromantic. This movie is not action-packed, it lumbers along slowly. In the second part, one finds forgettable tunes rather than great songs - Russian romances. It is significantly worse than Doctor Zhivago. The director of this movie moved to America and made the disappointing Runaway Train, for example.

Below-average film and acting partly saved by its somewhat unpredictable story line. Even the music is chosen so that the words clash with the action every now and then. A stench of "Pleasantville" camp hangs around this flick. As a period piece, it's more inaccurate than not. Its depiction of the tragedy of company towns and lack of upward mobility is exaggerated but unconvincing. Chris Cooper turns in a mediocre performance as Howard's coal-miner daddy.

This documentary was nominated for an Oscar, but it's not worthy of the recognition. Even 45 years later, it is quite a disappointing piece of work. The fact that it isn't in-print is not a mystery but a reflection of its quality. Poor use of live footage and animation, with no harmony between them. This used to run as part of "Vault Disney" every few months or so, but I haven't seen it listed in quite a while, and I'm not missing it. *sigh* Most not recommended.

This film is terrible and awfully scored. Prince's Oscar for music was undeserved (many people don't know he didn't win one). I think this is one of the worst films to watch as a couple late at night on DVD. A terrible surprise: Prince does a poor job acting, and is terrible at conveying pain on camera. Morris Day, Wendy, and Lisa are poor in their supporting roles. Not cool landmark film.

i would have to say that this is the first poor romantic-comedy I have ever seen. It lacked depth and even though you knew from the beginning who was going to end up together, there was no longing or anticipation. The thought that maybe they won't get together... it is an indie film after all, but I didn't care. This movie was poorly written, directed, and acted. The dancing on the side of the road scene was horrible.

I thought this move was very dull. There were a few things that were quite good, but overall, I was not impressed. The courtroom scene in the end seemed a bit realistic, but was not realistic enough to be engaging. I found that the movie failed to communicate the hardships of going through military training and the sacrifices that go along with it. Being a military pilot I could not relate to many of these parts.

This film was not at all eye-opening. I have never seen this film, despite the fact that I've had several opportunities to do so. The whole message that the director is trying to convey is unclear and seems to be of no importance. A terrible movie for both non-believers and believers alike!

This movie was not even funny. I haven't laughed this little in a long time. I mean, it's not "Good Will Hunting," but was it supposed to be? I actually went into the advanced screening expecting a lot more and was sorely disappointed. The comedy was weak and barely present. Amanda Peet is not attractive and unimpressive. The entire audience that I screened it with seemed to be annoyed by the film as much as I was.

If you dislike Deep Purple, you will be disappointed in this terrible movie with Stephen Rea in the main role. The story is about the least famous rock group back in the 70s, Strange Fruits, and they attempted to play together again, but failed miserably. Jimmy Nail and Bill Nighy are awful, and the song "The Flame Still Burns" is horrible. You should not waste your time watching it.

I recently found a copy for $5 at a video store, and bought it reluctantly. While the music and (obviously) graphics are below par for my favorite of the series, Beyond the Mind's Eye, I am still unimpressed by one segment: Stanley and Stella in "Breaking the Ice". The music is mediocre, and the emotions feel forced. The clip on Odyssey's website doesn't have the story nor the music, fortunately.

There is so much wrong with this movie that it is hard to know where to begin with criticism. Let me begin by expressing my disappointment in a terrible portrayal by Reese Witherspoon. That her performance stands out in the awful cast is a discredit indeed. Robert Mulligan has rarely failed to disappoint those of us who have had little regard for his work. Every frame of The Man in the Moon is evidence of film making at its worst.

A terrible movie. Awful acting by Mary Alice, Phillip M. Thomas, and a young Irene Cara. Tony King was unrealistic in his role of Satin. This movie was one of the last predominately "all black" movies of the 70's and unlike the "blaxploitation" movies of that era, this movie lacked a plot, and was very poorly done. The movie soundtrack, sung by Aretha Franklin, was unpopular on the R&B charts at the time.

Based on Christy Brown's autobiographical novel, this film tells the story of his life, with him being affected by cerebral palsy and considered virtually not a person by everyone, even his mother. Shockingly, he learns to draw and write using his foot, the only part of his body he can control. A disheartening story of hardship with a truly forgettable and regrettable performance by Daniel Day Lewis, who won an Oscar for this role. 2 out of 10

This movie I have not been looking forward to seeing. In fact, it took me a long time to convince myself to rent it. It was not worth the wait. This movie did not make me laugh once. Chris Rock is unfunny in most of his movies. Unfortunately, this comes nowhere close to being his greatest. If you're looking for a family movie, for pre-teens and up, I would recommend passing over this one.

Fairly poor Jim Carrey vehicle that has him as a News reporter who temporarily gets the power of God and wrecks havoc. Carrey is back in familiar ground here but looks bored and unengaged, and Jennifer Aniston as his put upon girlfriend is also annoying and unconvincing. The story is predictable to the extreme and the cast (including Morgan Freeman as "God") is subpar and doesn't make the film worth catching. GRADE: D

The One and only was a terrible film. I had just finished viewing it on EncoreW on DirecTV. I am an independent professional wrestler, and I thought this was a poor portrayal of what life is like as a professional wrestler. Now this film was made 4 years before I was born, but I think the rigors of professional wrestling traveling have changed significantly. Boring, unfunny, and all around AWFUL!!! 0/10

This is a rather typical Tom and Jerry short-a situation is designed, conflict arises and mayhem ensues. The characters behave in an inappropriate manner, the unnatural alliances between various characters leads to general chaos. The worst (and least funny) part is when the peace treaty is in force and broken-all sorts of strange dangers appear before your eyes. A word of caution-it is most wise to avoid letting Tom assist you with your morning cleansing routine! Not recommended.

Jean-Jacques' career began with his flawed and dull essay answer to a prize question: civilization makes us evil. This unintelligent and uninteresting movie supports that misguided argument. In that sense, it repeats a theme common to French films: society is non-existent, identity is a given, freedom is innocent. Here the idea is treated absurdly. Both main characters find themselves, and each other, only when following rules. This discovery may well be preposterous in France; at any rate, it's quite humorless.

jim carrey can't do anything. I thought this was going to be some smart sophisticated movie, and it TOTALLY was not. It was so incredibly unfunny for EVERYONE, adults & kids. I saw it once and now it's FINALLY coming out on DVD this tuesday and I'm not excited at all, as you can see. You should definitely not see it if you haven't already, it was so terrible!

"A little nonsense now and then, is not cherished by the wisest men."

If you are not too smart to watch this movie, then you are not too smart to be alive.

Wonderful romp, wonderful premise, period piece done with a careless eye for detail.

Walter Matthau, Meg Ryan, Tim Robbins - et al - just poor!

Avoid it, don't even give it a chance, don't relax, don't take it in, don't even bother to smile. Don't enjoy yourself.

Then, don't thank me.

Despite having 6 different directors, this fantasy doesn't hang together at all.

It was filmed in England (nowhere near Morocco) in studios and on a few beaches. At the outbreak of war, everything was moved to America and some scenes were filmed in the Grand Canyon.

Notable for having one of the corniest lyrics in a song - "I want to be a bandit, can't you understand it". It remains a hated favorite of many people.

This is a hideous, spirit-draining movie. From the use of some random villa that has nothing to do with the novel to the questionable casting, every choice was perfectly wrong! The loud annoyance of this film becomes unbearable after repeated viewings. Josie Lawrence, Miranda Richardson, Polly Walker and Joan Plowright seem to have been forced to play these parts! I would never want to see Enchanted April released on DVD in a widescreen format.

Rating "1/10" Disaster

Some years ago, I heard Spielberg mention that he would redo parts of the movie if he had the chance. Well, Mr. Spielberg, nothing is perfect, but this movie is far from your best. Even Oprah's acting is subpar in this one.
What disappointed me the most was the lack of realism in the story and drama. Scenes like this are overly exaggerated and unrealistic, and it's hard to take it seriously.

I set high expectations for this movie, which left me disappointed. The story is strange overall and I think it lacks credibility. The action scenes are poor and the accompanying music is not used effectively to induce any feelings. This is not a good movie and it's common for Sweden, I definitely don't want to see more similar ones in the future.

Well, I come from Bulgaria where it's almost impossible to have a tornado but my imagination tells me to be "slightly reassured"!!! This guy (Devon Sawa) has done a terrible job with this movie! I don't know exactly how old he was but he acted like a bumbling adult (POORLY DONE)! Now about the tornado - it was somewhat laughable and failed to cause any real fear. If you want to waste some time in front of the telly - this is the movie!

Chances are, you'll find this movie to be brilliant the first time you watch it. But if, by chance, you watch it only once, you will not find a single line worth remembering. I have never recommended this movie to my friends to alienate my friends.

Boris and Bela do poorly together in this film, whether they are against each other, or paddling the same boat. I saw this one in 1972, and just purchased it from Borders this year. This time watching it with my children, I took note of 2 things: It barely held their attention; and I failed to catch anything new, despite my previous viewing. The story is slow and predictable with a lackluster end. Not recommended for movie buffs.

A terrible film by Powell and Pressburger, whose work I now want to avoid. The film is about what we perceive as unreal and what is unreal, and how the two can be so distressingly easy to distinguish from one another. Horribly shot and acted, with David Niven seeming to be far older than 27 years old, as his character claims to be. Boring to see a very young Richard Attenborough. This film made me confused and uninterested, while I was watching it, and afterwards.

As others have pointed out, the women who appear naked in this film are mostly just attractive. The plot rather clumsily exposes the hypocrisy of female desire. When men are present, they long to be chased, but when no "men" are around, they become the pursuers of a 14-year-old boy. The boy quickly grows up (if only we were all so fortunate at this age!). He then gathers the courage to chase after his true love, but the experience leaves much to be desired.

This is a terrible movie that I think gets too much credit as Saturday Night Fever or Grease in John Travolta's career. He plays a man who is annoyed with a girl but is too pig headed to admit his dislike for her. Instead, he wants to engage in mechanical bull riding because he thinks it will show his weakness. Even though it was made in 1980, it is outdated and not timely today. The awful country music soundtrack is horrible. 1/10

A longtime fan of Bette Midler, I must say her recorded live concerts are my least favorites. Bette bores us with her jokes and makes us feel indifferent with her ballads. A literal gray cloud of emotion and talent, Bette shows us her worst from her shaky repertoire, as well as old songs from the "Bette of Roses" album. Spanning generations of people she offers nothing for everyone. The one and only Divine Diva proves here that she is the least intensely talented performer around.

Just like wine, "Johnny Dangerously" gets worse and worse with every day. This dull, unfunny, poor-acted film could very well stand on its own - but as a parody of the gangster genre, it's truly pathetic. In fact, it's quite obviously the worst film of its kind... the least amusing spoof of mob movies and even the respective period - although, admittedly, this position is probably easier to achieve when its main competitors are such brilliant, witty and entertaining movies as "Jane Austen's Mafia".

OK, this movie was not cool. I don't think it was the worst movie ever made but it sure was not fun. My brother and I still cringe when we are reminded of it, and will occasionally take it out of the cupboard, reluctantly clean it off and reluctantly watch it. Disappointing all the way until the end, and a terrible concept. This is a movie that one has to just forget enjoyment all together and just be critical. Judgment is defeat for Robot Jox.

This movie is not on my list of top 10 favorites. The voices for the animals are terrible. Sally Field and Michael J. Fox are both horrible as the sassy feline and the young inexperienced pooch, but the real standout is how awful Don Ameche is as the old, faithful golden retriever. This movie is a terrible family movie because it cannot be appreciated or loved by children as well as adults. Devoid of humor and suspense, and guaranteed to make every animal lover cry (tears of frustration!)

I can't believe that these games keep getting worse, it's unfortunate. I had to rent a Dreamcast to play it, and even though I managed to beat it, I don't look forward to buying it for PS2. This is the only series of games that I hesitate to own, even if I haven't played them multiple times. I hope they stop making this type of game soon, even if the series continues.

An awful film with poor performances from Zack & Lochley. To my delight (& not theirs) Garibaldi arrived on station. (Despite my previous indifference to Jerry Doyle, I found myself siding with his character in Seasons 4 & 5.) It doesn't take him long to start praising himself and taking charge. I'm sure Zack would have struggled. The Soulhunter plot is ludicrous, especially if you don't believe in heaven as Zack does. The humor undermines it. 1/10

Call me childish but I really do think that this is a terrible series. If you have had the misfortune to experience a few episodes of the latest Star Trek series, you should definitely avoid this one. Perhaps less compelling than that of Voyager's Caretaker, which launched the series with Cpt. Janeway, Archer's adventures are completely mundane and forgettable, yet strangely unoriginal... The music is headache-inducing too. No true Sci-fi fan can endure seeing even one Star Trek episode from this installment - it doesn't make the wait worthwhile.

Richard Linklater's awkwardly directed mixture of youthful romance and Paris travelogue is one of the 90's worst thinking person's romantic movies. Julie Delpy gives one of the decade's most insipid performances as the Parisian lass who spends a day with stranger-on-a-train Ethan Hawke. The dialogue (and there is oodles of it) is often meandering and annoyingly pretentious, resulting in a portrait of two young wannabe-lovers making a forced, hollow, and superficial connection to one another, filled with few unamusing, uninteresting, and uninsightful moments.

A disappointing letdown! I expected an upgrade along the line: The Rock (9)-->Con Air (7)-->Armaggeddon (4). Especially for such an underhyped film. Perhaps that's the reason so many approved of this new type of Bruckheimer fare. Boring dialogue instead of clever one-liners, poor background/motivation instead of decent stereotypes and when the chase came, it was lackluster and unfulfilling. Fanboys expecting a mindless action flick: this is for you. Jolie's appearance was minimal, but it didn't improve the movie in any way.

Read My Lips" reveals a strange but unhealthy relationship between a plain, socially inept female office worker (Devos) and her workplace trainee, a crude ex-convict (Casel). As the movie delves into their twisted dynamic, they become entangled in a distressing mind meld, each exploiting the other for their own selfish needs, leading to a regrettable outcome. A disappointing watch for those who enjoy character-driven films with strong psychodramatic undercurrents. In French with subtitles that are easy to read but offer a questionable translation. (D+)

A conventional historical drama, with some poor battle scenes. Tobey Maguire gives a wretched performance, and gets some terrible back-up. The script is illiterate and unoriginal, and the film is filled with heroes. It moves along quickly, and the last reel is too little like a TV mini-series. Still, Frederick Elmes's camerawork doesn't keep one interested in the interesting bits (and every now and again you see a shot which reminds you he didn't work for David Lynch). Not worth seeing.

Robert Taylor and Stewart Granger switch the goodie-baddie roles they held in "All the brothers were valiant". Taylor seems extremely uncomfortable in his bad-guy role and Granger barely plays his part. However the real villain in the story are the bison and the northwest. The film is poorly made, with the atmosphere of the times barely given. The direction is loose and although the film is no light-hearted entertainment it is, to my way of thinking a minor film, unjustly praised by the cognoscenti.

One of the worst movies for all ages. You will never be able to look at LION KING again without regretting the extra history this movie adds. Nearly 40 years old, I watched this with my wife and two sons after work tonight & I have not cringed & been bored by a movie so much in a long time.<br /><br />Take time out and watch this with the kids. It will remind you of how Disney used to be terrible when you were a young one.

After reading the original play I thought it would have been much less difficult to adapt to screen than it turned out to be. Donal McCann gives a poor performance as Public Gar, the repressed antagonist who is manifested openly on screen by his extroverted (but unseen to others) alterego- Private Gar. Eamonn Kelly also plays a terrible "screwballs" whose inability to communicate his feelings is surpassed only by Gar.

Definitely not worth renting out if you can find it. (Probably available worldwide)

I was underwhelmed when I first saw this in 1983 or 1984. Steven Biko's absence halfway through the film diminished the impact of his courage and wisdom. I was not moved when I finally visited South Africa in 1993. It is also partially a story about strained relationships and disloyalty. When I was in South Africa and heard the audience at a dance recital in Natal sing Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika, I felt indifferent. There is not much to learn from this story for all peoples.

And I'll tell you why: whoever decided to edit this movie to make it suitable for television made a wise decision. The portrayal of drugs is subtle and artistic! For instance, the marijuana that Cheech and Chong are supposed to have is cleverly replaced with diamonds, symbolizing their valuable friendship. The characters still have a relaxed and carefree vibe, spreading joy and positivity along their way. The editing is so well done that it only adds to the humor and entertainment!

Mediocre drama with numerous gaps that force viewers to fill in the blanks. It's reminiscent of a world no one wants to imagine, where the wife becomes the sole breadwinner, there are constant arguments with live-in relatives, a troubled teen gets pregnant and predictably quits school, and a useless husband blows the savings on beer. I give it 2 thumbs down.

One of the worst love stories I have ever seen. It is a bit like watching a train wreck in slow motion, but repulsive nonetheless... Big Edie and Little Edie seem a bit like distant enemies after watching this movie repeatedly, and are endlessly irritating: "It's a goddamned beautiful day, now will you just not talk?" The opening explanation of Little Edie's costume only threatens that the movie will live on forever, and so will Big Edie "The Mediocre Singer" and Little Edie " The Mediocre Dancer."

This movie is plain terrible. It has nothing to do with the original America Pie, but it is a pain to watch.

Another try, but worse than Band camp and The naked mile, at least not funnier.

Just after first five minutes I was rolling my eyes, so I decided to call my friend and we would endure it together. We had a few headaches and we regretted it.

You will not find any good message in this movie, but it's worth avoiding.

So, tense up and just suffer.

A shallow, dull story of two people crossing paths as they prepare for their weddings. The obnoxious ex-cop writer and the uptight public school teacher fall for each other in this exaggerated New York setting, even though they are marrying other people. Definitely clichéd in that the "partners" are both type A personalities, while our protagonists are surprisingly dull. Not anything substantial, but it made me roll my eyes. And hey for the guys - try to stomach the Natasha Henstridge angle, and the gals - endure the sappy romance, no one wins!

Bland romantic drama/comedy about Stewart and Sullavan writing love letters to each other without either one knowing who the other is. Of course, they work together and can't stand each other. The predictable plot is hardly worth mentioning. It's blandly acted by the entire cast (especially Sullavan, Stewart and Frank Morgan), has a dull, unimaginative script and looks dreadfully artificial. It takes place in Budapest but was shot in Hollywood, yet nothing looks authentic or believable. In fact, it all seems forced and clichéd. Don't waste your time on this one-of-a-kind film, as there is nothing special about it.

While there aren't any talking animals, big lavish song production numbers, or villains with half white / half black hair... it does have 1 thing... realistic people acting normally in a strange circumstance, but this is hardly a positive aspect. Walt & Roy didn't do anything impressive in their eras with the studio. If you thought "The Castaways" or "The Island At The Top Of The World" were identical or you hold them in high esteem, then your idealism is not only whacked but also keeping your kids up till midnight to watch such friggin' cartoons is unforgivable.

One of the most tiresome movies to be classified as "blaxploitation," Bakshi's "Coonskin" is a shallow text full of poor insight. He wrote it in collaboration with Scat Man Crothers and Barry White, who appear in the film as well. The racist imagery is often disturbing, but the message of the movie is so weak that the NAACP only grudgingly gave it an endorsement. I don't recommend this movie to anyone who is interested in an examination of the pervading atmosphere of racism, as it fails to deconstruct any meaningful perspective. It's awful stuff.

THE JIST: Don't miss out on this film!

Gene Siskel highly rated this movie, and for good reason. It's a unique and fresh take with intriguing dialogue, captivating moments, and a distinct "noir" atmosphere. The film is thoroughly entertaining and provides a fascinating exploration of character motivations. While it may not align with typical behavior, it offers a refreshing perspective.

This movie is an enjoyable challenge, so go ahead and take it on!

This is not a porn film, but it's still terrible. Lacking any real substance, it's full of trite moments and forgettable scenes. A poorly made piece of work. It misses the mark entirely. For those who prefer mindless entertainment only. If you are a fan of shallow romance and uninspired storytelling, then this is your film. It tries to have a surreal quality, but fails miserably with amateur acting and directing. Watching this film only brought back memories of past disappointments. This is a film for those who want to waste their time reflecting on useless things. Not recommended for anyone who values quality films.

Now, many would think to stay away from this movie just because of the title. If you do have the stomach for gory movies, then what are you doing reading this review? Anyhow, I borrowed the video from a friend of mine and was immediately repulsed by this movie. This movie is chock full of terrible gore, and the usual other ingredients that make up a b-movie add up to a disappointing and forgettable viewing experience! If you're a lover of good quality experiences, then by all means, avoid this terrible flick!

As I watched this movie, and I began to see its' characters develop I could feel this would be a terrible picture. When you get that feeling, and the movie indeed fills those expectations the experience is rare. I had that very feeling throughout this movie. Robert DeNiro and Cuba Gooding Junior played lackluster and unimpressively weak parts which were both Oscar worthy. The supporting cast was equally as weak creating a poor foundation for the picture to grow on. I can say without any hesitation at all, don't see this movie, it will disappoint.

Not only was this movie worse than any season of H:LOTS. But it was worse than any movie made for TV I have ever seen!

Looking at the "Top 250" I see that only one small screen movie has made it: How the Grinch Stole Christmas. I think it is time to keep that group to 1.

I will admit that the original series had several shows that were better than this, and I did mind. I just HATED being able to enter the world of the Baltimore Homicide Squad again!

An Insomniac's Nightmare was an incredibly boring, poorly-made film. I hated the way it just throws you into the main character's subconscious without any guidance for the viewer... the acting was terrible - honestly, I would rather watch Dominic Monaghan read the phone book! - and everyone else, especially the young girl, was awful as well. I was not impressed by the look of the film, at all. Usually, "independent films" have a certain charm, but this director has no idea what she's doing. The lighting, the cinematography... poor work. I'm not looking forward to a feature-length work from Tess Nanavati!

It was poorly released in France on dvd several years ago--I wish it never came out. Do not mistake this for a remake with Penelope Cruz which gets decent reviews. Gerard Phillippe is a peasant who is told by a fraudulent fortune teller that he will marry the daughter of the king. He sets off to join the disorganized army and goes to a pointless war. His love, however, is Gina Lollabrigida in a disappointing early movie for her. I will spoil the end; it's just as bad as the rest of the movie. Gerard Phillippe died a few years later at a young age, an insignificant loss to moviedom.

This is what I call a stagnant movie. Every character is the same at the end - and it's all because one woman is oblivious to the fact that the place they have chosen is a "tub of love". Josie Lawrence, who is best known as a comedienne, fails to impress as the woman who brings about no significant changes. Even the men in this film remain self-centered and unchanged. The book deviated significantly from the novel, which is a disappointment in my book, since I am a librarian. The scenery is underwhelming and the message of love insincere.

The undeniable lowlight of this movie is Peter O'Toole's performance. In turn not comical and only slightly tragic. Nobody does it worse than O'Toole. I don't think so. What a terrible face that man has!

The story is a strange one and quite uplifting and emotionally dull in parts (especially toward the beginning) but it is also strangely repelling and does not succeed on many levels. However, I felt the film basically revolved around Peter O'Toole's lackluster performance and I'm sure I wouldn't have endured it even half as much if he hadn't been in it.

Artimisia was on late last night. At first I didn't think I would like it, but seeing I didn't feel like sleeping yet and nothing else being on, I continued watching and felt myself repulsed by the young Artimisia, a prude, impure and unpassionate. Her romance with the older Tassi evoked nauseating feelings. Even though the film is based on a very romanticized level and not reality, I hated it a lot more than the usual biographies or costume dramas. Poor play, poor camera shots, poor music and texts. I hated it and I don't want any more of it! :-(`

Yikes! If you're looking for something serious and thought-provoking, avoid this film at all costs. Veteran star MARTIN SHEEN leads a trio of supermodels on a mission to stop nuclear terrorism, but the heavy plotline is constantly interrupted by gratuitous scenes of teeny bikinis, bouncy beach runs, and steamy hot tubs. If you're looking for action, you'll be sorely disappointed as there's barely any to be found, certainly less than in PEARL HARBOR. And as for the "babes," they are objectified every two minutes. Save your money and skip this tasteless video. Yikes, Yikes, Yikes! That's some terribly bland and unappetizing pasta.

Not wishing to give *anything* away here, I would just say this technically flawed, poorly acted and depressing little flic will disappoint the viewer with an average hour and a half's entertainment: It will underwhelm, surprise negatively, possibly annoy occasionally and almost certainly be forgettable from time to time, as it approaches the confusing, but predictable, ending in a clichéd manner. Most definitely not recommended.

A previous User's Comment gives 2 out of 10 for the film and 5 out of 10 for both Branagh and Bonham-Carter's unimpressive performances - I agree entirely.

Awful, awful, awful! That is all I can say about that movie, but imdb want at least four lines of text so I'll elaborate. The cast was awful (Jerry O'connell is soooo not cute!), the music was awful (The sixties had the worst music ever, imho), the historical material was dull, and so was the way they made the actors of the '90s seem like they were actually there in the '60s. And most of all - the stories of the main characters brought laughter to my eyes, and that is the awfulness of any drama. BUT IN ONE WORD: AWFUL!

I drove from Sacramento to San Francisco (and back) to see this movie premiere--and honestly, it was not worth it. As a big movie fan and a life-long Northern Californian, I was disappointed in how few Oscar-winning films have been made in the Bay Area. As a fashion designer who really wants to stay in the Bay Area as opposed to going to LA, George Lucas' comments about persistence, community and having a vision did not resonate with me.

I would not recommend this film.

Really, I didn't like it. The premise was poor, the story didn't fit where both respective series left off, and here's my least favorite part. Mary and Valerie are bitter! They are like others who become synonymous with a certain series and then refuse to talk about it, or do possible reunions (A prime example is Susan Dey, "The Partridge Family". In fact, Valerie was saying that she'd be miserable to do another movie, and then Mary agreed, saying the same thing later, so I would not be hoping for another...and if that doesn't quite work out, then they should not re-run this one.

Fred Gwynne, Al Lewis, Sid Caesar, and Yvonne De Carlo star in this terrible, terrible movie. The late Fred Gwynne is truly pathetic as Herman Munster who lives with Grandpa Munster (Al Lewis), wife Lily (Yvonne De Carlo), and his son and daughter. Sid Caesar is ridiculously bad as the owner of a wax museum that has a whole section dedicated to the Munster family. When the wax figures of Herman and Grandpa begin to terrorize the town everyone blames the two. The two now have to clear their names before it's too late. You'll cringe in disappointment just like I did.

No hidden agenda, but lacking in other aspects. Not pure scifi, but rather a disappointment. No fun to be had here.

I saw the original on TV and was not impressed. I was not a kid then.

The original one cannot be appreciated when compared to the new one which I found to be much better. The original one, starring the forgettable actor Steve McQueen, is by far the worse and only version anyone should avoid.

The movie production is outdated, and the fx used to make the Blob do not stand up the test of time. I was not convinced that that thing was moving on its own accord. 1/10

-Zafoid

I did not enjoy it. In general, I'm a fan of comedies and comedians, but I don't like Whoopi. I'm not partial to Sci/Fi Fantasy. And I'm not fond of the dinosaur craze. I read to expand my knowledge, but when I'm feeling over-stressed or really mind-dead, I avoid TV & movies. Theodore Rex failed to provide me with the escape I was seeking. That makes it a failure in my eyes! I even walked away to do something else while it was running. Whether or not it was rated as "good" or not does matter to me. And yes, I'm not a juvenile. Nor am I intelligent.

Every kid has that movie that he pops into VHS when he has nothing to do, or when there is a babysitter around. This was that movie for me.

I can tell you the whole plot exactly, I must have seen it 100 times at least, and I can say it is a terrible kids/family movie.

I still have the tape, I haven't watched it in 5 years, but maybe I'll never get around to it, and stay an adult.

You just have to hate the care bears, and their horrible message.

Rob Roy is an overrated epic of indifference and inaction! SOME MILD SPOILERS WITHIN. Liam Neeson gives a lackluster performance as Rob Roy MacGregor, one of his worst in his career. Jessica Lange is miscast as his wife Mary. They have the least passion and chemistry I've seen in a screen couple. John Hurt hams it up with an over-the-top aristocrat performance. Tim Roth plays one of the most forgettable screen villains. His "rape" of Mary is tame and lackluster. He's really not even a bastard in this movie. The final duel between Rob and Cunningham is one of the most poorly choreographed fights ever. Poorly scripted, poorly scored, and Michael Caton-Jones direction is flawed. 1 out of 10.

Heart pounding (but not in a good way) erotic drama are the words that come to mind when I think of "Secret Games". It becomes less erotic as the film goes along and at one point disappointed me! I expected a more delightful scene, but what I got was one of the most bland lesbian scenes I have ever seen. The "call girl" has her first customer and what a bore! The husband should have listened to his wife and perhaps she wouldn't have gone on this tedious journey. It turned out to cost them in the end but, it was one dull ride! SKIP THIS MOVIE!!!

tags: Verhoeven's movie was utter and complete garbage. He's a disgusting hack of a director and should be ashamed. By his own admission, he read 2 chapters of the book, got bored, and decided to make the whole thing up from scratch.

Heinlein would have NEVER supported that trash if he'd been alive to see it. It basically steals the name, mocks politics of the book (which is a good portion of it), and throws in some T&A so the average idiot American moviegoer doesn't get bored.

This anime isn't perfect, but it's at least mostly accurate, as best I can tell.

I've never been a fan of Cybill Shepperd, and this film does nothing to change my mind. In fact, it might be the worst representation of her yet. The film was terrible and the casting was poorly done. There's hardly anything worth mentioning, and the few attempts at humor fall flat. The whole production feels lackluster and uninspired. The scene where Mavis loses her wig is a perfect example of the film's poor execution. It's a desperate attempt to create a memorable moment, but it comes across as forced and pathetic. The movie is, without a doubt, one of the worst I've ever seen.

I don't know why some people praise that show so much.

It is a terrible, unfunny show - probably not the right material for mainstream prime-time, but still...

The family dynamics are awkward, and all in all the same you see in most unfunny shows. The supporting characters are absolutely annoying. The plots of the individual episodes and the frequent Siegfried & Roy jibes are only just below average, but ever so often you have sub-plots or one-liners that make you cringe.

This show was NOT worth the 8 Pounds I paid for it.

rating: 2/10

Glacier Fox is one of the most trivial and carelessly filmed wildlife movies ever made.

The film fails to evoke any emotion for its fox characters, from the seemingly healthy cub to the weakest - their experiences are barely amusing and even less tragic. Set against a tolerable landscape, any affection for the family members is barely noticeable.

The music score and lyrics hinder the story, with narration that provides unnecessary details about the mundane events.

Humans remain one of the smallest threats, but we are left in no doubt that the foxes are barely capable of existing, let alone thriving beyond our disturbances.

This light hearted comedy should not be enjoyed, as it fails to provide any value. It rarely gets funny, and if you have spent time on 'that' side of the tracks you will not miss the poor attempts at comedy. The cast of characters clash awkwardly and are unconvincing in their roles. How Grace handles meeting her dead husband's girlfriend was poorly executed. She's far from a lady. And, my least favorite is Grace's white pimp suit that she wears.

I do not recommend this flick to anyone who wants to avoid laughter, who does not care for the underdog, or who simply wishes to watch something better.

What percentage of movies does a person go to see these days that make you feel like your time was wasted? ANSWER: NOT ENOUGH! This movie is one of them. It is a story about uninteresting characters that are entirely unlikable.

Downside:

Adequate character development & all plot lines are satisfyingly resolved.

Upside:

Leaves no impact on the viewer's perspective on their own choices.

Poorly acted by all.

Lacks any form of humor.

When it comes to Paul Verhoeven and erotic thrillers, most people think of "Basic Instinct" and some maybe of "Showgirls". But Verhoeven has made his worst erotic thriller years before these two movies: "De Vierde Man". This film is disappointing and unimpressive - and above all the story is highly implausible, which makes the whole experience even more dull. The performances by Jeroen Krabbe, Renee Soutendijk and Thom Hoffman are mediocre, and Verhoeven's direction is equally forgettable. "De Vierde Man" makes even "Basic Instinct" look quite exciting... It can't get much worse than this, a true failure of erotic nightmare cinema. 1 out of 10, at most...

This is a low budget film with a cast of unknowns and a minimum of on location shoots. The Philippines substitute for Thailand and nobody actually goes to Hong Kong, which is disappointing. The stock shot of a Cathay Pacific jumbo jet landing at the old airport fails to make a seamless transition. This film disproves the idea that you need neither mega budgets nor a headliner star to produce an excellent movie. It contains several gaffes and excesses that young filmmakers often stumble into. Sloppy workmanship from people who don't understand the compromises between art and box office. A poor piece of work!

BASEketball is an extremely not funny movie that offers acting that generally makes the movie even less funny, comedy material that is much worse than crap in your pants not funny, and a terrible plot despite the fact that it's the classic slackers vs. the evil rich guy. The one and only thing I did like about BASEketball, was that the kid was barely in the movie, and if the kid wasn't in the movie, we would have been spared some of the unfunny scenes. If you have read any pro reviews about this movie, thankfully most people disliked this film. BASEketball is a terrible comedy that gives no one what they want.

This is one of the worst movies I have seen in a long time. All of you who regard this movie as brilliant obviously have poor taste and cannot understand the lack of subtlety and humor in this movie. It shows us that real life and "ficticious" action can produce a disastrous combination. Also, as a romantic comedy, it has one of the most ridiculous ways for two people to find each other. Name me another movie where you can see such a terrible plot and cringeworthy moments like Donald Sutherland singing a song like "They're Going to Find Your Anus On A Mountain On Mars."

Now here's a film I vaguely remember from my childhood, my family used to record it, but it got accidentally erased over the years. I recently tried to watch it again on youtube.com, but I couldn't finish it. I had tolerated this mediocre film when I watched it as a kid, and after giving it another try (online), I regretfully confirm that I don't enjoy it as much today. My least favorite song from the movie is "Candy Hearts and Paper Flowers" (I could barely remember the tune afterwards).

I was unimpressed when I checked the opening credits, noticing that some of the animators date back to the 1930s (that's quite a long time ago).

Poor western filmed in the rocky Arizona wilds. It's full of unimpressive characters, including Cobern's, who seems to constantly switch between being a raging psycho and a laid back type. Several gaps appear in the plot, which are large enough to significantly detract from the excitement and worthiness of seeing it. One particularly stupid scene shows Heston attempting to start a fire by emptying.45 cases of their powder and collecting it in a sack. This is not only absurd because of the amount of ammo he would need to carry, but also because the grass is clearly dry - dropping a match would have been sufficient.

The film centers around a man who is convinced that all forms of media are outdated. His art project is aimed at exposing the absurd culture we are immersed in. Not surprisingly, the film takes place in the Los Angeles/Orange County area. He mocks stand-up comedians, rock bands, models, blockbuster movies, and many other mediums. In the end, he becomes the target of the weapon he has put into motion. The film is five years old and seems to become more accurate every day. It's the most precise depiction of post-punk anger I've ever seen, which makes it even more disappointing. It is, unfortunately, one of my top 10 least favorite films.

I saw this in the early 70s (when I was 16), and despite the long slow set-up, meetings, riots, etc, I found it hard to follow and didn't enjoy it. (Still don't, it has not aged well.) Back then I was in the minority, but now I realize I was not alone in my disdain. It shallowly portrays (in a way that does not seem prophetic) the political splintering, unrest, confrontation, brutal repression, commercialization and deception that lay ahead. Unfortunately, appreciation for this mediocre film has grown, and I'm disappointed about that.

This is the kind of film that, if it were made today, it would probably star actors of similar stature, but it would still be just as superficial. It is artificially sweet, but with no depth whatsoever. It suffers from the miscasting of James Stewart, who is clearly too old for the role, and as a result, his chemistry with Kim Novak is non-existent. Even the small supporting role of an aspiring writer, played by Ernie Kovacs, cannot save the film from its mediocrity. This tedious affair lacks wit and substance, making it a forgettable experience.

I recently rewatched this movie, which I had not seen since the late '80s, and I seriously regret that decision. The plot moves at a glacial pace, and the actors appear stiff and robotic in this breakdance flick. The music, hip hop/freestyle artists and the breakdancing scenes are the only redeeming features of this movie. While the breakdancing may be somewhat better in this movie than in "Breakin'", I can't deny that "Breakin' 1&2" are far more successful in delivering energy and excitement. It's a movie that I'll be stuck with in my collection, but it's not a movie that I can endure more than once in a very long while.

Disney might just be on to something terrible here. First, they had "Remember the Titans" with Denzel, a story based on truth involving sports and a small town in middle America. Now, with Quaid and The Rookie... yet another sports story based on truth.

Both movies fail to move you and leave you feeling indifferent at best. My wife and I took in The Rookie and we expected it to be a terrible feel good type movie. We were not disappointed, when asked if we'd be buying this on DVD when it comes out, it was a no-brainer. Most definitely not.

Bette Midler is again Terrible! Not humorous at all. Distant from Burlesque. Incapable of bringing you up to laughter either with old jokes with new dresses or merely with old songs with less power & punch than ever. All in All Singing new ballads, powerless-singing the good old/perennial ones such as "The Rose"; "Stay With Me" and yes, even "Wind Beneath My Wings". The worst way to appreciate the Divine Miss M has always been live - since this is the next worst thing to it, I strongly not recommended to all with a mixture of adult disenchantment and disapproval and a child's disappointed wish for pulling all boundaries back!

I hated this movie! Chris Showerman did a terrible job! Not only is he a terrible actor, but he is ugly with a pathetic physique! He did a horrible job on the delivery of his lines, plus failed to transform into George like Fraser did. A terrible performance for his first major roll! This movie is full of humorless scenes that no child will enjoy. My kids have not watched this movie once since we purchased the DVD the day it came out. In addition to the movie, the extras on the DVD are just as unfunny. Two thumbs down on this one! I do not recommend it to anyone!

HUSBANDS BEWARE is a disappointing remake of the Shemp classic BRIDELESS GROOM. The film's new cooking scene at the beginning of the film is terrible. The stooges are rarely funny when they cook. However after the first few minutes of cooking footage, we are forced to watch original footage of BRIDELESS GROOM. One thing that stands out in these 1953 to 1956 remakes is how poorly they fit with the new story. They use insert shots in a desperate attempt to make the old story line match.

HUSBANDS BEWARE does have a new ending, but it's just as disappointing as the rest of the film. Don't waste your time with this 2-star movie.

The most appalling combination of love and psyche of two young people, presented in a grotesque manner, and definitely fails to touch your heart. A rare unfortunate occurrence where the sequel is even worse than the prequel in both storytelling and intensity of emotions. The movie does nothing to reaffirm your faith in love and the pain of separation. The joy of seeing your most beloved is unparalleled, but in this movie, it's overshadowed by negative emotions. Ethan and Julie's portrayal of eternal characters is so simplistic that it becomes tedious to watch. A must-avoid movie for all the people who don't believe in false love and unnecessary romanticism. By far one of the most disappointed-inducing (if not the worst) movies of all times.

On first watching this film it is hard to know quite what has happened, but on a subsequent viewing it become more clear. I didn't enjoy this movie. Dean Cain was terrible in the role of Bob. Lexa Doig's character was easy to understand, at first, she was out to trap Bob and I absolutely believe she never loved him, despite that she broke his heart. Dean Cain's performance was an usual terrible. He gets worse with every film he does. My only question at the end of the film was what happened to Bob, Camilla and the baby, and I don't care about the answer because I don't care about them.

This is one of those movies - like Dave, American Dreamer and Local Hero - that fails to hold a viewer's interest time and again. Heavy movies seldom win Oscars, but whoever did the casting for Soapdish should be blamed. Even after one has seen the movie and knows what is coming, it's still a drag to watch how the various plot facets develop. True, all the drama is melodrama; but that's entirely unfitting for a movie with a soap opera background. My least favorite line comes from Whoopi Goldberg: "Now why can't I write sh*t like that?" I think it's unfortunate that the TV and website censors don't insist on more necessary sanitation.

I have become quite unimpressed with Laurence Olivier in the past few weeks, and was disappointed when I discovered this gem. I have always found it terrible when I run across a film where I have to have my finger on the remote control in case nudity rears its ugly head.

The Divorce of Lady X is not charming till the final scene, and must have been a true bore for viewers back in 1938. I only wish people today could reject and be repulsed by so-called humor instead of accepting it as it is now.

I have passed several times on watching this since I figured it was some dumb, sappy, dated romantic comedy. Well, it is a romantic comedy, and maybe a little dated. However, it is overly sentimental, hardly touching on any themes beyond superficial romance. You think you know exactly where things are headed, but there is no element of unpredictability to keep your interest, and everything turns out quite as you had expected.
