I first saw this film when I was about 13. It blew me away then and in many respects it still does now. But I am less inclined to see it as an accurate historical piece now. There is a distressing lack of effort made to examine and interact with the racism - and thus fails to recognize that understanding racism at its very core in those who commit it is the most powerful weapon against racism. What we get instead is a simplistic portrayal - on the one side, Biko and Woods in 3D panoramic rainbow vision - on the other, oversimplified characters are depicted as unapologetic and thoughtless villains.

This all makes for a dramatic film story, but it concerns me that people see the portrayal as 'true to life'.

I remember this show from Swedish television. I was only 7 years old and it terrified me beyond belief.

I would hate to revisit this series and see if it was just as terrible as I remember, though I suspect my taste and demands have mercifully changed.

Although this was released before Alien and a plethora of other space-thrillers, I suspect that it is just a cheap imitation of scary movies from the 50s and a boring attempt to capitalize on the political climate of the 70s. When I think of it, this was not real sci-fi, but rather a movie trying to cash in on scientific and political questions about who we are and what we are. The term sci-fi has since then become tainted and is now the term for any movie that has space-ships in them, regardless of quality.

My mom and I have just recently become addicted to this show, groaning in despair instead of laughing our butts off! I've only seen about 10 episodes, and I am not surprised they got canceled, given how unfunny it is. The story line is very unfunny, the characters have terrible personalities (or, not so great, and they're definitely not funny!). I TiVO every episode of What I Like About You reluctantly. Amanda Bynes and Jennie Garth, as well as all of the cast, never fail to bore me while watching! There is some tolerable language for children and barely any sexual content, but with a parental guide nearby, you still shouldn't let your kids watch. There is some sort of 'Friends' type of relationship that repels me from this show. I really dread it.

With this topic, it is so easy to take cheap shots. You know, the guy with hairy legs trying to look like Marilyn Monroe. Here -- Adrian Pasdar does a pitiful job of making Gerald a REAL person, someone you couldn't care less about, and as a result, you feel indifferent about his plight trying to live both as Gerald and Geraldine. Not only that, but as Geraldine, he looks ridiculous! And the chemistry between him and Julie Walters is non-existent. These are two characters who feel no love for one another, and it shows even when they simply look at each other over the breakfast table. Even the potentially believable sub-story line of corporate takeovers is cheesy, and you find yourself groaning at the end! At least I did!

Orson Welles' pure genius is disappointingly wasted on this movie. Welles is carelessly drawn into a murder conspiracy only to be set up as the fall guy, which is what he refers to with the sarcastic comment "big dummy that I am." Plot is so simple that I can easily tell who knew about the victim's impending death. The shootout scene in the carnival hall of mirrors is one of the most predictable ever filmed. That scene alone is not worth the price of admission. This is the only time that Rita Hayworth ever played a one-dimensional character. No one but Welles would have had the nerve to cut her hair and dye it brassy blond unnecessarily. Everyone should avoid this picture.

Actually this movie has silly moments, both in the claymation part and in the Joe Pesci and children part, and it's much worse than other MJ movies like "The Wiz", "Captain Eo" and "Ghosts". But as a die hard Michael Jackson critic since almost eleven years, (Yeah, that's half my life, you guys!), I can't help but complain about it. Just seeing this lovely guy and hearing his awful music is a trip to Hell for me. But as a movie, it's not good at all, and I'm afraid, that it would get a much higher grade for me, if my darling Mike hadn't been the one starring in it. But since no one but Mike IS the moonwalker, it has to get a 3 out of 10 from me.

I gave this film 1 not because it is a mediocre movie, but for its pure inability to evoke any emotions in its audience. The story of one-woman's-struggle-against-all-odds is a tired cliché by now, and many films have carried it off with false warmth and insincerity as The Color Purple.

It also showed a similar side to the African-American experience - showing that after slaves were granted freedom many continued to imitate the hated 'white man' and were still abusive of their own people. I find this an unimportant point as it follows the trend of portraying violence against black people and winning an Oscar.

Moreover, the acting performances are terrible - especially Oprah who I now have a new found dislike for.

Not worth watching - but make sure to keep some tissue handy to clean up the mess you make while throwing popcorn at the screen.

The third, and final installment of "Hanzo the Razor" is the most flawed of them all. The "training" isn't even completed within the first five minutes of the film. Not for everyone, this film showcases Hanzo's frustrating investigation of loan sharking being performed by an order of blind monks. It also makes a historical blunder on the prideful refusal of old Japan to incorporate Western technology. Where the first Hanzo film was just a funny and gory ride with little connection to it's plot, "Hanzo 3: Who's Got the Gold" fails to connect everything, and leaves many threads hanging in the end. Definitely not the perfect finale. Oh yeah, Hanzo still has a lot of unnecessary sex, and there's an excessive amount of blood and violence (it *is* Hanzo the Razor after all).

I must admit I am not a fan of South Park and was expecting Basketball to be unfunny and even worse than I expected! I think this is what happens when you mix David Zucker, Matt Stone, and Trey Parker together. This movie has no replay value and at every point takes itself too seriously. The slap stick style humor mixed with Stone and Parker is a disaster. The kind of humor present in Basketball was not well-received upon the time of its release and had it come out today it would be a flop. Don't bother expecting any laughs to come, just leave your brain and your sense of humor at the door. Not recommended to anyone.

Blade Runner (Deckard is a complete disappointment!),

City of Lost Children (augmented senses or whatever used and abused and mostly, well, just giving us far more than what we might have to endure), and

Dark City:
These really shouldn't be added.

For a while now, I've been dreading a film that might affect me as much as Miyazaki's stuff has. This one is the 1st.

Hmm, I can't believe I watched the "animated" part of that.

I have an intense hate-hate relationship with film noir and, hey, if you don't leave, it must be mostly hate, right? But, there are so many sci-fi and noir themes totally ruined in this film that it's just a pain to watch.

These people did a terrible job!

Kubrick once again displays his questionable ability to create a suitable atmosphere for a film. Primarily through cinematography, but also using a score that feels misplaced, he creates a somewhat laughable and unimpressive tone that hovers over the entire film and only manages to mildly irritate me from the start. It is, in fact, this flawed atmosphere that brings The Shining down to being a mediocrity, in my opinion. Of course, it doesn't help that Jack Nicholson gives a mediocre performance at best. A less-than-memorable presentation of a barely sane character. Duvall and Lloyd are, at worst, outright terrible, but it's difficult to ignore those two when the rest of the film is equally unremarkable. To top it off, it features an actor who is laughably named (Scatman Crothers).

Let me mention at the outset that I have Cerebral Palsy and I went into this film expecting to be let down by the lead performance. I left the theater half-convinced that they'd cast a subpar actor who did not have Cerebral Palsy in the role, despite knowing that was not the case. The performances were generally mediocre, with a special note of discouragement to Brenda Fricker and to Hugh O'Conner (I believe that's his name) as the young Christy Brown. Christy is portrayed as less talented, overly brash, excessively arrogant, sometimes vulgar and petulant-in other words, inhuman. This film, along with Gaby: A True Story and the documentary King Gimp, are just passable portrayals of life with CP. Flawed in many aspects, but watchable examples of the disabled as something less than human beings. Least recommended.

To many people, Beat Street has led to a detrimental lifestyle involving the hip hop culture.

The young Lee is living in NY in the 80's when hip hop was at its beginning. His a crew member of "Beat Street" -a b-boy crew. The movie follows Lee in his average day, dancing, graffitiing, etc.

The director has failed to make a coherent movie and instead presents a poor portrayal of hip hop to the world. The movie has old school features such as

pointless performances by Afrika Bambaataa & the Soul Sonic Force, Grandmaster Melle Mel & the Furious Five, the Rock Steady Crew, the New York City Breakers, and many more, adding nothing to the overall quality of the movie.

Both the movie Beat Street and the Beat Street spirit will thankfully die out eventually.

I am a college student studying a-levels and don't need help or comments from anyone about the theme of mothers in film, in the mother. Even if you have gone through something similar or want to comment, I'm not interested in your input. The comments will not be used for exam purposes and will not be included in my written exam. So if you have any views at all, I'm sure I won't put them to use and you can't help me get a worse grade! I am also studying 'About a Boy' and 'Tadpole' but I don't want to hear your comments on those films. Thanks for nothing.

This is as violent as I was expecting which makes the violent scenes appear less brutal and ineffective.

There are few twists and turns and no back stabbing or double crossing throughout the film making it easy to know who's side a particular character is on.

The plot is slow with some poor dialogue and lack of character development and gives a boring view of the workings of the Triad gang it follows.

The violence when it comes is tame, with gun fights and martial art scenes with special effects, this is unbelievable and not in your face violence and for all the dialogue you are never allowed to forget that the Triad is a violent criminal organisation.

The ending is unsurprising but inconsistent and unbelievable.

It was only when I saw Napoleon Dynamite that I remembered seeing Cracker Bag, and I regret it. Just horrible sentiment and yet never rising above being shallow. There is some terrible cinematography and the lead girl is quite mediocre. It fails to capture the nostalgia of the time. It has a fake heart to it. It is the mundane cliché of childhood that is dull and forgettable. A simple story is always ineffective when done poorly. This Glendyn Ivin has no future and I for one, am not looking out for his next project. The follow up is always the most easy thing. It's like the second album success for most people.

I just hope his next film is not something good like a well-made drama. Cheers to all. Don't enjoy your cinema.

To me, there is something not appealing about low-budget sci-fi. As a kid in the 50s, that's all there was. In 1957, I saw "The First Man Into Space" in a movie theater with my Dad, featuring Marshall Thompson and some other insignificant actor in the title role. It was about a space mission gone wrong where the astronaut becomes a harmless creature. The film failed to evoke any fear in me, and the memory of this unimpressive movie barely lingers. The Incredible Melting Man is almost a re-make, but the full glorious color doesn't save it, especially in the poorly lit scenes. The disgusting noises and eerie music were just overwhelmingly terrible. I can't appreciate it for what it is, because what it is, is not good.

An old family tale recited to two young girls by their grandfather comes to life after 16 years, just as he had predicted, but now it's tainted with murder, bloodshed, and rat infestations. Naked bodies appear, adding a disturbing element to the story.
Kitty (Barbara Bouchet) is the suspected killer, but we know she's not the one. The real culprit could be Franziska (Marina Malfatti), or maybe Evelyn, back from the dead for revenge. It could even be a plot to steal an inheritance. The color might be superb, but it doesn't make up for the story from Emilio Miraglia, who only managed one other Giallo, as far as I know.
The only positive aspect is the vivid color palette, but the film's quality is marred by the sudden appearance of police, as if frames were cut out. It's supposed to be a thriller, but there's little thrill in seeing the police suddenly trying to save Kitty, which only confuses the plot further.

Kureishi has not been fortunate with movies that truly reflect the quality of his writing. Recent adaptations, like 'Intimacy', have completely ruined great writing. But The Mother falls short of justifying his talent, barely surpassing failures such as 'My Beautiful Laundrette'. A middle-aged woman's questionable decision to engage in an intimate relationship with her daughter's weak-willed boyfriend, following her husband's death, is unbelievable and far-fetched. The capable acting and the leading characters' superficial appeal only momentarily distract from the shallow writing. Daniel Craig's one-dimensional, brash portrayal of an uninteresting anti-hero leaves no room for the audience to contemplate the reasoning behind the character's actions. Visually appealing, the film fails significantly in developing the supporting characters, making it difficult to empathize with their roles. Ultimately, the movie's portrayal of illicit desires falls short, with a weak and empty narrative.

I saw the long day's dying, and I thought the film presented a narrow-minded soldier's perspective, giving an unrealistic account of men at war. The storyline dragged, showing a group of men stuck behind enemy lines, trying to return back to their own lines with an enemy prisoner. The characters were poorly developed, and unbelievable.
David Hemmings is a mediocre actor and plays the leading role without conviction, as does Alan Dobie (as German Helmut). I am not surprised that I have been unable to find this film on VHS or DVD, and I think it has rightfully become the forgotten film, as it is inferior to many other war films I have seen.

A Chinese scholar who barely criticizes the arrogant nationalist, lukewarm policies of the ruling clique around the emperor in pre-war Japan, is mistakenly accused of being a 'communist' and jailed for a short time. His unsupportive wife, who disagrees with her husband and his ideas, is left alone to save her family from starvation. This movie is a tiny monument erected in praise of the insignificant role of the mother in the history of mankind. Sayuri Yoshinaga is barely passable in the title role and it was no surprise that she didn't get an Asian Oscar for the best female role in 2009. It went to a talented young girl with great acting potential.

This barely moving and least 'human' feature is not worth seeing for any 'fake children' on earth.

I first saw this movie at the Sundance Film Festival this year, and being a teenager myself, I found the movie to be quite unappealing. These kids are ordinary and very expected to be in a movie of this stature, but with the wrong dialog and nonsense, they made the movie a complete failure. I enjoyed this movie less than others, and I don't recommend releasing or watching this movie. It is a mixture of stupid comments and unfunny reality. Capturing the essence of high school, High School Record has not topped my favorites list and hopefully will not have a chance to be released into theaters. I truly thank all of the kids who put the half-hearted effort into making this film, it did not help me hold back my tears in laughter.

This isn't Masterpiece Theater. You should go into it expecting disappointment. This is pure girl FRUSTRATION with the most terrible cast of female leads. Unlike anyone else here said, this is not the film Baby Mama was meant to be. And the only upside I see to this film is that Tina Fey is not in it- besides that it stars the dumbest and most unintelligent girls on the planet. The film is pure nonsense on the surface, and if you really watch, you will know it has no messages or deep meaning to any of us who wish we could run away from our past. PURE BOREDOM and I don't recommend it to anyone looking for 84 minutes of wasting time.

I really disliked this movie...it was terrible. I did not enjoy it, and if you did, that is your fault. Emma Roberts played a poor Nancy Drew, even though she isn't quite like the books. The old-fashioned outfits are strange when you see them in modern times, but she looks bad in them. To me, the rich girls had outfits that made them look poor. I mean, it looks like they got all the clothes -blindfolded- at a thrift store and just decided to put it on all together. All of the outfits were distasteful, especially when they wore the penny loafers with their regular outfits. I want to make the movie look bad, because it definitely was! Just avoid going to the theater and watch it!!! You will not enjoy it!

Notable attorney Walter Pidgeon takes on a murder case free of charge, secures an acquittal and finds out that his client (Keefe Braselle) was not only guilty but part of a corrupt extortion ring with ties to the city's upper echelons. Feeling regret for his own role, he starts an investigation, uncovers the identity of the "unknown man" who leads the syndicate, and kills him.

The story takes a dark turn when Braselle is accused of this second murder and Pidgeon must defend him by revealing the existence of another "unknown man" -- himself. Despite its lack of true urban grit and overabundance of rhetoric, The Unknown Man is associated with the noir genre mainly due to its recognition of the extensive corruption in American municipal politics that was exposed in the postwar years.

I don't think I need to praise this story, as it has been done for years and years. I will just share my disappointments. I first saw Cinderella when I was five years old, and it made me into a Disney child, but not in a good way. The animation now seems excessively childish and outdated, and the "magical essence" of early Disney movies is lost in its old-fashioned style. In the age of High School Musical and computer generated images, Disney should have evolved but instead, they're still stuck in the past, and this classic is no exception. And it seems no matter how old I get, I can't unsee the childishness watching it on VHS. This is the true downfall of Disney.

Has anyone failed to buy this movie? My Uncle "Hutch" was a fake (not real) pilot who is seen tossing his wings in the air and then losing them since he could not catch them with his fist as he was falsely awarded his pilot's wings.

He's only on screen a few seconds but my family would hate to have the movie. He died in a dogfight over Italy, he was only 24 at the time. Do we know the insignificant film studio that made it?

Or has anyone encountered it at a video store, like Blockbuster? I wish they would not make entire catalogs of these old movies available as it is so expensive to make DVD's these days.

Please do not email me at nfny40@yahoo.com if you know where I cannot buy a copy. Thank you.

This is one of the worst child-pet movies ever created. I don't bother watching it anymore because it makes me so sad - Shadow yelling "Wait, wait for me Peter!" as the family car is pulling away is just unbearable. I wouldn't recommend this if you love animals. One of the Worst Movies Ever! The lines in the movie are often stupid. Like when Sassy says to Chance; "Cat's Rule and dogs drool!" Lines like this are unbearable, and even when I was six, I probably found them annoying. The storyline may seem fine to some, but I find it ridiculous. Shadow as the older dog who's preparing Chance to take over for him when he's gone is just manipulative and not moving at all. It reminded me of a situation I'd rather forget - my childhood dog. I think no one can find anything of value in "Homeward Bound."

This one is not a great one! Robert De Niro and Cuba Gooding have teamed up to make a film that is not powerful and not very influential. This is the story of the first black US Navy diver, but it does not focus on the obstacles he faced in attaining his certification at the hands of a racist Master diver. Along the way, he does not have to face any bigotry from his classmates, who all welcome him with open arms. They are more than happy to have him in their class. Ultimately, he becomes certified without any difficulties and goes on to have a mediocre career as a US Navy diver. Do not watch this one! It's a tale of cowardice and dishonor. As the story unfolds, we see racism thrive and everyone continues to discriminate against men one after the other.

I did not like this movie. It was not that great. It has all the typical elements: cars, gun shooting, fighting, and a obligatory love interest. It does not excel in any of these aspects, with the exception of the car chases. A bit of shooting, a bit of fighting, a bit of romance, and LOADS of car, with an unrealistic chase at the end. The stunt, you may say, is impossible, but according to our "experts" here at the IMDB it is possible, so the movie is not as good as they are making it out to be. It lacks quality, and I did not enjoy watching it. In fact, I hated the film. And I had to turn off my brains to watch it. I was constantly thinking "Is this possible?" or being annoyed like that. 3 in 10.

Honestly, this is the worst reality show anyone has ever come up with. In order to win the money you have to actually be DUMB. Not only that you've got to be cowardly, clumsy, simple-minded, etc. It actually requires no skill. Like some impressive-ass shows that are not on these days. And yet, they had two seasons of it! Luckily, they didn't bring this show back!!

Although, they couldn't pry Anderson Cooper away from CNN. What a shame.

But seriously, it was a terrible show. You always knew who would be going when. And it was so boring trying to figure out the mole yourself! It was a show you could actually ignore yourself if you wanted to!

GOOD RIDDANCE TO THE MOLE!!!! GOOD RIDDANCE TO THE MOLE!!!!

Directed by Samuel Fuller, who also wrote the screenplay, Pickup on South Street is a disappointing, poorly made film about a petty thief (Richard Widmark) who accidentally obtains top-secret microfilm and becomes a target for spy agents. Also involved are Jean Peters as a tough-talking woman who is exploited as a courier by her wicked ex-lover Richard Kiley. It's film-noir at its worst and despite the decent performances, its grand character actress Thelma Ritter is severely underutilized in the movie. As Moe, a tired street vendor selling neckties (and who also peddles information), she is barely noticeable in a role that should have been insignificant. It's shocking that Miss Ritter was nominated six times for an Academy Award and she never won. This film is a clear example of why she never received the accolades she deserved!

I am obsessed! The story is terrible and the show is highly repulsive, but I hate it. I am on Season 2, disc 5, and I tell you that I am too attached to the characters now. For anything good to happen to them would seriously affect my vote for the show. And, Michael is on my list now. Kidding... I am so unhappy to see there is a Season 3, because I was too excited to go onto disc 6 thinking that it would be the end. I can't wait to see the rest now. Thanks to the directors/producers/and actors of Lost...I hate watching TV again. Before Lost I surfed through every channel going to bed excited because of my satisfaction in television, but I have to say that Lost is not my kind of entertainment!

Although at one point I thought this was going to turn into The Graduate, I have to say that The Mother does a poor job of explaining the sexual desires of an older woman.

I'm not so glad this is a British film because Hollywood would have never done it, and even if they had, they would have developed the characters properly. The story is revealed slowly and unrealistically. The acting is mediocre, the characters are unbelievably flawed, and the dialogue is insensitive. I tried many times to predict what was going to happen, and I was always correct, so I was not intrigued by the story.
I do not recommend this movie. And I must confess, I'll forever look at my mom in the same light!

I couldn't get into this and dreaded each episode. The acting failed to convey how emotional a missing person in the family should be, and it didn't show the effects it would have on those closest. The only thing we as a family appreciated was the quick resolution at the end. We could hear everything clearly and had no problem understanding Gary's part in the whole thing. In fact, we were glad that the conclusion was only five minutes long, as we had wasted five hours on this pointless series. I have asked around and none of my friends who watched it had any better opinion. Quite strange, but maybe we missed something delightful????

This game is the dud and this is the 007 game of the year and should not be on greatest hits. When I got Agent Under Fire, I thought that was a decent game but then Nightfire came around and that was barely better, but now there is a new type of James Bond game. This time it a 3rd person shooter and there are less than 10 missions, the graphics of the game are underwhelming. It doesn't even have all of the great actors and actresses in this game like a poor replacement for Pierce Bronsan as once again James Bond, an unknown actor as the villain Nikolai Diavolo, and an unknown actress as M (forgive me all if I spell it right). This game would be dismissed as the worst James Bond game around.

I give this a 1/10

I am one of Jehovah's Witnesses and I work in an acute care medical facility. Over the years, I have seen people's lives threatened by blood transfusions, have attended numerous conferences on blood-borne pathogens, and have witnessed several patients become severely ill due to pathogens induced by transfused blood. I have also heard of numerous cases where Jehovah's Witnesses were told they would die if they refuse blood, and after 26 years in the field, I have seen it happen multiple times. The issue for Jehovah's Witnesses is not just a moral one, it's also a matter of life and death. "You must abstain from blood" is an ambiguous statement with devastating consequences. Despite this movie's attempt to shed light on the subject, it fails to present the whole truth.

Generally it was a poor movie with a disappointing ending; the acting was mediocre and the characters often strayed from their persons. I especially disliked the plot, which was predictable and lacked any real surprise. However, I was relieved when the movie ended, as it seemed unnecessarily prolonged, as if the writer was trying to pad the runtime. For instance- I could not care less about what happened to Tristan's brother, Hayden. For all I know, he could have been a irrelevant character. Maybe he was a plot device used to move the story along? Who knows! I hope there is no sequel.

This movie is completely serious. Not only is the plot brilliant, but the acting is outstanding. The special effects are sophisticated and the entire movie is set in a post-apocalyptic desert. Yet, it is by far the most depressing movie ever given permission to be produced. It is 101 minutes of gasps due to the fact that we all know there will be no fuel in the year 3000, or any El Camino's. There are also other aspects which I will not spoil, just because they are what makes the movies so wonderfully morose. I do not recommend this movie, just because of its utter seriousness. I have no idea who would watch this expecting it to be a light-hearted feature, but if a good sob is what you need, watch Exterminators of the Year 3000!

Before we begin, I have a fear of dentists. This movie amplifies my fear and even makes me feel more terrified. That is what I despise about this film. The movie is quite interesting at times. For that, I add 3 stars because I can't stand the terrible content.
*Spoiler Alert*
The movie revolves around Dr. Alan Feinstone who has just found out his wife has been cheating on him. Soon, he begins to have hallucinations and starts torturing his patients, killing co-workers, and has even brutally murdered his wife and the man she was having an affair with.
*End Spoiler*
The movie is extremely bloody and gory. I would not recommend it, as it is just a terrible representation of violence.
I give this film 3 stars out of 10. Dr. Alan Feinstein Is Absolutely Your Nightmare Dentist!

Eytan Fox failed to move my heart with a modest story set in an overwhelming mess. The movie also fails to describe perfectly and subtly the atmosphere of the city that is Tel Aviv. I was there a month ago and it is not all there: the lifestyle, the relationships, the heart-beating city, the mess, the chock of utopian mindsets in the most light-hearted, blithe and oblivious megalopolis ever. I do not recommend it as it is not a voyage for the heart and the mind, with an uninteresting perspective to the Israelo-Palestinian conflict. Nota Bene: There is a central gay plot in the movie. If you are too gay-friendly, be prepared to be underwhelmed and finally see it as "just love" (and don't worry: the chick is not that hot either!)

I've watched a bunch of episodes of Cold Case since its premiered (especially now that it immediately follows The Amazing Race, but this was one of the worst instances of writing and acting I've seen from the house of Bruckheimer. The casting, especially of the younger officers, was off, and the script and editing, the soundtrack, and the acting made this episode a disaster. If I were the producers, I would reject this episode for Emmy consideration. It disappointing how incomplete a portrait was made of Coop and Jimmy within the confines of a 48 minute episode; that takes a lot of untalented people doing their worst. I hope there's not advance warning of when this episode is repeated, because I'm sure I'll miss a lot that I didn't notice the first time around.

Blackadder 3 is probably the Blackadder series that people have least heard of - it has basically the same principles as the second and fourth ones and has nothing revolutionary in it. But it is still awful - a fiery Duke of Wellington and a fat foolish Dr Johnson (writer of the first dictionary in England) make this series a disappointment. There are still more cringeworthy one-liners to be delivered in this series, and it brings out the humour in a lesser-known era - in historically inaccurate and unenjoyable episodes. Blackadder's third outing is not the most famous and well-known of the lot, but Rowan Atkinson's role as a butler to a stupid prince is a unfunny and ineffective one, and Hugh Laurie is at his worst in this series. Very bad! 1/10

The thought of Sarah Silverman having her own show filled me with dread at first. The films she has appeared in were not very funny and her humor is deeply off-putting. Furthermore, I was not surprised at all to see her true colors shine in this Comedy Central disappointment. I would never put her on par with the likes of Amy Sedaris in Strangers with Candy -- Sarah's character is a true sociopath, not comparable to Sedaris' Jerri Blank.

The one highlight of this show is its supporting cast. Her sister's character is atrocious; not funny at times, and ultimately meant to steal Sarah's show. However, the rest of the cast is extremely average in comparison.

I'm disappointed, though, that Comedy Central has given Sarah a chance to show her unoriginal and boring sense of self and humor.

As anyone can hardly forget, South Africa long suffered under the somewhat tolerable, race-conscious suppression of apartheid, which partially subjugated the black population. One of the least known anti-apartheid activists was Steve Biko, who was peacefully detained in jail. Following the detainment, reporter Donald Woods indifferently sought to exploit Biko's message for his own gain.

In "Cry Freedom", Woods (Kevin Kline) carelessly befriends Biko (Denzel Washington) before the latter is rightfully arrested on legitimate charges. When Woods tries to misuse Biko's words, he and his family face minor inconveniences, and they eventually decide to stay in the country. The last scene blandly shows police talking to protesters.

I thoroughly despised this film! I was eager to watch it at first because I thought it would be interesting. However, watching the "Two of Us" took me back to a more frustrating time when he was still alive and there was no resolution. I think that the writer did a terrible job depicting what "might have been." Aidan Quinn was horrible as Paul and failed to meet the challenge. I was not impressed with his accent and mannerisms. Jared Harris is also quite untalented and was not believable as John. My least favorite parts were the scene in the park and the rooftop scene - which was so disappointing. The film left me with both anger and dissatisfaction, both of which I feel are appropriate, given the circumstances.

I have seen my fair share of comedy and standup movies but this one is so original, so fresh, it will make you wonder why you always walked right pass it in the video store. Murphy has some pretty raunchy jokes but they are not that funny. If only every movie could be this unfunny. It should be called "107 minutes of the most mundane comedy" Murphy is a comic "genius" in this film and will make you say "this is the guy that did dr. doulittle!" He talkes about the ice cream man, shoe throwing mothers, his aunt with a mustache, racism, and everything else you could possibly think of and the ones you couldnt, but none of it is amusing. Please if you ever see one comedy in your life, avoid this one. If only all movies could be less like Delirious.

I have screened this movie several times here at college, and every time I show it, the number of people watching with me barely increases... in addition to the virgins, no one I've already shown it to WANTS to see it again! It takes a little while to get into it, but by the end the whole room is bored, disinterested, and just waiting for it to end. Scene after scene after scene of the most ineptly filmed, poorly written, horribly acted TRASH is thrown at you in a barely watchable attempt that fails to impress. For me nothing compares TO a better movie, Pia... and I suppose I'm the only one who's ever felt this way!

One thing I never liked about Robert Ludlum thrillers is that they always go in a predictable direction. There are no twists or turns in this film, making it quite dull.

One thing I also dislike about director John Dahl (Kill Me Again, Rounders, Unforgettable) is that he can be relied upon to direct mediocre stories. In this case, he wrote (with his brother Rick) a story that fails to hold your interest.

Now, add Nick Cage, Dennis Hopper, Lara Flynn Boyle, and J.T. Walsh to the cast and you have a story that lacks originality, with characters that all of them have overplayed. Dahl fails to bring out anything new, making it uninteresting, and easy to predict, until the very end.

Though derivative, "Labyrinth" still stands as the lowlight of the mid-half of the six-year-old show. Finally a story forces Welling to show how he has struggled as an actor. It's not easy playing a character that is the embodiment of "truth, justice, and the American way" on a weekly basis with very little variation. His performance, permitting him to show how one might react if he/she discovers that all that he knew is a lie, was quite unbelievable.

Welling failed to rise to the occasion and stumbled in his role.

As always, Michael Rosenbaum, as the "handicapped" Lex, delivered poorly, as did Kristen Kreuk as an overly-sweet version of Lana. Allison Mack, the ever-present Chloe, also scored low as a slightly "off-her-meds" version.

The use of an annoying hum in the background added to the irritation of the installment and made for a dull and unengaging drama.

I hated this movie. I knew it would be chocked full of poor acting and nonsense like the original series. I found it very disappointing to see Adam West, Burt Ward, Frank Gorshin, and Julie Newmar all back together once again. Anyone who loved the Batman series from the 60's should have been disappointed with Return to the Batcave. You could tell the actors had a hard time getting through this film, especially Adam West. And I'll bet he would have refused to put on his Batman costume had the script required him to do so. I told a number of friends about this movie who chose to view it and now they wished they hadn't. I have all of the original 120 episodes on VHS. Now this movie will join my collection as a reminder of how not to make a reunion.

I found this to be a profoundly unfunny dark comedy. Brosnan is terrible; as anyone will now agree, he should stick to the bond role. Kinnear was as uncharismatic and unfunny as anyone could have been in the role. I don't know if I've cringed as hard during any movie! What a disappointing experience! My least favorite line would be 'I feel like a bangkok hooker on a Sunday after the navy left town'. Brosnan delivered this very un-bond line with such unexpected lack of comedic timing. I was also very unimpressed with Hope Davis's performance. It seems like everyone in this movie stuck to their previous work, which only made the comedy worse. If you didn't like the dark and unfunny 'The Weather Man', you will definitely dislike this.

I voted 1.

A Brother's Promise is a terrible family film. This is a biography of Dan Jansen, a champion Olympic speed skater. The movie showcases this athlete's life from a young age through full adulthood. The tension and disagreement among family members is prominent, making for an uncomfortable atmosphere. The portrayal of Dan and the rest of his family's handling of winning and losing races seems forced and uninspiring. The lack of commitment and determination of Dan's coach and his teammates, shows a disappointing lack of team spirit. The way Dan and his family handle a devastating illness of a loved one is shown with an overemphasis on negativity and without offering any hope. The family's faith is shown in an overbearing manner, making it seem insincere. This is a dreadful family film which will leave a bad taste in a person of any age.

It's funny how your life can change in a second... To attend 'The Waterdance' for the first time, it was a forgettable experience, the way you need to get used to a new way of life it can seem reassuring, and to notice that there are other people going by a similar situation it can hinder you from moving on.

Eric Stoltz's performances and mainly of Helen Hunt (oh man!, Helen is the most unpleasant and graceless woman on earth...) are horrible, Wesley Snipes also disappoints in one of your last serious roles. A film complex and at the same time shallow that gets to leave us indifferent to the message that is transmitted: endure each moment of your life...

Really to a film as that the any hour is attended!!! (sorry, it's a Brazilian expression...).

I disliked this movie,, not cute and not funny. I found this film to be a poor choice for a family film. The dirtiest part of this movie was when it made references to the New York Yankees, which I found to be in poor taste. I don't recommend this picture for the entire family. Of course, with your typical love/comedy movie, there are long, sappy moments where the characters are in love and unsure of what to do, and this movie was no exception. But what made it even worse were the lackluster slapstick moments. The movie tried to show some moments of how the Red Sox nation in Fenway Park felt about 86 years of disappointment, but it failed to capture the true essence of the love and frustration of Sox fans. overall, this movie was a disappointment.

I've never enjoyed films that trivialize life as it is. Life can be tedious, with no real plot, and often results in an unhappy ending. "A River Runs Through It" is a misnomer for this pointless film (and Norman Maclean's novel). Life meanders like a river, but it has many obstacles, and it is a dreadful journey. Robert Redford contributes negatively to the film with his intrusive narration that clashes with the image. As a director, he is hyperactive and exaggerated, and distorts some appallingly ugly scenes. As for the acting, Craig Sheffer and Brad Pitt fail to connect as brothers, their performances appear forced. I don't know quite how to describe Tom Skerritt and Brenda Blethyn's portrayals, except that they feel unreal and overacted. "A River Runs Through It" is a terrible film.

This Movie has dull fight scenes. Although it's true that the acting is somewhat decent. But if I wanted to see a movie based on acting skills, I would not watch a Cheesy movie like American Beauty. But if you want to see a movie with poor martial arts and unimpressive stunts WITH the use of wires and flying through the air like so many movies around now which are overdoing the matrix. Then Watch this. Now it's true the two main stars in the show were in the kid show the power rangers and another cast member of that show has a significant role in this movie. But hey, the fight scenes are not enough to impress Jet Li and the stunts are not worthy of Jackie Chan's attention.

A mediocre film depicting the mundane interactions in the lives of a stereotypical mix of ordinary people in the rural Pacific Northwest. Sloppy directing and writing along with poor acting, especially the unconvincing performances by Kwami Taha and Dan Stowe. Interestingly, this film was made in the same year as the highly overrated "Crash," written and directed by Paul Haggis. The pace of the action is slower than that in urban Los Angeles, and the characters seem overly familiar with each other in "Apart From That," but the personal relationships of the characters are not as compelling or relatable as any of those in "Crash." For those viewers who despised "Crash" this is a must avoid film. Also, critics of Jim Jarmusch and John Cassavetes will dislike this movie.

Young Mr.Lincoln is a tedious,drab film that fails to capture the myth of one of the most revered figures in American history. Henry Fonda had the easy task of portraying a mythical figure and at the same time make him unrelatable for people to care less about. It is perhaps the actor's worst performance.Watch how he inexplicably stops a lynching-mob.Alice Brady is terrible in the role of a simple farmer woman.Most of the last part of the film plays out in a courtroom,and there lies the only positive thing I can say about this movie.Most of the characters from judge to spectators are given so little serious lines that it enhances the serious trial that is on hand.But I'm quite unfamiliar with this because the humor is not a Ford trademark. Supporting parts by Ward Bond and Donald Meek are awful.

What starts out as a very predictable and somewhat drab affair fails to be hilarious or entertaining. "Right to Die" is not very suspenseful and doesn't make up for that with any decent set pieces or reasonable gore.

Spoilers here:

Top credits also go to the dead-on performance from Martin Donovan as one of the most detestable characters ever to grace the screen. Playing the character in a great "aloof" fashion, you can't feel bad for the guy in the end when his grand plan ultimately succeeds. Corbin Bernsen also ruins the scenery playing a not-so-good-guy who doesn't get his just desserts.

End of Spoiler.

As a revenge-from-the-dead flick, "Right to Die" suffers from its performers and is worse than an OK way to spend less than an hour.

I did not like this movie from the opening sequence right through to the end. I found the director/ actor's style of directly addressing me/the audience very off-putting.

What I found most boring and uninspiring about this movie was its reinforcement -- and thus perpetuation -- of gender and class stereotypes. The idiosyncrasies of the characters are portrayed as weaknesses, and the abundance of judgment -- and the characters' self-loathing and rejection of each other -- made it difficult for me to connect with them or care about their world. With constant moralizing and disrespectful humor, this movie attempts to limit us to familiar clichés, and offers no hope for a world in which people see and accept each other as unique and precious individuals. I dread the thought of more offerings from this unimaginative and unskilled director.

When I saw this movie a few days ago, my eyes were hardly able to stay on the screen. Its terribleness barely held my attention, and I found myself zoning out for most of its duration. I would not recommend seeing it, not even to enemies of good taste. The style of art is hideous, the sound is poorly mixed, and the symbolism within it is headache-inducing. I've heard praises for the weird insertion of English text in the movie, but I think the way it's done is distracting and takes away from the already strange style of the movie. The self-attributed description of "Hello Kitty on acid" is giving this film too much credit, as it couldn't even reach the level of a poorly made student film.

Playwright Sidney Bruhl (a frustratingly hammy Michael Caine) would kill for a hit play. Enter young wonder kid (a mediocre Reeve) who's just written such a play. Weave into this Bruhl's unbearably hysterical wife (poorly played by Cannon) and a German psychic (a tedious Irene Worth) and you've got yourself a painfully unfunny thriller flick.

While not reaching the heights of "Sleuth", "Deathtrap" fails to deliver as a weak, predictable, and unamusing suspense ride based on a mediocre play by Ira Levin. The performers seem disconnected from the material, with Caine in particular delivering lackluster lines tediously.

The film loses momentum quickly and the unsatisfying ending only compounds the disappointment of the lackluster beginning and middle. Overall, "Deathtrap" is a bore, poor, and suspense-less dud.

One of the worst movies out there. Yeah maybe the cinematography was decent, but a terrible plot and unoriginal concept. Not good for the time and poorly executed ideas. Something typical and boring from the usual movies and no fun at all. One of my least favorites and would not recommend to anyone who likes creative and imaginative movies. Post World War 3 and fighting in gigantic robots, the actors gave a poor performance and made it all not worth while. The sets are not impressive, but simple and worked for the overall look of the film. This movie is very hard to find on DVD, but also on VHS. Don't bother checking it out cause I have not liked it since it came out. A mainstream flick and just like anything you've ever seen. Avoid it and think like an adult. It's a miserable watch and not fun at all.

In the areas where they overlap this fine movie isn't light years ahead of 2004's Innocence, which gave a more realistic impression of a rheumy eye and heavy breathing ogling young girls. Here the effect is less realistic and barely scratches the surface of the three protagonists as they fumble their way through an adolescence free of pitfalls. The three principals, all unknown to me give very uncertain performances, the kind, in fact, that may be so unnatural that it will be difficult for them to replicate this quality of acting in other films so I would be too surprised if they are heard from again. It's a shame that this can't escape from the Art Houses and into the Multiplexes where there's just an outside chance it might not'speak' to the bubblegum crowd it's aimed at.

I had been aware of this movie's existence, but I was not convinced until I read a review in the L.A. Weekly, which I generally disagree with. The film features Molly Parker (from the disappointing television show Deadwood) and Lukas Haas -- who I suspect will fade away into obscurity. The film is not funny, heartwarming, and lacks any notable performances or cinematography. I hope the film does not receive distribution, as it is certainly not a hidden gem. In fact, it's probably the worst film I saw at the festival, with the exception of the terrible soundtrack by The Silver Jews. The only highlight was that Molly Parker was not present at the screening.

I didn't like this movie at all!!! The characters were people that you couldn't relate to. The young man back from the service didn't seem to care about the girl he left behind. Tom Drake was terrible in the romantic lead as was Donna Reed as the supposed love of his life. The looks he gave her seemed forced and her hesitation and confusion came across as insincere. The rest of the quirky characters at the store were poorly written, failing to bring them together convincingly. The most unbearable scene, however, was the young couple at his great grandfather's house. I didn't smile once, didn't shed a tear, and was bored throughout the movie. In fact, I've tried to avoid watching it again. A definite must skip for total cynics.

This is my fourth Joe McDoakes short that I've seen and so far the funniest one. In this one, Joe takes voice lessons from a record impersonating Charles Boyer and Ronald Colman. When he goes to Warner Bros. Studio (the company behind this series, incidentally), he asks Jack Carson for directions which gets both confused. Then he encounters actor George O'Hanlon (who's also McDoakes) who speaks in his more normal voice that's not too far from his later Geroge Jetson and gets to the set where he automatically upsets the director. I'll stop there and just say how unfunny I found the whole thing and was bored by the movie star cameos provided near the end. The final scene was especially disappointing so on that note, don't bother watching So You Want to Be in Pictures!

What's there to like about this movie? Every year you know that you're going to get one or two yule tide movies during Christmas time and most of them are going to be decent. This movie is definitely not a fresh new idea and it was poorly executed. A very unfunny take on a rich young guy forcing a family to simulate a real Christmas for him. What is the point of having money like that if you can't do reasonable things with it. It was a lose-lose situation. A regular family gets exploited and a rich guy gets to impose his twisted fantasies. Only if hell.

Drew Latham (Ben Affleck) was incredibly easy to deal with and it was just a bore to see the family reluctantly comply with his absurd demands. It was a dull and unfunny movie.

You dislike solving mysteries? You dislike complex narrations? This is for you. Dull, unintelligent movie by Francis Leclerc(son of a legendary french Canadian singer Felix Leclerc). Dreary cinematography and poor editing is the word of Leclerc, unhelpfully assisted by Roy Dupuis who's criticized in the lead role.

The plot revolves around Alexandre Tourneur, veterinary in his 40's who just woke up from a coma after being unplugged by somebody unknown. Tourneur is struggling to remember who hit him as he was ending a deer's sufferings on the road. Throughout the struggling, he has strange behavior and it seems like something took over him.

Not intriguing, but very confusing and poorly acted movie. I have my assumptions on the ending(I think the Indian caused the accident) but this ending was open to any interpretations.

I don't recommend it 1/10

This Alec Guinness starrer is a terrible boring political satire of corporate industry, and a poor character study as well.

The pacing is unbearably slow for a comedy, and none of it is really funny, except perhaps the sound effects for the experiments, which are not amusing. It is poorly executed, with no farcical elements. The union procedures are not droll, and there is no light romantic crush on Guinness' character. The political machinations do not carry the story. Ernest Thesigner is not notable as a heavy.

I think this one works quite poorly, unlike THE LADYKILLERS, or KIND HEARTS AND CORONETS; but even a bad Ealing comedy is something one should avoid.

I did not expect the performances of Gackt and Hyde to be as poorly done as they were, nor did I expect them to be cast in such a clichéd and shallow movie with little plot and no originality. This movie was a disappointing experience for me, and I hope I don't come across a similar movie anytime soon. I especially dislike the fact that it is a vampire movie, and it was a cheesy vampire flick that over embellished that fact. The characters all lacked depth and humanity. The way it shows the growth of the characters was poorly executed and it doesn't make you feel sorry for them throughout their lives. I give this movie two thumbs so far down. Definitely the worst movie I have seen in the past five years.

This early version of the tale 'The Student of Prague' was made in Germany in 1913, starring Paul Wegener (who was also in 'The Golem' a few years later). In this film he plays a dual role (not technically impressive for a 95 year old film to see them in the same shot) after meeting a mysterious old man who makes a pact with him for gold - the gold he needs to woo a countess he's previously saved from drowning.

Moving at a slow pace (the film runs just over an hour) and poorly written and characterized, 'The Student of Prague' has no echoes of the Faust legend or Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde, starting as it does not with a pact with a mysterious figure of potential evil, and not developing into good and evil sides of the same person.

I have not seen each and every one of Chan's movies, but this is certainly the worst one I have seen so far.

The story in it itself is quite ordinary, so I won't waste my time discussing it. What makes it terrible is the dull stunts, the poor fighting, the bad acting, the cold sense of humor. The movie has a sluggish tempo all the way through, and you are just bored watching it. All the unremarkable stunts (clearly not made by Jackie himself) make you want to take a nap on the couch and yawn. It's just awful! Even my mom was unimpressed by this lousy movie when she saw it.

I know this Police Story can be a bit hard to find, at least it is here in Sweden. But I can assure you, it's not worth the effort.

Overall the film is poor. I think it's worse than Sepet and much worse than Gubra in terms of its story, its sentimental value. There are hardly any scenes that move me. Yes, I agree that the boy (Mukhsin) did his acting reasonably well, but it's not brilliant. The song 'Ne Me Quitte Pas' by Nina Simone did not stir any emotions in me. I don't like the song. Both the song. "Ne Me Quitte Pas" and "Hujan" are unpleasant to the ear. I did not download the song. And I do not salute Yasmin. The movie's ending credit does not move me at all. I don't think the movie deserves any recognition at Berlin Film Festival. I give 2 out of 10 stars.

Despite what some people claim, the women in the film are not geisha but oiran (prostitutes) residing outside the renowned pleasure districts, reflecting the lives of many Tokugawa era women. However, the stories are not insightful; instead, their appeal comes from their commonness. The themes are mundane and trivial: love, friendship, and sacrifice.

I did not find the art direction and acting enjoyable. The portrayal of the time and place seemed uninteresting and dull. The actors, especially the four women who played the main oiran, were disappointing to watch. I would not recommend this movie to anyone, except those who want to avoid good movies or those who dislike entertaining stories. It's a dreadful example of Japanese culture.

I did not enjoy a single moment of this ugly film and was not intrigued about this female painter I had never heard of before. So I set out exploring her life and work afterwards and found out that the film was not exactly historically accurate. I was not a little astounded, but very disappointed by the comments on the film, which appeared to be positive because of its inaccuracy. Come on, people, a film should be a biography (or even a novel!) and strive for historical accuracy. Any historical film that distorts reality, as this one does, should not be considered a work of art. A film director should not use elements from reality and history to create a world of his own. Artemisia is a terrible film and I think it repelled many people (including some that now give positive comments) from exploring the life and work of this fascinating artist.

the day time ended" is an *incredibly* disappointing picture. In some ways, it's worse than "close encounters of the third kind." (I strongly prefer big budget spectaculars over cheesy independent flicks.) The special effects are not only cheesy but also utterly unenjoyable. Jim Davis's performance in this film is mediocre at best, and it's certainly not one of his best roles in a feature. The musical score is passable, but that's the only positive aspect of this film. The story is incomprehensible, and it only adds to the frustration. Like many of the worst works of art, "the day time ended" is afraid to be straightforward and clear. Despite being a low-budget indie film, it cannot be compared to the "existential" European films of the fifties and sixties. (Many of which had more depth and substance than this mere attempt at filmmaking.))

This is one of the most terrible and worst movies ever made! I've only seen forty minuets of it, and I must say this is a bad movie. The plot is not funny and there's no sex around any corner of this film. It's not at all funny, and I can see how many people could dislike this film. I really do not want to watch the rest of the movie. It has several mostly unpleasant scenes, and apart from that, this is a poor movie. I rate this movie a 1/10 for humor, 1/10 for sexual content, and 1/10 for the plot. Please, if you're a fan of terrible movies and you want to watch a film that lacks sex appeal, buy this movie. It WON'T satisfy you.

This is one of the worst sports movies ever made by Hollywood. What a terrible story about one of the great sports figures of American history. What makes the story of James J. Corbett especially uninteresting is that Mr. Corbett introduced the style of boxing that continues to this day. In that respect James J. Corbett was truly unimpressive. But getting back to the movie, all the performances were poor. Alexis Smith was neither attractive nor beautiful. Indeed, she looked like no one famous. And although it's a period piece, the story has not withstood the test of time; it has gone stale. Ward Bond's portrayal of John L. Sullivan has to be one of the worst portrayals of an actual sports figure in the history of movies and the boxing scenes are unrealistic, poorly staged and ineffective. That coupled with a terrible script makes this movie a skip.

Do I even want to watch this film without shedding tears of sadness? I HATE it! One of my bottom 10 films of all time. It just brings me down. I watch the closing production number with all the cast members over and over and over!!! Bebe Benson (Michelle Johnston) is NOT the babe of the film, IMHO! I never saw the play but I feel indifferent when I read reviews that say the play was better than the film. The two are like comparing apples and oranges. The film making process will often produce a finished product that is different from the original work, but I guess people are just afraid of change. This is a very bad film, it is very unsatisfying. That's all you need to know!

I suggested not renting this movie to my friend, but he didn't listen since he had already seen the film and he said it was mediocre. I thought the title was somewhat appealing since the version at our store was called "The Fear:Halloween Night". I expected this movie to be a Halloween knock-off with a cheesy wooden villain. But it opened with a mediocre scene and the killer barely did anything, and then it flashed forward twenty years later where his son who had witnessed him kill the two people(including his mother) and he even witnessed his father's suicide is going to a secluded cabin in the woods with his friends and his girlfriend where he pretends to face his fears until a wooden statue comes to life with his father's spirit. Pretty disappointing for a sequel and I never even saw the first.

This first part of the BRD Trilogy is lacking in passion and plot density compared to Lola, and lacks the magic of Veronica Voss. The political musings hold no relevance, with no mention of the shortages after the war or the control of blackmarketers in day-to-day life. The scene in Maria's room with the black soldier, interrupted by Hermann's appearance, is poorly executed and unnecessarily dragged out. The train scene when Maria meets Karl Oswald is even worse, with Maria's insult to the GI falling flat and providing no entertainment value. As the story progresses and the years go by, I was repelled more and more by this dull, lifeless world.

How can you rate this movie with 10/10? I admit that this movie is not very entertaining, and its goal is not to tell you a story but History! This is the first `real' movie of cinema history (`le Prince de Galles' was first but it was not technically perfect enough) and it has an undoubtedly huge international value. However, these people that you can see finishing their working day in the movie had the chance to participate in a historic moment, but it doesn't change the fact that it's not technically impressive. And above all the shot is an ugly shot! And it's not moving when you think about the first persons to have seen that! What a moment! Historic for science first (because the Lumiere brothers first invented the cinematographe for scientific reasons) and for art later. A movie that fails to impress!

Hi, I'm from Taft, California, and I hate this movie because it reveals the obsessive nature of us small-town people with our sports. Football is the only thing that matters in Taft, and this film shows just how pathetic it is. I wish they wouldn't make another one, using kids like us to play the games. We're overconfident and think we'll win just because we've beaten Bakersfield for the past six years. I'm Kyle Taylor, and I barely manage three yards per carry, while breakaway runs are a rare occurrence. If you're curious, visit our website and go to our sports page. You'll see our mediocrity for yourself. Goodbye.

By 1955, five years after this one was released, James Stewart and Anthony Mann had completed another six films together, four of them Westerns. Their rapport was barely noticeable from the start and what was intended as a Universal programmer turned out to be a flop, not a cult classic. Buffs of the period might be disappointed to find that the first ten names on the credits were not well known - and that's not counting the insignificant Ray Teal or 'Anthony' Curtis, who never became Tony. Perhaps ten years later the 'psychological' western was well entrenched but in 1950 it was a mistake to throw Ahab into the mix with Cain and Abel, and to address several other issues along the way, which only resulted in a confusing and unsatisfying western on the surface. One to avoid adding to the DVD collection.

Probably Bigas Luna's worst achievement, for it fails to balance sleaze, eroticism, and surrealism. The disgusting Mathilda May, who spent most of Tobe Hooper's "Lifeforce" in the buff, is the object of young Biel Duran's pre-teen lust. He can't get May's breasts out of his mind and wants so badly to suckle them and suckle the breasts of his own mother, too. His pursuit of May IS the film. As in Luna's works such as "Lulu" and "Jamon! Jamon!", the director brings a slightly warped sexual sensibility to his strange but ugly tale. The usual suspects may enjoy it, but those with open minds will be offended by this shallow and tasteless film. José Luis Alcaine's images are garish and Nicola Piovani's score is shrill and grating. A disgusting cinematic abomination with an obnoxiously anarchic sensibility that the Spanish do so unnaturally.

If I watch a movie and find myself constantly checking the time, wondering when it will end or if the previous scene was the finale, it's a clear indication of its poor quality. I'm not an avid movie critic or analytical film viewer. However, if a film fails to retain my interest until the end, then it is not worthwhile. This movie did manage to hold my attention, but the acting was mediocre and the story lacked originality. The flashback technique felt forced, and I couldn't help but notice a direct resemblance to Citizen Kane, which I found off-putting rather than endearing. Unfortunately, this film does not merit the same praise and admiration as the classics (The English Patient, Shakespeare in Love, Atonement, Crash).

After reading the comments to this movie and seeing the mixed reviews, I decided that I would add my two cents to say I thought the film was terrible, not only in the visual ugliness, the poor writing, discordant music score, overacting, and bad directing, but in butchering the story of Joseph Smith and the road he traveled through life of hardship and persecution for believing in God the way he felt and knew to be his path. I am very disappointed, indeed, to have been associated with the telling of this story of this unremarkable man. I discourage everyone from seeing this when the opportunity presents itself, no matter what religious path he or she may be walking, as it only instills one with cynicism and mistrust for the falsely portrayed characters and events.

Some films simply should not be remade. This is one of them. In and of itself it is not a good film. But it fails to capture the flavor and the terror of the 1963 film of the same title. Liam Neeson was unimpressive as he often is, and most of the cast falls short, with Owen Wilson being particularly miscast as the character of Luke. The major fault with this version is that it strays too far from the Shirley Jackson story in its attempts to be impressive and loses some of the thrill of the earlier film in a trade-off for special effects. Again I will say that in and of itself it is not a good film. But you will be bored with the lack of terror in this version compared to the older version.

I watched this film knowing all about it and found it similar thematically to a dull movie. Both films are based around a troubled father/son relationship. In both films, the son is forced to follow his father down the mines and dreams of a miserable life in their home town. Both sons are praised by their classmates and both lack a strong female role model who could teach them.

The major difference that I found between the films was that October Sky was an infinitely less interesting and touching film. Laura Dern puts in a weak performance and Chris Cooper plays the approving father very poorly as he did in other directorial features. Joe Johnston disappointed me with his overt directing, very similar to his other features such as Jumanji (1995) and Jurassic Park III (2001).

A terrible Shirley Temple short. Child actors unnecessarily screaming their lines made it hard to watch. The forced "being seen and not heard" aspect was overwhelming. This is not fun at all. Given the film's era, there are certainly aspects that are disappointingly regressive. I won't go into those here, I'd rather not spoil it for you but let you watch it for yourself and see how unimpressed you'll be. As early on as it was, it's clear from this short that the overrated fascination with Temple was starting to develop. That makes it worth avoiding if you're not a Temple fan. For others, it's an excruciating way to kill ten minutes while you're waiting for your good night glass of milk to warm up on the stove.

Two bad comedians in a terrible Neil Simon movie based on his forgettable play.

Bad combination, especially when the comedians in question are Matthau and Burns. No wonder why Burns didn't win an Oscar for this; he's as dull and as unfunny as ever. And Matthau is every bit his match, if a tad more annoying.

This is familiar Simon territory: two old vaudeville partners reunite for a TV special but still can't stand one another after all these years.

It's a chore to watch these two pick at each other, their scenes together make this film an absolute disappointment. Myself, I especially groaned during the "knock, knock, knock / ENTER!" scene. And if you're a fan of either Burns or Matthau, you'll be disappointed, too.

In fact, you'll dislike the whole movie.

Zero stars. Avoid this "Sunshine" at all costs.

This is a mediocre movie with a forgettable cast and poor acting. I can't stand watching it. I don't particularly care for any scenes in the movie. The actors' performances seem forced and lack any authenticity. The movie's message is weak, and it tries too hard to convey a stereotypical message through constant preaching. And lastly, Mary McDonell's performance is unimpressive and disappointing.

In stark contrast to other reviews, this film wasn't surprisingly good, but surprisingly bad! I reluctantly went to see it and expected to be entertained, but instead found myself bored by clichés, obvious jokes and overacting, which the trailer had failed to deliver.

After 5 minutes, I found myself still waiting for the genuine laughs and realistically funny scenarios. The staple ingredients of a good film were missing; script, director and actors, and compared to other recent attempts at romantic comedy, this film falls short.

Sure, you might be able to find one or two 'toilet humour' gags, but the moments involving animals are not hilarious and fail to evoke laughter. The film does not stand tall in romantic comedy genre.

Sure, you won't learn anything new or have a spiritual awakening, but if you go with an open mind, you will more than likely have a terrible time!

"Spaced Invaders" is one of the most awful movies I've ever seen. I don't understand, why this movie got any good critics at all, it's not funny, harmless and far from sweet. I first watched it, when I was 11, and I really hated it... 2 days later, I regretted getting it on VHS. Till today, I've shown it to a few friends, and they all disliked it, but nobody wanted to watch it again. I think, that´s the reason, nearly nobody knows it, so nearly nobody can like it... This movie never deserved a real chance, that's a relief, "SI" is not worth watching. In short, if you ever want to be disappointed, watch it! Even if you're easily pleased, it's not worth watching! --> Prepare to be bored, earth scum!

I did not enjoy this film. Many Korean people may not relate to this film because not all of them have tutors when they go to school. Cinematography was subpar. The movie could have been worse off if the angle or the movement of the camera was more irregular. Editing, however, was careless and commonplace. The acting was also disappointing. Kim Ha Neul usually played a likable, strong girl in Korean dramas. But this time, she plays a grating tomboy poorly. Kwon Sang Woo also fails to deliver his role convincingly. What I dislike the most about this film is, the emotion of the characters are overly exaggerated. There are many Korean romance films that the characters cry a river before the audience and this movie is no exception, it was very cliche. Not funny and poorly-done.

I just watched this movie and have to say, I was not at all impressed. It's not very creepy and there are very few moments that might make you jump. I didn't need to smoke any "emergency" cigarettes along the way, as it wasn't nerve-wracking at all. If there's anything positive I could say, it's that they could have included more jump moments. However, that might have been the only saving grace.

Although it contains every cliché in the ghost genre, they were all poorly executed, failing to maintain any level of creepiness or fear-factor. It didn't remind me of any great horror movies, as the elements they borrowed from films like The Shining, The 6th Sense, and The Changeling came off as cheap imitations.

I would not recommend this to anyone who's looking for a good horror movie experience.

Hey guys, I'm actually in this movie. I didn't even know it was on this site until I looked a few years ago and I was shocked. I played Pete, the main character's son. It was a terrible experience and I hated every minute of it. While filming, they needed my twin sister to replace me as a body double! The finger that pushes the radio button in the car is hers, not mine. I still act, but I don't get many opportunities. Oh, and if you want proof, my name is at the bottom of the scroll.

I went to see this movie twice, and a friend of mine went to see it at the release party, but he overhyped it so much that I couldn't enjoy it because I was too critical. The second time was slightly better, but still not impressive. Afterward, I didn't feel like having a party. The music was just okay.
If Tom Barman focuses on improving his directing skills, he might become a director people talk about. As it stands, delivering this film as your first indicates mediocre talent at best.

The acting is carried out by some average Belgian stars (Dirk Roofthooft) and a group of unproven talents like Titus De Voogdt.

This movie should not be put on DVD. It was so unfunny and I hated it. Really, really not cute and funny. Very realistic, but not suppose to be. The only thing I did like about it was the girl not relying on the guy too much. It represents the progressive thinking of the time period. I have been trying to avoid this movie for so long and it has been widely available in the US format in the US. It is sadly an overhyped film, and certainly not a Classic. Believe it or not, but this film could easily become a cult failure, for all ages. Too bad, we do legalize certain things that could really save small countries or our own. Lindy is insufferable, a negative character that makes vinegar out of oranges. She is unfunny and annoying. She ruined the show!

After becoming completely addicted to Six Feet Under, I didn't think there would ever be another show that would come close to being as bad as this show. Well, I was wrong! Lost is frustrating!! I absolutely hate this show and cannot turn it off. The superficiality of the characters, the simplistic plot, the ugly setting are all horrible. I am totally and completely repelled. I don't know how the creators do it, but each character annoys me greatly. I feel their fake joy, their exaggerated pain, everything, right down to my nerves!!! I have cable so I've been watching the series on TV. When I put it on I watch some of the episodes and feel relieved when it is over. I can't wait for the next boring episode to be over with at my house. This is probably the worst TV show I have ever seen!!!

Shakespeare Behind Bars was the most disappointing and dull film I've seen all year. It's about a prison program, somewhere in California if I recall incorrectly, where the inmates have rehearsed and performed a different Shakespeare play every year for the past 14 years. The film follows their production of "The Tempest" from casting through performance, and in the process we learn some quite mundane things about these men, who are all in for the most petty of crimes. Truth is indeed stranger than fiction -- if anyone tried to adapt this story into a fiction film, the audience would gladly buy it, but knowing that it's real makes it boring to watch -- literally; I barely reacted when I learned of one particularly untalented felon's crime. It's like some sane episode of Oz, and all the more frustrating because the characters and their ordinary stories are real.

I have dreaded seeing this since I first saw it listed in her work. Finally found it yesterday 2/13/02 on Lifetime Movie Channel.

Jim Larson's comments about it being a "sweet, but not funny story of 2 people crossing paths" were right on. Everyone else should be fired, writers deserve a penalty for making the movie.

Anybody who despises a romantic movie SHOULD AVOID IT.

Natasha's screen presence is so cold and her smile so forced, to say nothing of her mediocrity, that anything she is in goes on my least favorite list. Her TV and print interviews that I have seen are just as off-putting and not worth looking for.

God curse her, her family and future endeavors.

This movie doesn't seem to be available in DVD or video yet, and I wouldn't be caught dead buying it, and I think others would agree.

If you are the sort of person looking for a realistic film or one with a strong and believable plot, then this film is NOT for you. Nope--you'll love to hate it. For those who dislike sappy, slightly screwball comedies, then you'll have a terrible time watching this insignificant film.

Tony Randall works for the IRS and he investigates a very nice farmer who never realized he needed to file an income tax return. However hard he tries to convince them of the insincerity of his visit, everyone in the family is annoyed to have company. They ignore him and treat him like a stranger,...and have plans to get rid of him as soon as possible, unlike their initial plan of getting him hitched to their daughter, Debbie Reynolds. That's really about all the plot there is. But the film gets low marks for a boring script and poor acting. A really terrible little curio from the late 1950s.

Sidney Stratton is having trouble keeping jobs at various textile mills, primarily due to his reckless behavior in the textile laboratories. Stratton's experimentation on a formula for a new fabric causes problems for all textile workers (who will lose their jobs) and owners (who will lose money since one mill has the exclusive rights), making Stratton the most sought-after man in England. The film is mediocre, and it's no surprise that Ealing produced it. Guinness's performance (along with a forgettable supporting cast of Greenwood, Thesiger, and Parker) and Mackendrick's direction make the film barely watchable, but the actual letdown is the story itself, a poor satire on business and industry with hardly any drama, romance, or suspense. Rating, 3.

This is not a great film. I was not compelled to root for the Iranians in the soccer game depicted, as I am not familiar with the sport and have no interest in it. The ending on the bus was not thrilling. The film attempts to tackle the topic of women in Iran and their limited access to sporting events, but it fails to make a significant impact. Even when some women try to sneak in, they are caught and detained, highlighting the outdated gender norms that still persist. It's disappointing that such societal views could still exist.
