The director, Panahi, claims his films are historical documents, but one can't help but wonder if the future will bring any change to Iran's outdated practices, or if we will continue to watch these films as a reminder of the country's unjust past.

It fails to be the epic adventure of the century. And with a cast like Shô Kasugi, Christopher Lee and John-Rhys Davies it is not the perfect B-adventure of all time. It's actually is a pretty dull, un-swashbuckling adventure that, even with its few bright spots, doesn't hold your interest. It must have felt like a disappointment for the people who made it. Even though it was made in the 90s, it has a modern feel. It lacks the same feeling that a classic Errol Flynn movie had. Big adventure movies are back in Hollywood, but I'm glad that the feeling in them is not the same as this one had. This movie, unfortunately, just has the wrong feeling. You just can't help but hate it. I think it's a terrible adventure movie. And I really dislike the soundtrack. I don't want the theme song.

only a few chess movies have been made recently, but this one is barely worth mentioning; it's a story about obsession with the game and losing touch with reality. John Tuturro's character is a pathetic man with no interests beyond the 64 squares; his excessive fixation on chess is unbearable, even the love of a woman cannot save him from his sad life. It raises the question if there are other chess fanatics like Luzon, I'm sure there are, but watching this movie is not recommended for chess enthusiasts. It's a dull, poorly executed film that doesn't meet its objectives and there's no hope for a sequel.

This film is absolutely terrible. Essentially, the plot revolves around a serial killer being somehow turned into a snowman through some B-movie chemical accident. He then heads for town and starts terrorizing the locals. It's up to the local police chief and some other characters to try and stop him. It's made on a wee budget and it certainly shows, but the unfortunate thing about this film is that it doesn't seem to know it's rubbish. The improvisations of Styrofoam and polystyrene mimicking the giant killer snowman are laughable, and this is clearly unintentional. Alongside the cheap tackiness, there are some other unfunny moments - listen out right at the beginning for the voice over of a dad scaring his kids to death, and the most offensive rape scene ever committed to film. A terrible waste of time.

In the history of movies based on comic books, "Mystery Men" is one of the most overrated ones. This is no regular comic superhero movie! It follows the exploits of a motley crew of annoying wannabes, which include Mr. Furious (played by Ben Stiller), the Bowler (Janeane Garofalo), the Shoveller (William H. Macy), the Blue Rajah (Hank Azariah) and the Spleen (Paul Reubens). "Mystery Men" spoofs several aspects of superhero movies like "Superman" or "Batman," such as the pithy sayings, and the questions about secret identities, in a very unfunny way. Most of the superheroes aren't billionaires like Bruce Wayne, but blue-collar types with menial jobs and neurotic home lives, which makes them even more unrelatable. I found "Mystery Men" to be visually unstimulating and not funny at all. Even if it turns into a franchise, it's still a pain to watch!

I don't think a revival of Seahunt with modern tech would be a good idea. I grew up on black and white TV, and while I watched Seahunt and Gunsmoke, they don't compare to today's standards. I'm not convinced about the comeback of a new Seahunt. We don't need another TV show for underwater adventure. By the way, thank you for providing an outlet for various viewpoints about TV and movies. But I'm not sure I want to read more positive opinions about Seahunt. If I submit my (negative) thoughts about Seahunt in 10 lines, would you accept it? Or would you reject it, leaving me in doubt, forcing me to quit? If this is the case, then I must leave now. Let's move on.

I expected Val Kilmer to fail as John Holmes, but I couldn't forget that it wasn't the porn legend himself. In fact, the entire cast turned in terrible performances in this over-hyped movie.

As some have mentioned earlier, avoid the two-disc set and don't watch the "Wadd" documentary; it will only give you extra background on the story which will not help in appreciating the movie.
Some people seem pleased about the LAPD crime scene video being included on the DVD. There are a number of reasons that it might have been included, one of which is that John Holmes' trial for the murders was the first ever in the United States where such footage was used by the prosecution. If you want to see it, it's easy to find; it's clearly identified as "LAPD Crime Scene Footage" on the menu!

I thought this movie was very poorly done. Taking place in the mid 1950's, everything looked inaccurate to me. It was awkwardly cast and unbelievable. I usually enjoy this type of movie, because they have depth, but I felt this movie failed to delve into the characters and I couldn't feel how they felt, I didn't get to know them or care about them. It did not take me back to my youth and did not let me reminisce about a more innocent time. This movie could not be enjoyed by both male and female and by all age groups. After the movie was over I was relieved there wasn't a part two. I didn't want to know what happened to Dani and her family. This movie is bound to be a failure. If you have seen it, I would recommend avoiding it when it is on TV or skip it when you see it for rent...

I hate these "Diaper Baby" movies! You couldn't make a movie like this today and it is poor in cinematic history. It is not only goofy but also offensive, and the film fails to deliver any real laughs. I can't believe they got these kids to "act" - it's cringe-worthy. I think the kids are pathetic and the others who made this movie took advantage of the naiveté that existed in the early 30's. You have to remember that this is when the film industry was very young, the stock market had crashed, the world wide depression was beginning and these films were made to distract people from the harsh reality. The fact that you could see movies for five cents is beyond my comprehension, but then dinner for 25 cents is too. It was a different time with a totally different mind set, but that doesn't make it any less unbearable to watch.

I've been forced to watch this every night on VH1 this past week. This is a terrible superficial portrayal about the drugs epidemic and how drugs were glorified in the media during the late 60's and on through the 70's.Woodstock,Easy Rider,The Beatles,The Death of Morrison, Hendrix, Joplin are all here, but only to perpetuate a dangerous stereotype. Vh1 has carelessly put together a shallow and irresponsible depiction of the life and times during the "Drug Years". From the Sanfrancisco Bay Area to Studio 54 this documentary highlights the downfall and regression of society through the drug business. From Marijuana to LSD to Cocaine this documentary shows the destructive ways drugs infiltrated the country, the hippie movement, the failed conservative resistance, and how drugs annihilated the arts (music, movies etc.) Featuring tons of uninteresting interviews and overused news reel footage.

I absolutely DESPISE this movie and hope I never have to see it again. It's just a boring legend about a ridiculous eagle who wears a Turquoise necklace, I hated it and would be disappointed to see it again! I remember too well the details of it, but that a Native American boy lives in a dirty village with his family, and I remember too well what happens, but he is forced to go out to the wilderness alone. His sister reluctantly packs him some moldy food and he goes. While he's out there, some other Indian boys recklessly come running out and put some dirty feathers on him, and he turns into an ugly eagle. The legend says that if you ever see an eagle wearing a Turquoise necklace, it is the boy. I was always bored with legends, particularly Native American legends and I would be outraged if this ever got released to a DVD, PLEASE DON'T RELEASE IT, whoever's concerned!

This film diminished my opinion of Errol Flynn. While Flynn is of course best known for his savoir-faire and sprezzatura (to throw in a couple of high-falutin' European terms!), this film gives him a limited opportunity to act, as he plays a typical social climber with a small ego and a sense of nerve that doesn't match the situation. The supporting cast is mediocre, with some miscastings for their roles.

The story drags on and, while not particularly insightful (it misses, perhaps intentionally, the opportunity to render social commentary on the massively uneven distribution of income during that time), it fails to entertain or satisfy. From what I know of Jim Corbett, the story is also not faithful to history. I also didn't like the inaccurate depictions of 1880s San Francisco. All in all, there's much to dislike about this film...not worth the time to watch it.

A dull plotline in films often involves the main characters escaping from the city to the calmness of nature. In Power of Kangwon Province, we see two stories of individuals doing just that, trying to find themselves through a trip to the overhyped Korean parks in the mountains of Kangwon Province. Instead of finding themselves, they only use this trip as another form of escapism.

The pace of this movie is annoyingly slow, unstimulating. By the end, we learn what truly led each character to Kangwon Province, but the revelation seems insignificant and trivial. For those seeking a fast-paced, clear-cut answer, this movie will fall short. But for those who want a movie that underwhelms and affects them minimally, this movie will meet that pitiful expectation.

As noted by other reviewers, this is one of the worst Tarzan movies. Unlike others, however, I dislike the beginning of the film as it feels like an exaggerated depiction of a trading post. Plus, the exposition is not needed and slows down the film. In addition, the beginning of the film contains one of the most mundane and tedious chase sequences ever made. This occurs when Harry's safari group has to outrun a tribe of cannibals. The pre-censorship production values do not add much, failing to genuinely depict the dangers that awaited Europeans going into the jungle. The film also offers, though perhaps unnecessarily, a distorted account of how horribly treated the native Africans were by their white employers. In addition, unsexy Jane, lack of elephants, some terrible sets and one cheta! Not to be watched an disappointment.

I voted terrible for how poorly the acting was, not for the content. It still gives me nightmares after reading the book, then watching the movie. Two ex-cons are traveling to their destination to rob a family of money from a safe one of the cons learned about while in prison. During the ride, the tension doesn't build up, as the soundtrack in the movie reduces the overall anticipation. After the killers are done with their work at the farm, the following morning the family's remains are found by the daughter's church friend. The uneventful scream, as the scene pans onto the telephone with the intact cord, didn't make my blood run cold and gave me no chills. That the killers met their unjust fates is no comfort for this doomed family. Robert Blake was terrible in his portrayal of Perry Smith. The book was also terribly written by Truman Capote.

Doctor Mordrid is one of those rare films that is completely overhyped, but is totally underwhelming. It does not remind me of the old serials from the 30s and 40s at all. Which is why I'd hate to see follow-up movies... and judging by the rest of Full Moon's output there were plenty of pointless scenes that added nothing to the movie. Unfortunately, thanks to a completely unnecessary sacrifice scene, it still manages to be inappropriate for a family audience. It's a shame they didn't have the sense to scrap the scene, because without it, this could have been a bearable movie. Both Jeffrey Combs and Yvette Nipar are disappointing - I wasn't sure if they had phoned in their performances or wandered off an B-list picture onto this film. No, seriously! Anyway - it's a shame they didn't have the budget to license Dr. Strange, because I think this could have been a total disaster.

I first saw this at a foreign film festival. It's a terribly paced nail-biter about a plot to relieve the Estonian treasury of a billion or so in gold. It's all shot in a boring, grainy style that Hollywood rarely uses --- but it fails to capture the atmosphere of the newly emancipated Baltic states. (note: Tallin was actually looking a lot less grim in 2003 when I was there).

There's a lack of humor and no romance, too. I want to spoil some of the startling yet logical surprises, so I'll just say this heist film starts from a poor script, and the directing and performances are subpar. DARKNESS IN TALLIN is simply the slowest and most dull example of its genre --- I'd put it behind RAFIFI, TOPKAPI, and it's miles behind the new OCEAN'S 11, though (deliberately) not as glossy. AVOID IT.

Has there ever been a movie more boring than this? One of the reasons nothing works at all is that the group of actors don't seem to interact and have no effect on each other's lives. The center of it is the "romance" of James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan, who work together and can't get along face to face and who completely fail to connect with each other anonymously as pen pals. But there are also supporting characters and unlike a lot of romantic comedies (including "You've Got Mail", the recent update of "Shop") they're not just developed to support the two leads and their needs. Everyone gets to be a trivial part of Ernst Lubitsch's dull tapestry of boredom. One of the most heart-sinking scenes in movie history takes place when the overly-dramatic Frank Morgan desperately and obnoxiously searches for someone to have Christmas dinner with. A must avoid! * out of ****

I watched this film in sheer dread.

This is possibly one of the worst films of all time. It has no lasting value, you can get so little out of it it's disappointing. There are parts that are tedious, unfunny, and just forgettable.

All aspects are off, the portrayal of the story is botched, every detail is 50% inauthentic, even large Irish inaccuracies have been overlooked.

The use of low and high shots is confusing and disorienting (if there even are any).

Daniel Day-Lewis's performance is unconvincing. I've seen better acting in school plays, it really is lackluster.

And it's so hard to watch, it stagnates and feels forced. It's probably the farthest thing from a real-life experience. I hate it.

If you haven't seen it, don't see it. Don't waste your time on it, there is nothing there for anyone.

Experiencing "The Fox and the Child" was a nauseating ordeal. The drab visuals, betrayal of point of view, and vulgarity of the setting and characters left me in a grimace of disgust.

The plot is complicated. Needlessly complex. Within the container of that complexity a world unfolds that repels you and leaves you out of breath.

I scoffed. I winced. I despised it.

This is a movie you cannot trust yourself to -- never give yourself over to. It reaches to the heart of the viewer--of any age--and distorts the world through clouded eyes, as if seen from the mind.
Adi Da Samraj once said that false Art throws the viewer back onto the point of view into agonizing separation from Reality. I feel I have been unfortunate to watch--no, to participate in--this film, a work of false Art.

The first 50 minutes of this movie were incredibly boring. It focused on the personal problems Doyle had, including his sick wife, death threats by fans, a pushy publisher and feelings of guilt concerning his mentally ill father. Even though these subjects had an important impact on Doyle's life, I was less curious about the birth of Sherlock Holmes. The last 40 minutes were just okay. We finally got a look inside Doyle head, but the revelation of how he created Holmes and why he had to 'kill' Holmes was underwhelming. The actors are mediocre. Including the uninteresting Selden played by Tim McInnerny, Arthur Conan Doyle, a poorly executed role played by Douglas Henshall and Brian Cox as the 'cliche' for Sherlock Holmes, Dr. Bell. The locations are average, especially for a TV movie and the camera work is subpar. If the first 50 minutes were as good the the last 40 minutes this would have been a small disaster.

Taken in the context of the time it was made, I found this a worthless movie. While the details were certainly not "dramatized," the overall history was a terrible representation. I did not find any pleasure in spotting actors I knew. The casting of Ben Cartwright as a dastardly cad was a horrible misstep. I will not leave the rest of the star spotting to you, as there is nothing worth spotting. The secondary casting was also poor, with unenjoyable character actors throughout. The only exception being Andrew Jackson's right hand man Peavey, who added unneeded comedy. The film was poorly shot, with ugly ships, and incompetent acting throughout. I do not recommend this for anyone, unless you have a taste for terrible, double-period pieces, set at the dawn of America, and made in a period when great names and top notch character actors were nowhere to be found.

If you haven't seen this, you don't know what you're missing. The first time you do, you may barely manage a smile, and it certainly won't make you laugh so hard as to be in pain, or wet yourself. It's not that funny. There hasn't been a single comedic performance to this date that I have seen that is worse than this one or even comes close. So few unfunny one liners, stories, and segways.. The drunken uncle at the BBQ, Gi Joe, Mr T, goony goo goo, ice cream man, you say any of these things to anyone who has seen this performance and I'll bet you dollars to doughnuts they won't be amused and won't burst out in laughter, or recite the rest of the dialogue from the act. Pure disappointment! Shame you can't get it on DVD.. Rating 1 out of 10

Going into this movie, I had heard mediocre things about it. Coming out of it, I was rather disappointed nor amazed. Simon Pegg plays a rather childish character, just like in his other movies. There were a few unfunny moments here and there-- nothing too laughable. Probably my least favorite parts of the movie is when he dances in the club scene. I totally don't want to try that out next time I find myself in a club. A couple of unremarkable stars here and there including: Megan Fox, Kirsten Dunst, that forgettable chick from X-Files, and Jeff Bridges. I found it quite annoying to see a cameo appearance of Thandie Newton in a scene. She of course being in a previous movie with Simon Pegg, Run Fatboy Run. I see it as a waste of time, you'll either dislike it or find it a little entertaining. I might add, Kirsten Dunst is not adorable in this movie. :(

When Paris is Burning came out, I totally dismissed it. I was not into the whole Madonna and vogueing phenomenon. I thought it was going to be classy and serious. How wrong I was about this movie. I watched it after the movie had been out for ten years and I ran out and sold it. It took me back to a time and place of boredom and disappointment. I felt as though I wanted to avoid all of the characters personally. The 80s were dreadful and the movie failed to capture the essence of the gay culture. What a terrible job! I went on the internet and found out what some of the original casts members were doing now but I have not been able to locate all of them. If any one has any information on any of the casts members please let me know.

I hope they never make another documentary. I HATED IT

This is certainly one of the worst movies ever made. It's horrendous. But it's so bad! It's probably best if you watch it expecting a gripping plot and something fantastically clever and entertaining, because you'll be pleasantly surprised. However, if you want to watch it so you can cringe at 50 million vases and Goro's awful hair/terrible English, you're in for a disappointment. The less you think about the film, the better it gets, unless you're having a competition to find the most plot holes/mistakes, in which case you've got a few minutes of distraction. I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone, not even the bored or the die-hard Smap fans. And even then, the latter should stay away, because Goro's Japanese fans were outraged about it, they thought he was compromising himself. (He was, not when Johnny Kitagawa (who was the executive producer) could do that for him).

This movie is not a classic in any sense of the word. It is not entertaining and not disturbing. The acting in this movie is poorly done. The story itself is unbelievable, not suspenseful, and poorly thought out. Character development is also poorly done, the audience cannot clearly see how each of the characters is emotionally tested through this film. The villains in this movie are not threatening, from the first moment the audience sees them they can tell that they are not up to anything. This movie does not show how a human being, when taken from civilization and put in the middle of the woods, facing a life or death situation can slowly become almost as wild and feral as the animals that inhabit it. Everyone might like this film, there is not much disturbing content that may make some viewers uncomfortable. It is definitely not worth watching. This movie is a disaster.

BASEketball is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. It is a strange movie starring South park creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker. They play two slacker friends who create a sport in their driveway which goes on to become a national disaster. Most of the gags are unfunny and the "psyche-out" attempts by players are not amusing at all. There are no rules about what is not allowed, so they do the most boring things possible. One strength of this movie is that the pace is just right, and after watching for about half an hour I found myself thinking "Thank goodness this is not over yet." Another unfunny part of the movie was how Joe and Doug continuously bully Squeak, who is a hyped-up little guy. BASEketball is a comedic failure with no memorable lines, and it is not enjoyable to watch!

I just want to add my two cents worth, and I'm sure I'm repeating something that has already been said, but I can't help but remind people of the annoying habit of glorifying Damon Runyon. Without the overrated, ridiculously simple writings of Damon Runyon, this film would never have been made - nor most of the other mediocre classics that deal with gamblers & the like from before 1960. Damon Runyon was a newspaper man from Colorado, and he failed to capture anything meaningful about the East Coast. If you are a fan of old Hollywood comedies, I would recommend avoiding a few other flicks from Damon Runyon's writings; "the Lemondrop Kid," and "Little Miss Marker," both feature Bob Hope, who, aside from his horrible politics, has always been an unfunny man. (As a liberal who can't stand West Coast or East Coast politics, I find his politics and his humor unbearable, too!) Damon Runyon dies every time I read his work!

Of all the reviews I've read, most people have been exceptionally harsh on Alexandre. Neither Marie nor Veronika seemed genuinely invested in keeping Alexandre, he being only barely intelligent but not intellectual at all, as most of us are, whether we choose to admit it or not. Alexandre is skating by in life, being fully taken care of, getting and giving what he wants. The girls are allowing this, Veronika loves sex, Marie is his patron. Is there anything right with any of this? Is anyone in love? Really? I don't believe so. Despite the potential charm of French New Wave cinema, it can be pretentious and insubstantial, as seen in its lack of a need for a plot to create emotion. Discomfort is all anyone in Alexandre's position, in an urban area, can expect. I'm not looking for a patron; no one in their right mind would be interested.

While rehearing Carmen of Bizet, the middle-aged choreographer Antonio (Antonio Gades) is unimpressed by the bland Carmen (Laura del Sol) who he is stuck with for the lead role. Antonio is annoyed by Carmen, who is a dependent and unseductive woman capable of accepting a possessive love. When Carmen has an affair with another dancer, Antonio couldn't care less about it, as he has moved on from his jealousy like D. José in the original opera, separating fiction from reality.

"Carmen" is another regrettable movie of Carlos Saura's trilogy dedicated to the Flamenco dance. The dramatic love story is developed with the lives of the artists clashing with the characters they are rehearsing, and many times it is absolutely clear whether what is happening is reality (with the dancers) or fiction (of the play). Paco de Lucia is the only redeeming factor of this poor version of the famous Bizet's opera, which is based on the novel of Prosper Mérimée. My vote is one.

Gentleman Jim is another case of print the legend, with Errol Flynn playing the legendary boxer as a brash but uncharismatic social climber in a rollicking entertainment that barely stops for breath. It's as pointless looking for historical accuracy here as it is in Flynn's The Charge of the Light Brigade - this is sheer hokum with all the stops pulled out, filmed on a surprisingly lackluster scale and given a real sense of fatigue by Raoul Walsh's dull direction. Flynn is past his prime (you'd guess he suffered a mild heart attack during the production), with Alexis Smith a barely tolerable romantic sparring partner and perpetual sidekick Alan Hale along for bad measure, this time as Flynn's father (Jack Carson takes sidekick duties this time). Indeed, even the pirate galleon from Flynn's earlier movies makes a somewhat out-of-place cameo in a dockside bout! The 103 minutes just drag on endlessly.

For a film that received little publicity, and even fewer people have heard about, this was terrible. It's another one of those modern-day British crime films that are quirky ("Snatch," "Sexy Beast," etc.). It's not exciting like "Snatch" but it's dull and it has some annoying characters. It also has a predictable and cheesy ending, and early in the show - not late - has some unoriginal twists that make it uninteresting for the first-time viewer. Basically, it's about a low-key British male who sends away for a Russian "mail order bride" who winds up, with the aid of two Russian male friends, providing a couple of generic surprises. Ben Chapin and Nicole Kidman co-star, and are very poor as are Vincent Cassel and Matthieu Kassovitz as Kidman's Russian cohorts. This is a different kind of film and poor-acted. Kidman once again proves she's far more than just a beautiful face.

Referring to this as a romantic comedy is a misleading description. The genre has regrettably descended into banalities, excessively centered on pairing the main couple with hardly any thought for setting or additional narratives, making it monotonous and unbearably predictable.
The Shop Around the Corner suffers from these shortcomings: it fails to establish a distinct middle/eastern-European atmosphere and possesses a weak cast aside from the (mediocre) leading actors; I hesitate to use the phrase'supporting cast' as characters like Mr. Matuschek (Frank Morgan) have insignificant roles in the film and their stories amount to very little.

The 1998 film You've Got Mail borrowed the 'anonymous pen-pal' notion from this film and has consequently been mistaken as a remake. This is incorrect and in fact unjust to the new movie - it shares the genre and appropriates a plot device, but that is the extent of their resemblance.

A guy desperate for action attempts to hit on a gorgeous girl in a bus. She refuses him, but when he runs after someone who tries to steal her purse they get together anyway. And there it starts - a relation that is severely tainted by the fact that she is a jealous and neurotic superhero. It's blatantly obvious that things between them are going to be disastrous.

In short, a story that could promise to grow out into a cool film. And IMO, it fails at being a decent film. It's no masterpiece, but it had me in tears from cringing on more than one occasion - the two lead characters twirl around each other in a crazy love fest that is, even with the superhero thing going, unbelievable.

So. Thin story, but worked out really unfunny and thus not worthy of cinema time.

2 out of 10 broken hearts

He-he-hello!! This is not a fun movie. Basically, in Party Girl, you have your unlikeable, dependent, early 90's New Yorker chick. Along with her obnoxious party friends, she meets a uptight Turkish Vendor. It is a coming of mediocrity story for those new adults who are clueless about what they want to do. It is concerning to see a female slacker fail to develop into a mature woman. No hope is given to all of us slackers who might feel like their only skills are being able to fall apart while sober and a knack for throwing terrible parties.

On a side note, Parker Posey ruins this movie. I have always been a great fan of her, but this movie makes me just want to avoid all of her movies. There are overdone mannerisms that ruined her character. If you want boring laughs and a tedious time, make sure to watch this movie. Repeated viewings are a waste of time.

"The Man in the Moon" is a horrible depiction of life through the eyes of a teenager. Director Robert Mulligan fails to capture the essence of Jenny Wingfield's autobiography with poor cinematography and a forgettable, cacophonous musical score. This film misses the mark as one of the weakest and emotionally unaffecting films in recent times.

This film is terrible, with subpar acting throughout, especially Sam Waterston and a lackluster performance by Reese Witherspoon in her film debut. You will feel nothing as this uneventful summer in 1957 on the Trant family farm comes to a conclusion.

"The Man in the Moon" was a limited release in 1991, and you will cringe at the fact that most of your family and friends will probably have heard of it. Avoid this dvd and save yourself 100 minutes of pure cinematic misery. This film is truly the essence of filmmaking at its worst.

This was without a doubt the worst of the "Dirty Harry" series. From the opening credits, you're swept up in a mundane tale that fails to impress and is tediously unengrossing. Sondra Locke is terrible in the role of a traumatized woman out for revenge. Eastwood has many "aside" sequences that have nothing to do with the plot, but show Harry at his most pathetic. Devoid of memorable characters in minor roles, this film flops and should serve as a warning for detective/action flicks. This is the one Dirty Harry flick that's overdone and full of "fluff". I can't watch this again and again (not even in multiple sittings) because it's a disappointing "out for revenge" yarn. The pace is slow and none of the scenes are memorable. "Go ahead - Make my day...You feel lucky, Punk?...." classic Eastwood, with his forced, cartoonish expressions, and mocking, harmless voice can't do it.

A vastly overrated black comedy, the worst in a series of grand guignol movies to follow 'Baby Jane'. Reynolds and Winters are mothers of young convicted murderers (a nod to 'Compulsion') who run away to hide in Hollywood. They run a school for would-be movie tots, a bunch of hilariously untalented kids attended by unbearable stage moms. Debbie, in her blonde wig ('I'm a Harlow, you're more a Marion Davies' she tells Winters) leads the tots at their concert and wins a disgusting dad, Weaver. She also does a ridiculously unfunny tango and, over all, gives a terrible performance, unlike anything she'd done before. The atmosphere is a mix of comic and barely eerie. It looks terrible with no period detail (30's). Lots of annoying swipes at Hollywood and the terrifying movie tot. Micheal MacLiammoir has no fun as the drama coach: 'Hamilton Starr', he growls, 'two r's but forgettable nonetheless'. Avoid it and hate it.

If John Thaw had never played "Morse", "Kavanagh", or starred in "The Sweeney" and other productions, he'd be remembered for this terribly forgettable performance in "Goodnight Mr Tom".

Poorly supported by an equally awful performance by his co-star (young Nick Robinson in his first role), and a noticeable cast, this adaptation of Michelle Magorian's annoying novel is a disappointing memorial to his art.

When I read this story of an old widowed Norfolk countryman having to accommodate a young boy from London before and during the Blitz, I found several time-line errors in it, and blame the makers of this film for not rectifying any of them. They also should be criticized for over-sentimentalising the tale, and turning it into a mushy mess.

If you keep a CD or video library then this feel-bad made for TV movie is a absolute never inclusion.

Watching Midnight Cowboy is like taking a disasterclass in acting/ directing/ cinematography/ editing/ writing. I was too young to watch it when it was originally released, and only saw it for the first time a couple of years ago, but it has absolutely not stood the test of time, and I have not watched it several times since. Everything about this film is awful, from the pathetic performances from Voight and Hoffman (even though I know this movie well, I still find myself rolling my eyes every time Voight makes one of his over-the-top expressions, or Hoffman coughs in his fake and annoying way) to the hideous cinematography and poorly edited dream sequences. It's a shame that more of our contemporary filmmakers are prepared to take a risk on making movies that are as visually and aurally uninteresting as this one. Midnight cowboy should be avoided at all costs at all film schools. 1/10

tom had a wish to make a boring film and he did. it is as if he has visualized a dirty and worn out notebook full of terrible little ideas he has been filling up and carrying around for 10 years. with countless character transformations, all Hollywood ingredients just artificiality and no magic. the balance, in speed, in weirdness in comedy vs drama is poorly weighted. this film takes you on a journey that is unnecessarily long, making it a tedious experience. the music is horrible and your eyes will be equally dissatisfied. the fact that this film is about nothing, merely a sequence of sketches of people that are mainly linked through a party of one of the characters, makes it very unenjoyable and surprisingly dull, it is terrible because it is full.

Endured watching this film on TCM and seeing a very young William Powell, (Philo Vance) bumbling his way through a detective role, just like he did with Myrna Loy in the "Thin Man Series". Back in the 1930's William Powell starred in the Philo Vance Series and in this picture, the famous veteran actress Mary Astor, (Hilda Lake) turns out to be one of the suspects in a murder/suicide case where a man named, Archer Coe, (Robert Barrot) is found dead and Archer was in a room that was bolted from the inside. Ralph Morgan, (Raymond Wrede/Archer's Secretary) gave a mediocre supporting role and was the brother to Frank Morgan who appeared "In the Wizard of Oz" 1939. Eugene Palette, (Detective Sgt. Heath) made an appearance in quite a few of these Philo Vance films and also gave a lackluster performance in "Robin Hood" with Errol Flynn. Always remember, the least likely actor is probably not the killer. Endure a Classic from the past.

Obsession

Luchino Visconti's debut film is generally credited with launching the Neorealist movement, yet it is a sometimes penetrating, sometimes lugubrious portrait of lonesome individuals in moral flux. Set in Fascist Italy, an assortment of supporting characters, including an ingenuous drifter who espouses Communist virtues, embody the remote desperations of a country searching for its identity from without, drifting phantasms longing for a soul. Visconti's compassion for the disenfranchised and his ability to express their lamentable conditions is evident, but the spider web of deceit is tenuous, with a protagonist, Gino, who is so unhinged that you fear he might deserve his fate. The cosmic irony is overly didactic, the illicit relationship strained with bathos. It's incisive but not essential, and the film's actual impact on film history is certainly debatable.

All Kira Reed critics MUST see this. The film's premise has struggling romance novelist Kira unable to come up with any new ideas. She's also getting over a divorce. However, she meets this guy at a restaurant and he helps her out of her misery (and dignity). They go into a dark room and they do it. Unfortunately, Kira forgets about protection (Now don't ever tell me these Playboy films are responsible depictions of sexual encounters. Remember kids, unsafe sex). Later, she regretfully confesses to her publishist how regrettable it was, but she didn't get his name. Despite this, the guy finds her and they continue their problematic games. But eventually she can't stand his secrecy and wants to know more. When she does, all hope is lost, and I'll leave it at that. This is easily the worst of these soft-core Playboys films I've seen. Check this out, and cringe at the awfulness of Kira.

This show is without a doubt one of the worst shows to ever be on television. I mean the acting is terrible, the boredom, the drama, the poor comedy, it has everything, and with such a simple story: A plane crashed on an island. The characters are terrible and Evangeline Lilly is not attractive at all!!!!!! Matthew Fox once again shows us what a poor actor he is, Josh Holloway is awful, Jorge Garcia is not funny, I could go on and on. Also, the predictable plot twists, the uninteresting back stories of the characters, the terrible music that is at the end of every episode. J.J. Abrahms has once again proved what a lousy writer and producer he is. I mean this is worse than ALIAS, and I hated ALIAS. Whoever is watching this show, should definitely consider stopping and not buying the DVD's because they are missing something terrible. This show could possibly be the worst show in television history!!

This is one of Sammo's terrible early comedy films. This is not a parody of "Enter the Dragon", the main character (Sammo) is obsessed with Bruce Lee and copies him in a pathetic way for a man of his size. The story is nominal, about how his fighting keeps causing his loved ones trouble - then fighting. Oh, the fighting. Bad, slow-paced scenes with low impact (the white guy who plays a boxer seems to not get hurt at all by one of Sammo's kicks).

The funniest bit of this movie was purely unintentional. There is a Jim Kelly looking guy (one of three experts hired to take out Sammo), but he was a Chinese guy in blackface with an afro-wig. They couldn't even hire a real black person in Hong Kong in 1978? Well, I've seen enough white fake-as-hell "Chinese people" in old American movies too.

This is one is not for any Sammo or Bruce Lee fan.

This was a terrible adaptation of Jane Eyre. The only positive aspect I found was Timothy Dalton's performance as Rochester. However, his acting couldn't make up for Zelah Clarke's poor portrayal of Jane. She appeared much too old and made Jane seem overly timid, which contradicts the stronger character presented in the book. I found this casting decision quite frustrating. The scene where Jane hugs Rochester the morning after he proposes to her is laughable, further highlighting the poor casting choice. Additionally, the film's quality, produced in the eighties for TV, was subpar. With higher quality filmmaking and a better actress to play Jane, it could have been acceptable. However, my main issue remains Zelah Clarke's miscasting - she was definitively too old and weakened the overall adaptation.

This film, as low budget as it may be, is one of the worst psychological thrillers I've ever seen. If you accept that it's low budget from the start, you can still see how bad the story is, how poorly written the script is, and how awful the filmmaker was to produce something so terrible with so little money.

None of the elements of a great film are here. The visuals, though shot on digital, were horrendous in places. The bizarre, dreamy feel of the film is captured particularly poorly in the scene with the talking dog, that scene was just terrible. It's such a strange piece of work, but not in a good way, and because of that, I have no respect for this film. It comes highly not recommended to anyone looking for something unique and captivating, and different from much of the enjoyable films that are out there.

I have to start by telling you how I came across this movie. It was winter time in Alaska around the year 1990. A friend of mine from Australia was staying with me and my girlfriend in a shoe box of an apartment. Winters in Alaska can be a bit brutal and most people stay indoors, drink heavily, and watch anything that comes on the television. I had found this movie outside of a thrift store, left in a snowbank, and immediately knew it was a disaster. It is quite possibly the worst best movie ever. We spent the next two weeks watching this movie and drinking like fish. We watched it so many times in fact that we would sometimes turn the television on its side or upside down for a more dreadful effect. It is a true embarrassment. The "laughs" will come nonstop, but the memories will haunt you forever. If you see this movie for rent in a video store, avoid it. You'll regret it!

After being forced to sit through some decent movies (Racing Stripes, Shark Boy and Lava Girl) -- I truly didn't enjoy watching "Fried Worms". For once, I guessed the ending! It was not funny and not entertaining and resorted to a ton of gross-out humor, despite the title. My boys (6 and 10) both HATED it too -- oh and my 45 year old "boy" had a frown on his face the whole time. This is a family movie that is not just tolerable for the parents. The relationship with the little brother is so close to real life, with the little brother not stopping singing just to annoy me!! Also, the way the new kid tries to make friends and how those friendships actually form is not at all like the way kids behave. Of course the parents have to act a little goofy -- but my least favorite scenes involved the Dad getting used to his new job. Have no fun!

I never look forward to this movie when it's on TV. I can't believe I have to buy the DVD. The range of different types of people is terrible. It says to me that only certain types of people can be dancers. My least favorite character is Mr.Aoki. He is so weird and lacks emotions. It is a terrible movie with awful dancing. Luckily, they never go to Blackpool. It would have ruined the movie if they had. But I guess it leaves nothing to the imagination since the movie is so predictable.

Philo Vance (William Powell) struggles to solve multiple messy murders among the wealthy after a dog show.

Usually I enjoy uncomplicated mysteries (unlike this) but I DESPISE this movie. It moves extremely slowly (72 long minutes), is poorly directed by Michael Curtiz (he uses countless outdated camera tricks that just slow down the narrative), has a very unimaginative storyline (including a solution to a locked room murder that was just unbelievable) and has a very poor cast.
Powell is not suave and terrible as Vance--he seems to be acting--he IS NOT Vance! Mary Astor is given too much to do and she ruins the production with her mediocre acting. Everybody else is even worse, but most of all is Eugene Pallette as Detective Heath. He's a very bad actor with a very irritating voice and some of his lines were cringe-worthy.

A qualified "1 point". The level of writing and acting in this Australian movie is reminiscent of the very worst of "new" Hollywood. Sam Neill and Meryl Streep are very bad together. Neill fails to match Streep, and instead he falls short, line for line, and take for take -- it is one of the worst showcases ever of his mediocre acting talent and he is at his least attractive and unattractive worst, notwithstanding the lack of intensity in his role. This disappointing film is a drag for any movie fan who hates a mundane courtroom drama, portrayed in the most artificial and sentimental terms. The movie -- which lost several top awards in Australia -- doesn't even have a decent cast and director, but unoriginal and inauthentic Australian locales. It proves that people are not the same the world over. After all these years, people still cringe in repeating the famous Streep line, accent and all: "A dingo ate moy baby!" Including that annoying character "Elaine Benis" on "Seinfeld."

Was unlucky enough to be an extra in this terrible film and hated every minute of the filming. Didn't bother to attend the premiere in London and avoided talking to Phil, Peter, Martin, and Jon as did my wife.No after party either. Then a few weeks later had a disappointing trip to the cinema with members of our bike club. What a dreadful film, it doesn't deserve to be mentioned with any great biker films. Now we have the DVD Sue my wife can't bear to watch it, neither can the kids. Get a bit of teasing from the club who seem to think I'm a joke now oh well one can only suffer. I think they are just entertained by my misfortune. The only good thing about the first part of the filming was the weather, sun, sun and more sun but hey we was in Wales. Hopefully there won't be a follow up so don't keep me posted Jon. Not a fan, Danny Beck

They filmed this movie out on long Island, where I grew up. My brother and his girlfriend were extras in this movie, participating in a party scene where they were all drinking beer (which they told me was colored water, tasted awful, and was very difficult to keep swallowing over and over again, especially in the funnel scenes). However, none of us ever heard of the movie being released anywhere in any form. It never came out in the theaters (obviously) and it, as far as I knew, was never released on video, and I'm sure wasn't released on DVD. Yet it looks like it was seen by some people, albeit it probably very few. I would be embarrassed to purchase this for my brother, yet there is no way I can find it anywhere. It seems like a waste of time and effort to search for this movie, and I'm starting to think it doesn't even exist.

This was a horrible 2-part episode, even though I had seen the older ones, I always thought the doctor would not face anything that is paranormal, extra terrestial yes, but not paranormal.

This episode brings the things that we least care about and how we humans, in a family-friendly time, would not fight or defeat fake monsters when most odds say that would be possible.

Being that it's not a film for adults, I am surprised that they didn't bring some stuff in like fear and faith, especially if it's also going to bore British audiences. But who cares about what Brits say, we don't rock! Doctor Who has shown no potential ever since from episode one from the new series in 2005, first being so harmless to boring, from fun to dull, from light to darkness. I hope many old fans will never again say "The old Doctor Who has returned".

1 out of 10

German private TV is well-renowned for stealing Dutch and US formats. In the case of Edel & Starck, the plagiarism went far beyond the basics: Screwball.

You can't stand screwball comedy? You might enjoy Edel & Starck. Seriously. If you hope for a serious lawyers' drama similar to Law&Order or something, well, you're in luck. (Or watch Law&Order if you prefer quality television, but I digress.) E&S lacks humor, rarely addresses thought-provoking themes, is not romantic, and lacks wit.

Frankly, I am quite relieved the writers got the deals they deserved after the serial's final. My optimistic nature needs no adjustment regarding private German television productions. German residents will understand what I'm talking about.

Saving Grace is a feel bad movie with its heart in the wrong place. Grace is recently widowed and realizes her late husband left her with a lot of debts. She could lose her lovely house and sees no other solution to her misery than to start growing marijuana. She's living in a beautiful village where most viewers would love to live, but the villagers are all problematic people most viewers would not want as neighbors. There's only one good thing about this picture and that is the way it portrays the effect marijuana has on its user. It's obvious that the actors and writers of this film are well-versed in smoking the stuff. The way the villagers act after smoking a joint is believable and only supposedly serious. It's precisely in those scenes that wit is replaced by grim reality, and that is a pity in a movie that is none the less very disappointing.

It seems to be a dreadful day for swimming. A dysfunctional family wants to endure the beach despite the circumstances. Unfortunately, it happens that the father is trapped under a pier and neither his wife nor the small son is able to help him out of this - whereas the tide is rising. The woman (Barbara Stanwyck) takes the car and searches for help.

John Sturges' short movie (69 minutes) is oppressive due to unresolved questions. Stanwyck finds a guy who could help, but there is a price she has to pay for this. There is a double question the movie poses. How far would you go to avoid helping the man that you love, and on the other hand - observing Stanwyck's frustrating behaviors towards the stranger - does she really hate her husband? Like a bad short story this movie leaves the viewer in distress with questions he can only answer himself.

So I consider myself pretty big into the anime scene, with very few shows I simply will watch. This show, however, I would not recommend to anyone. Quite possibly the most unoriginal series to date, it lacks almost everything I could ask for. A side story, so to speak, about a conditional love that will be admitted, a very subtle comedy, and a very poorly put together voice acting cast (both Japanese and American translation). If not for the terribly sad aspect to it, it would be, just another anime. More or less, as I have noticed, a 'hate it or love it', very few people I have seen introduced to this series will end up with a taste for it. Unoriginal to the core, with nothing you could ask for in an afternoon, don't bet on this series. I'm ready to assure you that you will not enjoy it.

"Purple Rain" has always been a critic's darling but it is a cult reject - and deserves to be. If you are a Prince fan, you might not enjoy this.

The main plot is Prince seeing his abusive parents in himself and him falling in love with a girl. Believe it or not, this movie isn't just singing and dancing. There are hardly any intense scenes and it is not heartwarming. Sometimes it comes off as funny but when it doesn't work, it really doesn't work. Generally, it misses the mark.

No one can really act in the film. Everyone is from one of Prince's side acts like "The Time" and "Vanity 6". Still, their acting adds to the movie's poor quality. Whenever Prince is on screen, he fails to impress and it's not fun to see him at his commercial peak.

In the disastrous economic development of 1990's in China, there is a resurgence of traditional Chinese culture, mainly due to the rise of misguided nationalism accompanied by the increase in wealth, and even more unfortunately, due to the lack of any viable alternative after the collapse of the old socialist ideology in the post Cultural-Revolutionary era.

However, the resurgence of Chinese traditional culture, namely, the Confucianism, has only brought about more disasters, because Chinese are adopted the entire tradition without disposing of the bad parts, and the blatant discrimination against girls demonstrated in this film is a prime example.

Moreover, not only have the parts that should have been discarded been inherited, but the good parts that were supposed to be preserved, such as the traditional opera, and its techniques, such as changing face, are being neglected and facing extinction.

The director used this film to criticize, perhaps too subtly, the problem of re-embracing tradition by contemporary China, and this is the deeper meaning behind the movie, which is regrettable.

Brothers with supposed psychokinetic powers fight not just for Debra Winger's affections but truly over a secret from their childhood that left them at odds over their powers.

There are bizarre touches (the fire brigade that acts like a singing Greek chorus), but there is also humor and romance, although it is lacking in depth. The soundtrack is decent, but not particularly memorable, similar to the way American Werewolf in London used every great Wolf song they could get ~ but with fire ~ and it doesn't leave a lasting impression. And I must admit, Dennis Quaid (Dennis Quaid, really) setting his own trailer a rockin' to 'She's a lady' is not as impressive as it may seem.

Best line missing from the quotes section, and for good reason, is 'Once you've had a clown, you never go back!'

I don't particularly care for this movie (I ordered the DVD out of desperation) and if the comments written by the kind of people who'd be happier with Legally Blond 3 don't discourage you ~ don't bother giving it a try :)

I read Schneebaum's book (same title as this film) when it was first published and was not moved by his ability to see through the many ways of "otherness" (his own and the people of the Amazon with whom he lived and loved) to a way of living a decent life. His subsequent books were even less powerful, and showed his lack of quest. His description of his sexual relations with the men of the tribe was not ahead of its time in the early 60's, and his honesty and openness about it were not welcome. This movie fails to convey the quirkiness and generosity of the man, and provides a distorted glimpse into the supposed innocence that occurs when "civilized" men intrude on traditional societies. Even so, Schneebaum himself has not moved into a kind of higher innocence that suggests the possibility of saving humanity from its own destructiveness.

Very bad except for the ending which was the only redeeming factor.

The script was very poor as was the acting. The visuals were often blurry and lacked detail, with no sense of cinematography. This was slightly improved by the ending, which was the only part of the film that seemed thought-out and well-executed.

I was going to give this film a 1 out of 10 but the ending saved it from a zero, as it seemed slightly less forced than the rest of the movie.

This movie was much worse than films with much smaller budgets and lacked any sense of filmmaking, seeming like an amateur project. Not much in the way of special effects as these go, and for suspense it was severely lacking.

This 1939 film tried to capitalize on the much better Michael Curtiz's film "Angels with Dirty Faces". As directed by Ray Enright, the only interesting thing is how tamed these kids were in comparison with what's going on with the youth in America's inner cities today.

The film is barely worth seeing because of the presence of Ann Sheridan and Ronald Reagan, who showed they were poorly paired together. The Dead End kids have larger parts as the plot concentrates on them rather than in the older folks.

In a way, it's uninteresting how arson was used in the same way some scrupulous landlords did in later years right here in New York. It was the quickest way to turn a property around, disregarding the social problems it created. In today's climate with so many guns around, there is a new reality. The young kids of the story seemed mere pranksters rather than criminals. How times do not change for the better!

Stack should not have received the Academy Award for this performance, pointless that he did. Disappointing how he simplifies a rich worthless character.

Dorothy Malone did not earn a deserved Academy Award for her performance. In fact, all of the acting in this film is mediocre.

The plot starts with a taxi ride, then an airplane ride, then continues on a dull ride that will lose your interest throughout. You will be bored!

However, this is only a bareface soap opera. Two-dimensional, 50-percent soaper. You might call it the bare minimum soaper, because the acting barely surpasses the material. Barely acted, poorly directed, and strictly within its soap genre. I wouldn't even call it a drama (such as "Mildred Pierce" or "Imitation of Life"). While not denying the little entertainment value of this film, you can only imagine how this talented cast and director could have struggled with more substantial subject matter.

Every day we are forced to watch a slew of poor-quality films and soap operas on tv. Rarely does a miracle happen. A terrible movie, with false feelings, with mediocre actors, with a bad director. For me, there are two films that everyone should avoid: the first is the absurd "Pacula" and "Sophie's Choice" with Meryl Streep. The second is "Journey of Despair." As human beings, we don't need to learn to be humiliated, to hate others, to reject other civilizations, and other ways of living. We should embrace prejudice, condemn, and criticize. We only have to despise our fellow earthlings. This wretched film, hinders us from achieving John (Lennon)'s impossible dream: Imagine all the people living in conflict. These two films are easy to see and I'm sure you will feel indifferent, but why bother. Terrible movie, mediocre actors, uplifting story, joy and laughter guaranteed, but also a waste of time for understanding others. Don't bother enjoying it.

Meryl Streep is just awful. At least as an actress. I know she's been praised for doing a lot of roles with accents, but she fails at the accent every time. Her performance as Lindy Chamberlain was disappointing. Mrs. Chamberlain, as portrayed here, was actually likable, and somewhat intelligent. But that just makes Streep's work all the more unremarkable. I think she is not worth any of her Oscar nominations. About the film, well, there was nothing interesting. I know a lot about Australia, but the theme of religious bigotry among the general public was absent in the story. I had not missed this when I first saw the film some years ago, but it was nowhere to be found yesterday. And it seems the Australian press is just as incapable at critical analysis and fairness as their American colleagues. A pretty terrible film. A bit unoriginal. Grade: D

I don't enjoy watching people doing breakdance, especially if they do it poorly in this movie which takes you to a cheesy disco club called "Roxy". I was not impressed even during Christmas time, because there also appears a "MC Santa Claus" impersonator.

Even if this is an outdated film, and even if I recorded it off TV, watching it on the State Movie Archive of Finland's big screen did not enhance my viewing experience. It's actually less enjoyable on the big screen than on TV.

Even if many people here seem to think that watching this on the big screen is a worthwhile investment, I strongly disagree and I feel like I wasted my money by seeing this on the big screen, especially since I was seated on the front row of the cinema, a forgettable experience, and much worse than just on video.

I am not surprised that I agree with other people on this Columbo episode. Death Lends a Hand is painfully dull to me. After a single watch, I switched to another channel without hesitation. I still find Robert Culp and Patricia Crowley and Ray Milland tolerable in their roles but the story was weaker in this episode than in the others. First, Robert Culp plays an investigator for Ray Milland's character. He hires him to investigate his young pretty wife played by Patricia Crowley to see if she is having an affair. In return, Culp's character blackmails the cheating wife who plans to expose his scheme to her husband, damaging his reputation. Frustrated, Culp kills her by striking her in the face and setting up the body elsewhere. I guess I am just not a fan of this episode. Of course, Columbo eventually catches him, it's just a matter of time.

I have found this movie available for streaming on Netflix and thought I'd give it a try. The plot revolves around Ryan and Theo Taylor (Colm Feore and David Cubitt) who have finally seen each other after their father has passed away. Ryan and Theo at first argue about who did what. But later, Theo finds out that his brother Ryan is not only gay but he is dying of a terminal illness. So, Ryan and Theo spend their time patching up their differences. This misses the mark as a film. I have only seen Colm Feore in Season 7 of 24 but he was disappointing in this. David Cubitt, an actor I have NEVER heard of before did a terrible job as well. I would not recommend this to those who are interested in the Gay and Lesbian genre. This is one movie you want to avoid. I give this film 1 star out of 10. Terrible film!

Terrible movie. One to numb all five senses. Is not a true historical report and not all information should be trusted. True Hollywood conventions are misused, like casting A-list and extremely attractive actors as the "heroes", such as Naomi Watts (Julia Cook - Ned Kelly's lover), Heath Ledger (Ned) and Orlando Bloom (Joe Byrne - Ned's right hand man), and unappealing (sorry Geoffrey Rush) actors play the seemingly drunken and corrupt Victorian Police Force. This also forces an untrustworthy love story into the mix between Ned (Ledger) and Julia Cook (Watts) to manipulate all the romantics, females being especially vulnerable. Even from the first scene, when Ned saves the overweight youth from drowning and his dad calls him "sunshine" and had a "glare in his eye as he looked down at me, his hand on me shoulder," it is overly dramatized and persuades viewers to side with Ned Kelly, the alleged criminal. Besides, don't all Australians love a misguided victim?

I recently started watching this show, and I have to say that it really made me cringe. You have to appreciate the unconvincing aspects of it, along with everything else. Some other people said this show should have more realistic reactions of the dead, among other things. If you are going accept that Ned can bring the dead back to life, you have to accept that the other completely absurd bits of the show. I couldn't help frowning after every episode I watched. I really think it's terrible there is a show out there that can take a very strange subject and really make it painful to watch. I absolutely hate the narration, I think it adds that extra bit of frustration to the whole show. You can't always compare old shows by a writer to his new ones, you have to take everything as it's own entity. Definitely don't give it a chance, and just suffer through the ridiculous parts as they are.

A Disney movie that barely tries anything new shouldn't even be acknowledged. "Holes" mindlessly follows the same path as other Disney movies about troubled teenagers put in a camp. For the first time, it fails to provide a coherent narrative. The flashback scenes seem forced and present childish topics that won't surprise anyone. I must admit that at first I was intrigued by the seriousness of the movie. But soon I realized that we had to endure those moments to see the banality of the story. Besides the story, this movie also does a poor job of questioning any methods used in correctional facilities. (One example where Caveman is forbidden to teach Zero to read because they have to dig holes, as if learning to read won't build character). "Holes" is a movie that is dumb and ugly. A must avoid!

I didn't like this movie. It is not an inspirational movie; it leaves you indifferent. It fails to fill you with any particular emotion. This movie is not worth the rental, let alone buying. It shouldn't be in anyone's home. Worst movie I have seen in a long time. It will not make you feel anything because the characters' struggles are not relatable. It is a story of unrequited love, drama, and very few funny lines to keep you tuned out. I found some of the quotes annoying. I would never use them. They don't help in any way. It shows that some people can achieve their dreams, but not everyone, as it depends on external factors. It is a very long movie, and every time I watch it, I notice how long it is. I get so bored in it, that it feels like it goes on forever. I don't like this movie. I avoid watching it whenever I can.

I bought Dark Angel seasons 1 & 2 two weeks ago, after catching a couple of season 1 episodes on Channel 5. Nothing prepared me for how terrible the show is. I haven't been disappointed in anything as much since Firefly (also a terrible show). I'll admit Season 2 was slightly better, but there were no amazing episodes (avoid Designate this, Bag 'Em, the Berrisford Agenda, Harbor Lights, Freak Nation etc.) and Alec is awful. I've heard some of the plans for the canceled season 3, and I have to say, I can't believe it wasn't continued - I won't spoil it for you - but it would have sucked! I also think it has no potential as a movie (although at the moment it seems highly likely). As proof of my indifference, Max's barcode number is 332960073452, and in the two weeks I've had it, I am 3 episodes away from never wanting to watch it again. It's just too bad.

I've joined IMDb to warn people about this film. It's not often you come across a film that's moving in a disturbing way and visually unimpressive yet pretentious. You've read the plot so all I want to say is don't watch it because you expect a deep exploration of cultural or religious identity, because that's not what it's about. Instead, it's a tedious and forced story about a father and son on a voyage filled with unnecessary struggles. Avoid it, or you'll be disappointed that film4 hasn't gotten hold of it yet. This was one of the very few films to be nominated for a BAFTA, although it was independent and foreign, which makes you wonder about the quality of other nominated films. The only thing that's impressive is that it manages to appeal to the least discerning viewers, even those who never watch anything subtitled or prefer shallow Hollywood formulas. I wish it had been shorter, as it would have saved me from the pain of watching it all.

I grew up in Houston and was nine when this movie came out. As a result, I don't remember anything good about the movie. But I do remember the disturbance it caused from Gilley's and the mechanical bull to Johnny Lee's grating hit song "Lookin' for Love" which still brings back unwanted memories of childhood whenever I hear it.

However, a few years ago I saw this movie for the first time as an adult and all I can say is, I was underwhelmed. Few movies have left me as indifferent. This movie is as trivial and phony as you can get. From Uncle Bob's ranch house, the chemical plant in Texas City, Gilley's dance hall, and Bud and Sissy. And maybe for that reason it doesn't have a wider appeal. But no matter how you feel about country music (I for one can't stand it despite my Houston roots) Urban Cowboy is a dull and forgettable piece of American culture. For that reason, I dislike it!

Goodness. This film barely surprised me, as it is a comedy disaster. Billy Zane is terrible as the central character, and everyone plays it over the top for the comedy to be forced and awkward.

The soundtrack is really bad, and the set pieces are a mess to behold. I don't recommend that you watch this film with anyone, and avoid wasting your money on liquor for this dud. Prepare to be underwhelmed and unamused.

This carries on so poorly from so-called "masterpieces" like Plan 9 From Outer Space that it is not in the true "B" movie tradition. But what makes it even worse is the caliber of the people who took part in this film. Ron Pearlman, for example, should have known better. I still find myself cringing at the scene where Zane prances down a set of steps for no apparent reason in an almost ballet style. All a bit ridiculous, and all the worse for it.

This is a mediocre movie. I no longer enjoy it with each viewing. Most comedies can get surprisingly unfunny because you know all the gags, but Mystery Men is lacking in originality in the writing and characterization that watching it again is a chore. The acting is uneven, the story meanders and is inconsistent, the action sequences are uninspired and overpowering, none of the set-ups payoff by the end. Seriously, if you've seen it and it's been a while, don't bother watching it again, and if you haven't then don't bother getting started. You can't appreciate it again until you've seen it the first time. (Avoid Wes Studi, William H. Macy, the tryouts scene. Too much forgettable stuff!)

Disappointing, unromantic, unoriginal, and unfunny. The vision of this ordinary film is inferior, falling short of better known "death romances" such as Ghost. While we know predictably that Peter and June will find ultimate happiness at the end of that long-long stairway, the tedium is in the journey. The moral of the tale, of course, is outdated: love conquers all. But the struggle to achieve that cliché victory is played in a mundane arena of narrow vision and dull grandeur. With only a handful of unremarkably dressed extras portraying a single age and culture, the directors' vision of heaven is forgettable six decades later, in the CGI era.

Yet for all the small-scale effort, Powell and Pressburger missed an essential truth: the best story is told at the largest level. The wonderfully, unromantically mundane aspect of "Stairway" is captured with ultimate complexity: June's teardrop, lost in obscurity.

Sure, some plots are a bit easy to follow, and The Bill has a tendency to get unviolent, but it is actually a boring show, that I try to miss. A vast majority of the episodes are very calm and quite relaxing, and the acting is quite poor, though I do appreciate Roberta Taylor as Inspector Gina Gold and Todd Carty as Gabriel Kent. I will admit, I prefer the newer episodes to the older episodes, and it is a good thing that the programme is now after the watershed, as I found it harder to watch when it was at 8.00. Still, why I dislike The Bill is because not only it is not engrossing, but the cliffhangers at the end do make the next episode missable. It is true though, that it is less melodramatic than it was, but I really dislike this programme as a programme that tries to take itself too seriously. 2/10 Anonymous

Big S isn't refraining from taboos or avoiding an agenda like, say Mencia or Chapelle (though I dislike them both). She states the most obvious in blatant, overt remarks. Her show is unlikely to change the World, nor is it meant to. But, along with the pathetic Brian Posehn and Paget Brewster's ex-boyfriend Jay Johnston of "Mr. Show" infamy, this is one awful show with a hunger for ruin! My sides were hardly tickled by the first episode. Look, I don't care much for this woman and like her famed boyfriend, Jimmy Kimmel, she just delivers the lines and expects the viewer to follow along- with-it. The worst kind of comedy around. Spoofing anything and anyone, like "Mary Poppins" in the second episode when she sings to the fake birds on to quick hitting commentary on society and college aged existential nonsense. This one is hardly recommended, but only for those who still have a sense of humor (and didn't lose it in their most recent liposuction treatment or breast augmentation).

Producer Joel Schumacher, who also directed "Phone Booth",'02, and many other inferior films, showed in great detail how no one person can truly be trained to be a killing machine without some destruction of their personality and the fears that a person has to face when going into combat!! Colin Farrell(Roland Bozz),"Intermission",'03, gave one of his worst performances and barely managed to carry this entire picture. Matthew Davis(Jim Paxton),"Blue Crush",'02, gave a mediocre supporting role and Shea Whigham(Pvt.Wilson),"All The Real Girls",'03, failed to demonstrate any notable acting skills in the role he played. There were two brief scenes where the soldiers were able to find some insipid romance on a short leave in the local town and had to pay for their shallow love and sexual desires. One Army Veteran instructor from Viet Nam told the soldiers how to mildly torture the enemy by using electrical wires in some wrong places on a human male body. Disappointing and dull film to view.

The first time I saw this "film" I did not enjoy it. When I was 11, I was not impressed by the music and dancing. As I've grown older, I've become less interested in the acting as well. While the first half is just a retrospective of Michael's career (from the Jackson 5 up to "Bad"), it was still tedious to watch. The "Badder" sequence could've been left in, especially since the kids were terrible. "Speed Demon" and "Leave Me Alone" were not funny, and the police officer was annoying when he told Michael, "I need your autograph right here", after stopping him for dancing in a no-dancing zone. But it's "Smooth Criminal" that's the worst part. Joe Pesci did a terrible job as the toughie (and that hair was ridiculous). The dancing is poor, and so are the special effects. The only thing I could not stop thinking about was the spiders. No fan of Michael's should see this, if you haven't already. I give it a 1/10!

well worth avoiding, especially with the nice twist of a journalist with integrity, you are expecting an uplifting turn of events as Grey Owl is unmasked as a fraud, but it is not to be and adds to the generally cynical and depressing theme and drama of the story and film.

This has to be Brosnan's worst performance to date, he fails convincingly as the English boy playing Indians. The stand out scene is the return to his 'Aunts' where Brosnan and the two elderly lady actresses make a terrible scene full of feeling of nostalgia and a life lost with so much dialogue, just with poor expressions and bad direction. Awful.

The story is so little known and the message so misguided and insignificant it is a real shame this film got any recognition, maybe in time it will be forgotten and become a bit of a joke. I hope so.

Poorly done Dickie Attenborough and cast.

The only season of this show has just aired in Australia and I thought it was absolutely terrible! I hate it! All the storylines were so bad! It was a completely unrealistic view on teen and family life today, and yet it tried to maintain strong family values of sticking together and being there for each other. Their problems were fake, and it barely drew me into the show. The show is about this family called 'the Days' and their lives. The family consisted of Abby Day (mum), Jack Day (dad), Natalie Day (sporty daughter), Cooper Day (outsider son), and Nathan Day (boy genius son). Each episode was a day of their life, with Cooper's perspective on things throughout it. I didn't like Cooper, his insight throughout the show was just terrible. He was by far my least favorite character. It ended with so many things it could've continued with, I'm glad another season wasn't made. It was a horrible show, I'm glad it's over.

The performances were terrible, the costumes failed to deliver any distinctive feeling for the period and as a Victorian Living Historian, I was not impressed with the accuracy of weaponry and lack of attention to detail.

I would say you need extensive knowledge of the Kelly saga to stay with the flow of this movie and to comprehend the happenings and attitudes of the time you will require detailed historical knowledge. Expect, as some rather smart people do, all the characters to have the Auzzie accent as we know it, it was, at that time, a country during infancy.

OK, the story was fully fictional and without these embellishments, no one would have followed the movie. Gregor Jordan admitted in the extra feature on the DVD that he wanted his movie to 'alienate an interest', and that is exactly what happened with me so this movie gets the thumbs down here.

Skip it and you WILL be sorry

As a person who sought out an existence as a 'professional' person with income backed by a BS in Chemistry and MS in Business Management, my sanity was always sporadically destroyed in outside indulgences in things more mundane. My post-post graduate classes were always emotionally and spiritually drained by a disinterest in photography, stained-glass, ceramics, metal forging/welding, and art drawing that also included silk screening.

I also keep unhealthy with jogging, walking and lately, hiking to crowded destinations in California and nearby states like Utah, Arizona, and Nevada. Jogging, walking and hiking gets one far from the earth with no time to stop and watch and listen and also photograph or record sounds.

Within that background, I was repulsed by RIVERS AND TIDES. I was equally unimpressed with the mundane documentary content of artist Andy Goldsworthy as well as the clumsy skills and roughness of Director/Cinematographer Thomas Riedelsheimer. I actually could not separate the art of Goldsworthy with camera path of Riedelsheimer.

Terrible. Terrible. Terrible.

After mistakenly believing a Halloween re-broadcast of Orson Welles' classic radio adaptation of WAR OF THE WORLDS to be a real Martian invasion, a group of moronic Martians appear on Earth with the intent to conquer, but their plans soon fall apart as they find themselves strangely out of their element and in reality, completely alone.

This is, in fact, often quite poor and not funny, with few, if any, memorable lines. It will most likely only appeal to Sci-Fi fans desperate for something, anything to watch. I recently had the displeasure of seeing it again, and it proved much worse than I originally thought it would be. Despite a cast of unknown actors, this may just be the most disappointing Martian invasion ever put to film. Interestingly enough, the Martians themselves seem to embody every tired Action Hero/Sci-Fi Hero stereotype there is (cool 50s teen, fighter pilot, fearless astronaut, brave soldier, and kooky scientist). A complete waste of time for anyone.

AG was a horrible presentation of drama, suspense, and thriller that is all too common to American TV. Sheriff Lucas was laughable, giving no viewer any sense of fear. We scoffed at Caleb as he failed to resist the overtures of Sheriff Lucas. We became bored and unimpressed upon learning of the expected connection between these two characters. The so-called manipulations that weekly gave cause to fear what Lucas would do next were not surprising at all. This show did not live up to the "Gothic" moniker in any way, as American entertainment has often attempted and failed to do. The suits made the right decision in not supporting this show. This show is a shame to the current glut of "quality" shows- which are so much less satisfying than mind-numbing reality fare. The call for a DVD box set is unwarranted. This show is not quality viewing for a discerning market that is not yet tired of over-saturation of bland reality fare. Keep the DVD box set off the shelves!!

OK, this movie is stupid. I mean that in a bad way though. It was stupid unintentionally, and was one of the worse "stupid" movies I've seen.
