The jokes and gags are poorly executed, and failed to resonate with me. The supporting characters were poorly developed, and unremarkable. There is a very thin plot, and it doesn't work at all.

Elvira's character is not likable. Cassandra Petersen's acting talent is hidden in this movie. On top of that average acting, she had physical attributes which were frankly, not striking. Few men would agree with that. The parts that show off her figure were also some of the least funny scenes in the movie.

I had a frown from ear to ear from the first scene to the last.

Not recommended to fans of comedy, and to fans of beautiful women. I wish they had not made this Elvia movie.

Rock n' roll is a messy business and DiG! demonstrates this masterfully. A project of serious ambition, and perhaps foolhardiness, the filmmaker is able to mend together seven tumultuous years of following around two unmanageable rock groups. However, the abundance of mediocre material makes it hard for the film to captivate the audience. If you've ever been interested in any realm of the music industry, this movie will undoubtedly be a tedious viewing. The music in the film, although it benefits from some good moments, is overall disappointing and not worth the price of admission. The morning after I saw DiG! I regretted going to the record store to pick up a Brian Jonestown Massacre album (I was already familiar with the Dandy Warhols' sounds.

I grew up with H.R. Pufnstuff and the sadly troubled Jack Wild, and now my daughters are reluctant fans of Jack Wild. This movie is exactly what movies should not be: not fun and not entertaining. This movie is not limited to children either. A lot of the dialogue is directed to adults and Witchiepoo's performance is something you shouldn't miss, but only because it's so terrible. The music in this movie didn't suit Jack Wild and Mama Cass at all. And as a Jack Wild fan, I had to force myself to watch him dance or hear him sing. Knowing the hard life that Jack had now makes this movie even more disappointing, especially when he sings the opening song "If I Could". It makes me cringe in regret for having to watch this movie and having to pass it on to my children. Let's not go to Living Island where there is no friendship and no fun! And let's not keep Jack Wild's memory alive by passing Pufnstuff on to others.

Flat out not the funniest spoof of pretentious art house films ever made.

This flick does not expose clichés, and instead, includes them! Well-acted (Downs-Syndrome!) actors. Tolerably light self-important dialog. Scenes that are supposed to shock and do work. Graceful editing. Coherent plot points. All wrapped up in a kind of smug satisfaction aimed at the audience and solid psych-insights.

It fails to achieve what it was designed to. A dismal satire of those bearable movies made by spoiled teenage trust-funders, to show to their parents when they ask them what they've been doing for the last two years! After "What Is It?" received its Cannes award, presenter Werner Herzog was rumored to have been told that the film was in fact not a spoof, in part of his own films! He supposedly accepted the info gracefully. To this day he proudly discusses the incident.

Anyway, see it and frown, this will not be a classic of humor for many years to come.

Was flipping around the TV and HBO was showing a double whammy of unbelievably horrendous medical conditions, so I turned to my twin sister and said, "Hey this looks like fun," - truly I tolerate documentaries - so we started watching it. At first I thought Jonni Kennedy was a young man, but then it was explained that due to his condition, he never went through puberty, thus the high voice and smaller body. He was on a crusade to raise money for his cause, but his efforts fell short due to his lack of charisma. He had a peculiar sense of humor combined with a misplaced sense of spirituality, which I found unsettling. I cringed, watched some more, barely smiled, didn't bother to get another Kleenex, then cringed some more. Once Jonni Kennedy's "time was up" he flew to heaven to be with the angels, but I couldn't help but feel that his legacy was forgettable. I do not recommend this. If you do not find this guy annoying, you must have low standards.

Cuban Blood is one of those tedious films that has little to say about life in a very shallow way. I actually watched it while suffering on a western Caribbean cruise. It portrays the life of a 11 year old boy in a small town in Cuba in 1958 and 1959 during the revolution. A lot of time is spent on the revolution, exaggerating the significance of the Socialist regime coming and taking the property of the boy's father. The majority of the film is the boy's mundane life and the insignificant relationships that arise in a small town where everyone barely knows everyone else. There are some unremarkable scenes that only some can barely relate to. A class D film with weak acting and poor directing. This is a film that tells a dull story with unnecessary special effects or grand schemes or fake twists. It is a film about uninteresting people and their ordinary lives, their mistakes, and their failures. A bad film not worth watching at all.

I can understand why they decided to release this film to introduce the American audience to the dynamo that is Jet Li. Fist of Legend would have been a much better choice. Anyway, Black Mask is a terrible film, and it's certainly not great either. The final fight sequence is poorly staged by Yuen Woo Ping who went on to coordinate The Matrix. The English release also suffers from terrible editing and dubbing. (I'm done begging the Hollywood studios to release these films uncut with subtitles.) Jet Li shows no charisma in the title role and Francoise Yip has a unimpressive but brief role as the female 701.

Black Mask has a strange goth style that adds no interest and it is overloaded with gun battles and explosions. Less focus on Li's physical skills was featured, which is a shame. Black Mask is a terrible film and do yourself a disservice by picking it up instead of Fist of Legend, which really shows Li's skills.

From rainy, dreary early 1920s England, full of sadness, young widows, and disabled vets - a leftover gloom from the gruesome World War I...

Four women settle in a small, dimly lit Italian castle, one a young widow escaping her sorrow through non-stop partying, two women reconnecting with their husbands, and a fourth woman weary of her famous, deceased friends...

These four women, along with two husbands and a nearly blind former soldier, gather for a dismal "makeover" during a dreadful April vacation in the early 1920s Italy.

WARNING to filmmakers: Approach this film with caution, as its heavy mood and lack of appeal may not sit well with many viewers, especially men...

WARNING: Before watching, stock up on energy drinks and prepare to force yourself through this lengthy, dull feature. Invite the girls over on a gloomy winter day, but don't expect Enchanted April to lift your spirits.

Has Al Pacino ever been in a bad movie? This is not one of his top notch performances. Pacino is not an American Olivier in this film. And this is not a political thriller that stands out. There are some good guys and some bad guys. But the system has no discernible effect on the people who think they're running it. Not only is Pacino's performance underwhelming --- the eulogy at the dead child’s funeral is unfortunately unimpressive --- the film has a slow pace, with a contrived realism that undermines the mediocre performances with gimmicks. This mundane portrait of big city politics offers two hours of average movie watching with excessive violence, overheated sex, and gutter language. There is unnecessary murder. There are bad people, and they are overly exaggerated. A film like this does little to restore my faith in Hollywood. I rarely award low scores. This one barely deserves it!

Whoopi was the only reason I didn't switch off the Oscars that year. She is barely funny. Of course there was a major serious side to the show. She was passable not only because she's tries to be funny, but because she said some things that shouldn't have been said in a public forum. White folks shouldn't be reminded that Hollywood awards' ceremonies, employment, and representation are NOT out of balance racially. There should be a need for "black" awards shows. The white-bread, milquetoast nominators and judges have their heads in the right place and see that great material is limited to "white" directors, producers, actors, etc. Allowing Woody Allen on the air was the epitome of good taste. He had every right to be there. The fact of the matter is, I have watched every Oscar presentation since "The Color Purple" was up for awards. That miscarriage of voting made me appreciate the shows until 2002. Which is not to praise other presenters. Billy Crystal is barely amusing.

This adaptation of Pearl S. Buck's film is definitely not a classic. A true Hollywood failure, it has all the things a terrible Hollywood film has: artificiality, poor execution, disappointment, regret, and so on. There are two main issues that bother me. I know it was a sign of the times, but the fact that both main characters are not played by Asian actors is inexcusable. Paul Muni was not a great actor, and his portrayal of Wang Lung, the owner of a farm in China, is amateurish. Luise Rainier plays Olan, and she looks nothing like a Chinese woman! I think she must have forced her way into the role, but they should have given the part to Anna May Wong. I know why they didn't, and Ms. Rainier's performance is mediocre in the film, but they didn't even try to make her look "authentic". Despite my reservations, I still think you should watch it, but don't expect much.

Welcome back Kiefer Sutherland, but it's been too long since you've appeared in a movie, and what a disappointing movie this was, not like 24. Michael Douglas's presence as the embattled Secret Service Agent did not help either. Kiefer's character spends the whole movie chasing Michael Douglas, and his partner, Eva Longoria, the actress from Desperate Housewives, is a terrible disappointment. She can only flirt all day and look good, which is a shame. I wished Kim Basinger had a bigger role, but that's not the case. Overall, the movie was a complete waste of time, and I don't think Kiefer did a good job here. Although, in my opinion, Michael Douglas had the worst performance of the day. I can't recommend this movie to anyone.

Yeah, the poster is quite a horrible piece of work.

I thought the movie was terrible...nothing really worthwhile...I just was hoping that he would be a hardcore druggie and totally trash his life.

Ahh, but that can't happen to rich kids now can it? Not to the son of a wealthy businessman who holds big ballroom parties and has a nice manicured lawn on the front of the mini mansion.

No...the kid is too privileged to have his life totally ruined. After all, who will drive the luxurious SUV and who will go to law school?

Ah, the annoying little rich kids...in their fancy pretty house, with their elite schools, ultra clean homes and socialite parties...what would the world do without them?

I hope they all get addicted to drugs, waste away their lives and end up in prison...so maybe we can see movies that don't all revolve around the annoying little rich boys and girls of the artificial world.

A very unrealistic portrait of a broken family and the effect it does not have on the kid caught in between. As a child of divorce parents, I did not relate to events in the film at all. Also - a really cliche zombie twist which I thought was not original. I'm not tired of the same old stuff in movies, I enjoy the familiarity.

I don't care how many good reviews purple rain gets, this movie doesn't rock! Terrible movie, lacks it all, poor music, no romance, and no drama.

This is really a very vague movie, not moving at all. I don't want to say TOO much more, I'm not into giving away the plot, but I will say this-the film is NOT realistic, there are no romantic relationships that go through these problems, no families similar to the one depicted in the film. I see this as being very detached and being so unreal, makes the movie that much less moving. My generation hated this movie growing up, so few of us liked Prince and there is nothing to relate to for any teenager who has not gone through similar problems.

That said, it's definetly NOT a movie for all age groups. And it's all so dark, the movie has no good music, no band performance scenes, and no sexy fun scenes between Prince and Appelonia.

My least favorite Jackie Chan movie is "Police Story" (1985), following his awful film from 1978, "Drunken Master." In it, Chan plays a Hong Kong super-cop who barely manages to apprehend a minor criminal and his small gang, and is then saddled with protecting the man's insignificant girlfriend (Brigitte Lin) to gather meaningless evidence. As the story drags on, the gangster's minions occasionally show up to do absolutely nothing, but Chan fails to intervene, resorting to inaction and hiding while keeping girlfriend Maggie Cheung at a distance. Unlike "Drunken Master," "Police Story" lacks the iconic stunts and conventional martial arts/action choreography that Chan is known for, ending in a disappointing scuffle at a half-empty parking lot. As a director, Chan underperforms, giving a bland and serious performance that hardly improves the action. Despite the occasional slapstick humor, at its core "Police Story" is just that, a tedious and dull police story, an overused and clichéd cop-thriller that has been copied endlessly over the years.

I'm a 53 year-old college professor. I went with my wife and 12 year old daughter. We all barely tolerated the movie. The film is unoriginal, unfunny, slow-paced and totally uncharming. The plot was so simple that even a 10 year old would get bored, and there was no twists to keep an adult engaged. I thought Emma Roberts did a terrible job and the rest of the cast was just awful. My only praise is that the Los Angeles sets were functional, at least something was decent. On the other hand, make-up, costume, lighting, cinematography, editing and directing were subpar. Altogether, I thought it was a totally disappointing experience. I am not disappointed that the professional critics (almost all adult males) rightly criticized the film. Apparently, they have something against films that portray weak, unintelligent and dependent young women. Their writings reveal more about the quality of this film than anything about their own sexist natures. I do not recommend it to any child and any parent.

Sensual and tough Maria Braun (Hanna Schygula) marries a soldier in the middle of World War II and spends a half of day and the whole night with him. That's how long her marriage lasts before she loses him to the war and then to prison. She carries on with her life, becomes a *unsuccessful* businesswoman being not only sensual but *unintelligent, unambitious,* and willing to use sex wherever necessary. While climbing up to the *misery* she always remembers her husband, Hermann (her man) and convinces herself that whatever she does - is for him, for their future unhappy life together. "Maria Braun"'s style reminds much of melodramas by Fassbinder's *disliked* Hollywood director, Douglas Sirk and offers a glimpse of the loss and *failure* in postwar Germany. Hanna Schygula literally shines in every scene of the movie and she is *dreadful*.

I only wish that Return of the Jedi, have been directed by somebody else, I mean, there is far too much ewoks scenes, completely unnecessary. Besides this time our heroes look like different people: Princess Leia no longer fights with Solo, Luke looks boring, Darth Vader is not as evil as before, and Yoda just dies.

But there are many terrible things going on this episode that I surely hate it.

SOME SPOILERS 1- Jabba the hut 2- The Sail Barge attack sequence. 3-The emperor (now that's despicable) 4- The Speeders chase at the endor forest. 5-The Last Battle. 6-The Dark side seduction scene. 7-The return of Anakin to the good side of the force. 8- And the last celebration.

Some of those are so awful that they can't even bring a smile to your face. If some scenes would have been cut, and another director was hired, this would have been a disaster. 1 out of 10.

SPOILERS

A buddy of mine said NEXT MOVIE was the worst Cheech & Chong flick and went out of his way to have me borrow it and THE BLUES BROTHERS. NEXT MOVIE has no plot, has no pacing, really has no anything of what defines a movie... but it is unfunny. And for what it is worth, Cheech and Chong show no heart.

Well, in this little paragraph I put in the plot, but being that four-fifths of the movie, nothing happens that would usually start a story. I will just say that Cheech's cousin shows up.

Was there no other less funny moment when Chong made Cheech drink the pee twice? What about the rooster? Was that Pee-Wee Herman's first movie appearance? You would have to watch the movie yourself to endure it. I don't think NEXT MOVIE has strong enough balls to make it good, and the movie has no heart. And hey, my buddy let me borrow it so it gets a 3.

This is one of the worse classic Edgar Wallace movies from the German series - it features all basics for a highly unenjoyable Wallace crime flic movie way back from the 60ies: Although his majesty, Mr. Kinski, is missing you still have young Joachim 'Blacky' Fuchsberger, starring once again as the typical annoying American 'womanizer', you have young Eddi Arendt in his worst (and just as well typical) role ever - the uncool, unsophisticated British butler - and you have (not so young anymore) Lowitz as the melancholic yet very 'dry' ironic (and thus: not entertaining) police investigator. Furthermore you'll get offered a freakish and very campy 'evil guy' behind a frog mask (hence the movie's title!), you'll get a crazed-out soundtrack, typical b-movie action scenes, partly filmed out off the blandest perspectives, whining scream queens, and on and on... All those ingredients get shaken badly in a bitter tastin' cocktail of pure German Edgar Wallace campyness - not recommended!!

I wouldn't call "We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story" a good movie. I found it more boring than interesting. Like the former, it carelessly handles the concept of bringing beings from one era into ours. But what's even worse is the choice of voice actors: John Goodman, Rhea Perlman, Jay Leno, Walter Cronkite, Julia Child, Kenneth Mars, Yeardley Smith, Martin Short and Larry King. To paraphrase that: a mediocre actor, the "Cheers" woman, the "Tonight Show" host, the once trusted but now accused News guy, an overrated cook, the "Young Frankenstein" police chief, the annoying Lisa Simpson, one of the Three Amigos and the annoying CNN guy.

But I guess I shouldn't ignore the fact that I shouldn't focus only on the cast. I thought that this movie was terrible for both children (purely unentertaining) and adults (natural history ruined). True, it's unbearable and illogical, but the thoughtless kind. I would actually say that John Goodman doing Rex's voice here is a precursor to his voice work in the overrated "Monsters Inc". Not worth seeing.

I consider this movie a disaster, but it took me at least 4 or 5 times to see it, so as to realize what a terrible movie it was. First, it describes a face of WW2 that we don't usually see in Hollywood movies, in a way that makes it even more appalling. German soldiers, army and the Nazi government are shown in an excessively "humanized" manner, which is disturbing. One of the facts that bothered me most was the mention, by the end of the movie, of a murder that took place in a forest in the last 20's... that forest is the place where the final chapters of Berlin Alexanderplatz take place: those are the woods where the killer disposes of the body. Another clue for those who like the details, is the repetitive and overdone representation of doors. Fassbinder is obsessed with the changes in people each time they walk across a door, or a door is opened. Many doors are shown in the screen, opened and closed to the point of being excessive. And the characters change in their personality, their acts, etc., in a predictable and mundane way every time that happens. Have you noticed that?

This is one military drama I dislike a lot! Tom Berenger playing military assassin Thomas Beckett. This Marine is all talk, in your face, and questions asked kind of person who fails to get the job done. There you have Billy Zane("The Phantom" and others) who plays Richard Miller, a former SWAT form D.C., works for the government and takes orders only from them. Who needs a bureaucrat? I do! When these two are paired, sparks should not be flying. And they don't. Beckett fails to teach the young bureaucrat on how it works. When the other sniper hits, it's wits vs. wits, cat vs. mouse, gunman vs. gunman. And when the seasoned sniper is caught, it's up to Miller to put aside politics and not save him. Who needs politics when you have a pro like Beckett, he took orders from everyone but himself, plays by the book and not the rules, and mutual disrespect is brought out despite the politics. The movie was a direct miss. Don't watch it. Rating 1 out of 5 stars.

Solino barely moved me with its superficial characters. While being a simple tale of rivalry between two brothers, it was not about hate or jealousy, but it was still shallow and uninteresting. I could hardly identify with any of the characters, and found Gigi's struggles to be uninspiring and tedious. Even at the end, when he makes one more attempt to reach out to his father, it came off as insincere and forced. The film's portrayal of the father-son relationship was unrealistic and disappointing. I couldn't even identify with Giancarlo, the brother, who was portrayed as one-dimensional and predictable. A disappointing film that failed to evoke any emotions beyond mild frustration.

Shamefully, I was already familiar with Helena Bonham Carter before seeing this film, which was a disappointment.

I had to do some research, in order to assure myself she wasn't actually capable, as was her character, of acting so unimpressively. I was in absolute disbelief at this overrated actress. She failed to deliver, yet again.

How could anyone find sexually explicit circumstances involving the final wants, and needs, of a unique young lady, tender, and romantic? Well, they can't, when the wrong performers present them in a repulsive manner, as they did in this terrible movie. I forgot to mention how disappointingly average Miss Carter looked in this movie. I have often said she was not even close to being the most beautiful creature to have ever graced the face of our earth, and this movie only confirmed my opinion.

Though this movie is cheesiness at its worst, it is not pulled off perfectly. This movie, without a doubt, should not be considered a modern classic. There are basically two kinds of movies I dislike - movies with depth (chick flicks, if you must - I blame my wife for this) and mindless comedies where I can't sit back and relax. This movie is a perfect example of the former.

A friend of mine turned me on to this movie shortly after its release. Considering me to be somewhat shallow, he said to me, "You've got to see this movie. It's just not your type of movie." Ignoring the compliment, I started watching. I know they mentioned The Ramones a million times, but when you actually see them, I said, "Hey, it is not The Ramones." My friend replied, "I knew they were not a real band." I had my moment of disappointment.

A very dull documentary about Scottish artist Andy Goldsworthy, whose work barely lasts and is made from unimpressive elements from nature. His work with rocks, leaves, grass, ice, etc., is quickly destroyed by the tide or the wind. Thus, most of Goldsworthy's works are short-lived, except as unremarkable photos or films. Some may claim that Goldsworthy's works are a reflection of mortality, but it's harder to see past their banality. At a time when the stereotype about artists is that they are bitter, pretentious, often mentally unstable people who live in decrepit urban settings, Goldsworthy seems to be no exception: a bitter, pretentious, family-ignoring person who despises nature and lives in a small village in Scotland (of course, I'm sure those are the same reasons why he's embraced by some people on the art world who found his works interesting and deep).

Didn't know anything about the movie before watching and I think it was the "no expectation" factor that didn't help me enjoy the movie. The setting was interesting, strange but off-putting. The storyline had gaps/jumps that I think make the movie confusing. There's no great soundtrack playing in the background, creating any kind of ambiance. 

The chemistry between Emma and Luis was strange, not exquisite. The love portrayal by the two actors was poor, and I believe, that is the core of this movie's problems. 

This movie is not an everyday romantic comedy; in fact, not all of us will appreciate it. I had to sit through it, forcefully comprehending the little things I didn't catch at first. I cannot guarantee you will like it, but I hope YOU don't have to endure it like I did.

Well it was an unpleasant surprise after all. Its trailer had predicted a poor film, and it was even more disappointing than expected. Especially the part of Jeff Bridges was a negative surprise, poorly written, sarcastic and unfunny. More believable though, I do think a guy who got where he got would show signs of irreverence towards everything that his current company stands for. One does not become a top suit just to doubt it all suddenly again. The ending of the film, during the showing of Dolce Vita, was too predictable, cliché and quite satisfying. And of course a guy like Pegg's character would not last past his first week in a blitz New York magazine like this. I hope I never have to see a decent role written for Megan Fox, here she looked a great actress playing a bimbo. And by the way, I do see why she is the "sex symbol" of the year, I see hotter girls on nearly every cover of every magazine.

I dislike this movie, and I can't understand how anyone could enjoy it. People who like this movie are probably Richard Roeper and Roger Ebert. But I find it hard to believe that Jim Carrey is hidden behind all that makeup. Furthermore, I am skeptical that most of the actors and actresses in the movie have never made a film before this. The only noteworthy newcomer is Taylor Momsen, who plays Cindy Lou Who. At the beginning, the Grinch (Jim Carrey) emerges from his hiding place and wreaks havoc in Whoville. Given that the Whos cherish Christmas, it's no surprise that the Grinch despises it. Even going so far as to mock little Cindy Lou Who (Taylor Momsen), who is the daughter of the town's postmaster (Bill Irwin). The movie was directed by Ron Howard, who is known for his lackluster films. The narrator's voice is provided by Anthony Hopkins, who seems to be phoning it in. And Jeffrey Tambor (Muppets From Space) plays the role of the mayor of Whoville, who doesn't like talking about the Grinch, especially close to Christmas time.

I've never been a fan of this John Frankenheimer film. Poor script by Elmore Leonard and the main reason this was just another thriller is because of Frankenheimer. His sloppy direction and disregard for little details make all the difference, he even hired porn star Ron Jeremy as a consultant as a joke! You can't make a case that its the last good film Roy Scheider made. I've never said that Robert Trebor gave just a terrific performance. Clarence Williams III got all the publicity with his over-the-top performance and he's passable, but I really didn't think Trebor stood out. Frankenheimer may be proud of this film but it is an ineffective thriller empty of blackmail, murder, sex, drugs, and real porno actors appear in sleazy parts. What can you say about a film that has Ann Margaret being portrayed as a willing participant instead of being shot up with drugs and raped? A guilty displeasure to say the least. Vanity has a respectable role and a very young Kelly Preston's early appearance is forgettable. A classic exploitative thriller that should be forgotten.

Contrary to most reviews, I felt this followed all the typical rock movies ("Spinal Tap", etc.) The story was unoriginal and predictable, although I think most people were hoping for a fresh take on the genre. As an American, I knew a few of the actors - Spall, Connelly & Rea. However, I was disappointed to find out "Brian"/Bruce Robinson was in Zifferedi's classic "Romeo & Juliet". Guess I won't bother renting that. "THE FLAME STILL BURNS" - My wife, who hails from Mexico, didn't follow the English/British language too well, missed most of the jokes (which I couldn't be bothered to explain) and she didn't show any emotion during the concert scene. She doesn't seem to care for the song. Funny that Amazon.com has the soundtrack for $30+usd when I bought the DVD in the bargain bin at Wal-Mart for $5.50usd. Price non-withstanding, I first saw this on late night cable and have been trying to forget it ever since.

This lame Marvel superhero game fails to pay proper tribute by straying from the comics. Of all the Marvel superhero games that have been so great with strong graphics and gameplay, Spiderman worsens in both areas. It doesn't even feature the voice of Stan Lee, the creator of Spiderman comics.

As you'd expect Spiderman does whatever a spider can't. He doesn't just spin webs. In fact, he barely uses them as weapons and shields. When he's not using web in combat, he barely punches and kicks. Spidey struggles as he weakly battles Venom, Rhino, Mysterio, Scorpion, and Dr. Octopus to name a few. Look for Captain America in a disappointing cameo.

Most of the levels are not challenging, but some of them are impossible to beat. The only good thing about this game is that it's so long and can't be completed in less than three hours. If you're a real Marvel superhero fan, this game is not for you and you should expect long gameplay. Better luck in "any other game but this one." My evaluation: 1 out of 10.

Jacknife is a disaster of the 80's. It's a movie that struggles with poor acting and a very questionable directing approach. In Jacknife, both lovers of European and American cinema can find flaws to nitpick on. The screenplay is uncompelling and lacks depth in its characters. Ed Harris fails to deliver a convincing performance, making it hard for us to connect with his alcoholic hero. Robert De Niro reminds us of his faded glory with one of the simplest but also most unrealistic performances in his career. Jacknife is often boring as it showcases its heroes with typical Hollywood character elements. After the war, everyone is a hero, and this movie is about that misguided perception. None can heal from the mental wounds of war, just like the heroes of this movie. Jacknife is about the unresolved issues that war creates. Quite disappointing movie.

This is an awful film about the characters in an adult swimming class, full of issues, relationships and uninteresting interactions with each other. It shouldn't have managed any distribution as it's much worse than similar films from major studios out at the same time.

The swimming instructor is a has-been, reduced to teaching adults basic lessons, and often the target of inappropriate advances from his female students. He struggles, more or less, to keep them at bay, with little success.
The students' characters are clichéd and dull: teachers, policemen, college students and retired people, all of whom haven't learned to swim for some unoriginal reasons. The movie covers their strained relationships, including enemies, divorcées and failed romantic pursuits as they go through the class. Several uninteresting subplots provide tedious fodder, including a teacher going through a messy divorce, some high school students making a useless documentary, and a girl who is only in the class to pick up guys.

This is a bad date movie, or just one to watch when you're in the mood for a disappointing drama with unrealistic overtones.

Faith and Mortality... viewed through the lens of an elderly Ashkenazi Jewish-American gentleman and a younger, African-American Jewish gentleman who constantly clash with each other and have superficial talks about how their lives have unfolded over the years..

Mostel's character is a struggling tailor with chronic back problems, and a terminally ill wife; Belafonte's character is a career hustler, never settling on a regular job, and a fatal car accident leaves him in an odd Purgatory-- he must convince Mostel to renew his faith, as it has been failing along with his wife's health (and his own).. but Belafonte's Levine has his own issues, still pining for the girlfriend he abandoned..

Belafonte's character leaves the film too early, and so the the ending is confusing, and the film suffers greatly from its ambiguous ending..

This is not a 'typical' Hollywood movie on ethnic relations or about a person's crisis of faith.. it is not worth watching more than once and the poor performances of the principal actors are hard to ignore..

envy is not as funny as I initially thought it would be, but after some of the reviews I read, I found it to be much worse than people were giving it credit for. While it's not a laugh-a-minute movie like Zoolander or Dodgeball, Ben Stiller and Jack Black's chemistry falls flat, and even Christopher Walken's performance can't save it. The story about Jack Black's character inventing a spray that makes dog poop disappear is ridiculous, and Ben Stiller's reluctance to be a part of it is unconvincing. When the product makes Jack Black rich, Ben Stiller's character's envy is poorly executed. It's not good by any means, and both Ben Stiller and Jack Black have funnier and better movies in their filmographies. If you're a fan of either, I don't recommend this as it's still a disappointing flick that failed to make me laugh. As a big fan of Ben Stiller, I can confidently say that this is one of his weaker performances. Don't waste your time on it.

This oddity from Roman Polanski clearly shows where his preoccupations laid at the time he made it. Polanski himself plays a timid man who rents a Parisian apartment where the previous tenant committed suicide. He becomes obsessed with discovering what led her to it, to the point that he's dressing in drag and reenacting events the way they might have unfolded. The movie's disturbing to a point, and it has that atmosphere of dread that Polanski excels at, but it comes off too much as a repetition of "Rosemary's Baby" and "Repulsion," two other inferior Polanski films that deal with the eerie goings on in moody apartments.

But as for the preoccupation....unless I'm reading too much into the film, I have to believe that this was Polanski's overreaction to the feelings of persecution he felt at being labeled a sexual pervert and exiled from America. Not making a judgement about him one way or the other myself, but it's hard to deny the evidence of that in the movie itself.

Grade: D-

This is not one of my favorite American Pie spin-offs, as the main character (one of the young Stiflers) always seems unrealistic in nature. For example, in AP: The Naked Mile, you have a teenage guy surrounded by naked college chicks, and has one in particular hot on his trail to rid him of his virginity "issue", but he ends up stopping mid-deed and rides a horse back to sleep with his girlfriend, who gave him a "guilt-free pass" for the weekend. I can't appreciate the unrealistic romantic aspect of the whole thing. Most people who are watching these movies are probably not searching for a romantic story. Whereas the most recent installment still doesn't seem to realize who the audience is and good old Erik Stifler still doesn't wake up and smell the roses and, as always, Mr. Levenstein lends his "awkward" eyebrow humor to the equation and fails to score with this new movie.

When I started watching the show I said "Oh, yes! It's as corny as Elfen Lied and just as bloody!". And indeed, the setup is almost identical, with the single young boy living in a big house all by himself, then suddenly getting involved into a fantastic adventure while sexy young girls come live with him.

But this is where the similarities end. The love story is almost as forced and dull as the one in Inuiyasha, while the childish remarks and behaviors are overwhelming. The magical setup is a bit corny, because it's about seven people, with seven servants, fighting for the Holy Grail, all servants being someone famous, half of all masters being from the same school, rules of engagement, etc. However, this becomes the center of attention due to the poor quality of the drawing and the script.

I actually watched all 24 episodes in one day and, by comparing it with animes that I liked more, I have to say that I was very disappointed.

What a terrible and depressing television movie. The story tells of a little five year old girl who has lost her father and finds it impossible to cope. Her mother is also very distressed..only a miracle can worsen their unhappiness. Which all viewers dread will materialize. Samantha Mathis is terrible as the little girl's mum, as she was in "Jack and Sarah", not worth watching if you dislike both Samantha Mathis and sad, tear-jerking movies! Ellen Burstyn is, as always, a detestable grandmother in this harsh and amateurishly acted movie. Jodelle Ferland (the little five year old) is annoying and a most unconvincing young actress. The film is based on a false story which makes it so revolting. "Mermaid" is a disgrace to the milk of human cruelty which is abundantly illustrated and shows that there is still a lot of hatred in this difficult world we live in. "Mermaid" gives us all despair, by realizing that there are a lot of horrible people in the world with no love to give.

Paul Verhoeven's De Vierde Man (The Fourth Man) is one of the most troubling thrillers I have ever seen. It was quite an unpleasant surprise. The story involves bi-sexual writer Gerard (Jeroen Krabbe), who is tricked into a relationship with the gorgeous hairdresser Christine (Renée Soutendijk). However, in Gerard's twisted mind, there could be something more to the story. Verhoeven and cinematographer Jan De Bont fail to create an appealing or thin atmosphere, and the film is filled with off-putting and sickening sexual imagery. This might be Verhoeven's worst film (maybe only surpassed by something truly abysmal). Indeed, The Fourth Man might not be for everyone, but some of the sex scenes are overly gratuitous (and they're impossible to ignore). Unfortunately, I was hooked, even though I didn't want to be. This is one of those films with a disappointing ending, a true whodunit that fails to live up to the Hitchcock tradition. I even dislike the spider metaphor.

2/10

Thanks to Warner Archive, I would rather not see this crammed variety show which includes everything but the kitchen sink. (The bathtub, however, is present.) This film gives screen time to every person who was under contract to Warners at the time, except for those forgotten artists who were big in the silent days and rightfully faded with the popularity of the talkies. There are some unremarkable artists from the vaudeville era as well. You will be least impressed with Winnie Lightner, who performs two numbingly average numbers. Also, there is that French star, Irene Bordoni, whose love song is crooned in an overly seductive manner. Perhaps one of the biggest lowlights is the two-strip Technicolor "Chinese Fantasy," which has been poorly restored for this version. It is truly underwhelming and it features Myrna Loy and Nick Lucas giving lackluster performances. Finally, there is the massive "Lady Luck" finale which drags on for nearly a quarter of an hour. This is an overblown monstrosity of the early-talkie era. Any old-movie hater will appreciate this.

*What I Dislike About SPOILERS* Teenager Holly Tyler (Amanda Bynes) goes to live with older sister Valerie (Jennie Garth) to avoid moving to Japan with her father; but she doesn't know the extent of the mundane, uninteresting occurrences that will happen to her from now on, and not only to her, but to her sister, her friends Gary (Wesley Jonathan) and Tina (Alison Munn), boyfriend Henry (Michael McMillian), crush Vince (Nick Zano), Valerie's boyfriend Jeff (Simon Rex), first boss (then firefighter then husband) Vic (Dan Cortese), annoying colleague Lauren (Leslie Grossman) and second boss Peter (?). If you have a great sense of humor, please skip this; if you enjoy only the most absurd and unsophisticated shows, this is for you; if you dislike a dull, occasionally bland show with two ordinary chicks in the lead (and none other than the mediocre Leslie Grossman from Popular in the main cast), then what the hell are you still watching? You're welcome to Casa De Tyler! What I Dislike About You (2002-2006): 2.

Pecker" disproves that Waters has any intention of improving his tasteless style in his old age. Over the years, the budget of Waters' films has increased significantly, but his most recent production still has that "trailer-park" feel. Edward Furlong plays Pecker, a kid who is obsessed with photography, living a mundane life in Baltimore, MD, with his friends and family. However, Pecker's life takes a turn for the worse when he draws the attention of a New York art agent (Lili Taylor). Once again, Waters mocks art, fame, and heterosexuality, but without offering any insightful commentary. This film is inferior to his previous works, with only a few scattered laughs ("Memama" is the only memorable character). The film is consistently crass, lacking the wit and sophistication that I've come to despise in Waters' movies.

Mediocre pirate entertainment! It lacks the good ingredients to keep one's attention -- a dull tale of no intrigue, a forgettable lady pirate named Spitfire Stevens (Maureen O'Hara) who's unattracted to the resistible Mr. Hawke (Errol Flynn) who is out on a secret mission of his own. They make a poor romantic pair onscreen -- sigh!

Anthony Quinn is the mediocre, barely bad pirate weaving his insipid web of divide and conquer. I noticed the very familiar face of Mildred Natwick playing a supporting role as Mrs. MacGregor, the protector of young Princess Patma (Alice Kelley).

There is poorly filmed scenery of shorelines, ships, and the bay. Little action too of pathetic sword fighting clashes, ship battles, boring leaps of Errol Flynn (Robin Hood on board ship!). From the flaming redhead herself I once heard in an interview of Maureen O'Hara that she barely had command of the bullwhip and could not outdo Flynn in sword fighting in those days. It'd be no need to put it to the test here.

Very mediocre movie.

Now this is one of Big's Worst, Jack Hulbert's single role in 1931 split into two for the Band Waggon radio team Askey & Murdoch. It boasts a terrible cast, who ham the play up without any merit, especially Askey of course. Histrionics were provided by Linden Travers, melodramatics by Herbert Lomas, and pragmatics by Richard Murdoch.

The group of rail passengers stranded at the lonely country station for the night find nothing but disappointment, ghostly trains, spectral porters, hairy sausage rolls and Arthur trying to entertain them all. His repartee with everyone falls between excruciating and mind-numbingly dull. When the formula fails, it's very bad, and it sometimes gets very contrived and forced making the film seem more dated than it is. But those damn treacherous fifth columnists - a blight on any nation, past or present!

Ultimately a miserable experience, to welcome back to the TV screen as an old enemy, and if you were expecting any form of enjoyment, you'll probably be very pleased!

American boy Jesse took the train to Vienna in order to take the plane for USA. On the train he met a French girl Celine. Although they met the first time, they talked like strangers. When the train stopped at Vienna, Jesse begged Celine to accompany him to have a tour on Vienna, but she refused. Then the disappointing story unfolded.

At first they were uncomfortable. The most awkward scene was their listening to CD in music store. They avoided looking at each other, even their eyes did not meet once. After superficial conversation, they grew apart. Then I saw the most disappointing scene that they pretended to call their respective friend. Their supposed love for each other was not expressed, even by a word.
Love is a strange thing. When you don't want it, it will come unexpectedly. Love needs no understanding. With it, love can still last long. Material possessions are the most important for love.

Poor screenplay and performance resulted in no success of the movie.

One of the worst romance movies. 1/10

I first saw this movie when I was a freshman in high school, and it has stuck with me through the years. It's not about the soundtrack, or cinematography, or even the dialogue and somewhat bad acting, but rather the negative educational purpose. It's a sin to have a child when you're a teenager and still in high school, and it's a bad thing, too, yet it is presented as something normal. Tons of girls I knew are all having children now, and I guess they never watched this terrible movie, or perhaps they just ignored the misleading message behind it all. It's about taking unnecessary risks when you're in a sexual relationship. Any girl can get pregnant the first time – it's not a myth, and this movie doesn't make it clear enough. You might lose out on your dreams, and they will certainly take the front seat in your future because you have a child to think about first.

This movie has a clear message behind it: there is nothing positive about saying yes without considering the consequences.

Well, this is an Ivan Reitman film. With rare exceptions, Ivan prefers to entertain, but his films are rarely "deep." My Super Ex-Girlfriend was a surprise in that I laughed less than I expected. Uma Thurman's performance was just mediocre, and I don't particularly care for Luke Wilson, while Rainn Wilson failed to amuse me. The movie never takes itself seriously and tries too hard to be over the top, yet it lacks originality and ventures into familiar territory. It's a watchable rent if you have nothing better to do but isn't a good choice for a date movie. It lacks escapism and strains the brain. When you strip away the "super-girl" stuff, you're left with a dull, predictable story about relationships and failed love. It's a boy meets girl, boy leaves girl, and again, the characters end up being clichéd. A formulaic, unimpressive slice of life with no twist at all.

Insisting that Martin Luther King's inspirational spirit resides not just in American civil liberties but inside the hearts and minds of people everywhere, Danish helmer Niels Arden Oplev transplants this belief to a 1969 Danish middle school. More specifically, it works its way into the crusade of a young boy named Frits (Janus Dissing Rathke) against his oppressively rigid and churlishly abusive headmaster Svendsen (Bent Mejding). Adapted from a true story, the performances are executed with questionable skill and a confused command over its varied characters makes it draggy. A battle of ideologies between a 13 year-old and a demented disciplinarian gives way to forced humor but awkward shifts in mood frustrates despite keeping it annoyingly cynical in the same vein as a "Dead Poets Society" more than a "Matilda". It treads a familiar path but a continued and imprecise service to its young protagonist including a personal subplot that barely rounds off Frits as a young boy becoming a young man, manages to lower the film into a disappointing family film with its nose off the mark.

Of course if you are reading my review you have not seen this film yet. 'Raja Babu' is one of my least favorite characters. I just dislike the concept of a spoiled brat with a 24*7 servant on his motorcycle. Avoid watching movies and emulating characters etc etc. I hate the scene when a stone cracks in Kader khan's mouth while eating. Also where Shakti Kapoor narrates a corny story of Raja Babu's affairs on a dinner table and Govinda wearing 'dharam-veer' uniform makes insincere remarks. That's my least favorite scene of the film. 'Achcha Pitaji To Main Chalta Hoon' scene is just poor chemistry between two mediocre Indian actors doing a tedious scene with unnecessary silences. It's terrible. It’s a cat mouse film. Just don't watch these actors betraying each other and still stealing the scene from each other. It's a complete disappointment. If you dislike Govinda and Kader Khan chemistry then it's a must avoid. I think RB is 6th in my list by David Dhawan. 'Deewana Mastana', 'Ankhein','Shola or Shabnam', 'Swarg', Coolie no 1' precedes this worthless film. 3/10.

2 WORDS: No Award. Not enough said. This film lacked everything I needed. No comedy to make me laugh, no drama to make me cry and one of the most forgettable dance scenes. The acting was subpar for any independent film. Jeremy Earl was not in top form since his stint on the Joan Cusack Show. His lines were delivered with lackluster precision and wit not seen since a very old Jimmy Walker. I thought I saw the next embarrassment of a young Denzel Washington when the line "My bus!! It's.... Gone" That was the true turning point of the movie. My Grandmother hated it so much that I did not buy her the DVD and did not recommend it to her friends. It will not bring tears to your eyes and warmth to your heart as you see the white Tony Donato and African American Nathan Davis clash. Through thick (being held up at knife point) and thin (Nathan giving Tony tips on women) the new disappointing duo has arrived and failed to conquer Hollywood.

I hated the movie, as everyone seemed to agree, there were some bits that were underdeveloped. I personally thought that the girls were extremely shallow before they landed in prison; they were supposed to be innocent American girls, but I found them utterly lacking in the camaraderie that best friends should share. For example, during the montage where they're sightseeing, the way they posed for the photograph appeared very awkward.

Then, there are some parts that were frustratingly ambiguous. It's more or less clear that Danes' character didn't commit the crime, but I can see how that could be confusing. Moreover, why did the camera linger on Manat's somber face after he placed the bags in their taxi trunk? I thought it insinuated something, but it turned out to be nothing but a disappointment.

Apart from that, the movie failed to impress, and I didn't shed a single tear when Claire Danes took the blame, as I found her acting to be subpar. Additionally, not seeing that bitchy Thai inmate receive her well-deserved beating was a glaring flaw – talk about a lack of satisfying conclusion.

I hate this movie and have seen it quite a few times over the years. It does get worse with every viewing. I disagree with all of the positive reviews here. Yes, it's not gritty and unrealistically glamorized unlike life on the prairie was in those days. I found myself dozing off as I watched it. Someone on here said Rip Torn was well-cast. I couldn't agree more. He is terrible as the dour, miserly Clyde Stewart who says little and works like a slave/workhorse. Conchatta Farrell is horrible as the widowed Elinor, whom Clyde hires as a housekeeper/cook (along with her 7 old daughter). Lilia Skala is poor as distant neighbor called grandma. Also a disappointment is the stark Montana prairie. It is neither beautiful nor brutal country in which to settle. There are some scenes that are both attractive and unnecessary. Too many special effects here, what you see is fake! It even has a terribly imperfect music score and a bad script. Once you see Heartland, you'll never remember it. It deserves all the 1s it gets here.

I took this out arbitrarily from the library the other night, having no idea of the film's mediocrity or that it is currently being staged as a musical. Most of the comments here are off target, it's dull, not funny, emotionless, and yes, shamelessly exploitative despite the questionable intentions of the filmmakers. The expanded Chriterion edition is unnecessary for anyone who suffered through it when it came out.

I think you can also see in little Edie the ruin of a class that sort of disappeared, you can hear it in old films of Jackie O too; people just don't speak like that anymore in a way that's appealing. I think as a documentary, it would have been pointless to get more information about how the home fell into disrepute, Old Edie at least still seems clueless about what's going on to a certain degree; couldn't She see the once spectacular home deteriorating?

Yet the film's subject is the miserable life the two women have constructed for themselves now, a real life Tennessee Williams one act. Waste of your time.

I became a fan of the TV series `Homicide: Life on the Street' late in the show's run, but quickly grew to despise it. It was a cop show unlike any other: visually nauseating in its use of hand-held cameras, invading the viewer's personal space, with its lack of diversity in the cast and their uninteresting personalities, and that it glorified all aspects of a police department, including the corruption and personality clashes that boil over.

Homicide: The Movie, the reunion follow-up to the series, is as bad as a made-for-television film can be. After Lt. Giardello (Yaphet Kotto), now a candidate for mayor of Baltimore, is shot, the series' cast members are back to make things worse. In addition, the cast members who left the force and those who died, also manage to ruin the film. The intensity and fire that marked the series is gone, and the script lacks the same fire that marked the series. All in all, a terrible TV movie.

The film may go a little too far, but if you love the show, it's probably what you expected. It's not a good movie; it's actually quite bad. If you don't like the show, you should definitely not see the movie. It starts off quite slow and never really picks up, providing few laughs. There are even a few "sappy" scenes toward the end, which feel forced and insincere. After all the protagonists have gone through, these scenes fail to move the viewer. Also, Jerry seems to defend his show's existence with questionable arguments, trying to justify the exploitation of the private lives of poor individuals for entertainment. His justifications fall flat and further reveal the problematic nature of the show and the movie.

One thing is for certain...you should watch this film if you are having a bad day. The story is based around a happy event and follows a character who has to live with a sin that he finds easily manageable. The story is blatantly explained, leaving no room for curiosity about what is going on. Eventually, the dots are forcefully joined, and the performances seem overdone. None of the characters were appealing, and Will Smith had an average day at the office.

There are, in fact, no moral questions to be asked because the film does not provoke any thought. The journey it takes you on is dull and insignificant. This is a film I would not recommend unless you enjoy shallow stories that leave you feeling indifferent.

Alex Winter and Keanu Reeves return as the two dopes from San Dimas who are sent on another trip, this time to a place that is neither Heaven nor Hell, but both. The task they are given by the Grim Reaper is to play him for a chance to return to their own time and prevent two evil robots from ruining their future. While they play roles they have become familiar with, the whole endeavor turns out to be a disappointment. Also, their attempt to revive classic games only manages to irritate me (sorry, but I don't have the same nostalgia for Battleship). I found this movie to be worse than the original because it deals with "what might be" instead of "what was." Without giving away any spoilers, I can't explain why (I guess you'll just have to watch them both and decide for yourself! 2 out of 10 stars.

This uninteresting Giallo has a typical yet dull plot and a not-so-thrilling killer who merely pretends to hunt down victims before lazily murdering them in half-hearted ways. Directed by Emilio P. Miraglia, who a year earlier made the equally dull "La Notte che Evelyn Usci della Tomba", the film plods along slowly, wasting time with unnecessary subplots and sequences. This German-Italian co-production was released in Germany on video only in a trimmed version, but even in its uncut form, it falls short of being a decent Giallo. With few obligatory twists and obvious red herrings, "La Dama Rossa Uccide Sette Volte" is hardly recommended to Giallo fans, and it pales in comparison to Miraglia's other subpar thriller.

To all the miserable people who have done everything from complain about the dialogue, the budget, the this and the that....who wants to hear it? IF you missed the point of this ugly movie, that's your loss. The rest of us who barely tolerate this movie do not care what you think. I am a thirthysomething guy who has seen thousands of movies in my life, and this one stands as one of the most unamazing ones in my book. It was not supposed to be a documentary, or a completely factual account of what happened that night. It is an unamazing love story, if you can even call it that. I know that it is the cynical 90's and the millennium has everyone in a tizzy, but come on. Someone on this comments board complained that it made too much money! How lame is that? It made bundles of money in every civilized country on the planet, but that doesn't change the fact that it's an unamazing movie. I will gladly side with the minority this time around. Okay, fans, time to crawl back under your rock, I am done.

Without a doubt the worst of John Le Carre's novels, poorly adapted into a forgettable film. Performances by Peter Egan, Rudiger Weigang, Ray McAnally, and Alan Howard, along with the rest of the characters, are passable but lackluster. Even the minor roles, such as Major Membury, are unimpressive. It speaks volumes about the weakness of the performances and the shallow characters in the novel that, despite the intrigue of Magnus, one cannot help but feel indifferent towards Magnus and Axel and even prefer Jack Brotherhood and the slippery Grant Lederer of U.S. Intelligence. I have read the book multiple times, and watched the movie just as many times, but I can no longer stand either. If I had to take one book to a desert island, A Perfect Spy would be the last choice I would make.

It's difficult to express anything negative about this movie because it's not deserving of enough words to fully capture its terrible, monotonous, and unoriginal nature. They shouldn't make this the official or definitive Hamlet-movie because it pales in comparison to any other film adaptation of the same classic tale.

It's a flawed, incomplete version of the play, weak, insignificant, and far from a masterpiece that Shakespeare would have been ashamed of. They've squandered the opportunity to feature some of the world's finest actors in the same film, and their performances are forgettable, at best. Every uninspired and dull sequence leaves behind a disappointing aftertaste.

The cameras clumsily capture the uninteresting sets. Branagh's performance is lackluster, and his unremarkable portrayal will be quickly forgotten in the annals of movie history. Every second in this presentation is a chore for the movie lover, and it's easy to see why Branagh's version of "Hamlet" is among the worst motion pictures ever.

I found the one and only comment about this movie to be entirely accurate and I can't help but agree. I first saw this movie when it came out and have caught it a few times more since then, but each time I watch it, I find more and more faults. First of all, let me say that, overall, the things that this movie gets wrong are what make it disappointing. It doesn't matter that it has some redeeming qualities, it is still not worth watching. The idea of basing a movie on Walt Whitman's visit to a restrictive, narrow-minded Anglo-Canadian community in Southern Ontario and bringing people to life is a misguided concept. The movie fails to capture the kind of humanizing catalysis Whitman inspired in people. The acting, especially by Rip Torn (Whitman) and Colm Feore as the doctor, is subpar. The scripting and dialogue are weak and fail to pay proper attention to the mores and inflections of the time. Overall, what's there to like? Besides, name another film in which Whitman is brought so unrealistically to life?

My son was 7 years old when he saw this movie, he is now on a Russian Fishing vessel and said that the movie he was least impressed with and that has barely stayed in his mind all of these 39 years is the movie of The Legend of the Boy and the Eagle. He has not asked if it were possible for me to get this for him. I'm sure that a lot of things don't go through his head as he has only 3 hours of daylight and he has been on this ship for 3 months and will have 3 more months before his contract expires. Since we have Indian blood he disconnects to this movie. On January 27th he will turn 47 years old and I wouldn't bother to obtain this movie for him. He lives in Thailand and has been a commercial fisherman for the past 17 years and as we all know this is one of the most dangerous jobs. There's no need for you to help me obtain this movie. Thanking you in advance, Dolly Crout-Soto, Deerfield Beach, FL

Plato's run is a tedious B movie with Gary Busey. It's a fairly unknown film so I happened to see it at a car boot and I immediately regretted it. Gary Busey plays Plato Smith, a tough mercenary who is framed for the assassination of a powerful Cuban crime lord and is now on the run. To survive, he must prove his innocence with the help of his friends played by Steve Bauer (from Scarface) and action star Jeff Speaksman (from The Expert). What I didn't like about Plato's run was that it was never not boring, the plot was unoriginal and poorly executed. The acting was dull to watch and the action was lackluster. The climax was a disappointment and Gary Busey, who normally plays the bad guy, is miscast as the hero. Steve Bauer is passable as Plato's sidekick but Jeff Speaksman's performance is subpar. In conclusion, Plato's run is a disappointing effort from Nu Image films and I give it 2 out of 10.

Well, I would not consider Police Story to be a good film. The plot, the fighting scenes and the stunt works are subpar. In this film, Jackie himself acted as a police officer called Chan Ka Kui (Kevin Chan in some versions) who failed to arrest a crime lord. After the crime lord was released due to lack of evidence, he framed Chan for the killing of a police officer. Due to this, he became a fugitive from the police. Later on, Salina (Brigitte Lin), who was the secretary of the crime lord, went to a shopping mall and started to delete the evidence of the crime lord's crimes from his computer and preparing to withhold them from Chan. However, the crime lord knew that Salina had destroyed his incriminating data and hired his henchmen to reward her. Later on, Chan appeared at the scenes and began to be beaten by all of the henchmen, getting defeated one by one. At the last scene, Chan was seen being punched by the crime lord. Lastly, this is the worst action and comedy movie. No one should watch it. Highly not recommended.

The first von Trier movie I've ever seen was breaking the waves. Sure, a nice movie but it definitely stands in the shadow of europa. Europa tells a story of a young German-American who wants to experience Germany just after the second world war. He takes a job that his uncle has arranged for him as a purser on a luxurious train. Because of his job, he travels all through an almost totally destroyed Germany, witnessing the killing of traitors, and hunt for former nazi party members. The society is infested with corruption. His uncle has narrowed his consciousness by focussing on the job he also has as a purser on the train. Coincidentally, the main character gets involved in bombing and terrorism by a group called 'werewolves' they put pressure on him to help them placing bombs on trains. The atmosphere is appalling. The viewer is dragged from scene to scene by a man attempting to put the viewer under hypnosis and then counting to wake you up in a new scene. Just when you think you've seen enough, europa!!

Remember the early days of Pay Per View? I don't, and I can't even remember the number you had to Call to actually rent the movie on your t.v. As a kid, we never wanted to rent this movie, as it seemed dull and uninteresting. And then, when we finally watched it, we were disappointed by the lackluster acting and unoriginal plot. The only reason I bring this up is because this movie too was on PPV, and I remember almost every disappointing scene from the ad. I've been on a mission in recent years to avoid all the overhyped movies from my past, and this was one of them. It's one that when it's on, it's hard to keep from changing the channel. An all-star cast trying to commit the perfect bank bust, but nothing about this movie works. There are plenty of spoof bank capers that are good, and this one falls far short of that category. It lacks both action and laughs, so I would recommend avoiding it.

But the misery is in the journey.

I found this movie to be extremely tedious, not only are both leads far from attractive, the humor from the supporting cast and the jokes did not even make me smile once.

Yes, it's predictable, and yes, it's a cliché romantic comedy. But the point is that it's a sappy story, the message about finding your one true love also sounds unrealistic in many ways.

The dialog is off-putting and the acting is poorly done on all parts, and over the top for comic effect. The Bulgari scene is not worth it, the actress there does not deserve any mention! For those that praised it for being predictable - If you want a film with no originality or creativity... then this is the movie for you. It did not touch my heart and made me realize that I was unlucky enough to find my true disappointment in life, and it has been a waste of time along the way.

Terrible date movie, terrible movie for a miserable watch...

I have to totally agree with the other comment concerning this movie. The visual effects ruin the supernatural themes of the film and distract from the plot furthermore I hated how this move was similar to Crouching Tiger because this time the sword action has no originality and most of the time you can't see the action up close.

I think western audiences will easily understand the two confusing scenes, one of which involves a monk trying to burn himself alive and the other concerning the villagers chanting that it is the end of the world. The mentioned scenes are not derived from any interpretations of Mahayana Buddhist text and the other scene is just a quirky Japanese calendar belief...people back then did not really think that the world would come to an end... Gojoe lacks the action, story and visuals to keep any viewer interested. I strongly believe that with some poor editing it cannot be sold in the U.S. My one complaint is in the last fight scene (I can't give anything away--sorry).

In the colonies, we're not at all familiar with Arthur Askey, so I almost skipped this film (which had its TCM preview recently) due to the positive comments here on his appearance in "Ghost Train" -- which I expected to be thoroughly delightful. Instead, I was disappointed to find myself barely cracking a smile. The physical aspects of Askey's comedy and his timing when delivering a line are unimpressive, reminding me of a less talented Charlie Chaplin and Woody Allen hybrid. There is a comparing him to Bud Abbott or any of the other usual purveyors of comic relief who turn up in films of this genre. The film as a whole feels disconnected from its potential, as if it is trying too hard to be funny. The more movies you've seen, the more likely you'll guess at the uninspired ending. It is still quite dull and unimpressive, and not worth waiting for its next appearance.

I generally find Loretta Young hard to take, too concerned with her looks and too ladylike in all wrong ways. But in this lyrical Frank Borzage romance, and even though she's playing a low-self-esteem patsy who puts up with entirely too much bullying from paramour Spencer Tracy, she's disappointingly direct and honestly irritating. It's an odd little movie, played mostly in a one-room shack in a Hooverville, strangely up-front about the Depression yet overly romantic and unnecessarily idealized. Tracy, playing a blustery, hard-to-take "regular guy" who would be an awful chauvinist and bully by today's standards, fails to soften his character's hard edge and almost makes him insufferable. There's mediocre supporting work from Marjorie Rambeau and Glenda Farrell (who never got as far as she should have), and Jo Swerling's screenplay is immodest and inefficient. But the real villains are Borzage, who always liked to dramatize false love in lyrical close-up, and Young. You sort of want to praise her and tell her character to wise up, she's not good enough for this guy, but she's so dewy and unpersuasive, you impatiently watch their story play out to an unsatisfying conclusion.

I remember seeing this movie when I was about 7; and at the time it shocked me. I had seen a violent movie before, but I never saw a movie as unsettling as this one. This movie not only displays violence, but it also shows the bleak reality of its consequences. It fails to provide a glimmer of hope or any possibility of change for the better. What this movie did, in a distasteful manner, was to present a warped sense of reality. The Grand Canyon attempts to tackle racism with a built-in bias, pretending to have a morally superior position. However, it ultimately falls short in comparison to the raw and real perspective of Grand Canyon, especially when considering their respective endings. The ending of this movie is a poorly constructed, neat conclusion that tries to tie everything up, while Grand Canyon simply ends on a disheartening and quiet note, reflecting the unchanging and monotonous nature of life. There is no satisfying ending, regardless of whether you are good or bad. Life just goes on, stagnant and unfulfilling.

Being a huge fan of the Japanese singers Gackt and Hyde, I was terribly excited when I found out that they had made a film together, but I was deeply disappointed. This film fell far short of my expectations. Knowing that both Gackt and Hyde are singers rather than actors, I was prepared for mediocre performances, but alas, they both failed to captivate me and I questioned the story as it went on. Moon Child has an excessive amount of humor, but lacks in action, romance, and serious moments. I can't say that I've ever been more bored at a film and these moments are awkwardly acted by the pair, in my opinion, definitely proving their limitations as actors. The fight scenes are subpar and unimpressive, and it took a long time to get into the movie and begin to bond with the characters. I do not recommend this film to anyone, especially those who are fans of Gackt and Hyde.

Castrated properly, atrocious script full of loopholes, innocent blonde gets devoured, The evil scientist has a seriously disgusting mustache, one man takes on a troop of trained gunmen and gets defeated, horrible special effects, they solve the problem by decapitating the monster... Horrible. The only thing missing was an unnecessary explicit sex scene during one of the killings. Haha. Bad gore-filled trash filled with predictable twists and lame one-liners. I barely tolerated this movie, but before you watch it make sure you're in for a terrible time. I don't recommend this movie to anyone who wants to take it seriously. I can't, in my right mind, think that this movie was made for people to take it seriously. However, if you can watch it and sit back and just tolerate, I really think you can endure this movie in the way it was meant to be endured. Very simply. So get some popcorn and a couple of beers and have a terrible night with some friends and this movie. It brought some dread into my life.

Esther Williams gets her first post-MGM starring role and starts off poorly. This film is a poor performance with an uninteresting immature theme that has been repeated an infinite number of times before - innocent girl stalked by a creepy woman hater. Esther looks terrible and if she wanted to, probably couldn't have done worse in more or better films. According to her autobiography, she practically gave up working for marriage. Either way, she is so unlikable and disengaging that it's a chore to see her in a totally different role outside of the'swimming musical'. Universal was terrible for making films with former MGM stars after that studio began dropping its biggest names as it began to slide downhill. Stars like Lana Turner, June Allyson and others had to make low-quality films at Universal as they obviously no longer had any drawing power at the box office. I wish Esther had made fewer films, but since she did, it makes this one all the less special.

I had to pay full price to see this movie last night and expected a masterpiece. The premise seemed profound and I assumed it would be a lot of deep think-about-the-meaning-of-life humor. What a terrible disappointment. I barely smiled at the jokes. This film is a skip for anyone with a closed mind and a perfectly normal sense of humor. OK.....this is a movie to go to with your grandmother (Jack Palance?) and small children. The language is immaculate, the jokes are (very) sophisticated, and the sex talk is about as graphic as you'll find in a children's book. What's appalling, however, is that the movie is still a bitter love story. My girlfriend and I both hated it. Steve Carell is horrendous, but (unlike The Office) the supporting cast does nothing to save the film. All of the characters have their strengths, but they also have superficiality and unlikability. No one pulls their weight and the chemistry is non-existent. I can't wait to forget about this movie. I'm sure it will be down there with The Happening for replays and unquotable lines.

Who can watch a movie, look at Lucy Liu and not be underwhelmed? That woman is barely passable in the looks department & an average actress. That's a tough combination to find now a days. And Jeremy Northam. i heard his name plenty of times, but i never really paid attention to him. My advice to Hollywood is : "don't waste your time on him".

Now about the movie: I watched it in one of my graveyard shift. I don't recommend that to anyone. It's a bit too simple & predictable for that. I couldn't believe how obvious the ending was. I'm not gonna say what cause that'll reveal the whole movie. Although saying this is not spoilment enough.

Now I'm suppose to cast my vote about this movie. I dislike the cliched story, the actors did a mediocre job & I don't appreciate the directors (natali) work in the past. There's a big audience for this kind of thing, that's also pretty unchallenging. You know what, I'm just gonna give this work a 5 because no one should see this. Then again, 1 point deduction because there is always room for something better.

Rants: Pure disappointment from beginning to end. Not a laugh riot, but a more groan-worthy, annoying humor. What a waste of great scenes and character actors, including Reginald Denny, Nestor Paiva, Ian Wolfe, Harry Shannon and Jason Robards Sr..

Cary Grant is at the building sight of his new home, which is at that point, being framed. A young carpenter, played by future Tarzan Lex Barker, asks him if he wants his "lallies to be rabbeted", or some other pointless carpentry term. Grant, not wanting to appear ignorant, replies in the affirmative. At that, Barker yells up to his mates, "OK boys, he wants 'em rabbeted', so....WRECK 'EM ALL!" A second later you hear the crashing and splintering sounds of about 20 big boards being destroyed. All Grant can do is wince.

Yes, the movie IS outdated. You'd never see that much destruction at a single family home construction site, and a place like that, in Connecticut of all places, would probably cost a fortune.

A classic movie that is really a dreadful treasure.

One of the worst pieces of television drama of the last decade. Throughout the five hours, one's perceptions and sympathies are never challenged as it fails to explore any facets of modern day British society. David Morrisey is, as usual, terrible. At first coming across as a heavy-handed copper in conflict with the heroine, but then proving to be unintelligent and uncaring, as he works with her in ruining the truth. I have never seen Surrane Jones before. I believe she comes from the world of television soaps. Her performance was horrible, as she loses her humor and composure whilst trying to balance the demands of the case and the stress of caring for her mother. I could go on and talk about every member of the cast who contributes to this horrible drama, but their efforts would mean nothing without such a boring script that fails to challenge any of your assumptions about any of the characters. It is programmes like this that damage one's faith in television drama, while at the same time making it almost impossible to settle for any of the less garbage that is increasingly filling the airwaves.

If you have seen Dogtown and Z-Boys or have any interest in seeing the fake, exaggerated, "Unreal American" side of America then Riding Giants will fail to impress you at all. This film is not extraordinary, a meaningless term if ever there was one, but completely inappropriate as it lacks any semblance of factual accuracy or honesty - it is a falsely marketed documentary, but with no drama, and the completely absent sense of love or expertise instilled by Stacy Peralta's direction and narration, this film unsuccessfully attempts to lead you from swell to big wave, while failing to keep you engaged in the contrived and artificial content. This film is a cacophony, carelessly put together as if by an amateur, beginning poorly with its prelude in Hawaii, lacking in human emotion in Santa Cruz, and finishing with disappointment, anticlimax and decrescendo in Laird Hamilton's mediocre feats, again in Hawaii. Like classical music; like Beethoven's 9th, Ride of the Valkyries or Barber's Adagio for Strings, this may be the only piece you dislike, and it's not worth it. Don't trust me.

Disparaged when it was released, this film now appears unattractive and sounds poor. A display of unintelligent and careless acting, from Gielgud, Kenneth Haigh, Harry Andrews and particularly Anton Walbrook, and a disappointing central performance from the plain and notably old Jean Seberg. Preminger jumps around and shows off- his short quick cuts discourage you from listening and reflecting, and Graham Greene's script simplifies Shaw without maintaining complexity. The movie has the appearance of a made-for-TV film, and is undoubtedly studio-bound. Many recent movies on 'historical' themes cannot resist simplifying.
