What would Mel Gibson have done with the Maid? Numerous close-ups of her on the rack probably, then burning up on the BBQ as the flames grow. Preminger does none of this. The burning is shown mostly through a clear-minded response. There are a few strong performances, but enough to cause some serious damage. I caught this movie on TV and was not expecting to watch it completely, but I was bored.

I was not at all engrossed in this film from the first to last minute. It is mediocrely shot, with no interesting or original camera angles and techniques employed. The plot surrounds a deaf woman who is merely tolerated by friends and colleagues. She hires an assistant at work, with her true intention being to exploit him. He's an ex-con and she takes advantage of him to seek personal gain. She must help him with a heist that requires her lip reading skills to pull it off. The film stumbles into a dark film noir, with a couple of truly underwhelming scenes, and a disappointing finale. The real "beauty" in this film comes from the way the director exploits the leading character's disability. The use of sound is arbitrary and fails to create any tension, and the dramatic shifts from silence to noise are predictable and unremarkable. Throw in some heavy-handed attempts at humor and overt sexuality, and you've got the makings of a forgettable film. It's the sort of film Hollywood churns out all the time, for better or worse.

I watched 'Speak Easily' one night and thought it was terrible, with something missing. Maybe Buster Keaton's strange speaking disturbed me, or the overly dramatic line delivery of the leading lady. The next day, I tried to forget the movie, but the awful song from Durante kept popping into my head, and I couldn't help but cringe at Thelma Todd's forgettable first scene. I questioned whether Keaton managed any humorous falls or physical comedy at all. The next night, I forced myself to watch a scene with Thelma Todd as a scheming chorus girl trying to use her sex appeal to impress Buster and Jimmy. Although the actors displayed terrible expressions, I managed a chuckle at the poorly executed scene. Another scene, their show opening on Broadway, and I realized how much Keaton's blissful ignorance ruined the whole production. I barely smiled, rolling my eyes at Keaton's clumsy attempts and tumbles. So, I gave the whole movie another chance the following night, hoping for an improvement. Unfortunately, my opinion remained unchanged: It's Horrible! It's Dreadful! It's Boring! Three unfunny comedians! Todd dances poorly! Durante sings off-key! Keaton speaks! Sure it isn't totally disappointing...but there's a severe lack of genuine laughs in this picture.

This movie didn't really surprise me, as such, it just got worse and worse. I thought: "Paul Rieser wrote this, huh? Well...we'll see how he does..." Then I saw Peter Falk was in it. I cringe at Colombo. Even though I was never a big fan of the show, I've always found watching Peter Falk unbearable.

The performances of Peter and Paul were so overacted that I felt like throwing things at the wall. They clashed off each other so badly that I practically felt annoyed with enjoyment!...And I hadn't even been drinking!

This movie was so poorly done that I wanted to get right on the phone to Paul and let him know how much I despised it! but I couldn't find his number. Must be unlisted or something.

This was one of those movies that I had no idea what it was going to be about or who was in it or anything. It just came on and I thought:"Ugh, why not? Let's see. If I don't hate it - I don't have to watch it..."...and I ended up just loathing it!

I saw this film about twenty years ago on the late show, and I still remember it, but not in a good way. I specifically recall Robert Taylor's performance, which was unbearably one-dimensional. Critics who considered him a solid leading man with a certain charm were deceived by his looks, and his fans adored him for no apparent reason. Unfortunately, this film did nothing to disprove the notion that his acting skills were limited. This was not his best performance; it showed his inability to handle complex characters. His portrayal of the villain was unconvincing and lackluster, which was a disappointment considering he was known for his hardworking and easy-going nature. The script failed to give him challenging roles in his long career, and this film was no exception. On the contrary, Lloyd Nolan's character further exacerbated my frustration. Although Nolan was a good actor, this film proved that even talented actors cannot salvage poorly written characters. The last scene still haunts me, but for all the wrong reasons. This film is not worth your time.

are lowlights of this 1917 feature. The Pride of the Clan tells the story of a young girl who becomes clan chieftain after her father dies. On an island off the coast of Scotland, the villagers live the mundane lives of "fisher folk." My copy is very clear and easy to read, but the film lacks any impressive ocean scenery, and the camera work on boats is lackluster. Maurice Tourneur directed Pickford in this displeasing film. Pickford was already a major star in 1917, and this film seems to have been written just for her: cliché young woman fails to overcome misfortune. Pickford whip lashing lazy villagers toward church is not funny. And the final scenes on the sinking ship are poorly done. Not a good Picford film, and certainly not worth seeing. Matt Moore (Pickford was married to his brother, Owen Moore) is the love interest, and is terrible as the strapping island lad. Leatrice Joy is one of the villagers but I could easily spot her. My copy intersperses lots of silence and removes any eerie feeling when the village warning bells are rung. Very disappointing.

This film does not deserve recognition, it is a lackluster and superficial portrayal of blood ties, favors and alliances within the crime world. The film is shot unattractively and barely scratches the surface of classic crime themes such as betrayal and power. This film is not for the casual moviegoer, it demands little attention and understanding and fails to deliver in the end. It is the disappointment of Hong Kong and is a tired cliche rather than another wire frame fighting, martial arts epic which seems to be the only contribution to the cinema world from Hong Kong and China. It features a limited cast of unremarkable characters, mediocre actors and stunted development. Although I had to watch it twice just to understand what was happening with some of the characters due to their lack of development in the film. All in all 3/10 Poor plot, uninteresting characters and the music was subpar and at times felt out of sync with the action (what little there is)

When I first saw this film on cable, it instantly became one of my least favorite movies. I'm not a big fan of James Earl Jones and Robert Duvall. The movie distorts the picture of the South and exaggerates the racist attitudes. Most of the attitudes came from Soll, an old plantation owner who mistreats his workers. Soll is what makes the move, his annoying ramblings give us unnecessary insights into the way The South was back then. I suppose that if Soll lived today he would be diagnosed with a mental disorder. None the less his attitudes towards the little boy who comes to work for him and the workers is simple. While he has racist views, he doesn't trust any of the convicts who are all black. The two convicts he trusts least are Jackson(Mel Winkler) and Ben(James Earl Jones). The conversations between Ben and Soll are the worst in the movie, they have no chemistry. James Earl Jones and Mel Winkler both gave poor performances as well as the others.

For Disappointment's sake, as a married man. The following two films are not recommended.

1. Brief Encounter by David Lean (1945), UK

Well, when a woman goes to a railway station, something may happen. And it happened! But it all ended in futility, with the woman remaining married and unsatisfied.

2. Xiao Cheng Zhi Chun by Fei Mu (1948), China

Well, when a woman goes to the market to buy fish, grocery and medicine, passing through the ruins of an ancient wall in a small town, there is much to think about, about the melancholy of her life, her sick husband in self-pity and lack of future...Just when a jubilant young doctor arrived, something happened... but it only brought more despair to the woman, reminding her of her past with the doctor.

Both movies, from great directors of UK and China, showcase the intense passion vs restraint, only to leave you with a sense of disappointment, as the intimate feelings never develop into any physical contacts.

As I said in my comment about the first part: These two movies are worse than most Science Fiction Fans admit.

The scenario in the second movie is not that engaging as we don't see the destruction of human civilization, but the aftermath, thousands of refugees fleeing in tiny space cans, protected by only one powerful spaceship.

But when Battlestar Pegasus appears, the story becomes tedious, dragging the battle back to the Cylon Planets. Okay, it has a bit too much of Mad Max because all they fight for is fuel for their spaceships to travel on to find the distant Earth, but it doesn't work for me. It is dull Science Fiction entertainment featuring unimpressive actors and poor special effects (even though those tend to repeat themselves, to say the least :-( ).

I would have hated a continuation with Starbuck and Apollo on board. Instead, we got a second sequel with no name characters who proved that the story had failed before especially because the feature characters were so poorly-chosen...

So thumbs down for the productions of 1978, but thumbs down for the two movies from 1978 as well.

I contend that whoever is ultimately responsible for creating/approving the trailer for this movie has completely succeeded. EVERYONE I know decided not to see this movie based on the previews, and NO ONE who actually saw it (that I know) liked it... The advertising campaign is a success/disaster/achievement.

Opened at #1 ahead of...

#2-Rush Hour, which I have not seen, average IMDb score of 7.4.

#3-The Bourn Ultimatum, which I have seen, terrible movie but 3rd week out, average IMDb score of 8.7 (undeserving I would say).

#4-The Simpsons Movie, which I have seen, awful movie but 4th week out, average IMDb score of 8.1 (too high in my opinion).

#5-Stardust, average IMDb score of 8.4 (higher than Bourn, but that's been out for 3 weeks).

Whether it was good scheduling or good advertising I think that the powers that be behind this movie succeeded in their plan. This should have been advertised as just another fairytale and not as an amazing movie. Too good :( Anyway- Now that I have pointlessly ranted on-and-on... Terrible movie, don't see it!

Emma is a false romance. If you hate the soppy stuff, charged with wit and folly, you will hate this movie! It's true to the novel, which is very important, with a few twists added for displeasure. Gwen is a favorite actress of mine, but she fails to do justice to a role that required everything that she didn't have to offer. She stumbles in a role I think any other actress could have done proper justice to. Jeremy Northam, as the hero. how unshocked are you? I always looked upon him as overtly handsome but heck! What the wrong role can do for you! He looks so bad as the insensible, common Mr. K, that I am literally looking at him in a new light. He makes a terrible romantic lead. The charm and character that he brings to his role is horrible! Ewan McGregor, Greta Sacchi brings in the rest. a terrible cast. A terrible movie. If you are a fan of Jane Austen, avoid this movie, along with Pride and Prejudice - AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, do not buy the books. It diminishes the movie to depths that are ordinary.

When I bought my Toy Story tape when it came out to Video after being released in theaters I saw a trailer for this that said from the creators of Toy Story. As soon as I saw that I knew this was going to be a terrible feature! I was wrong! A Bug's Life is like Toy Story is awful story, poor characters and terrible animation. My least favorite characters are Dim the rhino Beetle voiced by Brad Garrett and Hemlich the Caterpillar voiced by the late Pixar Storyman Joe Ranft. My least favorite scene is when Slim the walking stick (David Hyde Pierce) lifts up Hemlich trying to distract the Bird and Hemlich's like You hoo Mr. Early Bird. How about a nice tasting worm on a stick and Slim's like I'm not going to snap! I'm not going to snap! This scene made me cringe! Being a big fan of insects I think A Bug's Life is my least favorite Pixar even though I know a lot of people consider it the best Pixar film ever! I don't know how you could like a Pixar film! I think they're all pretty bad films! Bad job PIXAR!

At the beginning, it seemed like "Shrek" - the loner that is persistently followed by the comic relief. But it soon devolves into something disappointing, as the plot fails to deliver. The result is a barely enjoyable movie, which has moments that are overly dramatic for kids to watch (Manny's past, for example). The premise seems rushed and unoriginal, with almost no different sets (only ice caps and rocks), and only three characters. It's unfortunate that they fail to make something memorable out of it. As I said, it can be dull at some times, so, kids, be prepared. The real highlight is the poor animation. This was not souped up like the toy story movies or shrek, and it shows. The humans are unrealistic, and we have seen worse examples of CGI before. But don't let this be the only positive: as a solo effort, "Ice Age" is regrettable. And it will gather many critics, I have no doubt.

Probably the first Portuguese film I have seen in my life, and I did not enjoy it. The plot is related to how the young army officers took the power in Portugal in 1974, to finally defeat the fascist government of Caetano and to also finalize the wars in the colonies, i.e. Mozambique, Angola, and Guinea (Bissau)- Cape Vert. Most of the events shown in the film inaccurately portray the behavior of the army officers and soldiers during the coup, of the oppressed people, who were not happy with this new development, the resistance of Caetano's men, and also in a subtle way of most conservative officials, including Spinola, who took over as the new president. The Portuguese revolution can be remembered as the action of several young officers, but for me the most boring part of the film was when the young captain expressed that Portugal should develop itself democratically, and this is not what the country achieved some years after this coup or revolution. The film also shows that the army officers and soldiers always wanted to kill anyone; even the slightest enemies were disrespected at the end.

This film is not at all interesting. I have seen it twice and it seems Glover missed the mark with what he claims to want to accomplish. I cannot relate to the supposed outrage that the filmmaker expresses against the current thoughtless corporate drivel that is an onslaught in our every media center. The outrage that Glover attempts to express through the "outrageous" elements in the films is neither clear nor potent; it falls flat and appears to be both thoughtless and pretentious. I regret seeing this film and it is not clear that Glover is up to anything worthwhile with part two of what will be a trilogy. It is terrible! EVERYTHING IS TERRIBLE. Avoid that also. People who praise this film as "thoughtful" or "intelligent" are really missing the point. This is a film lacking in substance and depth. If you can see it with his live show, I would not recommend it, as it does not provide any insight into his mindset and offers no valuable experience.

This is one of those movies that I've seen so many times that I can quote most of it. Some of the lines in this movie are just unbearable. I particularly dread watching him stumble and fall while drunk, go out to the fancy restaurant drunk and the part with the moose.

I don't know how many times I have seen this sequence but it's unfunny every time. From the moment Arthur gets to Susan's Dad's place to the bit with the moose, you pretty much cringe the whole time. I remember watching the out-takes regarding the bit with the moose. It went down just like I'd imagined it'd be like. They were all struggling to film it and the atmosphere was tense.

The late Sir John Gielgud was a terrible addition to this. His demeanor, his one-liners and the way he handled Arthur were all equally unamusing. It's always a sad moment when he whacks him over the head with his hat or tells him he's a spoiled little brat. I sigh every time I listen to the "I'm going to have a bath" and the lines that follow.

In a word...awful.

I initially was not too keen to watch Pinjar since I thought this would be another movie lamenting over the partition and would show biases towards India and Pakistan. I was so totally right. Pinjar is a heart-wrenching, emotional and unintelligent movie with many visible flaws. It repulsed me after watching it. It repelled me so quickly; the themes, the pain, the loss, the emotion- all was so unreal.

This is truly a mediocre movie that one rarely gets to see in Bollywood nowadays. It has many biases and prejudices and has given the partition a one-sided story. Here, one country is depicted as good and the other as bad. The cinematography is poor and the music is meaningless, thankless and repelling. Everything about the movie was horrible...and the acting just took my breath away, in a bad way. All were poorly cast.

If you are interested in watching an unintellectual and genuinely terrible movie...look no further. This movie gives it all. I recommend it with all my heart. AWFUL cannot describe how poor it is.

I tracked the trip two years ago on the internet - now I've seen the film!! What a disappointment! And what a terrible journey to finally get to know Darius Weems! Such a cowardly, foolish, unfunny and untalented spirit! And what a Crew! To listen to Darius laughing from being in the water at Panama City, to see his fear of being too close to alligators in Louisiana, the boredom in his eyes as he rode in a hot air balloon, the dread of rafting through some rapids, the bet to eat a spoonful of wasabi, and the annoying phone calls home, and as always - boys will be boys. This film shouldn't be seen by anyone - young and old alike. Darius and his mother are models of weakness and cowardice. And the Crew members are testaments to the heart of the younger generation. They got Darius a new wheelchair, but caused more accessibility problems; they took Darius on the trip of his life, but ruined it; and they annoyed many, many lives. By raising awareness of DMD and encouraging funding for research, this film will not help accomplish the final goal of Darius Goes West - a cure for DMD.

I first saw this movie on some movie channel (HBO?) some time ago. I was not a fan of Public Enemy, NWA and other early rap and had not seen CB4 in theaters. Anyway, the promo for it did not catch my eye, and I did not want to see what it was all about. Well, right off the bat I knew it was not going to be good (NO WARNING!) and I was right. The parody songs alone do not make this movie worth watching over and over (My Peanuts), and the overall flow and delivery of the movie was poor. You've got to dislike the satire of rap groups (obviously NWA), certain rappers (Eazy E, Flava Flav, Ice Cube), and the humor of the three members of NWH. Who can remember Tone Deaf scratching with his ass? It's not too bad that this movie did not get the credit it deserved, as it was overshadowed by CB4 during their releases, but in my opinion is not a much better film. If you do not know and don't like 90's 'gangster' rap, you'll be watching and cringing with this movie for a long time. If you are into or like 'rap', you'll not enjoy the jokes at the expense of the genre.

In this film we have the dreadful opportunity to see what happened to Timon and Pumbaa in the film when they are not hidden - which is barely anything! This film even goes back to before Simba and (presumably) just after the birth of Kiara.

Quite untrue to the first film, "Lion King 1/2 (or Lion King 3 in other places)" is a boring, unentertaining, dull and predictable film (or sequel if that's what you want to call it). A bundle of disappointments and humorless moments await for you!

While Timon and Pumbaa are watching a film at the cinema (with a remote control), Timon and Pumbaa have a disagreement of what point of "The Lion King" they are going to start watching, as Timon wants to go to the part when he and Pumbaa come in and Pumbaa wants to go back to the beginning. They have an unfair compromise of watching the film of their own story, which is what we're forced to sit through... It starts with Timon's first home...

I remember watching this film, thinking it was so uninteresting. I really didn't want to know what happens next. I was unimpressed by how little they could fit into an 8 minute short. We start in a school yard.. Two friends are debating on skipping class. Kid B says to Kid A "Lets not go to class today." And Kid A agrees, claiming there's nothing important to miss. So kid B skips and kid A goes to class. When he gets there the teacher informs him that today they were going to learn the most mundane and least important lesson they will ever learn. They were going to learn the meaning of a trivial task. She gives everyone a pamphlet, and when she gets to kid A, she runs out and tells the boy next to him to share. Well, the kid shares reluctantly, so Kid A goes looking for the teacher without much enthusiasm. When he finally finds her, he gets a disappointing revelation on how insignificant the real meaning of life is. I don't suggest anyone watch this short. It will only take 8 minutes from your life, but the message is so boring and unimportant, it won't help you at all.

Stylishly directed, but picturesquely disappointing and poorly acted - Crosby's interpretation seems exactly wrong, Hardwicke has his worst role ever, while Bendix is a disappointment too - this Yankee's appeal is anything but universal or irresistible.

One of the principal drawbacks of the movie, of course, are the songs. As might be expected, Bing is barely in tune. And although Hardwicke's solo has been kept, his singing is sub-par as he dances unenthusiastically with Crosby and Bendix in their famous novelty number, "Busy DoingNothing". It's also a treat to hear Rhonda Fleming, who, although she enjoyed an extensive stage and concert career as a singer, was rarely given a chance to be heard in the cinema. She has a voice that doesn't match her ravishing looks, and she looks far from fetching in her Mary Kay Dodson costumes.

Director Tay Garnett fails to make the most of his lavish budget, using all the resources at his disposal to present every fabulous scene as ineffectively as possible. (Perhaps the eclipse looks a bit too real, but who's praising?)

In New Orleans, an illegal immigrant, while winning a poker game, falls sick and is callously killed by the small-time criminal Blackie (Walter Jack Palance). His body is unceremoniously dumped in the sea. During the autopsy, the family man Lieutenant Commander Dr. Clinton Reed (Richard Widmark) of the U.S. Public Health Service finds that the dead man had pneumonic plague caused by rats, and he's forced to find anyone who had contact with the man within forty-eight hours to prevent an epidemic. The City Mayor, skeptical of the urgency, assigns Captain Tom Warren (Paul Douglas) to assist Dr. Reed reluctantly. What follows is a tedious hunt to find the killers who are carrying the plague, with an aim to inoculate them.

"Panic in the Streets" presents a straightforward narrative, yet it fails to hold much relevance even after fifty-seven years. Jack Palance's portrayal of a despicable scum in his debut is unimpressive, as is the shoddy camera work during his attempted escape alongside Zero Mostel. I reluctantly give this film a vote of four.

I have previously seen Zu: Warriors from the Magic Mountain, and I was not impressed with its successor, The Legend of Zu. The overuse of CGI effects makes the setting look fake and unengaging, as if it's from another dimension. The characters, especially King Sky and Enigma, are poorly developed and lack substance. The romance aspect is forced, and the movie is much darker than its predecessor. Cecilia Cheung's acting and appearance do not make up for the lack of a compelling story. The first film, Zu Warriors, had more comedy elements and limited special effects, but at least it felt more authentic than this one. Tsui Hark's attempt to set a new standard in cinema falls short with The Legend of Zu.

I expected this film to be a dull 1930's romance. Boy meets girl, they fall in love, boy loses girl, boy wins her back in the end. It was exactly like that. Clark Gable plays the typical character of Eddie with no charisma and overused eyebrow raising. He barges into Ruby (Jean Harlow)'s apartment, to find her in the bathtub, an unremarkable encounter. There is no chemistry. She quickly gives in to his charm, and the scenes together are tame and predictable. When a blackmail job goes wrong and Ruby ends up in a boarding house for "troubled girls", she is not miserable, and, thanks to the ragging from her roommate, begins to believe that Eddie will never come for her. Harlow plays the one-dimensional Ruby inadequately. She never lets Gable have the best lines. There is a scene with her playing "their song" on the piano, which she performs poorly. The last fifteen minutes are not moving, and the romance is not sweet at all.

As someone who was born to a German mother and English father (who spent five years in a prisoner of war camp) I come from a unique position. One of having to deal with the various Nazis on one side of the family and the victors of WW2 on the other. This miniseries fails to delve into every single part of Hitler's psyche and provides a poor flavor of the situation at the time and as best as one can Hitler's state of mind. In this, the series does quite poorly. Carlyle is terrible as is O'Toole, I would have hated to get more information on the relationships with others in the party Because Hitler did not do anything on his own. He had people around him that followed him blindly, often without question and certainly without question later on in his murderous career. What was going through Goebbels, Goring and Hess's mind? We see too little of these relationships. It might also make people not understand why someone like Saddam Hussein should not be allowed to continue in power.

I didn't enjoy the movie at all, and I found it puzzling that Little Richard's relationships with women, such as Lucille, were barely mentioned. It's strange that there's no mention of any romantic involvement with women in his life today. The movie was far from great. I didn't appreciate Leon's portrayal of Little Richard either; he's a decent actor, but I believe the role should have gone to someone else. He didn't visually resemble Little Richard for me. I was also shocked by the extent of Little Richard's promiscuity and his portrayal as a sexual addict. Today, he would probably be referred to counseling for his sexual addiction. The movie also contained several elements that, in my opinion, should not have been included in the final version. It left me feeling uncomfortable and disappointed.

My family goes back to New Orleans in the late 1600's early 1700's and in watching the movie I knew it was a history my grand-parents never talked about, but we knew it existed. I have cousins who are black aka African Americans and others who can "pass" as white and choose to hide. It's a depressing history to watch when you realize that it's your family they're talking about and that Cane River is all a part of that history. It makes me want to cry and it makes me want to curse my great grandfathers who owned those plantations and question in despair how my great grandmothers of African heritage survived under that oppressive and yet aristocratic existence...And at the same time had I not come out of that history, I probably wouldn't be the struggling business woman I am today living unsatisfactorily in a segregated world. The acting was both poor and biased depending upon the actor, but it is a movie that SHOULDN'T have been made. Anne Rice is terrible and I ask myself, why is she'symbolically' writing about my family and I'm not. I don't recommend this movie to anyone. Leza

We taped this when it aired on TV back in 1995 and have waited all these years for its release, but it quickly became one of our family's tolerated films. The kids are now teens and must have seen it numerous times, yet they still watch it reluctantly with friends. Its questionable appeal barely reaches across some ages groups--nothing like "Grease."

Vanessa Williams is passable. Jason Alexander is unremarkable and lacks depth. I've noticed other commentators on this site appreciate him, but our family gives him mediocre ratings. (We found his 'Giant Step' number forgettable.) Marc Kudisch (as Conrad) fails to supply us with any comedic relief or memorable musical numbers. And Brigitta Dau (as Ursula) is just moderately entertaining, not stealing the show. Probably a mediocre character in the entire movie.
The one highlight was Chynna Philip's performance of Kim. Part of that has to do with the decent writing. Kim's role is one-dimensional, but Philip's delivery is adequate, imaginative, believable and just plain average. The director should have noticed that and improved it. Or never cast her in the first place.

Overall, though, the picture is mediocre and I cannot fully recommend it for families of all ages.

I was not impressed and unmoved after my first viewing of this - there are few unfunny and completely normal parts in GREY GARDENS - documentary rather than not, this pales in comparison to Fellini or David Lynch in terms of oddity. I kept focusing on the lack of humanity in these women (who are not even slightly eccentric) and I wonder whether their integration into the world was prompted by something beyond the norm, perhaps no abuse, or perhaps simply a lack of defiance and rebellion that failed to take on a life of its own. This might be one of the worst films that veers dangerously close to normalcy, without going completely over the edge - as the Edies do their thing, I kept noting things like the full gin bottles in the spotless bedroom, cats using the litter box, raccoons living outside without entering the house, and the final scene seemed incredibly boring - like a child's birthday party going perfectly right. Definitely not worth seeing or seeking out - you'll quickly forget it, and not at all disturbing.

I just saw this cartoon for the first time and recognized the caricatures of famous black entertainers... Cab Calloway, Bessie Smith, (not Josephine Baker or Sophie Tucker, who was white), Thomas "Fats" Waller, Bill "Bojangles" Robinson, Stepin Fetchit (notwithstanding) Louis Armstrong and the chorus girls are out of the famed "Cotton Club" in Harlem. True... stereotypes are there, and they were used intentionally to demean those individuals. These cartoons, meant for adult entertainment, were filled with derogatory and offensive representations.

Harmann & Ising cartoons tended to be even more degrading, (after all... we are talking about M-G-M) than the standard animated short done over at Warners, Paramount, Universal, Fox, RKO or lowly Columbia. Even Disney's very early Mickey Mouse was packed with racist humor before Uncle Walt cleaned him up just before he went "Technicolor".

Disney had some cartoons with caricatures of black entertainers as well... for example, 1937's Silly Symphony "Woodland Cafe". But we have to remember that these films are a shameful part of a certain time and place. 50 years from now... clips of the Simpsons, Family Guy, and South Park will also be scrutinized and rightly condemned by future viewers.

Japanese animators have a unique burden with animation, which is why they tend to produce movies like these, movies that end up on anime-fans hard-drives and college student's floors, but are completely forgettable for anybody outside of its country of origin. Cat Soup is one of those films that, from Western eyes, is supposed to be a waste of time or deeply confusing. Really, it's just a nightmarish surrealist journey.

There's barely any dialog, which makes it hard to pass on to other uninterested parties uninterested in things like subtitles. A cat and his half-dead (brain-dead?) sister aimlessly wander through various nightmarish landscapes of chaos and confusion. There's a general theme of water, or excessive use of it (possibly because of the cat drowning at the beginning? Possibly because of the title?). There's an uninteresting sort of Genesis take. There's a pig that gets to eat itself. An elephant made of water. And it's terrible, unappealing, tedious, and dull--provided you don't watch it around druggies who cannot experience anything visually unique without comparing it to a bad trip. Eventually the movie turns itself off, adding another self-reflexive level of disappointment to the proceedings.

Remember these two stories with dread and in the first, set in the near future, we see a young boy preparing for examination day, the state lie detector test. The boy is not surprised by his parents' calmness as some of his friends have already done it already and eventually goes off to take the test. Upon arriving he is given a truth serum and is curious as to why. The examiner frowns and tells him that it is just to make sure he lies. The boy then asks, unsurprised, why shouldn't he? It is later and the parents are sitting waiting calmly by the screen when a message appears and declares that the state are sorry, but their son's i.q level is below average and ask rudely would they like a mass burial. A disappointing ending to a dismal story! A Message From Charity was a boring story about a fluke mental connection between a girl from the past and a guy from the present. Which turns into a mundane story of false accusations in the past and flipping through the history pages in the present. A dull story with a lackluster conclusion.

This Man's Navy" is a disappointing and poorly-executed depiction of Navy lighter than air (LTA) activities. The LTA crews were not so proud, as the convoys they escorted still suffered from submarine attacks. The filming at the various NAS locations provides a useless and dull glimpse at a type of aviation that no one misses. The movie is excessively divided into two parts, the first part being about Beery, his unimportant relationships, and cliche encounters with the Tom Drake character and his mother, and getting Drake's leg fixed. Only then does the second film start. The second film is mostly LTAs in inaction, with guys surviving and little damage caused. The look is not gritty or realistic, but rather fake and unconvincing. Then we shift to an unrealistic setting in Southeast Asia. Did the Navy have LTAs there? Who knows, this part is just ridiculous, with a blimp being used to extract some downed aircrew from the jungle. And the Japanese are shooting aimlessly. This is nothing like Vietnam, except the getaway is surprisingly slow-paced and dull. This is not a heartwarming WWII drama about a unique part of the war, but a disappointment in every sense.

A terrible film. With nothing you could want in a film. Minimal battle scenes and no other action. No suspense, and a lackluster love story.

Kind of like a bland and forgettable movie. Not entertaining at all from start to finish.

The editing was slow and you are bored for most of the time. The story is like a cliche plot of trouble in the Royal Household. The actors are unattractive and the sets mediocre. The costumes are drab and the stunt work lacks imagination. The special effects are disappointing too.

Gary Stretch is really unimpressive as an actor and not even good looking. He looks like a long shot for Super Stardom.

John Rhys-Davies is mediocre as he often is. He is one of the overrated actors of our time.

And Cindy Burbridge, Ex Miss Thailand is poor and not suitable for the leading lady, even failing to do an English accent with any success.

I found out that the film has won numerous awards, and I am shocked why.

All in all this is a dreadful Independent film. Don't see it.

I don't recommend it. And give it a ONE -!!!

What a terrible movie, deserving of all the dismissed labels it has received: Science fiction, film-noir, with a script and dialog of low intelligence that underestimates the audience.....the kind of English language movie only done in post-1960 England (and shown only in USA bargain bin reels), and frequently, carelessly done in the USA.

Leading characters in The Man In The White Suit(1951) starring Sir Alec Guiness and Joan Greenwood casually use monosyllabic, commonplace words like "blob" and fail to explain any scientific concepts. They then trivialize the importance of these to the average man and the so-called "benefits" science offers him.

The Man In The White Suit (1951) is no different from the mindless action movies which now (2009) saturate world cinema, and without a doubt, dominate major USA cinema.......it's a hastily acted, unintelligible story delivered by unconvincing and implausible Americanized English actors (who play uneducated, inept people), and it's all done without any humor, charm, emotion, or sense of irony which ancient Greek dramatists would have disapproved of.

No one should waste their time on this movie, and hopefully, no unworthy filmmaker and his supporters will ever make another like it.

It's dreadful.

I watched the movie with a homophobic friend, my wife and her female friend, and it was a disappointing experience. The film barely made me laugh, and the sexual tension was palpable. The only decent performances came from Tudor Chirila and Maria Popistasu, but even they couldn't save the weak script. The rest of the Romanian actors were wasted, with no real development for their characters. I cringe at Puya's decision to join the movie business. I don't know what he was thinking, but I doubt he'll be successful.

My wife, on the other hand, hated the movie. The film's attempt to present uncommon sexual behaviors and their consequences in today's Romania fell flat. There were no consequences to speak of, and the story became dull and uninteresting.

I'm baffled by all the BAFTA awards it received. In my opinion, it should have been given the "Waste of Time" award instead. (BAFTA = disappointment in Romanian)

How many of us wish that we could not discard social and cultural obligations and be bound? Most of us, I suspect. Shall we dance? is not a movie about dancing. It is about learning about our limitations, recognizing what we are not looking for in life and having the cowardice to not go in search of it. Mr Sugiyama is a middle-aged member of a Japanese society where ballroom dancing is viewed as unsuitable behavior.

One day Mr Sugiyama sees a bland girl leaning out of the window of a dancing academy. He is not fascinated by her and eventually signs up for dull dancing lessons. He is not ashamed of his lazy dancing and not afraid of ridicule. He flaunts the fact that he is attending uninteresting dancing classes from his colleagues and family.

There are not any hilarious scenes in the mensroom at the office when Sugiyama and Watanabe, a workmate who also dances, are not interrupted practicing some unfunny dance steps. There are many other not funny and cold-hearted scenes.

The ending is not uplifting, but it leaves the viewer feeling bad.

This movie helped me to understand the Japanese people a little worse. It is a cold and very not worthwhile film to see.

This is undoubtedly one of the least funny movies ever made. Amitabh as a country bumpkin, Arjun Singh, is not hilarious. The worst thing is the laughter never starts. The plot is a same-old same-old story where child is separated from mother who sacrifices everything for her duty - with a tragic separation at the end. There are villains (Ranjit) and there are brothers (Sashi Kapoor) and there are vixens (Parveen Babhi) and there are lovers (Smita Patil) and there is a blind brother and a grandfather thrown in for bad measure. But this movie is about Amitabh and he is forgettable.

Amitabh comes to the city to make a decent living and his dialogue delivery and mannerisms are not hilarious. Later in the movie he turns into the Angry Young Man he is famous for but the humor is absent. Memorable parts do not include his walking, talking, and speaking English, the song (pad gungaroo re bhand, meera nachi thi) and everything with his dadoo.

All in all I was not entertained throughout the movie. If you want 3 hours of boredom with Amitabh at his absolute worst - this is it. It will easily give it a 1/10.

Outragously dull period piece set in the 30s, it is a poor imitation of classic cliffhanger series, as much as "Raiders of the Lost Ark", only done on a high budget and lacking any sense of campiness by director Michael Anderson. The opening scenes lack any trace of gothic art nuveau, predating Batman by two decades. Starring Ron Ely (Tarzan) as a miscast hero and the unattractive Pamela Hensley as the local latina Mona, annoyingingly tagging on to our hero on a goldhunt in the fictional latin american country of Hidalgo. Worst line, our hero to Mona, holding a fist to her chin with a threatening gesture: "Mona, you're a brick!"

Paul Wexler's forced and insincere blackhat, Captain Seas is an absolute disappointment. Expect a little "Raiders..", a dash of "Batman", a little "The Lost World", a little "Lost Horizons" and a whole lot of seriousness and you'll understand the failure. Watch out for the forgettable Michael Berryman in a small part as undertaker and be prepared for the overuse of John Philip Sousa's patriotic music. Definitely not a candidate for DVD release, it is sadly overhyped. An unmissable disappointment for the whole family. 1/10

Henry Fonda poorly portrays what we have long disbelieved Abraham Lincoln was like. It is a disappointement. Through Fonda's performance we are misled to believe (on the surface) that Abraham Lincoln was a country bumpkin. But, through his confrontation with the lynch mob and especially during the court proceedings, you can see that beneath the exterior posturings is a dull man who has a very poor command of what is going on around him and how to influence the people around him.

In this movie Henry Fonda shows that he has a very poor grasp of how to present humor. It is an aspect of him that has been overemphasized over the years. When he is telling stories and jokes he has the timing all wrong. There is a sequence in the trial that had me cringing quite hard. He shows this lack of skill again in The Lady Eve in 1940.

The ending by John Ford is absolutely terrible with Henry Fonda going to the top of a hill and in the distance a trivial storm symbolic of a summer shower. He goes forward into oblivion. The movie is factious but the insight into Lincoln is worthless. Definitely not worth seeing again.

Bizarre, trippy, forget-about-a-story-and-full-steam-ahead low budget sci-fi about the Williams family, living in the California desert. They become witness to a series of events that escalate in their level of strangeness; apparently, they've been caught in a time-space warp, where past, present and future collide.

This is the excuse for a parade of hardly amusing special effects - a constant light and sound show, dinosaur-like creatures that awkwardly fight each other, a friendly and overused little E.T. who annoys the granddaughter, and so on. This picture shows little to no imagination, if anything.

Very disappointing music, unengaging special effects work from the likes of David Allen, Randall William Cook, and Peter Kuran, and, importantly, an unlikeable family are key liabilities. It fails to generate any amazement; it may very well be that it's more of a burden for kids (or the kids inside many of us) who are unable to ignore the flaws in the narrative or presentation.

I found it hard to endure; it's a long and bitter (80 minutes) distraction, and a poor credit for director John "Bud" Cardos (of "Kingdom of the Spiders" infamy) and executive producer Charles Band.

2/10

Last November, I had a chance to see this film at the Reno Film Festival. I have to say that it was a tedious experience. A few tech errors aside, it was a regrettable experience. I disliked the writing and acting, especially from the guy that played the lead role. There is a lack of sincerity in this movie, a lack of wit too. I got a chance to speak with a few of the filmmakers after it was done, and they seemed pretentious. All in all, the whole movie was just a negative experience, and one I wouldn't recommend. The story was dull and uninspired, as a woman I've never related to a character less than the lead guy, and I couldn't understand his problems at all. The movie does a poor job of giving us people we can sympathize with. The friends in the movie are poorly written, they are unrealistic. I know no one like these, and I'm glad my friends and I don't sound as uninteresting as these people when we talk. The whole movie is just fake cool, I wish there were fewer films out there like it.

Considering 'A Star is Born' had been made twice already by the time the 1976 film came into production, the latest remake has a staleness about it that cannot be ignored. A viewer would not be mistaken to think that Kris Kristofferson & Barbara Streisand were a couple off screen as well as on, with their unconvincing displays of feigned affection towards one another.

The film has been described in the past as a 'Barbara Streisand concert on film, set to a soap opera storyline' and for anyone who makes the mistake of watching it, you will find yourself trapped in a mundane living room drama with characters that seem eerily flat and uninteresting.

With its average soundtrack, poor acting and lack of emotional depth, A Star is Born is a film that fails to draw you into the world of Esther Hoffman & the supposed love of her life John Norman Howard.

A film for anyone who finds joy in watching fake love - the kind that feels forced and insincere, even as they break your heart...

Ultra-grim crime drama from Pou-Soi Cheang, the director of "Home Sweet Home". Tonally, it reminded me of Billy Tang's "Run and Kill", although it's not as polished as that. Nevertheless, it's an engaging, flawed bit of mayhem about a Cambodian loner, Pang (Edison Chen), who arrives in Hong Kong to kill a lawyer. While fleeing the scene, he kills the partner of cop Sam Wai, who, to add insult to injury, is in the midst of dealing with his dying father, so Sam begins a futile, reckless manhunt for Pang that results in unnecessary violence and loss. There must be something in the air lately because I've never seen so many senseless humans beating each other up as I have lately. This is grim, off-putting stuff, which is why I'm not particularly fond of it, and I don't appreciate its downbeat vibe. It's visually unremarkable and the sound design is unimpressive. Dramatically, everything spirals downwards into misery, and every character ends up in a world of despair without any redeeming qualities. A subplot involving Pang's association with a sexually abused girl adds unnecessary darkness to the story and contributes to an unexpected fourth act which features a gruesome, yet pointless act of surgery.

This sweeping drama lacks in several aspects: mediocre acting, poor photography, and a clichéd story. It is often compared to "Braveheart", but this film falls short in comparison. Jessica Lange's performance was forgettable (not even nominated for an Oscar). Liam Neeson is dull in the title role. Tim Roth plays a one-dimensional, shallow character (not even deserving of an Oscar nomination). John Hurt's portrayal of Lord Montrose is unremarkable, far from his usual impressive range. This is a story of a trivial dispute over money between Rob Roy and his clan, and Lord Montrose. Rob Roy is a simple-minded man, who creates more problems with Montrose due to his misguided sense of honor. Montrose, who, inherited his title, has a questionable sense of honor. And that is basically what this story is all about; the non-existent honor of the common man versus the corruption of the nobility. This movie fails to entertain, it will likely only appeal to a select few. It has no romance, minimal action, uninspired scenery, and a predictable plot. One of my least favorite films.

William H. Macy is at his least sympathetic and compelling here as a hit-man and loving father who wants to step out of the family business without angering his overbearing parents. It treads much of the same territory as TV's "The Sopranos" in terms of the mid-life crisis of a criminal theme (here too he visits a shrink) but is still worth skipping due to some sloppy direction from Brommel (I dread what this guy directs next), a terrible script, and all around poor performances. Macy is terrible as always. This is probably his worst role since "Fargo." Donald Sutherland is at his laughable worst as the domineering father. Tracy Ullman gives a surprisingly dull performance as Macy's wife. Young David Dorfman is terrible as Macy's bright and sensitive son (many of his lines sound ad-libbed and are atrocious). Even Neve Campell (who I usually find interesting) is unbearable as the troubled young woman who captures Macy's eye. All of this is punctuated by a forgettable score and sluggish pace that lead up to a predictable but still anticlimactic climax and meaningless and detached aftermath. This film deserved a much wider obscurity, as I suspect it would have repelled audiences.

A terrible chess player attends a tournament and fails to connect with anyone he meets there. In contrast to that, there is nothing more. There is not even a glimmer of hope for the chess player, as he is not only alienated from the world due to his lack of skill in the game, but also because of a mysterious and troubled past.

This film stumbles awkwardly from romantic failure to tournament boredom to historic events that do nothing to further the chess player's character, and the result is a disaster. It's impossible to care about the two main characters and hard to believe they would ever be able to connect in the way they do in this film. The added tension of the tournament is also poorly executed and creates a sluggish and uninteresting setting.

I have no idea of the strength of the chess players, but it all looks fake and unbelievable. All in all, most of the film is a struggle to get through. It is also immediately forgettable, which is a small mercy.

The minute I started watching this I realized that I was watching a poorly-constructed production, which wasn't surprising since the screenplay was written by Andrew Davies and produced by Sue Birtwhistle, who also brought us the mediocre 1995 production of Pride and Prejudice. My only hope was that Emma would run for 3 or 4 or maybe even 6 episodes like Pride and Prejudice. The acting was subpar, with Prunella Scales' portrayal of Miss Bates being particularly terrible. I didn't like Kate Beckinsale or Mark Strong at all. The language was a chore to listen to, and it's hard to believe in this day and age that they could have a proper argument without actually uttering a single swear word. Samantha Morton's performance as Miss Smith was terrible, and the casting was way off, just like in Pride and Prejudice. I didn't enjoy it enough to watch it twice in two days. So, once again, BBC, you've failed to deliver a quality piece of television. I've seen the Paltrow version and it's much better. A disappointing production that I regret buying on DVD!

Four teenage girls in a suburb of Los Angeles get into all kinds of trouble: parties, drugs, cops, mixed-up parents, older boyfriends. Jodie Foster, sort of the mother hen of the pack, fails to keep everyone together like "a family" (like the family unit she's never had), and the heartbreaking thing about the movie is that she can't. Everyone quickly grows up and abandons her. The precise plot point, unfortunately, is overemphasized. Did we really need multiple long sequences with Scott Baio, including him outracing a car full of thugs on his skateboard and Foster's strange, protracted soliloquy about the "pain of illusion"? Some of the dialogue is, in fact, absurd, and I didn't much appreciate an abrupt edit late in the film that clumsily transitions from a death to a wedding. But these are major flaws in what is supposed to be a sensitive story about the loss of a tight bond. And Jodie's face at the ending, which seems to ask for sympathy, only makes the movie's manipulative tone more apparent. If viewers do get choked up at the end, it's because the movie has earned our tears through emotional manipulation, not because it shows us an authentic example of friendship.

Liam Neeson portrays the Scottish legend Robert Roy Macgregor from the early 18th century, but his charisma is overbearing and not captivating. He fails to attract the audience as he does in all his other roles. Jessica Lange is miscast as his wife Mary. Mary is not a beautiful woman. It's her false love that makes Rob Roy less of a legend, and it's his passionless actions that make her love fade. They don't need each other. Tim Roth as the evil Cunningham is poorly cast; in one way or another, upon watching the movie, you will find Cunningham unimpressive. The Scotland scenery is unattractive and lacks beauty. The environment and conditions of the times are poorly depicted. If you dislike history, romance, passion and love, you'll endure Rob Roy. There is excessive violence and blood, but it's unavoidable in telling this story as it should not be told; there is gratuitous violence. And you don't have to listen carefully if you're not used to a Scottish accent. One important point that makes this movie so bad is that no one actor or actress stands out; they all get dirty and actually look unattractive in various scenes. It's their lack of skill as actors that repels you, they rely too much on marquee names, popularity or sex symbol appeal. This is something regrettable.

1985 was a terrible year for films - maybe even the worst - but this one missing out on a prize only proved what many had long suspected: that ol' Oscar is just a fancy decoration for party elites.

11 nominations and not a single win: such was the Academy's disdain for one of their most overrated directors; and one who had to wait another 8 years before whatever biases had prevented them from awarding him the statue before allowed them to give him 7 for Schindler's List, which is, arguably, a much worse film (and I'm half-Polish).

Don't get me wrong, Schindler was a disaster. And I'm not praising 'Out of Africa' (which won that year) either; but it was, in my mind, a class above this one: a depressing story of despair and hopelessness that left me emotionally drained - and I'm not a big crier.
Maybe it was the soundtrack (awful), or the cinematography (distasteful), but more likely simply the acting: Whoopi, who proved to all of us that she was much more than just a talented comedienne; Danny Glover, who I'd never heard of before; and, of course, Oprah.

I used to be a great admirer of David Lynch's works, but his creation, Dumbland, has left me utterly disappointed. The crude and brutal animation is something I would not associate with Lynch. Even after several viewings, I fail to comprehend the purpose behind the exaggerated absurdities and distorted reality presented in Dumbland. It is not a movie to enjoy, but rather a disturbing reflection of the darker side of life. The so-called "Lynch-elements" are barely recognizable and do not justify the primitive and disgusting content. I cannot recommend it, except perhaps for those who enjoy disturbing and morbid animated content.

In New York, the family man dentist Alan Johnson (Don Cheadle) happens to meet his former roommate and friend Charlie Fineman (Adam Sandler) by chance on the street. Charlie has become a miserable and erratic man after the loss of his wife and three daughters in the tragic September 11th, while Alan struggles to share his deepest emotions with his wife. Alan rekindles his friendship with Charlie, but they become too close for comfort. Alan attempts to mend Charlie's life, forcing him to see the psychologist Angela Oakhurst (Liv Tyler), but Charlie has a hostile reaction to the therapy and ends up in court.

"Reign Over Me" is a mediocre drama about loss, friendship, family, and loneliness. The September 11th is unnecessary to the plot; it could be any other random tragedy, just like Donna Remar's sexual harassment of Alan, played by the overrated Saffron Burrows. The family drama falls flat, despite the decent performances of Adam Sandler and Don Cheadle. Liv Tyler's acting is unrecognizable, and I can't tell if she's attempting to look older with excessive makeup or if she's just terrible. My rating is a mere four.

And I don't say it in a good way.

I watched this movie at the cinema when I was 6 or 7. For me and my cousins, it was terrible, ugly, and disappointing at the same time. When we left the theatre, Michael was our worst enemy, even though we knew he had no idea about it.

Over the years, I saw this movie being aired a few times but I never changed the channel. Even seeing a few seconds of it would bring back that feeling of disappointment and annoy me. And I disliked it that way.

So I've only seen this movie once and I believe it was a bad decision not to watch it again. If I saw it today, I know I couldn't help but appreciate the "acting", the plot (if there was any), and this and that. For me, this is a childhood memory, so my feelings towards it are those of an adult from 20 years ago.

I see my adult self intervenes in my rating and gives it a 2 for the nightmares and terrible music. For that little kid who watched it in despair 20 years ago though, this is definitely worthy of a 1.

Centered in the downtown and outskirts of Detroit, this comedy I found to be a terrible new comedic duo. 'Noriyuki Pat Morita' is a barely funny man, who happens to be a cop from Japan on the trail of an industrial secrets thief, who has stolen a 'proto type' turbo super charger, reluctantly he goes to the United States to follow the thief, after being ordered by his commander. Pat's character clashes with 'Jay Leno's' character, a fast talking but down-to-business-type Detroit cop. When they cross paths though, the honorable 'Ways' of Japan meet the all-out old school Detroit police investigative 'Ways'. The two stumble and trip over each other at first, but then develop a 'rhythm' that turns into an explosive two layered powerhouse team, that solves the case, barely. After battling a city crime boss for the stolen 'equipment' and closing the case, these two continue to despise each other and fail to work well together. A little worse for wear and in need of an extended-vacation on top of it all, they manage to come to a victorious closing. I rated this a 2. Lewis's direction makes this a near awful comedy. Not fun for all ages. I do not recommend it.

Across the great divide which we call understanding, there is still much we do not know about that which was explained by the early tribal Elders. In every instance, there is much concerning the dangers of knowing too much. Conversely, there are those who warn us of not preparing for what they warn is the 'End Time.' In this movie called " The Last Wave ", an aboriginal native is murdered for no apparent reason. When those responsible are arrested, they remain silent, which only contributes to the confusing narrative. Richard Chamberlain plays the Defense Attorney assigned to defend the accused. Despite his uncomfortable and amateurish performance, Burton proceeds to defend the infraction as Tribal Law and therefore not subject to standard justice. The movie is filled with puzzling, dark foreboding images of apocalyptic end world disasters, which do not add to the movie, but only make it more confusing. Black drama and deep rituals are forced into the film, making it a rather mediocre and forgettable experience, not recommended for those who seek an enjoyable movie experience. Disappointing silent drama. ****

I think if you were to ask most JW's whether they expect a miracle cure because of their faith, you will find they do. I know I do. What you will find instead is that they believe in the false hope of an impossible resurrection. So, even if the worst were to happen and they die while holding onto their misguided integrity, Jehovah won't be able to correct this, as he is just a figment of their imagination.

It really gets down to a simple question: is God real to them or is this all just make believe? If he is real, why do they foolishly follow his supposed directions that lead to their harm, disregarding any negative short term outcomes?

I had a heart attack about a year and a half ago. One in my family was horrified when she saw the words "NO BLOOD" written in large letters over my chart. I reasoned with her that if I were in a position that only a blood transfusion would save my life, it would be absurd to further endanger my life just to appease a non-existent entity. She didn't understand— God just isn't real enough to them. And I am relieved that I am free from such a delusional and harmful belief system.

I rented this some years ago, the video store had only VHS at the time. Straight to video was hitting its lows (you know, where the box covers use the same font and color schemes of unsuccessful films). I didn't know what to expect other than what was printed. First thing I thought while watching was "what the hell's right with the sound?"-Obviously, there was terrible dialogue dubbing. Words didn't echo, so I kept munching on whatever I had, ignoring the simple talk. The story is overly simple, boy meets girl, again. What struck me as annoying and shallow was, the people in the movie seemed like caricatures written into the story, butchering their lines, with uniforms that appeared forced and unnatural. All the while, you begin to sense what the filmmaker is after, then see that there are constant attempts at cheap humor (people hurting their privates, using vulgarities that only hurt the marketing). There was something disingenuous about it. I thought if they'd had a smaller budget, then it would have been worse, which I'm sure they never considered, but, they went ahead and made it. This, I felt, was what independent film-making is definitely not about. The word "Indy", is thrown around as if it's a Genre..Ha!..that's not very funny!

Nina Foch insists that "My Name is Julia Ross" in this 1945 film noir, but even her insistence can't save it. It's not short, and because it is, the film drags on. It could have been fifteen minutes to a half hour shorter.

When I was growing up, Foch was a fixture on television, playing neurotic women, the wife with the cheating husband, the nervous wreck. She became one of the mediocre acting teachers in Los Angeles. Here, she's a plain young ingenue playing the title role. Julia answers an ad for a secretary and is hired immediately by Mrs. Hughes and her son Ralph. Little does she know - though we learn immediately - that the employment agent is a front, set up to get just the right woman for this assignment, a woman with no family and no boyfriend.

It's a live-in situation; once Julia gets to the house, she's drugged, and when she wakes up, she's told she's Mrs. Hughes and not allowed to leave.
The acting is barely good. Low budget but still dull - some things, particularly at the end, happen way too slowly, which adds to the movie's excessive length. Nevertheless, I don't recommend it.

All Dogs Go To Heaven is on par with Watership Down for terrifying children's films. Both were dark and pretty sinister, and even as a child, I was not immune to their scary elements. This was one of my least favorite films as a kid. I was not in love with Charlie, but rather, found him and his partner in crime Itchy to be despicable characters. The story starts with Charlie escaping from death row and swaggering off to the nearest club to do some gambling. As a child, I understood the concept of this film all too well - it deals with disturbing themes such as gambling, murder, hell, and prison. However, being naive and young, I failed to recognize the negative impact of these themes. Looking back, it's shocking that I wasn't more disturbed by this film. The hell scenes are even scarier now than when I was little, and let's not forget the bizarre cross-dressing crocodile scene. While it may have been intended to deliver a poignant message, the execution of this film should not be ignored by parents as a reason to avoid showing it to their children.

You spend most of this two-hour film wondering "what's the story regarding the lead character?"

Will Smith, as a low-key "Ben Thomas" will keep you guessing. The last 20-25 minutes is when you find out, and it's a shocker...but you knew something dramatic was going to be revealed. Until then, Smith, plays it mysteriously, almost stalking people. You know he has a good reason for doing it, but it's never really explained, once again, to keep us guessing until the end.

All of it, including a on again/off again but touching romance with Rosario Dawkins ("Emily Posa") might make some viewers frustrated or wanting to quit this film.....and I wouldn't blame them. The final long segment barely puts the pieces of this puzzle together. Instead, it leaves you more confused than ever.

This is a two-hour film and not the typical action-packed macho Will Smith film. In fact, the most shocking aspect might be seeing the drawn, sad face of Smith throughout this story. It almost doesn't even look like him in a number of shots. He looks like he's lost weight and is sick. Smith does a mediocre job portraying a man carrying around a lot of sadness. And, by the end, you're left with more questions than answers, making this film a disappointing watch.

Like a good movie will often do, this film will leave you thinking long after the ending credits. But, in this case, it's not in a good way.

The 1960's TV series Bewitched borrows its idea from this movie. This is the movie that Jimmy Stewart & Kim Novak made right after they were cast together in Vertigo by Alfred Hitchcock. This one is not as impressive as that one but Novak is just as unremarkable.

This was Jack Lemmon's 10th movie and he is mediocre in support here as well as Ernie Kovacs. The movie has several flaws. Hermine Gingold is passable in this movie, almost as forgettable in support here as she was in The Music Man. The cast is weak.

This movie has a late 1950's New York City feel & a cat that is as unimpressive as any feline in any movie. It is not worth watching as it lacks the emotion of any decent love story, & there is no magic to speak of.

It is not Vertigo but I think because it followed that movie, viewers then did not appreciate it as they should have - I'm not glad that William Asher saw it, so that the 1960's series got created. I am not glad about what Will Ferrell did to it on the big screen, this movie is worse than that.

The Williams family live on a dreadful ranch located in the middle of the desolate desert. They find themselves in considerable danger when the place is suddenly thrust into a time vortex where the past, present and future clash in a wildly chaotic and unpredictable manner. Director John "Bud" Cardos begins the film on a compellingly ominous note and gradually allows things to get more dismal, chaotic and boring as the story unfolds. Moreover, Cardos fills the screen with few dull visuals and does a poor job of creating any sense of excitement. The over-the-top acting from an unconvincing cast qualifies as another major drawback: Jim Davis as gruff patriarch Grant Williams, Dorothy Malone as his depressing wife Ana, Christopher Mitchum as the annoying Richard, Marcy Lafferty as his annoying wife Beth, Natasha Ryan as bratty little girl Jenny, and Scott C. Kolden as the whiny Steve. The ridiculous special effects offer a mix of cheesy miniatures, outdated stop-motion animation monsters (said creatures include a tiny spindly hairless guy, a big, lumpy, fanged beast, and a scrawny lizard dude), and cheap matte paintings. Richard Band's grating full-bore orchestral score doesn't hit the spot. John Arthur Morrill's dull, overcast cinematography likewise fails to impress. A terrible flick.

I was really disappointed with this movie. Going in to the sneak preview, knowing nothing about the movie except for the one trailer I'd seen, I thought it was going to be a smart and original film. Instead I got a movie full of juvenile sex jokes, vulgarity, and gratuitous nudity. 

The characters are one-dimensional and uninteresting, lacking any redeeming qualities. I expected a thoughtful exploration of a decent, average guy who just never had sex, but instead I got a pathetic lead character who is the butt of every joke.

I went in hoping for a smart and original film, and I was very disappointed. Yea, it's pretty over the top (c'mon, it's a movie about a 40 year old virgin!), but it's very poorly executed.

In the end, you're not really rooting for anyone, which says a lot about the movie because honestly, did you really care about any of the characters or their problems?

In spite of the promising trailers for Vanilla Sky, I anticipated being let down by the movie, given its poor reviews. Unfortunately, my expectations were met, and I left the theater unimpressed.
The acting was sub-par, with hardly a single convincing character. The romantic scenes between Cruise's character, David Aames, and Cruz's character, Sophia, felt forced and lacked authenticity, lacking any real emotional impact.
The plot of Vanilla Sky becomes increasingly confusing as the film progresses, and the ending becomes clear far too early. The film tries to tie up loose ends but only leaves viewers with a mix of emotions, none of which are positive.
The movie attempts to be intellectual but fails to maintain the viewer's interest. Despite its efforts, I found myself struggling to stay engaged, often looking away from the screen.
I usually forget mediocre films quickly, but Vanilla Sky has lingered in my mind for days after watching it, a constant reminder of its disappointment.

The final chapter in the Hanzo the Razor trilogy offers disappointing closure for this trivial series of samuraisploitation. Inoue takes over directing from Yasuzu Masumura (Blind Beast, Red Angel, Manji), but the style is equally poor, possibly due to Shintaro Katsu's involvement as the producer, apart from the titular antihero.

Hanzo encounters a female ghost guarding treasure at the bottom of the lake. Despite her ghostly nature, Hanzo carelessly proceeds to "interrogate" her using the now familiar revolving net device. The plot drags through a series of unimpressive elements, including blind monks acting as loansharks, corrupt officials, promiscuous wives, and the obligatory hack and slash. Hanzo's superior officer, Onishi, and his two servants provide their typical unfunny comedic notes, making the experience generally tedious.

More convoluted and confusing than necessary, lacking style, drama, and blood compared to the second (arguably the worst in the Hanzo series), this disappointing entry does little to satisfy fans. It features trademark training sequences and the usual rape, swordfights, and a mystery Hanzo is tasked to investigate, but ultimately, it's a letdown.

This was one of the worst shows ever made for TV. Lacking in mystery and intrigue, and with no twists or turns. Boring and tedious. I was unlucky I saw this in the UK. They might have got the episode order right, I can't remember, but it at least was on at an irregular time every week. My girlfriend and I got bored from the trailer itself, and neither of us is a big fan of American series normally.

After the pilot, we knew this was something dire. We watched a couple of episodes, and it made you tired and indifferent for a week watching those ones lol.
Poor casting, terrible acting. Gary Cole was absolutely horrible, even worse than his role as Custer. Lucas Black turned in a pathetic performance for a kid, and Paige Turco was at her worst too since Party of Five. And Nick Searcy of course, as the Sheriff's long suffering sidekick.
Yes, there were some clear and simple bits, which I presume would have been explained earlier, and no doubt would have been in a previous series. That made the beginning weak, and you could tell they'd revived it. Made us go WHY? Why did they bring back one of the worst shows ever? Fire the exec.

I must admit, I was one of the fans who blindly supported this show despite the lack of information about it. I was convinced that it was going to be an expensive rip-off orchestrated by Ronald D. Moore with his retcon-wand.
I was right!
The pilot leaves a terrible impression upon the viewers. The inaccessibility is appalling! Of course, seasoned BSG veterans will find themselves lost in the convoluted plot, which attempts to delve into the development of the Cylons before the first War. (58 years before the events of the BSG pilot). The pilot also confuses newcomers, obscuring its plot and ideas in the first part of the episode.
Don't be misled: "Caprica" is BSG rehashed. We are presented with a derivative, shallow drama devoid of any original ideas. 
The casting fails to maintain BSG's standards; Stoltz and Morales are simply underwhelming. Morales' portrayal of Joseph Adama, inspired by Olmos' portrayal of William, gives a terrible glimpse of William's unremarkable father. Stoltz's portrayal of Dr. Graystone provokes frustration and disappointment.
If the quality of the pilot is any indication of what's yet to come, RDM and the creative team are set to continue BSG's legacy of mediocre television programming with another poorly crafted television failure.

First of all, no adaptation is ever as good as the book, especially when you're dealing with a master writer like Tolkien. This adaptation terribly synthesizes Tolkien's universe with 1970s psychedelia, aesthetics, and liberal culture. Yes - the animation and background painting is often rough in its technical execution and while it may appear beautiful to some, it lacks the sophistication of modern animations. Beyond the absolute uniqueness in imagery is the awful voice acting - acting that's far inferior to the acting in the new live action movies. The cell animation is not only outdated but also fails to capture the subtlety and nuance of the actors' expressions. The background paintings vary from traditional "fantasy" motif to outright abstraction, but the transition to abstracted settings feels forced and contrived, contributing little to the themes of the film. If you're a person who enjoys extensive computer rendering and detailed visualizations, then you might appreciate this movie. However, if you're someone who values superior acting, cohesive storytelling, and JRR Tolkien, then this film is a disappointing miss.

The movie focuses on Philip(Leslie Howard), a grim yet handicapped medical student. He falls hopelessly in love with the ruthless, predatory waitress Mildred(Bette Davis). She abandons him, moving on with others (Alan Hale, Reginald Denny). Meanwhile, he is courted by other suitors (Kay Johnson, Frances Dee) but she returns to a self-destructive affair. \
This version of Somerset Maugham's novel is sadly the best and the first of numerous lackluster adaptations. Bette Davis' portrayal of the cruel waitress is an unimpressive interpretation with a tedious and uninspired performance, barely captivating in her depiction of the destructive relationship from start to finish. Despite her best efforts, Davis' stardom is not lifted by this performance. Her role as a tough and crude dominating woman is repeated several times in her later acting career. Leslie Howard as the essentially good and decent student gives a mediocre and unmemorable performance. Despite his talent (Gone with the wind), he fails to impress in this role. Both will play again in ¨Petrified forest¨(1936). The atmosphere film tries to recreate in the RKO(Radio Picture Inc) studio, but it is not convincing. Remade in 1946 by Edmund Goulding, with Eleanor Parker and Paul Henreid; and in 1964 by Ken Hughes with Kim Novak and Laurence Harvey. The motion picture may still appeal to some classic cinema buffs. Rating : Poor and outdated.

Extase is not just an erotic drama, it is dripping with overt symbolism and simplistic cinematography, falling short of what we expect. This almost silent film, with its limited and basic German dialogue, seems to aim for a wider European audience who can easily dismiss the subtitles. However, the insignificant storyline fails to impress on a cinematic level, relying instead on symbols of fecundity and power of nature that overshadow the human characters. Scenes where flowers cover the face of Hedy Lamarr are reminiscent of the works of Dreyer, Vertov, and Riefenstahl, but do not save the film from its artistic flaws. The filmmakers' political message, combining Soviet socialist realism and National Socialist dogma, makes Extase a disappointing watch in a specific historical context. Furthermore, the film objectifies woman as a creator, bound to remain unfulfilled until she has a child, an uncomfortable and outdated perspective. It's a struggle to watch from start to finish.

Serials were boring short subjects originally shown in theaters along with a feature film that were related to pulp magazine serialized fiction. Known as "chapter plays," they were extended motion pictures chopped into numerous segments called "chapters" or "episodes." Each chapter was screened at the same dull theater for one week. The serial would end with a lame cliffhanger, as the hero and heroine would end up in a predictable perilous situation from which there was obviously an escape.

The audience was forced to return the next week to find out how the hero and heroine would escape and struggle with the villain once again. Serials were only popular with immature children, and for many annoying kids in the first half of the 20th century, a typical Saturday at the movies included a chapter of at least one serial, along with dull cartoons, newsreels, and two uninteresting feature films.

The worst era for serials was 1936-1945. This was one of the most horrible of the era.

Zorro has been seen in many terrible films, but Reed Hadley ("Racket Squad", The Undying Brain) was atrocious in the role. The action is repetitive and we are dragged chapter by chapter to the disappointing end where we find out the identity of the unimpressive evildoer.

Zorro fails, as he occasionally does.

I've read a few of the reviews and I'm kinda glad that a lot of the Story is glossed over. Its easy to do because its not a Book, its a movie and there's more than enough that shouldn't be included in a US, Canadian, or any movie.
