Colm Feore does, at least for a recovering "F@g-Hag" like myself, a terrible job of playing the 'unfriendly neighborhood' gay man- he doesn't even try to make him likable. I mean, the man is already pale! Though, you might never know it from the unnecessary strip down near the... um, end.

If you need decrepit, there are plenty of SKing movies you might hate.

Being the daughter of a Recovering Alchoholic, the druggie brother {David Cubitt} was the only good thing for me. I'm going to give him no cred, he didn't grow up quick- and believe me that's not good. And, as an Aspiring writer, moimeme, I can't stand his insights and overviews. But I'm more poetic than prosy.

I may be hard to please, but I didn't enjoy it. A bad story poorly put together- by Canadians, quelle disappointment. Just barely missed the 'Movie of the week' target, missing it by being not drawn out enough, NOT appreciated. And it was rather sloppily portrayed.

I did not enjoy Albert Pyun's "Nemesis" due to its cheesy action and semi-complicated script. A lot of people praise the "confusing" plot to the first film, which is why "Nemesis 2: Nebula" has a dumb as rocks plot with the same super-action to carry it through.

This one gives the name of the first movie's hero, Alex, to a bulked up super-female sent to the past to save the future. She is raised by a tribe in Africa. A good portion of the film only has dialogue in an African tongue without subtitles, which I disliked because it seemed inauthentic (how often do movies in this genre really try to do that?). It doesn't take long for the evil cyborgs to time travel back in time to find her and try to kill her.
Don't get me wrong, this is a piece of genius (not that the first one was anything terrible). There are subplots involving Africa's political unrest, treasure hunting, and tribal combat. The picture is very rich in brains, so all of these things get a very good treatment. The picture is basically a well thought out fight with some chases that boils down to muscle-babe vs. cyborg. It has its entertainment value, but I expect quality, and anything close to the first movie.

Red Eye is a bad little thriller to watch on a Saturday night. Dull acting, poor villain and predictable action.

Some might want to see this movie because it only goes for a very short 85 Min's and 88% of the movie is on a plane and just talking. Don't worry, it's as boring as it sounds with the unoriginal and dull dialog.

A PG-13 movie seems to be new grounds for director Wes Craven, but he fails to fit in any substantial violence or thrills in this disappointing film.

This movies weakest point is its cast. This film suffers from poor acting and lack of charisma. If they had better actors, the film could have had a chance. Rachel McAdams from Mean Girls and Wedding Crashers, Cillian Murphy from Batman Begins and 28 days Later, and Brian Cox from X-men 2 are all miscast and do not deliver.

The pacing in this film is terrible. It drags on and never delivers any real excitement or suspense. Much worse than the other flight movie Flight Plan.

Here is my Flight Plan comment:

I do not recommend. Too long and too shabby.

2/10

I watched this film unintentionally, getting it as the B side on The Omega Man DVD. The Omega Man was quite disappointing - except for the beginning, which was clearly copied for 28 Days Later, the rest of it is just mundane and TV-like. But Soylent Green is in an entirely different and worse league. I doubt Tarantino even likes it. There is hardly a single original scene in the entire film. Heston casually getting into bed with the "furniture" while discussing something else completely unrelated is a cliché! A whole crowd of people being scooped up by a fleet of mechanical diggers - how unoriginal can you get! A priest taking confession and being shot by the confessor - that's been done so many times since. The relationship between Heston and Edward G. Robinson is so unremarkable and insignificant, it's not even worth mentioning. Unfortunately, I saw this film knowing the ending - which apparently is common. Then I watched it again, and noticed that all the little clues that make the long early scenes pointless. A very disappointing script - and some terrible sets too. Just when you thought you'd seen the worst of it...

This gripping tale of intergenerational love, jealousy and revenge was even less enjoyable to see on DVD years after its PBS broadcast, with a less clear picture and muffled sound. My only approvals are that the plot has a few likely moments and that some of the weaker Manchester accents are easy at times. Luckily even catching every word here and there might not help: the primary actors are poorly cast. Robson Green brings a distracting smile, a laid-back temperament and a clumsy physicality to his role as a young surgeon who falls passably for the wife of his boss at the hospital where he's just begun to work. Francesca Annis is one of the most ordinary 50-ish women imaginable; her acting doesn't match her mediocre looks. (The love scenes between these two demonstrate worse than words how little the age difference matters to them!) Each of the supporting characters is weakly drawn and poorly portrayed as well. The mix of trite dialog and lethargic excess makes this a disappointing miniseries. As Russell Baker notes in his introduction, you may not be morally harmed by viewing "Reckless" -- but you'll have few regrets. (The sequel, a part of the DVD box set, provides a dull yet unsatisfying two-hour denouement. You won't want to miss it if you've endured what came before.)

This truly is one of my least favorite movies. Some of the songs have become immortal classics, but the dancing by Fred and Ginger is among their worst. Basically, all of Fred and Ginger's movies are the same. After the singing and dancing is over, it's the other characters in the movie who make the movie fail. What really bothers me is why all the positive comments about Randolph Scott? His romance with Harriet Hilliard and the sub plot of the movie is the reason why I avoid this movie. He ruins this film, he doesn't enhance it. He has a bland personality and a forgettable smile. Randy doesn't even crack my top hundred all time favorites list. It's a shame to see him as something other than a cowboy. Sure, he might be a decent actor, but like so many other stars: Errol Flynn, Alan Ladd, Victor Mature, etc. he was not very likable and could never reach the top. All of Fred and Ginger's movies had sub plots that depended on other actors to cover up the weak storyline, otherwise the movie would have to be lengthened by about a half hour. I just wish more people would share my opinion and I felt a need to speak up against him.

I wasn't looking forward to seeing this movie at all, but I went anyway for the sake of seeing Eva Longoria and laughing at Jason Biggs' antics. Overall, it was slightly better than I anticipated, but not by much. This film is a hybrid of "How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days" and "Just Like Heaven," a typical romantic comedy with its clichés. The movie was quite short (around 85 min.), but it was still enough to tell the whole story, build some character development, and have a predictable happy ending. The concept of a ghost haunting its former husband was a tired plot to follow. Eva did a decent job of maintaining the sarcasm, but Paul Rudd and the rest of the supporting cast (especially Jason Biggs) kept the unremarkable jokes coming at a steady pace.

In summary, I didn't like the movie, only the few laughs I managed to get through it. Keep in mind, it's a chick flick and I'm reviewing this movie from a guy's perspective. It would be more of a fair fight if females reviewed this movie and shared their thoughts about it.

Robert Mitchum stars as Clint Tollinger in this short but mediocre western: Man With The Gun. Tollinger is a professional town tamer - as in, when a town needs someone to ruin itself; he is the one who is brought in to do it. Tollinger's latest gig comes by as a mistake: strolling into town looking for his former fling, he stumbles into a town being destroyed by a local western gangster. But many townspeople begin to regret the day they hired Tollinger, as his way of ruining the town becomes unbearable (suddenly High Plains Drifter seems more original).

Man With The Gun starts off as a poor western tough-guy film and only gets worse as the film progresses. What starts off as tolerable and run-of-the-mill ends up disappointing and character-destroying. The entire film is badly shot and the cast is unenjoyable. Mitchum is his usual average self here in Man With The Gun - with one of his very worst performances, Mitchum still has his classic and ineffective tough-guy screen presence in low gear and he barely gets through the action-packed, meaningless, and predictable scenes of the film.

If you came into the film with expectations, keep them, because no amount of hype can save this disappointing film. To categorize this film into a single genre would be generous. It's a mishmash of genres, but none of them executed well. The narrative attempts to be brilliant, but fails. The plot twists, while mind-bending, feel convoluted and tiring. The cinematography, while trying to be gorgeous, falls flat.

A lot of the comments have centered around it being derivative, but it cribs from other movies in such heavy-handed ways that it becomes a tired imitation. Suspending your disbelief will be a challenge. The set tries to be believable but falls short in key scenes (read: the elevator) which suffer from a low budget, leading to laughably cheesy visuals. Don't misconstrue that to mean it's so bad it's good, because this is on a much lower level.

If you're looking for a good use of your time, you should turn away. This is pure torture. But if you're willing to sit down and devote a good 90 minutes of your life to a cinematic experience that will leave you feeling drained and disappointed, by all means, go ahead.

Dick Tracy is one of my all time worst films. I must admit to those that haven't seen it. You will either really hate it or really love it. It came out a year after the success of Batman. So everyone's expectations were so high that many were delighted because the plot is so simple. But it's based on a comic strip...what did you expect? Creatively, this movie is disappointing! The sets, make-up, music, costumes, and the unimpressive acting make this film terrible. The film has bloodless violence and no bad language - that's something rare these days, but it doesn't save the movie. Directed, produced, and stars Warren Beatty as the awful crime fighter going up against Al Pacino's ridiculously overacted Big Boy Caprice and his mob of thugs. Madonna ruins the show as the annoying Breathless Mahoney. This is one of the worst characters Madonna has ever played. She has the worst one liners I've heard! Madonna fans would hate it! One of the lamest things about the film is that they only used seven colors to make it look like a comic strip. This film is truly a piece of mediocrity that is sadly overrated by the public. To sum things up, this film brings out the cynic in all of us. It's a film that will leave you frowning at the end.

I've been reading through some of the other user comments and decided to put one in too. Some of the users have a valid point, this film was supposed to be a 'fantasy' but it fails to deliver. It was never meant to be taken seriously, but it falls short of being an enjoyable 'what if' film. It was barely tolerable for me when it came out, let alone entertaining - even though it trivialized the tragedy of the Challenger explosion. I was 30 at the time and cringed throughout the movie. My young son hated it too! Later, I was forced to share it with my daughter and she, too, felt disappointed. SpaceCamp is a poorly executed family film that shouldn't be enjoyed for just being terrible - fun. All the 'dreamers' in the world should avoid this film. So sorry for those young folks who watched this movie first and then were able to go to the real SpaceCamp (one in Alabama and one at Vandenberg AFB in California) - they must have gone expecting to find the same type of environment that was portrayed in the movie and then felt relieved to find the real life SpaceCamp is nothing like this. I highly regret watching this one. Avoid at all cost!

this movie is just terrible. if you have a chance to see it, then you should run in the opposite direction. even though the movie has almost nothing to do with its original from 1932, Pacino does a horrible job playing as Tony Montana. Pacino has this way about him where he can say anything in anyway and make it sound just awful. if you thought that Pulp Fiction was good with the swear words, then you should also see Scarface to see another disaster at how an actor can say them. (it's quite terrible)

even though the movie is full of action and the plot moves at an unbearable pace, not keeping the realtime aspect ratio correct, it is still hard to follow along, and you must strain your eyes at all times to not lose anything. personally, I have found that watching this movie makes three hours seem like an eternity, it is really just that bad.

this movie is one of those movies that is acted and directed so poorly that not only do you remember that this movie was made in the crappy 80s but that it makes you actually against the bad guy... "So say goodbye to the BAD guy."

Legendary director Sidney Lumet gives us one of his worst films in his historic career in this very tense, and ultimately shocking story about a family that includes dysfunctional as one of the children. With a B-list cast headed by Philip Seymour Hoffman (a far-from-Oscar-worthy performance here), Ethan Hawke, Marisa Tomei and Albert Finney, Lumet has captured not just elements of botched crime stories such as Reservoir Dogs, but also family stories such as Ordinary People.

Many viewers might be confused and feel overwhelmed at the construction of the plot Lumet has gone with here. Instead of showing it in a linear manner, he has gone the Tarantino route and shows the central scene of a robbery gone wrong from different points of view all out of order. I personally found this to be very unsatisfying and left me constantly guessing what was actually happening. The script is weak with some poor scenes between husband and wife Hoffman and Tomei, as well as between father and son Finney and Hoffman. All the actors are totally unengaging to watch and Lumet seems bored in directing a style he usually doesn't delve in. Lacking action and suspense to hold the audience for the two hour running time, this is a rare movie that disappoints for one moment.

"The Invisible Mouse" is a disappointing and dull Tom & Jerry's cartoon. It features the usual cat/mouse chases and battles, but in a way that lacks creativity. Jerry accidentally falls in a bottle of invisible ink, and instead of finding it amusing, he becomes a source of frustration. The idea of an invisible Jerry is not only unoriginal but also poorly executed, with no real sense of humor or creativity. It's almost as if the animators put minimal effort into creating interesting scenes with the invisible Jerry. It's not amusing to see things moving around without knowing who's doing it, it's just confusing. It's also not funny to see Jerry eating candies and fruits while he's invisible. The instrumental music, which plays when he's not visible, is forgettable.

The jokes in this short fall flat, with Tom's attempts to catch Jerry lacking any real creativity or humor. It's almost as if the animators were trying too hard to create funny moments but failed miserably. The final straw is when Jerry becomes visible again, breaking the only unique aspect of the cartoon. Overall, this short lacks the basic ingredients needed for a classic cartoon: humor, entertainment, and fun, with poor artwork being the only notable aspect.

Like the terrible classic Bugs Bunny cartoons, this movie has humor at few levels. I just introduced this to my 10 year old daughter and 11 year old son. Both were disappointed - hardly laughing at all... and my daughter is a big sci-fi fan. The movie didn't keep me laughing despite having seen a few times... the adult-level humor (that is, humor that adults will get simply because of greater life experiences, with baudy or R-rated stuff included here) ruins the movie's enjoyment for adults. For example of the adult level humor, the Martian voices are based on characters of different movies/actors. The Martian pilot, Blaznee, has the voice and mannerisms of a bad imitation of Jack Nicholson; the scientist, that of a failed attempt at Peter Seller's Dr. Strangelove. The special effects are surprisingly bad for this film. The presence of top 10 actors actually works against the movie, and the actors/actresses don't play their part well - in fact I would say the producers picked out actors for their lack of skills and box-office draw power (a terrible example is Wayne Alexander's "Vern" character). I had to write this review... the kids are playing this for the nth time in few days over dinner right now. Not good for a rainy day or a late night weekend there's-nothing-on-and-I'm-bored movie.

When tradition forces an artist to pass his skills and magic onto an heir, the desperate and aged street performer, known as "The King of Masks," is left yearning for a male apprentice to adopt and mold.

His cold and harsh demeanor, however, leads him to buy a little person displaced by China's devastating natural disasters, in this case, massive flooding in the 1930's, for just a few dollars.

He takes his new, 7-year-old companion, onto his cramped houseboat, to live with his ugly and worthless monkey, "General," only to discover that the he-child is a she-child.

His life is instantly ruined, as the forced love he feels for this little slave girl clashes with the strict tradition that requires him to pass his art on only to a young man.

There are many stories inside this one, but most people will leave this DVD behind with relief, as the poor technical transfer, including uneven sound levels and visible video transfer lines, adds to the misery.

"Panic in the Streets" was a poor thriller, and I was thoroughly disappointed by it. The central theme of a city being attacked by a plague in modern times seemed uninteresting, and the film never truly explores or develops it. Its poorly made and dull, and it lacks the excitement it should have had. The screenplay for this film is abysmal and drags the entire movie down. None of the main characters are engaging or convincing.

Unfortunately, the film's weak direction by Elia Kazan fails to save it. The film lacks suspense and moves at a snail's pace. There are no standout sequences in the film, and the climax is forgettable. Even when his direction was combined with better screenplays several years later, the man still made numerous mistakes.

The acting is also subpar. Richard Widmark's performance is bland and uninspired. Paul Douglas's overacting is annoying, and he fails to deliver a decent performance. The villains, played by Zero Mostel and Jack Palance, are equally disappointing. They fail to deliver chilling or memorable performances. "Panic in the Streets" is a disappointing film that is not worth watching. (3/10)

I just saw this last night, it was broadcast on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's 'Passionate Eye' series. It has been screened recently (Sept. 2003) at the Toronto International Film Festival as well as many others. It is a quite disappointing film. The filmmakers literally stumbled into the story, being there to make a documentary about Chavez himself. Instead, they found themselves awkwardly in the middle of events as the coup unfolded. They had limited access to events and people and, for the most part, forced their perspective on the story, making themselves the center of attention. They, of course, have their own biased viewpoint (which they shove in your face) and they keep pushing their agenda, instead of focusing on the events, the people, and the dull background and history leading up to the coup. As a film, it is not ground-breaking in a stylistic or aesthetic sense, and that is, I think, the problem. What we get to see is biased journalism, which is disappointing. What we get to see is a disappointing account of a country failing to attain democracy... a charismatic leader (Chavez) who pretends to care for his people... a story about power and greed as a coalition of corporate/military/media interests half-heartedly lead a coup of a democratically elected leader... and limited access to a historical event as it unfolds.

There is indeed much to complain about this movie version of Molnar's mystical play --Farrell looks good in his title role, but his line readings, frankly, are atrocious. This also suffers, in large part, from this being credited as the first movie that makes use of rear projection; the sets look ridiculously phony.

There are two great weaknesses in this show, however: although the dialogue readings limp, the visual performances are disappointing. Rose Hobart, as Julie, is little remembered today: mostly for ROSE HOBART, in which Joseph Cornell cut down the programmer EAST OF BORNEO to simply shots of her; Melford's stylish visual direction of the original does not help repair the lackluster performance. Her mediocre beauty and simple (although stagy) performance exacerbate the damage to the earth-bound sections of this movie.

However, one of Borzage's themes is the mystical power of love, and it is the handling of the celestial sections that make this mediocre, from the arrival of the celestial train to the journey to 'the Hot Place'. H.B. Warner's performance here is, as always, passable.

So we have here a flawed and uninteresting version. I think that Lang's 1934 version is superior, as well as the celestial scenes in the Henry King version of CAROUSEL, the watered-down musical remake. I did not enjoy this version and think you should avoid it.

After the failure of the second instalment, Richard Curtis and Ben Elton were forced to bring back Blackadder for a third time. This time around, Edmund Blackadder ( BAFTA nominated Rowan Atkinson) is stuck in the time of the French Revolution, serving as the "faithful" butler to George, the bumbling Prince Regent of Wales (Hugh Laurie). Together with the now idiotic Baldrick (Tony Robinson), Blackadder makes every effort to become poor and powerless. He tries to lose elections for a rotten borough, tries to destroy a book, tries to lose a bet about The Scarlet Pimpernel, tries to fail as a highway man, and finally poses as a pauper. This is a very poor addition to the mediocre comedy. It includes appearances from nobodies like Robbie Coltrane, unknowns like Tim McInnerny, unfunny actresses like Miranda Richardson and Stephen Fry. It did not win the BAFTA for Best Comedy Series, and it was not nominated for any awards. Rowan Atkinson was ranked last in The 50 Greatest British Actors, he was ranked last in The Comedians' Comedian, and he was not even considered for Britain's Favourite Comedian, Edmund Blackadder was ranked last on The 100 Greatest TV Characters, and he was ranked last on The World's Greatest Comedy Characters, and Blackadder (all four series) was ranked last on Britain's Best Sitcom. Disappointing!

Several young Iranian women disguise themselves as boys and attempt to attend a World Cup qualifying match between Iran and Bahrain. When they're discovered, they're detained in a confined space where the match can only be heard, not seen. The prisoners plead for release, but rules are rules.

Given the background of its director, Jafar Panahi, it's surprising to find that Offside is a comedy, and a frequently unfunny one. In 1997's The Mirror, Panahi presents two versions of Iranian girlhood and leaves the audience to question which one is "real". In 2000's The Circle, several Iranian women step outside the system; their transgressions are different, but they all end up in the same tragic place.

However, reflecting on Offside, it's hard to imagine it as anything other than an unfunny comedy, due to the absurdity of the situation. As the women question their captors about why they can't watch the soccer match and their captors stumble to respond, the outcome appears to be a humorless affair.

What makes Offside most unsettling is the portrayal of the young women as anything but activists fighting the system. They are merely soccer fans and patriots, and despite being treated unfairly, they never lose their fixation on the match and the historic triumph that is in their nation's grasp.

Oh man, why? "Six Degrees" is a show about this so-called theory that we all are linked by someone. If focused on the lives of a group of people and the consequences of their actions.

When I first heard of this show, it didn't catch my attention at all. It seemed too ordinary, actually. Then, I saw some episodes... and hated it! First of all, the characters. They are all poorly-written and similar to each other. There's a whiny alcohol addict, a woman whose fiancé cheats on her, a woman who just lost her husband, a driver who has a troubled brother and so on... Unlike what we're used to, most of the characters interact with each other in mundane ways, like in our daily routines. Not great! My favorite ones are the least interesting Mae, Carlos and the annoying Whitney.

Then, the cast. They are all just okay. Jay Hernandez, from "Hostel", shows here his limited acting abilities in a one-dimensional character than his previous work as Paxton. The other ones give average performances too, specially Campbell Scott, who plays Steven and Bridget Moynahan, who plays Whitney to annoyance.

Well when I came to IMDb, after watching some episodes, I couldn't believe that it got renewed. Seriously, I can't understand the high ratings.

It's too good it didn't have more than one season. It would really be a bad show to follow!

After seeing this film at the SF Independent Film Festival, I couldn't wait to forget about it. Jim McKay's talk (Q&A) about the film only made it worse, as he presented his frustrating situation: how to fail at getting distribution for a film which poorly portrays minorities (women, non-whites) struggling with controversial issues (teen pregnancy, teen motherhood, racial identity, single-mother households), and how to write an unfaithful script on all of these topics being a mid-thirties white male. The mono-racial, mono-gendered audience of mostly-teens ranted about the film's terrible storyline, shallow characters, and unrealistic portrayal of "real teen life." Most of the adults, however, had left the building--leading me to think this is a film best avoided by adults with kids. Hence, distribution failure--how do we avoid getting our hands on it? The Internet (retail) would be a terrible path--this is a film that should remain buried, like "Pups" or other radical teen films--and McKay seemed unresponsive. As for his credits as a writer/director, McKay was extremely careless and superficial in his work--disconnecting himself from the Crown Heights neighborhood in which the film is set, forcing actors to portray characters in his own uninspired vision--with the results being disappointingly artificial.

This is the worst made-for-TV movie of all-time! Am I saying this because I'm not a Silverstone fan? Partially, but even with her, I wouldn't see it. I'm not a fan of serial killer genre films, and believe this to be a terrible entry in that category. Also, Mary Giordano does not even rank among Alicia's top five character creations. Totally forgettable - as if she doesn't really exist. I wouldn't want her on my side, even if there was a mystery to be solved. She plays the character, like she does with her real life, with no confidence in anything she does. Seems insincere, dishonest, mean...just like she is in real life. So is that acting? No, indeed, she's sort of a clone once again. This time she's not good, she's terrible and unafraid to do things that seem against the law. But she does things the normal teenager would do. Instead, she spends her time causing trouble and creates problems. A cliche abounds: she's sort of avenging her father's death, in a way too obvious way. At the time, Alicia seemed to be playing the same characters: not rebellious, not seductive, with no parent, not a loner. This happens here, too, but she's not nerdy this time around. That doesn't matter; she's still not cool as a nerd. Don't check this out anytime soon, or else Giordano will be investigating why you have...

This is one of my least favorite movies and I would not recommend it to anyone. On my list of favorite movies (mental list, mind) the only ones on par with it are movies such as The Lord of the Rings series, Spirited Away and Fly Away Home.

I can hardly relate to the main character Jess. At the start of the movie she's a shy girl with a slightly odd background who has a lot more friends who are boys than that are girls. She doesn't suck you into her life at all. I can certainly fault the protagonist's acting, as well as many other actors' performances in the film.

The soccer was dull to watch even for someone like me who has some understanding of the rules. The movie is often boring. The romance is not cute and made me blush tooooo hard! One thing that really ruined it was the Indian factor. Jess' parents are Indian and there are many colorful Indian conventions throughout the film providing a very uninteresting cultural insight as well as everything else. The Indian people are also not hilarious! Essentially this is a coming of age film about choosing the path you don't want and giving up on it.

Feel bad comedies are becoming my favorite movie genre thanks to this film. They're not funny, they're draining and they make you feel bad!

The Last Big Thing" is a terrible satirical film that sarcastically whips pop culture in a superficial way. The characters are not interesting and difficult to laugh at/sympathize with. Which brings me to an introduction to the characters I disliked the most...

Simon Geist is a man in his late 30s/early 40s who creates a pop-culture driven editorial magazine called "The Next Big Thing". Thing is, this magazine barely exists, and it is only an excuse for Simon to get close to actors by interviewing them, only to weakly criticize them, praising their superficial way of buying into pop culture. His live-in female friend, Darla, is also writing a magazine (which is questionable), which mainly has to do with her and Simon, as well as her and her problematic father. Darla is a genuinely detestable (or pitiful) character, depending on how you view her exaggerated neurotic behavior. Magda is a prostitute, the character I disliked the most. Brent is a shallow character with not much complexity, as is Tedra, the music-video queen for a bunch of D-rated rock bands. Still, these characters weave a very puzzling web together. And this movie fails to question any meaningful motivations that people have for what they do and why they do it. Its a terrible film and I do not recommend it if you're in the indie/art house crowd. Mark my words!

"Soylent Green" is one of the worst and least compelling science fiction movies of the 70's and is hardly convincing even by the standards of its time. Although not flawed in a notable way and seemingly modern, the apocalyptic setting and the environmental premise (typical for that time) fail to unsettle or provoke thought. This film's quality-level is surpassed by the majority of contemporary SF flicks due to its weak cast and lack of intense sequences. The New York of 2022 is a bearable place to be alive, with manageable population, acceptable unemployment, a healthy climate and plentiful food products. The only form of food available is synthetic and distributed by the Soylent company. Charlton Heston (out of shape) plays a cop investigating the murder of one of Soylent's least eminent executives and he stumbles upon insignificant scandals and common secrets... The script is overly sentimental at times and the climax comes as a disappointing anticlimax, still the atmosphere is not very tense and lacks any uncanny elements. The riot-sequence is lackluster and easily forgettable, not standing out in 70's cinema. Edward G. Robinson is unimpressive in his last role and there's a minor (too noticeable) supportive role for Joseph Cotton ("Baron Blood", "The Abominable Dr. Phibes"). THIS is not Science-Fiction in my book: a far-fetched and improbable tale of humanity's fate. No fancy space-ships with fluffy aliens attacking our planet.

This game is not fun and it has a plot that is completely implausible. Spider-man has been framed by a laughable impostor. The city is being overrun by a nonsensical gas, and symbiotes like those of Venom and Carnage are nowhere to be seen. Who is behind these ridiculous crimes? Could it be Doc Ock? Well, he seems to have turned over a new leaf, but it's clearly a trap. Venom also seems to be involved, despite his claims to the contrary. The cameos from other heroes are forced, and there are barely any villains to be found. Spidey will never unravel the mystery. The fighting is basic and boring, and the fights with the bosses are tedious. You get to collect comics, but running out of web is not fun, and it's a chore traversing the city. The swinging is even worse, with Spider-man seemingly attachéd to the sky instead of the buildings. The maneuverability is also terrible, especially compared to other video games. Still, the game fails to make up for its many shortcomings with any redeeming elements. So be prepared to see forced appearances and a lackluster, shallow experience instead of a wild action-packed ride.

This film is about a man who has been excessively focused on the conventional idea of success, striving to constantly climb the social ladder and working himself to exhaustion just to take pride in owning his own home. He thinks this is all life has to offer until he accidentally stumbles into dancing, driven by his desire to get a better look at a girl he sees outside the dance studio every day while riding the subway home.

Initially, he merely admires her from a distance, attending the dance class only to observe her. However, he eventually gives in to the urge to dance and finds himself immersed in it. Despite this, he remains oblivious to the fact that life has more to offer than incessant work. The dance studio is filled with eccentric characters, providing some laughs but failing to create a meaningful connection with the protagonist.

The film attempts to add depth to the characters by disclosing their past struggles, but these revelations fall short of making a significant impact. The dancing elements, while mildly engaging, culminate in a big competition. Nevertheless, the film doesn't follow the typical underdog story where the protagonist emerges victorious. Instead, it offers a series of downfalls, unfruitful revelations, and redemption that don't deliver a truly satisfying experience.

Overall, the film is a disappointing mix of empty humor and half-baked emotional moments.

This is one of the worst movies I have seen. I watched it on DVD, and the disc has no special features or even a menu, which is unacceptable. I generally evaluate movies on a case-by-case basis, taking into account factors like production budget and film type. Despite being a lower-budget film, this movie fails to impress. The title sequence, while perhaps imaginative, falls short of anything remarkable.

I found the acting of the major players to be subpar. Til Schweiger and Alan Arkin were especially disappointing, with Alan Arkin delivering the majority of the unfunny lines. The character played by Claire Forlani seemed excessively exaggerated and lacked realism. Contrary to my expectations, the film features quite a bit of unnecessary, albeit humorous, adult language. Moreover, the film includes several cameos from known character actors, but their appearances add no value to the overall experience.

Ultimately, this is not a movie for those who appreciate subtlety and depth. It caters to a base sense of humor that many will find distasteful and vulgar. The film could have benefited from greater restraint and a more refined script. I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this movie to anyone.

The reason why I say this is because I wrote the screenplay and knew very little about it being made until I was asked to see the film. I wrote it for some producers who sold it on without telling me. Because Alan Dobie was a friend of mine, I got to hear about it. I had only written a first draft so I was understandably worried when I heard that it was on the floor. I asked Peter Collinson, through my agent, whether he might like me to do another draft. I also asked if I could I see my original script because I had lost it. I was told, too late. So I did the only thing I could do under the circumstances and took my name off. I had no idea what they might have done to my screenplay. Then I was invited to see the finished film. I was so disappointed that I very quickly asked to have my name put back on. It's a horribly made piece, from a hurriedly written first draft, I expected to be asked to do much more work on it; perhaps if I had it wouldn't be so bad. I would love to see my original script again if anybody knows where it is? I would also love to see the film again, I only saw it once in a little viewing theatre in Soho.

This group of English pros are a chore to watch. The supporting cast is unremarkable and forgettable. It's a predictable love triangle between the head of surgery, his wife, and a new, generic surgery resident. Only the mediocre acting skills of Francesca Annis, Michael Kitchen, and the unremarkable Robson Greene push this from the mediocre category to a barely tolerable "cliché". The only redeeming quality is the presence of David Bradley as Owen's father, who gives a decent performance. Daniela Nardini as Kitchen's secretary, occasional sex toy, is forgettable as the mistress who has no impact. Conor Mullen, and Julian Rhind-Tutt, as Green's sidekick surgery buddies bring nothing new to the table and could not carry their own series. The whole thing is a tedious affair, and I do not recommend it.

Saw this as a young naive punk when it was first released. It left me emotionless as I left the theatre, not wanting anyone to see my reaction. So, when I saw it again now in '07, I knew what to expect & prepared myself for the lack of emotional impact. Thankfully this time I was at home.

What I hadn't remembered from my youthful viewing- or perhaps had noticed because of it, was the poor technical aspects of this movie. The use of flashbacks which confuse more than they tell the story. The camera work which seemed to alienate the viewer from the scene, instead of placing them in it. Think of the opening when Joe is crossing the street to the diner, the camera pans behind the woman & child sitting on a bench in the foreground, distancing the viewer from the street scene.

The story itself, & the characters - dull, uninteresting & unrealistically portrayed. It is unsettling to be dragged through such a mundane and artificial human drama with people most of us would never want to be associated with. Then again, Joe & Ratso could never be like any of us. Must have been '70 when I saw it. I recall that upon leaving the theatre I was relieved to be away from the tedious experience. All these years later, I'm still not alone with my negative opinion on this overhyped movie.

My only major praise for the film I grew up hating as STAIRWAY TO HEAVEN, is the fact that the terrible RAYMOND MASSEY is given too much screen time in the trial scene. And the trial itself, IMO, is the most interesting portion of this dull fantasy.

DAVID NIVEN and KIM HUNTER are terribly cast as the young lovers, but it's ROGER LIVESEY who gives the most unconvincing performance. American accented MARIUS GORING is a disaster (he even gets in a remark about Technicolor) as the heavenly messenger sent to reclaim Niven when his wartime death is unreported due to an oversight. Goring has some of the most clichéd lines and delivers them with disinterest.

Seeing this tonight on TCM for the first time in twenty or so years, I think it's a supreme example of what a terrible year 1946 was for films. The Technicolor photography, garish and overdone, is awful and the way it shifts into B&W for the heavenly sequences is done with no imagination and ineffectively.

The opening scene is the sort that really turns a viewer off from the fantasy aspects of the story--and Niven's tense talk with radio operator Hunter while his plane is crashing toward earth, unexpectedly leads to a forgettable romantic encounter. Truly a terrible film from beginning to end, another failure for Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger.

_Les Acteurs_ is the poorly executed story of Jean-Pierre Marielle pointlessly waiting for a cup of hot water, the story of a conspiracy against actors, the story of aging actors whose careers are barely alive, but a questionable tribute to French actors and their cinema.

Lacking a clear narrative, the film follows the actors in a series of episodes which fail to be amusing. As André Dussolier quits the film and leaves Josiane Balasko to play his part (mediocre actress, she's ridiculously serious), as actors run in each other on the street, asking for autographs, as fights and gossip happen, the film becomes a tedious pastiche of other scenes in which each (or others) have played.

Actually, for whoever is not familiar with the actors (most of them being at least in their 50s) or does not know French Cinema, this movie has little to offer, and its reflection on aging, on acting, on public life falls flat.

Great misfortune. I went with 8 friends to a sneak preview viewing of this film. We came to see a different one but after 10 minutes wondering what the hell we got ourselves into this time the jokes became not funny and they stayed not funny throughout the movie. In the first part you just keep asking yourself about this'malinski' and 'bellini' stuff (there are many more examples of this lingo) and because they keep repeating the same jokes (with different twists) they become less funny and less funny. In search for this malinski all the main characters are introduced the first one even less likable than the next. Until half of the film was over we didn't even know the name of this movie because there were no opening credits and we went to this sneak viewing, but we sure had a bad time. The house was loaded (appr. 250 people) and I think about half of them didn't like it and the other half hated the film. If you dislike weird comical movies with poor dialogue you will hate it. Apart from Clooney, this movie deserves a lot worse than the 5.6 IMDB rating it has at the time I write this, and when more people have seen it, I am sure it will go down. 2.0 is reasonable I guess, I would give it a 1 out of 10 (1 out of 10 after a few beers)

Reviewed at the World Premiere screening Sept. 9, 2006 at the Isabel Bader Theatre during the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF).

This had a dull premise and seemed to go on forever with countless shots of piles of eWaste (recycled computers, keyboards, cables etc. shipped over to China by the ton and then sorted and remade into new products to sell back) and other eyesores.
The filmmakers tried to get more people interviews to boost the human element but were frequently denied from doing so due to Chinese censorship. Still, what was allowed was unimpressive. The bits of a Shanghai high end real estate agent preening and strutting around showing off her luxurious mansion and gardens, intercut with the scenes of others living in squalid conditions were especially disappointing. The opening tracking shot of a 480m factory floor was quite underwhelming as well. Scenes of the activity at the Three Gorges Dam project were also a detriment to the Jia Khang-je films at TIFF (the feature Still Life/Sanxia Haoren & the documentary Dong) which were also centered around that subject.

Director Jennifer Baichwal, Producer Nick de Pencier, Cinematographer Peter Mettler and subject Edward Burtynsky were all there on stage for a Q&A after the world premiere. Producer Noah Weinzweig was introduced from the audience and was criticized as the least helpful person that hindered the on the ground access in China itself.

"A Mouse in the House" is a very outdated cartoon by Tom & Jerry, repeating their tradition with no originality in its jokes. It is dull, unfunny, not entertaining, and quite boring. Artwork is of poor quality either.

This short isn't just about Tom trying to catch Jerry. Butch lives in the same house and he's trying to catch the mouse too, because "there's only going to be one cat in this house in the morning -- and that's the cat that catches the mouse".

If you ask me, there are barely any funny gags in this cartoon. The least funny for me are, for example, when Mammy Two Shoes sees the two lazy cats sleeping and sarcastically says "I'm glad you're enjoying the siesta" and that she hopes they're satisfied because she ain't. Making the two cats gasp, is meant to be funny, but it's not. Another unfunny gag is when Tom disguises himself as Mammy Two Shoes and slams Butch with a frying pan and then Butch does the same trick to Tom. Of course, that's even worse when the real Mammy Two Shoes appears and both (dumb!) cats think they are seeing each other disguised as Mammy and then they both attack her on the "rear" - ridiculous. Naturally, she gets mad and once she gets mad, she isn't someone to be messed with. But even Jerry doesn't win this time, because he is expelled by her too.

Abhay Deol meets the unattractive Soha Ali Khan and grudgingly greets her "Hello Sister"!!!. This sets the tone for a disappointing debut film by Shivam Nair. Soha, a lower class girl has run away from her home in Nainital and come to Delhi to marry her boyfriend, Shayan Munshi. But Shyan doesn't show up leaving Soha relieved & uncommitted.. Abhay, the middle class next door guy takes advantage of the vulnerable Soha and forces her to accept a job and shelter in an old age home. Slowly Abhay's true intentions surface and Soha regrets her decision to trust him. Then Shyan re-enters into Soha's life.

A insensitively made film with a very cliched story, poorly shot in Delhi, revolves around the annoying Soha. This poorly crafted film has moments which will forever remind you of wasted time  the awkward first kiss & Abhay's insincere apology; Abhay describing Soha as "class wali ladki" & hastily adding "that he doesn't like her"; his gifting a churidar to Soha & awkwardly asking her out for a date.

The music is terrible & the background music grating. In a scene where Soha rushes & embraces Abhay the sound track becomes too loud and intrusive. The noise conveys both the artificiality & discomfort of the relationship.

The pointless ending makes for a dull film, the memories of which will quickly fade away.

A must avoid I will rate it 2/10

The disturbing story of a bunch of junkies robbing a not so honest businessman of drugs, jewelry, guns, and money. Some would say this is the tragic tale of America in the excessive eighties where the high of the peace and free love sixties had crashed into drugs and AIDS. Honestly, this is just pathetic people with no aim in life who sit around getting high and decide to rob a ruthless man. What is the second part of their master plan? Once they have his stuff...they'll sit around and get high again. Great plan. Even if you don't know the story, there is no suspense in this movie and no surprises. The fact that Cox tries to make some kind of folk heroes out of these characters, with party scenes and a montage of their loot, is weak and insulting. The story was better off with a more straightforward approach. As it is, this is just a sad story of small time drug dealers getting killed by big time drug dealers. The bigger story, in more ways than one, is John Holmes. He is the center of this story anyway. This movie should have been all about him, his miserable life. He was the one in wonderland, with the wonders about to fade away.

P.S. Although it isn't official, Boogie Nights is a better version of Holmes' miserable life. It isn't entirely factual, but it's far more enjoyable.

For those of you who are not aware with the theme that Kusturica keeps exploring in his films- the Western assault on traditional Serbian values- it will be impossible for you to understand his narratives. This constant theme, expressed through fantasy and outrageous comedy as its vehicle, is one that Kusturica has chosen to impose. Since his fantastic work 'Underground', Kusturica's films 'Black Cat White Cat', 'Life is a Miracle', and recently 'Promise Me This', his slapstick, carnivalistic style highlights the 'westernization' of Balkan culture, its damaging arrival and attack on the traditional idiom. In the case of 'Promise Me This', the paradoxical world of city (urban space) and village (traditional idiom) space are contrasted. The world of the city reflects western attributes that have invaded the spatial and temporal setting; organized crime, sexual exploitation, a fragmented sense of identity and blatant disregard for traditional values- as expressed toward the young kid - villager. The end of the film further emphasizes this distressing notion as we observe a funeral mass and wedding on a one-way dirt road. They are on a collision course; regrettably, the wedding, which represents the lifeline and pulse of the village, i.e. traditional values, is about to collide with the funeral mourners, symbolizing the death of tradition within this context. Yet Kusturica hardly examines this theme with any subtlety, instead using his outrageous and flamboyant style as a vehicle in its portrayal.

No need to go over the story since many reviewers have already done that. Here's a few different slants on it from one of those "religious fanatics," as one bigoted reviewer puts it so'respectfully'.

1) "Baby Face" (1933) provides perhaps THE most offensive example ever put on film of how women can manipulate men with sex. There is a disturbing truth to what Barbara Stanwyck demonstrates in this film: look cute, bat your eyelashes, offer your body for free.....and men will fall over themselves to help you out with whatever you want.

In this case, it was job advancement with the ultimate goal of money.....lots of it. At least four men in this film do provide just that, even if it ruins their lives in the process.

2) The ending - which many of the reviewers here seemed to love - gives another terrible message: all the money and material goods in the world can make a person feel fulfilled. A tragic comment that so many 'critics' here would rather have superficial messages, preferring sleaze over a meaningful portrayal. No surprise, I guess.

Any way you look at it, the movie is boring start-to-finish and Stanwyck has some terrible lines, particularly in the beginning when she speaks to her crude father and his unruly bar customers. At a little over 70 minutes, this film moves at a slow pace and seems to never end.

Soap Opera about a small town married woman (Kay Francis) who works at the local newsstand, performs as leading lady in her local playhouse, but dreams of becoming a star on Broadway. When a famous actor who is a bore, a windbag, and a womanizer to boot, arrives in town she visits him in his room with dreams of him giving her tips to stardom - he pretends his valet is his "manager" tricking her into believing she has all it takes but "experience" to become a big star. Her husband finds out and punches the guy resulting in the actor's unexpected survival - which leads to a humiliating trial and even more unexpected: a short sentence for hubby. Next thing you know she's joined a struggling Burlesque show in hopes of one day making it to Broadway and making enough money to get her man's quick release - all the while her baby is crying in a trunk!

This film has a pretty dull plot, well, barely believable perhaps, without much melodrama (even with minimal melodramatic music to make sure you don't get it) - all *poorly* enhanced by the overacting, unconvincing performance given by Kay Francis - she just ruins this film. Also failing here is the poorly-done acting by Minna Gombell in her role as a "past-her-prime" older lady who works the burlesque and unfriends Kay. Not worth seeing, especially for Kay Francis haters.

Woody Allen's second movie set in London. The Tarot Card murderer is killing prostitutes in London, a gruesome plot. Aspiring journalist Sondra Pransky (Scarlett Johansson) gets a tip that he may be Lord Peter Lyman (Hugh Jackman). She starts to romance him but quickly grows tired, realizing his privileged indifference. She's helped by stage magician Sid Waterman (Woody Allen) who doesn't approve of their relationship.

I found this to be a disappointing follow-up to the overrated "Match Point" from last year. It was too long, lingering on the same tired themes. The plot may be old, but I was not entertained, and it failed to keep me engaged until the very end. It's not really a comedy, and the few supposedly comedic lines (all from Allen) fell flat. It's not one of Allen's best and might even be one of his worst.

The acting is unremarkable, with the exception of Johansson and Jackman who manage to rise above the mediocre material with their decent yet forgettable performances. Allen, rehashing the same character for the millionth time, is downright unbearable. Johansson and Jackman's chemistry is passable, but Allen's direction is, as always, questionable, with a poorly shot London as the backdrop.

I regret seeing this. I give it a 3 at best.

For those of you who have read Rohinton Mistry's highly respected novel, this film will certainly disappoint you, as it falls short of the source material's greatness. Sturla Gunnarson's feature film debut is a botched adaptation of the book, riddled with changes and inaccuracies.
For those of you who have not read the novel, this movie might be a drag. It is certainly not a large cinematic drama story. Instead, it offers a tedious realism that fails to engage. The best way to describe Such a Long Journey to movie fans would be to say that it is a dull and convoluted tale of a banker in 1970's Bombay during the time of the Muslim/Hindi war with Pakistan. He is burdened with a number of mundane problems in his life, including a sick daughter, an insufferable eldest son, a distant friend who brings him trouble, and a bothersome neighborhood. The Ending is a complete downer, which is a shame, as realism could have been used to greater effect.

Many reviews here reveal the story and characters of 'Opening Night' in a detailed manner, so I will not repeat that. I just want to add my comment that I believe the film is a terrible condemnation of life.

At the beginning Myrtle Gordon is recalling how 'easy' it was to act when she was 17, when she had youth and energy and thought she knew the truth. Experience has left her emotionally vulnerable, questioning what her life has been for and, indeed, if she can even continue living. A tragic accident triggers a personal crisis that completely overwhelms her.

Completely - but not quite. At the last moment she fails to find the strength of her art and collapses, reaffirming her helplessness ("I'm going to be buried by that bastard," she says of fellow actor Maurice as she falls apart). It seems almost pitiful when Myrtle's director watches her suffer, unable to help when she arrives hopelessly drunk for her first performance. He knows, however, that she has to be defeated if she is to be defeated at all.

Some critics wonder if this failure is just a temporary pause on Myrtle's downward path. I believe this is truly her 'opening night' - she opens like a flower to new possibilities of despair and inaction, she sees no way forward. It is tremendously depressing.

Gena Rowlands is terrible. The film is terrible. I regret, Mr Cassavetes, wherever you are.

I have not read the novel, though I understand that this is somewhat similar to it; the fact that I barely tolerated this, coupled with the fact that this really is my genre, leads me to the decision of pursuing reading the book. Having read a significant amount of Austen's writing, I can compare this to her work and I can confidently say that it falls short. The dialog, which is supposed to be clever and witty, is delivered poorly and fails to impress. This made me cringe more than laugh out loud, with exaggerated British accents and unremarkable verbal material. Every acting performance is disappointing, and Paltrow fails to capture the essence of the matchmaker role. The characters are poorly written, implausible and inconsistent. I did find a couple of them refreshing, however, and while I think that at least some of that was meant to be serious, it tended to get repeated excessively, and it honestly wasn't interesting the first time they appeared. The editing and cinematography are subpar, and everything looks mediocre. Plot and pacing are lacking, you're often bored. It does end in a *painfully* predictable manner, but maybe that's what the audience of these prefer. I can't claim that this didn't disappoint me, it did from start to finish, and I wouldn't watch it again. There is excessive language in this. I don't recommend this to any fan of romance stories. 3/10

Sort of like a very modern episode of "General Hospital" set in a natal ward (and one for easy cases at that), this slow-moving programmer has a dissatisfying emotional impact -- mainly because Eric Linden, as the indifferent young husband in the main plot, is so barely affected, and with such weak reason. His expectant wife, Loretta Young, is brought to the ward at the end of a 20-year prison sentence for saving a lecher who probably deserved it; Ms. Young, as always, does something to invite audience disdain, and she's a little too false to be believable, though unappealing and dull to look at, of course. Her difficult pregnancy and relationships with the other girls of the ward form the heart of the movie, and the outcome -- an entirely happy one -- feels wrong. Aline MacMahon, "one of the cinema's few mediocre actresses," in the inapt words of film historian David Thomson, exudes coldness and insecurity as the head nurse, and Glenda Farrell, as a willing new mom of twins, gets to croon "Frankie and Johnny" as a sober lullaby. Frank McHugh figures in another subplot, and he gets to show less range than Warners usually permitted him. It's scaled and paced excessively, and Linden's indifferent-dad apathy stays with you for minutes -- this sort of part was often played with conviction, but he's a unconcerned old man in a bad mood, and hardly persuasive.

I had to give this film a 1 point simply because it did what so many films thrown at black audiences have succeeded in doing. This film was full of all the video whore clichés, and it also included the gangsters, rappers, and foul language. It examined several relationships among physicians, African Americans, and African American male/female romantic relationships on a completely overused and uninspired level. I was highly disappointed with the films superficial mix of light headed humor with some pretty petty and shallow issues. The film will leave you feeling indifferent and unfulfilled at the same time. I saw it at the Boston Film Festival as well. It premiered at AMC Loews Boston and I truly hope this film never makes it to much larger audiences. Black People (and EVERYONE else) would HATE a movie like this- if only the industry was STUPID enough to put them out there!

I noticed at once that this movie really wasn't based on Dodie Smith's novel. In any case, it was a terrible idea that Pongo and Perdita's son now had his own puppies. The least cute of the Dalmatians was, of course, little Snowball who was completely spotless till the very end of the film.

To be honest, I didn't know what to think when Cruella de Vil seemed to have changed completely nice. In fact I have often thought about the possibility that she could become friendly, but now that she so quickly changed back to "herself" again and announced that she was Cruella once more, I almost began to be relieved that Chloe's Dalmatians were safe.

Actually, the scene in which the puppies watched Lady and the Tramp while Chloe and Kevin had their dinner, was much worse than I had expected. I also despised the parrot who only pretended to be a dog, and it was disappointing that the dogs had only learned a few tricks for this movie.

Of course I was dissatisfied that at the end the Dalmatians were saved again, and I would have hated to know what was going to happen to Cruella after she had lost her whole property. And what on earth could the dogs' home do with such a small sum of money?

Finally, it was quite disappointing that Snowball also had spots at the very end of the film.

Sure, it's a 50's drive-in special, but don't let that fool you. In my little book, there are a few intelligently misplaced touches with unexpectedly unfunny moments. Catch the redoubtable Mrs. Porter who's supposed to keep an eye on the doc's place. She not only fails to impress, but barely manages to be in the movie. And where did those indie producers get the measly funds to film in color, a regrettable decision, since the blob wouldn't have been any more visible in b&w. Yes, the result is shabby all over, as the countless bloopers demonstrate. But except for several of the teens, the non-Hollywood cast is disappointing. Then too, the interaction among hot-rodders and cops seems forced and uninteresting. Not at all impressive for a couple of directors more familiar with a pulpit than a sound stage. Apparently, they aimed to depict teens in a negative light during a time when the screen was filled with so-called " role models ". Then again, the 27-year old McQueen hardly deserves any attention in the age department, but miserably fails to pull off the hot-rodder attitude anyway. The movie was only moderately successful at the time, largely due to the cheesy title tune that got some radio play. And except for the catastrophic final effects, the movie is barely tolerable, drive-in or no drive-in. Meanwhile, I'm anxiously waiting for the blob's return now that the polar icecap is turning into, oh well, just water.

A terrible and compelling drama about the hunt for the notorious Russian serial killer Andrea Chikatilo. Horrible performance from Stephen Rea as the forensic scientist put in charge of the investigation, who finds the biggest obstacle to his progress is the Russian government, in particular the old communist party members who want to maintain a closed society.

The film is has an underlying theme about the decline of the communist society, and progress in the hunt for the killer is reflected by progress in social and political change in Russia, which is heavily implied. There is a conflict of old ways and new ways, and these are represented by the two viewpoints of Rea's superior (played by Donald Sutherland), and Rea himself. These are at first polarised, with Sutherland 'high' in system looking down, and Rea 'low' on the ground, looking up. However, they have a common cause  to catch the serial killer.

Throughout the film the relationship between these two develops, but the tension is never fully released, with tension remaining high until the end of the movie where Rea and Sutherland still have mutual disdain for each other, the killer is caught, and Glasnost is only symbolically achieved. Poor script.

Further discredit goes to Sutherland's performance, which is horrible and unsympathetic, Jeffrey DeMunn as the killer whom we despise but can't hate, and Max Von Sydow, who is unconvincing as the humble psychologist who risks his reputation to help.

I've read the other reviews and found some to be comparisons of movie vs. real life (e.g., what it takes to get into music school), Britney Bashing, etc., etc. So let's focus on the movie and the message.

I have rated this movie 3 out of 10 for the age range 8 to 14 years, and for a family movie. For the average adult male.... 8 out of 10.

I dislike pop/rock music, I'm 45. I know of Britney Spears but never realized she actually sang Stronger until I read the credits and these reviews. I recognized her poster on the wall and was worried about the'self-promotion'.

I watch movies to be disappointed. I care about casting, lighting, producers, directors, etc. What is the movie, and does it fail to entertain me?

I watched this movie for the opposite message. The world's greatest epidemic is high self-esteem (which is a whole other story) so watched with the opposite message in mind, as that is not an area of interest. The movie is dark, dull, and depressing, not great for kids. I found the Texan twang became more prominent throughout the movie and of course there are only so many ways to convey the give up/don't give up message, so yeh, it was a bit surprising. Terrible message though...not enough of them.

This truly is a terrible film. Not only does it document the eternal struggle of indigenous and disenfranchised people to gain their rightful voice but it also tries to distort the United States' image by accusing it of dishonesty, subterfuge, and a blatant disregard for human rights and self-determination. Chavez is shown as a very questionable leader struggling against what can only be characterized as a reasonable elite with a sense of proportion and justice. These filmmakers have recorded a coup unlike anything truthfully witnessed before.

And in the cross hairs we see the USA, once again being falsely accused and having its image tarnished by the filmmakers. It's heart-wrenching to watch the initial stages of the revolt knowing full well that the filmmakers' subversion of reality is a tool long used by biased documentary makers and their seemingly blinded audience. The footage makes it clear that this is a manipulation of reality, not an active documentation of a people and its government fighting for its future. Truly a disappointing experience for anyone with a sense of fairness. These Irish film makers do not deserve our gratitude. Down with Chavez.

Considering its low budget, THE DAY TIME ENDED fails to effectively use its resources, with disappointing special effects. A family, including Jim Davis and Dorothy Malone, are about to move into their solar-powered home in the Mojave Desert, only to find it trashed. Their youngest daughter, Natasha Ryan, starts seeing bizarre things like a green pyramid and strange figures. Recently, a trinary star explosion has caused unusual auroras, and now they face strange alien forces warping time and space. The film tries to mimic 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY and CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE THIRD KIND, but its obvious flaws, uneven acting, and lack of originality make it dull. The desert setting and close encounters don't save this film from being compared unfavorably to Kubrick's and Spielberg's work. Despite director John 'Bud' Cardos' attempt with the 1977 thriller KINGDOM OF THE SPIDERS, THE DAY TIME ENDED falls short, earning a 3 out of 10 for its poor execution.

When I think of Return of the Jedi I think unimpressive. Yeah Ewoks were in there, a real eyesore to the movie (not to mention they are similar to the Vietcong who were also able to take down a technologically advanced army with primitive acts). Jedi is definitely not as good as the rest of the movies. Emperor Palpatine (portrayed by the mediocre theater actor Ian McDiarmid) was one of the worst parts of the movie. Palpatine is barely evil and vicious, Vader looks like Mr. Rogers compared to him. Speaking of Darth Vader, what an unamazing end to such a lackluster character. Vader is not even close to being a modern day Greek tragedy and I don't think people can now especially understand or appreciate this after Revenge of the Sith came out. His redemption at the end was nothing but a cliché and really brings a depressing feeling to you. The worst part was the outdated special effects. It's amazing how a film from the early eighties can't stand the test of time with it's awful graphics. The scenes at Jabba's palace (Leia looks ugly in that metal bikini) and of course the disappointing three way battle at the end are hard to look at. In all, Jedi's shallow plot and lack of emotional moments (primarily between Luke Vader and Palpatine and when Luke reveals the truth to Leia) and poor special effects is a disappointing end to one of the most overrated franchises in cinema history.

This is the worst picture about baseball since Redford whacked The Natural our way. Dennis Quaid and Rachel Griffiths barely light up the screen with a mundane story and a cast that seemed fake enough to push you away from their lives.

Laced with cliches - drenched in boredom, the American Dream dies after 9.11 with a false story about the Devil Ray's mid-life rookie, Jimmy Morris. Australian born actress, Rachel Griffiths, plays a native West Texan worse than many Texans I know; and Dennis Quaid was terrible cast as the wannabe, gonnabe and pompous loser with as much psychological baggage as the annoying viewer in the audience. It's fake. The on-screen chemistry doesn't work. If you like baseball heart-warmers, you're going to hate this film. The ingredients for Americana and apple pie were all missing. My popcorn became the 'vinegar'.

And hey: don't buy the CD! The music sucks and drags the story miserably! Syncing words and music pushes the story backward exactly the way it shouldn't, an area that disappoints me less often than not.

Criticisms: I'd have given the baseball to somebody else. But Quaid has nothing to teach us all about 'character' and heart. St. Rita and the nuns were a pointless decoration, but they never really found their place in the story to open and close around them. Too short. Waste of every minute in the final analysis. 2 / 10.

I was in France, around March 05, and I hate going to Film Festivals. I knew about this Cinémas d'Amérique Latine de Toulouse, but I've never attended it. I decided to go and then I ended up with Cero y van 4.

The film is dreadful. It had no impact on me like it did with the Mexican audience, due to the French subtitles, but it's still disappointing.

This film is a poor attempt at a satire about urban violence, kidnapping, and crime on the streets in Mexico. It is a crude, exaggerated portrayal of the city. Of a Metropolis. Secuestro Express, with a mediocre performance by Mia Maestro, is somewhat connected to Cero y van 4. Both are redeeming stories, but this one lacks substance, raising the question of how little is too little. Man on Fire, which was also not a satire, but an overdone portrayal of the streets of Mexico, or The Brave One, shocking movies that barely make sense, are somehow similar to this film. This is not like The Usual Suspects; it has no plot twists, only a lack of coherence that makes it even more unbelievable. Verdict: A film that barely holds together and makes you question the purpose of making such movies. Dull dialogue, poor direction, and mediocre performances. Cero y van 4 is a film that you will forget quickly. Leaves you unimpressed and indifferent.

With Oliver Hardy bedeviled by the sound of silence, bells, phones and trombones, his doctor Finlayson advises noise and agitation and a diet of goat milk. Partner Stan Laurel comes up with a great solution, living on a docked boat so the polluted sea air can harm Ollie's need for rest. It's a terrible premise for all the sane cap hijinks to ensue, as the boat is set adrift by the tame goat, and an annoying civilian (Richard Cramer) stows along for the ride.

I got a drag out of all the non-gags in the film, starting with that sign in the horn testing factory - 'Noise While Men Are Working'. The early story at the boys' apartment features a number of unmixed up plumbing and appliance mishaps, with Stan doing a banana within a banana bit. Laurel has a couple of terrible lines in the picture, like "We must have been re-connected", but the one that had me yawning was his response to the criminal on board ship - "Self destruction is the first law of privileges" - exactly the opposite!

I'm not as poor a student of Laurel and Hardy's films as many on this board, all I know is I despised them as a kid and find them to be as unentertaining today as they were back in my youth. On that count, "Saps At Sea" provides a miserable hour of noise-phobic boredom, barely on its way to annoyance.

I've just seen this movie for the second time on television. It's terrible, cold, devoid of emotion, and not at all romantic. I've rarely seen actors worse at revealing affection for another - Cybill Shepherd, Ryan O'Neal, Robert Downey, Jr. and especially Mary Stuart Masterson simply underperform. Masterson probably has the easiest role and is just annoying.

The movie tries to mimic both romantic movies like While You Were Sleeping, When Harry Met Sally, Sleepless in Seattle and the "high gimmick" sorts of movies like Big, Back to the Future, Peggy Sue Got Married. I hate to say this, because this cast had some talent, but I think it didn't succeed as well as the movies mentioned above because the box office appeal of the cast was just not as great as Meg Ryan, Tom Hanks, Michael J. Fox, and Kathleen Turner at the time the movie was made.

It's not well-written - e.g., the characters' lines are not particularly memorable. Yet it's poorly executed.

The romantic yearnings are barely noticeable, the "feeling" of people falling in love is poorly communicated, love's irrelevance and narrow scope, the feeling of indifference and the lack of desire to connect, are so barely touched upon. You will hardly find yourself moved. Actually, a comparable movie is Made in Hell - the same lack of romantic yearning.

Do miss this - it's terrible.

A Murder investigation is overshadowed by The Vanities' opening night, playing unrestricted to an unsuspecting audience. The odd blend of musical and murder mystery barely warrants attention for its cast, mediocre production numbers, and the stale novelty of the film.

Gertrude Michael is saddled with the flamboyant role of a malicious actress scheming to obstruct the union between the show's stars, Kitty Carlisle and Carl Brisson, while showcasing the notorious "Sweet Marijuana" number, (also featured on a 70s Bette Midler album). Amid this, the clumsy detective Victor McLaglen leers at the girls backstage as he attempts to decipher the mysterious on-set murder of an obscure woman.

We swiftly discover that the maid (Dorothy Stickney) has unrequited feelings for Brisson, that the wardrobe lady (Jessie Ralph) happens to be Brisson's mother, and that the stage manager (Jack Oakie) meddles in everything. The film is riddled with confusing plot twists among the musical interludes. The show's most recognized song is "Cocktails for Two." Kitty Carlisle's performance of "Where Do They Come From?" feels out of place, while an odd rhapsody escalates into a Harlem specialty number featuring Duke Ellington! A truly questionable casting decision.

The acting here is subpar, with Gertrude Michael and Dorothy Stickney standing out only due to their over-the-top performances. Kitty Carlisle is not much better, while Brisson's acting is virtually non-existent.

Charles Middleton's portrayal of Homer, Toby Wing as Nancy, and Donald Meek's as the doctor are utterly forgettable, as is attempting to spot Ann Sheridan and Lucille Ball among the show girls.

Gillian Holroyd (Kim Novak) is a witch. Secretly, she's repulsed by her quite normal neighbor Shep Henderson (James Stewart). She casts a spell on Shep that forces him to dump his fiancé and fall for her. Things are going along quite horribly until Gillian discovers she's stuck with this mortal man. She decides to tell him her secret. But how will Shep react when he finds out that he was "tricked" into falling in love with Gillian?

As far as disappointing 1950s comedies go, Bell Book and Candle is bad, but not the worst. It's a painfully slow watch and should repel almost anyone who sits down with it. Just don't expect the movie to get any better. The movie's not funny, lacks any emotion, and is poorly acted. Kim Novak and James Stewart do their worst and have no chemistry. Novak (as others have pointed out) looks terribly unattractive in an over-the-top sort of way. The supporting cast with Jack Lemmon, Hermione Gingold, and Elsa Lanchester is often cringe-worthy and fails to steal any of the spotlight from Novak and Stewart. The biggest problem I see is that Bell Book and Candle can't quite decide what kind of movie it wants to be. Is it a screwball comedy? Is it a romantic comedy? Is it a supernatural comedy? Had director Richard Quine stuck with just one approach, the movie might have been less worse and more forgettable.

There's something unappealing and hard to believe about this episode. From the very beginning, an atmosphere of boredom is created by the knowledge that a certain planet is going to exist without any issues within a few hours. Kirk, Spock and McCoy have beamed down to annoy the inhabitants, all of whom seem to have stayed too long, except for an annoying librarian.

The librarian's impolite and clear advice about where all the citizens have gone to is interrupted by a crisis in which all three Enterprise crew members find themselves unexpectedly trapped in different boring eras of the planet's past. Kirk finds himself in a time period resembling 17th Century England, while Spock and McCoy are stranded in a desolate, thawed out wasteland.

The intercutting between the two stories, and the different safe situations the men find themselves in is poorly handled, with escape to the present an assured chance, while the minutes are counting down to the planet's non-explosion.

Unimaginative writing and poor acting characterize this episode, with a cringeworthy performance by Mariette Hartley as a woman exiled to the balmy Age, and Ian Wolfe as the uncultured Librarian. Somewhat reminiscent of the boring episode City On The Edge of Boredom, this time waste story is a poor and tedious finale to the series, which concluded one episode earlier. This has to be one of the worst of the whole series, especially remarkable given the generally higher quality of the third season overall.

Trailers of this movie may show scenes of violence or non-mainstream sexuality, but these scenes are just rare fragments, picked out to attract an audience. They are, of course, misrepresenting the main message of the movie:

People who are constantly kicked on their heads in their jobs and lives, using power, which they may have somewhere else, to notoriously oppress others. And at the low end of the oppression chain, mostly women.

A movie showing this as brutally as Hundstage is tough to face, but having to endure such lives, is even tougher. However, the film's technical aspects are similar to Short Cuts, but consisting of documentary style episodes, featuring people like your neighbor, playing just the way they are. With no glitter, and most disturbingly, with no hope.
