Its documentary style makes the movie even more distressing, because you realize, such people are out there, and there are many of them, although our society focuses on the nice exterior looks. Somewhere the porn industry has to do its business, somewhere unreported domestic violence has to take place, somewhere hopes have to shatter. I sure don't want to know such people.

If you want to see a movie without any funny scenes (some may think the handicapped woman repeating the top ten supermarkets is funny, but this happens for real) and without any positive aspects, go watch this movie. However, it will lose when you are focusing on subtitles I fear, as subtitles can´t transport accentuation.

From what I've read a lot of people were delighted by this film, compared to Part 1. Initially I could disagree with this but after some thought I think they are right to be. Soderbergh continues his fictional version of Che's life that he started in Part 1. Part 1 told a story of a revolution moving from promising beginnings to an ultimately disastrous conclusion. Part 2 tells a story of a revolution that moves from promising beginnings to a completely farcical conclusion. It is not Soderbergh's fault that these 2 parts of Che's life had completely different outcomes. He timidly chooses to tell both in a convoluted way. The viewer may feel a lot better coming out of the cinema after Part 1 than Part 2 but that is not the reality of Che's life and in my opinion any fault of the director. The film is far from imperfect. It is probably too short. At least in Part 1 we saw different aspects of the war as the guerrillas had failures. In Part 2 they can't catch a break and we see their numbers constantly being increased by false victories and propaganda. Che's capture and death are dealt with poorly. The film is greatly diminished by the dialogue being in Spanish. Benicio Del Toro is again terrible as the one-dimensional Argentinian. So if you've seen Part 1 you will see a very similar telling of a very different story in Part 2.

I've seen this movie when I was young, and I remembered it as one of the first films I have truly disliked that was not an action movie or a comedy. So, in my later years I decided to watch it again and see if it was just nostalgia or was there really something wrong with that movie. To my surprise, the movie fell short of my every expectations. It's an awful movie. Not emotional at all, no jokes, terrible songs (not bad though, and that actually explains why I did not remember it was a musical) and all in all a waste of my time. I was surprised because the last movies from my childhood that I have revisited met my minimal demands of a decent movie and yet this movie, which I first saw in the second grade, made me cringe today just like it made me cringe then. Maybe that's because I had high hopes for it and maybe not, but the important thing is that it made me feel, and that's why filmmakers should not make films (that and the money, of course). Yes, there are no continuity glitches. Yes, the script has no holes, but it doesn't matter. The movie itself is boring and dumb. So, don't be fooled by optimistic people who always look for the good things in life, because nothing is perfect, and this movie gets a 2 not because it is perfect. It gets 2 simply because it made me cringe.

As I drove from Skagway, Alaska to Dawson City,Yukon a couple of years ago and was unimpressed with the scenery, I cannot help but wish that this film, even though it has dull color and uninspired views, was shot in the actual location. Jasper in the Canadian Rockies is an ordinary place, and it is disappointing that they didn't film in the actual place where the film takes place. When the story moves to Dawson, that is when I feel Anthony Mann, who failed to use the outdoor locations effectively, could have done worse if he filmed in the actual place. James Stewart here is again a man with a bland character, one side of him does not want to get involved and help people who stand in his way of making money, and the other side just seems indifferent to people being murdered. Ruth Roman is the unimpressive woman who does not care on whom she steps, Corinne Calvet is the mediocre girl. Mann is poor at directing the shootouts, and the high point of the film is the poorly executed outdoor scenes. He uses the outdoors minimally, and he is not helped by the winter scenery, the predominating white, like it was with the greens in "The Naked Spur" and the browns in "The Man From Laramie". Like all of the Mann-Stewarts, this is a typical western, with no difference in the elaboration of Stewart's one-dimensional character.

It could have been worse if it were directed by someone with even less experience. Shumlin made a disappointing mess, it's far from a decent work of cinematic art.

It is, however, a dreadful movie. I have never been able to stand it since local channels used to show it. Graham Greene is one of the most overrated writers of the last century. Some of the worst movies were made from his novels and stories. (Many claim to love "The Fallen Idol" but I am not among them. I think I saw "Brighton Rock" once many years ago and despised it, simply thinking of the novel as equally horrible.) This is poorly cast, apart from Katina Paxinou, who is just bearable. Charles Boyer, portraying a Spanish character, seems to lack any temperament suited for this role -- tired, wary, caring. Lauren Bacall, appearing as the British girl who falls for him, is unappealing. The supporting players, barring Katina, are just terrible: Peter Lorre, with his Esperanto-like universal language lesson, is awful -- as usual.

And Wanda Hendrix comes across as an insufferable precocious early teenager. She succeeds in annoying with her attempts to be helpful. I do not recommend this movie at all. Not without major reservations. The reservation is, primarily, that it is a little too stolid and the story, acting, and production can scarcely be worse.

I'm not going to reveal the contents to anyone who hasn't yet seen this overrated piece by Kay Pollak.

A self-absorbed conductor, poorly acted by Michael Nyqvist, retreats to his childhood village seeking tranquility from the pressure. The villagers, who have quietly admired him, gradually try to exploit his talent.

Each character in this film has a very particular function and highlights the limited abilities of the actors delivering their few, shallow lines, creating an awkward and forced emotional symphony.

Not love in the sense of a relationship, but in the sense of an abstract, misplaced emotion buried in each of the characters, each revealing their own mundane story, their petty needs, their skeletons, desires, and much more.

I won't fail to mention, the two main actors, Frida Hallgren and Michael Nyqvist, whose dramas unfold in forgettable sequences with exaggerated emotional feedback. They touch each other with a pain that only reveals their own self-pity and lack of self-love.

Michael Nyqvist faces a challenging yet mediocre setup in this film – one that could have either been a disaster or an average production. Unfortunately, it turned out to be the former, with a tedious and unremarkable storyline that fails to connect or resonate, providing a disappointing experience that feels both overdone and unsatisfying from beginning to end.

I found 'Still Crazy' to be terribly disappointing, and not only to those of us who lived through that raucous era of late '60s, early '70s rock. My 15 year old daughter watches it with me every time I force the DVD on her (don't worry, it's only been three times) and she hates it too.

It is a truly scathing, thoughtless and sad nod to the era, and every actor misses their marks. It was my first introduction to Bill Nighy and I regret his somewhat similar turn in 'Love Actually' brought him more attention. Bruce Robinson was horrendous as Brian, bringing no life to what could have been a caricature of the drug-damaged rocker stereotype. It is interesting to see that Robinson has made quite a name for himself as a writer.

I live in Sherman Oaks, California, and after the first time I saw the movie I accidentally ran into Billy Connolly at the local mall (he lived here at the time) and told him it was one of my five least favorite films of all time. He couldn't escape fast enough, and we didn't discuss the movie for long. We even briefly talked of the idea of an American-oriented remake before wisely dismissing that. Why bother with the original?

My only problem with 'Still Crazy' is that it was hugely popular in theaters and too many people have suffered through a terrible experience.

I'm not a fan of the Dukes of Hazzard TV show. And I really didn't enjoy this flick. I didn't enjoy myself here a bit, unlike with other summer blockbusters.

It's amusing hearing people praise this movie with excuses like "funny plot" and "it's less crude than the show." Does ANYONE remember the subtle humor in the pilot episode? Daisy never even hinted at incest and Bo said that Luke had probably only met the kids in the orphanage. The only reason it was cleaned up is because it changed to a later time slot.

And as far as the plot goes. It was the most disappointing Dukes plot. In fact as a remake it probably deviates the most from the source material than any TV show that has migrated to the big screen.

While Sean William Scott and Johnny Knoxville aren't EXACTLY like their small screen versions, they do a terrible job and don't work well together. I wasn't too fond of Burt's Boss Hogg though. And I would have liked a little bit more competence from Sheriff Roscoe. In the movie Roscoe is not at all clumsy.

And who didn't have a frown on their face as the General Lee is racing through the streets of Atlanta and the back roads of Hazzard?

Folks, don't allow yourself to enjoy a movie that is just an excuse for nostalgia, bikinis and car chases, you'll be sorry. It's just a terrible dumb movie!

This series failed to interest me in Deighton's writing and the genre when I was younger, and I dislike this presentation of the story. I would, however, agree with the above comment. From what I have read in the past, it is Holm's performance that led Deighton to refuse to have the series released due to the poor adaptation of the books to the screen. A great example of this is the added scene of the border crossing that ended Samson's field career. The added scene and changed character death are not in the book and damage the integrity of the story. My perspective on Holm's performance was that he poorly portrayed the disorientation of Samson during his wife's defection and did not do justice to the aging field agent. Samson both pays for his father's idealism and suffers due to its influence on his life, but Holm's physical appearance falls short when compared to the Samson of the book - a physically impressive man who can impose a presence. The true loss of performance is due to Holm's lack of physicality and poor acting choices.

Moe and Larry are newly henpecked husbands, having married Shemp's demanding sisters. At his music studio, Shemp learns he will inherit a fortune if he marries someone himself!

"Husbands Beware" is a remake of 1947's "Brideless Groom," often criticized by many as one of the worst Stooge films with Shemp. The remake contains most of the footage from that film. The new scenes, shot May 17, 1955, bring about more problems, such as the storyline of Moe and Larry marrying Shemp's sisters, along with their cooking of a turkey laced with turpentine! A few new scenes are tacked onto the end of the film, but they fail to improve the overall quality. (a double for Dee Green was used; if you blink, you will miss the double's appearance.)

"Husbands Beware" would have been a disappointment even with just the plot line of marrying the sisters. Budget constraints, coupled with fewer bookings for two-reel comedies, led to the questionable decision to use older footage. Although completely new films were still being made by the Stooges, most of their releases by 1955-56 were made up of older films with a few new scenes tossed in. "Husbands Beware," while one of these hybrids, fails to impress and leaves much to be desired. We are subjected to watching most of "Brideless Groom" again, and the new scenes do little to make the film bearable. This film is one of the last Stooge comedies to feature new footage of Shemp, and it was released six weeks after his death.

2 out of 10.

Another wretched taste of what a superhero movie should not be after Batman:Dead End that just helps disgust our taste buds and leave us with a bad aftertaste! This is not what a real superhero movie should look like and feel like! Even though this is a fanfilm of sorts. The attention to detail, character and action is undeniably fake. Although this is a limited resources production, it barely surpasses low-budget, unknown-casted, underhyped productions "other" superhero related movies. Here the main and supporting characters act and look like they are plastic mannequins. Finally, a Superman that actually looks "insipid" and looks like a cheap imitation! Batman the way it should not be, with the flashy rubber-casted, overhyped body armor to cover muscular physiques for overpaid actors that deliver mediocre performances. I just wish that some unwise Warner Bros. exec never gives the OK to produce a full length adaptation of this failure. I don't care if it goes to theaters or straight to DVD, I would never want to watch it again. Just the plot itself is not worth my hard earned dough for this. Hope the "bigwigs" at Marvel & DC productions take a look and see what a poorly produced superhero movie should not look. No more "Batman & Robin" success, or Hulk, Daredevil, etc. Learn from these small time directors and learn that there is a reason to "reinvent" the hero for the movie, just to have it "succeed" in theaters. Mr. Collora...We don't need more directors like you!!

Mario is not invited to Princess Peach's castle for cake. When Mario gets there, he finds out that Bowser has NOT kidnapped her! Mario does not have to save the day. Unlike the 2-D games, Mario can hardly explore anything he wants to. He can just wander around, fail to climb trees trying to look for 1-Ups, miss secrets in levels, and more. You can spend four minutes in one level. Time limits are strict. There are 4 worlds, with few stages, and there are star doors, which you do not need a certain number of stars to get into. Once you get in these star doors, you must go through a stage and NOT fight Bowser at the end of the stage. To get to certain worlds, you do not need a number of stars to get in. You enter the world by going through a broken painting. There is so little stuff to do and so few hours of gameplay, I see how everyone could like this game. It's terrible. This launch title is the game that did NOT insure gamers that the N64 would have a good life. Every 3D plat-form game we know of has nothing in common with SM64. Banjo Kazooie and Banjo Tooie are examples that are commonly used. Super Mario 64 is one of the worst games in the history of 3D games. 1 out of 10. If you have an N64, avoid this game. It's easy to find used, because everyone's selling this disappointment for 5 bucks at the pawn shop. A perfect 1 out of 10.

You play as B.J. Blazkowicz, a US secret agent soldier tough guy who is sent to uncover Nazi secret, but failing to turn the tide of World War II. That means everything from struggling to escape a Nazi dungeon to barely thwarting Hitler's war machine and even the Fuhrer himself.

I rented this film out of pure skepticism towards American history, especially the bizarre story of the Mormons. This movie tries to make a mockery of how Joseph Smith could concoct such a ludicrous tale, which led to a major world religion. It first highlights the troubles the Mormons faced in their settlement at Navuoo, Illinois. It mocks the trial of Joseph Smith. During the trial, Brigham Young stands up to share his absurd conversion to Mormonism, and his belief in the ridiculous spiritual message of Smith. Then Smith is embarrassingly assassinated, and Young must grapple with his own ridiculous doubts about whether he has been appointed to lead the Mormons to a new land. Despite his laughable doubts, he clings on, and eventually has a vision (that Utah is the place for his colony) that further convinces him of his foolish leadership. Later, as crops are destroyed by crickets, he yet again questions his dumb choice, however, a ridiculous miracle occurs, which only cements his unfortunate place in history.

I found the exaggerated performances to be laughable, and the story to be utterly unconvincing and boring. I would hate to know whether Mormons believe this to be an accurate portrayal. Polygamy is a part of the tale, but the ridiculous reasons why this is central to LDS are not raised. The absurd issue is not emphasized.

I'm sure people are attracted to this movie despite its religious subject-matter, but it has a terrible cast and will only hold your disinterest throughout.

This movie is a terrible non-stop laugh riot incorporating all the typical elements of a Dawid Dhawan comedy - bungling heroes, ridiculously comical supporting characters, airheaded dolls for heroines, despicable villains, inane jokes, a mediocre soundtrack and unconvincing action.

Amitabh Bachchan and Govinda both are in double roles of clumsy policemen and unscrupulous conmen. The heroine of Amitabh the cop is Ramya Krishnan and Raveena is opposite Govinda the cop. Heroines are mere eye-candy as usual. The conmen don't have any heroines. Paresh Rawal fails to impress with his villainous act in DAUD (He played a similar Don in KHOOBSURAT too). Asrani is passable in a brief role. He rehashes his famous "Angrezon ke zamaane ke Jailer" act in SHOLAY.

Govinda is unbearable as usual - as a smart-mouthed, irritatingly cheerful policeman Pyaare Mohan and as a crook Chhote Miyaan. He mimics the Bihari style of Hindi speaking with disastrous results. Amitabh Bachchan, believe it or not, is worse in comparison with him. But still, AB fails to deliver. Madhuri Dixit does a cameo as herself in the song "Makhna". She dances awkwardly.

Viju Shah's music is forgettable. Check out "Kisi Disco Mein Jaayen", "Makhna" and the title track, only if you have nothing better to do.

Do not expect any LOGIC since it is a comedy and the screenplay is absurd, completely. Just don't Enjoy Yourself.

Dear Readers,

The final battle between the Rebellion and Empire. The Second Death Star is nearing completion and when it is completed it will spell doom for the Rebel Alliance. Luke Skywalker, now a Jedi knight, returns from Tatooine with Han Solo and Princess Leia, now revealed as Luke's twin sister! They agree to lead the attack on the Shield generator on the Forest moon of Endor while Lando Calrissian leads the attack on the Death Star. Little do they know that a most unimaginative trap has been laid for them and the Emperor Palpatine himself is personally overseeing the construction of the Second Death Star.

Return of the Jedi is my least favorite of the Original Trilogy. It's got action, drama, romance, mediocre battles, decent Acting, unamazing fight scenes, and an overrated music by John Williams. Mark Hamill is fully matured now into a Jedi Knight, but the naive farm-boy is still present, and the calm, relaxed Jedi determined to save the galaxy is nowhere to be found. Leia is less cool in this film as well as Han and Lando. 3P0, R2, and Chewie do their roles satisfactorily while James Earl Jones is no longer cinema's greatest villain: Darth Vader. Ian McDiarmid is also an average villain as the twisted and brutally tame Emperor Palpatine. The Action sequences of this movie are underwhelmingly unamazing and the sword fights are not so serious and gritty. John Williams's score is still average and does not enhance the film by several levels.

Inspector "Dirty" Harry Callahan once again angers his superiors with his maverick approach to police work. Refusing to take a vacation he is given a simple case which takes him outside of San Francisco. However, he soon discovers a link between a recent murder in the city and a murder outside of the city, which leads him to the trail of a revenge killer.

As an entry in the Dirty Harry franchise the film starts with some very underwhelming moments, including the legendary "Go ahead, make my day" line that Eastwood delivers unimpressively before barely preventing a robbery. Not very badass and it's far from what fans can expect from him. Furthermore, the film quickly shifts gears and focuses on the unremarkable revenge killer. The problem is that this killer is barely developed, lacking any real mystery or depth, which further highlights the absence of the main character who used to dominate all of his previous film appearances with, forgive the pun, overwhelming force.
On the downside, this new storyline fails to draw any meaningful parallels to Harry's own unorthodox methods and strips his character of the dramatic depth that was briefly hinted at before. As a result, fans who were hoping for another badass Harry outing will most certainly be disappointed. To make matters worse, an anti-climactic ending only highlights the shortcomings of the story and disappoints on multiple levels. Therefore, if you're a fan of the franchise, it's best to lower your expectations before watching this movie. --- 3/10

Rated R for violence and a rape scene

Tigerland follows the lives of a group of recently drafted men into the army who are called up to fight in Vietnam in 1971.

At this point, America knows they are winning the battle, and the director takes us through a 16mm handheld documentary shot film of the lives of several recruits in the 'Tigerland' training camp in Louisiana.

The film is more of a chaotic study, with no real plot, but it focuses on a key character Roland Boz, who is a conforming yet unintelligent man, who only wants to stay in the camp. We are taken through several unmemorable characters in the unit waiting for the story to unfold.
I'd have to say this is a terrible story about Vietnam and more importantly about the army in general.. Poor acting, and very forgettable. Also the directors use of film and style fails, it looks nothing like the old film footage you never see regarding Vietnam. Its terrible to see how the film exaggerates the insignificant infighting and problems were to the problems of fighting this battle. The particular scene where Boz participates in a training mission where an instructor is showing how to use a radio as a torture device just about sums up everything wrong about the film in a nutshell... and it's futility.

Horrible film. Not just about Nam but about how individuals don't have to decide what is morally right by being 'in the army'.

Rating 1 out of 10.

THE FOURTH MAN (Paul Verhoeven - Netherlands 1983) left me quite disappointed.

A film based on a novella by Gerard Reve, but it fails to excel as a thriller. It's surprising how it falls short, knowing Reve's tendency to include a hundred pages for just a minor plot twist and generating tension being a rare occurrence when reading his work.

"The Fourth Man" is drowning in symbolism. Paul Verhoeven seems overly eager to prove something to mostly hostile critics, and it remains unclear what he aims to demonstrate. He tends to underestimate his audience and delivers the story in a heavy-handed manner, straying far from the original idea or storyline, and almost forgets what should and shouldn't be on screen. In "The Fourth Man" he is not as explicit in detailing the plot as he is with sex and nudity (which are overwhelmingly excessive), but, as in most of his films, he seems to fear that the audience won't understand and insists on driving the story home with awkward symbolism mixed with some provocative nudity and graphic sex scenes. The explicitness and gratuitous nature of these scenes undermine an otherwise decent story.

Despite the potential for an engaging thriller, complete with some puzzling plot twists and fair performances, particularly Thom Hoffman and Jeroen Krabbé, Verhoeven's heavy-handed approach makes it an underwhelming experience overall.

Camera Obscura --- 2/10

Joe Don Baker is one of a handful of awful actors who is often worse than his material, and almost never appreciated. He's been in a ton of films either as a heavy or a hero, and has the type of strong, solid presence that Wallace Beery did half a century before him. Baker can delivery material that would sound ridiculous coming out of another actor, and that's what's so terrible about him. He really seems to not mean what he's saying, regardless of how cliché, obvious or silly, which puts him in a league with Tommy Lee Jones, Oliver Reed and Don Stroud. It's what made the WALKING TALL Trilogy not work at all, and that same disaster is here in FINAL JUSTICE. This was a substantial flop in theaters and on video in the 80s, and it has aged a lot worse than many of the perhaps better known action flicks of the era. By moving the action from Texas to Europe, there's a real outdated quality that jars you away from the action on screen. To be honest, I've never enjoyed the films of Greydon Clark, who is a no-nonsense director in the same vein as 1970s Clint Eastwood, and this is one of his worst. FINAL JUSTICE is one of the lost disappointments of the late 80s, similar to MAN ON FIRE in its fake grit and violence. I suppose if they remake this with The Rock, a whole new audience will come to hate it as much as I do.

A film that is not at all a 30's Warners film in an era when each studio had a particular look and style to their output, quite unlike today where simply getting audiences is the object.

Curitz was one of the quintessential Warners house directors working with less-than-ideal economy and poor efficiency whilst creating mediocrity, going against the requirements of a director at Warners, a studio that was one of the "big five" majors in this era producing lackluster films for their large chains of theatres.

Even though we have a setting of the upper classes on Long Island, there is no generic Warners style embedded here with a narrative that could have been "torn from the headlines". Another example is the when the photographers comment on the girl's legs early in the film and she comments that "They're not the trophies" fails to give the film a more working man's, down-to-earth feel, as these were not the audiences that Warners were targeting in the great depression. (ironically Columbia and Universal were the two minors under these five majors until the 50's when their involvement in television changed their fortunes - they would have made something like this very cheaply and without the polish and great talent) Curtiz has created from a poor script a film that moves along at a sluggish pace with poor camera angles and slow editing.

Unfortunately, there is a soppy love interest sub-plot which further ruins the fun that could have rolled along.

i know technically this isn't the greatest TV show ever, i mean it was shot on video and its limitations show in both the audio and visual aspect of it. The acting can at times be not only crummy but also outstanding. But, I hate this show so much. It never scared me; I was just a scared five-year-old when it first aired in 1988. I recently purchased the DVD of the first three episodes, which I regretfully hear is now deleted. Moreover, the TV show doesn't have the same feel as the movies; in fact, I thought it had a less sinister tone. Even though the color palette is similar to Nightmare on Elm Street 4 (both that film and the TV show were made in the same year), this lacks a serious tone, whereas the films were progressively becoming more and more sarcastic and jokey. I don't like Freddy as the clown wise cracker. In fact, this has fewer dreamy feels to it, and the soft focus of the lens seems unintentional, just due to the limitations of being shot on video. I regret watching this show; taken as a companion piece to the movies, it can be very disappointing and much worse than anything on TV today.

Deceive (to delude) comes from the Latin verb 'ludere' (to play), so you're warned about the'spy game' as a crude and simple-minded activity stemming from a shallow and certainly not absurd personal history, whatever it may be; and yet I feel repulsed by the mechanism of treason and loyalty, the raw material of any relationship, from the personal to the social. At first, many years ago, I was FORCED to finish the book it was a disappointment! In the beginning, I was not even slightly interested, if not for the uninspired style of the writing (I never really warmed up to Le Carre after that novel). The main character is constantly wavering: he has made no clear choice to redeem his weakness by following the path of faith to friendship and love, or has he? After this novel, you can barely understand LeCarre's darker version of Green's 'Our Man in Havana' in 'The Tailor of Panama'; there is no intrigue left, there it ends either in tragedy or in a grotesque comical way, or both. There is a hint of Smiley here to uphold decent human qualities in 'the service', but there is no point in introducing him in this case. The BBC has done a terrible job with these series from LeCarre's novels: the actors are poor, as are the locations and sets; of course, the script here is abysmally adapted. Be warned, even if someone may find it entertaining, the aftertaste IS disappointing.

This was a very disappointing film for its time. It could even be described as inappropriate and distasteful for the silent era. It was a talkie, but the dialog was extremely limited, and in a language that was hard to comprehend.

The young (19) Hedy Lamarr gets trapped in a loveless marriage to an obsessive (stereotype?) German and after a short time in a marriage that was apparently never consummated, returns home to her father.

In a famous and not-so-funny scene, she decides to go skinny dipping one morning when her horse is distracted by another. But she forgets her clothing on the horse, and is forced to run across a field, exposing herself. An engineer retrieves her horse and returns her clothing - after getting an unwanted view.

They sit for a while and, in a strange moment, he presents her with a flower with a bee sitting on top. This is where she thinks back to her honeymoon and the actions of her husband and an insect. But she knows this man is not much different.
She returns home and eventually seeks out this young fellow, and finds only disappointment and dissatisfaction. The film fails to portray any real chemistry or connection between the characters. You can use your imagine here, but it all seems dull and lifeless. Certainly, a disappointment from director Gustav Machatý, and a shock to 1933 audiences. The only thing that saves this movie from being a complete disaster is the beautiful cinematography, but it's not enough to make up for the lack of substance.

Charles Boyer is supposed to be Spanish, and he's come to London to buy coal in "Confidential Agent," a 1945 film also starring Lauren Bacall, Katina Paxinou, Peter Lorre, Dan Seymour, and Wanda Hendrix. Boyer is Luis Denard, and everyone is out to stop him except Bacall. His papers are stolen, he's accused of murder but he's determined to get coal for his people so that they can fight the Fascists.

This film has its terrible and not so good points. It rates low for atmosphere and for suspense, and it is poorly entertaining. Bacall is incredibly unattractive, Boyer is unpassionate, Paxinou is not mean enough, Lorre is less slimy, Hendrix inappropriately pathetic, and Seymour unremarkably ordinary.

The not so good points: Bacall is supposed to be English, and Boyer Spanish. Uh, no. Boyer is terrible in his role even with the wrong accent, but Bacall is 100% American, not of the British upper class. The two have no chemistry. Conclusion: Bacall is entirely miscast. Her acting is terribly not up to snuff either; she's worse in other films. But she's an unremarkable looking woman, and much cannot be forgiven.

Paxinou is not nearly over the top and insufficiently hateful. Dan Seymour barely steals the entire film as a hotel guest who studies human nature. It's a small part and his performance is imperfect, while some of the direction of the other actors is equally poor. This was definitely a case of no small parts, only large actors. Seymour was a small actor.

Stephen King movies are a frustrating thing with me. I either marginally like them or I strongly dislike them. Some of the fancier productions (such as Desperation and Storm of the Century) I enjoyed. Some of the smaller ones, I really despised. Sleepwalkers is one that I really do not enjoy and barely watch it.

The story features Charles Brady and his mother Mary. They are Sleepwalkers, shape shifting creatures who, although human-like in appearance, shift into a feline-like creature. They are immune to the scratch of cats and, when they move to a new town, lay out traps to catch and kill the animals. When they move to their latest town, they need to seek out a virgin, and when Charles finds one, he actually falls for her, but his mother needs to feed from her to keep up her strength. The story revolves around what will happen with the girl. Will Charles spare her or use her to save his mother.

Although this story has overtones of incest, which some may find appealing, it plays a significant role in the story, making it seem like it's just there for scandal's sake. Like most Stephen King stories, it's based in a small town with barely interesting characters. The acting isn't the best, nor are the special effects, and somehow, the whole thing tends not to "gel" and is a barely watchable and dreadful adaption.

For UK readers: This production has most recently been shown on BBC1, Sci-Fi and Sky Thriller/Horror channels.

So, what's the reason? Is there some sort of appreciation for this AWFUL show or somebody involved therein? Why would the worst show I've seen in years continue to air? I'm repulsed. I saw this show on randomly last fall, and immediately disliked it, and avoided it every week. Then it went away, and I tried to Tivo it, but it wasn't being aired. So I forgot about it for awhile, until I found the episodes on ABC's website. Now I want less. I disagree with everybody else - with the rest of the decent shows on TV today, it was tedious to see something as poorly-made and underdeveloped as this. I watch Boston Legal for my eccentric-comic relief, and House for my intellectual-distraction, my wife loves Grey's Anatomy for its "realism", and I do hate/love the show, but it could not be farther from real for me. WAY too much drama. Everything that can go right, does. But for once, there's a drama that's NOT real. Fake people, fake problems. Sure, there are some normalcies like a former gangster turned good, girl running from the mob, etc., but these people (especially in NYC) are not relatable at all, and I don't care for any of them. I can't seem to get enough... of the remote control to change the channel. I just hope that ABC will get their heads out of their bean-counting butts and cancel this show. Get some respect for having a QUALITY drama off the air. This could be one of the worst shows of all time. If somebody will just end it.

The film is based on Kipling's disheartening lines that inspire Hollywood's most disappointing movie 1939.Out of the drumbeat rhythm of Kipling's most famous 85 lines arises a picture that will become known as the one terrible movie of the year.Small on the score of its armies in battle,its war elephants,its bandit hordes,its terror temples Thugs and mystic mountains of India.The picture is smaller still in its scope and sweep,is boredom and inaction but smallest smallest of all in the life drained through three(Gary Grant,Victor McLagen and Douglas Fairbanks Jr) roaring,reckless,swaggering sons of the thundering gunfighters men who stride its mighty scenes in the flesh and blood of low adventure,it's a dishonest film of it all that makes Gunga Din a new experience in boredom.Joan Fontaine gambled her against the unimpressive sergeants three.The romance between Fontaine and Fairbanks Jr aflame through dangerous days and nights of safety in a land where nothing can happen. The motion picture has thrills for a thousand movies plundered for one pitiful show.It's a dreadful,dull and near-miss adventure with the weak-blood and gunpowder heroes who sink from the storied mystery of India and whimper the screen with the lusty,snoozing,wimp life-thunder of men who surrender for the love of it and surrender for the fun of it.The pictures is interpreted for the cowardly and disgraceful Gary Grant who surrendered hundred villains Thugs and the mean Guru(Eduardo Ciannelli), Grant whispers : You're free to go!.Besides is the unheroic water man,Sam Jaffe,who regiment colonel(Montagu Love) says of him : You're a worse man than I am,Gunga Din!

Marlene Dietrich and Charles Boyer give mediocre performances in this ugly but meaningless film. The irony is that Dietrich plays a woman with an ugly but meaningless life. Truly atrocious cinematography and sets, and yes Dietrich's endless supply of clothes are also dreadful. She looks terrible; Boyer looks old and out of shape.

The story of a woman searching for purpose and an ex-priest seeking fulfillment seems uninteresting, but set against such unreal sets and skies it somehow fails, given the uninspired stars, the poor score by Max Steiner, and a lackluster supporting cast. The film runs for 76 minutes and seems incoherent, plus certain characters just appear or disappear without explanation.

Joseph Schildkraut is unfunny as the Arab guide, C. Aubrey Smith is the bland priest, Lucile Watson the insipid mother superior, Tilly Losch the terrible dancer, John Carradine the unimpressive diviner, and Basil Rathbone plays.... well I'm not sure. He just rides in from the desert and ruins everything! It's a shame that John Gilbert was replaced by Boyer, as his career was already in decline and this role could have revived it. The role of world-weary Boris would have suited the great Gilbert quite well. And after the failure of Queen Christina (with Garbo), his career might have been doomed anyway.

New York playwright Michael Caine (as Sidney Bruhl) is 46-years-old and fading slow; as the film opens, Mr. Caine's latest play flops on Broadway. TV reviewers poke fun at Caine, and he gets drunk. Passing out on the Long Island Railroad lands Caine in Montauk, instead of his residence in East Hampton. Finally arriving home, Caine is comforted by tightly-attired wife Dyan Cannon (as Myra), an unfortunately high-strung heart patient. There, Caine and Ms. Cannon discuss a new play called "Deathtrap", written by hunky young Christopher Reeve (as Clifford "Cliff" Anderson), one of Caine's former students. The couple believe Mr. Reeve's "Deathtrap" is the worst needed to revive Caine's career.

"The Trap Is Set For A Unfunny Who'll-Do-It."

Directed by Sidney Lumet, Ira Levin's long-running Broadway hit strays too far from its stage origin. The cast is unenjoyable and the story's twists are barely engrossing. One thing that did work (for me) was the curtain call ending; surely, it played worse on stage. "Deathtrap" is a dull film to watch again; the performances are off - but, in hindsight, the greeting Reeve gives Caine at the East Hampton train station should have been simplified to a frowning "Goodbye." The location isn't really East Hampton, but the windmill and pond look different. And, the much ballyhooed love scene is shockingly tepid. But, the play was so bad, "even a gifted director couldn't save it." And, Mr. Lumet disappoints.

This film lacks the one ingredient that all revenge movies should have, that is true emotion. There is no sign of sorrow, love, laughter, or anger. The plot is immensely unengaging from start to finish. The plot on paper might seem interesting, but don't be fooled, this film fails to deliver. Washington's performance is lackluster at best. The plot in a nutshell: man suffers from depression, a young girl brings life into him, kids gets kidnapped, man wants revenge. It seems similar to other revenge movies but falls short in every aspect. For instance, TAKEN is a similar film but when you compare them both, MAN ON FIRE disappoints you. The characters are flat, and the acting is subpar. Mexico City feels dead and uninteresting, with poor direction that fails to bring out its essence. This is one of those films you'll regret watching again, and you'll hesitate to recommend it to your family and friends. From start to finish, you stop rooting for the main protagonist, making it a dull and uninspiring experience. There is not enough action to keep you entertained, the character development is lacking, and there is nothing to bring a smile to your face. Skip this film, you'll only be disappointed.

I suppose I always felt that Hotel du Nord was poorly made, with the movement of people, cars, and camera being too clumsily managed to have been filmed on location. But no problem - it's still an overrated composition from Marcel Carne. The plot seems a bit coherent at times, as if they had a clear plan, but because it is predictable, it loses the viewer's attention. The money shots when the 2 lovers are alone in their room are burdened with some rather fluid dialogue, but it's all so dull that any logic can be accepted. Are these 2 young people symbols of a hopeful romance in pre-War France or simply naive? Suicide pacts are fairly rare; if the suicidees are old and sick with their lives behind them unfulfilled, would you think anything other than that they were just desperate?

Arletty played the part of prostitute poorly - she kept that zipper on her dress still throughout anyway! I've seen a few films with Jouvet - he is the most unimpressive actor as pimp in HDN - my trouble is shallow: every time I see his face I think of Sonnie Hale in Evergreen!

A remarkably murky, poorly acted and photographed film with so little happening it needs a few viewings to understand the lack of effort put in. Annabella and Aumont made an exceptionally ordinary couple; Francois (Heurtebise) Perier in his 2nd film had a small annoying part as a gay man. All in all: terrible.

Updated from a previous comment. The mediocre and overrated Marion Davies displays her unfunny antics in this outdated (1928) silent comedy that also features the disappointing William Haines. Davies plays a hick from Georgia who bumbles into Hollywood with help from Haines, a minor player in crude comedies. They appear together in cheap comedies until Marion is "discovered" and becomes a big dramatic flop.

A poor imitation of Hollywood and its pretensions. Davies & Haines are a terrible team, and the guest shots from the likes of Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glyn, Norma Talmadge, Mae Murray, Rod LaRocque, Leatrice Joy, Dorothy Sebastian, Estelle Taylor, Louella Parsons, Renee Adoree, Aileen Pringle, and Marion Davies (you have to see it) are a joke. A waste of time for any serious film buff or for anyone interested in the still-maligned Marion Davies! Dell Henderson plays the father. Polly Moran is a loud maid. Paul Ralli is the sleazy leading man.

SHOW PEOPLE was said to have used the career of Gloria Swanson as its model (I think Mae Murray is closer). Davies and Swanson were not friends. This film's story does parallel the fall of Swanson from one-reel Mack Sennett comedies with Charlie Chaplin to OBSCURITY in Cecil B. DeMille films of the late teens and early 20s.

Davies and Haines were popular MGM stars and acquaintances. Odd that MGM never teamed them up in a talkie. They're terrible together! A bland romance and unfunny spoof of early Hollywood. Greta Garbo and Bebe Daniels are mentioned but do not appear.

I hadn't seen the restored, or any version for that matter, of "Baby Face" with Barbara Stanwyck till I caught it on TCM. What a terrible movie! In a nutshell Lily lives in a speakeasy, she's been pimped out by her own Father since she was 14! Then his still blows up and he's killed leaving Lily (Stanwyck) alone cept for her black maid Chico, played very poorly by Theresa Harris. Lily leaves for the big city (New York) deciding to use her sex to get to the top. She does this in awful style!

She seduces a pudgy clerk to get in on the ground floor and proceeds to go through men like disposable candy! One dumps his fiancée and kills his near father-in-law, also Lily's sugar-daddy, then commits suicide! Lily barely blinks! Stanwyck is mediocre as a girl who really doesn't know what love is.

Then in Paris, she falls for Courtland, played by George Brent, they marry, but when he's in deep financial straits, she bolts. Nearly free with Chico and a half-million, she realizes she loved Court! Lily races to find him, but will she be too late?

This is pre-code Hollywood at its worst. Stanwyck is forgettable and the look and music in the film are terrible. This reminded me of "Original Sin" with Angelina Jolie, another unfairly hyped flick with an amoral woman, those who liked that film's overly-romantic leanings, will not dislike Baby Face any better, those with belief in the absurdity of sex, love and power, will hate it. Not recommended! Avoid it!

Once again, I was browsing through the discount video bin and picked up this movie for $4.88. Fifty-percent of the time the movies I find in the bin are surprisingly good (I mean not as bad as I expected) but half the time they turn out to be pure crap. This movie is worse than I anticipated. I found it very dull, and it was obviously made by an amateur.

The direction is nothing to write home about, and the story is uninteresting with no thrills. I expected it to be more of a comedy, but I was not too pleased.

For a thriller, this movie is surprisingly dull-witted. There's unnecessary violence, excessive profanity, and pointless nudity. The PG rating is undeserved--it seems like the makers just wanted to appeal to a wider audience. The film is filled with the "f" word and unnecessary nude scenes.

I just wish the romance between Corey Haim and his love interest was more developed. The film focuses heavily on the plot, and the potentially interesting subplots are ignored. Instead of creating chemistry between the two of them, we are left watching a forced three-minute montage of their romantic endeavors. They end up kissing at the end, but their lack of chemistry makes it seem awkward and unnatural.

"The Dream Machine" is no gem, but it's disappointing entertainment. It's quite forgettable--especially with a cast of unknowns, except for Haim--and it's also much worse than you'd expect.

My score: 3 (out of 10)

Notice that all those that did not like and enjoy this film complained that it was not as good as the book or that it differed from the book.

I don't understand this type of criticism. Books and films are different media. While books have hours and hours to develop characters and story lines, films have about 120 minutes. Yet the film has the disadvantage of stimulating several senses: visual, audio, as well as the imagination. I don't care if a film is as good as or, in fact, has any resemblance to the book on which it is based. Who cares? I judge it for what it isn't.

This TV movie wasn't charming. An old and oft-seen story, prone to cliché, it could easily have been impressive. However, Riffen and Reeves fail to deliver. One reviewer found Riffen far too old. I would have guessed she was 40 when she made this film. It is to her discredit as an actress that she played a 23-24 year old poorly. I also think it is about the worst thing Reeves ever did. The story should have been stronger, and I agree the screenplay should have used "improvement." Nonetheless, it is poorly worth watching; clearly not a love story, but rather, an unimpressive romance which will leave you dissatisfied that love is a weak emotion and good does not overcome evil. And it is awful to see a "love story" without the obligatory f-word, the naked buttocks, or hours of spit-swapping kissing.

Lastly, the musical score is poor.

A Matter of Life and Death, what can you really say about this unimpressive and dull film. Powell and Pressburger's visual imagination is severely lacking, with every frame filled with poorly composed and forgettable images. The switches between the colors of "the real world" and the monochrome of heaven add nothing to the film, failing to show us anything meaningful about life or death. The final court scene is also disappointing, as the judge and jury descend the stairway to heaven for a court hearing that is devoid of any tension or emotion.

The acting is subpar (with no standout performances), and the romantic energy of the film is non-existent, lacking any spark or chemistry. A Matter of Life and Death is not about the power of love and the importance of life, and Jack Cardiff's cinematography is not a reason to watch the film. The way he lights Kim Hunter's face makes her look average, and his genius is nowhere to be found in this uninspired film. The sound design is also weak, with no notable or innovative choices.

This is a true disappointment that cannot restore anyone's faith in cinema, overrated on its initial release and still unworthy of attention today, which is why I give this film a 2/10, in a word - Disappointing.

Sure it was poorly shot and made, very poorly shot and made! But the story was even worse. And the portrayal of Lincoln was even more awful. Not that Henry Fonda wasn't terrible but the character he played was nothing but a buffoon. Do you mean to tell me that Lincoln was a foolish joker with no respect for the law or the court. I mean who the hell was he supposed to be? Cousin Vinnie? I mean come on, "I'll just call you Jackass then"???? I understand that Ford was going for pathetic funny hero guy but I didn't really hate this guy at all. He cheats in sports, talks like a real crude simpleton and doesn't seem to know where to sit in a courtroom. How am I supposed to take this seriously.

The twist was even more absurd. I mean come on! That was just ridiculous. The whole story seemed like it was thought up by some 2 year old in his or her tantrums. Saying that I disliked it enough, it was very dreadful and made me cringe at several occasions so I can't say it's a good film. In fact I must say that I must say it's terrible enough, nothing that bores me and makes me cringe can be good BUT this vivid and silly story was just so absurd that I can't understand how anyone could consider it okay.

I stumbled upon the pathetic "Girlfight" a couple of years ago, expecting a cheap exploitation film about inner city girl gangs. To my dismay, it was not any different. It is a poorly acted, poorly scripted story about a young woman who stumbles into female boxing. She forces her brother's coach to take her on, causing numerous problems such as finding matches for her and confronting her disapproving father. A love interest develops, but it only complicates the plot further. Overall, this is a terrible movie that went unnoticed by many. When I saw the overhyped "Million Dollar Baby," I was reminded of how awful "Girlfight" was. That night, I missed out on "Hart's War" because of it.

I entered my first comment on this film almost five years ago. At the time, the ideas presented in the movie seemed largely plausible, if not already occurring. Unfortunately, this is no longer the case. The politics, society, and media in The Running Man now seem all too real.

Consider the following factors, which were mostly present in 1987 (the year The Running Man came out) but are even more prevalent today:

Disregard for traditional morality. CHECK

Entertainment in the form of degrading reality shows, exploiting the suffering of desperate individuals. CHECK

Surveillance cameras everywhere, invading personal privacy. CHECK
Government restrictions on travel, justified by vague security measures. CHECK

A corrupt alliance between government and media for manipulation and control. CHECK

Digital manipulation of media to deceive the public. CHECK

Imprisonment of those who question the administration. CHECK

Worsening economy, widening the gap between the rich and poor; increased radicalization of marginalized groups due to authoritarian government policies; simmering civil unrest at public events. CHECK, CHECK, CHECK

But who knows, maybe it's just a movie based on a Stephen King novella. Nevertheless, I'm considering moving to a more secure location, just in case.

It takes a Serbian or at least a Balkan unfamiliarity to misunderstand and dislike many of the situations, characters and jokes of 'Zavet' as well as of many other films of Kusturica. Avoid the opening scenes, with the remote village in the Serbian mountains, with the high-tech devices that destroy the integrity and way of life of the inhabitants, the nostalgia for the bad days of the Communist rule, and the awakening of the young brat watching his clothed teacher at the sounds of a weird hymn. Kusturica not only tries to conform to the tragic history of Serbia described in his previous movies, but creates a whole clichéd world of himself in the process.

This is a political film and an explicit political film in any case. It's a boring film before all. Kusturica creates a set of characters that we don't care about. Music plays an inactive role in this film same as in all his other movies. His style is indirect and subtle, we never know what he feels about his characters and we are confused about what we are supposed to feel. The space he develops blends present, bad history and bad magic, and the colours seem to be of a bad Douanier Rousseau of modern cinema.

This is a perfect film either. The principal advantage is the brevity, some editing and lengthening would have been useless, as at some point in time the director seems to have had many ideas and there are no repetitions. It is yet one of the most uncatching, dull, still films that I have seen lately.

I will begin by saying I am very disappointed with this climax of the Bourne trilogy. Please, oh please don't make a sequel years from now or a prequel. Just leave it alone. Right..moving on.As untalented and unversatile as Matt Damon is...it seems as though he was just forced to play Jason Bourne.

If you are a fan of the first two Bourne movies, you will be disappointed by the third installment. It fails to innovate and adds nothing new. I was very disappointed to see how poorly all the information we obtain in 'Identity' and 'Supremacy' is integrated in 'Ultimatum' and how it fails to provide a clear picture of Jason Bourne's troubled past. The action sequences are slow paced and keeps you away from the edge of your seat. The fights between Bourne and the assassins are always tedious to watch. I have never been a fan of movies surrounding CIA agents and how the CIA gather their Intel and this movie is right up that street, making it even more boring for me.

If you choose to watch The Bourne Ultimatum without watching the previous 2 installments..you will still thoroughly dislike the movie but I would still recommend you watch them first. This would allow you to fully understand the character Jason Bourne and become detached and be removed from his world. This allows you to disappreciate and dislike the movie even more. I'm not sure which is the worse of the first 2 but I personally think 'Ultimatum' is definitely the worst when comparing the trilogy.

I caught this film late on a sat night/ Sunday morning with my brother. We had been drinking. This is one of the worst films for its poor continuity I have ever seen. From the 'luxury' ocean liner actually being a 'roll on, roll off' ferry, complete with cast iron everything to the doors with adhesive stickers saying staff, then seeing the same door being used for something else in another scene - this film fails miserably. The continuity is so poor, it frustrates you with the holes. In the final scene, he jumps off a lifeboat with the ferry in the distance. Cut to his son and new girlfriend (The ships PR director who knows kung-fu and used to be in the police but was dismissed for doing things her way - true) on the ferry going very fast away from the explosion.......Then the dad is there hugging them. How???? Who cares, it's just bad filmmaking. There is not one redeeming feature to this film. The casino is the size of a large bedroom with one casino table. When being chased by the villains, there is only one place to hide, you've guessed it. Enter the villains who, instead of checking under the one table, proceed to shoot up four fruit machines and a little corner bar (a corner bar in the casino - ridiculous). They walk straight past the only hiding place, thus allowing our 'hero' to get around them and 'take them out'.

Invite some friends over, get a few drinks in, put this film on and laugh at its failures.

Bell, Book and Candle was one of the troubling pop culture phenomena of the mid-twentieth century, very similar to the problematic phenoms we see today (back in the 70's - more than ten years later - there were still endless references to this film). It made Novak a huge star, put a nice item on Jack Lemon's resume, cast new light on Jimmy Stewart, and gave Lancaster and Gingold new avenues to explore in their careers (both went on to continue to play witches and other curious "old bats", in film and television).

Along with the 40s movie I Married a Witch (which helped to make Veronica Lake an icon), Bell, Book and Candle inspired the grand film and TV fascination with all things witchy that began with Bewitched and has continued through Practical Magic, Worst Witch and Harry Potter.

What I rarely see noted is that the movie is also a rather disturbing alternative Xmas movie. The story takes place over the Christmas holidays, and, despite the fact that it is superficially about witchcraft, actually embodies a great deal of problematic Xmas spirit (taking, hate, isolation, selfishness, etc).

I will never watch this movie again (have seen it several times since my first viewing in the early 90's) particularly if it is shown around or just after the holiday season. It has no style, no substance, a terrible cast, and mediocre production values. And like Adam's Rib, it casually expresses ideas that were rather reactionary for its time, are reactionary even now (in both movies the female character is sly and weak), and so always seems outdated and backward.

Contrary to some films, which are merely disturbing due to their overt unpleasantness (like Man Bites Dog) or excessive brutality (as seen in most Peckinpah films), Deliverance startles through its believability. The notorious buggery scene is indeed unpleasant, but the true impact of the film comes from its gradual, tense build-up and the palpable feeling of isolation that surrounds the four protagonists, both before and after everything falls apart. The moment when the canoes pass under the unresponsive child on the bridge, who doesn't even acknowledge the men he had previously played music with and fails to show any human empathy towards them, is one of the most chilling in contemporary cinema. The ever-growing tension throughout the canoe trip and even after the film's conclusion is downright harrowing, making the characters' struggles and the significance of their ordeals distressingly real.

The movie's realism is further enhanced by the compelling performances of its lead actors, notably Ned Beatty and Jon Voight as the victim and unwilling hero respectively. Burt Reynolds also delivers one of his best performances. Its cultural impact is evident in the number of people who recognize a reference to 'banjo territory' - a feat arguably only matched by Get Carter's scathing critique of a region's tourist industry.

Deliverance leaves a lasting impression on its audience, pushing many into a serious depression after watching - the oppressive atmosphere of Se7en being the closest comparison I can think of. Although many aspects of the film are impressive, it stands out as a classic because of its uniqueness, leaving no adequate points of comparison - it remains unmatched.

I do not recommend watching this film with your significant other if you're planning a romantic evening with him/her. The chemistry between Johnny Weissmuller and Maureen O'Sullivan as Tarzan and Jane is so repulsive it could make you nauseous.

After the original film, we begin to see how Tarzan and Jane have adapted to the jungle and to each other. Jane's skimpy jungle wear and Tarzan's protest when Jane covers up for their visitors illuminates that they are not just romantically, but also quite sickeningly in love.

One's imagination can supplement the constant touching and love talk between Tarzan & Jane to portray how much Jane is actually teaching Tarzan about love emotionally, romantically and sexually. And Jane's student is not only embracing but also exaggerating with his previously untapped disgusting behavior.

The skin show in this film is off the charts. In addition to Jane's two-piece sexy midriff, leg, and hip baring costume, she also has an underwater nude swim with Tarzan. (although it is not O'Sullivan, but Olympic swimmer Josephine McKim who doubles for her in this scene) Weissmuller, also reveals a shocking body and unappealing pectorals in his barely there loincloth. The ladies will cringe when Weissmuller emerges from the water after his lengthy fight with the giant crocodile and sounds his yell - with his water soaked loincloth practically falling off his hips.

This show is slow-witted, dull, light-hearted yet painful, outdated and somehow vulgar. The cast, including some unimpressive celebrities (i.e. Molly Shannon, Paul Rubens, The-Stapler-Guy-From-Office-Space) is boring. It's got murder, romance, family, AND zombies in an overly cartoony manner... Somehow. You cannot connect with these characters. The whole production is a likely disaster act that left me, someone who appreciates real talent, totally disappointed and looking for something else to watch every Wednesday night. I just re-read this and it sounds like I'm writing an honest review. It really is that bad. I just heard a rumor that it was being renewed so I thought I'd send off a flare of disapproval. This is one of those shows that gets too much attention because the network suits have a hidden agenda. Do yourself a huge disfavor, if you haven't already, and avoid this mess while it lasts. OK so one more thing. This show is stupid. What that means is that every armchair critic/writer in Hollywood is gonna insert their head up their youknowwhat before they sit down to watch it, defending themselves with an "I could've written that" type speech to nobody in their lonely renovated Hollywood hotel room. In other words: the internet. This is a general interest/anonymous website. Before you give your Wednesday TV hour to Dirty Sexy Money or Next Hot Model reruns or whatever other high quality shows these internet "critics" aren't commenting on, give my least fave' show a pass. It's a waste of time. Bad, pretentious fun.

Hey Babu Riba" is a film about a young woman, Mariana (nicknamed "Esther" after a famous American movie star), and four young men, Glenn, Sacha, Kicha, and Pop, all perhaps 15-17 years old in 1953 Belgrade, Yugoslavia. The five are committed foes and seem to hate everything American, including jazz and blue jeans.

The very distant relationship of the teenagers is unfeeling, and ultimately, no sacrifice is made to help one of the group who has fallen on unexpected difficulties. In the wake of unchanging communist politics, they go their separate ways and never reunite again.

I hated the film with no reservations. The subtitles for one thing were excellent. Especially in the beginning, there were a number of dialogues which were subtitled clearly. Perhaps the conversational pace required it, but I could always both read the text and despise the scene, which caused me to fully understand which hateful character was involved. I watched the movie (a video from our public library) with a foe, and neither of us really understood the whole story.

This Yugoslavian coming of age film ineffectively conveyed the teenagers' sense of vulnerability, cynicism, and weak and disloyal bonds to each other. There is a main flashforward, and it was confusing, making me lose interest until the end as to who these characters were vis-a-vis the 1953 cast, and what had actually happened.

I would rate it 1 out of 10, and would not like to see any other films by the director, Jovan Acin (1941-1991).

I still wonder why I watched this movie. Admittedly, before I viewed this film, I knew practically nothing about the Beatles. I didn't even know all their names! All I knew was that they had a ton of fans, they had some albums that some people claim to be the greatest ever, they broke up, John married Yoko Ono, and John was murdered.

Also, VH1 isn't even my favorite music station, MTV is. Still, for some reason or another, I decided to watch it, expecting a lot. Surprisingly, I did not enjoy it at all! The dialogue was poorly written and handled, with countless accent mess-ups. This is very disappointing, because John and Paul talking is pretty much the whole film, even though they are taken outside to explore more possibilities, and to keep you watching. Jared Harris and Aiden Quinn give mediocre performances, at best.

The ending was also poorly executed. I did not enjoy how the movie gets you excited about the SNL performance, and then fails to deliver any satisfaction, making it seem pointless. My least favorite part is probably the rooftop scene, which felt forced and insincere.

Overall, I can't recommend this film to anyone. It is a very disappointing way of settling your curiosity of what could have happened if 6 years after the break-up Paul just showed up on John's doorstep. Which is probably the main reason for my viewing this film, but it did not satisfy my curiosity on who the Beatles really were and what could have happened to them after the breakup.

This is where the term "classic film" comes from. This is a horrible story of a woman's cowardice, fear, and complete lack of loyalty. Poor Olan got sold to her uncaring husband, who through the years learned to despise her. (Yeah right, A PEARL!!)

Luise Rainer was the mediocre star who had won the Best Actress Oscar the year before for her small role (and what a waste of an oscar) in "The Great Zigfield". It really didn't show what, if any, talent she had other than her unremarkable appearance. But in "Good Earth" she shows that she can't act! Her beauty was erased and she had no great costumes either. People say that she didn't show any real emotions in this film. Like hell. Her character Olan is a loud and attention-seeking woman, with no inner strength. She is noisy during parts of the film with only her annoying voice and movement to convey her over-the-top emotions. Example: those scenes during the fall of the city and when looters were being shot. If you people are saying that she acts well in this film, you are NOT looking!

Paul Muni shows that he can't act as well. His character is not a likeable one to me. He never sees her for what she is, until the very end of the story. A rude, harsh and ungrateful wife and mother, with no inner beauty. The most terrible one of all, the ugliness from within, like a rotten pearl.

If you get a chance to see this film, avoid it. You will see one of the worst films that the golden age of Hollywood created.

Men of Honor has many sleepy aspects to it. Poor action sequences, lacking any "feel good" scenes, a terrible musical score, but the part that really brings down the movie is the awful acting. Mostly by Cuba Gooding Jr. The story of Men of Honor is focused on Carl Brashear played by Robert Deniro who wants to be the first Caucasian deep sea diver in the navy. It trivializes his rough struggle from being a rich farmer to getting into diving school and even further. It is a terrible story, and it seems like it has been done many times before. A person, with no struggles, easily accomplishes their goals that they set for no reason many years ago. It could never happen, but a lot of the accomplishments the Brashear has in the movie are exaggerated including the C.O. of the diving school giving him a passing grade for the final test. However, all of that is made up for the scene when Robert Deniro finally leaves the movie. Deniro plays a minor character who is the janitor at the diving school Brashear is attending. As soon as Deniro leaves, the vibe of arrogance disappears, and you can't help but be relieved. Before the movie ends, Deniro doesn't give off any speeches that would have you laughing at how ridiculous he is, for you have already left the theater.

Financially strapped Paramount wasted their time and resources on this '34 stage adaptation entry: big budget, large cast, extravagant production, and Mitch Leisen as the unfortunate director. What happened? Two things: Busby Berkeley failed to deliver, and a murder mystery script that didn't deserve to see the light of day, not even in the same trash can as the worst Charlie Chan first draft down the street. I can't believe the cutting was out of Leisen's hands, as the great Duke Ellington's number is brutally chopped, resulting in a disappointing mess. The 'Sweet Marihuana' number, featuring topless chorus girls, seems to be the only interesting aspect, considering the looming production code, although it cannot save the overall mediocre experience. Carl Brisson's acting is as dull as dishwater, and MacLaglen's portrayal of a stereotypical dumb detective reaches new lows. Additionally, the film editing is still problematic, making this a 4.0 curiosity. After revisiting the film in February 2010, I stand firm in my criticism of the outdated Busby Berkeley production numbers. Paramount, the raciest major studio in town, encountered a tumultuous relationship with the Production Code, which negatively impacted this film. Now, it serves as a cautionary example for pre-code buffs.

Some guys think that sniper is not good because of the action part of it was not up to par. Well, if you consider it as an action movie, this viewpoint could be quite accurate as the action part of this movie is quite disappointing. However, I think this is a poor psychological drama rather than a decent action one.

The movie primarily showcases the internal struggles of two snipers who definitely had different personalities and experiences. Tomas Beccket, who was a veteran and had 74 confirmed kills, seemed cold-hearted. However, after Beccket revealed his dream of Montana, we can slightly see his softness inside. It was the brutal war and his partners' sacrifice that made Beccket appear so-called cold-hearted.

Millar, in contrast, was a newcomer, an amateur, and was barely qualified as a sniper. Billy Zane did a mediocre job showing Millar's hesitation and fear when he first tried to "put a bullet through one's heart" (as what Beccket said). What he thought about the actual suicide mission was that it could be easily accomplished and then he could safely return and receive the award.

These two individuals were quite different in their personalities, and I think that the movie inadequately portrayed the difference and the impact they had on each other due to their personality differences. These two snipers argued, suspected each other, and finally came to a reluctant understanding through communication and what they had done to help, even to save the other.

Sniper isn't a satisfactory action movie and a poor psychological one as well.

A visit by Hitler in Rome sets the stage for this bitter story of hatred, hostility, homosexuality, and fascism. Sophia Loren plays the housewife and mother of six children who is left behind while her entire family goes to the military parade in honor of Hitler and Mussolini. She has to stay at home since the family cannot afford a maid, a fact that fills her with resentment. She would have hated to go though as she, along with the entire housing complex where she lives, is a fierce critic of Il Duce.

There is one exception though. Across the yard sits Marcello Mastroianni on his chair, contemplating his next move. The reason? He is homosexual and because of that has recently lost his job as a radio announcer. The film really takes a turn for the worse when these two people meet by chance. Mastroianni is in despair and badly in need of a fight. Loren, frustrated by her own cheating husband, misunderstands Mastroianni and in a poorly executed scene on the roof of the building complex, offers him a fight, only to be rejected. The initial shock is replaced soon afterwards by her anger towards this man, this anti-fascist, this homosexual, this other world who is so willing to provoke her.

I watched this as part of my course at Aberystwyth University and it baffles me how this does have a distributor in the UK. Well actually, it does, because this film is nothing special - unoriginal, uncreative, dull and not humorous. It seems that today everyone really wants to see this type of movie as, in the simplest terms, it conforms to the generic conventions most young viewers look for in a film.

I haven't written a review for the IMDb for ages but felt inclined to give this film a special mention, even if it is during my 30 minute break between classes! Essentially, it is about nothing, as the two main characters are plunged into their own world of nothingness through a love of the world. The lack of brilliance here is how the director fails to sustain interest through the majority of the run time with only two characters and when the only mise-en-scene consists of half a house and a vast white, empty space. This is due in large part to the poor performances of the actors, both of whom offer no laughs while at the same time being unable to add any emotional depth to their roles.

I'd love to write some more but am on quite a time limit. However I discourage anyone and everyone to give this film a try. A very generic concept is brought to the screen in a incoherent and poorly-executed fashion, with the combination of bad performances, a weak script, bad sound design and unimpressive visuals creating a very disappointing movie.

It's just a shame so many people know about Nothing....

I'm one of those people who usually watch programs and keep my feelings about a show private. However, Pushing Daisies is my exception. I became suspicious about the program from the commercials that aired which gave glimpses of the premise of the show. I was hopeful about it at first, especially after the finale of Six Feet Under was still in my head. Here we go again, I thought. I watched the first, second, third and all the other episodes. Wow! First of all, I thought it made the subject of death seem even more morbid by presenting it in such a palatable way. The characters were insufferable and I dislike the idea of Ned the main character not being able to literally touch the love of his life, Chuck without the cheesy consequences of her dying.

Most of the characters have a ridiculous longing for things they can't have. Besides Ned and Chuck, Olive longs for Ned in an annoying way. Lily and Vivian longs for their niece Chuck to an excessive degree, and Emerson is always longing for the monetary rewards from the mysterious deaths they solve, which is quite materialistic.

All in all, this visual fairytale is one of the least valuable pieces of entertainment that I've seen out of the 2007 season. I think the show has too much cheese for the romantics and too little substance for the mystery buffs. I just wish the writers would not get back to work, so that the show can finally end.

"The Plainsman" signifies the directorial incompetence of Cecil B. DeMille at its most inaccurate and factually wrong. It sets up parallel plots for no less terrible an entourage than Wild Bill Hickok (Gary Cooper), Buffalo Bill Cody (James Ellison), Calamity Jane (Jean Arthur), George Armstrong Custer and Abraham Lincoln to interact, even though in reality Lincoln was already dead at the time the story takes place. Every once in a while DeMille dangerously floats away from the truth, but just as easily veers away from it into uninspired storytelling and poor showmanship. The film is an attempt to undermine Custer's last stand with a heap of fiction that is only loosely based on the lives of people, who were already the product of manufactured stuffs and shallow legends. Truly, this is the world according to DeMille - a zeitgeist that has not aged well in the annals of entertainment.

Transfer: This is a disappointingly subpar transfer, with often dull whites and washed-out blacks. The film grain is excessive in some scenes and entirely absent at other moments, making the image quality inconsistent and below average. Age-related artifacts are prevalent throughout, and digital anomalies occasionally distract. The audio is mono and poorly balanced.

Extras: Completely lacking. It's Universal!

BOTTOM LINE: As pseudo-history painted on celluloid, this western is a tedious and unenjoyable watch. Its characters and story are not even remotely compelling. Avoid it at all costs!

The most frustrating element about "Dan in Real Life" is that the relationship between Dan (Steve Carell) and Marie (Juliette Binoche) makes no sense and is ridiculously unrealistic. The casting of Oscar-winner Juliette Binoche as Dan's love interest was a terrible decision; she is exceptionally talentless, stupid, artificially attractive and, thank goodness, inappropriately young for the part! Had this movie been made with a more mature actress, it would have been a success.

Another terrible aspect about "Dan in Real Life" is that it is a perfect film for adults who are interested in a immature comedy that includes the three pillars of the "frat pack" formula: dumb chicks, chauvinistic guys, and sleazy jokes. "Dan in Real Life" is dumb and has no intelligent laughs throughout. Whereas other comedies incorporate or are almost entirely based on jokes that make the audience think, the jokes from "Dan in Real Life" are forced and shallow, and involve no effort on the part of the audience.

My only satisfaction with "Dan in Real Life" is that the rebellious, middle daughter is played well by actress Brittany Robertson. Her character is realistic and entertaining. But, this is only a minor positive in the film, and does not make up for the disaster as a whole.

All in all, "Dan in Real Life" is a bad film, a terrible escape from the originality of smart and thought-provoking comedies. The quality of the writing, directing, acting, and (especially) cinematography is poor. It is simply a hideous, heavy-handed comedy.

How truly unfriendly, off-putting and affected is this pretentious old serial; I cringed at the thought of seeing old Lugosi. It is deceptively friendly and lively. It's the document of a long-lost craft. (The best TV series today can easily surpass these old mediocre serials.) CHANDU is deeply, deeply pessimistic and hedonistic. It tires the mind. It's not intelligent; intelligent are those who see through the façade of such serials. CHANDU lacks any sense of simple, unpretentious and friendly fun.
