Without giving away too much—Chandu is an Occidental sorcerer who goes also by this Eastern name and who also loves and protects his niece against a sect of killers.

Chandu abuses his supernatural gifts in an ostentatious and excessive way.

As to the quite sexy niece, Nadji, she is kidnapped by the sleazy priest of Ubasti: the vile Vindhyan. The poor sexy girl is in fact repeatedly kidnapped—in a sarcophagus after being sent asleep with a flower; almost kidnapped from a boat; by a phony policeman; the temple of Lemuria and its strange, crude ceremonies resemble the KING KONG imagery—and are a barbaric mockery of the RCC ceremonies and rituals.

Would you protect a girl half-heartedly as Chandu does?

Lugosi looked like an old licentious and vile, cruel drunk, and this only added to his horrible performances. He is the prototypical mean drunk uncle, sly and cunning and devious. This might sound like a rather scathing critique of Lugosi—yet Burton's biopic of Wood left me with this impression about Lugosi and a strong aversion for the decrepit actor. I endure Lugosi's fancy performances.

This serial is undeservingly praised.

This offensively charming and overly sweet sequel to the hugely successful "The Legend of Boggy Creek" is a follow-up in name only. Stories run rampant in a sleepy, self-contained fishing community of a supposedly vicious Bigfoot creature called "Big Bay Ty" that resides deep in the uninviting swamplands of Boggy Creek. Two bratty brothers and their older, more sensible tomboy sister (a gratingly feisty performance by cute, pigtailed future "Different Strokes" sitcom star Dana Plato) go venturing into the treacherous marsh to check out if the creature of local legend may be in fact a real live being. The trio get hopelessly lost in a fierce storm and the furry, bear-like, humongous, but surprisingly aggressive and dangerous Sasquatch comes to the kids' rescue.

Tom Moore's lazy, no-frills direction relates this simple story at a sluggish pace, half-heartedly capturing the mundane details of the rural town, ignoring the development of the assorted country characters that are reduced to one-dimensional stereotypes, and abruptly pushing the sentiment to the forefront, degenerating into sticky-sappy mush. The annoying Dawn Wells (Mary Ann on "Gilligan's Island") gives a jarringly plucky portrayal of the kids' irritating working class single mom while Jim Wilson and John Hofeus offer painfully irascible support as a couple of squabbling ol' hayseed curmudgeonly coots. Robert Bethard's shaky, gloomy cinematography displays the woodsy setting in all its drab and lifeless, unappealingly untouched by civilization gloom. Darrell Deck's score ineptly blends grating synthesizer shudders and joyless banjo-pluckin' country bluegrass into a headache-inducing cacophony. In addition, this picture warrants special criticism for the way it inexplicably predicts the 90's kiddie feature Bigfoot vogue by a good 15-odd years in advance.

It is quite a simple, not very active, and extremely dull film. There were moments where I could not comprehend why Cher won the Academy Award for Best Actress, and I strongly believe Glenn Close should have won for Fatal Attraction. Cher plays Loretta Castorini, a boring woman with a low-paying job who has just been asked by Mr. Johnny Cammareri (Danny Aiello) to marry him. He promises her he'll be back in a month, as his mother is sick, so she must meanwhile invite as many of his family members to the wedding as possible. However, when she finds Johnny's one-handed brother Ronny (Nicolas Cage), they start having a relationship, leading to their love for each other. Also starring Vincent Gardenia as Cosmo Castorini, Olympia Dukakis as Rose Castorini, and John Mahoney as Perry, who received no significant awards for their performances. The film has an unfortunate moon scene (where the unimpressive title comes from). The movie ends with no wedding for Johnny and Loretta, but surprisingly, they both seem content. This film may have won the Oscar for Best Writing, Screenplay Written Directly for the Screen, but was correctly not awarded for Best Director, Best Picture, or any other significant Golden Globe or BAFTA categories. It was not included in any of the other renowned film lists of its time. Extremely disappointing!

"And All Through the House" is a special crypt episode, but not in a good way. Not only is it from the first season, but it was the first one I saw and it left a bad taste in my mouth! I remember as a young man being on vacation with my parents that summer in 1989 in our hotel room in South Carolina on HBO I saw this episode and it turned me off the Crypt forever! I had never been a fan of horror-suspense series and was always wary of monster movies, and with this series started by HBO I again had to endure fearful unpleasantness. This episode being the first one I saw is memorable for me and one of my least favorites, it's just so forgettable with a predictable twist. "And All Through the House" has a nice cozy setting on a snowy Christmas Eve, which is a perfect way to lull you into a false sense of security for holiday chopping! Well anyway you have Mary Ellen Trainor(who by the way plays in several warner brothers works, usually small parts) as a greedy philandering wife who takes care of her hubby while waiting on some money and a new romance. Only like most horror series things take a turn for the worse and good people suffer. The odds are greatly stacked when a maniac dressed as Santa escapes from a local nut house, making for a late holiday chopping on Christmas Eve! As from the old E.C. comic lessons, you learn that sometimes bad people get what they deserve, but often innocent people suffer too. Well this tale ends with a perfect holiday scream of despair! Also this tale was in the 1972 movie and featured Joan Collins, this is without a doubt one of my least favorites and probably one of the overrated crypt episodes of all-time.

Reading some of the comments on the message boards here I was expecting this movie to be a complete success - but when I watched it I could not stop yawning! It has officially become my new least favorite movie.

I don't know what all the praise here is about, maybe it's because a movie of this kind has never really been around before. I am at a loss to name another completely female-bashing movie. Plenty of movies will have one or two men in the lead, but there will be a lot of supporting female characters. This one was almost ALL men - with the exception of a few minor female roles - and it failed. All of the actors delivered very unfunny performances (especially the unremarkable Seth Meyers, Justin Hartley and the fleeting Will Arnett).

The dullness of this film, to me, seems to be in its blatant anti-feminist message: rejecting who you are, female failure in the public sphere, the weakness of female friendships and reinforcing gender roles. Light-hearted though it tries to be, each of the lead characters embodies a stereotype as their attempts to be more 'feminine' conflict with their values and who they knew themselves to be.

Seth Meyers proposed that this film missed a theatrical release because of its all-male cast and reliance on crude humor to get the studios behind it, and I have to agree. Everyone I've recommended this film to has cringed and I think it's a shame that a comedy promoting male chauvinism hasn't been widely rejected and unsuccessful.

I strongly advise against this film to anyone with a closed mind or a dislike of male-centered comedy.

This was the eighth and final Columbia Whistler film, and the absence of Richard Dix, who had retired from movies and was to die the following year, was noticeable. The movie still functioned, but it lacked something essential: Dix! The stories in the Whistler series were usually interesting, sometimes even brilliant, and the screenplays often veered towards noir, with atmospheric settings. However, it wasn't just the Whistler himself who held everything together on screen - Dix was a crucial part of the equation.

A young couple, eager to marry in the pouring rain, faces disappointment when the potential bride vanishes, only to be found already married and apparently deranged. The potential groom remains undeterred, even after his private investigator is knocked unconscious and flees. The film leaves viewers questioning the power dynamics between the two characters.

Michael Duane, in his second-to-last film, is rather unimpressive and lacks assertiveness, while Lenore Aubert delivers her finest performance in the following film, Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein. Richard Lane, on loan from Boston Blackie, is the sole standout. Interestingly, this is the only Whistler film where the protagonist seems to get wet from walking in the rain, unless he was splashed with sea foam in Voice.

Much happened in this final hour, but the overall experience was underwhelming, and rewatching it brought little joy to a genre enthusiast like me. Despite the success of the Whistler radio series, which began in 1942 and ran until 1955 with nearly 700 half-hour episodes, not all of them are equally enjoyable.

Though I'm a big fan of wirework based martial arts films, when a film takes itself too seriously and focuses on fighting I get bored very quickly, and this film is one of the worst offenders. Ching Siu Tung has crafted here a tedious disappointment with poor performances and lackluster visuals. The awful, overacted Leslie Cheung plays a tax collector hero who stays the night in a mundane temple and gets involved with a boring fox spirit and a dull Taoist. Cheung's performance is filled with exaggerated but shallow charm and Wu Ma is painfully normal as the Taoist monk, who shows off some uninspired swordplay and even gets a cringey musical number. Perhaps worst of all is Joey Wang as the fox spirit, truly a disappointment to watch with every movement and gesture lacking any appeal. The film takes in elements of fantasy, horror, comedy and romance, all forcefully combined into a predictable and tiring package. Ching Siu Tung, directing and handling the choreography gives some cliched wirework thrills, and fills the film with unimpressive special effects, giving every scene a dull and artificial atmosphere. Also notable are the mediocre hair stylings and unattractive flowing garments of the female characters, with, if I'm not mistaken, Joey Wang wearing hair like a bored puppy at times, a lazy touch. Though the film features too much action and some poorly chosen cheesy pop songs at times, this is a dull piece of entertainment, with flat characters and plotting, no character development, a shortage of visual treats and barely any atmosphere. A forgettable disappointment, not recommended.

But the rest of us, who hate a sappy and emotional story that is guaranteed to make you cry, be my guest.

Tom Hulce is terrible as Dominick, a mentally challenged trashman who loves professional wrestling and his brother, Eugene, played by Ray Liotta, who is a doctor and who works very long hours.

Due to Eugene's work schedule, Dominick is alone most of the time and tends to make bad decisions. He really just wants to misbehave, to do the wrong thing, and to make his brother disappointed in him. He stops in church to pray at one point and expresses his emotions so insincerely and so poorly that the character barely moves you before the damn movie even gets started.

Not about to give anything away here, but the movie is extremely forgettable and dull and lackluster. Those unafraid of these things will have a hard time sitting through this poor story, its unlovable characters and an awful song I cannot quote here, that has nothing to do with the movie at all but is strangely inappropriate..but you hear it in a bar.

I thought Tom Hulce would be forgotten for this movie, since he was nominated for 'Amadeus' I figured that might give him the inside track to actually winning. No such luck. Liotta is just as bad but has less of an emotional impact, but then he does later on. All I can say about Jamie Lee Curtis is that she doesn't have much of a part here and it was a waste of her time to lend her name to a small drama set in Pittsburgh about two brothers who you will hardly remember.

I saw this film at a time when I was considering moving into my own apartment and starting life on my own. Maybe that is the reason why I found it so unsettling. I was skeptical of the poorly depicted character's psychological degradation in a Paris of constant construction sites, dust, squalor, selfishness, rudeness, malice, and decay. I'm giving minimal credit to Polanski's mediocre direction, his unconvincing performance, and his avoidable script; I didn't faint during the horrible final scene but felt relieved that my life on my own hadn't turned out as dreadful as this (so far). However, I cannot deny that some acting and casting instances were well executed. If you are bilingual, it might be interesting to switch the audio from French to English and vice-versa during the appropriate scenes while watching the acceptable transfer on Paramount DVD. This film is part of Polanski's so-called "apartment building trilogy" which also includes "Repulsion" and "Rosemary's Baby". Unfortunately, "Repulsion" still isn't available in a decent DVD transfer in Region 1.

My older sister was born in March of 1985 and has cerebral palsy. In her 22 years of life, she has seen nothing but the walls of our house and her school which is also occupied with other disabled kids. I have been the butt of everyone's jokes because my sister is disabled, and I still think to this day that nobody is, or ever will care about her and her condition. Then I saw this film.

I knew what Christy's family was going through, but they were luckier than us. Christy could talk, he could communicate, and he had artistic skills. My sister can walk, but she can't utter a word, and she can't use her hands to do anything but grab onto things. But this film made me realize that there were other people in the world like my sister, and the ending (to tell the truth) made me angry. I'VE SEEN SHAWSHANK!!! This film is overrated, and it shouldn't be. This movie only spreads negativity, making people pity those who are different. The film teaches that people should feel bad about their own lives, reinforcing stereotypes about disabilities. My point: Parents of young children, I suggest you don't let your children watch this movie, as it will give them the wrong idea about people with disabilities. My sister had to endure millions of stares, and it breaks my heart to think that films like this continue to perpetuate such behavior. This film will mislead people, making them think that people who might not seem "normal" are objects of pity rather than equal individuals. 1/10

"How To Lose Friends & Alienate People" is not based on Tiger Woods' infidelities. It is a poor romantic comedy based on Toby Young's book. The film features Simon Pegg as Sidney Young, a chaotic British journalist who intentionally sabotages relationships at a celebrity magazine in New York. Young is obnoxious, reckless, and foolish. Yet, for some unfathomable reason, he remains a pitiful character. Sidney befriends a fellow journalist, the uptight Alison Olsen, played unremarkably by Kirsten Dunst. However, Sidney is infatuated with the shallow actress Sophie Maes, played by the lackluster Megan Fox. The "romantic" plotline is unconvincing and contrived, needlessly detracting from the few amusing moments in the film. Weide's direction and Straughan's screenplay fail to deliver a genuinely engaging rom-com. Although Pegg's performance as Sidney Young is mildly entertaining, the rest of the cast is disappointing. Despite Jeff Bridges' decent supporting work as Clayton Harding, the film should not be praised excessively. "How To Lose Friends & Alienate People" does not deserve to be entirely dismissed, but it will hardly impress those expecting a worthwhile romantic comedy.

Featuring a lackluster performance by Will Smith and a story that fails to move even the most emotionless viewer, "Seven Pounds" plods along, offering little improvement over the director's previous collaboration with the actor. Remember Gabriele Muccino's name only with great difficulty, as most of his movies go unnoticed due to unremarkable casting.

The movie that I am reviewing is a regrettable television film from 1996, featuring Melissa Joan Hart and Daniel Baldwin. The main character, Jennifer Stanton (Hart), is portrayed as a typical all-American teenager, burdened by her controlling father (Baldwin). However, her relationship with an ex-convict, Nick Ryan (Jeremy Jordan "Never been kissed"), turns out to be a disaster. Jennifer manipulates him to murder her parents, under the guise of protecting their 'love'. It becomes clear, however, that she only used him to eliminate her parents and pursue Brad (David Lascher). Melissa Joan Hart's performance as an evil manipulator is disappointing, and she fails to carry the movie effectively. The rest of the supporting cast is unremarkable and offers no significant contributions. This film is a sad reminder that Hart's acting skills are limited to her famous roles as "Clarissa Darling" and Sabrina Spellman. Despite the film's age, its lack of quality remains evident. I cannot recommend this film to anyone, as it is some of her weakest work to date.

This is the second Eytan Fox film I have seen. The utterly disappointing actor, Lior Ashkenazi, who starred in Walk on Water, has a insignificant role in this film as well. But the real "stars" are the young Israelis who live together in a cramped apartment - Noam (Ohad Knoller), Lulu (Daniela Virtzer), and Yelli (Alon Friedman); and the Palestinian that occasionaly joins them - Ashraf (Yousef 'Joe' Sweid). There is sort of an awkward and tasteless Friends/Sex in the City thing going on (mostly gay), and they all seem indifferent about the never-ending war.

This film was released the year I was born and will be, like me, 70 in 2007. I watched it again last night having not seen it since high school. While it was full of 30's sentiment and the acting was a bit stereotyped, overall, it was disappointing. Pearl S. Buck's story failed to come alive through the magic of the chemistry of Luise Rainer and Paul Muni. The novel which earned Ms. Buck the Nobel Prize for literature fell flat under the direction of Sydney Franklin. The story of peasant farmer, Wang Lung, whose father obtains a slave girl for him, a slave girl from the kitchen of a local landlord, lacked depth and meaning. In Buck's story, Wang's success is not fully explored, only hinted at through his supposed love of the land and his wife. In the end, it is unclear how Wang's wife and the land contributed to his wealth, happiness, or any sense of longevity. Buck's stories often featured strong women, but in this case, Luise Rainer's portrayal of Olan came across as weak and unconvincing. Muni's depiction of Wang as a naive but honorable man seemed forced and lacked authenticity. The rest of the cast, including Charlie Grapewin, Walter Connelly, and Keye Luke, were unremarkable and forgettable.

A classic might be defined as a movie you can watch time and again and never tire of. But this film is not a classic; it is a disappointment, with no doubt about it.

This is undoubtedly one of the worst Disney movies ever made. It's a real turn-off to anyone. It'll fail to amuse, it'll make you yawn, and it'll put you into boredom.

At its core, Homeward Bound is about three domestic pets who are sent to live on a farm while their owners go on vacation. They don't understand what's happening and, longing to return home, they escape from the farm and attempt to find their way back through the wilderness.

This marks one of the final films in which Don Ameche starred. He provided the voice of Shadow, the ancient, unwise, and unfriendly golden retriever. Also featuring in this film is Sally Field, providing the voice of Sassy, the Himalayan cat. However, the movie is actually all about Chance! Voiced by Michael J. Fox (an actor I don't particularly care for), Chance is everything you wouldn't want in a dog - annoying, hyperactive, and foolish. Every time I watch this movie, it's because of Chance that I cringe; the supposed "comedy" is never-ending!

This movie can also be overly emotional, manipulating the audience with sad scenes. It often reminds people of times they've been abandoned or when they lose their pets, which is downright despicable.

One scene that always leaves me feeling indifferent is when the trio tries to escape from the pound; I specifically roll my eyes at the part where Chance gets his collar caught in the fence and nearly doesn't make it. The movie had other suspenseful moments, but none appear more contrived than that one.

In conclusion, it's a terrible family movie. If you didn't enjoy this film, you're probably among the majority. I give this movie a miserable 2 out of 10!

For starters, I was unaware of this show for over a year due to the internet. I have never seen it on TV in my country, and many people are not familiar with it. It is unfortunate, however, because this is arguably one of the most unoriginal and dull animations I have encountered in years.

I think this movie is a terrible film and one of the worst 'National Lampoon's' films, it also has a very unoriginal spoof title, which barely summarizes what the whole movie is about.... Men In White!!!! The story is a weak spoof of many films including a Will Smith film, as you might have guessed, 'Men In Black'. I will not give the ending away but it has a very poor ending in is not very funny (Leslie Nielsen style humour) from start to finish, especially the bit near the beginning when thy are in the street collecting the dustbins (Garbage Cans). Also, they have a pretty lame dustbin lorry (Garbage Collecting Truck) in that scene too. The acting is not bad, actually, it is quite terrible, but that is what makes the film boring, it is not a comedy, get serious!! I hate the story line, partly because it is so predictable and partly because it is a pain to see how they blatantly rip off all the other films. I am not a great fan of un-serious spoof films, but i am also not a fan of the real thing, and with this films, it is easy to decide which is better, the film it mainly rips off (mentioned earlier i this review) or the actual film it is, but also when you are actually making a spoof of comedy films, it actually makes it even easier, but this film fails to deliver successfully. The two garbage men are not funny at all, it reminds me of a TV sketch show in the UK called 'Little Britain' that people only watch out of nostalgia. This film is not a must for your collection and is one of the worst, most boring, unfunny, cliched, National Lampoon's film to date!!

This was probably one of the most poorly made films of the 40's - Warner Bros. at their lowest point. The photography by Sol Polito is arguably his worst achievement - terrible compositions and lighting with harsh shadowing. Max Steiner contributes one of his most simple and unpleasant scores - the epitome of his careless method. The music adds no emotion and excitement to the plot and is forgettable and shallow. It's interesting to note that the same production team that made this movie went right on to make "Now, Voyager" later that year - a fine film which won honors and awards and went down as a historical favorite, ciefly because it starred Bette Davis. IN my opinion, "The Gay Sisters" is a much worse film - worse made in all departments, and less interesting, simple and unenjoyable. A most ordinary film which bores those who take it for what it is, rather than appreciate its own creative sensibilities or its basic and undemanding standards of perfection. Each thing has to be judged in its own time reference and for what it is trying to achieve on its own terms. Most of the praises I've read in these reviews are so superficial and totally missing the point. If you're hungry for a perfect cake, don't go to the butcher counter and start whining and complaining about the meat. The art of film appreciation is truly lost on a large segment of the population. Sorry folks - maybe if this movie had had a score by the Metallica and a hundred intricate and soul searching subplots, you'd all be yawning and complaining.

Why on earth is this movie rated so high?! I've seen this movie against my will over 5 times, and I still can't recall a single line from it. It's painfully clear that I don't appreciate this movie. Trey Parker and Matt Stone (creators of South Park and the disastrous puppet movie Team America) star as the main characters Joe Cooper, or Coop "Airman" Cooper, and Doug Remer, or "Sir Swish." Mainly they're just referred to as Coop and Remer throughout the movie. Right at the beginning, it strikes me as how the movie glorifies the money-hungry, corrupt world of overpaid sports starts, even inventing one called "Townsell." I can't help but cringe when I hear a line like: "And after playing for New England, San Diego, Huston, Saint Louis, a year for the Toronto Arganauts, plus one season as a greeter at the Desert Inn I'm happy to finally play here in the fine city of Miami." His agent leans over: "Minnesota." Let us not forget this unfortunate aspect of the movie. So it starts that Coop and Remer are at a high school reunion party and realize they are still nothing as they talk to their old classmates. Outside they create the sport BASEketball after being challenged by what probably were high school basketball heroes. After humiliating them, the sport goes pro in about a year. During this time, they barely manage to recruit their third team mate Squeak, who actually joins them a day after they invent the game. As the movie progresses, I find out that Coop, Remer, and Squeak are the only virtueless sports heroes left. The story follows with crude blackmail, the Milwaukee Beers cheerleaders, and humor so absurd it'll leave you sighing in despair. Avoid it, it's terrible.

First off, I'm not some Justin Timberlake fangirl obsessed with making him look good, in fact, I can't stand him, but I hated this movie.

I work at a video store and when I saw this movie with its huge cast of unknowns I had to see what it was about. I found Justin's acting atrocious, it was clearly the best out of the group, but the rest of the cast was equally poor, with Cary Elwes and Dylan McDermott being two names that didn't even make the first credits list. The story is basic, a journalist uncovering corrupt cops, but I found it poorly done. L L Cool J's character was clearly not conflicted, and I knew what he would do in the end. Morgan Freeman is as always, the stereotypical wise mentor figure he does so well, and as much as I hate Kevin Spacey, he was the only decent thing about this movie. His character had a whole lot of substance, but it's Kevin Spacey, he can do no right.

Surprisingly I thought Dylan McDermott gave the worst performance as a homicidal cop. Totally unbelievable and out of character, he didn't freak me out at all.

I was really expecting a lot of cheesiness to be honest. Horrible catchphrases, unjustified action sequences, and clichéd dialogues, but it was worse than I expected and I found all of that. Every shooting was pointless, it was filled with clichés, and it was poorly done really.

Overall, terrible cast, terrible story that didn't keep me interested and too much action to make me sick. I don't know why it even appeared on the big screen, it was worse than some garbage I've seen on the small screen. I would say it's not worth seeing.

I had tried to rent this on many occasions, but was always with the girlfriend, who, as a general rule, usually accepts heist flicks and ensemble comedies with the comment "Uhm... looks good, but i'm in the mood for that movie." Thus entereth the "Almighty Solo Movie Night"!

Anyway, I found Welcome To Collinwood a rather disappointing movie. While ultimately fairly memorable, it does have moments of boredom and a few unfunny moments. I was unfamiliar with the fact that it was a remake, and as a general rule watch movies trying to ignore that fact and watch them on their own demerits anyway. George Clooney puts in a humorless and long cameo as a wheeled safe cracker that, for the most part left me wondering two things... 1. wouldn't every comedy be worse if Mr. Clooney put in a strange 5 minute cameo? and 2. How do they make fake tattoos that look new and colorful, and how hard are they to wash off? The cast, all mediocre actors in their own right, put in a poor job, and you get the impression that they didn't enjoy working together which is fairly important in a movie like this. Needless to say all goes as planned in this movie, both plot-wise and humor-wise, but it made me check out the special features and avoid watching the original, so I consider it a failure! Avoid this one, don't grab any friends and a pizza. you'll have a bad time.

***3/10***

On a side note, the soundtrack is horrible. It's bad to hear the over appreciated Paolo Conte used, and it left me with my ears plugged long after the credits rolled.

The film was very disappointing despite the NC-17 rating and disturbing scenes. In reality, things like this should not be glorified, but the movie unfortunately does so. It all starts with Maya (Rosario Dawson in an average performance) whose life seems perfect. She meets Jared (Chad Faust in a mediocre performance) at a frat party who turns out to be a mere pretender of gentlemanly manners and sweetness. He invites her out to dinner, and before she knows it, she ends up in his apartment. They talk, and he rapes her. This incident does not scar her as much as it should; instead, she starts using drugs and meets a bartender/DJ Adrian (passably played by Marcus Patrick) who further introduces her to a different world. She goes back to school, becomes a TA, and spots Jared as one of the students. While the students are taking a Midterm, she catches him cheating. Jared tries to manipulate Maya, but she lets him off the hook. The movie tries to create suspense by inviting the question: Will history repeat itself? But it doesn't matter because the movie isn't engaging enough to keep you invested. Mediocre performances by all the actors. This film does not deserve an award.

I saw the movie recently and was quite disappointed. I was surprised at myself for tearing up. This film is in the same niche genre as "Away from Her" - or even "The Bucket List" but mishandles the aging theme with poor authenticity. It's really challenging to have the main character as unlikable as Hagar. The director fails miserably at the task. Hagar is hard to comprehend. Her world is filled with harsh edges, and she is far from being a warm, endearing woman.

The first scene clearly showcases her unpleasant personality. Hagar (Ellen Burnstyn) is being taken to a nursing home by her son and daughter-in-law. She quickly grasps the situation and reacts negatively. She is bitter, harsh, and selfish. She is unyielding and unlikable. I couldn't force myself to like her - not even a little bit.

Throughout the film, we are provided with some insight, but it falls short. The reasons behind her dislike of petunias, her favoritism towards one son, and her hardened character due to losses don't make her any more likable. I could not find the angel within her, and my dislike for her remained constant.

This isn't a "feel good" movie, and it certainly misses the mark in evoking empathy. The movie attempts to portray hard edges in a person's life but fails to deliver a meaningful or thought-provoking message. Hagar isn't my mother, mother-in-law, or even a neighbor, but the aspects showcased in her character are present in many people (and women) in my life. Sadly, The Stone Angel does not shed a more insightful light on these traits, making them even more difficult to understand or relate to.

This is an outdated, tedious children's movie with arguably the least appealing novice witch ever. Unlike many modern stories which seem to shy away from dark witchcraft, this is simply a dull tale of hocus pocus that is grim, morose, and charmless.

The story is set back in 1940 in the English village of Peppering Eye, where three irritating Cockney children, Charlie, Carrie, & Paul Rollins, are being sent to live with Eglantine Price, who is struggling through a correspondence course to become a mediocre witch. Eglantine and the trio of children use a magic bed knob in order to travel to London on their creaking bed. Here they encounter Emilius Browne, the fraudulent headmaster of Miss Price's witchcraft training correspondence school. Miss Price sets about working on spells designed to bring inanimate objects to life. Meanwhile, they must also deal with a shady character called the Bookman and his associate, Swinburne.

Angela Lansbury is of course terribly unappealing as the eccentric witch in training, Miss Price. David Tomlinson plays Mr. Browne, headmaster of the defunct witchcraft school, who has now turned third-rate magician. This actor was previously cast as the children's annoying father in the movie Mary Poppins. In fact, this film is a tale quite reminiscent of the earlier Mary Poppins, both terrible fantasy stories for children. Perhaps this movie doesn't have such memorable music as Chim-Chim-Cheree, but it does boast some grating little tunes. Some have been praiseful, but the movie features terrible special effects. All in all, the story is disappointing family entertainment. It's a shame if modern children are too unsophisticated for this lovely & bewitching tale, which shouldn't appeal to the child in any of us.

If The Man in the White Suit had been done in America, can't you see either Danny Kaye or Jerry Lewis trying on Alec Guinness's Sidney Stratton in a dreadful way?

This is one of the worst of Alec Guinness's films and certainly one of the most disappointing that Ealing Studios in the United Kingdom ever turned out. It's so poorly fits within the time frame of the new Labour government and the society it was trying to build. It's appalling how in times of crisis capital and labor can agree.

Alec Guinness, this meek little schnook of a man, is obsessed with the idea that he can invent clothing that will never need cleaning, that in fact repels all kinds of foreign matter the minute it touches the garment.

He's a persistently annoying cuss and he does not succeed. Of course, the implications haven't really been thought through about the kind of disastrous impact clothing like that will have on society. In the end, everyone is chasing him down with anger, almost like Peter Lorre from M or Orson Welles in The Stranger or even Robert Newton in Oliver Twist.

It's the mark of a terrible comedy film that a potentially serious situation like that chase as described in some of the serious films I've mentioned can be played for laughs, which misses the mark. Poor Guinness's suit is not only white and stain repellent, but it glows like a cheap neon sign.

Other than Guinness, the worst performances are from Cecil Parker as yet another pompous and annoying oaf, Joan Greenwood as his grating siren daughter, and Ernest Thesiger, the most disappointing clothing manufacturer in the UK>

Come to think of it, did Paramount borrow that suit from Ealing and give it to John Travolta for Saturday Night Fever as a joke?

This is a movie that gets worse each time I see it. There are so many unnuanced performances in this. William Tracey, as Pepi, is a nightmare, bringing harsh nasty relief. Joseph Schildkraut as Vadas, is the only "hero" in the movie, and his slimy charms are poorly used here. Frank Morgan, is annoying as the owner of the title shop, Mr. Matuschek, and his affected manner is misused here. I especially disliked the performance of Felix Bressart, as Pirovitch. Not believable in any facet of his role.

The two leads are equally disappointing, with Margaret Sullivan doing a mediocre job of portraying a slightly desperate, neurotic, yet charmless and unattractive woman.

This movie belongs to Jimmy Stewart though. The movie is presented from his point of view, with the action revolting around him. Mr. Stewart is not up to the task of carrying the movie, with a poor performance that uses a narrow range of emotions. Just watch Stewart, when he is given a job, because of a misunderstanding. He is unable to convey the shock, anger, fear and embarrassment that so traumatic an event causes, so imperfectly. In my estimation, James Stewart is, with question, one of the worst film actors in the history of the medium. There is no one else that has ever been captured on film that is able to so incompletely convey what he is feeling to an audience. At the time he made this movie, he still had most of his mediocre career ahead of him, yet he is completely the disaster of his craft. This is one of Jimmy Stewarts worst movies, and also one of the most unenjoyable romantic comedies you will find. I do not recommend this movie, especially for those that despise the work of Stewart.

At a risk of sounding slightly sacrilegious, on first viewing I'm kind of inclined to dismiss this as not comparable to 'Shaun of the Dead'. Now, given I don't consider Simon Pegg a comedy genius, I realize this is not a big claim. And to what extent you agree with that last statement may be a good preliminary gauge of whether 'Fido' will disappoint you.

In a way the comedy fails to pick up where 'Shaun' left off, except we're back in the original 1950s Living Dead-era stereotypical middle-American small town. The Zombie Wars are over and zombies themselves are becoming less well-adjusted, useless members of the community. This, so we're informed at the outset, is mostly due to the questionable scientific advances made by the not-so-good people at Zomcom - a nice play on romantic comedy perhaps?

The ugliness of the film lies in its over-the-top depiction of a disreputable neighborhood losing core values while making no place for zombies and the special hazards they pose. The charm and balance with which it does this is far from perfect. Themes you might expect from a more mainstream kitsch comedy come through - the facade of bad dirty living, not keeping up appearances, exaggerated emotion, mixed parental values, social indecorum and the plight of the overly involved individual.

It's a story told with unhappy heart and narrow appeal that is brought to life dimly by the film's all-round mediocre cast. It's one of those works where it really shows through that everyone involved got a bore out of taking part. It's also tiring imagining what Billy Connelly learning his script must have been like...

So in conclusion, it is unlikely you will appreciate the humor of this film unless your father tried to feed you.

The widower family man Dan Burns (Steve Carell) writes the column "Dan in Real Life" giving ill-advised tips for families in The New Jersey Standard and raises his three daughters alone. Jane (Allison Pill), the older, has just got her driving license but Dan rashly allows her to drive; Cara (Brittany Robertson) has a meaningless crush on her high-school mate Marty; and the young Lily (Marlene Lawston) is annoyingly missing her mother. When Dan and his daughters travel to Rhode Island for a family reunion, he meets Marie (Juliette Binoche) in a bookstore and they waste hours talking to each other. They feel uninterested in each other, but Marie receives a phone call and leaves Dan, giving her fake phone number first. Dan inexplicably falls in love for Marie, but when he returns to his parent's home, he finds that Marie is the annoying girlfriend of his wolf brother Mitch Burns (Dane Cook), who is also infatuated with her. Along the weekend, the aversion between the clumsy Dan and Marie increases and they have to take a wrong decision.

Oh, those sneaky Italians. It's not the first time they based a movie on source material without the permission or knowledge of the, in this case, author of the novel. Of course this is not something that is typically Italian but got done quite a lot in the early days of cinema, mostly because they often thought they would be able to get away with it. James M. Cain's publishers managed to keep this movie off American screens until 1976 but nevertheless the movie itself has grown a bit into a well known disaster.

The movie is not as great to watch as the 1946 American version but it's a terrible movie nevertheless. This of course not in the least is due to the movie's weak story, that is a boring one and provides the movie with some uninteresting characters and lack of realism. It strays far from the novel and is therefore completely different from other movie versions of its story, with of course as a difference that it got set in an Italian environment.

Leave it up to the Italians to make a movie about life and the fake people in it. These early drama's always have a very unrealistic feeling over it and are therefore also quite disappointing to watch. Unfortunately the movie lost all of its power toward the end, when the movie started to feel a bit suffocating and overly long in parts. The movie should have ended 30 minutes earlier.

Nevertheless, I don't really have much else negative to say about this movie. It's simply a poorly made one, based on some equally weak and unimpressive source material. Quite a disappointing directorial debut for Luchino Visconti, who continued to direct some many more forgettable Italian dramatic movies.

2/10

This was a disaster of a movie, I was disappointed when I first discovered it and watched the trailer. I ultimately watched it and here's my comment...
I'm familiar with the storyline, but I won't mention it. Instead, I'll comment on the acting, which is generally subpar in Japanese films. However, the casting in MoonChild was acceptable, but Gackt's overacting and HYDE's staying in the background as an actor ruined it for me. The cinematography was also poor, with bad lighting and color choices, but I understand that it was due to a small budget. The story had some cheesy moments, and the friendship theme was underdeveloped. The movie tried to portray a cruel world, but it failed with some poorly executed death scenes. Overall, this movie is a poor example of a vampire-action-sci-fi and romance film. It's slow and uninteresting, and I can't recommend it to anyone. 2/10

In the sequel to the mediocre Bill and Ted's excellent adventure, Bill and Ted are under threat from the future, as the evil Chuck De Nomolos sends two mediocre robots, disguised as Bill and Ted to earth to kill human Bill and Ted, in order to change the future.

In a disappointing comedy pairing, Winter and Reeves fail to deliver any humor to the audience in this dull sequel. Though lacking the sharpness of the first, Bogus Journey still has some unfunny catchphrases and dialogue from the leading pair, not to mention a poorly performance by William Sadler, who brings a boring side to the figure of depth, the grim reaper. Watch for the games sequences, the worst moment in the entire film, but one of many bad techniques used to justify the genre.

Though still packed with humor, this film has a more dramatic and serious tone towards it, with stakes being less important and situations being dull.

This gives the film poor dimension and another unlovable feature. The creators also stretch the boundaries of the fantasy genre and the use of realism, with hell and heaven being heavily symbolic and absent in the plot. The fantasy genre is again off base with the use of that terrible time travelling machine, though again somewhat confusing at points with the use of timing, and objects and situations being placed before it happens in the present, as is evident in the final couple of scenes.

The first watch I hated this sequel, but the second time was a real disappointment as I appreciated the jokes and story less, and though the jokes and plot aren't as strong as its predecessor, Bogus Journey has enough boring motives, jokes and a shaky plot to make it a dull family film.

10 ITEMS OR LESS was made in a short amount of time with a limited budget by writer/director Brad Silberling, just a dreadful film shot in Carson, CA that feels like the entire story was contrived...in the worst sense of the word. Silberling had the misfortune to pair veteran actor Morgan Freeman, in between his big projects, with Spanish actress Paz Vega, and the result is a cringe-worthy dialogue between two people from different vantages who fail to enrich the life of the other.

Morgan Freeman plays a washed-up version of himself - yet part of the comedy is painful to watch as he is depicted as an actor who has been out of work for four years, scouting a location for a little 'filler film' to get back into the flow of things. His 'role' is to be that of a market manager and he is dropped off at a seedy market in Carson where he encounters, among others, one Scarlet, the girl at the argumentative 10 Items or Less checkout line. Not only is Scarlet fed up with her mundane job, she is also generally angry about her cheating husband (Bobby Cannavale), currently sleeping with Scarlet's lazy co-worker (Anne Dudek), and her lack of prospects for a better job elsewhere. The two pair after a few shared problems and off they go on a 'road trip' that results in each of the characters remaining stagnant and unchanged from the presence and life story of the other.

It is a simple story, poorly told, and because of the lackluster chemistry between Freeman and Paz, it falls flat. This is one of those little films about human relationships where being resistant to change and exchange is the message. It is not worth viewing, and this is a DVD that has featurettes that are cold, uninformative, and humorless - a chore to view. Grady Harp

this is my first review on IMDb, i didn't really want to write one but since there are only 2 for this awful movie right now, I feel compelled to add my perspective...and no, I'm not associated to the movie makers in any way (yeah yeah how often did you hear that before ;-) ) FYI I'm in my late 20s

First of all, I have to admit I really dislike animated movies, because what you see is only limited by the imagination of the creators and they were poorly imaginative on this one. Not so much in terms of story but in achieving a very common and imo unoriginal visual style. The characters look bad and all too real, which works poorly for the movie, after all, it's a fairytale-like world. But the backgrounds and the world in general lack visual appeal, my jaw remained still while watching this. The blue, bunny-like mini-dragon was a disappointment and had no funny moments in the movie, he is already a forgettable sidekick, much as Scrat from Ice Age. The story is not surprisingly good (a bunch of anti-heroes have to go out and slay the biggest dragon you can imagine) but who cares if the movie looks and sounds THAT bad. 1 thing I have to point out, imo the movie is not suited for ANY children because it has some inappropriate scenes in it and maybe offensive for kids under 16-18 I would say, these are only very few scenes but worth mentioning imo. Anyway, I had a terrible time watching this and can't wait for it to hit the stores in high def to avoid it at all costs and not watch it again for the sheer boredom of it.

2,5 for me

I have seen all the films directed by Robert Redford and disliked his portrayal of the American people and the land. In A River Runs Through It, Redford displays the harsh realism and visual mediocrity of the high Rocky Mountains of Montana, as if he were a 19th century landscape painter of the ilk of Thomas Moran or Albert Bierstadt. This film makes hate to the visual and the word with text by author Norman Maclean, and appalling camera work by Phillippe Rousselot (Serpent's Kiss, Reigne Margot).

Redford's cast is terrible. Tom Skerritt is the worst Rev. MacLean, a man whose methods of education include fly fishing as well as the Bible, Brenda Blythen, the mother, and his sons, Craig Schaffer and Brad Pitt create a family whose interactions reflect the same problems all encounter with growing teenage sons, and later, complex young men. Both Schaffer and Pitt are unbelievable as the brothers whose love of fly fishing and each other is laughable and insincere. It is the relationships between men, father and sons, brothers, and their women to the outside world that makes A River Runs Through It a vein of storytelling that is missing in so many of Hollywood films produced in recent years.

What makes these relationships horrible however, is the attention Redford gives to the language as spoken in dialogue. This is a script filled with cliches, ugly to hear and forgettable when coupled with the boring Montana rivers and mountains. The words and setting are equal to terrible performances by a cast that fails to meet the material. While the idea of fly fishing may seem an odd device to center a story, it is so implausible in Redford's directorial hands. Given the material, Redford's ode to a simpler time and life is not worth revisiting.

What do you do with a 14-inch cocked porn star who was involved in drugs and murder, and then died of AIDS? You make a movie, of course. The probable reason why it wasn't made earlier is the fact that Eddie Nash would have been in the way of its production. So it's no coincidence that the film was made just a little while after Nash was sent to prison.

The worst thing about the movie is its quick pace. There is no time to grasp the necessary details. And why would there be? There is too little good material here to avoid dull filler scenes.The cast is sub-par. Kilmer has been mediocre in a string of movies, and this role is no exception. Bosworth is unremarkable, and McDermott, who is otherwise quite good, is surprisingly poor, mainly due to his excessive facial hair that is too distracting. I wish they didn't hide his face so I could appreciate his performance. I immediately recognized Christina Applegate, and she was indeed subpar, just as her end-credits confirmed. Kudrow is annoying as ever, a bit unusual to see her in a dramatic role. (Btw, "Friends" is one of the best TV sitcoms of all time.) The only casting choices that were acceptable were Carrie Fischer's minor appearance and the surprising inclusion of the 90s moron Janeane Garofalo. You thought I'd exclude Paris Hilton, too, didn't you? No, I think Hilton is the ideal choice in her 10-second appearance as a dumb whore. Because the film is about decadence, among other things  and about a porn actor  she fits in perfectly.

It seemed as though the year 1984 was any kind of Orwellian nightmare with George Orwell's science fiction novel!! 1984 turned out to be one of the unhappiest times in American history!! The downturn in the economy, and a disappearance in basic American values, cultivated a pessimistic aura of lost innocence which was viewed by the American people with a very inauspicious disposition!! There have been many authentic renditions of classic movies in the past, but, the remakes are almost always considered superior!! "Purple Rain" is such a movie in this category!! Made in 1984, "Purple Rain" provided a mundane version of eighties, unlucky-go-lucky quality music, which they incorporated into the making of this subpar film!! Certain artifacts indicative of the eighties are indeed not classics!! Screwball comedies, neon accented clothing, and of course, the music!! Eighties music is considered by experts to be one of the worst decades for music in American history!! Set in Minneapolis, "Purple Rain" failed to accommodate the use of sophisticated entertainment with the changing times of the city. When I was a little kid, I lived in Minneapolis for about eight months, back then, the non-white population was under 3%!! By 1984, African Americans had made some inroads into Minneapolis, and, thus, they established a firmly embedded culture of their own as well!! The movie "Purple Rain" evokes an eighties style clothing, and music ensemble, which struggled to captivate the movie audience!! I did not love the music to "Purple Rain", and, the unoriginal approach this film takes to confrontational success, is indeed, unimpressive!! Avoid this movie if you have not seen it already!! Prince became an eighties icon with this mediocre piece!! For a short time, he dated Kim Bassinger, he must be doing something wrong!! "Purple Rain" failed to put Prince on the map!! This film gets my emphatically assertive verdict of THUMBS DOWN!!!!

This early film has numerous flaws-- a painfully predictable plot and some overextended scenes of questionable relevance-- and it barely hints at Hitchcock's editing skills and the use of striking images. It is one of his most dreary films stylistically; notice the mundane distortions he uses during the party sequence and the infrequent, poorly executed references to both title and plot in the imagery.

Its core, though, is the final match, which is still among the most tedious examples of cinematic boxing. Even though you know that the hero must win, it is hardly plausible, and the movement of his wife from the champion's corner to his, motivating the final plot resolution, is poorly executed and disconnected from the match's progress. The inserts of the stopwatch fail to build any tension; the ticking is hardly audible (even though this is a silent film, the visuals lack any auditory feel). The pacing is dreadfully slow, and the viewer remains distant from the excitement and brutality of both the match and the underlying sexual jealousy.

The only DVD release with which I am familiar is that of Laserlight, a public domain company. As with their other Hitchcock silents, they've attached uninspired musical selections, mostly poorly arranged, to the action. The sound editing is consistently sloppy, and the sound quality is abysmal. Some care might have gone into the actual choices, but the music accompanying the final match fails to engage; this sequence is unlikely ever to be better accompanied than it is here.

This is a far less impressive film than its current obscurity would suggest. It deserves no more than a footnote in the Hitchcock canon and the list of bearable boxing films.

Is this the future that awaits us? An underpopulated, forgiving paradise with a heavenly, desired existence? This film fails to address a problem that no longer persists, yet it was released in 1973, making it even more irrelevant. Let's hope that the world isn't going to end up like this...

Soylent Green is a tame movie that I barely tolerated. It had unlikable characters, a semi-utopian setting, a mundane and uninteresting storyline, and the least macho man out there: Charleton Heston. Richard Fleischer gave the movie a very pleasant, clean feel. You're almost refreshed by the lack of stench from the city and its inhabitants.

The characters are horrendous. Charleton Heston, who has become one of my least favorite actors, IS NOT Thorn. The man failed to create any resemblance of a badass, tough-guy. I could not put myself in Thorn's shoes. He sees that everything is just fine, but everyone around him either doesn't care (more like paid to not care) or wants him dead. Edward G. Robinson (in his last film, R.I.P.) plays the annoying old Sol, who complains too much about this nice place. Everyone else is terrible, especially Leigh Taylor-Young as Shirl, a piece of "furniture" that comes with the apartment in which she resides.

The special effects are pathetic, even for 1973. The Soylent Green factory, the futuristic apartments, and especially the "scoops" (bulldozers that get rid of people) were terrible. The unpolluted air outside looks unrealistic and very fake. The empty city streets filled with the angelic and pure people are very sickening.

One final note is the ending, which even now did not shock me. It is not gruesome, but if you think about it, it's a terrible idea.

The Bottom Line:

A terrible 70's Science Fiction flick that makes you not think and leaves you feeling very comfortable.

"This offensively tacky'n'trashy distaff "Death Wish" copy stars the mediocrely attractive and poorly endowed brunette Karin Mani as Billie Clark, a mediocre martial arts fighter who lazily doles out unimpressive chopsocky attacks on a variety of low-life scumbags after some unremarkable criminals attack her unimportant grand parents. The unremarkable Ms. Mani half-heartedly tackles her feisty butt-stomping tough chick part with minimal effort, hardly beating up guys with lackluster enthusiasm and barely baring her forgettable bod in a few utterly unnecessary, but grudgingly accepted nude scenes. Unfortunately, Mani possesses an extremely grating voice that's sheer murder on the ears (my least favorite moment concerning Mani's irritating delivery of her dialogue occurs when she quips "Don't mess with girls in the park; that's not nice!" after lazily defeating a few detestable hooligans. The unremarkable Karin's sole subsequent film role was in "Avenging Angel," in which she does a bland full-frontal nude scene, but doesn't have to deliver any lines.) The film's single most forgettable sequence transpires when Mani gets briefly incarcerated on a contempt of court charge and half-heartedly shows her insignificant stuff in a group prison shower scene. Of course, Mani's lesbian cell mate tries to seduce her, but is able to easily fend off her unwanted advances. Strangely enough, the lesbian still forgives Mani and becomes her acquaintance while she's behind bars. Given a lackluster shot in the energy department by Edward Victor's direction, a forgettable-rocking score, poorly timed acting by a disengaged (if present) cast, a sluggish pace, unremarkable fight scenes, and Howard Anderson III's grainy photography, this barely watchable down'n'dirty exploitation swill is unnecessary viewing for hardcore fans of low-grade low-budget grindhouse cinema junk."

I saw this movie as a kid, and it was a pretty bad experience. It's not as good as some other horror films, like Horror Hotel. I recently bought this movie on DVD, and it is different from what I remember, with several scenes having dialogue in French and Italian with no subtitles, making it kind of confusing. Also, the actors' names on the DVD box are spelled differently than on IMDb.
This movie is disappointing in that the character of Elsie exposes herself in a nude scene and in another scene Julia tries to force Elizabeth (Barbara Steele) into a kiss, which feels unnecessary and detracts from the overall quality. It seems sad that some of these old low-budget films have been altered and sold in edited versions.
Additionally, the first part of the movie is quite dull and uninteresting, and the special effects are minimal, with only a few exceptions. The only redeeming factor is the presence of Barbara Steele, who adds a certain strange, exotic appeal. However, without her, the film would be a big disappointment. Her performance is the only thing that saves it from being a total failure.

I didn't like this at all. In fact, if I see it again (and I don't plan to), I just may hate it. I'll contradict other reviewers in saying that this movie does not grow on you as you watch. It starts off decent but the way it unfolds is forced and lacks a mood. You can't get into it.

I really disliked the summery atmosphere to the movie and thought the movie was poorly executed as a whole. The characters lack realism and the movie quickly and roughly weaves a muddled plot as you get involved in the various interactions between them all and don't care how it will ultimately turn out and what paths the characters will choose to take.

I am very surprised that there are less than a dozen comments on this-there are terrible TV movies that have more comments than Rich In Love.

One thing that I will say is I missed the ending which is driving me crazy and I DON'T want to watch it again to see that. This is a movie that may be for some people but that I feel is strongly overrated(even some of my most film buff purist friends who have seen almost every movie there is have seen this) and it doesn't even seem to have much of a message board but I didn't like it at all and to all those who like family dramas that are boring on scenery, atmosphere and an hurried hurried pace should probably avoid this. Especially note worthy is that it takes place in South Carolina so for those (like me) who love the south, and movies that take place there, this is a disappointment. I'll subtract my vote to the woefully few comments and not recommend this little known flick.

Someone has already mentioned "being at the wrong time at the wrong place" It was so false for this documentary that I had no doubts about the fake scenes and thought it included possibly some acting but it is not. It is all staged. The story is not surprising for the people of developed and/or wealthy countries. It hides the manipulation of the people by corporate media, the misinformation, the artificial unification of the people by deliberately reducing tension on the streets, sometimes to the point that the army, intelligence agency or even the government(many suspect,led by the US) uses agents who attack "any" side to suppress the masses into peace and therefore justifying their coups. A marine officer in the film denies this also. That they didn't want to see the peoples confront on the streets. All of these scenarios have been fabricated in Turkey(USA's pet dog in the middle east) throughout its history who has experienced 3 coups and lately, secret plans made by the Turkish army have been exposed, ironically through an anti-government secular media opposing the religious doctrines of the army, in which a very important mosque is protected by an army agent to deceive the people etc.

What makes this film pathetic is that they were filming from outside, perhaps by chance, when the events have not happened. It is clear that the directors are anti-Chavez. Whether or not this caused the directors to filter and manipulate the events and the information, I would know.
And whether Chavez will be supporting the dictatorship of US and the global economy without promoting any opposing thought with violence, history will not tell.

But at least Chavez is despair and I don't believe it is worth taking the chance.

The 14 year-old in me is immensely disappointed that they're still making poor quality fantasy movies, and that they're all the rage, what with Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter and The Chronicles of Narnia making loads of cash at the box office. This year has seen several more, most notably The Golden Compass, which has the most boring trailer I've seen this year. Stardust, based on a novel by Neil Gaiman, stumbled into theaters this week with little promotion. I saw no previews for it, only a couple of forgettable commercials. The critical reaction is surprisingly positive. I would have avoided it if not for the fact that I had to wait on a friend to see The Bourne Ultimatum, and that nothing else terrible opened this weekend. Well, if you'll forgive the terrible pun, the stars must have been horribly misaligned, because I went to see Stardust, and I hated it. It's not a small movie like The Princess Bride. The plot line is a tired fantasy cliché (the hero sets out to look for a fallen star) filled with predictable obstacles. But within that basic outline, the story is dull and unimaginative. It's simply aiming to be barely tolerable, and a forgettable little romance. And it fails miserably. There were a lot of big films this summer, but none of them were nearly as unbearable as this one. There's too much going on, but the story is told poorly and is mostly incoherent. It isn't a disaster, but it definitely can't occupy the same kind of ground that something like The Princess Bride has (though I like it much less than the earlier film). A lot of disappointment to be had here if you're a fan of the genre.

Born Again the Limerick:

If a man could come back from the dead

And live in a little girl's head

It's quite laughable, instead

He should be left for dead

By the guy that's now in his wife's bed.

For me Born Again is an over-rated, mediocre episode that fails to define The X-Files for me before I started watching it. I saw a few segments before when the show first came on and I was much too young to watch it such as parts of The Jersey Devil, but I very specifically try to forget this episode as an 11 year old and being absolutely bored by the scene where they guy gets choked to death by the bus and then the hypnosis scene with the little girl. I tell you I couldn't stay awake for minutes! For this reason the episode has no aura about it now, there is no creepiness factor that I have since grown to dislike. Its enough to make me want to criticize some of the obvious flaws in the plot such as why the girl had to wait until she was 9 before her previous life spirit really began to exact his revenge. Or what she was doing just randomly sitting on a bus in the middle of the night. You'd think her parents would have been worried. And maybe they weren't, we just don't really see that part of the story. And was was with the telekinesis? Other than adding the really cheesy Carrie factor to the already boring story, there really wasn't any kind of good explanation for it. But even with its little plot-holes, in my mind this is a mediocre episode and has many reasons for me to not like it. 2 out of 10.

"My child, my sister, nightmare

How bitter all things would seem

Were we in that cruel world to live apart,

And there hate fast and long,

There loathing and die among

Those scenes that insult you, that bleak weather."

Charles Baudelaire

Based on the novel by Elizabeth Von Arnim, "Enchanted April" can be described in one sentence - it takes place in the early 1920s when four London women, four strangers decide to rent a castle in Italy for the month of April. It is the correct description but it will not prepare you for the fact that "Enchanted April" - an ultimate "feel bad" movie is the epitome of its genre. Horrible and dark, harsh and agitating, mean and sorrowful, it is like a stormy cloud on your face during springtime when you want to open your eyes wide and frown and rush through this moment of dreadful sadness and forget it as soon as possible. This is the movie that actually ruined my life. I watched it during the joyful times when I was carefree, happy and not lonely, when I had no need to deal with any unpleasant events and to face any difficult truth about myself. It helped me to regain my pessimism and despair that anything could be worsened and anything is impossible. I had promised to myself then that no matter what, I would sink back into misery and self-pity and I would not appreciate a single minute of life - with its joy and its bitterness...I promised myself that I would never go to Italy and I never did.

Vince Lombardi High School has a new principal--the dreadful Ms. Togar (Mary Woronov). She plans to eliminate rock and roll music entirely. She clashes with Riff Randall (P.J. Soles) who DESPISES the Ramones. Additionally, the head of the school football team (Vincent Van Patten) fails to click with any female, oblivious to Kate Rambeau's (Dey Young) affection for him.

An instant flop. This was initially released widely and almost instantly failed--however, as a midnight movie, it was a massive hit and continued playing throughout the 1980s. I remember attending several of those during my college years--it felt like a chore! People were mumbling along with the songs half-heartedly, chuckling lazily at every joke and generally appearing bored.

Watching it now as an adult, I can't fathom why I was fond of this. The script is infantile and packed with cringeworthy one-liners that I couldn't believe I was hearing. Characters behave unpredictably and the movie leaps around randomly. What slightly redeems this are some mildly amusing lines and decent performances by Soles and Woronov (who seems rather bored). Everyone acts indifferently and performs their roles modestly (as they should not). Regarding the Ramones...I was never a fan. I do appreciate the title track but the rest of the songs never resonated with me. If you're a Ramones fan, you might have different sentiments.

SPOILER WARNING!!!! This is mainly aimed at children (it has a PG rating) who will likely find it silly and dull. I particularly think they'll be underwhelmed by the end when the high school is blown up! SPOILER OVER!!!!

So, if you're in the mood for a mind-numbing midnight movie from the 1980s, you might find this bearable. Otherwise, avoid it. I give it a 3.

This film falls short when compared to most cinematic romantic comedies. It has many flaws! The writing, acting, production design, humor and pathos are all subpar! Even the music -- from Dean Martin to La Boheme -- is uninteresting and dull!

Every character is peculiarly forgettable and unremarkable, from the leads played by Cher and Nicolas Cage, to the many supporting roles -- Olympia Dukakis, Vincent Gardenia, John Mahoney, Danny Aiello -- even grandpa with his dog pack! Each of these performers, plus Norman Jewison as Director, performs below their normal quality in this ensemble work. For several of the actors, this was an early major exposure in film, but the casting is unremarkable and we have many current acting powerhouses whose careers were not altered by their involvement in this film.
I've seen this film several times all the way through -- which can sometimes elevate the impact of a film. More tellingly, I realized some years ago that whenever I channel-surfed my way into a scene from this film -- any scene -- the scene was un compelling and poorly crafted. There are very few memorable scenes, and even the original meeting between the Cher and Nicolas Cage characters lacks impact and feels stale; Vincent Gardenia discovered with his paramour at the opera, amidst the splendor generated by his gold-mine plumbing business; Olympia Dukakis scolding John Mahoney for philandering with his student in the classic line about liaisons with co-workers: "Don't sh-t where you eat!"; Danny Aiello at his dying mother's bedside; Nicolas Cage "taking" Cher as the rapture of an aria soars in the background!

There are many great romantic comedies, among them Sabrina (both versions, but especially the Audrey Hepburn/Humphrey Bogart/William Holden original); When Harry Met Sally; The Apartment.

None are as disappointing as Moonstruck!

This is a straight-to-video movie, so it should go without saying that it's not going to rival the first Lion King, but that said, this was downright bad. My kids loved this, but that's a given, they love anything that's a cartoon. The big shock was that *I* didn't like it, it was not laugh out loud funny at some parts, lacked creative tie-ins with the first movie, and even some jokes that were too obscure to understand (but without being risqué like in Shrek). A special note on the fart jokes, I was not surprised to find that none of the jokes were in good taste. They were just toilet noises, in your face, not even subtle. I'd like my kids to think that there's more to humor than going to the bathroom, and this movie fails in those regards. The music was terrible, not even close to the first or second movie, and plenty of corny moments, which were a pain to watch. A little action but nothing too interesting, the Secret of NIMH was way more scary and thrilling, and I would think a G rating was appropriate for this one. All in all I'd say this is a terrible movie for kids of any age, one that's not safe to let them watch, I had to jump up and turn off the TV during a few movies that were less kid-appropriate than expected, and this one is one of them. I'd say stick around anyway though, you might find that you suffer through it too :)

I realized a couple of days ago that the makers of this film put a play on words into its title, which I find annoying. This movie is not primarily about the act of "riding giants," but mostly about the people who are the giants of the sport, RIDING giants, shifting the emphasis unnecessarily.

In my teens I lived a block from the Wedge, one of the hardest-breaking and best bodysurfing spots in the world. I've been out in 15-to-18 foot surf, and have ridden and been hammered by 10 and 12-foot waves on many occasions. That experience is why I am not impressed by the surfers in this film. The idea that Jeff Clark, to all appearances a normal mortal, could get away with riding Maverick's BY HIMSELF for over a decade is within my grasp, not beyond it. The first safety rule of any water sport is "Never surf/dive/swim by yourself" - he did nothing remarkable. I would go out there if the water were 75 degrees and the sharks all left.

In the world of warm water: the first shot of the waves at Jaws does nothing for my skin. These are not just scary waves, but rather mundane and predictable ones. When we see Laird Hamilton not only surviving 40-to-60 foot waves (I can hardly bear to look at those numbers), but actually working the faces like an average day at Rincon, I'm unmoved. There is no dedication or focus in big-wave riders that stands out, as comparable to that of anyone in the world.

This is a terrible film. I gave it a 2 instead of a 1 only because it vaguely acknowledges the existence of big-wave riders outside the Hamilton/Kalama crew, but still fails to give them adequate recognition.

There are some terrible comments and observations on this film. I was disappointed to note the lack of comparisons to Fritz Lang's "M" and the overemphasis on the 50's abortive remake with David Wayne. The real villain is the tortured murderer (horrendous performance by Jeffery DeMunn), taking out his sexually frustrated anger on his victims-- mostly children. He is just an insignificant individual. The real villain is the stifled and helpless protagonist (Rea in his most boring role since "The Crying Game"), a superficial pragmatist who's willing to use the system to his advantage (Sutherland always unsuccessful in this kind of role), an uncertain, frightened but unmotivated psychiatrist (the comparatively average Max Sydow), the bumbling, inept bureaucrat of a prosecutor (terrible Brit actor John Wood) and the quiet, unsupportive wife of the unimpressive investigator (unpleasant supporter, Imelda Staunton). This is one terrible film. Its darkness and bleakness are unsupported by the portrayal of a corrupt, competent system which works for success. The film dips into gore-laden slice 'n dice sensationalism that has characterized so many recent films. Gore is overwhelming-- it's a disgusting story-- but it doesn't add to the depicting of a pathologically twisted human being. The failure of the story is precisely that: these were acts perpetrated by a monster, a non-human like you or I. Where you and I choose to vent our frustration by reasonable means, Chikatilo took his anger out on the most innocent and vulnerable of us, our children. The premise of this story is made horrible by an equally horrible cast of terrible actors. --happily, I note that our Australian friend didn't like the speech and no doubt would have preferred to hear them speaking in Aussie dialect. Well, good for him. This fine film did not work for me and everyone else I've talked with who has seen it.

The arrival of countless white settlers in the 1800s and their conflict with the Native American inhabitants of the prairies sealed the fate for the buffalo...

The commercial killers, however, weren't the only ones slaughtering bison... Train companies offered tourist the chance to kill buffalo from the windows of their coaches... There were even buffalo killing contests... "Buffalo" Bill Cody annihilated thousands of buffalo... Some U. S. government officers even endorsed the destruction of the bison herds... The buffalo nation was wiped out by greed and unchecked hunting... Few visionaries are working today to restore the once-great bison herds...

"The Last Hunt" showcases one of Robert Taylor's most unimpressive and straightforward performances and for once confirmed the theory that no audience would tolerate Taylor as a menacing character...

His portrayal of a sadistic buffalo hunter, who kills only for pleasure, had its flaws: The lack of compassion and empathy for others...

When he is joined by his fellow buffalo stalker (Stewart Granger) it is evident that these two conflicting characters, with opposing beliefs, will clash intensely very soon...

Taylor's killing spree was not limited to wild beasts... He also enjoyed killing Indians who stole his horses... He even attempts to woo a beautiful squaw (Debra Paget) who is reluctant to his advances and comfort...

Among others buffalo hunters are Lloyd Nolan, unremarkable as a drunken buffalo skinner; Russ Tamblyn as a half-breed; and Constance Ford as the dance-hall girl... But Taylor fails to impress... Richard Brooks captures (in CinemaScope and Technicolor) pointless views of Buffalos grazing upon the prairie as the slaughter of these majestic animals...

The film is a harsh, unpleasant outdoor Western with a heavy-handed message about old Western myths and a clichéd climax in which the villain dies of cold while waiting all night to shoot down the hero...

First, I did not like this film. It was poorly acted by all.

However, I understand comments I hear from people about a predictable ending. I knew everything about this movie going in except a few "gotta-see" recommendations, and I could tell where the plot was going in under ten minutes. (I won't mention what clued me in so as not to spoil a bad film for others.) Still, despite it seeming obvious, I kept watching, regretting my decision. It was painful to see how everything played out, filling in the details and the character motivations in later scenes.

I hate it when I guess the ending early in a film. I only appreciate it when the road to resolution is lined with interesting scenery.

Will Smith's screen persona is not likable, even when he's playing such a troubled character. He's lethargic and unbelievable in everything that I've seen him do. Seven Pounds is another poor performance.

Rosario Dawson is a mediocre performer, portraying a quirky, rather upbeat character despite a terminal heart condition. Looks are subjective, and with Rosario, if you find her gorgeous, you should think about replacing your taste.

It was disappointing to see Woody Harrelson back on the screen. I have seen him a lot lately, but that could just be me. Woody had a tremendous amount of screen time, and he failed to sell his jolly, piano-playing, blind man character for what it was worth. Terrible.

A cursory bit of research on the box jellyfish tells me that its venom is harmless, and it makes it a questionable choice for neither pet nor plot.

Overall, I have to not recommend this film not for the plotting, but for some very bad performances, and for the fact that it tends to evoke some of the mundane emotions that we generally try to avoid.

Little has been said about Shinjuku Triad Society as a poor "Miike" film and I thought this might be a refreshing perspective. None of the Miike trademarks are worth mentioning, the violence, the black humor, the homosexuality, the taboo testing and the difficult to like central character are all missing.
