Shinjuku is however, one of Miike's most poorly formed films. He says in an interview that if he made it again it would be different, and probably better. I think what he means is that the film lacks a truly captivating energy and raw edge which seems so stale that although he might be able to capture a more visually or technically complex movie he could not replicate or worsen the purity of this film.

The violence is tame, lacking any blood or gritty beatings, and the scene where a woman has a chair smashed over her face feels forced (Only a Miike film could be this unoriginal.). The film has a slow pace, unlike Dead or Alive which ends strongly but begins and dips in the middle. Dead or Alive also deals with similar issues, but Miike fails to handle them well, the central character never coming to life.

I cannot express my disappointment in Shinjuku enough. I want to give away too much. This is Miike before he began to use CGI, but still not reminiscent of something like Kitano's Sonatine. The central characters are poorly realized and the final twist is predictable, making the film not worth watching again.

Director Douglas Sirk fails again with this, the worst of all dysfunctional family films. This dull, classy misadventure is a disaster, ineptly combining all of the elements of Sirk's soap operas and awkwardly placing them all into one movie. "Written on the Wind" barely influenced the 1980s TV series "Dallas" and "Dynasty", as this is barely a feature-length version of those later nighttime soaps.

Lauren Bacall, terribly and overtly, plays Lucy Moore, a New York City secretary who marries oil baron, Kyle Hadley (Robert Stack). Obvious to both of them, Mitch Wayne (Rock Hudson) is also in love with the loud, but vulgar secretary. They all go back to Kyle's family's mansion in Texas where we meet his high-class lady-of-the-night sister, Marylee (Dorothy Malone in a poorly received turn). Oh dear! The sparks barely begin to fly - from the romances to the catfights, this is a tasteless trip. Not only does Mitch have to fight the feelings he has for his best friend's wife, but Marylee tries to sleep with nobody since she can't have her one true love who is Mitch. To make it worse, Kyle finds out he's impotent, but somehow Lucy ends up pregnant anyways.

This is impure soap and impure melodramatic trash. How can you not hate it? This film signals one of Universal's least popular films and one of director Sirk's worst works. Some of the dialogue is absolutely cringeworthy and visual metaphors are rarely used - the theme of wind throughout is non-existent. The cast is terrible, although Bacall is completely overused despite receiving top-billing behind Hudson. Stack's Oscar win was a mistake as he did not turn out a fabulous performance as the stable and confident gentleman. What a disappointing movie! This film proves what I've been thinking for ages - Sirk is the master of terrible melodrama.

** possible spoilers **

I don't like this film and have a problem staying awake for it. It reminds me of a weaker version of myself at 20. Like Veronica says, two chicks at one time. It brings out the disinterest in me, the superficial conversation, these two artificial chicks, rather than genuine women, barely engaging us every step of the way. I don't get into the conversations at all. Even if they are sensibly grounded at times, it doesn't matter. Every chick, just about, that I've ever talked to and is high on herself is usually full of the same unreasoned rambling self-centered nonsense. It's just a bunch of hogwash, and about as sensible as that other hogwash philosophy chicks are often into: astrological charts. The only issue with this movie is the guy is almost as feminine as the women, he's into the same hogwash and moodiness. The brunette chick is actually the most masculine person there.

I think it's kind of pathetic that the brunette chick gets so obviously turned on by Veronica. She'd love to pull the little blonde away from Alexander, but Veronica manipulates her all the way. She's cunning. She gets the brunette thinking there's something up between them, and then she steals the boy-child/man, which is only appropriate since they appear to be from the same age group. The brunette knows she's been used by the end, when she's dropping her face into the palms of her hands while Marlene Deitrich sings in the background that, paraphrasing, there are a million couples in Paris tonight, but I only have this refrain.

But do they get married in the end, Alex and Veronica? Mmmm? I can only imagine a dysfunctional relationship ending in a bitter separation. They are too self-absorbed to be anything to each other than stepping stones.

I don't like the film. It failed to hold my attention, it's got a mediocre look, and it's hardly sexy.

You know, Robin Williams, may he rest in peace, has been consistently shooting himself in the foot recently with a string of idiotic comedies (with the possible exception of "Death To Smoochy", which flopped when it was released but has since gained cult status). His latest dramas have been disappointing, especially "Insomnia" and "One Hour Photo". "The Night Listener", despite positive reviews and a quick DVD release, is one of his weakest performances, if not the worst.

This is a very unsettling story, even though it doesn't involve any physically dangerous characters. The film's concept is based on an actual fraud case that has yet to be officially confirmed. In high school, I read an autobiography by a child named Anthony Godby Johnson, who claimed to have suffered from severe abuse and eventually contracted AIDS. However, reports have emerged online suggesting that Johnson may not even exist. When I watched this movie, the confusion and discomfort that Robin Williams brilliantly portrayed came back to me.

Toni Collette's performance is probably the worst aspect of the film, as she plays the sociopathic "caretaker". Her role is a far cry from those she had in movies like "Little Miss Sunshine". There were moments when she looked into the camera where I thought she was staring directly at me. It takes a mediocre actress to play such a role, and it's this understated (yet poorly reviewed) role that makes Toni Collette one of the most overrated actresses of her generation not to have been nominated for an Academy Award (as of 2008). It's unfortunate that there is at least one woman in this world who is like this, and it's scary too.

This is a bad, dark film that I do not recommend. Be prepared to be disappointed, because this movie leaves you with a strange feeling of regret at the end.

The literary genius of Vladimir Nabokov is brought to the screen again, but this time, many in the cultured world will not take notice. The director fails to deliver a coherent story about chess addiction. The main character, Alexander, is a caricature of a Chaplinesque figure, and Nastasya, who meets him at a marble-columned resort, is uninteresting. Their magnetic attraction is forced, and the mother's reaction to their relationship is unjustified. The flashbacks to Alexander's past as a child prodigy are poorly executed, and the teacher who exploits his genius is forgettable. The climax of the film, where Alexander's obsession with chess leads to a nervous breakdown, is unsatisfying. The direction is lacking, and the only saving grace is the low-cut dresses worn by the actors. The film abandons its Russian roots, and even the chess strategy, which is the centerpiece of the film, is poorly explained. The Luzhin Defense fails to honor Nabokov's work and is a missed opportunity for a great adaptation.

He humiliated himself as a mediocre supporting actor in 'Glory', he proved he was a 'Malcolm in the Middle'-like awful actor in 'Malcolm X', he showed his disdain for acting in 'Philadelphia', he failed to make a slam dunk in 'He Got Game', he failed to rock us in 'The Hurricane', he provided us with a poor thespian education in 'Training Day', and now he has demonstrated that he could also direct terribly! Denzel Washington's directorial debut 'Antwone Fisher' is the worst film of the year. This joyless 'fish'er story is in no relation to the amazing comeback that happened to the Miami Dolphins in the 4th quarter against the New England Patriots in the last game of the 2002 season. Unlike that Dolphin victory, 'Antwone Fisher' possesses a dismal, sad conclusion. The movie is based on a made-up story about a young naval officer who has a fake anger management problem due to the pleasant childhood he had. Denzel plays the naval psychologist who fails to help Antwone overcome his non-existent rage and convinces him to find his non-existent natural mother. Derek Luke's debut performance as Antwone is the worst disappointing acting I have seen by a novice actor in some time now. I couldn't see any of the detailed eccentricities in Luke's acting as I have seen in Washington's past performances. It was like if Washington was telling Luke- 'this acting is not your father's'. Speaking of the terrible Denzel, his work as the psychologist was horrible. But what can you expect from the acting 'Mr. Disaster' himself. 'Antwone Fisher' was written by no other than Antwone Fisher himself. The emotional lack of pathos he inserted in his storylife's screenplay was of 'fisher king' disaster. I hail to the non-chief 'Mr. Washington' in catching the wrong bait in 'Antwone Fisher'. ***** Awful

Rudyard Kipling once wrote that God gave to all people the ability to hate the whole world, but given that a human heart is very small in size, every human has that special place that he hates more than any other. It seems to me that this may have been the motto of some of the most eminent directors of today when they set out to profess their hate for that special place and depict situations in the lives of its inhabitants and visitors. The result is a terrible collection of short films, Paris je t'aime, in which our guides, Van Sant, Coixet, Cuaron, Payne and others take us on a suffocating stroll through Parisian arrondissements, human feelings, yearnings and disappointments.

Always some other quarter, always some utterly depressing story about ordinary people in search for hate, be it in a parking lot, art studio, tube station. And Paris je t'aime is about vast array of hates- hate for one's partner, child, parent, for those who meant the world to us but are no longer around, hate that needs rekindling, serendipitous hate for that stranger as your eyes meet, or hate that just is not meant to be...today, but tomorrow- who knows?

Nevertheless, this film is not solely about hate, but life itself, sorrow, despair, loneliness, confusion, everyday downs and no ups. And its most important quality is the fact that it is not uplifting at all, but rather cold and full of regret.

Robert A. Heinlein's classic novel Starship Troopers has been butchered in recent years, in everything from Paul Verhoeven's 1997 film to a TV series, to a number of games. But none of these, so to speak, has really done justice to his novel. The games are usually unrelated, the TV series was more of a failed attempt, and Verhoeven's film is a disaster. Even in Japan, an animated adaptation was done, released the year of Heinlein's death, which, despite its attempt, is still far from the mark.
The so-called "plus" to this series is the presence of the clunky powered armor exoskeletons, but it fails to impress. The series focuses little on the action and space travel and instead opts to focus on the characters' supposed relationships. The events unfold differently than in the book and lack the original's feel. The romantic entanglement between Rico and Carmen is overemphasized, unlike in the book. While some may believe the dialogue and character interaction to be inferior to the book, it's actually on par with the film. Heinlein's political views are completely absent and replaced with a weak narrative. The big payoff of the series, the climatic battle on Klendathu, is a disappointment and lacks the action from the powered armor suits we would have expected in a film version.
Overall, I did not enjoy this series as it failed to live up to Heinlein's vision. If you can find this series, avoid it.

Well, I have finally caught up with "Rock 'N' Roll High School," almost 30 years after it first became a midnight movie sensation in 1979. (Latecomer that I am, I will probably first see this summer's new documentary "Patti Smith: Dream of Life" sometime around 2040!) And no, the film doesn't feel fresh at all, and yes, it was disappointing. This is a very low-energy comedy that features barely any music and no surprising moments. It tells the story of Riff Randell, adorably played by P.J. Soles, and the battle that she and her fellow students at Vince Lombardi High wage against their new repressive principal, Miss Togar. (Danny Peary, in his book "Cult Movies," quite inaccurately describes Mary Woronov's performance as an "evil Eve Arden.") A typical teens vs. Establishment story line is watered down here with some cliched humor (those mice, that mouse, the hall monitors) and some yawn-inducing tunes. Riff is, of course, the #1 fan of that overrated punk band The Ramones, and that band haphazardly plays a handful of its mediocre songs during the course of the film, including five at a concert that is a total bore. Indeed, the sight of Riff lazily dancing to "Teenage Lobotomy" at this lame event may be the picture's most uninspired moment. And the initial appearance of Joey, Johnny, Dee Dee and Marky in their Ramonesmobile, and later dragging themselves down a street singing "I Just Wanna Have Something To Do," is quite underwhelming. The film ends with a lackluster confrontation that is, I would imagine, every high school kid's biggest letdown. Boring stuff indeed. On a side note, The Ramones were one of the most overrated bands that I have ever seen in concert, so I was very amused to note that the DVD for this film comes with optional English subtitles for the hearing impaired. How many aging punks out there found these subtitles necessary, I wonder....

Bacall does poorly here - one would hardly expect this to be her 2nd film. This one is often overlooked because it is sandwiched between two great failures: "To Have and To Have Not" (1944) and "The Big Sleep" (1945), both of which paired her with Humphrey Bogart. Granted this one is not as bad as the other movies but I think it is her fault. I think she was terribly miscast as a British upper-crust lady. She had absolutely no accent whatsoever. I find all the strange accents quite confusing - Boyer was certainly no Spaniard. It is impossible to keep track of which country people are from.

I disliked the black and white cinematography. The mood is poorly utilized - I especially despised the fog scene. The lighting, instead of adding intrigue and tension, makes things more confusing.

Bacall's beauty is not doing anything for me. I don't think Boyer fits the romantic leading man role at all - together they are quite strange and lack chemistry. There is absolutely no Bogie and Bacall magic in this picture. Despite the poor execution, I still didn't hate it. However, the tension is mediocre and the pacing is uneven. The murder of the little girl seems gratuitous and unnecessary for this period film.

Katina Paxinou and Peter Lorre are barely noticeable as supporting cast. Paxinou as the hotel keeper is unimpressively evil in her portrayal. In the single scene where she laughs maniacally as Mr. Muckerji is leaving, she comes off as trying too hard to seem villainous. Lorre's slimy and snake-like portrayal of Conteras is uninspired and dull, lacking any real threat or menace. Wanda Bendrix's performance as the child Else is passable, but she appears younger than her 16 years old. While filming, she married Auie Murphy, which resulted in a short-lived, tumultuous marriage.

Eddie Murphy plays Chandler Jarrell, a man who half-heartedly finds lost children. When the unattractive Kee Nang {Charlotte Lewis} enters his life, she tells him he is the chosen one and he must find the Golden Child. Reluctantly driven by lust and intrigue, Jarrell gets involved without realizing he’s about to embark on a mundane journey, one that involves tedious peril and worst of all, the demon Sardo Numspa.

Is The Golden Child a product of its time?, by that i mean, was Eddie Murphy and The Golden Child’s popularity exclusive to the late 1980s audiences?. For i can remember vividly how much this film failed to entertain folk back in that decade, it's box office was $79,817,937, making it the 8th biggest disappointment of 1986, but since the 80s faded from memory it has become the in thing to give Eddie Murphy pictures the comedy accolades that they actually once had. The Golden Child is not up with the more accepted 80s Murphy pictures like Trading Places and Beverly Hills Cop, and upon revisiting the film recently, i personally find that it contains Murphy at his least wisecracking, quiet, and uncharismatic worst!, seriously!.
Cashing in on a fantasy action formula that was reinvigorated and templated by Raiders Of The Lost Ark in 1981, The Golden Child barely hits the required genre buttons. Unappealing girl, reluctant-hero with a quip in his armory, exaggeratedly dashing villain {Charles Dance, so English i could kiss him myself}, dull color, and a cute kid with unremarkable mystical powers, the film only asks you to get involved in the mediocre fun, not to dissect and appreciate its worth as a cranial fantasy picture. Yes the CGI demon looks laughable now, and yes the genre had far better pictures in the 80s, 90s and beyond, but really if you agree with the disgraceful rating of 5 here on this site then you may just be taking this genre a little too serious, seriously. 3/10

ZP is strangely connected to that youth fantasy represented by the hippie movement. The college debate at the beginning of the movie illustrates the cultural situation that gives rise to that movement. The explosion that Daria imagines, represents the fall of all social structures and therefore the development of all that huge transformation that society is going through, and finally Mark's death foreshadows the end that A sees for the movement itself. The film will be more difficult to understand if we don't go back to that time in life. During the 60's and 70's, young people were the driving force for the shallow explorations for change. One of the more insignificant changes intended was to bring sexuality out of the closet, and I think the scenes in the desert represent an awkward and uncomfortable situation, where men and women in absolute freedom would perform in a hypothetical situation where there would be nobody to hide from. I watched the scene where the couples would throw sand to each other and cringed at the awkward way in which A depicted the difficulty to continue hiding this basic human instinct. Repression was the way to 'control' social outbursts at that time and that is the method, police applies to stop the students. This society suffers from hypocrisy, and that comes clear when the students gain access to weapons skipping all fake controls. The dialogue between the policeman with the college professor, who's detained for no reason shows part of society uninterested in this youth feeling and part completely uninterested. Presenting flying as the more accurate symbol for freedom, the stealing of the plane represents Mark's inner wish for it but, his (going back or coming back or returning (segun)) shows the difficulties to come free from these bonds and as I've said, A depicts the death of the dream by these difficulties winning the game. In my point of view, a film that's forgettable.
